**Act 1 - Trouble At School**

[image: ./images/act1_splashscreen.png]

title: Act1Epilogue
text:
You rush home, not stopping and not looking back until you are behind your deadlocked front door. Only then do you find yourself able to breath without gasping.

The image of Stitch’s ice cold stare is burned into your brain and won’t leave. You mull over all he said. The Prom. The pithy curses. His amulet.

Your thoughts keep returning to that amulet. You felt it immediately. Something like you’ve never experienced. Something that overshadowed your own powers. Something that voids any progress you’ve made stopping what’s happening at Charlton.

If you can’t use magic on them, what can you do? The police certainly aren’t going to believe a Headmaster of a school is using magic to brainwash his students.

 

 Then there are the threats. Could he really turn you into a stripper? Working in some sleazy bar. What did he call it, Dicks? Somewhere men call you names.

 

 *And would it be you, or would it be Emily?*

 

 Both options send a shudder coursing through you. 

 

 You think back to the curses and how meekly Christina agreed to correct them. All that effort, wasted. And to think, he expects you to come to him willingly.

 

 Then there is his offer. You reflect on how easily you accepted. How you willingly agreed to attend that secret meeting. If there’s one silver lining, it’s that you might be able to learn more about their plans. And stop them. If you still want to.

 

 Your thoughts turn to Christina. The memories that you gave her would have solidified by now. She no doubt has woken up as a brand new person. A small, meek thing, clumsy and unpopular. Everything that Christina would have hated. And you did that to her.

 

 Then there is his arrogance that you will come around. He didn’t even react to your challenge. Is he really so confident that you can do so little to stop him?

Lost in your thoughts for an hour, you admit the day is wasted. You’re too preoccupied to do anything else today.

Actions

<>

choices.label: Go to your room to reflect

title: CheerleaderIntervention1
text:
“I’m just checking on the Ward in here,” you whisper to her. “Making sure no one has tampered with it.”

 

 She looks at you with a confused look. “I thought I was checking in here,” she mumbles.

 

 You gesture holding up your hands. “I didn’t know we had set Wards.”

 

 Stacey gives you a look, but shrugs her shoulders. “Alright. So long as its done by someone. Chrissie will go mad if we miss something.”

 

 “I’ll double-check,” you reply.

 

 Stacey smiles politely, then turns and walks out. You sigh with relief. 

 “Fall asleep,” you mutter, “and let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 Stacey falls to the floor as your magic strikes out, her tall and gangly body hitting the floor with a hard thump.

 

 You rush over to her, checking her for injuries. Her forehead is swelling up. She’s going to have a nasty bruise, but otherwise she isn’t significantly injured.

 

 You quickly push her to the side of the door, at least out of sight unless anyone enters. Satisfied with your impromptu efforts to conceal her, you only hope that the spell has taken hold on her memories.

Actions

<>
 
 
 
 
 <>

title: CheerleaderIntervention2
text:
“Wait!” you cry out. “I’m just checking the Ward! Christina told me to!”

 

 Reagan maintains her look of distrust, but you sense her magical build-up subsiding. “Is that what you were doing? Checking it?”

 

 You nod. Reagan eyes you carefully.

 

 “I don’t like you,” Reagan says. “And I don’t trust you. But Christina seems to think you are worth it. And she’s the head cheerleader. For now.”

 

 You return her stare, but avoid replying.

 

 “Make sure it’s still working,” she says, before turning at leaving. You watch her go, still sensing the raw power within her.

 

 She could have bested me if that got ugly, you think. I’m going to need help.

 “Fall asleep,” you spit out, “and let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 Reagan’s eyes glare at you as you throw every piece of magic you can muster at her. You can feel her putting up a fight with her own power, pushing back. She grits her teeth and you feel her draw upon her own affinity to counter you.

 

 Then, with a brilliant flash of yellow energy, Reagan falls back to the floor.

 

 You walk quickly over to her body. She’s out cold. 

 

 Staring at the unconscious Reagan, you take a deep breath. Tiredness washes over you. The magical wellpool inside yourself feels empty. Drained. You think you managed to wipe her memories. Just.

 

 She almost bested me, you think. I’m going to need help.

 

 Not wanting to stay any longer, you leave Reagan to her slumber.

Actions

<>

title: CheerleaderIntervention3
text:
“Fall asleep,” you cry, “and let your memories drift as you slumber."

 

 
 
 You send a tsunami of magic towards Christina, almost knocking her to the ground. She is quick to put up a defence, as you feel a surge of energy rise up from within her. She grits her teeth, and tries to push back against your relentless assault.

 

 Smiling with grim determination, you press harder. Drawing upon the additional training that Gladys gave you, the well of magical affinity inside your body only grows stronger.

 

 “No!” Christina shouts, as she sees what you are doing. She tries to push back, but a moment later you watch as she flies back to the floor.

 

 You cease your assault, taking a deep breath. Slowly, cautiously even, you walk over to your bested opponent, still feeling a flicker of magical aura within her.

 

 Against all odds, she is still fighting against the spell. She looks up at you with sad eyes. “I thought we’d be friends, Em.” 

 

 Her head then tilts on her neck. She finally falls asleep.

 

 You take another deep breath, centering your energy in the calm and quiet. Silence is only fleeting, however. From outside, you hear a quiet set of footsteps. Approaching.

 
 If Christina is surprised by your boldness, she doesn’t show it. As you crash a wave of magic into her form, you feel a surge of energy rise up from her being to counter. She even grins, drawing deep down in her own well.

 

 You yourself grit your teeth, feeling your wave being turned towards you. Inside your body you draw and draw from your own essence, looking for glimmers of energy that have gone previously untapped. 

 

 It’s just not enough. With a smirk, Christina steps up her ferocity and you lose control, hurtling back, landing on your bum in a heap.

 

 With the slow sound of clicking heels, Christina walks towards you. “When you look back on this, Emily, at least you can say you tried. Unfortunately, as much as I’d like to look past this altercation, I’m afraid I’m out of time.”

 

 You look up at her, trying to understand. Only when do you hear a second step of footsteps outside the room does her words start to make sense.

 

 “I’m changing your curses,” you tell her. “Making a few changes.”

 

 “I can see that,” she replies. “It’s a real shame, Emily. I had such high hopes for you. You have so much potential. I was hoping someday I’d be able to call you a peer.” Her tone lowers, just slightly. “Even a friend.”

 

 “Now though,” she says quietly. “It’s too late. You’ve forced my hand. And I don’t have an ace to play.”

 

 You give her a look, trying to understand. Only when do you hear a second step of footsteps outside the room does her words start to make sense.

 Coming to a stop in the doorway is familiar figure. A tall and distinguished man, dressed in a tailored grey suit and a matching waistcoat. His deep-set eyes surveys the scene briefly, then turns his attention to you.

 

 Stitch.

 

 “Miss. Phillips,” he says. “A pleasure, as always."

 

 He smiles, coldly.

 
 Coming to a stop in the doorway is a tall and distinguished looking older man, dressed in a tailored grey suit and a matching waistcoat. His angular face is striking, with sharp features and prominent cheekbones. His deep-set eyes surveys the scene briefly, then turns his attention to you.

 

 “Miss. Phillips,” he says. “I believe we haven’t met. My name is Peter Stitch. But you shall call me Headmaster.”

 

Actions

<>

title: CheerleaderIntervention4
text:
“You’ve been very busy,” he says to you. “A pity to waste such a powerful gift on a hopeless endeavour.”

Reaching down into the magical well inside your body, you see if there’s anything left to throw at him. You stop when he chuckles. 

“Your magic can’t affect me, girl.” He then reaches into his waistcoat pocket and pulls out around something that consumes your eyes. An amulet, near-identical to the one you wear. 

“You’ll find I’m quite well protected against your charms. And the rest of Charlton’s male faculty have similar trinkets to protect them.”

Stitch walks further into the room, giving you a wide berth as he doesn’t take his sharp eyes off of you. “I’m curious, Miss. Phillips. Fiddling with pithy curses seems beneath someone of your power. Is it a coincidence, then, that your sudden appearance occurred just as our plans for this year’s Prom are being finalised? Or is disrupting that also part of your goal?"

 He glances at Christina, sleeping on the floor. “She was a powerful tool,” he tells you. “To best her in the magical arts would have taken great skill. But a tool that can be broken is of no use to anyone.”

 

 He eyes you before continuing. “You must understand that you can’t hope to defeat me. I’ve been here longer than you’ve been alive. And contrary to what you might think, you are not the first rebel with such power.”

 

 “Instead, I propose a deal.” He gestures with his hand back to Christina. “Remove her memories. Take away her recollection of ever being a cheerleader. And take her place as the head of the school coven.”

 

 Stitch stares back at you, unblinking. Waiting for an answer.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>
 
 He eyes you carefully before continuing. “You have a choice now, Miss. Phillips. One more chance. Either get in-line, accept your fate, and knuckle down. Or the only curses you’ll care about will be the names the reprobates call out to the strippers in Dicks.”

 

 He gives you a final stare, then turns to Christina. “Reinstate the wards that she’s changed.”

 

 Christina looks at you, before returning Stitch’s gaze. “Yes, Headmaster.”

 
"And, of course, she is expelled from the cheerleader squad from this moment forth.” Christina nods again.

 

 “Now,” Stitch says, turning back to you. “Go home. Leave the school. Pause and reflect. Think about how you can make up for this deviancy to your school.”

 

 His eyes flick towards the door. Shaking with nerves, you gather your things up, and rush out the door.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: CheerleaderIntervention5
text:
“I’ll take her place,” you whisper. 

 

 Stitch nods, still unsmiling. “Then prove your commitment,” he says, gesturing to Christina. “Be merciless. Give her a life that she would detest.”

 

 You take a deep breath. You focus on Christina’s mind, drawing upon a reservation of magic buried deep in your body. You see her thoughts and feelings as colours and swirls, slowly swirling around in her sleeping mind. The yellow and oranges of a bright, popular and confident cheerleader.

 

 You push hard on her memories. They fracture into a thousand pieces. One word comes to mind. Nerd.

 

 Christina’s elements fuse together again, but as they do so you notice what was once yellow and orange is now brown and green. Clumsy, you think. Unkempt. Unpopular. Magic is just in the books that she devours.

 

 The memory package forms in front of you, solidifying in Christina’s brain. Satisfied, you take a deep breath and relax.

 

 “Good,” Stitch comments. “Now. You will attend the Charlton Hotel tomorrow evening and introduce yourself as the new head of the coven. Select individuals from this school meet there to confirm arrangements for our Prom. You have a lot of work ahead of you, Miss. Phillips. Don’t fail me like her. As for your tampering with our instituions protections against the tainted world, I shall see that they are reset. You of course, will be exempt. Now you will choose your own submission willingly.”

 

 You look at Christina, asleep. You can still see traces of what you have done to her memories. “Yes,” you say. “Headmaster.”

 

 “Now,” Stitch says, looking directly at you. “Go home. Leave the school. Pause and reflect. Think about how best you’re going to serve your school.”

 

 His eyes flick towards the door. Shaking with nerves, you gather your things up, and rush out the door.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 “No,” you tell him, finally finding the courage to speak. “I won’t help you.”

 

 Stitch stares at you, emotionless. “A pity. And pointless. You will find, Miss. Phillips, that you have no choice. You can’t stop me.”

 

 “Your only real choice is to submit and find your place in our society, or rebel and be dealt with. There is a reason that this town is immune to the permissiveness of society. That reason is me.”

 

 You look at him, seeing a hint of spite in his otherwise expressionless face. “I can stop you,” you say quietly.

 

 He looks at you, nodding. “Yes. I believe you think you do. Don’t hold on to that for too long, Miss. Phillips. I want your power. I want it badly. In time, I hope you will choose submission willingly, but should you prove a significant threat I won’t hesitate to destroy you in ways you can't comprehend. ”

 

 “Now,” Stitch says, looking directly at you. “Go home. Leave the school. Pause and reflect. Come see me when you’re ready to relent. You'll find your tampering with our instituions protections against the tainted world will be reset before you return here.”
 
 

 
"And, of course, I don't believe it's appropriate for you to remain a cheerleader. I'll see to it that you are removed from the squad."

 
 
 His eyes flick towards the door. Shaking with nerves, you gather your things up, and rush out the door.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: Day3
text:
You feel yourself stirring from a dreamless sleep. You slowly open your eyes and look around your room. Your new room. Your new life. Which feels very different to what it did even twenty-four hours ago.

Yesterday's events bubble up to the forefront of your mind. Emily's struggles at school. The amulet. The transformation. The lessons. The teachers.

You take a deep breath as you realise you've run out of time to ponder what you will do next. For the time being you've got to keep up appearances and find a way for Emily to get through the school year so she can leave. And so can you.

One thing is clear. Either you or Emily has to go back to Charlton Upper School. If Emily goes back to school, she'll be susceptible to whatever is going on. How long can she hold out before she is irrevocably changed?

Yet, even putting aside how you feel using the amulet again, there are challenges in you taking her place. You need to retain your job to survive, and Mr. Thompson won’t accept many more sick days from a new employee. Then there’s Jennifer. How could you possibly tell her what you’ve uncovered?

Bracing yourself, you swing your hairy legs over the bed and put your feet on your carpet, ready to face this day. Albeit with trepidation. 

You glance over to your bedside cabinet and see the amulet, it's green emerald shining brightly. Even a metre away, its presence warms your heart and lungs. 

You reach out and put it in your pocket. However you are going to deal with today, you're sure the amulet will play a part. 

**Actions**

<>

title: Act2Prologue
text:
You lie down on your bed, letting hours drift by as you run through the encounter with Stitch. Once you feel the amulet warm, you transform back into your self and hang the amulet on your beside table. Lying back on your bed, soon sleep takes hold of you.

**Actions**

<>

title: Act2Sleep
text:
Your dreams are filled with empty corridors at school, as you run from faceless stalkers, hearing your heels clip-clopping as you fruitlessly try to find an exit to the maze of corridors without end. 

Heels?

Then you realise who you were in your dream.

**Actions**

<>

You jolt awake, bolting up in your bed. You hear the quiet cooing of pigeons from outside and the sunshine pouring in from your windows. Then you notice the shadow cast over your bed. 

An ageing woman, skin withered and cracked, is perched on the end of your bed. She has a gleam to her eyes and a smile that hints at secrets.

Perched on the end of it, smiling with hidden secrets, is Gladys.

“I think we better have a little chat, don’t you?”

title: Act2CharacterScreen
DreamLeafAnnie
text:
**Charlton School Gates**

 [image: ./images/School_Gates.png]

 

 You open your eyes to find yourself standing before the iron arch of Charlton Upper School. Pale silhouettes stream through the gates, uniformed figures whose gray blazers and pleated skirts blur together, faces lost in mist.

 

 You glance down at your own body: the familiar cut of a teenagers uniform hugging your slender frame, a single lock of blonde hair slipping from its ribbon to brush across your vision. You realise, you are Annie. Young, defiant, and on the cusp of everything that changed.

 

 A sharp laugh snaps you back. There, just inside the gate, stands Jennifer. Except, a caricature of her. All athletic poise and perfect grin, clad in the school’s cheerleader outfit. 

 

 She steps forward, arms on hips. “Oh hello, Annie!” she beams. “Remember how we never got along? Because you bullied me. This will be interesting, showing you exactly what you did!” 

 

 “Who are you?” you ask.

 

 She laughs, high pitched and youthful. “I’m the collective memories of Jennifer, of course. This is how everyone remembers her. But we both know that’s not the full truth, don’t we? Come on! We have school to attend.”

 

 Her green eyes gleam as she turns and strides through the gates, inviting you to confront the past.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 **Charlton School - Main Corridor**

 [image: ./images/School_Corridor.png]

 

 You find yourself in the long, gray corridor of Charlton Upper School. Faceless students drift past in uniforms, their footsteps echoing on polished floor.

 

 Ahead, Jennifer stands by her locker. The real Jennifer. Dressed in a daggy school uniform. Younger, more innocent. You notice how pale and tense she is. How her books are held close as if they might shield her from the world.

 

 At her right shoulder, a darker echo of herself shimmers. The caricature. She watches her real self, then turns back at you with a dramatic raised eyebrow.

 

 “What are we doing here?” you whisper.

 

 The caricature’s lips curl into a knowing smile. “We’re here at the beginning,” she breathes. “To understand. Watch.”

 

 Before you can answer, someone brushes past you and strides up to Jen, racking their knuckles on the locker next to her. Jen jumps at the noise and looks up into a face you’ve seen before. Penny. Dark hair and pale skin. But here, she’s confident and authoritative. 

 

 She leans into Jen, voice soft but with an edge of mockery. “Nice skirt,” Penny purrs, eyes flicking over the pleats. “I bet the boys love how easy it is to reach underneath.”

 

 Jennifer’s gaze flickers in your direction briefly, then returns to Penny with her shoulders hunched. Penny grins, continuing as though this were any casual chat. “I saw you top of Biology… but your last exam? Disaster. How’d you manage that? Sell out to Harrow’s new methods? Or did his handsome face inspire more… participation?”

 

 Jennifer’s eyes glisten. Her mouth parts as though to answer, but no words come. She looks to you again, this time meeting your eyes. Pleading for some shelter in your presence.

 

 The caricature is suddenly beside you, whispering into your ear. “Yes, she sees you,” she purrs. “In this context, you are Annie. After all, you were in this very spot. Watching.”

 

 “So are you going to let her be spoken to like that? You know what Annie did here, don’t you? She heard it all and said nothing.”

 

 A tremor runs through you: the memory of Annie's silent complicity, and the choice that still stretches out before you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 You stand mute, lips pressed tight, as the caricature’s grin widens to a cruel arc.

 

 “Ah, so this is the truth,” she purrs, voice echoing off the lockers. “You let me be bullied. I was doing fine. Not quite top of the class, but good enough. No magic needed to boost my grades. But Penny, ever the rebel, couldn’t accept that a good girl could excel. And you… you heard every cruel word and stood by silently.”

 

 You glance back at Jennifer - the real Jen - shuts her locker and walks quickly away, tears streaking her cheeks. Penny tosses you a contemptuous look and rolls her eyes. “Sell-outs,” she spits.

 

 “Not so innocent, are you?” the caricature whispers in your ear.

 

 Her laughter rings out, triumphant. “Now the truth is out. And that truth will flow into the real world, reminding Annie of what she did. There’s no magic to dispel here. Just a memory for her to recall.”

 

 The caricature steps in front of you, catching your eyeline as Penny and the school melt away. “Good for you in telling the truth. But how do you feel?"

 

 You ponder the question. Something in you feels different. Meek. Humble. Less assertive.

 

 A smile forms on the caricature's face as she sees your realisation. "Yes. This is more than a dream. You are Annie, here. How she feels will flow into you."

 

 "And," she adds, grinning. "Aside from that fleeting feeling of discomfort, this was a free pass. Next time, lying will mean Annie’s hidden memories will never find their way home.”

 

 "You mean... I can restore her memories?" you ask.

 

 The caricature nods, just as the corridor darkens around her. “But as with all magic, it can't be destroyed. Just transferred. Her false memories must go somewhere. And if not back to little Annie, then they'll find someone else's head to live in."

 

 The remains of the room begins to evaporate, as if its fragments were like leaves in the wind. You feel something changing in the ether. Something escaping from the dream.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You step forward, voice steady: “That’s enough, Penny. Leave her alone.”

 

 The corridor shudders. The uniformed figures blur and warp as Penny’s eyes snap to yours, shock painted across her features. Jennifer turns too, momentary surprise softening into relief. 

 

 Giving you a dark glance, Penny’s lips part in a hiss before she spins and stalks away. Jennifer watches her go, then turns back to you, lips moving in a silent “Thank you” before she, too, slips off into the corridor, vanishing into the mist.

 

 The air trembles as the caricature appears at your shoulder, her tone light and mocking. “This isn’t how it happened,” she says, fingers tapping on your arm. “You let it happen. Stood by while you both tormented me. Was that truth too hard to bear?”

 

 The caricature steps in front of you. “So, now you've told your first lie, tell me. How do you feel?"

 

 You ponder the question. Something in you feels different. Assured. Confident. More assertive.
 
 
 
 A smile forms on the caricature's face as she sees your realisation. "Yes. This is more than a dream. You are Annie, here. How she feels will flow into you."

 

 "And," she adds, grinning. "Aside from that fleeting feeling of discomfort, this was a free pass. Next time, lying will mean Annie’s hidden memories will never find their way home.”

 

 "You mean... I can restore her memories?" you ask.

 

 The caricature nods, just as the school around you dissolves into drifting dust. "Some friendly advice, between old friends,” she whispers, breath cold against your ear. “If you lie next time, Annie’s stolen memories will never find their way home."

 

 “But," she adds, as the corridor darkens. "As with all magic, it can't be destroyed. Just transferred. Her false memories must go somewhere. Maybe into you.”

 

 The last remnants of the corridor peel away like battered leaves in a gale. You feel the dream unravel. Something precious loosening in the ether and slipping free into the night.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Football Field**

 [image: ./images/School_Football_Field.png]

 

 You find yourself sitting onto the bleachers and gaze down at the empty football pitch, the afternoon sun warming your shoulders. The metal presses against your bare legs, cold to the touch.

 

 A battered boombox crackles to life at the edge of the field, pumping a steady beat. You glance over to the turf and see Jennifer begin a routine. She’s clad in old workout gear, hair pulled into a ponytail as she launches into a series of energetic dance drills. Only one other person is present. A taller athletic girl, her own dark hair pulled back tightly. You know in your heart their name. Skye.

 

 Jennifer moves with fierce concentration. Each leap and pivot executed with practiced precision. She’s alone, and yet she’s giving it her all.

 

 Beside you, the caricature materializes, her grin sharp. “You came all this way just to watch me?” she taunts. “Why’d you bother?”

 

 The routine finishes and Jennifer stands, hands thrust into the air. Skye launches herself forward and pulls Jennifer in a congratulatory hug. Jennifer beams, then skips off the grass toward the bleachers. Towards you.

 

 As she approaches, she smiles. “Hey!” her voice bright. “Didn’t expect to see you here. Guess what, though? I made it! I’m on the squad.”

 

 The caricature leans in close, whispering in your ear, “So… what did you say? Did you lift me up, or knock her down? Were you a nice person?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You scoff and say, “Congrats. Now you’re just a glorified Barbie doll.”

 

 Jennifer’s bright smile falters. Her shoulders slump. She just stares back at you, all happiness lost. 

 

 Skye’s voice breaks the tension, as it rings out across the field. “Time to hit the showers, Jen!”

 

 Jennifer looks over her shoulder and forces a nod. Then, after glances at you once more, retreats toward the locker-room, head bowed.

 

 As her gentle footsteps fade, the caricature reappears at your side. “You did that to steal my moment,” she purrs. “Jealousy. Envy, maybe. But you weren’t kind. Not one bit, and you did it on purpose.”

 

 She tilts her head, laughing. “I might’ve slipped a fib before - you've got another free pass! These are just more buried memories Annie refuses to face. But the warm-up’s done. Now comes the meat of the tale. Truth versus fiction.”

 

 With a sudden ripple, the bleachers and turf dissolve into drifting fragments, and the football field melts away beneath your feet.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You offer Jennifer a warm smile. “That was incredible, Jen. Well done.”

 

 Her face brightens as she beams back. “Thanks,” she says softly, eyes meeting yours in a moment of unspoken understanding. A sense of a friendship between you two, even now.

 

 A call rises from the edge of the field. “Time to hit the showers, Jen!” Skye’s voice carries across the grass. 

 

 Jennifer hesitates, then turns back to you. “Maybe… we could grab a coffee at Fresh Pot one morning this weekend?”

 

 “That would be nice,” you reply. 

 

 Jen smiles at you, then skips away toward the locker room. Beside you, the caricature reappears, her face painted with a warped grin. “A heart-warming piece of fiction,” she purrs. “But you know that never happened, do you? You were snarky. Dismissive. You torn me down at my most treasured moment, instead of lifting me up.”

 

 Her hand fluttering to her lips in mock astonishment. “Oh!” she exclaims. “I told a fib before. That, too, was a freebee. But now the warm-up’s over. Time for the meat of the tale: truth versus fiction.”

 

 At her words, the bleachers and pitch dissolve around you, melting into drifting motes of light as the dreamscape shifts once more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Math's Room**

 [image: ./images/School_Maths_Room.png]

 

 You sit at a narrow desk in the Maths classroom, the top pushed up, your bare knees pressing against someone next to you. Penny.

 

 She’s leaning in with a small compact, dabbing a powder puff at your cheekbone. “Hold still,” she comments with affection.

 

 You feel something touch your hand at your side. Her fingertips brush yours, light and electrifying.

 

 “Almost done,” she murmurs, eyes bright as she smooths a stray speck of dust from your skin. Her hand lingers, brushing yours again, and a warmth spreads through you. A tender, unexpected flutter.

 

 At your shoulder, the caricature’s voice speaks in your ear. “This is one Annie doesn't remember," she says softly. "At least, not like this.”

 

 Penny’s fingers wrap around yours. Squeeze. Lightning bolts shoot across your body. 

 

 “Now,” the caricature tells you, “she recalls making out with a boy during this lunchbreak." For a moment there is a sadness to the caricature's tone, almost regret.

 

 But it quickly fades. "Though really," she continues. "What is the past if not a collection of memories? Surely if she doesn’t remember this, it just didn’t happen. And if she does remember it, whose is the memory of that boy?”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 The caricature's voice echoes in your mind. The voice is still Jennifer's, but something darker underneath. Almost like someone breaking character in a play. “So be it. Annie can have her memory of Penny back. And you can have a little treat.”

 

 The lights flicker, stuttering like a dying pulse. Penny’s eyes widen in admiration, framed by the rapid darkness. Then a longer blackout swallows the room whole.

 

 When the light returns, you’re not looking at Penny but at a boy. Chestnut hair brushing his brow, chiselled features softened by a grin that’s all warmth and wonder. His gaze settles on you, and you register out of the corner of your eye that you’re no longer in Charlton. This is a Maths classroom, but the one from your school. 's school. Back in the city.

 

 Before that thought can catch up, he leans in and kisses you. Your heart flutters fiercely, a thrill curling low in your womb as his hand slides just above your knee, and for a moment you are aware of how close to the hem of your skirt his fingers are.
 
 
*Womb? Skirt?*

 

 Surprise melts into desire, and you part your lips, kissing him back, leaning into the moment as his fingers press into your inner thigh. You question whether to shift your legs wider. So ready for more.

 

 But before you can make a decision, the memory fades, fragments scattering like embers on a breeze. The classroom dissolves, and you know, with a sudden clarity, that this memory is now one of when you were at school.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 The caricature's voice echoes in your mind. The voice is still Jennifer's, but something darker underneath. Almost like someone breaking character in a play. “So be it. Let Annie’s recollection of this moment with Penny be lost to time.”

 

 The lights flicker, stuttering like a dying pulse. Penny’s eyes widen in admiration, framed by the rapid darkness. Then a longer blackout swallows the room whole.

 

 When the light returns, you’re not looking at Penny but at a boy. Black hair. A chiselled face. Handsome. And grinning with admiration. 

 

 The blonde lock of Annie drifts into your view and you instinctively tuck it back over your ear. You hear yourself giggle, as the boy smiles.

 

 And before you can say or think one more thing, the boy leans in and kisses you. Your heart flutters fiercely, a thrill curling low in your womb as his hand slides just above your knee, and for a moment you are aware of how close to the hem of your skirt his fingers are.

 

 Surprise melts into desire, and you part your lips, kissing him back, leaning into the moment as his fingers press into your inner thigh. You question whether to shift your legs wider. So ready for more.

 

 But before you can make a decision, the memory fades, fragments scattering like embers on a breeze. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Fresh Pot Cafe**

 [image: ./images/Fresh_Pot.png]

 

 You’re perched in a cozy booth at Fresh Pot, laughter bubbling between sips of steaming coffee. Through the window’s reflection, you catch sight of yourself. Still Annie, but now her uniform is more fitted, the top few buttons casually undone. 

 
 
 You look across the booth to see Christina. Young. Just a freshman. Then to your left, a dark-haired boy whose handsome features soften with every shared joke. Christina chirps, “I just knew you two would get on.”

 

 Beside you, the caricature materializes, squatting down next to the booth. “You started spending time with the cheerleaders,” she tells you. “Chrissie introduced you to her friends… including our handsome friend here. Definitely your cup of tea, don’t you think?”

 

 You meet the boy’s eyes and smile. Then the café bell above the door jingles. You look up and feel something inside you drop.

 

 Penny stands in the doorway, cheeks flushed, eyes shimmering with hurt. 

 

 The boy follows your gaze and asks quietly, “Who’s that?”

 

 At your ear, a whisper from the caricature. “Remember what you said?”

 

 You answer, quiet but firm. “Just a friend.” 

 
 
 Penny’s gaze holds yours a beat longer, then she turns on her heel and storms out.

 

 The caricature sighs, amusement and accusation warring in her tone. “And how did that make you feel? The real truth, not Annie’s new doctored version. But remember, Annie. Memories don’t vanish. They have to go somewhere…”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 A slow haze of confusion seeps into your mind. Why are you here, sitting with this boy instead of Penny? And why did you choose Christina’s company?

 

 A flash of Penny’s hurt expression cuts through the moment. You recall her eyes, brimming with betrayal. 

 

 You turn to the caricature at your shoulder, voice trembling. “I feel… like I’m never going to forget that look Penny gave me.”

 

 The caricature moves into your view. Her usual grin fading into something almost solemn.

 

 “Yes,” she whispers, voice grave. “That's how you felt, wasn't it? Whatever the cheerleaders were doing, it hadn't set in just yet."

 

 Behind you, the cafe seems to stutter, as if caught between two frames on a worn videotape. The world freezes and flickers. Only the caricature moves with certainty. She sits in the booth next to Christina, looking at you.

 

 “I’m just a collection of people’s memories of Jennifer,” she says quietly. “But based on other people's recollections, I feel… well, I know she’s sorry of her part in this.”

 

 You swallow and ask, barely above a whisper, “What did she do?”

 

 Before she can answer, the lights gutter and die, plunging the booth into darkness. In the void, her voice echoes, already distant and ominous. No longer entirely Jennifer's. More sinister. Spiteful. Dramatic. “The truth has been revealed! Annie remembers her regret. But now… Annie’s current recollection has to go somewhere.”

 

 A crackle of raw energy ripples through the blackness, and the lights suddenly drop out.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Student Apartment**

 [image: ./images/StudentApartmentGathering.png]

 

 When the lights snap back on, you’re no longer in Fresh Pot. Someplace different. Someplace you recognise. A dimly lit apartment you know all too well. Your first year at University.

 

 You’re sprawled on a threadbare sofa, once again you, not Annie, loose T-shirt hanging tightly over the waistline of a pair of short denim shorts, legs draped across a lean young man’s thighs. He wears a tight white T-shirt and faded blue jeans, one hand tracing slow circles up and down your calf.

 

 The door bangs open, and a voice stumbles out mid-sentence: “I swear, I don’t know where they get the gall to --”

 

 Your best friend, Jeanette, stands framed in the doorway, eyes wide as she takes in you and the boy. Shock ripples across her face before it hardens. You open your mouth, but she whirls and stalks out, the door clicking shut behind her.

 

 Jason glances over his shoulder. “Jeanette seems… upset.”

 

 His words pull the memory into focus. And finally, you remember his name. Jason. Your impulsive liaison halfway through your first year. Before him, you and Jeanette were inseparable; after, your friendship splintered.

 

 You sit up, brushing a strand of hair behind your ear. “She’s been a bit much recently,” you murmur, and in the quiet that follows, it feels undeniably true.

 

 
 *Does it? Does any of this seem like that at all?*

 

 “Sounds like there’s another voice inside that pretty little head of yours,” another voice whispers in your ear. This one the caricature. “Along with a memory not too dissimilar to what has been rattling round in Annie’s head,” she adds. “Or is it your memory now? It’s getting hard to keep track of who remembers what around here.”

 

 Pretty little head? Who is this shadow?

 

 You glance in the mirror. At your reflection. That’s you, isn’t it? The girl with her legs across a young man, staring back at you.

 
 “Sounds like you have a memory not too dissimilar to what has been rattling round in Annie’s head,” a voice whispers in your ear. The caricature. “Or is it your memory now? It’s getting hard to keep track of who remembers what around here.”

 
 

 You feel the squeeze of the boy’s hand against the inner of your thigh, bringing you back to the present. He grins at you, then, lifting one of your legs over his shoulder, presses his lips to yours as moves on top of you.

 

 Sensations spread across your body and the lights glow bright, enveloping the room.

 

 “Now for the grand finale,” you hear the caricature's voice whisper through the light.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You shrug and force a casual smile. “She just… overreacted," you tell the caricature. "When she saw me with the boy. Thought she owned me because we were friends.”

 

 Since when did it become you and not Annie?

 

 Before you can think about it, time starts to move again. The boy puts his arm around your shoulders. “She seemed… upset,” he murmurs.

 

 You remember this boy’s name. Jason. You hooked up with him halfway through your junior year at Charlton. Before that, you and Penny were inseparable. After, you drifted apart.

 

 “Seems like this was the truth that happened, after all,” a voice whispers into your ear. The caricature. “Penny and Annie always seemed closer than just friends. But I guess you know what really happened.”

 

 With that, the café’s warmth shatters. The booth, the glass, the echo of laughter, all dissolving into shards of memory drifting in the air.

 

 “Now for the grand finale,” you hear the caricatures voice whisper through the wind.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Gymnasium**

 [image: ./images/School_Gym.png]

 

 You sit on a bench in the centre of the gym. Glancing around, things look strange. The markings for the basketball court are etched into the wooden floor, but they form strange shapes. Triangles. Pentagrams? You feel as though you’ve taken acid.

 

 A face appears in front of you. Skye. “It’s okay, Annie. You’re safe. We found you outside. It looks as though you’ve taken something.”

 

 “Taken something?” you try to say, your words slurring.

 

 “It’s like she’s trashed,” you hear a voice say from a blurry figure in the background. You recognise it as Christina.

 

 Skye shoots her a look, then turns back to you. “It’s okay. You’re with friends.”

 

 “Penny?” you slur. Your head is fuzzy. You can almost hear chanting in the background.

 

 *She called it care, she called it friend,

 But these feelings must now end.*

 

 Skye shakes her head. “Penny is gone, Annie. She left Charlton.” Her voice is flat. Cold. The murmuring seems louder, whatever sounds like chanting seems to increase in volume. Your head begins to ache.

 

 “Careful,” the caricature whispers in your ear. “Try to focus. See who’s here.”

 

 You strain your neck, demanding your eyes focus. Skye stands in front of you, blocking your view. Just behind her, you see Christina sitting with two other cheerleaders in a semi circle. Eyes closed.

 

 *Burn the root that should not grow,

 What she felt, she’ll never know.*

 

 Skye sees. Reaches her hand out and places it on your forehead, gently lowering your head to look at the floor. “Just rest, Annie. Wait for whatever you’ve taken to pass through.”

 

 “She’s lying,” the caricature says. “Don’t listen to her.” But you can barely respond. The sounds all around you sound like chants. Like words. Coming from the cheerleaders.

 

 *Mirror bright and voices cheer,

 Make her path and purpose clear.*

 

 Though your head is heavy, you manage to look up. Skye is gesturing Christina forward. “Ready. If it goes wrong now, it can’t be redone.”

 

 Christina nods.

 

 *False desires now unwind,*

 

 “Do it,”

 

 *Let sweet boys possess her mind.*

 

 And you feel your chin being pulled up… and Christina’s lips press firmly on yours -

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Clancy Household - Annie's room**

 [image: ./images/ClancyHouseAnniesRoom.png]

 

 You jolt upright in your bed, heart hammering. The familiar pastel walls and floral curtains of your old teenage room come into focus. Every frilly cushion and polished vanity surface a monument to the life of a teenage girl.

 

 “Annie!” a cheery voice calls from the hallway. “Are you ready for school yet? Your father can drop you off on the way to the station.”

 

 It feels like any ordinary morning for Annie Clancy. Except that, sitting at the foot of the bed, is the caricature.

 

 *And you’re not Annie Clancy!*

 

 “It was just a dream, wasn’t it?” the caricature asks. “The chanting, the cheerleaders, the kiss from Christina. Pure fancy, right? Just another of Annie’s wild nightmares. Or is the truth about to break loose?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 The caricature looks at you with a satisfied grin. “Correct. They did something to you.”

 

 And by they,” she adds, looking away at the floor for a moment. “I mean they. Not us. Not me.”

 

 You recall the memory. Though hazy, you know one thing for sure. Jennifer wasn’t there.

 

 “What did they do?” you ask.

 

 She looks back to you, offering a small smile. “I’m just other people’s memories of Jennifer, remember. And whatever that was, someone keeping the memories of what they did guarded. But look in the mirror. You’ll see what they were trying to break. The real Annie.”

 

 You swing yourself out of bed and move over to the vanity table. Annie Clancy, aged seventeen. Still beautiful. But more care free. No make-up. Innocent.

 

 You also notice one thing tucked at the bottom. A photo of two girls sitting outside on a beautiful cloudless day, smiling brightly at the camera. Sitting on a grass verge, legs sprawled across each other, their temples leaning against each other. Both look carefree. Happy. Innocent. Penny and Annie.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You force a shaky laugh and wave a hand. “It was just a dream.”

 

 The caricature looks at you with sad smile. “I suppose it was,” she murmurs, eyes drifting around the pastel room. They settle on the vanity. “It looks oddly bare for someone like Annie, don’t you think? She ended on up many dates. You could say she went a bit boy-crazy.”

 

 You look up to the mirror on the vanity table and notice one thing tucked at the bottom. A photo of two girls sitting outside on a beautiful cloudless day, smiling brightly at the camera. Sitting on a grass verge, legs sprawled across each other, their temples leaning against each other. Both look carefree. Happy. Innocent. Penny and Annie.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 You stare at the image, a surge of feeling stirring just beneath your awareness. There was… something between Annie and Penny. Fleeting, tender, adolescent. Yet unmistakably there, before it was walled off and hidden.

 

 A whisper drifts across your shoulder. “You’ve wrestled the truth from fiction.” You turn to see the caricature of Jennifer smiling sweetly. “At a cost to yourself, perhaps. I’m impressed at your sacrifice.”

 

 She sits down on your bed, staring up at you, playing with the hem of her cheerleader outfit. “Annie will remember how you said things were. Her real memories, not the fake ones implanted. And by Annie, I mean the real one. Or at least, the one that isn’t you.”

 

 You swallow and ask softly, “They used magic against her, didn’t they?”

 

 The caricature only gives a rueful shrug. “I don’t know much about that. There’s not that many recollections of Jennifer’s involvement in it for me to form an opinion. And those memories of what she knows... they seem to be behind some sort of mental walls, put up by people in their own minds. Take what you want from that.”

 

 “Will Annie know what happened to her?” you try.

 

 “Annie will understand even less. No longer seeing it as a dream, but still. If you're not aware of magic, it seems odd, doesn't it? Just a fleeting flashback of a hazy evening in the gym. Ripe enough for a lifetime of questions.”

 

 “And will she remember how she felt for Penny?”

 

 She meets your gaze, her eyes bright. “But why give spoilers. You should go ask her, yourself.”
 
 
 You study the photograph, searching for an echo of emotion, but your mind remains strangely unyielding. You know Annie and Penny were good friends. But you just can’t recall anything more.

 

 “So it seems,” the caricature sighs from behind you. “They were simply good friends… at least for now. Memories shift like sand these days. Who knows what paths are yet to be walked that could give her a different view?”

 

 You glance back at her and venture, “What about that gym… was it magic?”

 

 She shrugs, voice soft. “I don’t know much about that,” she replies, shrugging. “And Annie, well, she will know even less. Only that it was a vivid dream.”
 
 
 

 You begin to feel tired. You take a step back from the mirror, turning sluggishly towards the bed. The edges of your eyes begin to blur.

 

 “And now,” you hear the voice of the caricature say. “Our time has come to an end. Thanks for walking with me down memory lane. Maybe I’ll see you again, sometime. In a mirror, someplace. Maybe at a carnival...”

 

 The words barely register as you stagger forward. And fall, straight down on to the mattress.

 

 Actions

 <>

choices.label: Follow Jennifer into Charlton Upper School
Tell her this is what happened
Say Annie made out with a guy
Tell her you felt annoyed with Penny’s reaction
Wait for the lights to return
Tell her it wasn’t a dream
Tell her it was just a dream

title: DreamLeafJennifer
text:
**Charlton School Gates**

 [image: ./images/School_Gates.png]

 

 You blink awake beneath the iron arch of Charlton Upper School. Pale silhouettes drift through the gates. Identical gray blazers and pleated skirts, faces blurred by morning mist.

 

 Your gaze drops to your body: the crisp lines of a student uniform fitted to your curves, a single lock of brunette hair slipping free from its ribbon. In this moment, you are Jennifer. Young, uncertain, poised on the edge of everything that would change.

 

 A tinkling giggle cuts through the hush. There, just inside the gate, stands Annie. Only not the Annie you know but a larger-than-life caricature of her. Her school skirt is scandalously short, her white blouse buttoned low, the heels of her black Mary Jane’s impossibly tall. She bounces forward on tiptoe, blue eyes sparkling.

 

 “Oh, hi Jen!” she purrs with saccharine cheer. “Remember how we never got along? You used to pick on me. This’ll be fun! Showing you exactly what you did!”

 

 You swallow and manage, “Who are you?”

 

 She tosses her hair and giggles again, voice high and breathy. “I’m the sum of everyone’s memories of Annie, silly. The way they all remember her. Coy, over-the-top, a flirt. But we both know that’s not the whole story, don’t we? Come on, let’s explore.”

 
 
 With a flourish, she steps through the gates, beckoning you to follow.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 **Charlton School - School Cafeteria**

 [image: ./images/School_Cafeteria.png]

 

 You step into the bustling cafeteria, gray-uniformed bodies drifting past like restless phantoms. The smell of the food is absent, reminding you this is not reality.

 

 Your eyes settle on Annie, seated alone at a corner table, quietly nibbling her sandwich, every gesture measured and small. Her uniform is regulation, her make-up subtle. She looks more timid and humble than you would have ever dreamed her being.

 

 Beside her perches the caricature of Annie - with her too-short skirt and exaggerated grin - leaning forward towards you as if eager to spill a secret.

 

 “What are we doing here?” you whisper.

 

 She tilts her head, voice soft as silk. “We’re here at the start,” she whispers. “To understand. Just watch!”

 

 Before you can reply, someone brushes past you and raps on the table. Annie jumps, looking up. The girl is older, most probably in her senior year. Her dark hair pulled back into a ponytail, her athletic physique complimented by a Charlton cheerleader uniform. Deep down you know who this is. Skye.

 

 “Nice hair,” she says in a mocking tone. Her gaze drifts over Annie’s neatly braided hair. “Did Penny style that for you?” 

 

 Annie looks up at Skye, then looks beyond her. To you. She locks her blue eyes with you, wide and pleading for help.

 

 The caricature is suddenly right next to you, whispering in your ear. “She can see you, you know? Not me. But you’re right here! With her.”

 

 Skye remains focused on Annie. She leans in, hand resting on the edge of the table. “Must’ve been nice, lying in those fields, braiding each other’s hair. Very… intimate.” 

 

 Annie’s lips press together, eyes flicking again towards you.

 

 Skye’s voice drops to a whisper. “Here’s a thing, though Annie. One of the girls on the squad lives opposite Penny. Saw you slip into Penny’s house one evening. And you didn’t emerge until morning. Her parents were away that weekend, too. Bit old for sleepovers, aren’t you?”

 

 Annie’s face blanches, tears threatening. She glances your way, seeking refuge. At your shoulder, the caricature hisses, “Are you going to let her take that? Because you know what Jennifer did here. She said nothing.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 You remain still, lips sealed. The caricature of Annie grins wide. “That's right!” she exclaims, voice tinged with triumph. “You let it happen. You saw Skye taunt me, and though we were friends, you stayed silent. You didn’t dare cross Skye for fear of a future spot on the squad.”

 

 She leans closer. “Now the truth is out. And that truth will flow into the real world, reminding Jennifer of what she did. She won't be able to bury this one.”

 

 The caricature steps in front of you, catching your eye line as Skye and the cafeteria melts away. “Well done for telling the truth. Girls shouldn't lie! But you can tell me, girl to girl. How do you feel?"

 

 You ponder the question. Something in you feels different. Meek. Humble. Less assertive.

 

 A smile forms on the caricature's face as she sees your realisation. "Yes. This is more than a dream. You are Jennifer, here. How she feels will flow into you."

 

 "And," she adds, grinning. "Aside from that fleeting feeling of discomfort, this was a free pass. Next time, lying will mean Jennifer's buried memories will never bubble up to the surface. She'll be able to keep them buried, where she wants them."

 

 "You mean... I can force her to confront her part in this?" you ask.

 

 The caricature nods, just as the cafeteria shimmers and dissolves into drifting flecks of light. You sense the dream’s fabric unraveling. And something else shifting in the ether, slipping free into the night.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You rise forward, voice firm. “That’s enough, Skye. Leave her be.”

 

 The cafeteria warps around you as tables stretch and fluorescent lights bend. Skye’s spins to face you, eyes flashing with surprise. Then she turns and stalks away. Annie watches her go, then leans forward to mouth thank you.

 

 The air trembles as the caricature appears at your shoulder, her tone light and yet mocking. “Naughty. This isn’t how it happened,” she says, fingers tapping on your arm. “You stood there and said nothing. You let me be picked on to save your own skin. Do you really want to hide from the truth?”

 

 Staring back at the caricature, you try to make sense of it all. She tilts her head. "And how did those fibs make you feel?"

 

 You ponder the question. Something in you feels different. Assured. Confident. More assertive.
 
 

 A smile forms on the caricature's face as she sees your realisation. "Yes. This is more than a dream. You are Jennifer, here. How she feels will flow into you."
 
 

 Her nostrils flare, before she breaks into a giggle. A performance returning. “Some friendly advice, between old friends,” she whispers, breath cold against your ear. “If you lie, Jennifer’s buried memories will never find their way out. No talking through your feelings with her for you.”

 

 "You mean... I can force her to confront her part in this?" you ask.

 

 The caricature nods, just as the cafeteria peels away like battered leaves in a gale. You feel the dream unravel. And something precious loosening in the ether and slipping free into the night.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Football Field**

 [image: ./images/School_Football_Field.png]

 

 You find yourself standing on the school football field, nervous butterflies filling your stomach. You look down to see yourself clad in old workout gear, faded either from use or age. It feels constricting, as if you bought before a growth spurt.

 

 A battered boombox crackles to life at the edge of the field, pumping a steady beat. Instinct takes over you. You begin a routine, ponytail whipping around as you launch into a series of energetic dance drills. You moves with fierce concentration. Each leap and pivot executed with practiced precision. You feel self-conscious as the only one on the pitch, but you keep focused on the end goal.

 

 Too quickly the routine finishes, and you find yourself in a standing pose, hands thrust into the air. Only when you gasp for breath do you see Annie, dressed in her uniform still, watching intently from the bleachers.

 

 “I came to watch you,” the caricature whispers in your ear. “Even after all you did. I still wanted to see you succeed.”

 

 An enthusiastic clapping breaks you attention, and for the first time you notice Skye launches herself towards you, pulling you into a big hug. “That was perfect, Jennifer!” she beams. “Congratulations. You’re on the team!”

 

 Lost for words, you break into a smile. As Skye releases her grip, you notice her eyes flick towards the bleaches. “Clancy’s been sitting there throughout. Are you two still friends?

 

 You glance up, seeing Annie still sitting there. Whispering in your ear is her caricature. “Tell the truth, Jenny! What did you do?”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You meet Skye’s steady gaze. “Annie and I were close when we were kids,” you admit, voice low. “But I... I outgrew that.”

 

 Skye’s lips curve into a small smile. She glances toward Annie, still perched on the bleachers. “I thought so,” she says softly. “Her and Penny. They seem to revel in being outsiders. Flunking classes, stirring up trouble. That’s not the crowd that’s going to help you, Jennifer.”

 

 She snaps her fingers. “Now, leave her be and join us. We’re celebrating your place on the squad.”

 

 Skye turns and strides away, cleaning up the practice gear. 

 

 Looking back to Annie, you see her still watching you. At your side, the caricature appears, her grin sharp. “Well done,” she purrs. “You told the truth. That you cast aside a friend to win favor with the in-crowd.”

 

 She tilts her head, giggling again. “This was just one more buried memory that Jennifer refuses to talk about. Now she won't have a choice! But the warm-up’s done. Here comes the meat of the tale. Truth versus fiction.”

 

 Around you, the field melts into drifting embers of light as the dream world unravels once more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You offer Skye a sunny smile. “Of course we’re still friends.”

 

 The world wavers, the turf rippling under your feet as Skye narrows her eyes. “Just watch yourself around her and Penny,” she warns. “They seem to revel in being outsiders. Flunking classes, stirring up trouble. That won’t do you any favors on the squad.”

 

 You shrug, voice light. “They’re not so bad. We go way back.”

 

 Reality stutters again, the field fracturing into shards of green light. The caricature slips in beside you, tone dripping with mock warmth. “Oh little Miss Fibber!” she purrs. “You know this never happened, don't you?”

 

 The caricature pouts. "I guess Jen is never going to have to deal with this one. As if it never happened, really."

 

 Then she giggles, grinning with glee. “Now. Time for the meat of the tale: truth versus fiction.”

 

 Around you, the field melts into drifting embers of light as the dream world unravels once more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Math's Room**

 [image: ./images/School_Maths_Room.png]

 

 You find yourself standing near the door of a hushed Maths room, looking through the ajar door into a class of pale sunlight filtering through high windows onto rows of wooden desks.

 

 Two of them have been pushed closer together. And sitting at them are Annie and Penny. Their knees press together. Penny leans in, touching up Annie’s make-up, their fingers curling together at Annie’s side. 

 

 At your shoulder, the caricature’s murmurs, voice soft and bittersweet. “How sweet! Shame the real me can no longer remember it. Or at least, not like this. She actually remembers making out with a guy in this particular lunch break!”

 

 A whisk of movement draws your attention. You turn to see Skye standing beside you, arms crossed, eyebrow arched. She follows your gaze and looks into the room. Then back to you, an eyebrow raised.

 

 “See what I mean, Jen? Behind closed doors is one thing, but out in the open. This could ruin her."

 

 Skye looks to you, focusing solely on you. “If you really care about your ‘friend’,” she continues, injecting contempt into the word. “Then help save her. Penny’s a bad influence. She’s corrupting her.”

 

 You glance back in, at the pair. Penny leans in, smoothing a stray eyelash on Annie’s cheek with gentle care. 

 

 “That sort of thing might be fine for outside Charlton,” she continues. “But you know what it’s like around here. She’ll be ostracised for life. Long after Penny disappears into whatever gutter she’ll end up living in, Annie will be shunned. Help me, Jennifer. And help her, if really care.”

 

 As Skye looks at you for an answer, the caricature whispers into your ear. “Pretty convincing, don't you think?” She asks, then giggles at the idea. “This was the moment, wasn’t it? You knew Skye’s story was a lie, didn’t you? That she was manipulating you. So what did you say?”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You meet Skye’s gaze and say softly, “I’ll help. Just so long as Annie doesn’t get hurt.”

 

 Skye’s expression shifts, approval gleaming in her eyes. “Good. Remember the charms we’ve been using to steer the delinquents back on track. We’ll do the same for Annie.”

 

 You blink. “You want to use magic on her?”

 

 She shrugs, casual and unflinching. “Just enough to nudge her toward the right path. To give her a bit of independence from that… influence.” She glances toward the desks where Annie sits, absorbed in Penny’s quiet tenderness.

 

 You feel the weight of her words and find yourself nodding, however reluctantly.

 

 At your shoulder, the caricature’s voice slips in, low and mocking with a hint of another voice behind her own. “Good," she murmurs. "At least you admit what you did. But I’m not sure it makes up for what happened next.”

 

 The school corridor fades, the Maths room fragments, and the dream slips away into something else.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You straighten to meet Skye’s gaze. “I won’t help you do that,” you say, voice firm. “I won’t use magic on Annie. It’s wrong.”

 

 The world around you buckles. The floor ripples like water; the lockers twist into jagged shards. The caricature's shape materialises in front of you, fracturing into frantic, ink-black lines. Her smile torn and wild.

 

 Skye’s brow furrows. She shakes her head, disappointment in her tone. “Perhaps I misjudged you, Jen. We’re doing what’s right. Guiding those who veer off track. You didn’t balk when we charmed the math class into focusing, did you?”

 

 The frenzied caricature spits into your ear: “That’s the truth! You started using your little charms willingly!”

 

 Skye’s voice softens, a warning edge beneath it. “You’ll need to see that Annie is going to get a reputation in Charlton. You don’t want to know about girls who get tarred with that brush. But we can use our gifts to help her.”

 

 You lift your chin, resolve hardening. “I’m not using magic on her.”

 

 Reality convulses again. The caricature's form becomes a wild, scrawled outline. Her laughter is a razor’s edge. “Liar, liar, pants on fire! Let’s see how much more you can deny.”

 

 The school corridor shatters, the Maths room fragments, and the dream slips away into something else.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Fresh Pot Cafe**

 [image: ./images/Fresh_Pot.png]

 

 You find yourself in a booth in Fresh Pot, the cafe’s warmth and chatter swirling around you. A girlish giggle drifts from the table behind you. Annie’s giggle. 

 

 Glancing over your shoulder, you see Annie sitting there. Opposite her is Christina. Young. Just a freshman. And next to Annie is a handsome dark-haired boy, grinning. Christina’s calculating voice chirps, “I just knew you two would get on!”

 

 A sharp elbow in your ribs pulls you back to your own booth. Skye occupies the seat next to you, her eyes flicking to the tabletop where a curious spread awaits. A smudged lipstick crayon, a napkin scrawled with curling script, an empty pastry plate, salt and pepper shakers, and one of Skye’s black hair ties.

 

 Your pulse quickens. You recognize the pattern. A charm circle. Skye glances around, then lays her palm flat over the arrangement. A soft amber glow seeps through her skin, veins lighting up beneath her flesh. She meets your eyes and gestures for you to place your hand here, too.

 

 At your shoulder, the caricature whispers, her voice now clearly a mixture of Annie's and something else more sinister. “Brazen, isn’t it? Weaving magic in plain view, right behind me. But you’d already had a lot of practice by this point, hadn’t you?”

 

 You look at Skye’s waiting expression. And the spread across the table. Both calling out to you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You swallow and press your palm into the makeshift circle. A jolt of warmth ripples up your arm as the lipstick, napkin, and pepper shaker tremble on the tabletop. A soft hiss of amber light seeps from beneath your skin, mingling with the glow around Skye’s hand, and a halo of energy drifts over Annie’s head like a golden mist.

 

 The cafe bell above the door chimes. You turn to see Penny framed in the doorway, looking at Annie. Her face looks upset. Heart-broken.

 

 The boy beside Annie glances up, brow furrowed. “Who’s that?”

 

 There’s a moment of relative silence, with only the hissing coffee machine punctuating the atmosphere. Then you hear Annie’s voice, low and sad. “Just a friend.” 

 

 Her gaze flickers to Penny’s momentarily before Penny whirls away and storms out.

 

 “That’s right,” the caricature whispers in your ear. “Your little charms drove a wedge between Penny and me. A simple suggestion here, a nudge there. And I was none the wiser. Just thought this is how things had always been."

 

 Before you can give any more thought to it, the boy next to Annie leans in, sliding his arm around Annie’s shoulders. “She seemed… upset,” he murmurs. Annie says nothing.

 

 The caricature exhales in your ear, voice brimming with dark excitement: “Buckle up. Time for the grand finale!”

 

 Fresh Pot falls away, leaving you falling into the next dream.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You pull your hand back and tuck it into your lap. Reality quakes again as the amber glow sputters. Skye looks at you. She reaches out to your hand, but you wrench away.

 

 The cafe bell on the door rings. You turn to see Penny framed in the doorway, looking at Annie. Her face looks upset. Heart-broken.

 

 The boy beside Annie glances up, brow furrowed. “Who’s that?”

 

 There’s a moment of relative silence, with only the hissing coffee machine punctuating the atmosphere. Then you hear Annie’s voice, approaching confidence. “That’s Penny.”

 

 Her gaze flickers to Penny’s momentarily before Penny whirls away and storms out. But suddenly Annie leaps from the booth and rushes after her, sprinting through the doors.

 

 In an instant, the booth and the café dissolve into shards of memory, spinning like leaves in a storm. The caricature's enraged cackle echoes around you as the world tilts into a boundless black void.

 

 “You can’t face the truth, Jennifer!” she screams, and the darkness swallows you whole.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Charlton School - Gymnasium**

 [image: ./images/School_Gym.png]

 

 You open your eyes to the cavernous hush of the school gym, the echo of distant footsteps and the sharp scent of sweat hanging in the air. To your right, Christina stands impassive, flanked by two cheerleaders you don’t recognize. Each tracing chalk symbols into the scuffed hardwood floor. Preparing.

 

 But more pressing is Skye, standing in front of you.

 

 “This isn’t right,” you find yourself saying.

 

 Skye eyes you darkly. “And what about it is so different?” she replies. “You’ve been playing with her mind for weeks, Jen. This is just the final nudge. Penny’s gone anyway. Her parents moved last week and took her with them. At least this will save her from heartbreak.”

 

 “But she won’t remember,” you try. “And this whole boycrazy thing. Isn’t that a bit too much?”

 

 She laughs softly, sharp as a blade. “Better than being a social pariah. Imagine it, Jen. If people were to find out, she’d be cast out at eighteen. Her father would probably lose his job. And believe me, when you take over this squad, you’ll have to deal with some people that collect cast-outs to do some very unsavoury things.”

 

 Your jaw tightens. “This isn’t what I signed up for. It’s not helping people with charms. It’s changing someone because they aren’t like us.”

 

 Skye’s eyes glint. “You say tomato…”

 

 You stare back, resolute. Next to Skye, the jagged outline of the caricature flickers into view. Her voice, a sibilant whisper, “It’s close now. The question that sealed your fate. Can you remember how you answered it?”

 

 Before you can respond, Christina strides forward, appearing at the side of Skye. “She’s here. Might need to carry her in here, though. Confusion spell hit her harder than expected.”

 

 Skye looks at Christina, then nods. “You just get her in here. Make sure it’s strong enough to hold throughout. If it goes wrong during the chant, it can’t be redone.”

 

 Christina walks off towards the gym exit. Then Skye leans forward, offering a smile at your lack of response. “Come on, Jen. Haven’t I always given you what you wanted? You now… just fit in. Don’t you want Annie to experience that too?”

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You draw in a steady breath and meet Skye’s glare. “No, Skye. I want no part of this.”

 

 Her eyes narrow in disbelief. “Are you refusing to participate? Be careful, Jen. If you can’t make the hard choices, you can’t be a leader.”

 

 You lift an eyebrow, voice calm. “Maybe I’m not cut out to lead this squad. Or maybe I just don’t want to.”

 

 A ripple of tension sweeps the gym. The other cheerleaders, kneeling in a perfect semicircle around a chalk pentagram, glance between you and Skye.

 

 Skye’s tone turns ice-cold. “Is this a challenge?”

 

 “No challenge,” you reply. “I just refuse.”

 

 Skye flashes you a dark smile. “Refusal is a challenge, Jen. You try to deceive me? You have become a rival.”

 

 Magic crackles in the charged air. You feel a sting of power surging from Skye’s outstretched palms and instinctively weave a shield of your own, warmth flaring beneath your skin. The other cheerleaders freeze, but you feel them summoning their own energy. Skye glares at you.

 

 You see a ball of amber energy in Skye’s hands. You feel your own skin glowing from your defensive charm.

 

 The gym doors open with a creak and your attention flicks to the door. Christina hoists Annie in, arm around her to keep her upright. Then she sees you and almost drops Annie.

 

 Her eyes flick to Skye. You glance too at the head cheerleader, feeling your eyes raise. She throws you a dark look, then shakes her head at Christina. 

 

 “Get out,” Skye tells you. “If you get in our way, they’ll be others who come for you.”

 

 You glance at Annie. In her magic inflicted state, barely registering where she is. Then to the cheerleaders. To Christina. To Skye. Four versus one. Bad odds.

 

 Quietly, you take a step forward towards the exit. Then another. And another. You pass Christina. Glance at Annie. Your heart sinks. But you keep walking.

 

 The open gym door leads to a black void. As you step through it, darkness takes you.

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You bite your lip. “Alright. I’m in.”

 

 The gym warps around you. Floors ripple, lights fracture into jagged sketches. But it returns momentarily. Skye nods. “Take your position.”

 

 You move to join the squad, now knelt on their knees in a semi-circle. In front of them is a chalk pentagram. On its centre is a gym bench. You kneel down. Only one spot remains for Christina. Skye steps aside, arms folded, watching.

 

 The main doors groan open. Christina half-drags Annie inside, arm hooked around her shoulders to keep her upright. Annie’s eyes are glassy, her gait unsteady. Too slow, too deliberate. She looks drunk. Or drugged. Perhaps both. But Christina mentioned a spell. Confusion. You don’t know it, but that sounds about right.

 

 Christina sets Annie down on the bench in front of you and joins the semi-circle, now complete. Annie’s head rolls, trying to focus.

 

 “It’s okay, Annie,” Skye says as she leans into Annie, with a tone more maternal than normal. “You’re safe. We found you outside. It looks as though you’ve taken something.”

 

 “Taken something?” Annie tries to say, her words slurring.

 

 “It’s like she’s trashed,” Christina mutters from beside you. The rest of the squad titters.

 

 Skye shoots her a look, then turns back to Annie. “It’s okay. You’re with friends.”

 

 “Penny?” she slurs. You watch her eyes try to focus, but Christina nudges you. Meets your eyes.

 

 You hear words forming in your mouth. Your throat tightens as a phrase surges up from some buried memory. Words you didn’t know you knew. You begin to chant, clear and steady.

 

 *She called it care, she called it friend,

 But these feelings must now end.*

 

 The squad falls in, voices rising in unison. A soft amber glow coils through the chalk lines into the pentagram, pulsing with your breath. Tiny faces form and flicker within the magic, drifting toward Annie.

 

 Meanwhile, Skye continues to reassure Annie in front of you. “Penny is gone, Annie. She left Charlton.”

 

 Annie strains her neck, trying to see beyond Skye. To you and the squad. To the chanting. You feel the pentagram drawing upon the energies the chanting is generating within you. 

 

 *Burn the root that should not grow,

 What she felt, she’ll never know.*

 

 Annie’s eyes flick toward the circle, confusion and fear mixed in her gaze. You feel Skye’s hand gently tilt Annie’s head down. Again you chant, louder now, the gym trembling with your combined will.

 

 *Mirror bright and voices cheer,

 Make her path and purpose clear.*

 

 The pentagram’s glow intensifies. The faces inside coil tighter, baring snapping jaws. Skye beckons. “Ready?”

 

 *False desires now unwind,*

 

 You nod and rise to your feet, the monsters of raw magic crawling up your arms, sea serpent scales against your skin. Moving forward, you stand next to Skye. “Do it,” she quietly demands.

 

 *Let sweet boys possess her mind.*

 

 Your heart thunders as you lift Annie’s chin. The pentagram burns beneath you. With a final surge of magic, you press your lips to hers. Soft, stunned, innocent.

 

 The world tilts on its axis.

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Chambers' Household - Jennifer's room**

 [image: ./images/ChambersHouseJennifersRoom.png]

 
 
 You bolt upright, breath catching in your throat. The room around you is achingly familiar: pastel walls adorned with cheer photos, a vanity strewn with brushes and makeup, trophies lining a shelf. You’re in your old bedroom. Every detail a testament to your over-achieving popularity.

 

 A bright male voice calls from the doorway. “Jennifer! Are you up? Don’t want to be late for school today. Aren’t you starting preparations for the prom?”

 
 
 “Coming, Daddy!” you reply, your voice uncharacteristically lilting and high-pitched. Gone is the haze of sleep; in its place, a spark of excitement at the thought of prom planning.

 

 Seems like a normal day for Jennifer Chambers in Charlton. Except. Sitting at the foot of the bed is the caricature of Annie.

 

 And you’re not Jennifer Chambers!

 

 “Truth is stranger than fiction,” the caricature says. “To be honest, that’s not what I expected from you. For some reason, you came through at the end. Or at least, refused to be involved.”

 

 You wince. “That happened?”

 

 The caricature takes a breath. “Shocking, no? But yes. You finally took some responsibility. It made no difference, though. The ritual still happened. And we never got that back.”

 

 She nods the study desk. You glance over. Amongst the books and schedules you notice one thing pinned to the back. A photo of two girls on swings out in a field. Annie and Jennifer. As children. The one from Jennifer’s bedroom. Happy.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Chambers' Household - Jennifer's room**

 [image: ./images/ChambersHouseJennifersRoom.png]

 
 
 You bolt upright, breath catching in your throat. The room around you is achingly familiar: pastel walls adorned with cheer photos, a vanity strewn with brushes and makeup, trophies lining a shelf. You’re in your old bedroom. Every detail a testament to your over-achieving popularity.

 
 
 A bright male voice calls from the doorway. “Jennifer! Are you up? Don’t want to be late for school today. Aren’t you starting preparations for the prom?”

 

 “Coming, Daddy!” you reply, your voice uncharacteristically lilting and high-pitched. Gone is the haze of sleep; in its place, a spark of excitement at the thought of prom planning.

 

 Seems like a normal day for Jennifer Chambers in Charlton. Except. Sitting at the foot of the bed is the caricature of Annie.

 

 And you’re not Jennifer Chambers!

 

 “A beautiful piece of fiction,” the caricature intones, voice high and bubbly. “To be honest, that’s what I expected you would have done. But for some reason, you chose the other path.”

 

 You wince. It felt so real. So plausible. “That didn’t happen?”

 

 She sighs, a gesture both weary and triumphant. “More or less. Though without you. For me, you’re sudden turn-about made little difference. The ritual still happened. And we never got that back.”

 

 She gestures to the cluttered study desk in the corner. You turn to look: planners, school schedules, a corkboard pinned with reminders. Tucked at its edge is a single photograph. A photo of two girls on swings out in a field. Annie and Jennifer. As children. The one from Jennifer’s bedroom. Happy.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 You look at the photo, feeling emotions at the edge of your conscious. Pain. Betrayal. A friendship turned sour.

 

 “You’ve wrestled the truth from fiction,” you hear the caricature say from behind you. “Jen’s attempts to bury her own guilt will be undone. She'll have trouble thinking of anything else! The real Jennifer, I mean. Or at least, the one that isn’t you.”

 

 “They used magic against her, didn’t they?” you ask the caricature. “Against you?”

 

 She shrugs. “Like I'd know. I’m just a collection of memories, remember? And, Annie, the real one, well, she knows even less that me.”

 

 “Can she remember her feelings for Penny?” you ask.

 

 The caricature seems to think quickly. “Not without help. But you have a knack for that, don’t you? Finding it in even in the most surprising places. Maybe there’s a way you’ll uncover.”
 
 
 You look at the photo, feeling emotions at the edge of your conscious. But try as you might, you can’t seem to feel them. You know that Jennifer and Annie were good friends. Then they weren’t. But you still can’t piece together what happened between them. Or what really happened to Annie.

 

 “So that's that!” you hear the caricature say from behind you. “Jennifer and Annie were friends. Then they weren’t. The cheerleaders were involved. Magic might have been too. But it's tough to tell the difference between fact and fiction these days. It makes my brain hurt.”

 

 “What was that stuff in the gym?” you ask the caricature. “Was it magic?”

 
 
 “As if I'd know,” she replies, shrugging. “Jennifer has buried those memories deep. Good luck trying to get her to talk. And, Annie, the real one that is. She knows even less. Maybe the odd dream here and there. That's it."

 
 

 You begin to feel tired. You take a step back from the mirror, turning sluggishly towards the bed. The edges of your eyes begin to blur.

 

 “And now,” you hear the voice of the caricature say. “Our time has come to an end. Thanks for walking with me down memory lane. Maybe I’ll see you again, sometime. In a mirror, someplace. Maybe at a carnival...”

 

 The words barely register as you stagger forward. And fall, straight down on to the mattress.

 

 Actions

 <>
