title: ShadowSelfFem
text:
[image: ./images/SportsBar.png]

 

 The air is thick with the scent of beer, sweat, and fried food, the low hum of conversation punctuated by bursts of laughter from nearby tables. Neon signs flicker lazily on the walls, casting a warm amber glow across the bar.

 

 You blink. Something feels off. You can feel the weight of your shoulders, the broader width of your chest, the familiar but now alien sensation of stubble grazing your jaw as you exhale. You glance in the nearby window and catch your reflection staring back at you. The reflection of .

 

 *"What’s wrong?"* a voice murmurs inside your brain. *"Feeling out of place?"*

 

 You swallow, your throat thicker, voice deeper than you remember. You remember this place. A dive bar, back in the city. That your brother Brock and his friends used to frequent. The ones around this table, right now.

 

 Opposite, your brother leans back in his chair, tipping his beer bottle toward you. “You gonna order, man, or what?”

 

 You look up to see a waitress standing patiently beside the table. A table full of Brock and his friends. And now you. As .

 

 She’s young, pretty in a casual, effortless way, her blonde ponytail swinging as she pulls out her notepad, a pen tucked neatly behind her ear. She’s already smiling, friendly but distant, the kind of practiced politeness that comes from waiting tables in places like this.

 

 “What can I get for you boys?” she asks. Boys. The word slips over you strangely, both familiar and wrong.

 

 “Uh, yeah,” you clear your throat. “Can we grab another round of -”

 

 “She’s asking what *you* want, genius,” Brock cuts in, smirking. “Come on, don’t keep the lady waiting.”

 

 *Careful. Wouldn’t want her thinking you’re soft, now, would you?*

 

 You ignore the voice and smile politely at the waitress. “Same as the rest, thanks.”

 

 She nods. “Coming right up.”

 

 That’s it? Where’s the fun in that?

 

 But the conversation moves on before you can dwell.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Brock watches the waitress leave, shaking his head. “Man, she’s cute.”

 

 “She’s alright,” one of his friends says, leaning forward. “I bet she’d be more than alright if you took her home.”

 

 The table erupts in laughter, beer bottles clinking together, the easy camaraderie of men being men.

 

 *"You remember this, don't you?"* your Shadow Self murmurs, a dark satisfaction curling into his tone. *"This is where you belong. Sitting with the guys. Laughing. Being one of them."*

 

 “Come on, bro,” Brock says, bringing you back to focus on the table. “Live a little. Play the game. When she comes back, tease her a bit. She gets paid for it.”

 

 “I don’t think she’s into geek,” one of Brock’s friends quips. The group collectively laughs. 

 

 The waitress returns a few minutes later, carrying a tray, balancing bottles with expert ease. She sets them down, smooth, practiced, then pulls out her notepad.

 

 “That’ll be twenty-five fifty,” she says, giving you a small smile.

 

 You glance around the table. Eyes rest on you. Brock’s eyebrow raises.

 

 *Come on. You remember what you said to her, don’t you?*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 You lean back in your chair, flashing a smirk, letting the moment stretch just enough before responding.

 

 “Come on,” you say, voice smooth, familiar, slipping into the rhythm of banter as easily as pulling on an old, worn jacket. “Don’t I get a winning smile with my drink?”

 

 The waitress freezes for just a second. A flicker of something unreadable passes over her face - then, she plasters on a polite laugh, moving through the motions, the same way she probably has a hundred times before.

 

 Brock and the others laugh as you hand over three notes to her. “Keep the change,” you tell her. She flashes you a polite smile, but you notice how forced it seems. Behind it is a quiet resignation of yet another drunk customer. 

 

 The waitress scribbles down the receipt quickly, then nods, moving away without another word.

 

 *See? That wasn’t so hard. Just a little push, and you’re already slipping back into place.*

 

 You take a long sip of your beer.

 

 The night carries on, and you don’t think about the way her eyes looked dead to you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You smile politely, reaching for your wallet.

 

 “Here,” you say, handing over the cash without hesitation. “Keep the change.”

 

 What? What was that?

 

 She looks mildly surprised, eyes flicking up to meet yours before giving a small, genuine nod.

 

 “Thanks,” she says, then turns to leave.

 

 Brock raises an eyebrow as you pick up your beer. “Damn, getting soft on me, huh?”

 

 You shrug, taking a sip. “Just being polite.”

 

 Brock scoffs but doesn’t push it. The moment passes, the conversation shifting, the beers flowing again.

 

 That’s it? Just being polite? That’s not how it went, . Or should I just keep calling you ?

 

 But you ignore him.

 

 The night moves on, and you don’t feel bad about it.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Talk to your brother and his friends

title: ShadowSelfOri
text:
[image: ./images/StudentApartmentGathering.png]

 
 
 The room is warm, dimly lit by a mix of cheap fairy lights and the glow of a game paused on the TV in the corner. The air is thick with the scent of cheap beer and microwave pizza, voices overlapping in a haze of conversation and laughter.

 

 You blink. The beer bottle in your hand feels solid, familiar. Your clothes fit differently, the looser, more relaxed weight of a hoodie against your arms.

 

 You’re . And this is a memory. It seeps into your brain. A low-key university gathering, not a raging party - your crowd. A handful of guys from your course, a few friends of friends, and Emma, the girl you’ve had your eye on since the start of the semester.

 

 Feels good, doesn’t it? Being yourself again. No makeup, no skirts, no giggling for attention. Just beer, games, and a pretty girl worth chasing.

 

 Emma is sitting on the couch, curled up with her legs tucked under her, laughing at something one of the other guys just said. She’s cute, in a way that feels attainable. Not the kind of girl who’d be out of reach, but someone you could have a real shot with. Maybe even a real thing with.

 

 You’ve also seen the way she glances at you, the small moments where she lingers in conversation.

 

 You can do this.

 

 Yeah, you can. But you have to prove it. Don’t just sit there and let the night pass you by. Show her you’re interested. Show everyone.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You move over to the couch, but just as you approach a voice interrupts from behind it.

 

 “Hey, Emma,” Greg says, leaning nervously over the sofa.

 

 Memories swell up. Greg is one of your friends. A decent guy. Geeky, quiet, not blessed with confidence. 

 

 “Oh. Hey Greg,” Emma responds, politely smiling back to him. 

 

 Watching him for a moment, you grimace. Something about the way he’s leaning forward just a little too much, the nervous way his fingers twitch against his bottle. He’s trying to put himself out there. Just like you’ve told him to.

 

 You just didn’t say anything about it being Emma, though.

 

 *"He got in your way,”* your Shadow Self whispers to you. *“And you weren’t cruel about it..."*

 

 Make yourself the better option. Make her laugh. If Greg crashes and burns, that’s his fault, right?

 

 You glance at Emma. She’s listening to Greg prattle on about the current state of the opposition government, but her smile is neutral.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 You grin, watching Greg stumble through his point - he’s trying to explain a theory he’s developing on a way to engage grassroots activism, but he’s over-explaining it, his enthusiasm drawing it out and making it hard to follow. 

 

 It’s harmless. Yet it’s boring. You bet that Emma is too polite to shut him down. *But you’re not.*

 

 You lean back, sitting down and stretching your arms lazily over the back of the couch. Then jump in just as he pauses for breath.

 

 “Greg, my guy,” you say, smirking, “I think Emma came here to have fun, not to sit through a lecture.”

 

 Greg blinks, startled. “I was just -”

 

 Emma titters. And that’s all it takes.

 

 Greg closes his mouth, his confidence draining like a battery on its last charge. His eyes hang on you, hurt and ashamed. Without a word, he slithers away.

 

 Emma turns her attention fully to you, sipping her drink, smirking slightly. You smirk back. And you know where the night is going to take you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You stay quiet, watching from the edge of the sofa.

 

 You could make a joke, could shut Greg down, but… Emma is listening to him.

 

 She’s not leaning in, not flirting, but she’s giving him a chance. And instead of forcing yourself into the moment, you just… let it happen.

 

 *"What are you doing?"* your Shadow Self hisses, voice laced with irritation. *"You’re just going to sit there? Let Greg take the shot?"*

 

 Maybe. Maybe Greg has a shot. Maybe he doesn’t. But it’s not your call to make.

 

 Emma gives a polite laugh, nods, but then glances away, taking a sip of her drink.

 

 Greg was never going to win her over tonight. But at least it wasn’t because you stepped in and made him look bad.

 

 Instead, you go to the kitchen and grab another drink. You know there will be plenty of time to catch up with Emma later. For now though, you’re happy just enjoying the evening.

 

 *Unbelievable.*

 

 The night moves on. And you don’t feel bad about it.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: ShadowSelfInt
text:
[image: ./images/OfficeBreakoutSpace.png]

 
 
 The hum of the office is distant, muffled by the walls of the breakout space, where a small team huddles around a whiteboard covered in diagrams and equations.

 

 The air smells of dry-erase markers and stale coffee, the low buzz of conversation punctuated by the occasional laugh or sigh of frustration.

 

 You’re standing with your team, sleeves rolled up, half-drunk coffee in hand, watching as people throw out solutions for the latest issue in your solution design.

 

 This is familiar. You know this space. You know this team. Your team, back in the city, before you moved to Charlton.

 

 *"Feels good, doesn’t it?"* your Shadow Self murmurs, his voice curling at the edges of your mind. *"Being the smartest guy in the room again. Not the cute little office worker waiting for approval.”*

 

 You shift slightly, the familiar weight of your stance, the comfortable press of your shirt collar, the distinct, once-automatic confidence of being in his element.

 

 The whiteboard is a mess of half-formed architecture, lines and notes attempting to solve a thorny bottleneck issue in the latest system rollout.

 

 Everyone’s talking, but no one has the right solution. Then -

 

 “I have an idea.”

 

 A young woman steps forward. You recognise her. Claire.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You glance at her as she moves towards the whiteboard. She’s eager, pushing past the subtle groans from a few guys who, despite working in tech in the city, still think she’s out of her depth.

 

 But she doesn’t let it shake her. She grabs the marker and launches into an idea.

 

 It’s… smart. Really smart. A novel approach, one that pushes the limits of what the system can handle.

 

 *She’s good. But she’s also wrong.*

 

 You see the flaw immediately. Her solution is too clever for its own good. It’ll create a severe load on server requests, causing bottlenecks elsewhere.

 

 She doesn’t see it. Neither does anyone else. They’re nodding, impressed, warming up to the idea now that they can see how it works. The attention for once has shifted from you. And it’s incorrect.

 

 *"You gonna let this stand?"* your Shadow Self whispers, mocking. *"This is your moment. Step in. Shut it down. Show them who the real expert is."*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 You bite your tongue. You could cut in right now, take control of the conversation, fix the problem in front of everyone.

 

 But you don’t. Something about doing that to Claire doesn’t sit right.

 

 *You’re letting this happen? Letting her talk nonsense while they all nod along? What happened to you?"*

 

 Claire finishes her pitch, stepping back. The team discusses it, bouncing ideas, still impressed. And then the meeting moves on.

 

 You don’t step in. Instead, you wait.

 

 Later, as the office empties for lunch, you find Claire at her desk, typing away. You lean on the partition next to her desk. “Hey. Got a second?”

 

 She looks up, surprised. “Uh, yeah. What’s up?”

 

 You tap the side of her monitor.

 

 “Your solution. It’s smart,” you say. “But it’s going to create server overload because of how the requests pile up. You see it?”

 

 She pauses, processing. Then her eyes widen slightly.

 

 “Oh, shit. I didn’t think about that.”

 

 You nod. “It’s an easy fix, though. We just need to adjust the processing sequence, and it’ll work without the overload.”

 

 She laughs, shaking her head. “I can’t believe I missed that.”

 

 “You were close,” you say, smiling. “And you got the team thinking differently. That’s worth something.”

 

 Claire grins, looking genuinely appreciative.

 

 *Pathetic. You could’ve fixed it in front of everyone, but instead, you handed her the win.*

 

 Maybe.

 

 But Claire doesn’t look humiliated. She looks like she learned something. And you don’t feel bad about it.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You step forward, lifting a hand. “Wait,” you say, cutting in before she can continue.

 

 Claire pauses, blinking at you, the marker still hovering near the board.

 

 “This won’t work,” you say plainly, gesturing toward the core of her diagram. “Your approach is going to overload the system with unnecessary requests. The bottleneck won’t be where you think. It’ll be here.”

 

 You underline a section of the design, the flaw standing out like a neon sign once you point it out.

 

 The energy in the room shifts. Claire’s confidence falters, the hesitation flashing across her face for just a moment.

 

 You look back to your audience. One of the senior devs nods along with you.

 

 “He’s right,” they say, rubbing their chin. “We’d be adding way too much processing overhead.”

 

 Claire opens her mouth, about to argue, but then she sees it. Her shoulders drop slightly.

 

 The conversation moves on, someone building off your correction, turning it into a new approach.

 

 And just like that, Claire is out of the conversation.

 

 *"Damn, I missed this,"* your Shadow Self murmurs, satisfied. *"The moment where you remind everyone that you're just... better."*

 

 Claire doesn’t say anything to you after the meeting.

 

 But you don’t feel bad about it. Because you were right. And that’s what matters.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Stay quiet and wait to work with Claire to improve her idea
Butt in and critique her design publicly

title: ShadowSelfAss
text:
[image: ./images/HearthAndHome.png]

 

 You’re sitting at a table in The Hearth & Home - Charlton’s finest dining establishment. Where couples celebrate anniversaries, families mark milestones, and the atmosphere itself hums with quiet tradition.

 

 The restaurant is quiet but elegant, the soft glow of candlelight reflecting off polished silverware. The scent of rich sauces and wine lingers in the air, blending with the muted hum of conversation.

 

 Every table is perfectly arranged, white linens crisp and untouched, couples sitting with straight backs, speaking in hushed, polite tones. The waitresses move gracefully, all smiles and pristine uniforms, their hands folded neatly behind their backs when not in use.

 

 The very air here carries an unspoken expectation. Of manners, poise, and tradition.

 

 And yet, the moment feels stifling. You shift slightly in your chair, the collared shirt fitting snugly against your frame, the weight of your old form grounding you. You’re again. And across from you, Jennifer sits, her arms resting neatly on the table, her blue eyes sharp as she watches you.

 

 You somehow recall this moment. You remember this. This was your first couple’s fight.

 

 *"Funny, isn’t it?"* your Shadow Self murmurs, his voice dripping amusement. *"How quickly things fall into place when you’re in the right skin again."*

 

 The candle flickers between you, and Jennifer exhales, shaking her head.

 

 “You keep acting like this is something I can just accept.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I’m not asking for the world, ,” she tells you, a restraint notable in her voice. “Just that you consider me. I’ve never been anything other than forthcoming about wanting to move from Charlton.”

 

 You feel yourself looking around. People are watching. Not obviously, not overtly, but in the way Charlton does.

 

 You can feel their eyes flicker over to your table, women whispering behind delicate hands, men occasionally glancing between their own conversations to assess the dynamic.

 

 *They’re waiting to see how you handle this. You wouldn’t want to embarrass yourself now, would you?*

 

 You keep your voice even, leaning forward slightly.

 

 “I’m not saying you have to walk away from Emily,” she says, measured. Her eyes look around the restaurant. You know her restraint isn’t just for you. “I just don’t understand why you’re so determined to stay.”

 

 “Jen,” you say, sighing. “Charlton isn’t a prison.”

 

 “That’s debatable,” she murmurs.

 

 You feel yourself huff with irritation. “You’re being ridiculous. It’s just until the end of the school year.”

 

 *"Here it comes,"* your Shadow Self hums, pleased. *"She’s trying to reframe it. Make you the unreasonable one. You gonna let her?"*
 

 Jennifer leans back slightly, graceful and composed, but you can see the tension in her shoulders, the restraint in her movements. “You think we’ll last that long?”

 

 You don’t look away from her, but feel the eyes of the restaurant now firmly on you. The guests at Hearth & Home are watching you both, waiting to see who will win.

 

 *What’s it gonna be? The strong, assertive man at the table… or the one who backs down?*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 

 You exhale through your nose, tilting your head slightly.

 

 “See, this is the problem,” you say smoothly, keeping your voice even. “You act like I’m the one being unreasonable, but all I’m doing is telling you the truth.”

 

 Jennifer’s brows snap together. “Excuse me?”

 

 “Emily’s education is the most important thing to her right now. The world isn’t going anywhere. But you’re making this an ultimatum between her graduating and our relationship. Frankly, it’s childish. You’re acting like a spoilt kid.”

 

 Jennifer’s lips part slightly, but you keep going.

 

 “Charlton isn’t a bad place, Jen. You need to learn how to accept the best of the situation. I’m not going anywhere until Emily graduates. If you can’t accept that, the door is over there.”

 

 You gesture to the exit. It’s a dramatic gesture, one that you know everyone has seen.

 

 Jennifer glares back at you, her cheeks reddening. She looks around towards the other patrons, who watch her with creeping smiles and raised eyebrows.

 

 “You have no idea about Charlton,” she mutters under her breath, before returning to picking at her food. But she doesn’t make an attempt to leave.

 

 The whispering in the restaurant starts up again. The watchful eyes shift, murmurs passing between couples, subtle nods exchanged between men at other tables.

 

 You realize they’re approving. Not of Jennifer. Of you.

 

 *That’s more like it. See? You just have to remind them who’s in charge.*

 

 Jennifer puts her knife and fork down, exhaling sharply, her disappointment evident. But she doesn’t argue further. Because the conversation is over. You won.

 

 Or did you?

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You inhale slowly, resisting the urge to push forward. Because something about this… feels wrong.

 

 Not just the argument. The way people are watching. The way they’re waiting to see you take control.

 

 Jennifer shakes her head. “You keep talking about this place like it’s just for a year, but have you ever thought - just for a second - that maybe I want to be here? Like, this second. If I could leave tomorrow, , I would.”

 

 You lean back slightly. “I..."

 

 Jennifer raises a brow, waiting for you to speak.

 

 “I understand,” you finally reply. “Maybe we should discuss this at home.”

 

 A moment passes between you. Jennifer’s eyes shift around the room. She’s putting up a measure of defiance. Not just from the argument. But from the patron’s judgement of her hostility to their way of life.

 

 “I just want you to be happy,” you say to her, letting the hostility drain from your voice.

 

 “Thank you,” she says after a moment, her voice softer.

 

 You glance around again. The guests at other tables are still watching. But they’re not nodding along anymore. The approval is gone.

 

 *"Weak,"* your Shadow Self mutters, disgusted.

 

 But for the first time in this conversation, his voice doesn’t feel like the loudest one.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Calm down and listen to her

title: WorkPerformanceEvents
text:
**Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Thompson's Office**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Office_Thompson.png]

 
A cluttered and cramped office, lined with filing cabinets. An imposing desk is the centerpiece, covered in files and paperwork.

 

 Inside, Thompson drops into his leather chair with a grunt, the worn material groaning under his weight. You take a seat opposite him, the chair height at the lowest setting. You suspect, on purpose.

 

 "Gotta admit, Phillips," he starts, cracking his knuckles behind his head. "When you first showed up, I wasn’t sure you’d hack it. Thought you’d fold under pressure."

 

 A pause. He smirks. "But, I’m the first to admit when I’m wrong."

 

 You offer him a polite smile. He’s actually the last.

 

 "You’ve put in the work. In Charlton, that matters." His gaze sharpens, locking onto you like a challenge. "Hasn’t been easy, has it? Parents off on business, brother gone to Uni. That’s a lot of responsibility for someone in a new town."

 

 You give a slow nod, unsure where this is going.

 

 Thompson exhales through his nose, pulling open a drawer. "But if you pull your weight around here, Charlton looks after its own. Once you're in, you're in. And I’d say you’ve proven yourself enough that it’s time to get in."

 

 He slides a slip of paper across the desk. The ink is slightly smudged, but the address is clear - a house towards the outskirts of town, on the border between the community and the farming fields that surround it.

 

 "Poker night." He says it like that explains everything. "Happens at the Mayor’s place. One of the teachers - Darcy Harrow - organizes it. Just a gathering. Some of the local men, couple of the older students to show them how to play a few rounds. Maybe some beers, cigars." He leans back, watching your reaction.

 

 
 Thompson tilts his head slightly. "Bring your sister along, too. It’s not exclusive for men. We’re an equal opportunity community. Some of the guys bring their girlfriends and wives to help out. Always snacks and drinks to serve."

 

 A beat. Then, his smirk deepens.

 

 "Your sister seeing anyone?" He doesn’t wait for an answer, just chuckles to himself. "Wouldn’t be a bad way for her to show her value to some of the bachelors around town. Who knows? She might snag a man." He flicks a glance at you. "Get her out of your hair."

 
 Thompson studies you for a moment, then gives an easy shrug. "It might seem a bit manly, but there’s a role for women too. Get to meet some of the guys around the town. Share a few little jokes as you serve them a beer. Some of the guys bring their girlfriends and wives along to help out. You could meet them too."

 

 Then, too casually, he asks, "You single?"

 

 Before you can answer, he waves a hand. "Not a bad way to show your value to some of the bachelors around town. Who knows? You might snag a man."

 

 Then, as an afterthought: "Bring your sister along, too. Always room for women to offer a helping hand."

 
 

 Satisfied, Thompson leans back, clearly expecting you to take the offer without question. "Come by," he says. "And keep up the good work."

 

 Actions

 <>

 You stare him down. “You can puff your chest all you want, Dan. But I’m not here to play your games. And I’m not scared of your threats.”

 

 Dan’s expression hardens, just for a moment. The smirk still lingers at the edges of his mouth, but the warmth behind it has frozen over.

 

 “Think you’re a big shot now,” he says slowly, tone shifting to something more menacing. “All assertive and confident. Trying to be like Thompson? He respects a bit of alpha male in his workforce.”

 “Oh, you’ve got fire,” he says slowly, tone shifting to something more menacing. “Thompson must like that. He’s got a thing for a bit of cheek.”
 
 

 He steps closer, lowering his voice.

 

 “But he’s got a short thread, Phillips. One slip. One wrong word. One off day. That’s all it takes.”

 

 He leans back, flashing his teeth in a smile that doesn’t reach his eyes.

 

 “And when it happens? I’ll be waiting. Cigar in one hand, whisky in the other. Watching the show.”

 

 His words linger like smoke in the air as he turns and strolls back to his desk - no longer bothering to block your path, but making it clear that whatever game he’s playing… you’re on his board.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 You meet his gaze, keeping your tone calm. “I’ll be sure to mention your name to Mr. Thompson. Let him know who’s been helping me settle in.”

 

 Dan’s grin stretches wide. Smug, satisfied, and far too pleased with himself.

 

 “That’s what I like to hear,” he says, giving your shoulder a mock-patronizing pat. “Smart move, Phillips. Very smart.”

 

 He walks past you slowly, tapping your desk twice with the flat of his palm. “Good to know you understand how things work around here. There’s a pecking order in every part of Charlton. Thompson’s Repairs is no different.”

 

 He turns back, clearly enjoying himself. “And around here? I’m the head hen.”

 

 The sentence hangs awkwardly in the air. You blink. *Surely, he meant rooster?*

 

 But Dan, oblivious, just laughs at his own joke and strolls off. And yet, even with the idiotic slip, his next words still manage to land like a warning.

 

 “Stick to your lane, Phillips. You’ll be just fine. Stray too far from it…” He whistles, low and casual, “...well, things have a way of getting messy.”

 

 Actions

 <> 

 You square your stance. "This isn’t fair. I don’t think this is the right way to handle it."

 

 Thompson stops mid-stride. His head tilts slightly, like he can’t believe what he just heard.

 

 "You think you’re in a position to argue with me?" His voice drops, dangerously quiet. "You think I’m giving you a choice?"

 

 His fingers twitch, like he’s resisting the urge to point straight in your face again.

 

 "This is me being generous, Phillips. You don’t want this? Fine. I know every business owner in this town. You think they’ll hire someone who can’t handle a simple booking system?"

 

 His smirk fades completely, replaced with something colder, sharper.

 

 "What happens to that sister of yours if you’re out on the street, huh?"

 

 The office is so silent you can hear your own pulse.

 

 Thompson exhales, taking a step back. His tone shifts into mock amusement, but there’s nothing funny about it.

 

 "Wednesday and Friday lunchtimes. You’ll be at that front desk. We’ll review the situation if your work improves."

 

 He sneers. "If you don’t find yourself enjoying it, of course. Some people just fit the chair better."

 

 With that, he stomps back into his office, the tension in the room finally breaking as he slams the door shut.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 You grit your teeth, swallowing the urge to push back, and nod. "Understood."

 

 Something in Thompson’s expression eases. Just a fraction. His anger is still there, but now it’s laced with something approaching approval.

 

 "Good," he says. "Wednesday and Friday lunchtimes. Be there. And if your work improves, we’ll review it."

 

 Then, smirking faintly, he adds, "Unless, of course, you find that the receptionist chair suits you better."

 

 He turns on his heel and stalks back into his office, his anger spent. For now.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 You get ready in silence, stepping out into the grey Charlton morning. The streets feel colder than usual. Watchful, like the town knows something you don’t.

 

 You push open the door to Thompson’s Repairs. The bell above the entrance sounds too loud in the stillness.

 

 Annie looks up from behind the desk, but doesn’t greet you. No wink, no wave. Just a polite, tight smile. Then she looks away.

 

 You move past her and enter the main office. Dan is at his desk, but he doesn’t look up. He sees you. You know he does. But his eyes stay fixed on the screen in front of him.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 **Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Thompson's Office**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Office_Thompson.png]

 

 You step into Thompson’s office. The door clicks shut behind you.

 

 He doesn’t look up immediately. Just finishes making a note in the ledger on his desk. When he does raise his eyes to meet yours, they’re devoid of fire. Somehow, that’s worse.

 

 He leans back in his chair. "This isn’t working out, Phillips."

 

 His voice is quiet. Measured. Like he’s already made the decision.

 

 "The booking system’s still riddled with issues. Suppliers aren’t getting orders. Some have stopped taking our calls. We’ve got addresses missing from job sheets. I’ve got Clive telling me he hasn’t been paid in two weeks."

 

 He shakes his head slowly. "It’s basic. Foundational. And it’s not happening."

 

 Thompson exhales and leans forward, folding his hands on the desk.

 

 "Annie needs some time away from the front desk. I’ve been thinking of promoting her to a more… internal role. PA work."

 

 There’s a brief silence as that lands.

 

 "In the meantime, I can get Theodore back on freelance. He won’t leave that caravan of his, but he can work remote. While he handles the code, you’ll cover reception."

 

 He lifts his chin.

 

 "If you can prove you belong here, if you show me you understand what responsibility looks like, I’ll consider moving you back onto development. Full time."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 <> 
 
 You nod, keeping your expression neutral. There’s no room to negotiate.

 

 Thompson doesn’t thank you. He just watches you a moment longer, then finally says:

 

 "Take the rest of the day. Think about things."

 

 He opens a drawer, pulls out a set of keys, and places them on the desk.

 

 "Tomorrow morning. You’ll be behind the reception desk."

 

 You pick up the keys in silence and step out.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You square your shoulders. “Give me another chance. I know I can turn this around.”

 

 Thompson stares at you. Unblinking, unreadable. His voice stays level, but something flickers in his jaw.

 

 "This is your other chance, Phillips."

 

 He leans forward slightly, his voice still calm but laced with steel.

 

 "You either accept the position… or you walk out that door."

 

 You think of Emily. Of the rent. Of what comes next if you leave. You swallow.

 

 “…Fine. I’ll take it.”

 

 Thompson nods once.

 

 "Take the rest of the day." He places the keys to reception on the desk. "Be here first thing tomorrow."

 

 You take the keys and leave, knowing you've barely managed to hang on.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 As you step out of his office, the weight settles over you. You’re on your last warning. One wrong move, and you're out.

 

 You need to talk to someone. Someone who matters. Emily comes to mind immediately.

 

 You should really speak to your sister about how serious this has become.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 You rub your forehead and let out a slow, exhausted breath. "I’m not sure, Em. I need to go over our finances. See what we can cut, if we can stretch what little we’ve got left."

 

 
 Emily doesn't say anything for a moment. Then, slowly, she walks over and rests a hand on your arm.

 

 "Maybe I could find a part-time job? Just something after school, or weekends. I mean... I’m not useless."

 

 You shake your head. "You need to focus on school."

 

 "I will," she insists. "But we’re in this together, right? We’ll figure it out. I’ll head to school now."

 

 She grabs her bag, offering a small, encouraging smile. "We can talk properly when I get back."

 

 The door clicks softly shut behind her. You exhale, already dreading the numbers you're about to face.

 
 Emily stares at you for a moment before scoffing. "Seriously?" Her voice rises, a mix of fear and anger. "You better *think* of something. I can’t deal with this. Not on top of everything else!"

 

 She storms past you, grabbing her schoolbag with a frustrated swipe.

 

 "I’ve got enough pressure from everyone at school. If I come home and find out we’re being kicked out too -- "

 

 The door slams before she finishes her sentence. You're left alone in the quiet house, the weight of her panic pressing down like a stone on your chest.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 You spend the day reviewing your finances, spread across the kitchen table. Bills, statements, whatever scraps of income you can find. It doesn’t take long to realise the truth: things are bad. Really bad.

 

 Your parents had made it clear when they left that there wouldn’t be much help from them. Getting Brock into university had drained nearly everything. What little remains in your account won’t last more than a few weeks.

 

 By the time the sun dips low, casting amber light through the window, you hear the front door open and Emily step inside.

 

 She drops her bag by the stairs and looks over at you. "How bad is it?"

 

 You exhale. "It’s not great. We don’t have much. We’ll need to find ways to bring in money around town. Just to keep things ticking over."

 

 Emily frowns. "What about getting another job?"

 

 You shake your head. "Programmers aren’t exactly in demand in Charlton."

 

 She nods. “I guess it’s tough when Charlton still thinks fax machines are cutting-edge. What about remote work?"

 

 You smirk a little. “I can’t even get a web page to load quickly here. I don’t think Charlton was designed for online jobs.”

 

 Emily grimaces. “I guess we’re left with only a few options.”

 

 Staring at her, you notice a strange look on Emily's face. She is bracing herself to speak.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 Emily gives a small shrug. "At least I’m already bringing in a little from the hotel. Maybe I can try harder for tips."

 

 You frown. "I don’t want you to take on the burden."

 

 "We need money," she says again. Simple. Undeniable.

 
 She pauses. "I could get a part-time job. At the hotel. As a maid or something."

 

 You hesitate. "Em -"

 

 "We need money," she says, firm but calm. "I’ll ask tomorrow."

 
 
 

 There’s a quiet moment, then she adds, "Maybe there’s a way the amulet could help."

 

 You glance up. "What do you mean?"

 

 "Well… maybe you don’t need to do your job. You could do someone else’s."

 

 Your brow furrows. "You’re not seriously suggesting I steal someone’s job? And their wages?"

 

 Emily shakes her head. "No. Let them keep their pay. But some jobs in Charlton come with perks. Tips. Gratitude. A little extra slipped your way. Maybe you can use the amulet to become someone who earns those things too."

 

 You say nothing at first. You can’t help but think of Florence. Andrea. People working themselves to the bone just to scrape by. Would it be right to step into their shoes, even for a day? Even just for the tips?

 

 But then again... survival is survival.

 

 “I’ll consider it,” you tell Emily. “For now, that’s enough worrying for one day.”

 

 She nods, but remains silent. Eventually, Emily tells you that she's ready to call it a night. She quietly takes the stairs up to her room, leaving you alone.

 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 <Emily will need to take on jobs around town.">>

choices.label: Spend the day reviewing your finances

title: AndreaDialogue
text:
“You seem a little on edge,” you say to her. “Is everything okay?”

 

 Her eyes flick back to the room, then to you. “Lennox is being particularly spiteful today," she confides in you. "He's threatened to fire me three times today."

 

 She glances over her shoulder, then sighs. “We’re so understaffed right now,” she says quietly. “I’m trying my best. Mr. Sermon and Lennox won't budge on their strict hiring policy. They've worked their way through almost every unemployed girl in town."

 

 "What are they looking for?" you ask.

 

 "Young. Pretty. *Compliant*," she replies. "Unless you know of anyone new to town, I don't think I'm getting a break."

 
 
 
 “Planning a trip?” you ask her. She gives you a puzzled look.

 

 “Why would I do that?” Andrea asks you. “Foreign countries are dangerous.”
 
 
 “Planning a trip?” you ask her. You notice a little grin form underneath the nervousness.

 

 “I’d love to,” Andrea tells you. “I know they told at school other countries are dangerous, but I still want to go on a plane. Just once.”

 
 

 You hear a distant clatter from the kitchen, but it’s enough to make her jump. “I’m sorry!” she stammers. “I should get back to it. Unless there's anything else?”
 
 
 “You seem a little on edge,” you say to her. “Is everything okay?”

 

 Her eyes flick back to the room, then to you. “Yeah, everything is fine. Is there anything I can help you with?”

 

 “You seem busy,” you try. “Are you alright?”

 

 She again looks around, then sighs. “We’re just a bit understaffed right now,” she says quietly. “I’m trying my best. Please don’t tell Pierre or Lennox. Hopefully they’ll find some more help soon. Maybe then I can take a break.”

 
 
 
 “Planning a trip?” you ask her. She gives you a puzzled look.

 

 “Why would I do that?” Andrea asks you. “Foreign countries are dangerous.”
 
 
 “Planning a trip?” you ask her, offering her a pleasant smile. You notice a little grin form underneath the nervousness.

 

 “I’d love to,” Andrea tells you. “I know other countries are dangerous, but I’d just love to go on a plane. Just once.”

 
 

 You hear a distant clatter from the kitchen, but it’s enough to make her jump. “I’m sorry!” she stammers. “Mr. Matox doesn’t encourage talking to guests at the hotel. Is there anything else I can do for you today?”

 
 “You seem a little on edge,” you say to her. “Is everything okay?”

 

 Her eyes flick back to the room, then to you. “Yeah, everything is fine. Is there anything I can help you with?”

 

 “You seem busy,” you try. “Are you alright?”

 

 She again looks around, then sighs. “We’re just a bit understaffed right now,” she says quietly. “I’m trying my best. Please don’t tell Pierre or Lennox. Hopefully they’ll find some more help soon. Maybe then I can take a break.”

 
 
 
 “Planning a trip?” you ask her. She gives you a puzzled look.

 

 “Why would I do that?” Andrea asks you. “Foreign countries are dangerous.”

 "But you're eighteen, right?" Andrea asks, pointedly. "Mr. Sermon has a strict policy about his staff. In many areas."

 

 You nod, trying to feign innocence. *You can imagine why he is so strict.* "Sure. No problem there."

 

 Andrea gives you another long look. "Alright," she says, with hesitancy. "It doesn't pay well," she adds. "But it will give you a bit of pocket money. If you're interested, speak to Lennox." She gives you a small smile. "I'd really appreciate the help."

 You look around the lobby to ensure no one is watching, then turn back to stare at Andrea.

 And slowly, almost delicately, you let out your breath. The magic infused within the elements highlights a thin trail of air drifting towards Andrea's face.

 After gaining some composure, Andrea looks at you. "Believe me, there's nothing you could say that could make my life any worse."

 

 She stares back at you with a measure of defiance. Then returns to her work. For once, ignoring you.

"Hey Annie, I was wondering if you'd like to go for another drink this evening?"
 
 

 Annie gives you a look. "I think we should have a chat, first of all," she says, the demeanour of a bright and bubbly secretary disappearing. "Come over one morning before work. We can talk."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You nod. She smiles. "Great! I'll see you there."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You clear your throat, trying not to sound too eager. "Hey, Annie," you say, leaning casually on the counter. "I was wondering... any chance I could borrow the key to the shop? Just for a little while?"

 

 Annie's lips curves into a teasing smile. "Oh, , I’d love to help you out," she says, her voice lilting with mock seriousness. "But you know, a girl’s gotta have her secrets." She twirls a strand of her hair around her finger, her blue eyes sparkling as they meet yours. "Besides, what would Mr. Thompson say if he found out I was handing out keys to handsome men? Probably wouldn’t go over so well."

 

 She steps a little closer, her tone softening just a touch. "Tell you what, though. If you really need something in there, maybe we can figure it out together. Just don’t go thinking you can charm me into trouble." Her grin widens, the playful glint in her eyes making it hard to tell if she’s joking or challenging you.

 
 You lean on her desk, smiling at her. "Annie, would you mind lending me the key to Thompson’s office? I promise I’ll be careful."

 You lean on the counter, smiling at her. "Annie, would you mind lending me the key to Thompson’s office? I promise I’ll be careful."

 

 Annie listens to your request, tapping her nails lightly against her desk as you finish. "Oh, , I totally get why you’d want the key," she says, her tone sympathetic but firm. "But, you know... some things are best left off-limits. Call it an unofficial house rule." She shrugs lightly, her expression apologetic but still friendly.

 

 "Don’t get me wrong. I trust you. It’s just that if Thompson found out..." Her voice trails off, and she lets out a soft laugh. "Let’s just say I’d rather not end up on his bad side. You understand, right?" She reaches out, giving your arm a light squeeze. "Look, if there’s something in there you need, maybe we can figure out another way. You know I’ve got your back."

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 You lean in slightly, lowering your voice to ensure only Annie hears you. "Annie, about that key... I think you’ll want to hear me out before saying no."

 

 Her bright smile falters for the first time, and her eyes narrow slightly. "What’s this about?" she asks, her tone still playful but with a wary edge.

 

 "You know exactly what I mean," you say, your voice calm but firm. "The hotel room. Lunchtime. You and Mr. Thompson. I didn’t think you’d want everyone knowing about your little... meetings."

 

 Her cheeks flush, and she exhales sharply, crossing her arms as her smile disappears completely. "You really don’t know when to quit, do you?" she says, her voice low and clipped. She glances around the room, her unease clear as she leans closer to you.

 

 
 "Fine," she mutters after a long pause. She pulls the key from her pocket and slams it onto the desk between you. "Take it. But you’d better keep your mouth shut. If I hear even one word about this, you’ll regret it." She steps back, her blue eyes now icy as she watches you take the key.

"I was curious about who had my place on the squad before me," you begin. "Tandi. At least, I think that was her name."

 

 Britney shares a look with Stacey before turning back to you. "Who's been talking about Tandi?"

 

 You shrug. "Just heard the name mentioned a few times."

 

 "Tandi was - is - someone you don't want to get caught up with," Britney tells you, for once losing her sparkle. "She's toxic, Em. Got into all kinds of bad stuff."

 

 "Or bad stuff gets into her," Stacey snipes. "Regularly."

 

 Britney shushes the cheerleader, then smiles at you. "She used to be on the squad. But Em -" she hesitates, then lowers her voice. "She's turned into a total slut!"

 

 Stacey rolls her eyes at Britney's anxiety about talking this way. "Stop it!" Britney says to her friend. "She has! Last I heard, she hangs out with those icky bikers outside of town."

 

 "What happened to her?" you ask.

 

 Again, Britney seems uncomfortable. "Just didn't belong in the cheerleaders. But I'm sure that won't happen to you, Em. You belong with us!"

 

 You notice Stacey giving another dark glance to her friend. It's enough to make Britney fall silent.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 "Curses?" Britney’s eyes light up with excitement, and she leans in closer. "Oh my gosh, they’re, like, so fascinating! Did you know you can use them to make people totally do what you want? Like, Reagan was being super bossy the other day, and I thought, Wouldn’t it be hilarious if she couldn’t stop hiccupping during practice?" She giggles, the thought clearly delighting her.

 

 "Of course, Reagan didn't let that go unanswered," Stacey follows up, causing Britney to pout. After glaring at her friend, she turns back to you.

 

 "They’re kind of like this secret weapon, you know? A way to, like, set things right when people are being... difficult. And they’re fun to experiment with! You wouldn’t believe how many tiny changes can totally mess with someone’s day." She twirls a strand of her hair, her tone bright and carefree.

 

 Then, as if remembering herself, she shrugs. "I mean, as long as you don’t, like, overdo it or anything. Some people get all serious about curses, but honestly? It’s just a little harmless fun. Right?"

 

 Her grin falters for a moment, a flicker of doubt crossing her face, before she brushes it off with a breezy laugh. "Anyway, if you’re dealing with one, let me know! I could totally help you figure out how to turn it into something... fun."

"Sometimes she can be a little... pushy, you know? Like, she knows what’s best for everyone. I just wish she’d, um, let people figure stuff out for themselves sometimes."

 

 She glances at you, her smile returning, though it feels a little strained. "But she really does mean well. I think."

I mean, I’m not exactly, like, the most interesting person around or anything." She fidgets with the bracelet on her wrist, glancing away for a moment before flashing a small, genuine smile. "But, uh... thanks."

 

 She hesitates, clearly unsure where to start, before her face lights up. "Oh! Well, I’ve been pretty busy lately. My brother - Marc, he runs our family farm - is getting married soon, so I’ve been helping plan the wedding. It’s kind of a big deal, you know? Catherine - his fiancée - just moved to Charlton a little while ago. She’s, like, amazing. So creative and thoughtful. She runs the new flower shop. Have you seen it?"

 

 Britney leans in slightly, her voice dropping as though sharing a secret. "It’s funny, actually. Catherine’s... different. She doesn’t really fit the Charlton mold, you know? Kind of like you." Her eyes meet yours, and she gives a soft laugh. "I think that’s why I like her so much. She’s not afraid to do things her way, and it’s... refreshing."

 

 She straightens up, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear. "Anyway, the wedding’s going to be beautiful, but I’m kind of freaking out about planning the hen party. Catherine’s not really into all the traditional Charlton stuff, and I want her to actually enjoy it, you know? But Reagan and my mom keep giving me these ideas, and... ugh." She sighs, her bubbly tone faltering for a moment. "It’s just a lot."

 Stacey rolls her eyes. “Christina’s just trying to help him. You know how she is.”

 

 You tilt your head. “Help him how?”

 

 Britney shrugs, too fast. “We’re just trying to bring a little joy into his life. He looked so lonely. Honestly, it was kind of sad.”

 

 Stacey rolls her eyes. “And it was working, too. Until -”

 

 Her words drop off when Britney catches her eye. You look between the two, sensing the awkwardness between them. “Come on,” you push. “We’re all friends here. What’s the plan?”

 

 “You should talk to Chrissie,” Britney says, almost serious. “She can tell you.”

 

 “I can help, though,” you try.

 

 “If you want to help,” Britney says, too quickly, “figure out what’s in that book.” 

 

 Stacey nudges her with her elbow, giving her a dark look. You raise your eyebrow at them, waiting.

 

 “His biology book,” Stacey admits. “He was starting to warm up. But now his head is always in it. He clutches it like it’s his diary.”

 

 You narrow your eyes. “Isn’t that helping him?” 

 

 “Not in the way Chrissie would like,” Britney mutters.

 

 “And how -” you begin, but Stacey cuts you off. 

 

 “You need to trust Christina will tell you what you need to know when you need to know it,” she says, curtly. “If you really want to assist, find a way of seeing what’s in that book. Break into his locker or something.”

 

 You narrow your eyes. “Tell me what, though?”

 

 They say nothing.

 

 Stacey sips her drink. Britney studies the whipped cream on her spoon like it’s suddenly fascinating.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: CarmichaelDialogue
text:
You force a smile, nodding your acceptance. "That sounds like a wonderful opportunity for Emily. I'm sure she'll appreciate the experience."

 

 Lydia’s smile broadens subtly, a gleam of approval flickering in her calculating eyes. "Splendid decision. Thompson’s Repairs will provide her with precisely the experience she needs to excel after school. Mr. Thompson will be pleased."

 

 She scribbles something neatly onto a notepad before placing her pen carefully down. "I'll inform Emily immediately. I'm certain she'll make the most of this opportunity. Have a good day, . Phillips. I’ll make sure Emily is aware she is expected at Thompson’s Repairs each Friday afternoon."

 

 You nod, holding back your feelings, and exit the office. You push back the thoughts that come to mind, of what Emily will experience working as a secretary. Hoping that you’ve made the right decision.

 

 Thoughts turn to Emily and how she will react. You might want to talk to her before she goes to school next and finds out for herself.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You clear your throat gently, meeting Lydia's gaze with practiced calm. "I appreciate the offer, but I'd prefer Emily focus on her academic achievements for now."

 

 Lydia’s smile dims noticeably, her eyes narrowing for just a fleeting instant before returning to composed professionalism. "Oh, I see. While academic excellence is admirable, practical experience is also essential for our students here in Charlton. Real-world responsibilities shape character, after all."

 

 “I understand,” you reply. “But I want to give Emily the best opportunity to graduate with grades that reflect her abilities.”

 

 The career advisor gives you a polite smile, but you sense something underneath it.

 

 
 ”I commend you for your commitment to academic resilience,” she says. “In fact, perhaps we can help spur Emily on. Our cheerleaders are granted certain perks for their extra-curricular activities. We can rescind these, however, if we feel the student needs opportunities to prove themselves. I will have a word with Mr. Stitch. Perhaps Emily would benefit from achieving on her own merit.”

 

 She gives you another smile, this one barely hiding the subtext. You can only nod at the trap you’ve walked into.

 

 
 ”I commend you for your commitment to academic resilience,” she says. “In fact, perhaps we can help spur Emily on. I will have a word with Mr. Stitch. Perhaps Emily would benefit in her teachers knowing that she would like more challenging assessments of her academic work.”

 

 She gives you another smile, this one barely hiding the subtext. You can only nod at the trap you’ve walked into.

 
 

 She gives a polite but cool nod. "Good day, . Phillips. I’m sure we’ll meet again."

 

 You nod, holding back your feelings, and exit the office. You push back the thoughts that come to mind, of what Emily will experience after Carmichael talks to Stitch. Hoping that you’ve made the right decision.

 

 **Actions**

title: CaseyDialogue
text:
“You seem like you’re not from around here,” you tell Casey.

 

 He takes a drag from his rollie and chuckles. “What gave it away?”

 

 You glance at the cigarette, causing him to laugh further. You grimace when the laughter inevitably turns to coughing.

 

 “I was born and bred in Hackney,” Casey tells you. “Back before it all turned into fancy flats and coffee shops. Moved here about ten years ago. Wanted a quiet life. Didn’t know how quiet things could get.”

 

 “Why Charlton?” you ask him. 

 

 “I was a boxer,” he replies after he takes a drag. “Almost went pro, didn’t quite make it. Had a nasty blow in the ring and Doctor said I needed a holiday. Ended up breaking down just down the road and spent the week here getting the motor fixed. Liked the quiet life so much that when I got back to the big smoke, it felt like poison every time I took a breath.”

 

 He puts his roll-up in his mouth and inhales. “Irony and such like,” he mutters as smoke drifts out of his mouth. “I know.”

 

 You nod, watching the roll-up burn. “What do you think of it? The town, I mean.” 

 

 Casey grins wryly. “Well I must not mind it too much if I spend a decade here.” After another drag, he continues. “It’s like going back to when I was younger. Some of that’s good. Some of it’s bad. All things being squared, I think it balances out.“

 

 Actions

 <>

 “I’m interested in signing up for classes,” you tell Casey. “What do you have here?”

 

 “Boxing for the blokes, ballet for the girls,” Casey sighs, blowing out smoke through his nostrils. "Flo tried to start up some yoga, but that business with the karate chops put the skids on it.”

 

 “Karate chopping?” you ask.

 

 He sniggers, and coughs from the action. “Yeah, got an old mate of mine to come up from London. Teach some of the kids some self-defense. Only they got carried away and judo chopped John Kaplar’s fence.” He pauses to take a drag from his roll-up, then continues. “Then that Owen Oakswood made a big song and dance of it in his paper. Next thing I know, I’ve got Chelsea Duncan and her women’s lib lot on the blower giving me an earful. So back to boxing.”

 

 You nod, feigning interest. “When do the lessons run?”

 

 “Only time that made sense was weekends,” Casey replies. “I do boxing at lunchtime, then Margaret DeBussy does a ballet class on afternoons. Just stop by and you can sign up. Never get enough to turn anyone away.”

 

 Actions

 <> 

 “I’m thinking of signing up,” you tell Casey. “How much does it cost?”

 

 
 The side of his mouth twitches and he almost chokes on the smoke in his lungs. “You feeling alright, love? You’re already signed up. Got your name on a locker and everything. Don’t need to pay anymore. Feel free to use any of the equipment you like, or come and talk to me if you're thinking of doing one of the classes.”

 

 He takes a drag and offers you a pleasant smile, but says no more. 

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Casey quickly appraises you, but if he’s skeptical it doesn't show. “One time fee gets you access to the lockers and equipment. Classes are a bit extra, but not too much. Not exactly Kings Cross around here. I’ll take what I can get. You interested?”

 

 You shrug. Before you can say anything more, Casey has written out a form and has pushed it across the desk towards you. “Magic. Pop your name on here then and I’ll send you an invoice.”

 

 You pick up a pen and scrawl a signature. Casey takes back the form without looking at it. “Let me know if you want to sign up for a class. Otherwise, I’ll pop a name tag on a locker in the ladies. You can set the locker combo when you first use it. If you need some exercise gear, pop down to Evans. They’ve always got a sale on.”

 You pick up a pen and scrawl a signature. Casey takes back the form without looking at it. “Let me know if you want to sign up for a class. Otherwise, I’ll pop a name tag on a locker in the gents. You can set the locker combo when you first use it. If you need some exercise gear, pop down to Evans. They’ve always got a sale on."

 

 Casey slips the form into a drawer and takes out a laminated card to hand to you. It’s off-white, tarred from the cigarette tar that seeps into the fabric of everything Casey touches. “Here. Your membership card.”
 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Casey quickly appraises you, but if he’s skeptical it doesn't show. “One time fee gets you access to the lockers and equipment. Classes are a bit extra, but not too much. Not exactly Kings Cross around here. I’ll take what I can get. You interested?”

 

 You grimace, unsure of how in this form you could even sign up for a gym membership. Sensing your reluctance, Casey shrugs. “Suit yourself,” he says. “If you change your mind, give us a holler.”

 

 Casey takes another drag from his cigarette and doesn’t say another word. If you want to sign up for the gym, you’ll need to be in a form you at least can pay legitimately for. 

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 You glance at the mats. “You setting up for the boxing class?”

 

 Casey doesn’t look up straight away. He finishes nudging the last mat into place with his boot, then finally meets your eye. “Wasn’t sure anyone’d bother showing,” he says. The roll-up twitches on his lip. “But yeah. I’m running it. You after a go?”

 

 You shrug, noting the cigarette still in the man’s mouth. “I’m considering it.”

 

 He nods, then tilts his head toward a pair of gloves draped over the ropes. “Won’t be bag work though. It’s sparring. Just you and me. I’ll show you how to keep your feet, throw clean. Nothin’ fancy. But you’ll need to hit back.”

 

 He grins, as if taunting you. You glance him over. He’s still got the frame. Heavy shoulders, hands like bricks. But there’s a stiffness in his leg when he shifts his weight. And that cigarette hasn’t moved since you walked in. You can’t help but wonder if this will be a proper sparring match or charity work.

 

 Suddenly, there’s a sharp knock on the window. You look up to see a group of teenage boys pressing against the glass, grinning like hyenas. They all seem focused on Casey. One of them throws his head back, miming a knockout punch while the others cackle.

 

 Casey glares, lifting a gloved hand and jabs it toward the window. “Oi! Off with ya! Go leer at a lamp post!”

 

 The boys retreat, half-laughing, half-lurking. You note though that they don’t leave. Instead, they fade from the window surface, their murky silhouettes still watching the two of you.

 

 “Bloody kids,” Casey says, turning back to you. “Only turn up to perve on the ballet class. Could do with a proper hiding, if you ask me.”

 

 You shrug, noncommittally. Casey sighs and shakes his head. “Well? You want a class, go get changed. I’ll be waiting.” He smirks, but almost coughs on the cigarette as he takes a drag.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 Change for the boxing class - *You'll need to buy workout gear from Evans' to participate*

title: ChristinaDialogue
text:
“I was wondering if you think I’ve done enough?” you ask her. “If I’ve proved I have what it takes.”

 

 
 
 ”You’ve been a busy bee, haven’t you?” Christina says with hushed tones. “I’ve been hearing all around the school of some unfortunate souls finally being put in their place.”

 

 She leans into you, flicking her blonde hair over her shoulder. “Nice work.”

 

 She glances back at the cheerleaders momentarily, before turning her whole body to face you. “I think you’re ready, Emily. Really ready. Tell you what. Come see us at the school gym after school. We’ll have your initiation ready.” 

 

 Her blue eyes sparkle with mischief, but she says nothing more and turns back to the cheerleader practice. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ”Keep at it, Emily,” Christina tells you. “We don’t just let anyone climb the Charlton social ladder, after all.”

 

 She smiles conspiratorially, then turns her attention back to the cheerleaders. It seems you’ll have to do more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 “Hey Christina," you say. "I need a favour."

 
 
 Christina glances back to the other girls practicing, then focuses on you. "Sure Emily. We've got to look after each other, after all. How can I help?"

 
 
 You take a step closer, lowering your voice. “I need you to cause a distraction after school. Enough to make Prichard leave her classroom.”

 

 Christina grins, raising an eyebrow. "My, you're being inventive already, Emily. Good work."

 

 You feel yourself smiling at the compliment. "Thank you."

 

 "Are you sneaking in after she leaves?" Christina eyes you curiously. "Or are you planning on being held back after school?"

 

 "Detention," you admit to her.

 

 She nods. "Sound plan. Just be careful. Prichard's punishments are very forceful. Plus, you're also a cheerleader now, Emily. You have a reputation to uphold. Detention is not a good look for our team."

 

 "I'll be discreet," you assure her.

 

 "Good." Chrissie appears to mull over something before continuing. "I'll keep an eye out for you. If I see you entering the class after school, I'll come by and help."

 

 "Thanks Chrissie," you say.

 

 She gives you a small grin. "What are squad mates for."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 You spend the next hour or so following Christina around the clothing department, as she studiously inspects every shoe, dress and skirt that the department store stocks. Her judgement is absolute. There’s little that meets her standards. 

 

 When she does find something acceptable, more often than not you realise she’s shopping for you. She holds numerous blouses and skirts up against your body, asking for your opinion on whether you like it. “Too daggy?” she asks. “Too skimpy? Too much?” 

 

 As you relax into the role of Christina’s clothes mannequin, you find yourself becoming more at ease with spending time this way. There is something empowering about someone looking out for you, trying to find something that will make you look great. 

 

 “That would look divine on you,” Christina says as she holds up a silk black skirt. “Classy, elegant, but short enough to show off those legs. Jake and the boys would be on their hands and knees at the sight.” 

 

 As you and Christina dart around the store, she also chatters about several rumours floating around about students at Charlton School. "Did you hear this one?" she whispers quietly. "<> Can you believe it?"

 As you and Christina dart around the store, she also chatters about several rumours floating around about students at Charlton School. Most are not news to you. Those that are hold no interest.

 

 Time flies by and you actually feel a twinge of disappointment when Christina tells you she needs to leave. 

 

 “It’s been fun, Em,” she says to you as she says goodbye. “We should do this again sometime.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I’m sorry,” you tell her. “I have to get back home today.”

 

 Christina rolls her eyes, but laughs. “Live a little, Em. You can’t spend your life cooped up inside.”

 

 “I really can’t,” you enforce.

 

 “Some other time then,” she tells you. “I’ll be here for a while if you change your mind.”

 

 Christina returns to browsing the clothing. You decide for the moment to leave her.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 “Sure,” you tell Christina. “Why not.”

 

 She immediately looks at the salon assistant and raises her eyebrow. “Can you fit her in? My father will pay.” 

 

 Over the next hour, your hair is given the full treatment. You relax as dye is smeared through your locks. You spend a lot of time with your head back as the make-over is applied, listening to Christina talk about the importance of grooming and training in equal measure. You focus straight ahead as fake eyelashes are stuck to your own.
 
 
 
 “Time for the big reveal,” Christina says after your hair is blow dried. She stands behind you and turns the chair around herself, facing you towards the mirror.

 

 You stare at your reflection, barely recognising your sister. Your hair is golden blonde, radiant and glistening. But the difference it makes to you is deeper. Instead of a mousy bookish girl, the blonde hair makes you look carefree and bubbly. Whereas previously Emily would have looked at home in a library, the girl in the mirror looks like she should be cheering alongside a football game.
 
 

 The make-up only enhances the stark change. Staring back is a Hollywood starlet. Large, pouty lips. Long and luscious lashes. Flawless skin and thick mascara. 

 

 “See,” you hear Christina’s voice from behind you. “Told you that you had what it took.”

 

 You glance at your reflection again. You have never seen Emily wear this amount of make-up before. It’s almost too much for her. Or at least, casts her in a very different light. 

 

 She helps you out of the chair, still admiring your new look. “Now. Remember what I said, Em.” she tells you. “Prove you belong on the squad. When you have, come see me at practice.”

 

 Without another word, Christina turns and walks out of the salon. You assume that the payment will just be added to her father’s account.

 “So, magic is real?” you ask Christina. She grins.
 
 

 “It’s not so strange, is it?” she replies. “You’ve spent some time here. Surely you must have suspected something was up. The curses certainly haven’t grabbed hold of you.”

 

 “What is it? How can it be real?”

 

 Christina leans forward, smiling patiently. “I’ll tell you what I know. It feels like a power, living inside of you. Only women can use it. But it flows through everyone and everything.” She gestures around to the gym. “Even this room. Although we nullify its effect when we gather here.”

 

 “How do people not know about it?” you ask her.

 

 “People see what they want to see,” she replies, nonchalantly. “Those with the affinity share a solemn vow not to divulge its existence outside of the coven. We’re taking a risk on you.”

 

 “A big risk,” Reagan interjects. 

 

 “Imagine it,” Christina continues, ignoring the interruption. “The power to manipulate people. Sway people’s emotions. Alter their memories. It isn’t something to be treated lightly.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 “So you’re all, what?” you ask. “Witches?” 

 

 Britney sniggers, but quickly stops after Christina throws her a look. “I wouldn’t call us that,” she says, turning back to you. “The cheerleader squad is what we call a coven. 

 

 “We can all cast magic,” she says, casting another look at Britney. “To some degree.”

 

 “But to perform our duties we operate as five. The power of a full coven is significant compared to the lone wanderer. That is one of the reasons we’ve reached out to you.”

 

 Your eyes flick around the room. Stacey. Britney. Reagan. Christina. And now you.

 <>

 <>

 “Can you teach me magic?” you ask.

 You nod, looking around the room. “Did you teach everyone here?” 

 

 “Christina recruited us,” Stacey chimes in. “She taught us everything we know.”

 

 Glancing around, you see a degree of pride on Stacey and Britney’s faces. Only Reagan seems sullen and unwilling to engage with you.

 “You mentioned your duties,” you tell her. “What do you mean?”

 

 Christina smiles and nods, eager to share. “Charlton is a special place. For generations the cheerleaders have been taught the magical arts. It’s passed down from person to person, so order is maintained. You must have noticed how idyllic Charlton is? We work with the teachers to make sure every generation maintains that.”

 

 You nod, understanding more than Christina knows. “What do you do?” 

 

 “We enchant objects within the school. Magic that helps steer the students in the right direction. Course correct deviant behaviour. Ensure they graduate to be the best they can be.”

 

 “Do people not realise?” 

 

 Christina gives you a measured look. “Some. Not many though. Let’s just say it brings out their natural impulses. And smooths down the rough edges.”

 <>

 “You mentioned the teachers,” you say. “So they know?”

 

 Christina nods. “Some. Those that do are our advocates. We work with them to help guide the other students. Most of the teachers are men. Magic evades them. So they ask us to support them. In turn, we are given special privileges. Now, and in the future.”

 

 You frown. “What do you mean?”

 

 “Why, we rule the school,” Christina replies, laughter in her voice. Stacey and Britney titter too. 

 

 “Hall passes. Free periods. Plus, there’s not a cheerleader in memory who hasn’t passed her exams with top grades. And grades mean education. Good jobs. Influence.”

 

 She leans further towards you, lowering her voice. “If you join us, you won’t ever have to worry about passing school.”

 <>
