 Britney and Stacey laugh between them, knowingly. Christina smiles warmly. “It’s a bit dramatic, isn’t it? Probably needs a rebrand. But Charlton is very traditional.”

 

 “There’s objects around the school. Embedded with magic. We just make sure that the spells are working. I can teach you how to do it, if you join us. But they’re just parlour tricks. Simple manipulation of urges and desires. Real power is what we keep to ourselves.”

 

 The cheerleaders share satisfied looks amongst themselves. “Oh my gawd, Em” Britney says to you. “You’re gonna’ love it.”

 

 Christina gives her a look, silently shushing her down, and turns back to you. “As you have demonstrated, they aren’t so bad. Some might say bringing a little order to some of the deviants in Charlton should be praised. Myself being one of them.”

 <>
 

 Actions

 <>

 You glance at Christina, who waits for you to speak. “Hey Chrissie, I was wondering if you had any strange dreams after you started using magic?”

 

 She frowns but looks curious. “Nothing out of the ordinary. Why, has something happened?”

 

 You hesitate as you choose your words carefully. “Just some intense dreams. Almost as if they were real.”

 

 Christina looks at you, studying. “I can’t say I’ve experienced that,” she says, after a moment. “Nor heard of it. Are you sure it wasn’t just an intense dream?”

 

 You shrug, careful not to reveal too much. “Maybe. But I’ve noticed some other things. Things that weren’t right. Or more like, I’ve felt something was off.”

 

 To your surprise, she nods along with you. “Your feelings are a big part of what makes you powerful. You should trust them. Magic is just a projection of our inner willpower exerting itself over reality, after all.”

 

 You briefly consider that the words seem jarring to come from Christina. You wonder where she got them from. But you dismiss it, trying to move the conversation along. “I feel since I’ve been practicing that maybe I’m changing. But I don’t know how.”

 

 Christina gives you a sympathetic smile. “Emily, that’s perfectly understandable. You’re learning your new place in this world. My advice - embrace it. Leave behind who you were. It’s what we do now that matters.”

 

 The cheerleader turns her smile to a grin, satisfied in her tutorage. You can only smile back at her, hiding your disappointment in her advice.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You step forward and run your hand over the selection, considering each piece carefully. Eventually, you pull out an outfit. A top and skirt, something simple but flattering.

 

 “This one works,” you say decisively. “It’s clean, stylish, and actually pretty cute.”

 

 Christina’s brows lift, her lips pressing together as she considers your choice. For a moment, you think she might argue. But then she hums, nodding slightly.

 

 “Well, at least you’ve got some basic instincts, I suppose.” She turns back to Jennifer, eyes sharp. “Still, this is barely passable. Next time, I expect better. Find something suitable for Emily's first trip to the Kaplar's country club.”

 

 Jennifer looks at you, with narrowed eyes. You can see her trying to understand the scenario, but caught in a web where she can say nothing. Instead she nods and silently walks out.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You sigh, stepping closer to the clothes and making a show of flipping through them, unimpressed.

 

 “This is just… bland,” you say, shaking your head. “None of these stand out."

 

 Jennifer's eyes lock on to you. You see the betrayal flash beneath her attempts to remain professional.

 

 Christina’s lips curl into a slow smile.

 

 “Exactly,” she purrs, turning toward Jennifer with a small shake of her head. “Honestly, Jennifer, I thought you’d know better. I suppose working this job dulls one’s sense of fashion over time.”

 

 Jennifer’s jaw tenses, but she nods. “I’ll try again,” she murmurs. You know that tone. You've dealt with it once or twice, even. She's furious.

 

 Christina smirks, turning back to you.

 

 “See, Em? You’re getting it,” she says approvingly. “Knowing what doesn’t work is just as important as knowing what does.”

 

 She waves a dismissive hand. “Jennifer. Try again. Find something suitable for Emily's first trip to the Kaplar's country club. If you don’t get it right this time…” Her voice trails off, but the implication is enough.

 

 Jennifer bristles, but turns around and heads back into the store. As soon as she’s gone, Christina folds her arms, glancing at you with clear amusement.

 

 “I can see us getting along swimmingly,” she says lightly.
 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You exhale slowly, nodding. “Yeah… I guess this is the look for a country club.”

 

 Christina’s smile spreads like honey. “Good,” she says, handing you the dress and motioning toward the cubicle. “Now let’s see it on you.”

 

 Jennifer blinks, momentarily caught off guard. You offer her a smile and take the dress into the changing cubicle, the fabric feeling almost too smooth in your hands. The moment you slide it over your body, the transformation is unmistakable. The dress hugs your waist, flares out in a dramatic sweep of fabric, and moves with an effortless grace that feels… unnatural. You turn slightly, catching your reflection. For a moment, it doesn’t feel like you looking back.

 

 And then Christina yanks the curtain open. Her eyes gleam with satisfaction. “Good,” she declares. “A little too much for my liking, but you make it work, Em.”

 

 "Now," Christina says, turning to Jennifer with a grin. "For the final test. Emily has got a big date coming up with Brendan Glove, one of our star football players. Bring her some options to dress to impress."

 

 "I have?" you ask, nervously.

 

 "Hypothetically," Christina replies. "But I'm sure we can work on that."

 

 Jennifer looks to you with an eyebrow raised. You can only shrug. The frustration is almost drained from her face. Instead, replaced by bafflement. She quickly exits, wordlessly.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You eye the outfit in your hands, the pristine pink fabric, the delicate lace trim. It’s ridiculous. You can’t imagine yourself in this. You won’t.

 

 Your lips press into a thin line before you scoff, tossing the dress carelessly back onto the pile. “I'm not wearing this” you say, loud enough for Jennifer to hear. “What is this? A fancy dress costume for a housewife?”

 
 
 Jennifer’s eyes snap to you, startled. You try to avoid her look. You know what Christina wants to hear. You can do it, but you can't look at her whilst you say it.

 

 “Really? This?” you continue. “This isn't me. What part of me says ‘frilly little doll’? It's awful.”

 

 Christina laughs softly, but it’s the kind of laugh that’s meant for Jennifer’s humiliation, not yours.

 

 Jennifer doesn’t move for a moment. But you see it. The way her fingers tighten, the way her posture goes rigid like she’s forcing herself to hold back. Her eyes burrow into you, simmering with rage.

 

 Christina smirks, flipping idly through the discarded clothes with a single manicured finger. “Honestly, Jennifer, it’s like you’re doing this on purpose.” She sighs, tilting her head. “Or maybe getting old has dulled your taste. It’s sad, really.”

 

 Jennifer’s jaw tenses visibly, but she nods. “I’ll try again,” she mutters, clipped and controlled.

 

 “You will,” Christina agrees, her voice light, almost mocking. “Because I’d hate to have to explain to my father why one of his employees can’t even follow simple instructions. Go find something for Emily. She has a little date coming up with a football player.”

 

 Jennifer stiffens. You watch as she inhales slowly, steadies herself. Then turns on her heel and walks back out into the store without another word.

 

 Christina grins, folding her arms as she looks at you. “Now that,” she says, clearly pleased, “is how you handle the help.”

 

 You try to put Jennifer out of your mind. That face. That anger. "A date?" you quickly remember.

 

 "Just a thought experiment, Em," Christina says. "But you never know. I'm sure there's plenty of charming young men who would like to court you."

 

 “Let’s hope she does better this time.”

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You hesitate, but not for the reason you expect. Your fingers brush over the fabric. It’s soft. Inviting. The thought replays in your mind. You, in this dress, on that date.

 

 A moment later, you nod. “Yeah… I think I can.”

 

 Jennifer looks at you, momentarily stunned. She had been expecting a cruel remark. But instead, you take the dress from Christina’s hands and step into the cubicle, heart pounding just slightly harder than before.

 

 The moment you slip it over your head, it’s like stepping into a new skin.

 

 The fabric clings, accentuating every line of your body. The way it shapes you, the way the mirror frames your figure. Even as Emily, you barely recognize yourself.

 

 Her? You barely recognise her. Right?

 
 
 And yet… you don’t hate it. Your mind drifts again. To that movie date, to the way that football player would look at you. And for the first time, you don’t push the thought away.

 

 Christina pulls the curtain back, eyeing you critically. “Well, well,” she says, lips curving into a smile. “Would you look at that?”

 

 She tilts her head. “You almost look comfortable.”

 

 Jennifer doesn’t say anything, but there’s a flicker of something in her eyes.

 

 Confusion. Worry.

 

 Maybe even disappointment.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You let out a short, incredulous laugh, tossing the dress back onto the bench.

 

 “This is ridiculous,” you say, shaking your head. “Seriously, Jennifer? What, do you think I’m trying to pick up guys at a bar?”

 

 Jennifer’s expression doesn’t change, but the way her jaw tightens tells you enough.

 

 Christina’s grin widens. “Exactly,” she drawls, letting the dress slip from her fingers onto the pile. “It’s inappropriate. Honestly, Jennifer, what’s gotten into you?”

 

 She folds her arms, tilting her head mockingly. “You know, back when I was a junior, I actually looked up to you. Thought you had taste. But this?” She gestures vaguely at the pile of daring outfits. “Seems like someone’s spent too much time on the shop floor. The gutter must be rubbing off on you.”

 

 Jennifer’s nostrils flare, but she doesn’t take the bait. Instead, she inclines her head slightly, her voice clipped. “I’ll find something else.”

 

 "Don't bother," Christina says smoothly. “I'll be letting my dad know how helpful you've been.”

 

 Jennifer doesn’t reply. Just turns sharply and leaves.

 

 Christina smirks, turning back to you. “Perfect, Em!” she murmurs, her voice almost pleased. “That's how to let people know their place. Wear it like an accessory for all to see.”

 

 She brushes a hand lightly over your bare shoulder as she steps past you, voice dropping to something almost conspiratorial.

 

 “And you know what? It looks good on you.”

 

 Actions

 <> 

 “I wanted to ask… is there any kind of magic that lets someone change their appearance?”

 

 “I don’t think you need diet pills,” Christina says, grinning. 

 

 “No,” you reply. “Like changing completely. Changing someone… into someone else.”

 

 She studies you for a moment, expression sharpening slightly. “Magic doesn’t work like that,” she says. “Charlton isn’t a school for witchcraft and wizardry. Magic’s influence is mental. Subtle. It changes how people think. How they feel.”

 

 “So,” you say, cautiously, “you don’t know of anything that changes form?”

 

 Christina shakes her head. “No. If I did, you can bet you'd see at least one of me having fun instead of knocking these girls into shape.”

 

 You’re quiet for a beat, then ask - boldly, “But hypothetically, if it was possible… who would know?”

 

 Christina narrows her eyes. Just slightly. “That’s a strange question.”

 

 You try to cover. “Just… curious.”

 

 “Hm.” She steps slightly closer, still smiling, but with more calculation behind her eyes now.

 

 “Magic is passed down through the squad,” she says. “Controlled. Trusted. We don’t learn spells from dusty books or mysterious strangers. We inherit them. Share them. In time, I’ll teach you what you need to know.”

 

 “And what about when you don’t know?” you ask.

 

 Christina gives you a knowing smile. “Then I get help. From a friend.”

 

 You tilt your head. “Who?”

 

 She chuckles. “You’ll find out. One day.”

 

 You’re not sure if that’s a promise… or a warning.

 

 “But take it from me,” she adds, stepping back and motioning toward the rest of the squad. “Case in point - magic in Charlton isn’t flashy. It doesn’t shoot sparks or transform people into frogs.”

 

 She meets your eyes. “It changes feelings. And feelings… change everything.”

 

 Her eyes glint with energy. Sensing something primal underneath, you decide not to push her further.

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 You lift your chin and let your voice carry just enough edge. “I get by perfectly well on my own, Christina.”

 

 An eyebrow shoots up. “You think you’re getting by?”

 

 A grin this time forms on your face. “I think I do okay. I don’t need Daddy’s money to buy a dress.”

 

 Her carefully poised smile falters, surprise flickering in her icy eyes before she smooths it back into place. “Well, I’ll be damned,” she murmurs, stepping closer so her words drop between you. “I thought Jennifer destroyed your backbone.”

 

 She leans in towards you, a smile forming again. “Careful though, Annie. I’m not as soft as her. And unlike her, I make sure I do things properly.”

 

 The teenager looks at you with presence and power beyond her age. You meet her look, but say nothing. When she breaks away you take the opportunity to walk off.
 
 <>
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You lift your chin, but your voice wavers. “I… I manage,” you stammer, forcing a tight smile.

 

 Christina’s lips curl into a lightly mocking laugh. “Manage?” she repeats, arching an eyebrow. “Sweetheart, relying on that repair-shop wage to pull off any look must be quite the challenge.” Her eyes appraise you again. “Even something as trashy as that.”

 

 She flicks a finger at a nearby rack. “Enjoy your… browsing.”

 

 With that, she turns on a heel and melts back into the aisle, leaving you standing alone among the dresses.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “I’ve noticed some strange behaviour from Britney, Reagan and Stacey recently," you begin. "They've been spending a lot of time with Terrence.”

 

 She turns to you and her lips curve into a slow, dark smile. “So you noticed,” she murmurs, voice smooth. She reaches out, brushing a stray hair from your face. “That took some sharp eyes.”

 

 You meet her gaze. “What are you doing to him?”

 

 She doesn’t flinch. Instead, the smile curves deeper.

 

 “We’re helping,” she says. “Terrence was drifting. Always on the edges. Quiet, unsure. But he’s clever. Just needed structure.”

 

 Her voice lowers, the weight of something practiced in it.

 

 “He’s doing better.” She tilts her head, just enough for the light to catch in her eyes. “He’s becoming who he should have been.”

 

 “How are you doing that?” you say. “I can help.”

 

 Christina looks at you, assessing. “All in good time, Emily,” she replies. “Soon, I will need your help. For now, if you really want to help, there is something. I want to see what he keeps hidden in his biology book.”

 

 You frown. “What?”

 

 “Something is interfering,” she whispers, smile fading. “I want to know what.”

 

 “You think it’s magic?” you murmur, looking around. 

 

 “I think people don’t suddenly get better at biology without help. I want to know who. And why. Try finding a way to open his locker at lunch. I’m sure you can figure out a way to do that.”

 

 She steps back, brushing imaginary dust from her skirt. That perfect smile returns. “You have good instincts, Emily. Use them.” Then, softer, with just a trace of warning. “Don’t make me wait.”

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 "I know what you're planning on doing to Terrence," you tell Christina flatly.

 

 For a second, you see the surprise threaten to spread across her face. But a moment later it's gone. Instead, she just smiles. "Pray tell, dear Emily. What do you think you know?"

 

 "I know you're going to try to change him," you tell her. "Using a ritual. In the gym."

 

 "Someone has a nosy little narc," she says, playfully mocking. "What do you think about it?"

 

 "I want to help," you say. Wondering how much of those words are the truth.

 

 Christina eyes you carefully, then nods. "Alright. Come by the gym. Wait for us in the evening. I will explain everything then. But just remember, Em. This is a big step for you. You don't have to do this, if you don't feel ready."

 

 She offers you a friendly smile. It's practiced and polished, but for Christina, it almost seems genuine.

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 “Christina,” you say quietly. “Do you know how I could get a hall pass?”

 

 
 She turns her head toward you with a sly smile. “Oh? And why exactly do you need to be sneaking out of lessons? Or do I want to know the answer to that question?”

 

 You hesitate. “I… want to check the boys’ classes. I want to make sure the curses are still active.”

 

 Christina raises a brow, her interest piqued. “Smart thinking, Em” she purrs. “I’m quite sure I would have noticed if anything was amiss, but a little check-up wouldn’t hurt. I knew you belonged on the squad.”

 

 She steps away and saunters over to her bag by the boombox. Unzipping a side pocket of her bag, she pulls out a single hall pass and returns to you, holding it delicately between two fingers.

 

 “Here,” she says. “Fill in your details and hand this to Harrow or Prichard. They won’t question it. Tell them you’ve got squad business and flash that smile of yours.”

 

 You reach for it, but she doesn’t let go immediately.

 

 “But Em,” she says, her voice lowering. “Just look. Do not go inside. Trust me, those lessons aren’t somewhere respectable girls like us want to end up.”

 

 She lets go of the pass, the smile never leaving her lips.

 

 “Report back if anything is out of place. And don’t do anything reckless. Those lessons get… rowdy.”

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 She turns her head towards you with a forced smile. "Oh? And what exactly makes you feel that you deserve such privileges yet, Emily?"

 

 When you part your lips and take a shallow breath, Christina corrects herself, stifling a giggle that sounds practiced. "I'm just playing with you, Em. I understand all too well the desire to make your own way in the world. Bend the rules a little, so to speak."

 

 Chrissie glances back to check on the progress of the squad, before turning to survey you with her cold blue eyes. "As far as I know, there's only two ways of getting a hall pass. Sign up for the cheerleaders, or improve your grades enough for the headmaster to notice."

 

 
 
 "I'm afraid I'm still not convinced you have what it takes to be a cheerleader," she adds, with a slight wince that seems mechanical. "But try speaking to Mr. Stitch if you can. I'm sure there are less athletically intensive routes to obtaining one."

 

 A shriek from the squad captures Christina's attention and she turns her attention away from you, instantly forgetting the conversation in-flow.

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 "You're making good progress in joining our team, Em," she adds, giving you a smile that borders on genuine. "Keep it up, and I'll be able to give you a pass after your initiation."

 

 A shriek from the squad captures Christina's attention and she turns her attention away from you, instantly forgetting the conversation in-flow.

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 "You should try out for the team," she adds. "Like I said, I think you've got what it takes."

 

 Britney howls from the pitch, taking Christina's eyes away from you. "There was a bug!" you hear Britney cry back at Chrissie, as if to answer her unspoken question.

 
 
 Actions

 <> 

 
 

 “I had some trouble with a spell,” you begin. “I tried casting it on the school janitor, but it didn’t work.”

 

 Christina shoots you a wary look, accompanied only by a slight grin. “I’m not surprised, Em. The teachers don’t like us using magic on them without their permission. Did anyone see?”

 

 Quickly, you shake your head. “It was in the basement. No one saw.”

 

 She lets out a small titter, her grin widening. “Probably for the best. The headmaster has certain ways of limiting our abilities. Especially on faculty members. What on earth made you want to try magic on that repulsive janitor?”

 

 “I was trying to get a key from him,” you tell her truthfully. “To keep an eye on the wards.”

 

 Christina offers you a reassuring smile, tittering again. “I commend your enthusiasm, Em. But really. You should find other ways to get a look at them. With our cheerleader privileges, surely it can’t be that hard?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: CliveDialogue
text:
“You went to Charlton Upper School, didn’t you?” you ask him. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “It was pretty swell, as school goes,” he says. “Used to play a bit of rugby. Still can throw a ball with the best of them.” He flashes you a smile.

 

 “Did you ever notice anything strange going on?” you try, pressing him.

 

 “No more than anywhere else. Bit of bullying, bit of favouritism. Some social darwinism, if you get my meaning. I bet you would have ranked top of the food chain when you were at school, that right darlin'?"

 

 His disarming smile diminishes your eye rolling. "Did you notice anything odd?" you press on. "About the lessons?”

 

 “Yeah. Lots of equations. Couldn’t understand any of them. Never used one since. I'm more of a do'er and a thinker than a fancy academic. Algebra never impressed a pretty lady.” His eyes sparkle as he looks at you.
 
 

 Clive scoops up some of the tools and puts them back in the kit. “As much as I like spending time talking to beautiful girls, I got a job to get to. Tell you what, though. Come by McTafey’s in the evening and I'll buy you a drink. Then I'll have all the time in the world for you."

 

 Clive gives you yet another smile and returns to sorting through his equipment, leaving you watching him.
 
 
 “You went to Charlton Upper School, didn’t you?” you ask him. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “It was pretty swell, as school goes,” he says. “Used to play a bit of rugby. Still can throw a ball with the best of them.” He flashes you a smile.

 

 “Did you ever notice anything strange going on?” you try, pressing him.

 

 “No more than anywhere else. Bit of bullying, bit of favouritism. Some social darwinism, if you get my meaning. I bet you would have ranked top of the food chain when you were at school, that right darlin'?"

 

 His disarming smile diminishes your eye rolling. "Why’s that?" he continues, moving on. "Your sister having a hard time there?”

 

 You nod, just a little. “A little,” you tell him. “Did you notice anything odd? About the lessons?”

 

 “Yeah. Lots of equations. Couldn’t understand any of them. Never used one since. I'm more of a do'er and a thinker than a fancy academic. Algebra never impressed a pretty lady.” His eyes sparkle as he looks at you.
 
 

 Clive scoops up some of the tools and puts them back in the kit. “As much as I like spending time talking to beautiful girls, I got a job to get to. Tell you what, though. Come by McTafey’s in the evening and I'll buy you a drink. Then I'll have all the time in the world for you."

 

 Clive gives you yet another smile and returns to sorting through his equipment, leaving you watching him.

 
 “You went to Charlton Upper School, didn’t you?” you ask him. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “It was pretty swell, as school goes,” he says. “Used to play a bit of rugby in my teens. Coach always did alright by me. Some weren’t so lucky.”

 

 “Did you ever notice anything strange going on?” you try, pressing him.

 

 He frowns. “No more than anywhere else. Bit of bullying, bit of favouritism. Some social darwinism, if you get my meaning. Why’s that, Phillips? Your sister having a hard time there?”

 

 You give him a noncommittal shrug. “Just making sure she’s alright,” you tell him. “Did you notice anything odd? About the lessons?”

 

 “Yeah. Lots of equations. Couldn’t understand any of them. Never used one since.”
 
 

 Clive scoops up some of the tools and puts them back in the kit. “As much as I’d like to tell you about the good old days of ten years ago, I got a job to get to. But swing by McTafey’s in the evening and we can grab a beer. Sounds like you’ve got something on your mind."

 

 Clive returns to sorting through his equipment, paying no more attention to you.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 “I’d like to ask you about Charlton School,” you tell him. “You went there, right?”

 

 He nods, giving you a smile. “A while back. Graduated a fair few years before you were a freshman, I'd wager. Or are you city girls just naturally youthful?”

 

 You smile politely at his compliment, but push forward. “It sounds different to where I went to school.”

 

 Clive nods his head, as he takes a sip of his drink. “I bet. Pretty traditional. Boys will be boys. Girls are girls. If you don’t agree with that, it’s a hard time there.”

 

 Rhiannon walks past, hearing the conversation. She smirks. “I thought you had a hard time because you skipped most lessons?”

 

 Clive grins at her, deflecting. “I still did okay. Not the top of the class, but I guess I didn’t make Stitch’s cut. Only those who toed his line got up to those giddy heights.“

 

 When Rhiannon moves on, Clive turns back to you. You give him a look. “Do you believe in all that traditional stuff?”

 

 He shrugs and smiles at you. “All manner of people in the world that believe in things. I believe that people should be a little less precious about what they believe in. Go with the flow. See where the world takes you.” 
 
 
 “I’d like to ask you more about Charlton School,” you tell him. “My sister is struggling to settle in.”

 

 “The School’s polarising, in every way,” he tells you. “Boys against girls, popular against nerds. Kill or be killed too. My advice? Don’t rattle the teachers and pick a side. She’ll need friends to get through the year. But what’s she struggling with?” 

 

 “The lessons are very traditional,” you say quietly. “More conservative. Different from her last school.”

 

 Clive nods, thinking. “Yeah. Bet it’s been a while that city schools said men should be the breadwinners and women stay at home. Charlton’s old like that. If you didn’t toe Stitch’s party line, you’re in some trouble. Had a few close calls with him, myself.”

 

 Rhiannon walks past, hearing the conversation. She smirks. “I thought you got in trouble because you couldn’t pass geography lessons?”

 

 Clive grins at her, deflecting. “Lived knowledge doesn’t come from books, sweetheart. What I know about I couldn’t learn at school. And I didn’t get fancy lessons from Stitch. Doesn’t matter how smart you are if you don’t have those. Magically the top of the table is out of bounds for you.“

 

 When Rhiannon moves on, Clive turns back to you. You give him a look. “Do you think what they teach is right?”

 

 He shrugs and takes a swig of his beer. “Don’t matter what I believe. I’m just a sparky. Only time I go to school these days is to fix the generator. Not everyone agrees with what’s taught at Charlton, though. I’d tell your sister to find like minded folk. With any luck, they can help each other out.”
 
 
 “I’d like to ask you about Charlton School,” you tell him. “You went there, right?”

 

 He nods, giving you a smile. “A few years before you, I’d wager. You must have only just graduated. Or you just look naturally pretty.”

 

 You smile politely at his compliment, but push forward. “I don’t think it’s changed much.”

 

 Clive shakes his head, as he takes a sip of his drink. “Pretty traditional. Boys will be boys. Girls are girls. If you don’t agree with that, it’s a hard time there.”

 

 Rhiannon walks past, hearing the conversation. She smirks. “I thought you had a hard time because you skipped most lessons?”

 

 Clive grins at her, deflecting. “I still did okay. Not the top of the class, but I guess I didn’t make Stitch’s cut. Only those who toed his line got up to those giddy heights.“

 

 When Rhiannon moves on, Clive turns back to you. You give him a look. “Do you believe in all that traditional stuff?”

 

 He shrugs and smiles at you. “All manner of people in the world that believe in things. I believe that people should be a little less precious about what they believe in. Go with the flow. See where the world takes you.” 
 
 
 <>
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 ”How are you, Clive?” you ask him. 

 

 “Doing just dandy, honey,” he says to you, taking a swig of his beer. “Got a beer in my hand, a paycheck in my pocket and I’m at a bar talking to a gorgeous girl. Can’t ask for more.”

 

 You can’t help but smile. Despite his lines sounding rehearsed, his disarming grin and casual honesty takes the embarrassment out of it. *In fact*, you think, as you feel your lips creep up. *It’s almost endearing.*

 

 “Did you grow up in Charlton?”, you ask him, leaning a little closer toward him.

 

 He nods. “Sure did. Born and raised here. Went to school, got a gig as an apprentice, worked my way into a trade. Just need the girl to complete the set. You know of anyone hiding away in the office that I've looked over?”

 

 He flashes you another smile and takes a swig from his bottle.

 

 “Did you ever want to do something else?”, you ask. “Go elsewhere?”

 

 He shrugs. “Not yet. Love to travel Europe in a van, but can wait for that. An honest day’s work, a cold beer and someone to warm the bed is still the dream.”

 

 “Anyone warming the bed right now?” you can’t help but ask.

 

 He grins back at you. “Position is vacant.”
 
 
 ”How are you, Clive?” you begin ever-so casually. “What’s happening with you?”

 

 He shrugs his shoulders. “Just living. Worse places to be than here.”

 

 You’re not sure that’s true, but you don’t challenge him. “Did you grow up in Charlton?”

 

 He nods. “Sure did. Born and raised here. Went to school, started at Thompsons’, worked my way out of apprenticeship and into a trade. Not a bad life.”

 

 “Did you ever want to do something else?” 

 

 He grins. “Ambition comes in different shapes. For me, it’s all about freedom. Work when I work. Eat when I eat. Drink when I do. Sure, seeing the world has its appeal. But for me, nothing beats a cold beer after a hard day’s work.”

 
 ”How are you, Clive?” you ask him. 

 

 “Doing just dandy, honey,” he says to you, taking a swig of his beer. “Got a beer in my hand, a paycheck in my pocket and I’m at a bar talking to a gorgeous girl. Can’t ask for more.”

 

 You can’t help but smile. Despite his lines sounding rehearsed, his disarming grin and casual honesty takes the embarrassment out of it. *In fact*, you think, as you feel your lips creep up. *It’s almost endearing.*

 Then, only a minute or two after beginning, Dan arches his head back and clamps his hands around your head, pushing you forward into his pubic hair. And you feel the jets of cum hit the back of your throat.

 

 Your body convulses. It takes all your efforts not to retch. But, still forced to stare up and meet his eyes, you gulp. Feeling the thick slimy juice crawl down inside your body.

 

 A moment of silence. Dan’s grip eases. He smiles. Pulls his prick out of your mouth. And you close your lips around it, wiping it clean of semen. You lick your lips, swallow again, then - without thinking - smile up at him.

 

 Dan straightens, adjusting his jacket like nothing happened. “Told you it’d be quick,” he says with a wink. “We should do it proper sometime. Maybe after hours.”

 

 He’s out the door before you can say anything.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You stay behind for a second, staring at the sink. The mirror. Your reflection stares back.

 

 Same face. Same job. But something feels... shifted. Like you’ve dropped something important, and you can’t quite figure out what. You splash water on your face. Dry it quickly. Then straighten your skirt and walk back out.

 

 Reception is quiet. For now. The phones aren’t ringing. The inbox isn’t screaming. You still have time. Time to catch up. Time to look productive. You sit down. Start typing.

 

 You’re good at this. Efficient. Focused.

 

 You don’t feel proud. Or ashamed. Not yet.

 

 Just… off. Like something’s not quite where it used to be.

 

 But the work gets done.

 

 And that, at least, feels normal.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 Before you can stop yourself, your voice lifts into a bright, sugary tone.

 

 “Oh, Dan… I bet you’d fix the whole system yourself if they let you.”

 

 You tilt your head just slightly, fingers brushing the edge of the desk. Your smile lands somewhere between helpless and adoring.

 

 Dan straightens, practically preening. “Yeah, well. Someone’s gotta keep this place running. I swear, half the time I feel like I’m the only adult in the building.”

 

 You giggle and hate the sound of it the second it leaves your mouth.

 

 “I just think it’s amazing, how you keep things together," you continue, almost listening to the words coming out like they were new to you. "Maybe Thompson needs to be reminded who his real MVP is?”

 

 He smirks. “You know what? Maybe he does.”

 

 “And remind him that even star players need their support staff,” you add sweetly. “Like .”

 

 Dan mulls this over, then flashes you a grin. "Phillips?" he says. "You reckon they'd come back?"

 

 You nod. "I think it would help."

 

 He considers you, then leans in, his eyes wandering over your body. "It would give me more time to spend on... other things."

 

 Without a moment's hesitation, you smile coyly. "I'd be ever-so grateful."

 
 
 His teeth flash at you, as he gently pats your hand with his. “If it means so much to you, I’ll drop something into Thompson's ear," he whispers. "You'd owe me, but I'm sure you can think of something you can do to make it up to me."

 

 You feel your face smile back at him. He massages your fingers with his, then stands and strolls off, entirely too pleased with himself.
 

 You stay seated, the smile slowly fading from your face. It worked. He bought it.

 

 But the tone and body language came out so easily. Too easily.

 

 *And didn't you enjoy his touch?*
 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You force yourself to smile. And not the polite receptionist smile. This is something warmer and sweet.

 

 “I don’t know how you do it, Dan. Honestly. Half this place would fall apart without you.”

 

 He raises an eyebrow, pausing mid-rant. “Yeah? You noticing, Annie?”

 

 You nod, eyes holding his. “It’s hard not to.”

 

 That does it. He straightens, smoothing down his shirt like he’s on a date.

 

 “Well,” he says, flashing a grin, “someone’s gotta take control when the rest of them are chasing their tails.”

 

 You let out a laugh, just shy of a giggle. You hate how real it sounds. But you continue. “You should get some support, though. You're so busy, I hardly ever see you."

 

 His eyes wander over your clothes. "I'd always make time for you, Annie. Even if it's just a quickie."

 

 Burying the feeling of sickness, you force a smile. "Maybe if came back, you’d have more time for… the important things.”

 

 He tilts his head, mock-thoughtful. “You think they'd come back?”

 

 “I think,” you say carefully, “if someone with your… influence had a word, it might help.”

 

 Dan smiles, all teeth. “Alright. I'll say something."

 
 
 He stands and steps back with a wink. “Not just a pretty face after all, huh?" His eyes glance down to your legs. "Amongst other things."
 
 

 He walks off, smug and satisfied. You exhale, your posture relaxing the moment he’s gone. You played the part and it worked. But nevertheless you feel something oily clinging to your skin.

 

 If you’re going to flirt to survive… how many more times will you need to?

 

 And is it really just playing a part anymore?

 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You try a smile. Not too much. Just enough.

 

 “Dan,” you say, tone lighter than you feel. “You always seem to keep things together around here. Honestly, I don’t know how you do it.”

 

 He stops, narrows his eyes. “Annie,” he says slowly, “are you trying to butter me up?”

 

 You blink. “Just saying what everyone’s thinking.”

 

 He tilts his head, unimpressed. “Right.”

 

 A pause. Then he sighs, and the moment crumples in your hands. “You're gonna have to give me a bit more than that, love. Words might work for customers, but I expect to get a little more action."

 

 His eyes linger on your breasts, then he looks back up to you. “Anyway,” he says, stepping back, “I’ve got a system to unbreak and a manager to report to.”

 

 He flashes a grin. “Better luck next time, sweetheart.”

 

 And then he’s gone, leaving you at the desk, the warmth from shame on your face.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You straighten in the chair, spine tall. “Dan,” you say, voice firm. “You’re right. The system’s a mess. But this isn’t just about Theodore.”

 

 That catches him. He stops pacing. You press on.

 

 “You said it yourself, knew how to keep everything on track. You think I don’t miss that? You think the customers don’t?”

 

 Dan narrows his eyes, arms folding. He’s listening now.

 

 “Then do something about it,” you continue. “Thompson listens to you. You walk into his office and say Phillips should come back. That carries weight.”

 

 Dan looks at you, then grins. "Girl's got some teeth. I bet you could put them to good use."

 

 “I’m serious,” you shoot back, refusing to play along. "Thompson needs results. And you need people around you who know what they’re doing.”

 

 You meet his gaze, unblinking. “I’m not asking for a favour. I’m asking you to fix something that’s broken. You're good at that, right?"

 

 Dan pauses, jaw working slightly. Then he nods. “Alright. Sheesh. If it means so much to you, I’ll say something. Can’t promise anything, but I’ll put it on his radar.”

 

 He stands and steps back, looking at you differently now. “Not bad, Annie. Maybe there’s more to you than... the obvious.”

 

 He walks off, already muttering about pipeline delays. You exhale slowly, the adrenaline fading. It worked.

 

 *And you didn't have to lose yourself to survive here, after all.*
 
 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You square your shoulders, trying to match Dan’s energy. “Look,” you say, keeping your voice steady, “if you really think was valuable, then maybe tell Thompson. You said it yourself. They held this place together.”

 

 Dan raises an eyebrow, unimpressed. “Annie,” he says, dryly. “You trying to run the company now?”

 

 You shake your head. “No. I’m just saying --”

 

 He cuts you off. “You’re just saying something that isn’t your business.”

 

 He steps in slightly, tone softening but not kindly. “Look, I know you like playing boss when you’re behind that desk, but maybe leave the strategy talk to the grown-ups.”

 

 You freeze, lips parting but with nothing to follow. Dan sighs and turns, already heading toward the office. “I’ll deal with it myself,” he mutters. “The last thing I need is advice from someone who files highlighters alphabetically.”

 

 The door swings shut behind him. You stay seated, staring at your screen, cheeks burning. You tried. You really did.

 

 But here? That doesn’t always count for much.

 

 *Not when you look like Annie.*

 <>

 <> 
 
 You offer a small shrug. Nothing more.

 You manage a faint smile, but say nothing. He chuckles, as if amused by his own generosity.

 

 “See, this is what I like about you, Annie. You don’t get in the way. Just smile, answer the phones, and let the grown-ups fix the mess.”

 Dan tilts his head, clearly enjoying this. “You sticking up for Phillips now?”

 He grins at that. “Stuffy old man? Careful Annie, you wouldn't want to get into trouble."

 

 "Oh, you wouldn't tell on me," you say coyly. "I'm sure we could keep this between us."

 

 He winks. “But I’ll remember you owe me one, sweetheart.”

 

 You nod, still smiling, and watch as he strolls off with his usual swagger.

 And part of you wonders what Dan will expect for keeping this between you and him.

 

 Don't you mean Annie?

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You pause, then let out a soft laugh. Not too much. Just enough.

 Dan grins, basking in it. “Relaxing, huh? That your medical advice, Annie?”

 

 “I just think you work too hard,” you say sweetly. “You don’t need to be sorting out other people’s problems. Especially not when you’ve got people like me to help keep things running smooth.”

 

 He tilts his head, openly appreciative. “Well damn. If I knew I’d get this kind of service, I’d have been complaining more often.”

 Dan chuckles low in his throat. "I was thinking more nurse than therapist. Tight little uniform, clipboard, checking me over… yeah, I think you’d make recovery worth it."

 

 You hold your smile, feeling sick inside your stomach.

 

 He laughs again. "Alright, Annie. I’ll keep it quiet. And maybe I’ll keep Phillips out of any chats with Thompson too… for now.”

 

 He shoots you a wink and strolls out of the building, self-satisfied and humming to himself.

 

 You stay frozen a moment longer, then sink slowly back into your chair. The feeling inside of you refusing to go away. Dan won't be talking to Thompson this lunchtime, but your mind races back to the words you said to keep him away.

 

 And you chose those words, too.

 You hesitate. Then, unsure why, you lean forward slightly, letting your hair fall just a bit to the side.

 Dan glances at you. One brow lifts, but he doesn’t grin. “Thompson does thank me. Every Friday. It's called a paycheck.”

 Dan turns fully, one eyebrow raised. You press on.

 There’s a pause. Dan narrows his eyes, weighing your words. "You think I can't sort things out without help?"

title: DeBussyDialogue
text:
“Mrs. DeBussy,” you begin, measured and respectful. “I need access to Terrence Handle’s locker.”

 

 She turns to you, eyes blinking quickly in confusion and then sharpening with interest. “Emily, darling. That’s a rather... unusual request, don’t you think?”

 

 You keep your expression level. “I have reason to believe he may be in possession of something inappropriate. Something that contradicts the standards we hold here at Charlton.”

 

 Her smile tightens into that familiar, thin line. “You’re suggesting… contraband?”

 

 You nod. “Yes. Something in his biology notebook. I think it could be worth investigating. I thought it best to come to you before it became more… public.”

 

 DeBussy tuts softly, as if the very notion has already inconvenienced her. “Normally, I’d have to speak to Headmaster Stitch. Locker searches are not typically within my remit.” Her voice rises slightly, just enough for the rest of the club to overhear.

 

 You lean in, tone hushed. “This is sensitive. And time-sensitive. If there’s something in that book, I need to see it before he hides it or destroys it. I wouldn’t ask if I didn’t think it was important.”

 

 She considers you for a long moment, then sighs in that dramatic, theatrical way she reserves for self-congratulation. “Very well. You’ve been a tremendous help to the club. And I suppose, as President, a certain... discretion must be afforded.”

 

 From beneath her desk drawer, she retrieves a small brass key, dangling it in front of you for a beat too long.

 

 “Straight there and back. And I expect a full report on what you find.” Her smile returns to its usual sugary position, still soured at the edges. “It’s such a delight when our brightest girls take initiative.”

 

 You take the key, pocketing it with a nod. “You’ll have your report.”

 

 “See that I do, dear,” she says, already scribbling in her notebook again.

 

 Actions

 <>

 
 “Can you tell me a little bit about the lessons you teach here?” you ask DeBussy.

 

 At the words her face lights up, eyes bright behind her glasses. “Oh, I’m so glad you asked,” she says, holding her clipboard a little closer to her chest.

 

 She steps forward with a kind of deliberate elegance, her voice lowered to a confidential tone. “Ballet is one of the finest tools a young woman can possess. It teaches posture, discipline, control. But more than that, it teaches presence. The ability to command attention without needing to raise one’s voice.”

 

 She pauses to let the words settle, smile unwavering. “Of course, it requires commitment. You have to be willing to be seen. If you’re hiding at the edges, or pretending not to notice the way the world watches. Well, you’ll never truly benefit.”

 

 Your eyes narrow, as you struggle to comprehend. “Are you saying that you teach women how to be watched?”

 

 
 She turns her attention fully to you now, her smile softening. “Come now, dear. We all have sharp eyes. We are watched, whether we like it or not. That is the natural way of things. The trick is, how to convey what you want through it. That is what I teach.”

 

 DeBussy eyes you carefully, reasserting her smile. “I do think you’d take well to it,” she says. “You’ve a thoughtful way of carrying yourself. That can be shaped. Refined.”

 

 She leans in, lowering her voice and whispering conspiratorially. “There’s strength in grace, you know. Ballet teaches you to hold space. To own it. To shape the way others look at you. And to enjoy being looked at.”

 

 She winks, then lets out a gentle laugh. “And in Charlton, that’s a rather valuable skill.”

 
 DeBussy’s tone shifts slightly, still pleasant but now marked by irritation. “I’m always pleased when a gentleman takes an interest. Though I’m not surprised that the subtleties of what's taught here are lost on you.”

 

 She takes a deep breath and reinforces her smile. “Boxing, football, cricket. All excellent for a young man’s frame. You’ll need that strength, after all. But for a lady?” She shakes her head with a smile. “No. Ballet is better. It cultivates poise, balance, grace. It is ideal for women who keep one eye always on their waistline. Which is the vast majority of us, I must say.”

 

 “You see,” she continues. “Girls are judged not by their strength, but by how well they move through a room. Whether they draw the right kind of attention. That is a natural fact.”

 

 Her voice lowers, just slightly. “Being watched is part of growing up. Best to learn how to enjoy it. With grace, of course.”

 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You take a breath. “Alright. I’d like to join the lesson.”

 

 
 DeBussy’s smile widens with unmistakable satisfaction. “I’m so pleased to hear that, my dear. Very wise. I take it you're a member here?”

 

 
 
 You nod. “Yes.”

 

 DeBussy gleams with joy. "Lovely! And you've brought suitable clothes with you?”
 
 

 
 
 You nod again. She lets out a small giggle. "I'm sure you look wonderful in them, dear. Now. Spit spot. Off to the locker room. The other young ladies will be here shortly. I’ll be issuing ballet shoes if you need them once everyone’s present.”

 

 Her tone is cheerful, efficient. As she returns to jotting notes on her clipboard, it becomes clear that conversation is over.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You give her a look. “Don’t you have anything spare?”

 

 She winces, trying to retain her smile. "I'm afraid I don't," she tells you. "But I can recommend the selection in Evans. There's a beautiful pink outfit that would look super on you."

 

 She looks down at her clipboard briefly. "Come back when you've brought your clothes, dear. I'm here every weekend.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You shake your head. “Do I have to be?”

 

 DeBussy presses her lips together, but nods. "I'm afraid so, but don't get disheartened, dear. Just have a chat with Mr. Holloway. He'll sign you up in a jiffy."

 

 She offers you a wide smile, nodding towards Casey.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 DeBussy’s smile widens with unmistakable satisfaction. “I’m so pleased to hear that, my dear. Very wise.”

 

 She gestures lightly with her clipboard. “Spit spot. Off to the locker room. The other young ladies will be here shortly. I’ll be issuing ballet shoes if you need them once everyone’s present.”

 

 Her tone is cheerful, efficient. As she returns to jotting notes on her clipboard, it becomes clear that the conversation is over. You’re expected to go get changed.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 DeBussy’s smile widens with unmistakable satisfaction. “I’m so pleased to hear that, my dear. Very wise. I take it you're a member here?”

 

 You aren’t sure the answer to that, so you instead shrug. “Do I have to be?” 

 

 DeBussy presses her lips together, but nods. "I'm afraid so, but don't get disheartened, dear. Just have a chat with Mr. Holloway. He'll sign you up in a jiffy."

 

 She offers you a wide smile, nodding towards Casey. You grimace, unsure of how in this form you could even sign up for a gym membership. If you want to sign up for the gym, you’ll need to be in a form you at least can pay legitimately for. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

Go change in the locker room
Say goodbye to DeBussy and leave her

title: DennisDialogue
text:
“Dennis,” you begin. “I want to apologise. I haven’t been nice to you.”

 

 “What do you want, Emily?” he says, not looking up at you.

 

 “I just wanted to say that I think I was mean to you because I actually like you,” you continue. “I think I got carried away.”

 

 He looks up at you, then looks back to what he’s doing. “You are making fun of me.”

 

 You realise you’re going to have to do more than speak to him. You step towards him, cautiously stroking his arm. “No, I mean it. I like intelligent guys.”

 

 His eyes flick between your face and your hand on his arm. You catch him even looking at your breasts. He gulps. “I don’t believe you.”

 

 You look at him, feeling his conflict. You know you’re going to have to give a final push to get him over the line. 

 

 Grasping his hand gently, you move it around your waist and against your skirt. “Would I do this if I wasn’t serious?” 

 

 You jump a little as you feel his hands clasp your bum, giving it a gentle pinch. His hand darts back and he refuses to meet your eyes with his, but you see a little smile on his face as he returns to what he was doing.

 

 The faint sting of his pinch lingers below your skirt. You know you have won him back over, but more pressing is that the sensation of that sting has brought a smile to your own face.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You clear your throat, glancing nervously at Dennis. "Uh, hey, Dennis," you start, your voice a little too high-pitched. "You’re, um... good with all this AV stuff. It’s... impressive."

 

 Dennis doesn’t look up, his attention fixed on the camera. "Thanks," he says flatly. "What do you need? Is something broken?"

 

 "No, no, nothing’s broken," you say quickly, shifting awkwardly from foot to foot. "I just thought, you know... maybe we could, uh... talk? Or something."

 

 Dennis glances at you briefly, frowning. "Talk? About what? You need help setting up a projector or something?"

 

 You force a laugh, your cheeks burning. "No, I mean... I think it’s really cool how, uh, knowledgeable you are. About... cables. And stuff."

 

 He pauses, his brow furrowing in confusion.

 

 You nod, fumbling for words. "Yeah, well, I guess I just... think you’re, you know... smart. And, um... interesting."

 

 Dennis blinks at you, then shrugs. "Cool. Thanks." He turns back to what he was doing. "Anyway, I’m kinda busy, so if you need something specific, just let me know."

 

 You stand there for a moment, unsure whether to laugh or cry. Finally, you mutter a quick "never mind" and retreat, Dennis already lost in his work. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I’ve been wondering,” you begin. “How are the boys' lessons different to the girls? You know what they teach us in biology. How is that different to your lessons?”

 

 His face reddens at the topic and you notice he increasingly avoids making eye contact with you.

 

 “It’s the same in biology,” he stammers. “We watch the video tapes like you do. Except… It's rowdy. Loud. It’s like a zoo.” You notice he spits a little as he says the last sentence.

 

 “And other lessons? Geography?” 

 

 He looks up at you, a little more relaxed in talking with you. “Geography is all about the places men have conquered. All the things to do. I usually write about Japan. I’d love to go there.”

 

 Dennis titters a little. “Mr. Stitch doesn’t like girls attending boys' lessons,” he tells you. “The only way you could would be to get a pass from a teacher. And I don’t think it would be safe for you, even if you did.”

 

 “And Stitch doesn’t let just anyone have a pass,” he adds, a little bit of frustration seeping into his voice. “I've only got one to help out with the AV equipment. Usually they’re just for those who get extra lessons from Stitch.”

 

 “Extra lessons?” you ask.

 

 Dennis' face bunches up with anger. “Yeah. Supposed to be for people at the top of their classes. But it’s like you get to the top by just having those lessons. I have to work hard to be there."

 <>
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “What do you think about the school”, you ask him directly.

 

 “I can’t wait to leave,” he blurts out. As he says the words you can see fear on his face. He looks at you, eyes widened. 

 

 You offer him a reassuring smile. “It’s okay. It’s a bit strange here.”

 

 He smiles meekly, relaxing. “I hate it. The boys here are bullies. All they care about are their dumb football games and impressing girls. The teachers are just as bad too. They call it Social Darwinism. It’s just a way to control us.”

 

 “Have you noticed anything out of the ordinary?” you ask him.

 

 He looks at you, his lips pursed. “You shouldn’t be asking that. It will get you in trouble.”

 <> 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Hey, can I ask you something?” you begin. “About Biology class.”

 

 Dennis keeps his attention on what he’s doing, not looking at you. “What about it?”, he stammers.

 

 “The documentaries seem very strange,” you reply. “Where do they come from?”

 

 Dennis looks up, his face redder than usual. “I don’t know. They’ve always been here.” He flicks his eyes to the floor.

 

 “Why do you help out with the lessons?” you ask.

 

 “I’m in the school AV club,” he says, with a hint of embarrassment in his voice. “I *am* the school AV club, actually. Mr. Stitch lets me watch whatever I want, as long as I fix things when they break and I keep the cassette cupboard neat and tidy. He hates it when things are untidy.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “So you keep all the equipment and cassettes in that cupboard?” you say, nodding your head to the closed door at the back of the room.

 

 He nods, almost smiling at the topic. “Yeah. I’m the only one with the key. Well, except staff. And Olaf. The janitor. Mr. Stitch doesn’t like people to have access to the tapes. He says that some of them should only be watched with adult supervision.” He blushes. “Except he lets me.”

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I couldn’t borrow the key to the AV cupboard, could I?” you ask him. “I’d love to see some of the tapes in there.”

 

 He looks at you, a small twitch in the corner of his mouth. “Do you like old movies too?”

 

 You nod, placating him. “I’d love to see what’s in the library. Do you think I could have a peek?”

 

 He grimaces. “I don’t think I can do that. If Mr. Stitch found out, I’d get in a lot of trouble. But…”

 

 
 
 Dennis pauses, looking at you. “I could tell you all about them, if you like,” he stammers. “I could meet you at Fresh Pot one evening. I could buy you a coffee. Maybe even afterwards we could pick out a movie to watch together.”

 

 His lip is quivering slightly once he stops talking. It takes a moment for you to register what is happening here. *He is asking you out on a date.*

 

 Your mind races. Whilst you may look like Emily, this would be you, going out on a date. But it would get you closer to Dennis, and the key to the AV cupboard.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>

 
 
 Dennis shifts his weight from foot to foot. “I… could lend you it. After we got that coffee.”

 

 He won’t quite meet your eyes as you stare back at him. “You’d give me the key if I met you at Fresh Pot?”

 

 Dennis nods, repeatedly. “Yes! I could definitely do that!” He sniffs. “I’ll see you at Fresh Pot, yeah?”

 

 You sigh. It seems that Dennis really wants a date with Emily.

 

 Actions
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 Dennis gives a small, pleased smile. “Okay. For you, sure. Just to have a peek, okay?"

 

 He reaches into his jumper and pulls out the key attached to a necklace, holding it out to you. “Here you go,” he says.

 

 "Thank you," you reply, taking it.

 

 "And Em," he stammers. “If you'd like to come over one evening... to watch a movie. Just let me know.”
 
 

 You smile politely, noncommittally.
 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 Dennis gives a small, pleased smile. “Okay. For you, sure. Just to have a peek, okay?"

 

 He reaches into his jumper and pulls out the key attached to a necklace, holding it out to you. “Here you go,” he says.

 

 "Thank you," you reply, taking it.

 

 "And Em," he stammers. “If you'd like to come over one evening... to watch a movie. Just let me know.”
 
 

 You smile politely, noncommittally.
 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Dennis frowns, glancing down. “I don’t think that’s a good idea.”

 

 You wait for him to say more. He takes a deep breath, as if scared of confrontation. “It just felt like... maybe you weren’t really there. You know?” He shrugs, voice quiet. “On our date.”

 

 You grimace, understanding the expression on his face now. “Dennis…” 

 

 “It’s a lot to ask, Em,” he cuts you off. “I don’t know why you want that key, but I don’t know if I can trust you. And I don’t want this coming back on me.”

 

 Actions 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 You turn the conversation to topics that you know that Dennis is enthusiastic about.
 
 

 Quickly it becomes apparent that he loves old British movies about the Second World War. He tells you all about directors and movie stars that you've only heard of in passing. He casually derides you for how many of them you haven't seen.

 

 Time goes by ever-so slowly, but eventually the conversation comes to an end. Dennis apologies and tells you he needs to pack up, but enthusiastically tells you to come back another time if you want to talk more. A little too hopefully, he also tells you he spends his weekends in the town's public library, which has an AV room to rival this school's collection.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “If I say yes to a date, do you think you could give me the key?” you ask him.

 

 His eyes widen and he stares at you. “A date?” he stammers. “Like a real one?”

 

 You nod and watch his face light up.

 

 “And you’ll dress-up and look nice and we’ll be out in public together?”

 

 You nod again, trying not to be condescending. “Would you give me the key then?”

 

 He giggles nervously. “Okay! I’ll need to just tidy up in there, but okay - if you meet me at Fresh Pot, I’ll give you the key. I’ll do anything for you!”

 

 You decide to leave him by, as he processes you agreeing to go out to him. “I’ll see you there,” you say, heading for the door.
 
 
 

 “Oh, Em!” Dennis says as you are leaving. “Just one thing. I think you’d look really good as a blonde. Really cute. Maybe you could get that done at the Salon on Orchid Road for our date?”

 

 You notice that for the first time, he’s looking directly at you. You nod, taken aback at his newfound confidence. “We’ll see.”

 

 He grins and you feel his eyes on you as turn away from him.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I’m sorry, Dennis,” you say politely. “I’ve just got to concentrate on my studies. Now’s not a good time.”

 

 His gaze returns straight away to what he was doing. “I understand,” he mumbles. “If you change your mind, you can let me know.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “How about you give me the key, and I won’t tell everyone that about the photos I saw in the basement,” you tell him.

 

 He doesn’t look up, but you can see his teeth clenching. “What photos?”

 

 “The ones that you’ve taken for Olaf. Ones of girls walking up the stairs. Or in the girls' bathrooms. Or even the girls' changing rooms.”

 

 He glances up at you briefly, then turns back to what he was doing. “I don’t know what you are talking about.”

 

 “I think you do, Dennis,” you tell him. “And I bet that the headmaster would like to know about them. Or, perhaps I should tell Jake?”

 

 His head turns towards you, shaking. “No. Please don’t!”

 

 “Just give me the key,” you say. “And your secret stays with me.”

 

 With only the slightest hesitation, he reaches into his jumper and pulls out the key attached to a necklace. He holds it out to you, his hands trembling. “Here you go,” he stammers. “Please! Just don’t say anything!”

 

 You take the key from him and smile thinly. “Thank you, Dennis. We’ll keep this between us.”

 

 He nods and looks back down, trying his best to ignore you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 You watch Dennis avoid your eyeline and take a deep breath, stirring the familiar sensations of dormant magic inside you.

 

 Your stomach churns as you feel magic snaking around inside you. It wraps around the cool air that you draw into your lungs. You feel the crackle as it bonds with the elements inside your chest.

 

 Dennis sits unaware, purposefully staring away from you. Blissfully unaware that, for all intents and purposes, you are about to alter his mind.

 

 You exhale, watching the gas escape your mouth. Like breathing out into a cold evening, you see your breath hanging in the air, slowly making its way towards Dennis. Unlike on those icy nights, though, the gas sparkles with yellow energy.

 

 It hits Dennis firmly in the face. He sniffles, inadvertently drawing in your magic.

 

 Slowly, almost methodically, he turns to look up at you. "Oh," he stammers. "Hello."
 
 
 Something is wrong with the code, as Dennis has no magic.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 "I need that key, Dennis," you say, letting a hint of malice into your voice. "I don't have time to mess around."

 

 Dennis glances at you. You see him visibly gulp. "I can't. Mr. Stitch gave me explicit -"

 

 You lean over towards him, letting a thin smile rise on your face. "Mr. Stitch isn't here. It's just me. And believe me, I can be as much of a problem as Mr. Stitch can be if you get on my bad side."

 

 The lip of the school boy quivers. "You'll get me in trouble," he whispers.

 

 You flash him a menacing grin. "You'll be in worse trouble right now if you don't hand it over."

 

 Dennis sniffs, staring back at you, fear in his eyes. Reluctantly, he reaches into his jumper and pulls out the key attached to a necklace. He holds it out to you, his hands trembling. “Here you go,” he stammers. “Please! Leave me alone!”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 "You should give me that key," you tell Dennis. "Or, er, you wouldn't like me when I'm angry."

 

 Dennis stares back at you for a long moment. Then starts to laugh. "I've read that comic book too! Sometimes Old Pete gets them imported in from America and sells that at the Pharmacy! I didn't know you were into comics too, ?"

 

 "I'm being serious," you say, with little confidence.

 

 He chuckles again. "I don't know if you've met Mr. Stitch, but I don't think you can get as angry as he can. He gave me explicit instructions not to share the key. Sorry, but I'm not going to risk the wrath of his green form. Now, I should get back to what I was doing."

 

 Dennis titters to himself as he returns to his work. Your attempts to intimidate him have actually lowered his nervousness around you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “You know,” you say casually. “How do you even get out of your own classes to help with the biology lessons?”

 

 Dennis shifts awkwardly. “Oh. That. Um… I’ve got an understanding with Mr. Harrow. And Stitch. They don’t really get how any of the equipment works.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “You mean the tape decks older than we are?”

 

 He gives a sheepish laugh. “Yeah, well. They’re technically challenging. I know none of it's cutting-edge, but if the video doesn’t load right or sound doesn't come through, Stitch gets... intense. So I help.”

 

 You nod, wondering how these people have survived. “You must have a hall pass, then?”

 

 Dennis glances away. “Sort of. I mean… yeah. Harrow gave me one. Just in case anyone asks.”

 

 Sensing an opportunity, you lean in slightly. “Think he’d give one to me?”

 

 Dennis fidgets with the hem of his sleeve. He shakes his head. “He only gave me one because I’m helping. He doesn't just hand them out.”

 

 You don’t say anything. Just watch him. Your focus makes him fidget nervously.

 

 “Although,” Dennis continues, “I still have to go to my own classes. It's hard to double-hat. Maybe Harrow wouldn’t mind an extra hand for the boys' lessons." Dennis looks at you, wincing slightly. "Especially if it was, uh, a girl.”

 

 
 
 Dennis hesitates, chewing his lip. “I could maybe talk to him,” he says carefully. “But… I guess it would depend. On why you want it.”

 

 He looks up at you, flushed but determined. “Would you maybe want to get a coffee with me? At Fresh Pot? We could talk a bit more about why you need it. I could talk to him after that.”

 

 His lip is quivering slightly once he stops talking. It takes a moment for you to register what is happening here. He is asking you out on a date.

 

 Your mind races. It seems insane, but it would get you closer to Dennis and Harrow’s hall pass.

 

 *Are you considering going out with Dennis for a hall pass, as Emily? Or maybe you could just convince him to do your dirty work for you?*

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>

 
 
 Dennis shifts his weight from foot to foot. “I… could maybe talk to him. After we got that coffee.”

 

 He won’t quite meet your eyes as you stare back at him. “You’d talk to him if I met you at Fresh Pot?”

 

 Dennis nods, repeatedly. “Yes! I could definitely do that!” He sniffs. “I’ll see you at Fresh Pot, yeah?”

 

 You sigh. It seems that Dennis really wants a date with Emily.

 

 Actions

 
 <>
 
 
 
 Dennis gives a small, pleased smile. “Okay. For you, sure. I’ll talk to Harrow. He listens to me. And I think he likes the idea of… expanding the team.”

 

 He pats his pocket. “Come back tomorrow. I should have an answer.”

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Dennis gives a small, pleased smile. “Okay. For you, sure. I’ll talk to Harrow. He listens to me. And I think he likes the idea of… expanding the team.”

 

 He pats his pocket. “Come back tomorrow. I should have an answer.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 Dennis frowns, glancing down. “I don’t think that’s a good idea.”

 

 You wait for him to say more. He takes a deep breath, as if scared of confrontation. “It just felt like... maybe you weren’t really there. You know?” He shrugs, voice quiet. “On our date.”

 

 You grimace, understanding the expression on his face now. “Dennis…” 

 

 “It’s a lot to ask, Em,” he cuts you off. “I don’t know what you’d need a hall pass for, but I don’t know if I can trust you. And I don’t want this coming back on me.”

 

 Actions

 
 <> 
 
 
 
 “If I say yes to a date?” you ask him. “Do you think you could ask Harrow for a hall pass?”

 

 His eyes widen. He stares at you. “A date?” he stammers. “Like a real one?”

 

 You nod, and watch as his entire face lights up.

 

 “And you’ll dress up, and look nice, and we’ll be out in public together?”

 

 You nod again, trying not to sound condescending. “Would you ask Harrow then?”

 

 He giggles nervously. “Okay! Yeah, I’ll talk to him. If you meet me at Fresh Pot, I’ll do it. I’ll do anything for you!”

 

 You step back, letting him ride the wave of adrenaline and disbelief. “I’ll see you there,” you say, turning toward the door.
 
 
 
 
 “Oh, Em!” Dennis calls after you. “Just one thing. I think you’d look really good as a blonde. Really cute. Maybe you could get that done at the salon on Orchid Road? For our date?”

 

 You pause. It’s the first time he’s really looked at you head-on.

 

 You nod slowly. “We’ll see.”

 

 He grins, and you can feel his eyes on your back as you walk away.

 
 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 “How about you ask Harrow for a hall pass,” you say calmly. “And I won’t tell anyone about the photos I found in the basement.”

 

 Dennis freezes. “What photos?” he says stiffly.

 

 “The ones you’ve taken for Olaf. Of girls walking up the stairs. Or inside the bathrooms. Or changing rooms.”

 

 His head jerks slightly, but he keeps his head down. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

 

 You step closer. “I think you do. And I bet the Headmaster would be very interested to know. Or maybe Jake should hear about it first.”

 

 “No,” Dennis stammers. “Please don’t.”

 

 “Then get me a hall pass,” you say. “And your secret stays safe.”

 

 For a long moment, he just stares off, at the TV. Then nods. “Fine,” he mutters. “Come back tomorrow. I’ll ask Harrow.”

 

 You don’t thank him. Instead, you just meet his eyes. He looks away quickly, shame burning across his face.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I need that hall pass, Dennis,” you say flatly, letting a thread of malice into your voice. “I’m not in the mood to negotiate.”

 

 Dennis glances at you. You see him swallow. Hard.

 

 “I… I don’t know,” he stammers. “Harrow only gave one to me and -”

 

 You step in closer, letting a smile edge across your lips. “Harrow’s not here. And neither is Stitch. Just me. And you really don’t want me getting irritated.”

 

 Dennis stiffens. “I’ll get in trouble."

 

 You tilt your head. “You’re already in trouble if you don’t fix this. Or would you prefer I start asking around about the other things you get up to in the AV room?”

 

 His face goes pale. “Fine,” he mutters. “I’ll talk to Harrow. Just… just come back tomorrow.”

 

 You watch him squirm for a moment longer, then step away, leaving the tension in the air behind you. Dennis wipes his palms on his jumper, not daring to meet your eyes.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “You should get me that hall pass,” you tell Dennis, narrowing your eyes. “Or… you won’t like me when I’m angry.”

 

 Dennis stares at you for a long moment. Then breaks into a laugh. “I’ve read that one too! The Incredible Hulk! I didn’t know you were into comics, Em! Did you know that Old Pete gets the reprints in at the pharmacy?”

 

 You try to hold your expression. “I’m being serious.”

 

 “Right,” he says, grinning. “Sorry, but I’m not going to risk getting on Stitch's list. I’ve got enough problems to worry about.”

 

 Dennis hums to himself and turns back to his equipment, noticeably more relaxed. If anything, your attempt at intimidation just made him feel more comfortable around you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Hey Dennis,” you say. “Have you spoken to Harrow yet about that pass?”

 

 
 
 
 
 Dennis doesn’t look up. “Yeah. I did it.”

 

 He picks at the edge of a cable, avoiding your eyes. “He said it was fine. You can help during the boys’ biology lesson. It’s on at same time as your geography class.”

 

 He glares at you from beneath his eyebrows, but continues talking. “Just give Prichard this,” he says, tossing the pass on to the table in front of him. “I’ll leave the AV trolley outside the door.”

 

 “There. You’ve got what you wanted. Don’t talk to me again. And good luck in Harrow’s lesson. You’re going to need it.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Dennis frowns. “No. I haven’t.”

 

 He sounds drained as he speaks. “I said I’d do it. But I haven’t had a chance. Harrow’s hard to pin down.”

 

 He runs a hand through his hair. “Don’t push it. Please.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 “Oh! Yeah. I did speak to Mr. Harrow,” he says, nodding quickly. “He was… weirdly into the idea, actually. Said it was good to see a girl showing ‘proactive initiative.’” Dennis makes a face at the phrasing.

 

 “He said you can help during the boys’ biology lesson. It’s on at the same time as your Geography lesson. Just give this pass to Ms. Prichard,” he says, holding out a pass. “She’ll let you out.”

 

 He taps the side of the TV cart. “I’ll leave this right outside the boys’ classroom. You just wheel it in like you belong there.”

 

 He gives a nervous smile. “I hope you know what you’re doing, Em.” He winces. “Those lessons are full of testosterone.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Dennis shifts his weight. “Not yet. Sorry. I haven’t had a chance to catch him.”

 

 He offers a faint, apologetic smile. “Come back later? I’ll make it happen.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 
 You nod toward the piles cluttering the desk. “What are you doing, Dennis?”

 

 He stiffens, eyes fixed on the flickering screen. “W-w-watching a movie.”

 

 “Not that.” You gesture to the teetering stacks of cases. “Those.”

 

 His hand hovers above his notebook, knuckles tight around the pencil. “Tapes,” he stammers. “I’m… working my way through them.”

 

 You frown, picking one up. The cover shows a rocket launch frozen in grainy print, the title faded into illegibility. Row after row of them, all documentaries. Space exploration, the cosmos, things that feel less like leisure and more like lessons. “These don’t look like entertainment.”

 

 Dennis grimaces, as though you’ve caught him out. “Stitch and Harrow asked me for a favour,” he mutters. “Said they’d give me extra credit if I found tapes that… got donated. By accident.”

 

 You arch a brow. His shoulders sag, the fight going out of him. He leans closer, voice lowering. “Mr. Whitley. The teacher before Harrow. He gave a box of them to the library when he left. Stitch wants them back.”

 

 Your eyes drift over the spines again. One sleeve in particular prickles against your fingertips. A program on the universe. You blink, and for a heartbeat you see amber eyes peering from the cardboard edge, where no space exists for them. A chill runs through you.

 

 Dennis notices you staring. He mistakes it for curiosity. “We can watch one, if you like.” His voice drops to a whisper. “They’re not like Harrow’s biology reels. These talk about… facts. Science stuff. I’ve been doing better at school since I started.”

 

 The tape shifts in your hand, heavy in a way it shouldn’t be. Helpful or not, nothing in Charlton ever comes free.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <> 
 
 “What's your favourite tape?” you try. “Any that you couldn’t be without?”

 

 Dennis brightens at the change of subject, but shakes his head. “Oh, none of these are mine. You can’t get some of them anymore, but I’m glad they’re here for everyone to see. You can learn a lot from old movies.” His eyes flick downward as if retreating into thought.

 

 You press him like a fish slipping from your grasp. “I would have thought you’d a favourite. There's not one you'd be lost without?”

 

 Dennis shakes his head again. “I’m not really a collector. My mum says it's impossible to buy presents for me.”

 

 “Not even your camera?” you try. "Don't you treasure that?"

 

 His shoulders stiffen at you mentioning the object. “I mean… I like it. But it’s just a cheap one. I’ve gone through a few. Sometimes I leave them behind without thinking. They’re… replaceable.”

 

 “So you don’t have anything personal?” you say, trying not to let frustration seep into your voice. “Nothing personal that you couldn’t be without?”

 

 Dennis frowns, regarding you suspiciously. “Why are you so interested?”

 

 “Just trying to get to know you,” you deflect. You flutter your eyes as you lower your voice. “What you value.”

 

 
 
 Dennis hesitates, then glances away. His cheeks redden. “I still have the receipt,” he says quietly. “From our date.” He looks up, for the first time staring back at you without hesitation. “That means something to me.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 Dennis shifts his weight, eyes flicking to the floor. His voice dips. “Well… there could be something I’d keep.”

 

 A knot forms in your stomach. “Like what?”

 

 His eyes lift for the briefest moment, then drop again. “A photo. Of you.”

 

 As if sensing your reaction, he looks up at you and quickly continues. “I mean, I’ve taken a lot of nice photos, but. Never one of you.”

 

 You swallow, trying to bury the feelings rising up inside. “You’d treasure that?”

 

 Dennis nods. “More than anything,” he mutters.

 

 You stare back at him as he grows red. It’s just a photo, right? But do you really want to send Emily to pose for this boy?

 

 Or worse still, do you want to do it yourself?

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 “Do you think I could see it?” you ask him.

 

 Dennis blinks at you, confused. “Uh… right now?”

 

 When you nod, he fumbles in his wallet. He produces it carefully, almost reverently.

 

 The bill from a date, still pristine. At the bottom, in a neat scrawl is Flo’s handwriting: “Hope you had a good time x”. You note that Dennis left a modest tip.

 

 As you look, you notice his eyes never leave the slip of paper, as if afraid it might vanish or be torn from him. There's a stirring from the amulet.

 

 You feel the words to the transformation spell on the tip of your tongue, spurring on the amulet as if it is anticipating this. Glancing back at Dennis though, the realisation catches you. He's a man.

 

 And when you're in his body, you won't be able to cast magic. And make him forget what he's just seen.

 

 The answer is obvious. You need him unconscious first.
