 <>

 
 Cast Sleep & Forget on Dennis - *You'll need to be in the school library at lunch to transform into Dennis for the lessons*

 
 <>

 You gently stretch the receipt back out to Dennis. He takes it quickly, checking it for damage, then puts it back into his wallet.

 

 "Why so interested?" he stammers, as he pockets his wallet.

 

 "I just... like that you keep it," you feign. And you note that your response draws more red to his cheeks.

 

 Getting good at that, aren't you?

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 "How about you take a photo of me, then?" you offer, as casually as possible. It still causes Dennis to freeze, blinking at you as if he misheard.

 

 “Really?”

 

 You nod. His face floods with colour. “O-okay. Right. Just... just wait a moment.”

 

 He fumbles with his bag, pulling out a squat polaroid camera. He then looks around, standing and walking over towards a blank wall, almost tripping over his own bag. He pulls down a white projection screen and pushes a chair out of the way, creating a space in front of it.

 

 “Just… stand there," he says, moving back to the other side of the desk. "I mean, only if you want to."

 

 You smile politely at him, but stand and walk over to the projection screen. Your anxiety easing with each stammer from Dennis. You stand casually, looking back at him.

 

 "Like this?"

 

 "Yeah," he says, trying not to look at you. Then he raises the camera to his face and you feel a lump in your throat. "Perfect,” Dennis mutters, his face hidden, sidestepping as he studies you through a viewfinder.

 

 The camera snaps as he snaps a shot, making you jump. The camera whirs, spitting out the square of paper. He waves it in the air, watching it bloom. His mouth twists. “It’s… okay. But not quite right.”

 

 He looks back at you, again trying to avoid looking. "Try smiling?" he asks, voice trembling. "Or you don't have to. If you don't want to. Maybe... just look natural."

 

 As you shift slightly and smile politely, you don't feel exploited. There's a tension in the air, but it all stems from Dennis. As he takes another snap and his frown deepens as the polaroid comes into focus, you realise that he doesn't really know what he's doing.

 

 Or isn't assertive enough to be able to tell you what he really wants.

 
 
 At this rate, he’ll burn through them all unless you step in.

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 <>

 
 <>

 
 <>

 
 
 
 
 <> 
 
 <>
 

 As you watch Dennis fumble with the camera, something inside you hardens. If you leave him in charge, he’ll waste them all.

 

 “Here,” you say, straightening. “Let me.”

 

 Dennis blinks, lowering the camera slightly. “W-what do you mean?”

 

 
 
 Instead of answering, you turn to the side, sliding one hand down to tug your dress up. You arch your back, deliberately shaping the curve of your body. Then you twist your head, giving him a coy glance over your shoulder.

 
 Instead of answering, you turn around, back facing him, pulling at your skirt just enough to reveal a flash of your underwear. You arch your back, deliberately shaping the curve of your body. Then you twist your head, giving him a coy glance over your shoulder.

 
 Instead of answering, you lift your leg high in the air, bending it at the knee, pulling it close to your chest. Aware that your skirt has ridden up around your waist, exposing your underwear. You flash him a smile.

 
 

 Dennis freezes. The room goes silent. As you stand there, for the first time he takes you in. You notice him gulp.

 

 Click.

 

 The camera snaps, ejecting the Polaroid with a mechanical whir. His hands tremble as he snatches it, waving it quickly, eyes fixed on the image as it develops.

 

 “This…” his voice cracks. “This one’s perfect.”

 

 You can feel the heat of his gaze still darting between you and the photo. The rush is undeniable. Not just his approval, but the control of making him look exactly where you wanted.

 

 Dennis swallows, holding the Polaroid out towards you like an offering. His fingers are white at the edges, reluctant to let go. "You want to see?"

 

 Taking the photo, you glance down to see Emily's smiling face posing for the camera. Around your neck, the amulet tingles.

 

 You feel the words to the transformation spell on the tip of your tongue, spurring on the amulet as if it is anticipating this. Glancing back at Dennis though, the realisation catches you. He's a man.

 The answer is obvious. You need him unconscious first.

 <>

 As you watch Dennis fumble with the camera, something inside you hardens. If you leave him in charge, he’ll waste them all.

 

 “What about if I turned to the side?” you say, turning to face your hip towards him. "Does that work?”

 

 Dennis blinks, lowering the camera slightly. “W-what do you mean?”

 

 You put a hand on your hip. "Like this?" The words are meant to be assured, but you don't really feel you know what you're doing. As he wordlessly raises the camera and takes another snap, you grimace.

 

 “Just.. turn a little," he mutters from behind the viewfinder. "No, back. Chin up. Maybe both hands on your hips? Or not… actually, just stay like that.”

 

 You follow each fumbling command, letting him adjust you with words alone. His instructions are clumsy and his mood sours with each photo he takes. For your part, you are left with a series of conflicting directions, feeling progressively awkward as you attempt to contort your body to accommodate his bumbling asks.

 

 After a few more snaps, Dennis lowers the camera. "That's all the film I've got," he mutters.

 

 You join him as he surveys the spread of polaroid photos on the table. A series of snaps of Emily, looking confused and uncomfortable, twisting her body into inelegant poses.

 

 "Thanks for trying," Dennis stammers. "I guess I'm no good at this."

 

 "Maybe we could try again?" you offer. "When you've got more film?"

 

 Dennis shrugs, almost in defeat. He gathers up the photos and tosses them into a paper bin. "Sure."

 

 One thing's for sure, you think. You'll need to be firmer with him to get him something he treasures. Or, as you watch him return to the table, maybe there's something that you could wear that would inspire him.

 

 Are you really thinking of dressing up for him?

 

 You grimace. But you really need him to treasure the photo. Maybe you should speak to Emily about looking through her wardrobe for something else to wear.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 "Hey Dennis," you begin. "Do you think I could see that photo you took again?"

 

 There is a momentary look of confusion on his face, as he flinches. "Which one?"

 

 You bury any urge to unpack what he just said and smile politely. "The one of me."

 

 His eyes light up, and he scrambles into his pocket. "This one?" he says, holding out the Polaroid out towards you.

 

 Taking the photo, you glance down to see Emily's smiling face posing for the camera. Around your neck, the amulet tingles.

 
 
 You feel the words to the transformation spell on the tip of your tongue, spurring on the amulet as if it is anticipating this. Glancing back at Dennis though, the realisation catches you. He's a man.

 <>

 "Hey Dennis," you begin. "Do you think I could see that receipt you kept?"

 

 There is a momentary look of confusion on his face, as he flinches. "What receipt?"

 

 You smile politely, burying the resistance to say the words. "The one from our date."

 

 Dennis blinks at you, confused. “Uh… right now?”

 

 When you nod, he fumbles in his wallet. He produces it carefully. As you look, you notice his eyes never leave the slip of paper. There's a stirring from the amulet.

 

 You feel the words to the transformation spell on the tip of your tongue, spurring on the amulet as if it is anticipating this. Glancing back at Dennis though, the realisation catches you. He's a man.

 

 And when you're in his body, you won't be able to cast magic. And make him forget what he's just seen.

 

 The answer is obvious. You need him unconscious first.
 
 

 Actions

 
 <>
 
 

 
 Cast Sleep & Forget on Dennis - *You'll need to be in the school library at lunch to transform into Dennis*

 
 <>

 You take a deep breath. "Fall asleep," you whisper. "And let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 Dennis looks up at you, frowning. "Huh?"

 

 Amber-yellow magic mist drifts out through your teeth and wraps around Dennis. His confusion turns to panic, but it quickly falters as the spell takes hold. His eyes roll back and his body folds like a marionette with its strings cut, tumbling on to the desk with a soft thud.

 

 You hurry forward, checking to make sure he's alright. He’s limp, bruised, but breathing shallow. As you check his face, it twitches, before smoothing into blankness.

 

 Glancing around, you see the perfect place to lay him to rest. The room is already dark from the blacked out windows. A corner behind the unused teacher's desk is perfect for what you need.

 

 You drag him carefully by the arms, the teenager weighing no more than you do right now, and lay him down in the darkness. He rolls over to his side, but doesn't stir. In slumber, Dennis finally looks peaceful. No nervousness or anxiety stretching his face. He seems almost content.

 

 Taking a deep breath, you ready yourself for your next step.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: ElizabethDialogue
text:
“Hey Liz, I need a favour,” you tell her.

 

 She looks at you from over the rim of her glasses. “Sure,” she says after a moment. “What’s up?”

 

 You take a step closer, lowering your voice. “I need you to cause a distraction after school. Enough to make Prichard leave her classroom.”

 

 A half-smile rises up on Liz’s face. “Do I want to know why?”

 

 You match her expression. “Let’s just say there’s something that needs investigating in there. Something very cursed.”

 
 
 
 Her half-smile twitches with excitement. “A curse? Is that what’s causing it?” You nod and her eyes gleam.

 

 “And you can remove it?” 

 

 You nod again. “So you'll help?"

 

 She holds your stare for a moment, her smile thinning. “Say I do. Can you teach me how to lift the curses too?”

 

 “It’s more that I know how to change them,” you try to explain, but this only encourages her. 

 

 “Even better! Think what we can do if we both know how to do that! Come on, *Emily*. Share the knowledge!” 

 

 You stare at her, almost blinded by beaming enthusiasm. You could really do with Liz’ help, but do you think she should know more magic?

 

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 But regardless of whether you would teach her, you can't. You tell her honestly that you don't know how to perform the curse. 

 

 "Well, you best get learning it then!" she replies, smiling. "I'm sure our mutual friend at the junk shop might be able to help. You should go see her. We're not exactly on great terms - she thinks I don't take these things seriously enough. But I'm sure she'll teach you!"
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 A slight frown appears on Liz's face. "A curse? What do you mean?"

 

 The young woman stares back at you, blankly. She has no idea what a curse is, as she has no idea about magic.

 

 "It's not important," you deflect. "I just need to get into the classroom. If I were to find myself in detention, do you think you could distract Prichard for a while?"

 

 "You? In detention?" Elizabeth looks taken aback by the idea. "Okay Emily, you did try and help to tutor me. And tried to help when I passed out. I guess I owe you. If I see you in there, I have a few ideas of how to get Prichard's attention."

 

 "Thanks Liz," you say. She smiles pleasantly at you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 

 ”Hey Liz,” you say quietly. "You've got something in your eyes.”

 

 You launch your arm forward and snatch her glasses from her face before she can even realise what you’re doing. Immediately and instinctively you see her pupils try to compensate, squinting as she adjusts to her limited vision.

 

 “Look at you, you must be as blind as a bat!” you say, leaping back to avoid her lunges at your hands. “Maybe you’re the exception to the rule and you look worse without these nerdy things.”

 

 A small circle of students forms around you and Liz, who tries in vain to grab back her spectacles. Her lack of depth perception is obvious. She staggers around and you evade her easily.

 

 “Give them back, you bitch!” Liz snaps, her teeth snarling with anger. Meanwhile, other students are starting to laugh.

 

 “Careful there Liz,” you continue. “You wouldn’t want to cause an accident.” Dramatically you let go of the glasses. They fall to the floor. You raise your shoe over them.

 

 Liz freezes at the clattering as her frames bounce on ceramic. “Why?” she asks.

 

 “Because under all that make-up and short skirt and ripped tights,” you reply. “You need to be reminded of what you are.”

 

 You put your heel over one of the lenses. “That is, a spectacled little nerd.”

 

 The sound of crunching glass gets a cheer from the crowd. A random student sticks their leg out as Liz spins around and she falls backwards, landing with a crunch on her back. She whimpers in pain.

 

 The cheers from the crowd die down, but Liz’ whimpering continues. Slowly, the crowd disperses. You turn around and walk off. In all probability, Liz will never talk to you again. But you believe you are one step to acceptance by Christina and her friends.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Alright, I’ll do it,” you tell Liz. 

 

 “Wonderful,” she says, with a crooked smile. “Call me in the evening and I’ll come over. And when we’re done - I’ll know exactly how to cause a little distraction.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You feign an excuse. “I’m not sure Gladys at the junk shop would be happy with me doing that.”

 

 Liz looks at you, but shrugs. “No spell, no scene. But your call, *Emily*. Let me know if you change your mind.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “What are you reading?” you ask her, glancing at the books sprawled over the table.

 
 
 
 “Research,” she tells you quietly. “This library has a few secrets of its own, if you know where to look.”

 

 She turns a book around to face you. “Have a read. Anything seem familiar?”

 

 You glance at it. The book is titled *“Under the soil - A History of Pagan Britain."* Reading through the open pages, the author is recalling an eye-witness account of a festival celebrating May Day. You recognise references to fields and farmlands that surround Charlton. One paragraph stands out to you:

 

 The three-day event was brought to a climax on May Day by Lord Raglan Greenwood, Baron of Howerby, whose hour-long rally whipped his enamoured audience, mostly young women, into a writhing frenzy. As he read from the Translations of the Sevrene Shards, his brilliant smile captivated his flock and his Hecate Wheel amulet outshone even the spring morning sun. Lennon and his recently disbanded group may have been more popular than Jesus, but if Greenwood had their exposure he’d unquestionably be the Almighty Father.

 

 “Remind you of anything?” Liz says after she sees you pull back from the book. 

 

 “What’s this book mentioned?" you ask. “The Seven Shards?”

 

 “Sevrene”, Liz corrects you. “It’s referenced in other books too. The library is supposed to have a copy, but it’s always checked out.” She leans towards you, smirking. “If someone were to stake out the library, they might just see who keeps on borrowing it.”
 
 
 Liz seems a bit embarrassed by your question. "School work," she says quickly.

 

 You glance at the old tomes laid out in front of her. They don't look like school books. In fact, you would bet money that they are about the occult.

 

 "I didn't learn that when I was at school," you say.

 

 She giggles, remembering too late that she's in a library. "You caught me. I'm writing. I like to write stories on the side. About magic. I'm doing some research. It's always fascinated me. Something about it calls to me, like an urge or a dream."

 

 Her face drains of joy, as if she's trying to remember something but it's just out of reach. But then she shakes it off.

 

 "It must seem childish," she says quietly.

 

 "Just so long as you know the difference between fact and fiction," you can't help but comment.

 

 This causes her to laugh, just a little. You hear a librarian shush from the counter.

 

 "Anyway, it's just a bit of fun," she tells you.
 
 
 Liz actually seems to blush. "School work," she says quickly.

 

 You glance at the old tomes laid out in front of her. They don't look like school books. In fact, you would bet money that they are about the occult.

 

 "Interesting topics you study at Charlton," you say, sardonically.

 

 Her face continues to turn red. "Fine. I'm writing. Stories. About magic. I've always been fascinated by the subject. It's as if something about it calls to me, like an urge or a dream."

 

 Her face drains of joy, as if she's trying to remember something but it's just out of reach. But then she shakes it off.

 

 "It must seem childish," she says quietly.

 

 "Just so long as you know the difference between fact and fiction," you can't help but comment.

 

 This causes her to laugh, just a little. You hear a librarian shush from the counter.

 

 "Anyway, it's just a bit of fun," she tells you.

 
 Liz smiles. You can sense a hint of embarrassment on her face. "I write," she says. "Stories. In my spare time. This is research."

 

 You glance at the old books laid out in front of her. They look like they are about the occult.

 

 "What are you writing about?" you ask.

 

 "Magic," she says, almost reluctantly. "Witches, wizards, spells. I guess I never grew out of Harry Potter. Must seem a bit silly to you."

 

 She looks at you, almost blushing. You offer a sympathetic smile.

 

 "We all have our guilty pleasures," you say.

 

 At this, she breaks out into a grin. "I find it fascinating! Can you imagine if you could cast spells, Em? Imagine how much fun you could have!"

 

 You say nothing as she drifts off into her own indulgent fantasies.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You take out *Translations of the Sevrene Shards* and put it down on the table, smiling knowingly at Liz. 

 

 Her eyes grow large when she sees the title and she hurriedly flicks through the pages. “Oh. My. God. Where did you get this?”

 

 “A mutual acquaintance,” you tell her. “She had enough time with it.”

 

 Liz grins, but her attention drifts to the new book. “Fascinating,” she murmurs. “Hey, do you think I could borrow this?”

 

 She says it casually, but you can tell by the way she’s already grasping it with both hands that this means a lot to her. You surmise that if you agree, you won’t get it back for some time. Also, you wonder if giving someone like Liz more knowledge of magic is such a good idea.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 <> 

 With only a slight hesitation, you reach out and place the book down in front of Liz.

 

 She snatches the book up to her chest, beaming with excitement. “Thank you!” she cries loud enough to draw some tuts and shushes from the librarians. 

 

 “Thank you,” she repeats. This time whispering.

 

 You nod politely, watching as she opens the book to the first page and quickly her focus falls away from you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “Maybe after I’ve finished with it,” you tell Liz, taking it back. 

 

 The smile drops from her face and her eyes watch with disappointment as you take the book back. “Okay,” she says, “I’d love to read it. Once you’re done.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “I need to know more about the amulet,” you say.

 

 Liz lets her enthusiastic smile waver slightly and adjusts her glasses as she matches your serious demeanour. “Okay. How can I help?”

 

 "Firstly, where did it come from?"

 

 “There’s an old shop on Avian Lane,” she replies. “Wedged between McTafey’s bar and some other building. It’s funny - until I was looking for it I don’t remember being aware of it before.”

 

 “Magic?” you ask. Liz shrugs.

 

 “There’s an old lady that runs it,” she continues. “She was sweet and kind. Reminded me of my grandmother. When I picked out the amulet off a stand of old jewelry and rings, she told me that I was meant to find it. She practically gave it away. And slipped the note into the shopping bag when I paid for it.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “An old lady in a mysterious junk shop? Did she ask if you were from Hogwarts?”

 

 
 Liz’s mischievous grin returns. “Scoff all you want, but you’re the woman who sometimes looks like other people. Who knows what’s real and fiction anymore.”
 
 
 Liz’s mischievous grin returns. “Scoff all you want, but you’re the man who sometimes looks like a girl. Who knows what’s real and fiction anymore.”

 
 

 “Do you know anything more about the amulet?” you ask, trying to change the topic from your current physical form.

 

 Liz shrugs. “Only what I found in my research. Something to help those who need help. I bet that old lady knows more though.”

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 “I need to know as much as you know about… everything,” you begin. “About *magic*,” you add, almost conspiratorially. “If I’m going to help.”

 

 She takes a deep breath and nods, glancing around the corridor checking if anyone is listening. “Alright. I’ll tell you what I know.”

 

 "So, what is it?" you ask her.

 

 “What is it? It’s amazing,” she says, excitedly. “And terrifying, of course. But still - can you believe it? Actual magic. In the real world.” 

 

 You stare back at her. Not for the first time, she tapers her enthusiasm. “I guess you can believe it,” she adds.

 

 “What do you know about it?” you ask.

 

 “Just a bit,” she says, lowering her voice to a hushed tone. “It feels like warmth. Inside your body. Like when you stand next to a fire and suddenly feel the heat. Except, it’s inside you.”

 

 "How did you learn about it?" 

 

 "Google," she says, with a smile. "Or a bit of research here. You would be surprised how many books this place has nested away."

 

 “When I was first testing my research,” she continues. “Late one night I thought I’d just try. I tried a spell I’d uncovered that claimed to put someone to sleep. I felt a rush. Fire. Energy inside my body. Then two hours later, I woke up.”

 

 You nod, silently. Thinking about the similar sensation you felt when you used the amulet. After a moment, you focus again. “You can cast spells?” 

 

 It’s her turn to nod, that gleaming smile returning. “Just one. Sends people to sleep. Plus, they have trouble remembering anything recent. The more I practise, the longer people forget. My mum has been complaining of forgetting things a lot recently.”

 

 Liz looks to you, a glint in her eye. “I can teach you, if you like.”

 Liz looks to you, a glint in her eye. “I can teach you, if you like. One thing though - every book I’ve read says that magic can only be learned by a woman.”

 
 

 Without waiting for a response, Liz rips out a page from her notebook and scrawls her phone number down. She hands it to you. “Call me in the evening and I’ll come over."

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 
 
 You focus the spell carefully, weaving the magic as Elizabeth stares at you. For a moment, the air around her seems to still, and then blinks as if a new thought just occurred to her. When she resumes, her tone is the same, but there’s an ease in her demeanor that wasn’t there before.

 

 "You know," she says, tilting her head slightly, "it’s actually kind of fun talking to you. You don’t just zone out like half the people here." She smiles warmly, her hands gesturing as she dives back into the flow of the conversation. "Anyway, as I was saying.. well. What was I saying? I've lost my train of thought. Was there something you needed from me?"

 

 Her energy remains high, her grin returning. There’s a subtle shift, though. She seems more attentive to you, leaning in slightly as she listens, her smile lingering a little longer.

 
 You steady yourself, weaving the spell as Elizabeth talks. The magic flows toward her, but the moment it reaches her, it dissipates entirely, like a ripple vanishing in still water. She stops mid-sentence, her bright, curious expression hardening in an instant as her gaze snaps to yours.

 

 "Wait." Her voice is quiet, almost calm, but there’s a dangerous edge to it. "Did you just -" She exhales sharply, her jaw tightening. "Was that a charm spell? On me?"

 

 Her tone rises, incredulous. "What is wrong with you? Do you seriously think I wouldn’t notice?" She takes a step forward, her eyes narrowing as her usual enthusiasm turns into a cold, cutting anger. "You really thought you could manipulate me? After everything I’ve said about Charlton? Do you even listen when I talk?"

 

 Elizabeth shakes her head, her hands clenched into fists at her sides. "I don’t know what’s worse. That you thought it would work or that you thought I wouldn’t care. Here’s the thing," she says, her voice dropping to a sharp whisper, "I do care. And I don’t ever want to feel like someone’s trying to pull that kind of garbage on me again."

 

 She steps back, her usual energy completely drained, replaced by a cold, bitter disappointment. "Next time, just talk to me like a normal person. Or don’t talk to me at all."
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 “Hey Liz,” you begin. “This is going to sound funny, but I had a dream..."

 

 Liz gives you a smirk. “Am I about to get an insight into your wild fantasies, ?”

 

 You roll your eyes. “I’m serious, Liz. This was intense. Magical, even.”

 

 At this, Liz turns her head to the side slightly. Her smile wavers. “What do you mean?”

 

 “I dreamed that I was having coffee with Jennifer,” you begin. “When we first became friends. Except, we were interrupted by Dan Mandel. From work. He wouldn’t shut up about men being men.”

 “I dreamed that I was back on a date with Jennifer,” you begin. “When we first started dating. Except, we were interrupted by Dan Mandel. From work. He wouldn’t shut up about men being men.”

 

 Liz shrugs. “That sounds like the typical Charlton man. Come on, . It was just a dream."

 

 You grimace. “There’s more. When I woke up, I felt…” You drift off, trying to find words to describe the nagging feeling in the back of your brain. “Do I look different to you?”

 

 
 She gives you an appraising look. “Nothing strikes out. Maybe a few more bags under the eyes. Finding it hard to sleep lately?”

 She chuckles. “Do you really want me to answer that?”

 

 “Come on, Liz,” you shut her down. “I think something’s different. Something’s changed. But I can’t remember what it is.”

 

 “So then, don’t worry about it?” Liz says, a hint of impatience to her words.

 

 “What if it’s permanent, though. What if… it continues. And I can’t see the changes when they happen.”

 

 Liz considers your words, thinking. After a long pause, she sighs. “Listen, if you’re really concerned there’s things you can try. That amulet isn’t the only source of magic in Charlton, after all.”

 

 “I came across a few things whilst studying,” she continues. “There’s articles online about the flower power movement. How it had a big presence here. They experimented, and not just with love, if you know what I mean. They were into expanding their minds."

 

 "Like with acid?" you ask.

 

 "And other things." Liz giggles. "There’s some magazines in the library stacks from that time. They set up their own publishing house in Charlton. Rumour is, their publications could - again - expand their minds."

 

 "Even I wouldn’t risk playing around with them, but if you’re desperate then it might be worth you taking a look at.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “You think reading old magazines is going to help?” 

 

 Liz rolls her eyes. “Use your brain, dummy. This is Charlton. I wouldn’t mention it if there wasn’t something special about them. Try looking up Sally Hope Publishing. Word of warning though. I wouldn't touch anything that group put out. And that's coming from me.”

 

 She gives you a grin. With her boundless enthusiasm for magic, you wonder exactly what could scare Liz off. But if it could help you, perhaps it's worth investigating.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 "I was wondering...” you say. “Do you know of any spell that could let someone be in two places at once?"

 

 That gets her attention. She arches an eyebrow, smirking. "Isn’t that what the amulet’s for? You and Emily, pulling the twin act. Pretty convincing, if you ask me."

 

 You shake your head. "I don’t mean as Emily. I mean me. As me."

 

 You explain everything. The demotion to secretary, the mountain of admin, the missed meetings, the feeling of everything slipping through your fingers. You’re trying to keep your job and investigate the school, but there’s too much. And Emily suggested… maybe magic could help.

 

 Liz leans back, watching you with interest now. “So Emily’s the one pushing magical body doubles now? Guess she’s really getting into it.”

 

 You hesitate. “Or maybe she’s feeling left out.”

 

 Liz shrugs. “Could be both.”

 

 You wait. But she just sighs. “I don’t know anything that would do that. At least, not cleanly. Not safely.”

 

 "Nothing?" you ask. "No workaround?"

 

 She gives you a look. “You could try the junk shop. You-know-who, I mean. If anyone in this town has a line on obscure magic, it’s her.”

 

 You nod slowly. “And no one else? Nothing that you’ve come across in your research that could help?”

 

 Liz is quiet a beat too long.

 

 “There are… fragments,” she says carefully. “Notes that infer the bits of magic scattered around Charlton. Someone had some fun way back when playing around with it. But they’re charms. Trinkets. Nothing like what you’re describing. What you want is more advanced than I know about. Even anything at the school.”

 

 You lean in. “There must be something. Someone.”

 

 Liz’s expression tightens. Then, reluctantly: “If you can’t find help here... well, there’s the carnival.”

 

 Your stomach twists. “The one outside town?”

 

 She nods. “I don’t know much. Just that every time it rolls in, something strange happens. Old papers talk about sudden fights, people going missing, unexplained accidents. Always when the carnival’s here.”

 

 You frown. “You think that’s it’s magic?”

 

 Liz shudders. “I think it’s something. I’ve walked past it, and I swear - I feel cold. Not like weather-cold. Like... wrong. Skin-crawling wrong.”

 

 She meets your eyes. “But if you’re serious about this, maybe that’s where you’ll find what you need.”

 

 She adds, almost as an afterthought: “If you’re that desperate.”

 

 Actions

 <> 

 “I had some trouble with a spell,” you begin. “I tried casting it on the school janitor, but it didn’t work.”

 

 “You tried to cast magic on that creepy janitor?” Liz exclaims, failing to keep her voice low. “That’s bold, . Even for you.”

 

 “It was in the basement,” you correct her. "No one saw.”

 

 She raises an eyebrow, but shrugs it off. “What happened?”

 

 “I cast it correctly,” you tell her, trying to ignore her scowl. “But it just didn’t take. Almost as if something was protecting him.” You snort. “It’s lucky he’s not the smartest tool in his box.”

 

 Liz offers you only a wince before speaking. “Sounds like it’s nothing to do with you. Maybe there’s something at the school that affects magic. I wouldn’t know - I might love all this, but I would think twice about using magic at school.”

 

 “But maybe ask our mutual friend,” she adds. “If anyone is old enough to know what’s what, it’s her.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

text:
“Can you help me do my make-up?” you ask her. 

 

 Emily raises an eyebrow. "This is a role reversal. Until recently I was asking you."

 

 "You know your face better," you reply.

 

 She shrugs. "Okay. Let's go to the bathroom. This better be worth it."

 
 “Can you help me do my make-up?” you ask her. 

 

 For a moment she just stares at you. “Fine. Let’s go to the bathroom. This had better be worth it.”

 
 
 
 You follow her as she leads you to the bathroom. She instructs you to sit on the bath rim and she takes out a number of products from the cabinet.

 

 For the next fifteen minutes, Emily applies a variety of products to your face. She works quickly and silently, having done this time and time before. You sit passively as creams are worked across your face, powder is peppered over your skin and gloss is pressed against your lips.

 

 “Hold still,” she says when you squirm. “We’re almost done.”

 

 Finally, Emily steps back and looks at you. “There. Take a look.” She nods towards the bathroom mirror.

 

 You stand up and glance at your reflection. The face of Emily stares back at you, but it’s not the image you’ve become accustomed to. Her eyes look large and radiant. Her lips are glossy and pronounced. Her skin is smooth and clear of the blemishes you’ve noticed as you’ve inhabited her body.

 

 You look cute.

 

 *Or do you mean sexy?*

 She smirks a little. "You might recognise a few things. I haven't got a lot that you didn't hand down to me."

 Emily shrugs. "Let's go have a look in wardrobe, then."

 
 “Do you think you could help me pick out some clothes?” you say to her quietly.

 

 She rolls her eyes. “You’re really going all in on this aren’t you? Fine. Let’s go to my room.”

 
 

 You follow Emily into her bedroom and sit down on her bed as she looks through her wardrobe. “If it were me, I’d just wear something casual. You don’t want to give him any ideas. She pulls out a pair of jeans and a T-shirt. What about this?”

 

 You glance at her selection, remembering that Dennis asked you to wear something nice. You don’t think that jeans and a T-shirt was what he had in mind.

 “That's fine,” you tell her. She throws the T-shirt and jeans down on the bed. “I would say try it on, but I think the fit shouldn't be a problem.”

 

 You begin to take off your clothes, feeling a bit strange stripping down to your underwear in this form. You've changed in front of Emily more times than you can remember, but it feels foreign to do it as her. She watches you as you do so, a curious look as she observes her body from an outside perspective.

 

 "Do you think I've lost weight?" she asks, as you pick up the clothes from the bed.

 

 You pull on the jeans and T-shirt, not replying. The jeans hug your legs and the T-shirt is snug, feeling tight across your breasts. “What do you think?” you ask Emily.

 

 She walks over to you and pulls at your clothes, adjusting them slightly. “There,” she says, then adds: “You look cute.”

 

 You smile meekly at her, trying to digest how strange this scenario is for both of you. “I should get going,” you say.

 

 “Enjoy,” she deadpans. “And don’t do anything I would do. I mean it. Anything else?”

 
 “That will do,” you tell her. She throws the T-shirt and jeans down on the bed. “I would say try it on, but I think the fit shouldn't be a problem.”

 

 You look between her and the clothes, hesitating. She senses your reluctance. “I’ve seen it all before. Literally.”

 

 You don’t reply and once again she sighs, turning around. “I thought sisters were supposed to be okay getting undressed in front of each other,” she says.

 

 You begin to take off your clothes and pull on the jeans and T-shirt, not replying. The jeans hug your legs and the T-shirt is snug, feeling tight across your breasts. “You can turn around now,” you tell Emily.

 

 She walks over to you and pulls at your clothes, correcting how you’ve put the clothes on. “There,” she says, then adds: “You look cute.”

 

 You smile meekly at her, trying to digest how strange this scenario is for both of you. “I should get going,” you say.

 

 “Enjoy,” she deadpans. “And don’t do anything I would do. I mean it. Anything else?”

 
 

 **Actions**

 “I was thinking, maybe a dress?” you say to your sister. Her eyebrows raise, but she turns back to her wardrobe. “You really want his help, don’t you?” 

 

 She flicks through the hangers and pulls out a dress, throwing it on to the bed. It’s the sundress that you remembered Emily wearing on the holiday last year. You remember when you first changed. Seeing your toned legs stretching out from your torso, exposed as the hem clung to your thighs.

 

 "This wasn't one of mine," you say, as you pick up the cotton dress. "I remember you wearing it on holiday."

 

 "I'm surprised you noticed," she says, grinning. "Your attention was consumed by that lifeguard."

 

 You take off your clothes and pull the dress over your head, letting it fall down your body. It hangs off your shoulders, but looking down you see again how low-cut the dress is, exposing the tops of your breasts. The hem cuts off halfway down your thigh. You consider that whilst you won’t have to be careful sitting down, it shows off a lot of your toned legs.

 

 “Here,” Emily says as she emerges again from her wardrobe. She holds out a pair of sandals with a small heel to them. “These will look good with it.”

 

 You sit down on the bed again to put on the shoes. When you’re done, you stand and Emily makes some minor adjustments to how the dress rests on your figure.

 “We really need his help,” you tell your sister. “I think it needs to be something... a bit more sexy.”

 

 Emily stops what she’s doing and looks at you. “This is just about getting Dennis' help, right? You’re not looking forward to this, are you?”

 

 You snort. “Of course not.” But Emily’s narrowed eyes tell you that she doesn’t believe you. 

 

 She turns back to the wardrobe and rummages in the back, where you can tell she stores things she doesn’t typically wear. After a minute, she throws down two pieces of clothing on the bed. “That’s the best I can do.”

 

 You look at her choices. A denim miniskirt that you’ve only seen Emily wear a couple of times in the city, which you're certain she bought when she was a few inches shorter. And a strapless crop top that you only recall seeing her in when she went through a phase of sneaking out to parties to try and impress a boy.

 

 "Slutty enough for you?" she asks, raising an eyebrow.

 

 You take off your clothes and put the outfit on. The skirt drops just below your buttocks. You know you are going to have to be careful standing up and sitting down. 

 

 The crop top warrants you taking off your bra. You pull it over your shoulders and adjust it around your breasts, feeling your nipples rub against the fabric. You feel vulnerable with your stomach exposed.

 

 “If you are going all in, you might as well wear these,” Emily says, holding out a pair of heeled platform boots. “Just be careful not to fall and twist your leg.”

 

 You sit down on the bed, keeping your legs firmly squeezed together to avoid the ever-present threat of flashing. Once you’ve put on the boots, you stand. They are higher than you are used to wearing. You are surprised that your sister has taller heels than you.

And a strapless crop top that you only recall seeing her in when she went through a phase of sneaking out to parties to try and impress a boy.

 

 Looking back to Emily, you catch her judging eyes. “Do you mind?” you say quietly, motioning for her to turn around. She shakes her head, but does so.

 "I just couldn’t write those horrible lines in class” you try. “But I’m sorry."

 

 
 Emily stares at you, arms still crossed, and exhales slowly. “*You* couldn’t?” she repeats, voice tight. “I have to do that everyday, . I don't get a choice. And you don't if you're me, either.”

 

 She rubs her temples, clearly frustrated. “You don’t have to mean it. You just write the stupid lines and move on.”

 

 There’s a pause, and then she shakes her head, her frustration bleeding into something else. Concern. “You do realize this town doesn’t forget, right? You think Prichard’s just going to let this go? She'll be watching me closely from now on."

 

 "I'm sorry, Em," you try. "I just couldn't do it."

 

 Your sister stares hard at you, then sighs. "I get it. It's demeaning. I know."

 

 She looks away for a moment, chewing on her lip. “What happens next time, though?” she mutters, her voice quieter now. “When I walk into class, and I don’t even know what I did? If you're going to pretend to be me, a little heads-up would be nice.”

 

 "You're right," you reply. "I should have told you."

 

 She lets out a breath, rubbing her arms before finally looking back at you. “Just… don’t make this a habit,” she mutters, softer now.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily lets out a soft laugh, her frustration vanishing in an instant. “That’s what this is about?” She leans back against the cushions, shaking her head. “You really thought that was worth detention?”

 

 She gives you an almost pitying look. “Look, Prichard expects you to fall in line. You don’t have to mean it. You just do it, and she’ll leave you alone.”

 

 Her fingers toy with a strand of her hair as she smirks. “Honestly, you made it way harder on yourself than it had to be. And that makes things harder on me.”

 

 She shakes her head, her amusement draining from her face. “Next time, don’t make things so complicated. Just do the exercise, pass my lessons and don't make my life harder because you have a crisis of conscience.”

 

 You stare back at your sister, but she looks away, clearly done with this conversation.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 "It’s just detention,” you say. “It's all part of the plan, Em. Don’t make a big deal out of it."

 

 
 Emily lets out an incredulous scoff. “Oh, sure, it’s just detention,” she snaps. “Except now I have to deal with the consequences of *your* choices.”

 

 She shakes her head, standing up and pacing slightly. “I don’t want to be on her bad side. She remembers things. She holds grudges.” Her voice lowers slightly. “You don’t have to deal with that. *I* do.”

 

 She exhales through her nose, looking down for a moment before meeting your gaze again. “If you want to pick fights with teachers, fine,” she says, her voice quieter but firm. “But don’t drag me into it.”

 

 Her words feel less like an order and more like a quiet plea.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily laughs, rolling her eyes. “Yeah, exactly,” she says easily. “Who cares? It’s just detention.”

 

 She stretches her arms above her head, completely relaxed. “But next time, just avoid it. Just smile at her, tell her what she wants to hear or do what she says, and move on.”

 

 To your surprise, Emily then winks. “You’d be amazed at how easy people are to handle when you give them exactly what they expect.”

 

 She watches you for a moment, tilting her head. “You really should try it sometime,” she adds, almost teasing. “It’s way easier.”

 

 Her words are light and playful. But the ease with which she says it makes something in your stomach twist.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You take a breath, keeping your voice steady. "I had to get close to them. They know things about the school. This was the best way."

 

 
 Emily stares at you, her frustration twisting into something more like disbelief. “You had to?” she repeats, voice tight. “You had to parade me around like some Charlton doll just to dig up dirt on the cheerleaders?”

 

 She lets out a short, bitter laugh, shaking her head. “Do you know what Christina and her little clones are like? They talk so much about, like, ‘sisterhood’ and ‘teamwork,’ but the second you don’t match their exact vibe, you’re out. And they don’t just ignore you. They ruin you.”

 

 She exhales sharply, rubbing her temples. “And now, thanks to you, I’m in. At least as far as they’re concerned. I’m supposed to sit at their table, act like I care about their stupid designer bags, laugh at their awful jokes. And if I don’t? I become their next favorite joke.”

 

 Her voice dips slightly, her fingers gripping the back of the couch. “I can’t let that happen. Which means I have to play along.” She fixes you with a hard stare. “So congratulations. You just signed me up for months of pretending to give a damn.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily lets out an amused laugh, shaking her head. “Ohhh, so you had a plan.” She leans back against the cushions, stretching her arms above her head. “And here I thought you just wanted to have a little fun.”

 

 She waves a hand dismissively. “Honestly? Who cares about all that? Britney, Chrissie - they’re everything in Charlton. And I’m in. That’s what matters.”

 

 She grins, her excitement bubbling over. “I used to think you were such a stick-in-the-mud, but look at you.” She giggles, shaking her head. “You actually came through for me.”

 

 She wriggles on the couch, stretching slightly before turning back to you. “Can’t wait to get out onto that pitch,” she purrs, practically glowing. “The boys are going to love it.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 Your stomach twists as you meet her gaze. "I didn’t really think about what it meant for you," you admit. "I just did it."

 

 
 Emily lets out a sharp, incredulous laugh. “You didn’t think about it?” She presses a hand to her forehead. “You...” She stops herself, inhaling slowly before exhaling through her nose.

 

 For a second, she just stares at you, like she’s trying to understand. “Do you get what you just did?” she asks, her voice quieter now. “You didn’t just sign me up for some dumb after-school club. You made me one of them.”

 

 She gestures vaguely, frustration bubbling up again. “Britney, Christina, all of them. The girls who walk around acting like their shoes are worth more than people’s lives. The girls who laugh at anyone who doesn’t fit their little picture-perfect idea of Charlton.”

 

 Her voice softens slightly, but it doesn’t make it any less painful. “And now, I’m one of them.” She swallows, her shoulders dropping just a little.

 

 “You want to know what the worst part is?” She lets out a small, exhausted laugh. “The boys. I already know what’s coming. The attention, the flirting, the expectations.” She shakes her head. “They’re going to see me differently now. And I can’t stop it.”

 

 You step forward, your voice low but sincere. “I’m so sorry, Emily. I got carried away. I wasn’t thinking about you, just… what I needed to do. I won’t make a decision like that again. As you.”

 

 Emily closes her eyes for a moment before sighing, finally meeting your gaze again. “Just… don’t do something like this again,” she mutters. “I know you didn’t mean to screw me over. But think next time, okay?”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily blinks at you, then smirks, tilting her head. “Really? Because I think you do.” She lets out a small, incredulous giggle, shaking her head. “I think you know exactly what it meant for me. You're just not willing to admit that you wanted it, too?”

 

 She crosses her arms, studying you. “You saw them. The way they get treated. And you got up there and felt the eyes on you. The attention. The power.”

 

 She leans forward slightly, her voice dropping. “You wanted a taste of it. Of being them. Because they’re everything in Charlton. And you liked it.”

 

 You shake your head. "That's not it at all, Em. I just took advantage of the situation."

 

 She turns her nose up as she flicks her hair over her shoulder. “Now that concerns me. You might have done right this time, . But what happens next time if your little flight of fancy goes against the grain. Are you going to cozy up to Heather Oats next, too?"

 

 You step forward, your voice low but sincere. “I’m so sorry, Emily. I got carried away. I wasn’t thinking about you, just… what I needed to do. I won’t make a decision like that again. As you.”

 

 She purses her lips. “See you don't. You don’t get how Charlton works. I do. Britney, Christina, the squad. They matter. So, here’s the deal: stay out of things at school that don't concern you. This is *my* shot. *My* future. Not yours.”
 

 She leans back, completely at ease. “So don’t mess it up for me.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You exhale, rubbing the back of your neck. "It was the curse," you admit. "I was trying to do the work, but I couldn’t focus. I could barely keep my eyes open. It was like something was pulling me under. Everything felt hard, even when I was trying my best."

 

 
 Emily lets out a sharp breath, rubbing her arms as she processes what you just said. “That’s… stupid,” she mutters, shaking her head. “You should be fine at maths. It’s your thing.”

 

 She exhales, running a hand through her hair. “So it wasn’t just that you forgot how to do it?” she asks, her tone still edged with irritation. “You were trying - but it didn’t work?”

 

 You nod. Her voice drops slightly, some of the anger fading into something more thoughtful. “That’s actually… kind of awful.”

 

 She looks away for a second, then sighs. “I know what it’s like to sit there, knowing you’re supposed to get something, but nothing clicks.”

 

 She rubs her arms, her frustration shifting into something more subdued. “Just… try to avoid it in the future, okay?” Her voice is quieter now, concern peeking through. “You don’t need to put yourself through that again.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily stares at you for a second before suddenly bursting into laughter. “Oh my God,” she gasps, clutching her stomach. “You... you really couldn’t do maths?”

 

 She wipes a tear from the corner of her eye, still giggling. “Man, I bet you loved that. Once top of your class, university prodigy, fumbling through equations like some clueless airhead.”

 

 She leans in slightly, eyes gleaming. “You talk a good game, . About how you can use your big brain to get ahead of Charlton.” Her smirk fades slightly. “But if you can’t even handle maths anymore, then what’s the point of you going to school as me, at all?”

 

 She tilts her head, an eyebrow raised in curiosity. “Honestly, I don’t even care about this curse anymore. But if you’re too busy floundering in my classes to actually pass, maybe it’s time you stop.”

 

 Her smile sharpens. “And if I need to take Rogers up on those extra lessons?” She shrugs. “Well, Michelle doesn’t seem to mind the attention. Maybe I won’t either.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You take a breath and meet her gaze. "I needed to get into the Maths room alone," you say. "There’s something wrong with it. I had to investigate."

 

 
 Emily’s expression flickers, her frustration twisting into something more controlled. “You needed to get into the Maths room?” she repeats slowly, voice cautious.

 

 Then her expression hardens. “So you got me detention, just so you could snoop around?”

 

 She crosses her arms, her nails digging lightly into her sleeves. “You really don’t think things through, do you?” Her voice is quieter now, but there’s an edge to it. “Rogers already gives me too much attention as it is.”

 

 She exhales sharply, glancing toward the window. “I don’t know what Michelle does in those extra lessons,” she mutters, her voice lower now. “But I don’t want to find out the hard way.”

 

 For a second, she looks like she might say more. But then she stops, lips pressing into a thin line. Whatever’s on her mind, she’s not about to share it.

 

 She exhales, shifting slightly. “You keep saying you’re trying to figure out what’s going on.” She lifts her chin slightly, fixing you with a tired look. “Then just… figure it out. Stop making my life harder in the process.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Emily raises an eyebrow, then lets out a soft, knowing hum. “Ohhh,” she purrs. “So that’s what you were up to.”

 

 She leans forward slightly, intrigued. “Honestly? Smart.” She flashes a grin. “You needed information, so you made an opportunity for yourself. It's not like anyone at school really cares about me getting detention. Some of the boys probably find it appealing.”

 

 She tilts her head, her smile growing. “It’s about time you started thinking like me.”

 

 There’s no irritation, no concern. Instead, she’s studying you, almost approvingly.

 

 She stretches, letting out a slow, satisfied sigh. “And detention doesn’t matter anyway. Rogers will get over it.” Her smile curves slightly, a glint of amusement in her eyes. “And if I do have to spend some evenings with him because of you… well. That just may be a bonus.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You sigh and lean against the counter. "I need to get access to the Business Studies room. This is the best way to do it."

 

 
 Emily exhales sharply, shaking her head. “Are you serious?”

 

 She paces slightly, rubbing her arms. “Do you know what DeBussy does with what she learns?” Her voice lowers slightly. “I’ve seen it. Someone lets something slip, and suddenly, she’s got them.” She presses her lips together. “She finds out about family problems, grades slipping, secret relationships. Then she uses them. And now you are sitting in that club, handing her exactly what she wants.”

 

 Her voice drops even further, her arms tightening around herself. “It’s not just random people, you know. It’s my friends.” There’s a flicker of something raw in her expression. “People I sit with every day. People who trust me.”

 

 She looks at you again, something uncertain in her eyes. “I know you think this is important. But is it that important?” Her voice is quieter now, almost pleading. “Is finding out what’s happening worth hurting people?”

 

 She stares back at you for a moment, then looks away. “I thought you were better than that.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Good to see you’re still around,” he says. “You learn that trick with your necklace from Annie, or are you born this way?”

 

 She giggles softly.

 

 “Reckon she’s earned a coffee, don’t you?” Dan asks, not even looking at you now. “Or we could step into the back and talk about her future here.”

 

 You step in, your tone sharp. “She’s working.”

 

 
 Dan's smile fades slightly. “She’s allowed a break, isn’t she?” Then, quieter: “Offer still stands. I could put in a good word about her . See if Thompson would take them back.”

 Dan shrugs, unbothered. “Your call. But maybe Thompson needs a reminder of how things used to run smoother.”
 
 

 Emily gives you a sly look, waiting for permission.

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 <>

 
 
 You’ve been waiting too long.

 

 Whatever Dan wanted to “chat” about, it’s taking more than a few minutes. The front desk feels quieter without Emily nearby, but it’s not in a peaceful way. It’s the kind that tightens your chest. You keep glancing toward the door, hoping to hear footsteps. Nothing.

 

 Then, at last, the door opens.

 

 
 Emily steps out, head lowered, cheeks pale. She doesn't speak. You hear Dan's voice bellow out as she walks through the door. "See you again soon, sweetheart."

 

 Her eyes flick to you, but only briefly. Instead she sits down in silence. A long moment passes, but you hear her sigh. "Alright. What's next?"

 

 You open your mouth. “Emily…”

 

 She cuts you off with a look. "Don't. He's just a creep. Enough said. You were showing my the filing on the server."

 

 You monotonously walk through the details of how to file documents across the network, but your voice is flat and emotionless. Emily keeps her comments to a minimum, focusing on the work at hand.

 

 The last hour of the day drips away. Soon, it is time for Emily to leave.

 

 "I'll see you at home," you say. "I've got to finish up."

 

 She nods. Then silently picks up her bag and walks out the door without a word.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 The door swings open mid-laugh. Dan’s voice is louder than it needs to be: “Maybe next time, you can show me how you do it.”

 

 Emily stands in the doorway, looking back over her shoulder into the office. Her voice, lowered and sultry, sings with amusement. “Maybe I will.”

 

 She saunters back to the desk, cheeks flushed, tucking a strand of hair behind her ear. There’s a new bounce in her step, something performative in the way she smooths her skirt and pretends not to notice your stare.

 

 You lower your voice. “You should be careful with him. He’s not --”

 

 “He’s not that bad,” she interrupts gently, almost dreamily. “Actually kind of charming, once you get past the bluster.”

 

 For the next hour you walk her through how to file documents across the network, but her attention is elsewhere. She keeps staring back over to the office door.

 

 The day soon gets away from you and before you know it, Emily's afternoon has passed.

 

 "Thanks for today," she says as she picks up her bag. "And thanks for not being, well, overbearing." She grins. "It's nice to have... some fun."

 

 You watch her go without comment. She bounces over to the door with her grin not leaving her face.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 After some time, you hear the office door creak open. Emily steps out, her face carefully blank. She doesn’t look at you, doesn’t say a word. She walks straight to the desk, drops into the seat, and picks up where she left off like nothing happened.

 

 For a moment, you just watch her. Eventually, you ask, “Everything okay?”

 

 She doesn’t look up. “Fine.”

 

 Taking her at her word, you start to show her some complexity in the calendar scheduling system. She follows along, clicking when told, nodding when expected. There’s no conversation. No connection. Just silence filled with keystrokes.

 

 As the hour ends, Emily gathers her things.

 

 “Thanks,” she says, still not meeting your gaze.

 

 And she leaves. You glance over to the door, wondering what Dan said to her this time.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 The door opens with a laugh. Dan’s, loud and satisfied.

 

 Emily appears a second later, grinning as she steps out. Her cheeks are flushed again. You catch the soft sway of her hips as she walks back to the desk, seemingly unaware of how it looks.

 

 She slides into her seat, humming something under her breath.

 

 You keep your voice low. “Be careful with him.”

 

 Emily just shrugs. “He’s funny.”

 

 You blink, unsure what to say. But she’s already leaning back in her chair, half-listening as you try to walk her through filing protocols. She keeps glancing toward the door, as if half-expecting Dan to call her back in.

 

 Eventually, after another hour passes, she stands and grabs her bag.

 

 “Catch you later,” she says breezily, already moving for the door. “Same time next week?”

 

 The door clicks shut behind her.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 

 
 
 Dan finally gets the hint, wordlessly leaving and the door swings shut behind him with a smug little click. Silence fills the front office again. Not peace, but pressure.

 

 You and Emily don’t speak at first.

 

 Eventually, you clear your throat and gesture to the screen. “We should get back to the scheduling interface. You were asking about recurring appointments?”

 

 She nods, wordlessly. You ease back into the teaching.

 

 
 Emily follows along, if a little slowly. Her focus isn’t quite there, and you can see her glancing now and then at the door Dan walked through. More out of dread than distraction.

 

 You guide her through the double-booking system and how Clive prefers phone confirmation on anything marked 'tentative.' She listens. She's trying. She doesn't say much, but when she does, her voice is steady.

 

 By the end of the hour, she’s moving with more confidence again. As she gathers her things, she pauses beside you.

 

 “Thanks,” she says. “For stepping in. I didn’t… I didn’t want to be alone with him.”

 

 A beat passes. “I mean, not just because of him. But… it was nice for someone to have my back.”
 
 

 She smiles and opens the door, stepping out into Charlton.

 
 
You smile too, but are distracted by an email. From Thompson. You don't read it, but you can see from the header he's complaining about 's performance again. Dan must have had a word.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 Emily takes her seat, but her posture is closed. You resume your explanation, but she’s barely engaging. Her replies are clipped. Her fingers tap impatiently at the edge of the desk when you pause.

 

 You walk her through the internal memo process, but she doesn’t seem to be listening. When you ask her to repeat something back, she sighs and leans back. “Do we have to do this? I'm more interested in where you got that dazzling lipgloss."

 

 You give her a look. “We should really focus on work, Emily.”

 

 She pouts, but returns to looking at the screen. Yet after an hour, you have not gotten much further. Emily seems reluctant to learn, almost purposefully derailing your teaching.

 

 "Everything okay?" you try, as the day draws to a close.

 

 She sighs. “You wouldn't understand," she mutters. "I just want to have some fun. Not sitting behind a desk. Following the rules.”

 

 She grabs her bag and stands, moving towards the door. “See you, Annie.”

 

 The door closes gently. But firmly.

 
 
You grimace, but are distracted by an email. From Thompson. You don't read it, but you can see from the header he's complaining about 's performance again. Dan must have had a word.

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 Dan’s exit is a little less dramatic this time, but no less unwanted. The door shuts. Silence returns.

 

 You look over to Emily. “Calendar system?” She gives the faintest nod.

 

 
 She listens quietly as you walk her through the process again. She asks fewer questions this time. Not out of boredom. Just restraint.

 

 There’s a heaviness to her silence, but not bitterness. Just tiredness. She finishes the tasks without fuss.

 

 When the hour ends, she picks up her bag.

 

 “Thanks,” she says simply. “For again keeping him out of my face.”

 

 And she leaves.

 
 
You watch her go, but are distracted by an email. From Thompson. You don't read it, but you can see from the header he's complaining about 's performance again. Dan must have had a word.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 Emily slouches back in her chair as you begin, not bothering to pretend she’s interested. Her eyes glaze over halfway through the example booking flow.

 

 After trying for some time, you stop explaining. "Do we have a problem?"

 

 She lets out a quiet snort. “No, no problem. Not at all. Just once again, I’m not allowed to have any fun.”

 

 No eye contact. No thank-you. Just that.

 

 She stands, pulls her bag over her shoulder, and walks out without another word.

 
 
You watch her go, but are distracted by an email. From Thompson. You don't read it, but you can see from the header he's complaining about 's performance again. Dan must have had a word.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 

 “Hey,” you start carefully. “I need to ask you for a favour.”

 

 Emily looks up, soft smile already on her lips. “Sure. What is it?”

 Emily sighs, folding her arms. “Another one? These days your favours aren’t just picking up milk on the way home from school.”

 
 

 You press on. “This one’s important. I need a personal item from Dennis. Something he treasures. To power the amulet. I need to spend some time as him. See what the boys’ lessons are really like.”

 

 
 Emily gives you a strange look. “That feels odd… thinking about you. As Dennis.”

 Emily wrinkles her nose. “Ew. Why would anyone want to be Dennis? Are you sure this is necessary?”

 
 

 You nod. “It’s the only way.” A pause, then you add, “The thing is, when I asked him, what he really said he wanted was a photo. Of you.”

 

 
 Emily’s mouth drops open, nose wrinkling like she’s smelt something foul. “That’s disgusting. I don’t even want to think about why he wants that.”

 
 Emily bursts out laughing. “That little perv! He wants a picture of me for his private collection? What a loser.”

 
 

 You stay quiet. Emily notices, her reaction fading from her face. “Oh no,” she murmurs, staring at you. “Don’t tell me. You want me to pose for him?”

 

 You don’t answer. The silence is enough.

 

 Emily fidgets, looking away, then back again. Her voice drops, heavy with reluctance. “What exactly is Dennis expecting out of this?”

 

 You shrug, playing dumb. “What do you mean?”

 

 She presses: “You know. What sort of photo is he anticipating?”

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 
 "Just whatever he needs to treasure it," you say. "It needs to mean a lot to him."

 

 
 Her mouth falls open, eyes wide. “I can’t believe you want me to do that,” she says, barely above a whisper.

 

 Guilt burns in your chest, but you push anyway. “It’s important, Em. This could help fight the curse, help the school. Help you.”

 

 Emily shakes her head, hurt spilling into her voice. “And my self-worth? Is that worth less than your investigation?”

 

 The words stop you cold. She swallows and continues, quiet but sharp. “You’re the one asking me to flaunt myself for some pervert, let him take a photo, just so you can get something over him. Is this really the only way forward. Or just the easiest for you?”

 

 You pause, staring at her. She looks up at you, eyes burning with betrayal. “Well?” she presses.

 

 Quietly, you repeat. “It’s important.”

 

 Emily exhales through her nose, rolling her eyes. “It’s always important.” Her voice sharpens. “And Dennis? Do you know what that would happen if he showed people?”

 

 “He won’t,” you reassure her. “Just warn him not to. He’s too enamoured with you to ever betray that.”

 

 She stares at the floor a long moment, then sighs. “Fine. I’ll pose. I’ll try and catch him at school, or in the library.”

 

 “Thanks, Em,” you murmur. “It means a lot.”

 

 Her eyes flick back to yours, dark and wounded. “Seems all I’m good for in this town,” she replies bitterly, before rising and heading upstairs to her bedroom.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Emily’s grin widens, eyes glittering. “So how far are we talking?” she teases. “Suggestive? Underwear? Nude? Or do you want me to go full-on sex tape material?”

 

 You stare, shocked at the words tumbling from her mouth. She scolds you with a sharp laugh. “Don’t look so shocked. You’re the one asking me to flaunt myself for some pervert, let him take a photo, just so you can get something over him. Don’t act like you’re innocent.”

 

 Hesitating, you watch her dangle her foot on the edge of her heel, smiling back knowingly. “Well?” she presses.

 

 Quietly, you repeat. “It’s important.”

 

 Emily rolls her eyes. “It’s always important.” Her voice hardens. “And Dennis? Do you know what that would do to my reputation if he showed people?”

 

 You answer quickly. “He won’t. Just warn him not to. He’s too enamoured with you to ever betray that.”

 

 Emily snorts. “Just my luck it’s a nerd that’s infatuated with me. Couldn’t have been Brendan you needed to transform into?”

 

 “Fine,” she says at last. “I’ll give him a little show. Make him blow his load in his trousers. I’ll try and catch him at school, or in the library.”

 

 “Thanks, Em,” you murmur. “It means a lot.”

 

 Her eyes turn dark, almost unreadable. “Seems that’s all I’m good for in this town,” she replies flatly, before slipping off the sofa and heading upstairs to her bedroom.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You exhale slowly. “Nothing fancy. Just stand there. Let him take something simple. Enough that he’ll treasure it.”

 

 
 Her shoulders sag, relief mixing with frustration. “So you don’t want me to do anything.., improper?”

 

 You shake your head. “No. Just being there will be enough for him. Trust me.”

 

 Emily studies your face, still doubtful. “I still don’t like it,” she says finally. 
 

 Quietly, you repeat. “It’s important.”

 

 “Fine," she says, letting out a sigh. "I’ll try to catch him at school, or maybe the library. I’ll keep it simple.”

 

 “Thanks, Em,” you murmur. “It means a lot.”

 

 She turns away, voice bitter. “Seems even that’s all I’m good for in this town,” she says, before rising from the sofa and heading upstairs.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 Emily raises an eyebrow, almost amused. “That’s it? Just stand there and let him snap something dull? Where's the fun in that?"

 

 You hesitate. “He’ll value it, Em. That’s what matters.”

 

 She smirks faintly, a sharp edge in her voice. “If you say so. He'll probably faint just having me in his frame."

 

 "Don't push him too much," you try to warn her. "It’s important.”

 

 "Fine," she says at last. "I'll find him. He hangs around the AV room or library, doesn't he? I'll let him get his precious picture."
 

 “Thanks, Em,” you murmur. “It means a lot.”

 

 Her eyes turn dark, almost unreadable. “Seems that’s all I’m good for in this town,” she replies flatly, before slipping off the sofa and heading upstairs to her bedroom.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "Hey Em," you begin. "Can I ask you about something?"

 

 Emily stares back at you, nodding absently. “What's up?”

 Emily gives you a skeptical look. "Here we go again."
 
 

 "I was wondering if you'd mind me borrowing some things from your wardrobe." You wince, aware of how odd this all sounds. "When I'm you, I mean."

 

 She narrows her eyes, staring back at you. "You want dress differently?"

 

 You inhale, pausing to muster the words. "I just think it would help. In certain situations.

 

 
 She looks down at herself, eyes lingering on her own clothes. "Are you saying that I look a bit plain?"

 

 You shake your head, trying to course correct. "Not at all. You look great."

 

 "But not enough for when you're pretending to be me?"

 

 You study her face, noting her wide eyes and top teeth biting her bottom lip. She seems almost upset, unable to quite meet your eyes.

 

 "I didn't mean it like that, Em," you reiterate. "It's just..."

 

 "Just you think you can do better?"

 

 You look back at your sister, staring back at you in expectation. "Some situations just need a change," you offer.

 

 Meeting your eyes for only a moment longer, she sighs and shrugs. "Sure. Fine. Feel free to use it. I guess it's sort of yours when you're me, anyway."

 

 But her own eyes linger on clothes. As if she's regarding them with a fresh perspective. You decide to leave her, but you feel the weight of responsibility set into you.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 A smirk forms on her face. "You starting to enjoy the perks of being me, ?"

 

 You shake your head, trying to deflect. "I just need to dress differently for other situations."

 

 An eyebrow raises. "But can't you change my clothes when transform?"

 

 "Yes, but -"

 

 Emily interrupts you with her sniggering. "Sounds to me like you've got a taste of playing dress-up," she comments after her giggles die down.

 

 "Go ahead," she continues. "There's some new skirts in there that you won't have see before." A playful smirk returns to her face. "Might be nice to taste what it's like to show off a bit of skin."

 

 Emily turns back away from you, conversation over. You guess you have gotten permission to go through her stuff. Yet it doesn't feel like a victory.

 

 Because maybe she's more right than you think.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: FlorenceDialogue
text:
“What’s that you’re reading?” you ask Florence.

 

 “Oh this?” Florence says, gesturing to the paperback on the counter. “It’s nothing. Something silly that I’ve been trying to read for the last year.”

 

 You glance down at the cover, noting the title. *“Executive Success - throw punches like a girl in the boardroom.”*

 

 “It's not about travel or other countries," she replies. "So I don't know if it's your thing. But I can't give up being interested in businesses. Even small shops like this one. I know it's stupid. Men make better leaders? Numbers and books are beyond us.”

 

 You follow her plucked eyebrows as they glance at the book. “I keep trying to understand it though. One day, maybe something will stick.”

 

 Looking at the book with interest, it seems personal to her. You could probably use it to power the amulet, if you could get your hands on it.

 You glance down at the cover, noting the title. *“Executive Success - throw punches like a girl in the boardroom.”*

 

 “I’ve always been interested in businesses," she continues. "Even small shops like this one. I used to dream of owning my own. Before I grew up. Men make better leaders anyway, don't you think? Numbers and books are beyond us.”

 

 You follow her plucked eyebrows as they glance at the book. “I keep trying to understand it though. One day, maybe something will stick.”

 Looking at the book with interest, it seems personal to her. You could probably use it to power the amulet, if you could get your hands on it.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 <>

 <>

 
 “Hey Flo,” you say. “Do you ever think about when we were at school?” 

 

 "Sometimes," she replies. "I miss learning. Not so much the teachers, but I miss it. I still like reading. In my spare time of course. Closest I get these days to using my brain is counting out change.”

 

 “I've been thinking about it, recently. Did you notice anything strange?" you continue. "About the lessons."

 

 "Nothing special," she replies. "Only what happened to Tandi. Have you seen her recently? She's really different."

 
 “Hey Flo,” you say. “You went to Charlton Upper School, didn’t you?” 

 

 "Graduated last year," she replies.

 

 “Did you enjoy your time there?” 

 

 She smiles. “Oh yes! I love all those classes. Learning about all those places far away and past history and how businesses work. I still like reading. In my spare time of course. Closest I get these days to using my brain is counting out change.”

 

 “Did you notice anything strange?" you continue. "About the lessons or the teachers." 

 

 "Nothing special," she replies. "There were favourites. Miss DeBussy had a bunch of girls stay behind after school for extra lessons. But not me.” 

 

 "Anything else?" you ask. 

 

 “Only the disappearance of Tandi. But you've heard about that, right?" 

 
 

 Actions

 <> 

 
 “What happened to Tandi?” you ask her.

 

 Flo looks at you, her trademark smile fading. “She's changed. You remember how she was, don't you? Popular. Pretty, did well at school. She's like a different person now.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “How?”

 

 “She spends a lot of time with Annie. They go to the Red Room a lot. And..." The waitress glances around, worried about talking in spite of the shop being empty. "I've overheard some customers. They've seen her working at Dicks.”

 

 Florence pauses, then leans further over the counter towards you. “She’s had some work done, if you know what I mean.”

 

 “I think she now lives out at Misty Falls Caravan Park. Shame. She was really sweet.”
 
 
 “Who was Tandi?” you ask her.

 

 Flo looks at you, her trademark smile fading. “Tandi was in the year below me,” she says in a hushed tone. “On the cheerleading squad. Popular, pretty, did well at school. Until one day, she just stopped turning up.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “What happened to her?”

 

 The waitress glances around, worried about talking in spite of the shop being empty. “No one knows for sure. A few months after I graduated, people started seeing her around town again. Just fleeting. Glances. She doesn’t seem to talk to anyone. And she looks different…”

 

 Florence pauses, then leans further over the counter towards you. “She’s had some work done, if you know what I mean.”

 

 “I think she now lives out at Misty Falls Caravan Park. Shame. She was really sweet.”
 
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 
 "Sounds interesting," you tell her. "Do you think I could borrow it?"

 

 "What, now?" Flo replies, raising an eyebrow. "I wouldn't have expected you to be interested in a book about business."

 

 You nod. "If you’re struggling with it, it could give you a break. I'd like to try it."

 

 She thinks for a moment, then shrugs. "Sure, I was struggling with it anyway." She pushes the paperback over to you. "Maybe you can help me understand it. Just make sure to bring it back after you’re done."

 

 You smile and pick up the book, then thank her.

 <>

 You nod. "If you’re struggling with it, it could give you a break. I’m a fast reader."

 

 She thinks for a moment, then shrugs. “Sure, I was struggling with it anyway.” She pushes the paperback over to you. “Maybe you can help me understand it. Just make sure to bring it back after you’re done.”

 

 You smile and pick up the book, then thank her.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 "What, now?" Flo replies, raising an eyebrow. 

 

 You nod. "If you’re struggling with it, it could give you a break. I’m a fast reader."

 
 
 She smiles politely, but shakes her head. “I think I’ll keep trying. Maybe once I’m done though.”

 

 You look down at the book. For someone who’s been reading for a year, her progress is small. You imagine you’ll be waiting a long time for her to finish.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 You wait until Florence turns back to the coffee machine behind the counter, then quickly reach out and grab the book. Only then do you realise that you don't have any pockets in your trousers to pocket it away. Why did you forget that?

 

 Not a moment later, Florence turns and puts your coffee down in front of you. She notices immediately. “Is that my book, ?”

 
 You wait until Florence turns back to the coffee machine behind the counter, then quickly reach out and grab the book, jamming it into the back pocket of your jeans. 

 

 Not a moment later, Florence turns and puts your coffee down in front of you. She notices immediately. “Where’s my book?” 

 

 No amount of quick thinking can help you with an answer. You watch her pleasant professional attitude fade quickly. “Did you take my book, ?”

 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <>

 
 
 <>

 
 
 
 Feeling yourself blush, you put the paperback back on the counter. “I’m sorry, Flo,” you say. “I don’t know what I was thinking.”

 

 She nods, but takes the book as soon as you put it down and puts it out of reach. “You could have just waited until I was finished with it,” she tells you. “I won’t be reading it forever.”

 

 You don’t say a word. She snorts and turns her back to you, wiping down the coffee machine. You decide to leave her alone for now.
