 She nods, but takes the book as soon as you put it down and puts it out of reach. “You could have just waited until I was finished with it,” she tells you. “I won’t be reading it forever.”

 

 You don’t say a word. She snorts at the inference and turns her back to you, wiping down the coffee machine. You decide to leave her alone for now.

 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 You shake your head. “No, this is my copy,” you say unconvincingly. 

 

 Flo glares at you. “Don’t lie, . You took my book. Give it back!”

 

 Determined to hold on to the paperback, you shrug. “I don’t know what to tell you, Flo. This is mine.”

 

 Flo flares her nostrils and grits her teeth. “You…” she trails off, trying to regain her professional composure. “I think you better leave, .” 

 

 She twirls around and grabs a cloth, scrubbing the coffee machine down with more intensity than could ever be needed to clean it.

 
 You shake your head. “I thought you moved it,” you say unconvincingly. 

 

 Flo glares at you. “Don’t lie, . You took my book. Give it back!”

 

 Determined to hold on to the paperback, you shrug. “I don’t know what to tell you, Flo. I don’t have it.”

 

 Flo flares her nostrils and grits her teeth. “You…” she trails off, trying to regain her professional composure. “I think you better leave, .” 

 

 She twirls around and grabs a cloth, scrubbing the coffee machine down with more intensity than could ever be needed to clean it.

 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 Channelling your innate magical abilities, you focus on Florence and feel the stirring of magic in her mind. "Fall asleep," you mutter, “and let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 Florence’s perfectly plucked eyebrows raise ever so slightly before she collapses, hitting the floor with a crash. You rush around the counter and see her sprawled on the ceramic floor. 

 

 You squat down and check her pulse and her head for bruises. Fortunately she seems okay, albeit in a deep sleep. You can’t be sure how much of the morning she’ll remember when she wakes up, but you are certain she won’t remember the last few minutes.

 

 Gently, you slap her cheek and bring her around. Her eyes flicker open, confused as she sees you beside her. “?” she slurs. “What happened?”

 

 “It’s okay,” you say quietly. “You just fainted.”

 

 You help her to her feet. She holds on to you for balance. “I fainted?”

 

 “You work too much,” you tell her. “Maybe take a day off, okay?”

 

 She nods, her face the picture of confusion. "Maybe I should," she replies.
 
 

 Actions

 <> 

 
 
 You take a breath, focusing the spell carefully as Florence stands across from you, her posture impeccable and her hands folded neatly on the counter. The air around her shifts slightly as the magic takes hold, softening the sharp edges of her demeanor.

 

 "It’s interesting," she says finally, her tone quieter but no less precise. "I hadn’t really thought about it until now, but… I find our conversations stimulating." Her gaze lifts to meet yours, and though her expression remains composed, there’s a warmth in her eyes that wasn’t there before. "You ask good questions. Not the kind I'm used to from other customers."

 

 Florence taps a finger against the table, her brow furrowing slightly, as though deep in thought. "Perhaps I’ve misjudged you," she adds after a moment.

 

 Her words come slower now, each one deliberate, but there’s a softness to her tone that balances her professional banter. As she continues talking, it feels like the space between you has shifted. Like, for once, she’s not just listening to respond, but genuinely hearing you.

 
 This has failed, as Florence isn't magic.

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 You glance over at the teenagers in the booth at the back. “What are they doing here?”

 

 Florence glances up, a fond half-smile playing on her lips. “They’re here most lunchtimes, Jen. Always huddled in whispers, plotting whatever schemes float through their minds." She glances over, wistfully. “It feels like ages since I was that young.”

 

 You look back briefly, before turning again to Flo. “But why aren’t they in class right now?”

 

 Florence rolls her eyes. “Oh come on, Jen. You should know better than most. They’re cheerleaders. They come and go as they please. Just like you did.”
 
 <>
 

 Actions

 <>

title: GladysDialogue
text:
She chuckles. “I am Gladys. Just an owner of a junk shop. Nothing more than that, I’m afraid.”

 

 
 “You’re lying,” you reply. “I’ve never seen this place before and my friend lives opposite it.”
 
 
 “You’re lying,” you reply. “I’ve never seen this place before and my girlfriend lives opposite it.”

 
 

 “Maybe you weren’t looking for it,” she tells you. “It has a funny habit of only attracting those who already know about it. I should really do some marketing, but you can’t teach an old dog new tricks. At least, not whilst they're old.”

 

 
 
 “I did some research,” you try. “And this shop came up. It said you might be able to help me.”

 
 “I was told about you,” you try. “And this shop. They said you might be able to help me.”

 
 

 Gladys grins. “That I can. But you can help an old lady in asking the right questions. Who I am is incidental. What I can tell you is another matter.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 “So. Just to be clear,” you tell Gladys. “Magic is real.”

 

 She laughs. “Yes, dear. By the fact you are here, you must have experienced enough to know that. But that is not your real question, is it?”

 

 You give her a look. “How does it work?”

 

 Gladys smiles. “I haven’t the foggiest. It is something deep-rooted in certain people, attached to their very souls. I have a bit of it attached to me, in spite of what face I am wearing. A condition that I’m sure you can sympathise with, can you not?”

 

 “It does have its limitations,” she continues. “It can be found in anyone, but only a woman can use it. Men are susceptible to it, can be blessed or cursed by it, can use its charmed trinkets. But only a woman can create. Or a soul in a woman’s body, to be specific. A hunch says that may be important to you.”

 

 She looks you up and down. “I can teach you, if you like. If that’s why you’re here.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 “There’s something strange happening at Charlton School,” you tell her. “I was told you could tell me about it.”

 

 “And what do you mean by strange?” Gladys replies. “Go on. Don't dilly dally, dear. Say it. Out loud."

 

 “Something magical,” you tell her after a moment. 

 

 She grins. “How curious. All you must have been through and still hesitant to state the obvious. Very well. Yes, that school is cursed. Some evil men have perverted power beyond their means and have enforced their own worldview on its pupils. They control and manipulate them with magic. I’m afraid it has been going on for some time.”

 

 “Almost as much time as I’ve been waiting for someone powerful enough to challenge them. That is what your amulet was made for.” She offers you a toothy grin. “So it seems we’ve both been surprised of late. But I will not be too quick to judge. Appearances can be deceiving.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 You take out the amulet from your pocket and show it to her. “A friend of mine bought this from you. Can you tell me about it?”

 

 She looks at the amulet, a gleam spreading on her face. She holds her hands over it, as if warming them from its energy. “You’re not exactly what I expected,” she says, staring up at you. “But beggars can’t be choosers.”

 

 “I blessed that amulet with certain powers,” she continues. “Some of them, I think you have already uncovered. But its intent has perhaps been lost on you. Its only directive was that it should find its way to the person with the magical affinity strong enough to put an end to trouble at Charlton School." 

 

 “I did wonder when that girl picked it out from my trinkets if I had blessed it correctly. But now you are in possession of it. Even in my old age, magic still has surprises for me.”

 
 
 Actions

 <>

 “The lessons at Charlton. What are they doing to the students?” 

 

 Gladys smiles again. “Why to manipulate, of course. Truth be told, I haven’t been to the school in decades. These days I tend to shy away from those men. But things seldom change in Charlton. That is the way they like it. The way they maintain it. It’s all about power and control.”

 

 “Are you saying the teachers are responsible?” you ask her.

 

 She chuckles. “Some of them, undoubtedly.”

 

 “But I thought you said that magic could only be used by women?”

 

 Gladys gives you an appraising look. “Very good, dear. Maybe the amulet was onto something with you, after all. The headmaster and his minions have old-fashioned views, where women know their place and men rule the roost. In their minds the sun never set on The Empire.”

 

 She leans over the counter, whispering in spite of no one else being here. “There will be a coven. A group of women, under the guidance of the men. Who they are, I don’t know. They could be the female teachers, other staff, students or even women from the town.”

 

 “They will be instructed by the teachers to curse objects and equipment, curses that make the students as the teachers think they should be. Subservient. Feminine. Or deviant, depending on their desires.”

 

 “If there were to be a hero in all of this, they would need to lift the curses on those things. And put a stop to whoever was cursing, once and for all.”

 <>
 

 Actions

 <>

 
 “Could you teach me to use magic?” you ask directly.

 

 She raises an eyebrow. “So, you think of yourself as a saviour? The one who will free the school from the curse that plagues its students?”

 

 “My sister goes there,” you reply.

 

 You see Gladys eyeing you carefully. “That explains the amulet’s path to finding you. A selfless hero, ready to sacrifice their own well-being in the service of others. Does that sound like you?”

 

 You shrug. “I just want to help.”

 

 “You realise that by walking this path, there will be sacrifices?” she asks. “What you’ve experienced so far is just the tip of the spear. As time passes, the blade will push further and further. Without care, who knows what condition you’ll be left in?”

 

 She notices your weary look. “So tell me, are you sure you’re willing to do what it takes?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “Could you teach me to use magic?” you ask her. 

 

 Gladys cackles. “Forgetful, aren’t you? Magic can only be learned by a woman. I’m afraid that in your condition, you would find the lessons frustrating. There are ways around your impediment, however. I’m sure you are aware of an option or two.”

 

 Her smile fades. “Come back and see me when you are ready. Then we shall see.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 

 
 
 "Will you teach me to remove the curses?" you ask Gladys.

 

 “Spells are tricky things,” she replies. “They can not be easily nullified. I can teach you how to perform the curse. It is known as Ward. That should suffice to amend its properties. A curse changed to do nothing is effectively not a curse at all.”

 

 You nod. “If it helps me stop them.”

 

 Gladys smiles. “Then we shall begin.”

 

 She motions you towards the rocking chair and you take a seat. She instructs you to concentrate on your power and the warmth it burns inside your body. 

 

 You close your eyes, letting your breathing slow. Becoming ever-aware of the magical energies churning inside of you.

 

 “Now,” you hear Gladys say. “Reach out. Look for that sensation outside of your body. In me. In the relics and jewellery scattered on stands. In the shop front and the door.”

 

 You reach out, as instructed. Immediately, you’re struck by presence. Your eyes may be closed, but you can almost see the room. Dark and unlit, but certain things glowing. Burning with magical energy.

 

 “Good,” Gladys says. “Pick one of the trinkets. Concentrate on it.”

 

 You focus your attention on a simple dimpled pint glass that glows brightly in your mind’s eye. It rests on the table near the counter. You can feel the heat from its arcane power. 

 

 “Now. Repeat after me,” Gladys says. “I cause this object with power beyond its power. Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by none who use it.”

 

 You brace yourself, ready to say the words.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You look at Gladys directly. “Can you teach me how to remove the curses?” 

 

 “Alas, my dear, you are missing some essential body parts,” she replies. “Or carrying around an extra one. Come back to me when your body is more suited to the use of magic. I suspect that for you, this will not be hard.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 “Can you teach me how to remove the curses?” you ask her.

 

 “Quite the go-getter,” she says to you, but her words trail off.
 
 

 
 She stares at you, harshly. Her eyes looking through you, studying. Then her mouth drops open. “That little minx,” she mutters. “You’ve already learned some magic, haven’t you?”

 

 You look at Gladys and after a moment, nod. 

 

 The tension is broken as she lightly chuckles. “I can feel it within you. She didn’t do a half-bad job. For a child. Be mindful of her enthusiasm. I was a young upstart once. Rushing too quickly can cause unexpected outcomes. And be prone to the attention of others in our community.”

 
 She stares at you, harshly. Her eyes looking through you, studying. Then her mouth rolls up as her lips thin. "You’ve already learned some magic, haven’t you?”

 

 You look at Gladys and after a moment, nod. 

 

 The tension hangs in the air, before Gladys sighs. “I can feel it within you. Children teaching children seldom leads to good outcomes. Be mindful of the price people will claim for their tutelage. Secrets in Charlton are seldom given freely."
 
 
 
 

 “As for you,” she continues. “A basic introduction to your inert power is not required. We may move on to more complex things.”

 
 
 “Spells are tricky things,” Gladys says, resolving some authority. “They can not be easily nullified. I can teach you how to perform the curse. It is known as Ward. That should suffice to amend its properties. A curse changed to do nothing is effectively not a curse at all.”

 

 You nod. “If it helps me stop them.”

 

 Gladys smiles. “Then we shall begin.”

 

 She motions you towards the rocking chair and you take a seat. She instructs you to concentrate on your power and the warmth it burns inside your body. 

 

 You close your eyes, letting your breathing slow. Becoming ever-aware of the magical energies churning inside of you.

 

 “Now,” you hear Gladys say. “Reach out. Look for that sensation outside of your body. In me. In the relics and jewellery scattered on stands. In the shop front and the door.”

 

 You reach out, as instructed. Immediately, you’re struck by presence. Your eyes may be closed, but you can almost see the room. Dark and unlit, but certain things glowing. Burning with magical energy.

 

 “Good,” Gladys says. “Pick one of the trinkets. Concentrate on it.”

 

 You focus your attention on a simple dimpled pint glass that glows brightly in your mind’s eye. It rests on the table near the counter. You can feel the heat from its arcane power. 

 

 “Now. Repeat after me,” Gladys says. “I cause this object with power beyond its power. Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by none who use it.”

 

 You brace yourself, ready to say the words.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 “Can you teach me how to remove the curses?” you ask her.

 

 “Quite the go-getter,” she says to you, smiling thinly. “I can, but this is hardly rudimentary, though. Let's start with the basics, first. If you choose to be the hero I’ve been waiting for, you’ll need to understand the fundamentals of magic before moving forward.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 

 “I think I know who is performing the curses,” you tell Gladys. “When I was removing a curse, one of the cheerleaders came in and started questioning me.”

 

 “Is she aware of what you are doing?” Gladys asks, concerned.

 

 You shake your head. “I dealt with it.”

 

 “Good.” Gladys purses her lips and turns to the bookshelf behind the counter, riffling through volumes. “Be light on your feet with your steps forward. You have only begun your journey into the arcane. Those who conjured these curses should not be so easily overcome. I suspect you have not faced the leader of this group.”

 

 With a thick thud, Gladys drops a withered hardback book on the counter and opens it to a well-eared page. “See. This is what you will encounter.”

 

 You glance at the open pages. A picture of a pentagram is spread across the fold of the fading paper, with illustrations of young women at each of its five points. Printed around it are words in a language you don’t understand. 

 

 “Five souls, brought together under the sign of the witch,” Gladys narrates. “Each one a threat, but five together magnifies their power tenfold.”

 

 She taps her cracked nail on the page. “This is your current adversary. Should they continue to interfere, come to me. We shall accelerate your studies to counter them.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 “I had a problem with the last curse I found,” you tell Gladys. 

 

 She looks at you with a serious look. “Oh?” 

 

 “A girl called Reagan. One of the cheerleaders. She knew what I was doing. I tried to make her forget, but I struggled. It almost didn’t work.”

 

 Gladys gives you a smirk. “Unsurprisingly, there are those behind the curses with magical affinity that matches your own.”

 

 “She also mentioned the Prom,” you add. “Something about it being too important to be disrupted.” 

 

 Gladys mulls this over. “I fear there is a greater work at play than the gradual effects of simple curses. Continue your investigations. We must learn their secrets if we’re to challenge their plans.”

 

 You nod. “I think I’m ready to learn more. I think I need to if I’m to continue.”

 

 “I concur,” Gladys replies. “For your own protection, it is time you learned how to manipulate magic. With this comes a new spell, which will allow you to tamper with the building blocks of the self.”

 

 Gladys sees you frown. “Memories, my dear. You are nothing if not the collection of your experiences, are you not?”

 

 “We must move quickly, but thoroughly. This will take some time. Are you ready for the next step in your training?”

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 
 
 “I’m sure,” you tell her, bracing yourself for the lessons.

 

 “You seem sure of yourself,” Gladys comments. “Most faced with learning the dark arts have a degree of trepidation about them. But you’re not even nervous.” 

 

 
 She stares at you, harshly. Her eyes looking through you, studying. Then her mouth drops open. “That little minx,” she mutters. “You’ve already learned some magic, haven’t you?”

 

 You look at Gladys and after a moment, nod. 

 

 The tension is broken as she lightly chuckles. “I can feel it within you. She didn’t do a half-bad job. For a child. Be mindful of her enthusiasm. I was a young upstart once. Rushing too quickly can cause unexpected outcomes. And be prone to the attention of others in our community.”

 
 She stares at you, harshly. Her eyes looking through you, studying. Then her mouth rolls up as her lips thin. "You’ve already learned some magic, haven’t you?”

 

 You look at Gladys and after a moment, nod. 

 

 The tension hangs in the air, before Gladys sighs. “I can feel it within you. Children teaching children seldom leads to good outcomes. Be mindful of the price people will claim for their tutelage. Secrets in Charlton are seldom given freely."
 
 
 

 “As for you,” she continues. “A basic introduction to your inert power is not required. We may move on to more complex things.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You nod. “I’m sure.” You watch a smile creep across her lips.

 

 “Precisely what I wanted to hear. Now. Let’s start with the basics. Plus, as a bonus, a little spell that will make people fall asleep and become ever-so forgetful.” She grins. “Perfect if you wish to do a little moonlighting in their bodies, if you were so inclined.”

 

 Gladys moves you over to an old rocking chair and motions for you to sit down. “Now,” she says after you’ve sat in the chair. “Relax.”

 

 You listen to Gladys' words for what seems like hours. She speaks to you softly, hypnotically even. You sense your breath grow shallow and become aware of your heartbeat slowing.

 

 Then. A feeling. Something inside you, warming your lungs. At first a flicker, then a spark. As you concentrate, the energy grows warmer and consistent. A rush of euphoria, an ever-growing sensation, a connection flowing through your organs.

 

 “That’s right, dear,” Gladys whispers. “Feel it. Feel its power.”

 

 You concentrate on the growing pulsing in your body. Now you’re aware of it, it only grows stronger.

 

 "Now," Gladys continues. "Repeat after me. 'Fall asleep, and let your memories drift as you slumber.' And," she says, almost sardonically, "think of me."

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 

 Gladys nods as you express your hesitance. “You are wise to be hesitant. Curiosity did kill the cat. What is asked from you will lend you great power, but there is a price to be paid.”

 

 “Take your time to consider if this is a path you wish to tread. But I will tell you that the amulet has waited longer than you can imagine to leave this shop. If you choose to reject it, I fear the school will retain its hold over its pupils for a long time.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You utter the words that Gladys spoke to you. This time, you feel the energies of the glass begin to break apart, like a tablet dissolving in water. 

 

 Except, instead of dissipating, you’re able to channel your mind into another form. As it threatens to become unstable, you find you can form it. Shape it. It’s malleable. 

 

 You focus your mind on the words again. The magic embers you can see floating around the object change as you consider the words. None who use it.

 

 Then, as quickly as the dark imagery of the room appeared, it fades. You open your eyes and find yourself still in the junk shop. 

 

 Gladys is grinning. She looks back at the cup on the table near the counter. “That glass drained the intelligence of anyone who drank from it. Over the years a number of overly friendly men at McTafey’s have become its prey. Alas, no more.”

 

 You stare at the glass. It looks the same, but it feels different. You see no aura, nor shimmering energy, but you can feel it. Feel it like other objects in the shop. You can tell just what is blessed with magic, and what isn’t.

 

 “You feel them, don’t you?” Gladys says. Less of a question, more of a statement. “Good. Now you have all you need to find the source of the curse to the school, and change them for the better.”

 

 You cast your eye over the shop. Not everything is magic. Though hidden amongst the jewellery and crockery are at least two dozen pieces that give off magical energy. They are almost drowned out, however, by the front of the shop, which radiates power.

 

 “Easy,” you hear Gladys say. “Perhaps awakening your senses here was an oversight on my part. You will find no other place like this in Charlton. We must hope.”

 

 You push back the wave of nausea, as your new sense adjusts to the sensory overload. “I feel sleepy.”

 

 Gladys nods. “Perhaps it is time to call this lesson concluded,” she tells you. “Safe travels home, dear. As always, I will be here when you need me.”

 

 You look back at the old woman and smile politely. Then make your way back out to the street.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 “I’m ready,” you tell Gladys.

 

 “Very well,” she replies. She motions you to take a seat. “Let us begin.”

 

 Sitting down, you close your eyes and concentrate on the energies inside your body. Gladys instructs you to reach out with your mind’s eye, feeling the emanations of the magical objects littered around the shop. You consider now that naturally you feel the ebb and flow of magic through everything, but when you focus the world lights up with a hidden layer, like street lamps coming up at dusk.

 

 “I have opened up a small window into my own mind,” you hear Gladys tell you. “Just a sliver, but enough for you to feel a sensation. Now. Reach out and tell me what you feel.”

 

 You turn your focus to where you feel Gladys’ presence. You notice a glowing speck of energy that was hidden from you before. You concentrate on it. 

 

 "Coco puffs," you whisper, incredulously. 

 

 You don’t need to see Gladys to know she is smiling. “One of my small vices,” she says. “This morning’s breakfast. What can I say - the teeth I still retain are sweet ones."

 

 “Concentrate on the memory. The magical orbs that bind that memory together. As you did with the curses, try to pull it apart.”

 

 You look beyond the memory with your mind’s eye. To the fragments that comprise it. The strands of magic that fuse it together. With a flick of your mental wrist, you feel the bond between its elements weaken.

 

 “Good,” Gladys whispers. “Now. This level of magic is beyond words. Just think. Alter. And change it.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “I’m ready,” you tell Gladys.

 

 “I would remind you that you are not,” she says. “Return to me as a woman and we shall further your progress.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 "You are right to be cautious," Gladys replies to your hesitancy. "But a word of advice. You have set in motion events that will blossom in spite of your ongoing efforts. Whether they come back to poison you or you can make fruit from your pruning is down to you. 

 

 “And nature, be it physical or magical, does not pause for indecision.”

 

 Gladys smiles thinly back at you, but says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You pull apart the memory with your mind, watching mentally as the kernel of the memory fractures into a thousand pieces. One thing pops into your mind. *Toast*.

 

 The elements begin to fuse again, the yellow and oranges altering to greens and reds as the memory reforms. Toast, you think. Gladys ate toast.

 

 The memory package wraps itself back up in front of you. Returning to one solid item, a shimmering nugget in Gladys’ mind that still shimmers with magical energy, but what was once yellow is now blue.

 

 You open your eyes and look at Gladys. She grins back at you with relish. “A dry breakfast,” she murmurs. “But different to my routine. Congratulations.”

 

 “You know that I changed your memory though?” you ask her.

 

 “Only because I am conscious of what we were doing. That, and I follow a strict regime. In all things. So I can easily identify if a duplicitous individual has been interfering with my mind. Tell me dear, is there anything that seems different to you?”

 

 You take a breath and survey your surroundings. Nothing in the shop appears different. 

 

 Then you turn inwardly and immediately sense your own mind. Before a black box, dead to the world of magic. Now you see it as a collection of colourful swirls and energy, open to the universe.

 

 “Your powers have increased,” Gladys tells you. “You can see the open book others see you as. Such is how inviting the unknowing majority are to the powers of magic. Now that you are aware of it, you can begin to close that door.”

 

 “Will this prevent the effects of the curses?” you ask.

 

 Gladys chuckles. “Not quite. There are still those who are far more powerful than you. Including those behind the curses. But this is your next step to overcoming their sway.”

 

 She helps you stand, as you suddenly find yourself exhausted. “This ends the lesson. Continue your work. When required, we shall complete your education. For now, go home.”

 

 You smile politely to Gladys and nod, leaving the shop as you mull over how exposed your mind feels to the wider world.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You repeat the words Gladys told you, thinking of the old woman as you do so.

 

 With a rush of energy, you feel the aura within your body shoot forwards. Your eyes flick open and you see a rush of light hit Gladys square in the chest.

 

 She stumbles, grabbing hold of the counter to maintain her balance. Her eyes roll and for the briefest of moments you think she’s going to collapse.

 

 A calm quiet fills the room, the only sound Gladys’ breathing. 

 

 After a moment, she chuckles. “That was impressive. For a moment, I thought I was going to fall.”

 

 You stand up, reaching over to help her, but she casually hushes you away from her. “I’m alright. Alright dear. No harm. You did well.”

 

 “Did it not work?” you ask her.

 

 She sniggers. “More than expected. I’m no spring chicken, but I’ve been practising magic for longer than you’ve been having hot dinners. Don’t take it to heart. That I almost succumbed to your spell is most promising. Promising indeed.”

 

 You nod, and wait for Gladys to stand upright. Once steady, she looks at you. “How do you feel?”

 

 You spend a moment reflecting. The inner energy swirls inside your body, no longer requiring effort. You can sense its power. 

 

 You grin at Gladys. “I can feel it.”

 

 She nods. “Good. Good. That is enough for this evening. But come see me again. We have lots to uncover.”

 

 You nod. Gladys smiles at you, with nothing further to say. Understanding, you walk wordlessly to the door. The bell rings as you open it and you walk outside, feeling your newfound power flowing through your body.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “I need to tell you about something,” you say to Gladys. “I think something is happening to me.”

 

 The old woman’s eyes narrow, alert to danger. “Oh?”

 

 “I had a dream,” you tell her. “Except it was vivid. Like it was real.”

 

 Gladys' eyes linger on you. “Tell me dear, what was this dream about?”

 

 “I dreamed that I was having coffee with my friend,” you begin. “When we first met. Except, we were interrupted by Dan Mandel. From work. He wouldn’t shut up about men being men.”

 “I dreamed that I was back on a date with my girlfriend,” you begin. “When we first started dating. Except, we were interrupted by Dan Mandel. From work. He wouldn’t shut up about men being men.”

 

 “Was this a dream or a memory?” Gladys asks you.

 

 You hesitate, then shrug. “I’m not sure. I mean, I remember it. It did happen. Just like in the dream. But...”

 

 “You have a sense it didn’t happen just like that, don’t you?” she asks, flatly.

 

 As you nod, Gladys smiles sweetly. “Lesson the first. The amulet changes to your perception of reality. These are not just physical transformations you’re experiencing. Surely you’ve noticed it? That some things come easier for you, some harder, depending on how you perceive the person you’ve become. If your own sense of self-perception is faltering...” She trails off.

 

 You let this sink in. “But I’m still me. I mean, I still know who I am.”

 

 “Do you?” she asks. “I remember being a thin young lass dancing around fields with male suitors at my feet. But I know in my heart that’s not who I am anymore.”

 

 “As we become accustomed to our reality, our self-perception changes. We don’t notice it, but we are forever changing. With the amulet, you are pushing that into overdrive. Recall my advice - you may have to make sacrifices to be the hero we need.”

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 “What about you?” you ask Gladys. “You have powers. Do you see anything different about me?”

 

 Gladys chuckles. “You overestimate my power. What you’re describing is unknown to me. The amulet is a powerful artifact that fuses spells together. Stacking magic tends to lead to unexpected consequences.”

 

 You snort, feeling anger rising. “And you’re telling me this now?”

 

 “I did warn you,” she replies, cutting you down. “This is not to be trifled with lightly. But if you are indeed experiencing changes without knowing of them, we should act fast. I shall begin my research immediately.”

 

 “Research?” you stammer. “But what about now?”

 

 “I would advise you not to use the amulet frivolously,” Gladys responds. “If there is any hint of your own sense of self drifting, additional transformations should be avoided wherever you can.”

 

 You feel your blood boiling. “But I have to use the amulet!” you exclaim. “How else am I going to put a stop to this?”

 

 “Use caution,” the old lady says. “Look at me. Do you think that I wouldn’t prefer to be in the form of a young woman, with life ahead of her? There are some consequences to magic that are too great to indulge in idle fantasies.”

 

 
 
 You take a deep breath, feeling tension throughout your body. Gladys looks at you, curious. Then a flash of frustration.

 

 "You've had other dreams, haven't you?" she says. "This hasn't been an isolated incident."

 

 You look to her, then shake your head. "I didn't think it was important."

 

 She sighs deeply, closing her eyes for a moment. When she opens them, you see irritation within them. "I will prioritise my research. Come see me tomorrow. We shall see what we can do."

 

 You nod, cheeks turning a little red. Gladys sighs again, shaking her head. But says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 You take a deep breath, feeling tension throughout your body. Gladys looks at you, curious. Then a flash of frustration.

 

 "You've had other dreams, haven't you?" she says. "This hasn't been an isolated incident."

 

 You look to her, then shake your head. "I didn't think it was important."

 

 She sighs deeply, closing her eyes for a moment. When she opens them, you see irritation within them. "I will prioritise my research. Come see me tomorrow. We shall see what we can do."

 

 You nod, cheeks turning a little red. Gladys sighs again, shaking her head. But says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Gladys turns away from you, flicking through a nearby book. “Now, unless you have any further questions, I should begin my research.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 “I had another dream,” you begin.

 

 Gladys looks at you curiously. You can see her mulling over her response. “Go on.”

 

 You take a deep breath. “It was from my first week at my first job. Back in the city.”

 

 She nods. “And was it, how you remember it?”

 

 You reflect on her words before answering. “Yes. Except. There’s a nagging feeling that it wasn’t how it happened at all. But I remember it all the same. Just like in the dream.”

 

 Gladys looks down at the floor of the shop. When her eyes return to meet your gaze, you can see sadness on her face. She reaches down below the counter and takes out a vial, full of red liquid.

 

 “I have completed my research,” she tells you. "What you’re experiencing is a form of the spell, Alter Reality. The amulet is infused with elements of it. Clearly, my calculations were incorrect when I enchanted it.”

 

 You look between her and the vial in her hand, trying to comprehend her words. “What’s happening to me?”

 

 “The amulet is reflecting your sense of self,” she replies. “As that changes, it’s shaping reality to suit. What was once straight is now curved. To all who see it.”

 

 “Your dreams are one way magic is having an effect on you,” she says quietly. “They are your memories, changing and reforming. What you do in your dream is what happened to you.”

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 "How is your research coming along?" you ask, still feeling a tinge of shame for causing Gladys' rare display of frustration before.

 
 
 Gladys looks down at the floor of the shop. When her eyes return to meet your gaze, you can see sadness on her face. She reaches down below the counter and takes out a vial, full of red liquid.

 

 “I have completed my research,” she tells you. "What you’re experiencing is a form of the spell, Alter Reality. The amulet is infused with elements of it. Clearly, my calculations were incorrect when I enchanted it.”

 

 You look between her and the vial in her hand, trying to comprehend her words. “What’s happening to me?”

 

 “The amulet is reflecting your sense of self,” she replies. “As that changes, it’s shaping reality to suit. What was once straight is now curved. To all who see it.”

 

 “Your dreams are one way magic is having an effect on you,” she says quietly. “They are your memories, changing and reforming. What you do in your dream is what happened to you.”

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 “But… you can change me back, right?” you ask her, hearing the desperation in your voice.

 

 Again, the sad smile appears. “I have no more knowledge of who you are than you do. To me, you are and always have been the young girl that stands in front of me, asking for help.”

 

 You consider Gladys' words. In spite of everything that’s happened, that truth burns brightly. Aside from that clawing feeling at the back of your mind, you feel like you are just as you are. How you’ve always been.

 

 “This,” she says, finally acknowledging the vial. “May help. Then again, it may not. In fact it could complicate matters. Like I said, stacking magic upon magic can lead to unexpected effects.”

 

 She hands you the vial. You look at it curiously, rolling the liquid around. “What is it?”

 

 “A potion,” Gladys says, with a trace of satisfaction. “Drink it as yourself before you go to sleep. You will experience a dream unlike any other. Where the energies of magic will piece together the fragments of the past. With any luck, you’ll see who you were.”

 

 “But it won’t change me?” you ask, still trying to understand what you’ve been given.

 

 Gladys shakes her head. “No. But it will give you insight into what you’ve lost. With the right mindset and the right choices, you may find that you hold on to some pieces when you awake.”

 

 Gladys sighs dramatically and moves back around to her counter. “My advice, though, is not to use it. You are adding magic on top of magic. It never ends well.

 

 “Besides,” she adds, looking you up and down. “I think you’ve turned out quite nicely.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I took that potion you gave me,” you tell her with a hint of embarrassment at your actions.

 

 She looks at you, her sharp eyes evaluating your mood. “And?”

 

 You nod, the weight of the dream still clinging to your skin. “I saw… him.”

 

 Her expression doesn’t change, but you see the slight tightening around her eyes. “Who?”

 

 Your voice is quieter when you continue. “I saw my old self. He… wasn’t what I expected.”

 

 Gladys exhales through her nose, slow and measured, as if collecting her patience.

 

 “I did warn you,” she says. “I told you. Stacking magic on top of magic is dangerous. What did he say?”

 

 You reflect on the memories of your dream. “That he was the fragments of memories from other people. He seemed disgusted with what - with who - I am.”

 

 “He was hostile?” she asks quickly. 

 

 When you nod, she moves over to a cupboard and takes out a book. She flicks through the pages and spends some moments reading. “How did it end?” she says as she reads. “As much as you can remember.”

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You take in a deep breath, feeling the old woman's eyes looking at you in spite of her seemingly reading from the book.

 

 
 
 "He said, 'Maybe there's hope for you yet,'" you reply. “And that he’d be seeing me around.”

 
 "He said, 'If you won't fight for yourself, then I'll have to take matters into our own hands.'"

 
 

 Gladys looks up from her book. “The visage you saw was a tapestry of people’s memories of you. In the dark recesses of their mind. Stitched together by magic to form a personality. Unfortunately, those memories that remain buried are the potent ones. Anger. Frustration. Hatred. They aren’t the sum total of your old personality. Fused into one, it seems he’s not as friendly as you might have been.”

 

 “Was it just a dream?” you ask.

 

 Gladys looks at you, then shakes her head. “The potion conjured him from other people’s memories and placed him on a magical plane. That’s where you visited. He’s bound there for now, but I fear the potion has weakened the walls between planes. From what you’re telling me, he seems resolute in breaking back into reality.”

 

 A cold chill settles over you.

 

 Gladys sighs, rubbing her temple. “Which means, unfortunately, he’ll need a body.” Her gaze settles pointedly on you. “And there’s only one option for him.”

 

 You swallow hard. “Mine.”

 

 She nods once. “Yours.”

 

 You stare back at her, unblinking. The silence hangs in the air.

 

 “It won’t be easy,” Gladys tries to reassure you. “He’ll need your actions, or inactions, to gain traction. Be mindful of how much you desire to know of your former self. Any avenue to your past will be an opening for him. Heed my words of caution - use magic sparingly. And above all, accept who you are.”

 

 “What if I want to change back?” you ask.

 

 
 
 Gladys sighs. There is no more frustration. If anything, she looks… resigned.

 

 “You've already gone so far," she states, leaning forward on the counter, her voice low. “The longer you exist like this, the harder it becomes to trace what was.”

 

 Your stomach tightens. “So… what are you saying?”

 

 “I’m saying that any further changes will be irreversible and long-lasting.”

 

 She doesn’t let the words hang for dramatic effect. She just lets them land.

 

 You grip the edge of the counter, heart pounding. “You mean, if I use the amulet again, I - ”

 

 “You may push yourself past the point of no return,” Gladys confirms, her expression grim. “Your reality is on the verge of changing completely.”

 

 The weight of her words settles deep in your bones.

 

 Gladys folds her arms. “You need to be more cautious. If you want any chance of stopping your Shadow Self, or even holding onto who you are, then you can’t keep using magic recklessly.”

 

 Her gaze sharpens, her voice turning serious.

 

 "I will continue my research, but again. Heed my words. Next time, there may be no going back."

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Gladys sighs. “I will continue my research. In the meantime, come see me immediately if anything further occurs.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 She exhales sharply, setting aside the half-burned candle she’d been working on. “It’s happened again, hasn’t it?”

 

 You nod, rubbing your arms as if trying to shake off the lingering weight of the dream. “I - something changed. I know it did. But I don’t know what.”

 

 Gladys doesn’t look surprised. If anything, she looks… resigned.

 

 “The changes are accelerating,” she states plainly, leaning forward on the counter, her voice low. “I can’t be sure how much - reality is rewriting itself. It’s not just your memories shifting. It’s the memories of everyone around you. The longer you exist like this, the harder it becomes to trace what was.”

 

 Your stomach tightens. “So… what are you saying?”

 

 “I’m saying that any further changes will be irreversible and long-lasting.”

 

 She doesn’t let the words hang for dramatic effect. She just lets them land.

 

 You grip the edge of the counter, heart pounding. “You mean, if I use the amulet again, I -”

 

 “You may push yourself past the point of no return,” Gladys confirms, her expression grim. “Your reality is on the verge of changing completely.”

 

 The weight of her words settles deep in your bones.

 

 Gladys folds her arms. “You need to be more cautious. If you want any chance of stopping your Shadow Self, or just holding onto who you are, then you can’t keep using magic recklessly.”

 

 Her gaze sharpens, her voice turning serious.

 

 “I will continue my research, but again. Heed my words. Next time, there may be no going back.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Without waiting, she speaks. “You seem troubled.”

 

 You hesitate for a moment before stepping closer. “It’s Emily.”

 

 That gets her attention. She stops what she’s doing and finally looks up, her sharp eyes scanning your face. “Go on.”

 

 You take a breath, thinking of the words to describe what you’ve seen. The shifts in Emily’s personality, the way she carries herself now, the flirtation, the way she talks about men and how little she cares about school anymore. How she’s completely stopped questioning Charlton.

 

 “She’s… different,” you finish. “Not just a little, not like she’s growing up. It’s like the town got to her.”

 

 Gladys listens without interrupting, her expression unreadable. When you finish, she leans back slightly, crossing her arms. “And what exactly are you asking me?”

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 "You’re a witch," you press. "There has to be something you can do, right?"

 

 Gladys lets out a slow, measured breath. “I was hoping you wouldn’t ask me that.”

 

 She gestures for you to follow her deeper into the shop, where the shelves are stacked high with bottles, powders, and aged tomes. “I’ve seen this before. I know what Charlton does to people.” She picks up a small jar, inspecting its contents before setting it down again. “But magic isn’t the answer here.”

 

 You frown. “Why not?”

 

 “Because this isn’t just one curse,” she says firmly. “It’s just not a single spell I can wave away. The magic is woven into many aspects of the school. Adding more magic into the mix without solving the root cause?” She shakes her head. “That’s a gamble I’m not willing to take.”

 

 You open your mouth to argue, but she cuts you off. “Even if I could snap my fingers and ‘fix’ her, what happens next? She’s still in the school. Still under its influence. Still surrounded by everything that’s shaping her into what Charlton wants.” She gives you a knowing look. “You’d be back here in a week, asking me to do it again.”

 

 She folds her arms. “The only real way to help her is to stop the source of the problem. You need to deal with the school.”

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 "There has to be something else. Some way to help her."

 

 Gladys lets out a quiet sigh, shaking her head. “I don’t think you understand how deep this runs.”

 

 She gestures around the shop, at the jars and books that line the walls. “Magic could help. I could give you a potion, a charm - something to slow it down. But it wouldn’t be a cure. It would be like throwing a single drop of water into a raging fire. Charlton is stronger.”

 

 Her gaze hardens. “If you really want to help Emily, you need to stop the school. That’s where the magic is concentrated. That’s what’s reshaping her. And that’s what you should be focusing on.”

 

 She turns back to the counter, picking up her vials again. “I know that’s not what you wanted to hear,” she says, softer this time. “But it’s the truth.”

 

 You stand there for a moment, feeling frustration coil in your stomach. Gladys won’t help.

 

 If you want to save your sister, you’ll have to deal with the school. *Or find another way.*
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 "You look tired," she says. "And desperate."

 

 You manage a weak smile. "That obvious, huh?"

 

 She finally glances up. "More than usual. What’s on your mind?"

 

 "I was wondering... is there any kind of spell that could help someone be in two places at once?"

 

 Gladys narrows her eyes. "Why would you want to be?"

 

 You hesitate, then explain everything. The demotion. The receptionist desk. The growing pile of responsibilities and the slipping grip on your investigation into Charlton Upper. The look on your face is all but begging.

 

 "I’m trying to balance everything. Work. The school. I can’t do both. Emily suggested maybe there’s a spell. Something where she could take my place while I keep looking into the school."

 

 Gladys straightens slowly, her expression shifting from curious to cold. "No," she says, flatly.

 

 The abruptness catches you off guard. "What? Why not?"

 

 The old woman looks down at the shop counter, playing idly with a silver necklace, wrapping it around her fingers. "What you’re asking is called Alter Form. The ability to transform one thing into another. To change the shape and truth of something. It’s not a parlour trick."

 

 You blink. "Yes. And isn’t that what the amulet does?"

 

 Gladys looks up, clutching the necklace tightly. "Precisely. And look at what a mess it’s created.”

 

 A sweet defeated smile spreads across Gladys' face. She loosens her grip on the necklace and tosses it aside. “The amulet was forged in desperation,” she continues. “To protect Charlton. There’s not a day that goes by where I don't question whether creating it was the right thing to do."

 

 "Magic doesn’t just ‘do’ something and stop,” she adds. “It ripples. One change becomes ten. The world tries to correct what it doesn’t understand, and what you end up with isn’t what you asked for. It’s what reality thinks makes sense."

 

 You start to protest, but she lifts a hand, silencing you with just a look.

 

 "No more of this talk," she says firmly. "I will not teach you this. Not for something as trivial as poor time management. Unless there’s an urgent and pressing need, you’re not ready."

 

 She meets your eyes, her stare alone shooting down any protest. You realise that unless you have a better reason, you will not learn this spell from her.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Something has happened to me,” you begin as Gladys looks back at you. “I don’t know what happened. I must have blacked out. And when I woke up, I had this.”

 

 You lift up your top and turn your back to face her, feeling the pink heart tattoo pulsate with magic like blood flowing through veins. Gladys remains silent, but when you glance over your shoulder you see her eyes are locked on the tattoo, whilst her lips curl up tight.

 

 “Do you know what it is?” you ask, pulling your top back down.

 

 Her eyes flicker up quickly to meet yours, watching you carefully. “I do not. Only that its arcane properties are obvious and powerful. Curious though, I did not sense it before you revealed it. Tell me everything that transpired.”

 

 You breathe through your teeth as you shrug. “I’m not sure. I woke up on my doorstep. Clive found me.”

 

 “The drunkard masquerading as a philosopher?” Gladys asks, eyes narrowing.

 

 You nod. “He said that I must have had too much to drink. I don’t remember drinking though. I don’t really remember anything. Especially how I got this.”

 

 Gladys’ eyes drift back to your hips briefly as she purses her lips. “The drunkard is a red herring. In other times, a night of excess would be justification for lost memories. But around here, at this time? Feels like too much of a coincidence, don’t you think?”

 

 “Can you remove it?” you ask her.

 

 She sniggers through her nose, skin cracking on her face as she smiles. “Does this look like a tattoo parlour? It may be magic, but the blemish is still ink and pigment. I’m afraid you’ll have to live with it, like any youthful regret.”

 

 “What does it do, though?” you press. “It’s not just a tattoo. I can feel the magic in it.”

 

 Gladys’ smile morphs to something akin to admiration. “Now. The right question comes. Alas, I have never seen anything like it before. Its intention is unclear, but it radiates energy without revealing itself. Like I said, I failed to sense it.”

 

 Her eyes drift back towards your back briefly as her voice lowers. “Like a silent whisper, heard only by those listening for it.” 

 

 She shakes her head and focuses back on you. “Be mindful on where you use magic. Someone, or something, is keeping an eye on you.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “I had some trouble with a spell,” you begin. “I tried casting it on the school janitor, but it didn’t work.”

 

 Gladys’ eyes widen. “You tried a spell at school? Around others?”

 

 Quickly, you shake your head. “It was in the basement. No one saw.”

 

 She lets out a small sigh, glancing at the floor briefly until she turns her eyes back to you. “That was a risk.” She holds your gaze for a moment longer before continuing. “How did it fail?”

 

 “I cast it correctly,” you tell her, trying to ignore her scowl. “But it just didn’t take. Almost as if something was protecting him.” You snort. “It’s lucky he’s not the smartest tool in his box.”

 

 Gladys looks away as you momentarily lose her to thoughts. “I would deduce that something is protecting him,” she says finally. “Even if he’s not aware of it.”

 

 Her eyes once again focus on you as her mouth twitches with concern. “Be mindful on using magic in that place. Who knows what wards are watching at school.”

 

 “You think someone knows?” you quickly ask.

 

 “I think you should be careful on where you practice the dark arts,” Gladys replies curtly. “You are at the beginning of your journey. There are powers at play that exceed your own.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Say you need to think about it
Agree to learn how to Alter Memories
Say you need to think about it
Say goodbye and leave the shop
Ask if she notices anything different about you
Ask her if she can do something magical to fix it
Push for another way to help Emily

title: GordonDialogue
text:
“I was thinking about joining a gym,” you tell him. “You’re a member of one, aren’t you?”

 

 Gordon nods, grabbing a box beside his vehicle. “Casey’s. Off Orchid Road. You should come. Never too late to get in shape.”

 

 As if demonstrating his own level of fitness, he throws the bulky box into the van. You know you wouldn't be able to lift it.

 

 
 “Look pretty flexible already. So we can start you with some weights. Then cardio. Soon you’ll be long-distance running. Plenty of clubs run through the fields outside of town. Can do personal sessions, if you like. Like I do for your friend, Jennifer.”

 

 "You teach Jennifer privately?" you ask.
 
 
 “Look pretty flexible already. So we can start you with some weights. Then cardio. Soon you’ll be long-distance running. Plenty of clubs run through the fields outside of town. Can do personal sessions, if you like. Like I do for Chambers. You know her?”

 

 "You teach Jennifer Chambers privately?" you ask.

 
 

 He nods. “She stops by the gym sometimes,” he replies. “Works next door at the department store.”
 
 

 Gordon continues to load his van. You eye him carefully, noticing how he appraises your body without hiding it.

 

 “Stop by in the evening,” Gordon tells you. “We’ll get you fixed up.”

 
 “I was thinking about joining a gym,” you tell him. “You’re a member of one, aren’t you?”

 

 Gordon nods, grabbing a box beside his vehicle. “Casey’s. Off Orchid Road. You should come. Never too late to get in shape.”

 

 As if demonstrating his own level of fitness, he throws the bulky box into the van. You suspect you’d struggle to even lift it.

 

 “We can start you with some weights. Then cardio. Soon you’ll be long-distance running. Plenty of run clubs through the fields that test your calves. Bet your pretty girlfriend will appreciate it.”

 

 "How do you know Jennifer?" you ask, caught off-guard by Gordon mentioning her.

 

 “She stops by the gym sometimes,” he replies. “To chat. She works next door at the department store, doesn’t she?”

 

 Gordon continues to load his van. You eye him carefully, but sense no ill-intent coming from him. 

 

 “Stop by in the evening,” Gordon tells you. “We’ll get you fixed up.”

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 
 "Hey Gordon, did you go to Charlton Upper School when you were a kid?" you ask him.

 

 He nods, bending to pick up some heavy-looking drill boxes. Without elaborating, he turns to the van and slots them in neatly. 

 

 "What did you think of it?"

 

 "Waste of time," he replies. "Decent gym. Too much reading."

 

 You pause, wondering whether this is worth pursuing. "Did you find anything about it… strange?"

 

 "Teachers were weird," he says, tying some clunky industrial equipment against the wall of the vehicle. "Always talking about how guys are superior. And you women should know your place."

 

 "You don't think that?" you ask, raising an eyebrow.

 

 He shakes his head. "Anyone can be strong. Just like anyone can be weak. Teachers don't like that. Only Coach Beach helped me. Helped me get ripped."

 

 Gordon grins, as he picks up a canister of gas in each arm and puts it into the back of the van without straining.

 Gordon grins, as he picks up a canister of gas in each arm and puts it into the back of the van without straining. 

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “You went to Charlton Upper, didn't you?" you ask Gordon. 

 

 Gordon nods. “I did. Didn’t you?”

 

 You nod, at least knowing that Jennifer did attend the school. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “Waste of time,” he tells you, calmly. “Did well at sports. Not in classes. Probably different to you.”

 

 You give a confused look. “What do you mean?”

 

 “Used to see you around,” he replies. “Hanging around the town. Popular. Skipping school too. Must have had Stitch's special privileges.” 

 

 You look at him, but sense no deception. *Jennifer was skipping school?* There’s a lot about Jennifer that you don’t know, you realise.

 <>
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “You went to Charlton Upper, didn't you?" you ask Gordon. 

 

 Gordon nods. “I did. Lots of weaklings. Brings the team down.”

 

 You nod too, trying to remain neutral. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “Waste of time,” he tells you, calmly. “Did well at sports. Not in classes. Only Coach Beach looked out for me.”

 

 "I have him for PE too," you reply, considering what Emily might say. "Any advice?" you ask him.

 

 Gordon looks at you for a moment. "Don't come last. Hard lesson for girls.”

 <>

 Gordon nods. “I did. Lots of weaklings. Brings the team down.”

 

 You nod too, trying to remain neutral. “What did you think of it?”

 

 “Waste of time,” he tells you, calmly. “Did well at sports. Not in classes. Only Coach Beach looked out for me.”

 

 “My sister is struggling with PE," you tell him.

 

 Gordon looks at you for a moment. "Tell her not to come last. If you had gone there, you would know that girls are taught differently to boys. Hard lessons to learn for girls.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 "So Gordon," you begin, trying to think of how to question him. "How does this gym compare to the one at Charlton School?"

 

 “Better,” he replies. “No slackers.”

 

 "Gyms don't force people to come. Too many weaklings in school PE. Brings the team down.”

 

 “Did you get on with Coach Beach?” you ask him. 

 

 He nods. “Beach helped me. He looks out for you. If he likes you.”

 

 “Yeah,” you reply. “My sister said.”

 

 Gordon looks at you for a moment. “Tell her not to come last,” he tells you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 
 “Many students from Charlton come here?” you ask Gordon.

 

 He snorts, a spark of frustration fueling his sudden rush of words. “Yeah. Bunch of momma’s boys. Especially the Mayor’s son. Kid thinks I don’t notice hiding small weights between the big ones. Tries to impress the ladies. He can’t bench for shit.”

 

 “Do you mean Jake?” you ask him.

 

 Gordon nods. “All talk and no muscles. Should get his head in gear if he wants to impress the scout that’s staying around.”

 

 You give him a look. “What scout?”

 

 “Football one,” he tells you. “Staying at the hotel. Looking for talent. Should have just drove through this town.”

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 “So you mentioned before that Jen comes by here sometimes?” you ask him.

 

 He nods. “Your girlfriend, right? Works next door. She trains here. Working on her core.”

 

 You stare at him, trying to gauge whether he’s hiding anything. There’s no nervousness about his demeanour. Either he’s a great liar or there’s nothing he’s hiding. Still, you find it strange that Jen hasn’t mentioned to you that she’s started going to the gym.

 

 “You should follow her lead,” he tells you, bringing you out of your thoughts. “Come back regularly.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You let your brow knit, tilting your head slightly as if trying to puzzle out the screen.

 

 “Oh… right. Yeah, I always get a bit muddled with this system,” you murmur, letting a small laugh slip through. “I think was the only one who knew how it actually worked.”

 

 
 
 Gordon snorts. “Phillips?” He raises an eyebrow. "Didn't seem to do much with a second chance.”

 

 You wince. "I think they could sort this out easy.”

 

 Gordon snorts. "Not sticking my neck out for that loser again,” he mutters. “See you, Annie.”

 

 He turns and walks off without waiting for a reply.

 

 You sit in silence and grimace. It looks like you've burned all your bridges that lead to being rehired.
 
 
 Gordon snorts. “Phillips?” He raises an eyebrow, but his tone softens. “Well. Didn’t break as often when they were here.”

 

 You nod, eyes wide with manufactured innocence. “Yeah. I dunno. I can barely figure out how to set the out-of-office,” you add, tapping a random key for emphasis.

 

 He folds his arms, grumbling more to himself than to you. “Computers. Too many buttons.”

 

 You glance at him, voice still sweet and slightly dazed. “Shame they were let go, really. They could’ve sorted this out easy.”

 

 Gordon pauses, eyes narrowing just slightly. Thinking. “Might mention that to Thompson,” he mutters. “See you, Annie.”

 

 He turns and walks off without waiting for a reply.

 

 You sit in silence, the glittery mouse cold in your hand.

 

 It was just an act, you remind yourself. But something inside of you seems fuzzy. The words came out easier than they should have. The fluttery tone, the soft confusion.

 

 You’d meant to act like it was hard to understand, but now you’re not sure how much was performance. How much being in Annie's form is impacting you? If you keep doing this - pretending to be too ditsy to follow - will it stop being pretend?

 

 Will you even be smart enough to do the job when you get it back?

 
 
 
 
 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 

 You hesitate for a beat. Then lower your eyes, letting your voice soften.

 

 “I dunno,” you mumble, half to yourself. “Just feels like things worked a bit smoother when was still around.”

 

 
 
 Gordon snorts. “Phillips?” He raises an eyebrow. "Didn't seem to do much with a second chance.”

 

 You wince. "I think they could sort this out easy.”

 

 Gordon snorts. "Not sticking my neck out for that loser again,” he mutters. “See you, Annie.”

 

 He turns and walks off without waiting for a reply.

 

 You sit in silence and grimace. It looks like you've burned all your bridges that lead to being rehired.

 
 Gordon grunts. “They knew their way around the systems, yeah.” He adjusts the strap of his overalls, gaze distant. “Didn’t waste time.”

 

 You tuck a strand of hair behind your ear. Only just realising the gesture felt instinctive. It's almost comforting.

 

 “I mean… maybe someone should say something?” you offer, gently. “To Mr. Thompson. Not me or anything. Just… maybe.”

 

 He gives you a long look. Then nods, just once. “Might do.”

 

 Without another word, Gordon turns and walks away.

 

 You exhale. That worked. But there’s a strange heaviness in your chest. It was just a trick, wasn't it? The way you dropped your voice, the way you stepped back, made yourself smaller. It was all just an act.

 

 Fingers comb a strand of hair behind your ear, again. You realise, just like that, it felt natural. Too natural.

 

 *If you keep deferring like this... what happens when someone tells you to sit. Will you?*

 
 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 

 You meet Gordon’s eyes for a moment. Then look away. “I’ll see if someone can help,” you say quietly. 

 

 Not really a promise. More of a placeholder.

 

 Gordon grunts. “Right.” He lingers just a second too long, then turns and walks off.

 

 The office feels quiet again, but your shoulders stay tense. You could've said something. But you weren't sure how to say it. Maybe you just didn't want to cause a scene. Maybe Annie wouldn’t have said anything either.

 

 The fact of the matter is, nothing came out.

 

 You reach for the mouse again, hand still trembling slightly.

 

 *If you don’t speak up now… will you even remember how?*
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 Before you can stop yourself, your voice turns honeyed, your tone lilting. “Oh, Gordon,” you say with a soft little smile, twirling the phone cord between your fingers. “I’m sure it’s not that broken. Maybe it just needs a gentle touch.”

 

 The words fall out far too easily. You lean slightly forward in the chair without thinking, posture curved, lashes fluttering just a little too much.

 

 Gordon stares at you with a stone-faced demeanour. He isn't flustered. But he isn't charmed by your wiles either. He just looks... confused?
 

 “What’s that meant to mean?”

 

 You titter, without meaning to, then wave your hand as if to dismiss the moment. “Nothing! Just trying to lighten the mood, you know?”

 

 He snorts. “Right.”

 

 There’s a pause. Then he glances once, vaguely, towards the door that leads through the office and to Thompson. But then he shrugs.

 

 “Doesn’t matter. I’ll figure it out.”

 

 And with that, he turns and walks off.

 

 You sit there, blinking. Your heart races and not just from nerves. You didn’t plan that. Didn’t mean to act like that. It just happened. Worse, it felt easy. Natural.

 

 *It keeps on happening though, doesn't it?*

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You offer him a small, playful smile. The type you've seen Annie use before to defuse situations.

 

 “Well, maybe if you smiled more, Gordon, the system would work properly for you.”

 

 You say it with a light touch, eyes meeting his just a second longer than necessary. You lean back, letting the chair curve your spine, legs crossed with perfect casualness.

 

 Gordon blinks. He doesn't blush. Instead, his body goes rigid. “Uh huh,” he mutters.

 

 A moment of silence passes between you. Eventually he shrugs. “Look, never mind. I’ll fix it myself.”

 

 He turns without another word, the lines of his shoulders a little tighter than before.

 

 You exhale slowly. That worked. Kind of.

 

 But even as you return to the screen, you feel a sinking feeling. You’d used your smile like a weapon. Bent your posture to disarm him. And it worked.

 

 As much as you try to tell yourself otherwise, you're not sure if you were pretending to be Annie. Or just being her.

 

 *Or is this just you, now?*

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You offer him a small, practiced smile. Tilt your head slightly, soften your tone.

 

 “Maybe if you smiled more, Gordon, the system wouldn’t act up so much.”

 

 You can feel the tension in the air. They were words that Annie might have said, but you missed the warmth and affection that she almost instinctively injects into banter. Instead, it felt like a slight.

 

 Gordon stares at you for a beat. Then he frowns. Deeply. “Is that some kind of joke?”

 

 His voice is flat. You look down at the desk, feeling your cheeks redden.

 

 “I’ll speak to Thompson. Can’t run this place with people mucking about.”

 
 
 He doesn’t wait for a reply. Just turns, strides toward the office door and disappears inside.

 

 You sit there, frozen. The air feels suddenly thin. Your cheeks burn. Trying not to think about the conversation he must be having with the boss.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You straighten in the chair, keeping your voice even but firm.

 

 “ is on a job this morning,” you say, meeting Gordon’s eyes. “They’ll fix the booking issue as soon as they’re back. I’ll log it now so it doesn’t slip.”

 

 It’s a clean, practiced deflection. You offer no space for doubt.

 

 Gordon squints at you. “Since when do they do field work?”

 

 You shrug, deliberately casual. “New ideas on understanding customers. Thompson’s orders.”

 

 A beat. Gordon grumbles something under his breath. But he nods.

 

 “Fine. Just make sure it gets sorted.”

 

 He turns and walks off, his boots thudding dully across the carpet.

 

 You let your breath out slowly. Gordon seemed to accept your point. You're quite sure he won't be going to Thompson.

 

 What brings you more joy is that you feel, for once, that you didn’t have to smile, giggle, or play helpless to get there.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You sit up straighter, crossing your arms as you lock eyes with Gordon.

 

 “ is handling something more urgent this morning,” you say flatly. “They’ll fix the system when they’re back.”

 

 Your tone is sharp. Possibly too sharp. Gordon raises an eyebrow.

 

 “Urgent? Since when?” he says. “System’s broken now.”

 

 You try again. “Look, it’s covered. You don’t need to take it to Thompson.”

 

 Wrong move, amateur.

 

 “I’ll decide what needs taking to Thompson,” he replies, already turning away. “Not my job to babysit office staff.”

 
 
 He marches toward Thompson’s office, muttering to himself. You stay rooted behind the desk, heat rising behind your eyes. It wasn’t the wrong idea, but you just pushed it too hard.

 

 Maybe in your body, with your voice, it would have landed. But in this form, Annie comes off differently. Snapping. Not leading.

 

 You grimace, trying not to consider the conversation Gordon is now having with Thompson.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <> 
 
 You meet Gordon’s gaze for a moment. Then look away. Your shoulders lift in a faint shrug. Nothing more.

 

 He waits. One second. Two. Then exhales sharply. “Fine. I’ll go straight to Thompson.”

 

 You open your mouth, but no words come out. By the time you think of something, he’s already walking off.

 

 The office is quiet again, but your chest feels tight. You didn’t lie. You didn’t flirt. You didn’t try to spin some story. But you just… did nothing.

 

 You grimace, trying not to consider the conversation Gordon is now having with Thompson.
 
 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 <>

title: HarrowDialogue
text:
You raise your hand quickly before the lesson begins. Harrow catches sight of you immediately, flashing a gleaming smile. “Yes, Miss Phillips?” he says, voice warm and theatrical. “What could possibly be more compelling than the marvels of natural biology?”

 

 You hesitate under his gaze. “I’d like to be excused from the lesson.”

 

 He tilts his head slightly. “Excused?” he repeats, the smile never faltering. “Miss Phillips, surely you’re not suggesting you’d rather skip today’s fascinating dive into the instincts of the natural world? The primal elegance of procreation, the biological imperatives of the female form.” He spreads his arms wide, like a magician revealing a final trick. “There’s so much to admire.”

 

 You shift in your seat. His words are friendly enough, but something in his tone makes it hard to push back. His charm is thick. Heavy. And somehow oppressive.

 

 Still, you take a breath. You need to see the boy’s version of the segregated lessons.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

 <>

 You reach into your bag and carefully withdraw the hall pass. Harrow’s smile freezes for a split second. His eyes narrow as he takes in the slip, then flick up to meet yours.

 

 “Well,” he says, the warmth in his voice not quite masking the suspicion beneath. “It appears you’ve been given permission for other priorities.”

 

 He steps aside slightly, folding his hands behind his back. “Though I must ask. Are you quite sure, Miss Phillips? Today’s lesson is especially illuminating.”

 

 You nod, even as something in the pit of your stomach makes you hesitate. A quiet itch to stay and watch.

 

 Harrow’s smile returns. “Very well. Hurry along then. We wouldn’t want to deprive your other commitments of your… presence.” He gestures toward the door with a graceful wave. “I’ll see you next time.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 You shift slightly in your seat, fidgeting. “I’m sorry, sir,” you say, keeping your voice low. “I think I might need to be excused. It’s… women’s stuff. Cramps. I didn’t want to make a scene.”

 

 For a moment, Harrow says nothing. He presses his fingers together in front of his lips, gaze flicking over you. Then he sighs with an air of theatrical sympathy.

 

 “Ah,” he murmurs, keeping his voice to a whisper. “The silent sufferings of the fairer sex. Say no more.”

 

 He crosses to his desk, opens a drawer, and withdraws a small pad of paper. You watch as he scribbles on it, ignoring the looks of other students now watching you.

 

 Eventually he returns, sliding a slip onto your desk. "While I can't claim to know what you're going through," he whispers, "I can at least spare you the miracle of marsupial birth on film for one day.”

 

 You grimace politely.

 

 “This will excuse you for this lesson only. I expect you to return next time with renewed spirit and... abdominal stability.”

 

 You nod, taking the slip. “Thank you, sir.”

 

 He gestures toward the door, his smile slipping just slightly into a smirk. “Stop by Nurse Rancy’s. She’s frightfully good at treating these delicate matters. You’d be surprised what a little institutional intervention can fix.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You raise your hand quickly before the lesson begins. Harrow catches sight of you and flashes you a gleaming smile. “Yes, Miss Phillips?”

 

 You hesitate under his gaze. “I’d like to be excused from the lesson.”

 

 He tilts his head slightly. “Are you still suffering from the female affliction, Miss Phillips?"

 

 You shift, feeling the eyes of the class on you. "Just feeling unwell, sir."

 

 Harrow studies you, then nods. "Nurse Rancy said you might need to be excused," he comments. "Very well. Make sure you head straight to her office though, Miss."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: HeatherDialogue
text:
“What are you doing waiting here, Heather?” you ask her. 

 

 She looks off to the side, reflecting, before turning back to you and whispering softly. “Coach Beach said that I might as well clean every evening after classes. I always come last in PE, anyway. This way, I’ll get extra credit for cleaning. I’ll at least pass.”

 

 “Where’s Coach Beach now?” you ask her.

 

 She shrugs. “Sometimes he comes,” she says quietly. “Sometimes he doesn’t. He gave me a key to the gym. He lets me come and go as I please. I even clean in the mornings too.”

 

 “You sound like you enjoy it,” you tell her.

 

 She looks up at you with her large eyes, a smile appearing in spite of clear reluctance. “You get used to it. The smell. The scents. The boys.”

 

 You let one of your eyebrows rise up. “The boys?”

 

 Heather nods, replying in a hushed, if a little resigned, tone. “Beach lets his football players watch sometimes. Comment. Not that I blame them. After all, girls are made for boys.”

 

 Actions

 She looks down to the floor, her cheeks reddening. “Coach Beach said that I might as well clean every evening after classes," she mutters. "I always come last in PE, anyway. This way, I’ll get extra credit for cleaning. I’ll at least pass.”

 “You sound like you enjoy it,” you tell her.

 

 She looks up at you with her large eyes, a smile appearing in spite of clear reluctance. “You get used to it.”

 

 You frown. "The cleaning?"

 

 Heather looks at you for a long moment. "Yes," she mutters. "The cleaning."

 

 Actions

 <> 
 

 “What do you mean he lets the boys watch?” you ask, narrowing your eyes.

 

 Heather looks at you, stone-face free from emotion. “They watch me… clean,” she says.

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “Clean?”

 

 She looks at you, suddenly worried, as if she’s revealed too much. “Just clean,” she reiterates. “Sometimes, I clean… privately. For Beach.” She gulps, her face going sour. “At least he keeps that private.”

 

 You regard the waifish girl in front of you, considering what her emotionless tone really means. “Isn’t that bullying?”

 

 Heather shrugs. “Isn’t that how it works around here?” she asks you without care. “That’s how the popular kids keep people in-line. There’s a pecking order to uphold.”

 

 The words sound foreign to Heather’s voice. As if she’s been told them time after time, now used to repeating them without question.

 <>
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 “Hey Heather,” you begin. “Could I borrow the key to the gym for a while?”

 

 Her eyes lock onto yours immediately, filling with fear. She grinds one of her top teeth into her bottom lip. “I can’t do that.”

 

 “Come on, no one would find out,” you try to reassure her.

 

 She takes a deep breath. You see the hesitation on her face. “He will find out,” she whispers.

 

 “I promise you, he won't," you say, reassuringly.

 

 Another deep breath. Her eyes glance off to the side. Then she reaches down and takes out a single key from inside her sock. "I didn't give you that," she says, eyes wide. "Please.”

 

 You nod. "Secret is safe with me."

 

 Heather winces. You are convinced she has little faith this won't end badly for her.

 Her eyes lock onto yours immediately, filling with fear. She shakes her head rapidly. “No. I can’t do that.”

 

 “Come on, no one would find out,” you try to reassure her.

 

 She continues to shake her head. “He will find out,” she murmurs. “I can’t do it.”

 

 “Can I do anything to help?” you try.

 

 She shakes her head again. “Just don’t ask me for that. I don’t want to get in trouble.”

 

 Actions

 <> 
 

 
 "Don't play coy with me, Heather," you say. "I know exactly what you do when you 'clean' in the gym."

 

 Heather looks up directly at you from beneath her eyelashes, suddenly alert. "What do you mean?" she splutters.

 

 You smile, menacingly. "I know what sort of cleaning Beach asks of you. What sort of things you have to wear. Or what you don't."

 

 You watch as Heather shakes her head quickly, almost a flex. "I don't know what you mean," she says in a whispered voice.

 

 "I think you do," you say. "And I think unless you want the whole school to find out, you'll give me that key."

 

 The large eyes look back at you, unmoving. You can see the moisture glistening over each iris.

 

 "No," you hear a voice say, more assured than you would have expected.

 

 Heather tilts her head up, just slightly. She stares back at you, almost smirking. There are still tears ready, the face is painted in fear. But she's smiling. Almost manically.

 

 "He'd stop you," she says with venom. "Before you could even tell a soul. And then you'd be in there. With me."

 

 She looks back at the floor. "Go away," she murmurs.
