title: JackieDialogue
text:
“Can I have something else?” you ask. You notice a few students behind you roll their eyes.

 

 “Nurse’s orders, Phillips,” Jackie replies sternly. “You get what you got.”

 

 You look down at the bland salad. Your stomach rumbles, demanding food. 

 
 “Can I have something else?” you ask. You notice a few students behind you roll their eyes.

 

 “Nurse’s orders, Mannet,” Jackie replies sternly. “You get what you got.”

 

 You look down at the steak, dripping with fat. Your stomach rumbles, even in spite of how tough the meat looks.
 
 
 “Can I have something else?” you ask. You notice a few students behind you look at you in confusion.

 

 “Nurse’s orders, Duncan,” Jackie replies sternly. “You get what you got. Most kids would kill for it, too.”

 

 You look down at the burger, dripping with fat. Your stomach rumbles, even in spite of how it looks.
 
 
 

 Actions

 <> 

 “Who makes the lunch?” you ask Jackie. 

 

 She sighs with irritation. “Lunch is prepared in the morning on-site, made specifically as per Nurse Rancy’s direction. If you don’t like it, take it up with her. Now, anything else you want to nit-pick?”

 

 Jackie looks at you, impatiently. Other students mutter behind you in the queue.

 

 Actions
 
 <>

 "Hey Jackie," you begin. "I was wondering if I could borrow the key to the kitchen -"

 

 "Let me stop you right there," she says, her voice clipped and short. "That key? It’s staying right here with me." She gestures sharply at her pocket, her fingers curling protectively.

 

 "Do you have any idea what would happen if I handed it out? Chaos. Kids messing with the ovens, adding hot sauce to the soup. I’ve seen it all before.

 

 "Nurse's orders. Food is as per her instruction. No exceptions. If you're looking to stage some kind of prank, find another way. I’m not playing."

 

 Actions
 
 <>

 "I really need to get into the kitchen," you try. "It's important. I promise I'm not up to mischief."

 

 Jackie hesitates, her hand brushing the edge of her pocket. For a moment, she studies you with an uncharacteristically soft gaze.

 

 "What do you need it for?"

 

 You grimace, but offer her a smile. "I can't say. I promise though, it's not bad."

 

 She continues to look at you. "You’re not like the others, are you?" she says, her voice quieter now. "I’ve heard about you - people say you’ve got a good head on your shoulders. Not like the troublemakers."

 

 With a reluctant sigh, she pulls out the key, holding it just out of reach. "Listen to me. You mess this up, and I’ll make sure you never get another favour. Got it?"

 

 She drops the key into your hand, her tone softening just slightly. "Don’t make me regret this."

 The second item: a torn piece of paper. Evans’ Department Store note stock, just like the one in Terrence’s locker. Watermarked. The handwriting matches the note from Terrence's locker.

 

 Thanks for your help! Sunday mornings. 01434 457045.

 

 The number tugs at your memory. You’ve dialed it recently. It’s the landlord for the Handle household.

 

 So Jennifer’s been tutoring him. Quietly. Off the record. And she’s kept it to herself. And someone here at Evans Department Store knows where and why. Even stranger is the photo of Annie and Jennifer. And why she's got that inside this book.

 

 You tuck the note and photograph back where they were and slide the exercise book back into place. Then, quietly, you shut the locker. You’ll need to follow up. Whatever Jennifer’s doing, it isn’t just about grades.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: LennoxDialogue
text:
"Andrea told me that you're looking for work?" you tell him. "I was wondering if you had more details."

 

 Lennox frowns. "Andrea? Oh, Miss. Cinders. Do you mean to tell me she's been fraternising with guests?"

 

 You shake your head. "I just asked her a question about it."

 

 Lennox tuts, but returns his stare to you. His eyes drift over your body. A thin smile passes across his lips. "Well. Regardless of how you discovered it, we do have a vacancy. Are you over eighteen?"

 

 You nod. "Just finishing my final year at Charlton."

 

 A thin smile passes across his lips. "I'm sure you are an exemplary student."

 

 "We need a cleaning assistant to help Miss. Cinders. Lord knows she needs the help. We wouldn't want to jeopardise your studies, but if you're willing to work weekends and late nights, there may be a role for you here."

 

 You nod. "How do I apply?"

 

 He looks at you, his eyes cautiously wandering over your face. "No time like the present. Do you have some time free now? I think we should have a little chat. To assess your suitability for the role."

 

 The question is, do you really need to do this? Is access to the hotel really worth that much to you? Or are you that strapped for cash?

 

 *Because you wouldn't have any other reasons for applying for a maid job, would you?*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 You nod. "Just finishing my final year at Charlton."

 

 A thin smile passes across his lips. "I'm sure you are an exemplary student."

 

 "We need a cleaning assistant to help Miss. Cinders. Lord knows she needs the help. We wouldn't want to jeopardise your studies, but if you're willing to work weekends and late nights, there may be a role for you here."

 

 You nod. "How do I apply?"

 

 He looks at you, his eyes cautiously wandering over your face. "No time like the present. Do you have some time free now? I think we should have a little chat. To assess your suitability for the role."

 

 The question is, do you really need to do this? Is access to the hotel really worth that much to you? Or are you that strapped for cash?

 

 *Because you wouldn't have any other reasons for applying for a maid job, would you?*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 "I saw the advert in the Charlton Gazette," you tell him. "I was wondering if you had more details."

 

 Lennox's eyes drift over your body. There is a hint of a wince. "Are you sure that customer service is something suited to you?"

 

 You nod. "I'm sure I will manage."

 

 A thin smile plays across his lips. "Just managing isn't what we expect at the Charlton Hotel. Our staff are expected to exceed our expectations. And their own."

 

 You wince at the slip. "I assure you, I'm a hard worker."

 

 "That may be the case," Lennox says. "But I'm afraid that someone of your reputation isn't suitable for our establishment. If you struggle to fulfil the duties of a secretary, I have no doubt you lack what we're looking for."

 

 Lennox's eyes meet yours. The icy stare makes you grow colder. You accept his judgement without a word and quietly nod.
 
 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 

 “I’ll get to it in a bit,” you tell him, a slight tinge of defiance in your voice. 

 

 Lennox’s eyes narrow, but you can see the surprise on his face. “Excuse me, Miss. Cinders? You’ll get to it? In a bit?"

 

 You nod, trying to meet his cold eyes and only being partially successful. “I’m needed in the kitchen,” you tell him.

 

 “I bet you are,” he says, a sneer in his voice. “You spend a lot of time in there. Alone. With Pierre.”

 

 This time you say nothing. After a moment, he flares his nostrils and snarls at you.

 

 “Fine,” he barks. “Get yourself to the kitchen. But I expect the lobby to be spotless within the hour.”

 

 He turns and returns to his work, leaving you alone.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 “Yes sir,” you say, hearing your voice meek and subservient.
 
 

 “Get to it, then,” he barks back at you. 

 

 You walk over to the cleaning trolley and take out a feather duster. For the next hour, you brush down the oak panelling and dim lampshades. Your feet soon begin to ache as you stretch up to dust the tops of paintings and fixtures, trying desperately not to fall over when you lean back on to the stilettos of your heels.

 

 With your petite frame, the lobby feels oppressive and hostile. Lennox watches you carefully as he goes about his work, but additionally you catch the handful of guests giving you looks. You become all too aware of the shortness of your uniform and catch the male patrons staring at your legs. You can’t help but wonder if they catch a glimpse of your buttocks as you stretch up to clean.

 

 Time soon passes and once you feel you have cleaned the entire lobby, you look over to Lennox to seek his approval. He stares back at you for a moment, but says nothing.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 You take a deep breath, holding it steady as you focus the spell. Slowly, you exhale, letting the magic drift toward Lennox like a subtle breeze. His expression remains fixed in its usual disdainful sneer at first, but then his posture loosens slightly, his sharp gaze softening just enough to give you an opening.

 

 Lennox sighs through his nose, adjusting his cuffs with deliberate precision. "Fine," he mutters, his tone clipped and cold. "I have enough to do than play babysitter to people like you."

 

 He steps aside with a slow, deliberate motion, gesturing toward the staircase with a sharp flick of his hand. "Go on, then. First floor. Try not to embarrass yourself. Or worse, other guests." His words drip with sarcasm, though there’s a strange, detached smoothness to them, as if he’s barely aware of why he’s letting you through.

 

 As you pass, he straightens his jacket and exhales sharply. "I assume you’re capable of finding your own way," he adds, his tone returning to its usual cutting edge. "Don’t make a mess of it. And for heaven’s sake, don’t draw attention to yourself. I don’t have the time or the patience to explain why you’re up there."

 

 His eyes linger on you for a moment, narrowing slightly as though he’s trying to convince himself that this makes sense. Then he waves you off with an air of finality, turning his attention back to the lobby as though you’ve already ceased to exist.

 
 Something is wrong with the code, as Lennox has no magic.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You stand your ground, meeting Lennox’s smirking gaze with a level, unshaken stare.

 

 “This is a mistake,” you say smoothly, arms crossed. “I was on an errand for the hotel, and Sermon overreacted.”

 

 Lennox raises an eyebrow, clearly amused. “Oh? And what exactly were you doing out there, parading around town in that get-up?”

 

 You exhale sharply, keeping your voice calm, but firm. “There was a guest request. One of the regulars needed an item picked up. I was just handling it quickly between duties. If I changed out of the uniform, it would’ve wasted even more time.”

 

 Lennox’s smirk lingers, but you see the way his eyes narrow slightly, calculating. He lets the silence stretch, letting you sweat under his gaze, before finally exhaling through his nose, rolling his eyes.

 

 “Fine,” he mutters, waving a dismissive hand. “Get out of here before Sermon decides he wants your head on a silver platter.”

 

 You nod sharply, turning toward the door without hesitation. You’ll have to be more careful when outside as Andrea from now on.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 Lennox’s smirk widens, the amusement in his eyes growing sharper as he watches you desperately try to explain yourself.

 

 “An errand?” he repeats, mocking, his voice dripping with disbelief. “Really, Miss Cinders?”

 

 He tilts his head, studying you like you’re some pathetic little thing trying to climb out of a hole you dug yourself into.

 

 Then, before you can even open your mouth to try again, he grabs your wrist and turns sharply, guiding you toward the door with purposeful strides. “Come!”

 

 “Wha --" you stammer. "Lennox, wait -”

 

 “No, no,” he cuts you off, dragging you forward. “You wanted to play the responsible, dutiful little maid, didn’t you? Then it’s only right you take responsibility for your actions.”

 

 Your heart sinks as he pushes open the door and leads you through to the hotel. Toward the hotel restaurant.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You swallow hard, your pulse quickening as you look at Lennox’s unimpressed stare.

 

 "I... didn't mean to cause trouble,” you stammer, voice softer than you’d like. “Please. If you just let me go, I won’t do it again.”

 

 Lennox tilts his head, watching you with quiet amusement.

 

 “Let you go?” He grins, like a cat playing with a cornered mouse. “Are you suggesting I forget the standards we have here at the Charlton Hotel?”

 

 Your breath catches, but you push forward, voice wavering but desperate.

 

 “Because…” You hesitate, before forcing yourself to meet his gaze, trying to look as pitiful as possible. “I don’t want to get in trouble. Please, Mr. Lennox.”

 

 His smirk flickers, something satisfied gleaming behind his eyes. “Mr. Lennox?”

 

 You gulp. “Sir.”

 

 The begging. The submission. The way you’re waiting on his decision. For a long moment, he savors it.

 

 “Very well,” he sighs, like he’s doing you a great favor. “But only because I don’t feel like dealing with your whimpering today.”

 

 You nod quickly, turning toward the door.

 

 But just as you reach for the handle, his voice drawls behind you.

 

 “A word of advice. Don’t go skipping around town in uniform again, Miss. Cinders. You make the place look unprofessional.”

 

 You bite your lip, forcing yourself to nod and walk out without looking back.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You swallow hard, pulse quickening as you meet Lennox’s cold, amused gaze.

 

 “I... I didn’t mean to cause trouble,” you stammer, voice smaller than you’d like. “Please, just let me go. I won’t do it again.”

 

 Lennox’s lips curl, his smirk deepening. He leans against the lockers, arms crossed, watching you like you’re some desperate little thing squirming under his attention.

 

 “Oh, you won’t do it again, will you?” His voice is mocking, but there’s an undercurrent of something sharper beneath it. “Well, that’s sweet, Miss Cinders. Really, it is.”

 

 His smile lingers, but his eyes darken. “But tell me,” he continues, voice silkier now, “why should I just let you off? What kind of example would that set?”

 

 You open your mouth to say something - anything - but he’s already pushing himself off the wall, gripping your wrist firmly.

 

 Your stomach drops.

 

 “No, I think an apology is in order.”

 

 And just like that, he’s pulling you forward, his grip firm. Your heart sinks as he pushes open the door and leads you through to the hotel. Toward the hotel restaurant.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 You inhale deeply, drawing your magic from within, feeling it coax through your breath as you exhale. A subtle, shimmering mist of gold and amber drifts from your lips, sliding invisibly through the air toward Lennox.

 

 His expression softens, the sharp edge of his usual sarcastic smirk dulling, his eyes blinking just a little slower than before.

 

 “Please sir,” you say smoothly, stepping closer, voice sweet and gentle. “I really don’t want to be in trouble for something so silly. You don’t want to waste time with this, do you?”

 

 He tilts his head slightly, blinking lazily. “Hmm,” he murmurs, voice slightly dazed. “No… I suppose I don’t.”

 

 You press further, tilting your head in an innocent, almost apologetic way. “Then just let me go,” you coax. “It’s easier that way, right?”

 

 Lennox hesitates for just a moment. Then he shrugs, rubbing his temple. “Just... go before Sermon finds you again.”

 

 You smile sweetly, stepping toward the door. As you pass, he frowns slightly, like he’s trying to recall why he was mad in the first place. But the charm lingers.

 

 And by the time you’re out the door, he doesn’t even seem to care anymore.
 

 
 Game broken, as Lennox doesn't have magic.

 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Lennox offers you a thin smile. “Excellent. Follow me.”

 

 He leads you away from the reception, down a side hallway, and to a door tucked beneath the grand staircase. He opens it with a flourish.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Lennox’s smile tightens. “Ah. A pity.”

 

 He clasps his hands in front of him, tone growing more brittle with every word.

 

 “It is so very rare to find young women who are capable of managing their time with any degree of discipline these days. But I do understand. Hair to be curled, household duties to attend to, and all that.”

 

 He glances at his watch. “Do return when your schedule permits.” His tone is dry enough to sand a floor.

 

 “I’m currently reviewing a number of applicants,” he adds, brushing a speck from his cuff. “But given the state of modern attitudes toward work, I suspect the role shall remain open for some time.”

 

 He nods toward the lobby without another word. You are dismissed.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Lennox adjusts slightly in his chair, opening his notebook and uncapping the sleek black fountain pen.

 

 “Let us begin with a question on customer service. A scenario.”

 

 He doesn’t look at you as he speaks. His attention is entirely on the notebook, the pen already hovering.

 

 “You are working front desk. A guest comes down, agitated. They claim the towels in their room were not replaced. You are certain they were. However, when the towels are shown to you, they appear quite… soiled.”

 

 He pauses, glancing up at you.

 

 “There are, shall we say, marks of indeterminate origin. The guest is insistent. How do you respond?”

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [House Proud] <>

 
 <>
 
 <>
 
 
 You blink, the mental image of dirty towels causing you to feel queasy. “Honestly, I’d be horrified,” you can’t help but reply. *Even more concerning is that’s the honest truth.*

 

 “I’d replace the towels immediately and take them down to be properly cleaned. It wouldn’t matter if I was sure I did it before. If they’re dirty now, they need cleaning.”

 

 Lennox gives a slow nod. “Excellent. Quite right. At the Charlton Hotel, a guest’s perception is reality. It is not your job to defend your honour, Miss Phillips. It is your job to meet needs. Quickly. Quietly. Without fuss.”

 

 He taps his notebook. “Whether you changed the towels is immaterial. The customer must never be left with cause to doubt our standards. Even if their requests seem unreasonable… or outside your remit.”

 

 A faint smile. “The intention, I hope, is clear.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You hesitate, recalling when you used to work part-time jobs at University. You know the scenarios and know how to respond. Even when you are in the right.

 

 “I’d apologise,” you say. “And suggest I must have mistaken which room they were in. I’d still swap the towels out immediately.”

 

 Lennox raises an eyebrow. “Even if you are adamant you performed your duties?”

 

 You nod. “It’s not about being right. It’s about making the guest happy.”

 

 There’s a flicker of approval. “Very good. Our personal pride must always yield to our professional duty. Arguing achieves nothing. Swift resolution does. Well said.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You grimace. It’s not like you don’t understand customer service, you worked enough jobs at University to know what Lennox expects from you. But in Charlton, you know, the smallest sign of appeasement seems to lead to dangerous consequences.

 

 “I’d tell them I definitely changed the towels,” you say. “But I’d swap them out again just to be sure.”

 

 Lennox’s face hardens just slightly. “I see. So you would contradict the guest. Assert your version of events.”

 

 “I’d just want to be honest.”

 

 He writes something down, the pen scratching with quiet precision.

 

 “You must learn this now, Miss Phillips: our guests are never liars. Only… misinformed. And even then, it is not our place to say so. If your first instinct is to defend yourself, rather than serve. Well, that may need work.”

 

 He looks back up. “Shall we continue?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Lennox flips the page in his notebook. The pen glides into position again.

 

 “Let us discuss competence,” he says. “And, more specifically, the recognition of one’s… limitations.”

 

 He taps the page lightly. “You are doing laundry in the service room. The machines are complex, industrial-grade. You find yourself struggling with the dials, the settings… which cycle is which, how long, how hot. It’s rather overwhelming.”

 

 Lennox’s gaze settles coolly on you. “And then, in walks Mr. Sermon himself. Eager to meet his new maid.”

 

 His voice takes on a silken edge. “He watches you fumble. And says, ‘Do you need help, young lady? These settings can be complicated for someone like you. Do I need to explain how to operate a washing machine?’”

 

 There is a long pause. Then: “How do you respond?”

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [Citizen Charlton] <>

 
 <>
 
 <>
 
 
 You hesitate, but the image forms clearly in your mind. Sermon standing tall, authoritative, questioning your ability. And the strangest thing is… you don’t want to argue.

 

 Of course you could work it out. You’ve written code. Handled backend systems more complicated than any appliance. But something in the tone you assign to him makes you wilt.

 

 If he thinks you need help… maybe you do.

 

 “I’d ask him for help,” you say softly. “If Mr. Sermon believes I’m struggling, I wouldn’t want to waste time.”

 

 Lennox gives a long, pleased sigh. “Good. Very good. Some things,” he adds pointedly, “are simply beyond the capacity of a young lady’s brain. They are smaller, after all. Not made for the complexities of machinery.”

 

 He leans closer, voice like syrup. “Deferring to a man’s intellect is often the most… efficient path. Mr. Sermon would appreciate that. He might even give you an affectionate pat on the bum for being such a good girl.”

 

 Your breath hitches.

 

 “And I dare say,” Lennox smiles thinly, “you’d like that. Wouldn’t you?”

 

 A shiver runs down your spine. Not from disgust. But because… he might be right.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You try to imagine it. The knobs. The unfamiliar cycles. Maybe you could figure it out… but then again, maybe you’ve overestimated yourself. Maybe this job requires more nuance than you assumed.

 

 “I’d admit I didn’t understand it,” you say. “At least not completely. I’d ask for help.”

 

 Lennox nods slowly. “It’s refreshing to see honesty. So many young women think this sort of work is all tips and smiling at guests.”

 

 He uncaps his pen with a sharp click. “But recognising when a task exceeds your capabilities… that shows maturity. Knowing your limits is the mark of a reliable maid.”

 

 You nod faintly.

 

 Still… it’s just a washing machine. *Isn’t it?*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You frown. “Honestly? I’d tell Mr. Sermon I appreciate the offer, but I’d like to figure it out myself. It’s just a washing machine. I’m sure I could manage.”

 

 Lennox’s face cools immediately. “I see. So you would decline the offer of assistance. Risk inefficiency. Risk error. All in the name of… pride?”

 

 You shake your head. “I’d just rather not trouble him.”

 

 He closes his notebook slowly. “Andrea said the same when she started. Until we had a week of white linens turned pink and she had her pay docked.”

 

 He straightens, voice like glass. “Young women must understand that guidance exists for a reason. Your job is not to prove something. It is to deliver results. And at this hotel, that means recognising when something is beyond you.”

 

 His smile returns, but it’s cold this time. “You’ll need to understand that if you wish to work here.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Lennox flips another page, eyes calm and unreadable.

 

 “Let’s consider… interpersonal boundaries,” he says, voice light but deliberate. “And the expectations of a young woman in a place such as this.”

 

 His pen floats above the page. “You are dusting a guest’s room. A prominent figure in Charlton, let’s say. Someone returning from a productive day of meetings at the Town Hall. They’re in high spirits. Grateful for the hard work you’ve put in.”

 

 Lennox leans back slightly, almost enjoying the scene he’s painting.

 

 “They order room service. A fine meal. And then, they extend an invitation. For you to stay. To dine. To celebrate with them. A quiet dinner. A little company.”

 

 He tilts his head. “How do you respond?”

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [Boy Crazy] <>

 
 <>
 
 <>
 

 Your cheeks flush before you even realise it.

 

 “A guest?” you murmur, a flutter catching in your chest. “What… do they look like?”

 

 Lennox’s pen halts mid-stroke. He frowns.

 

 “This is not a dating agency, Miss Phillips,” he says sharply. “We are not running a social club for the romantically inclined.”

 

 You squirm in your seat, but your thoughts drift anyway. To glasses clinking, candlelight, the warmth of a gaze across the table. A guest, charmed by you. Holding your hand. A soft bed only a few feet away…

 

 “A maid at the Charlton Hotel,” Lennox continues coldly, “has the establishment’s reputation to uphold. Floozy behaviour might be standard at certain low-rent motels, but here? We maintain decorum. Unauthorised fraternisation is not allowed.”

 

 The word unauthorised flickers in your mind. *Might be a version that is allowed?*

 

 “Focus,” Lennox snaps. “This is not the time to entertain your little fantasies about eligible bachelors, Miss Phillips.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 You hesitate. The scenario plays out in your mind. An invitation, polite and sincere. A guest who simply wants a bit of company after a long day.

 

 “I think I’d accept,” you say. “If they were kind. Polite. It wouldn’t be a date. It’d be customer care.”

 

 Lennox exhales. A disappointed sound, but not a surprised one. “There is a line, Miss Phillips. One must always maintain boundaries. This is a hotel, not a madam’s boudoir.”

 

 You blink. “I understand.”

 

 “Unauthorised fraternisation is strictly frowned upon,” he says. 

 

 The word lingers in your mind. Unauthorised?

 

 Lennox’s voice slices through your thoughts. “I commend your dedication to customer service,” he says, “but in this case, preserving the dignity of the hotel must come first. A polite decline would suffice.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You shift in your seat. “I’d thank them for the invitation, but decline,” you say firmly. “I’d mention I have duties still to finish. And… I’d try not to offend them.”

 

 Lennox’s pen glides confidently across the page. “And if the guest insisted?”

 

 You nod. “I’d decline again. Politely. But clearly.”

 

 Lennox’s eyes gleam with something almost like approval. “Good. Very good. The Sermon family values its name, Miss Phillips. This hotel is a place of professionalism. Not… indulgence.”

 

 He straightens a little. “Any unauthorised relationships with guests are strictly prohibited. I’m glad you understand that your behaviour reflects on this establishment.”

 

 You nod. But inside, the word sticks in your mind like a pebble in your shoe. *Unauthorised?*

 

 Lennox clears his throat. “Too many young women fail to walk that delicate line between being polite… and retaining their virtue. I’m relieved to see you are not one of them.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Lennox places his fountain pen down with slow, deliberate precision. He closes the notebook, then rests it beside him on the desk.

 

 “Well, Miss Phillips,” he says, his voice smooth and unreadable, “that was… very insightful.”

 

 
 He clasps his hands together, almost pleased. “Your answers showed a strong grasp of customer expectations and internal conduct. Your instincts were sharp. Your manners, suitably deferential.”

 

 A thin smile.

 

 “I believe you’ll do outstandingly well here. You’ve demonstrated the kind of mindset Mr. Sermon prizes. One of service, discretion, and respectability. I’m sure your time with us will be fruitful. At least,” he adds, eyes flicking over your face, “until you settle down and raise a family of your own.”

 

 He lets the words linger before adding, “But that’s a few years away, I should hope. Until then…”

 

 He pulls a crisp envelope from his drawer. “A little incentive. An advance. A reflection of the trust we are extending.” 
 
 He exhales softly, nodding. “You did well. A few answers could use refinement, but overall I believe you’ll settle in here just fine.”

 

 Lennox then fixes you with a more serious look. “Remember, at the Charlton Hotel, a maid must always consider two things: the reputation of this establishment… and the experience of the guest.”

 

 His tone hardens slightly. “I expect you’ll work on the areas where you require a step up. And I’ll be happy to assist where needed.”

 
 Lennox pauses. “I shall be blunt. There are… concerns. Your responses indicate you are not yet aligned with our expectations.”

 

 He stands. “Ordinarily, I would have serious reservations about offering you a place here.”

 

 Then he sighs. “But our applicant pool has been rather limited of late. So I’m willing to extend you an opportunity. With the understanding that you will learn.”

 

 He leans in ever so slightly. “And if not… well. We have ways to encourage the right attitudes.”

 
 

 Lennox opens a drawer and removes a small form. He hands it to you. “Fill in your measurements and personal details. Your uniform will be ready in the staff locker before your first shift. The code to the staff room is written at the top of that form. See that you remember it.”

 

 He adds, “Do not wear it outside. Mr. Sermon is… particular. He expects his maids to uphold this hotel’s standards. Public shame reflects poorly on us all.”

 

 Then he straightens, the faintest smile returning. “I expect to see you for your first evening shift promptly. Welcome to the staff, Miss Phillips.”

 

 He gestures to the door. “You may go.”

 

 *You should really let Emily know you’ve taken a job at the hotel as her, so she doesn’t go to the hotel when you’re working.*

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: LogainDialogue
text:
“You go to Charlton, right?” you ask him.

 

 “As little as I can,” he replies. “But there’s not much else to do in our sleepy little town, so sometimes I grace them with my presence.”

 

 “How do you find it?”

 

 “Stimulating. Invigorating. The centre of my world.” 

 

 He looks at you, waiting for you to respond. “You’re Phillips’ older sister, right? She’s in some of my classes. She's fun.”

 

 You give him a look. "Easy, no offense meant. She's just cute, is all."

 

 You look at him, feeling odd to be discussing your sister in this way. *Especially as recently your sister has been you.* 

 

 “Now, if you don’t mind,” Logain says, gesturing away. “I have things to do.”

 
 “You go to Charlton, right?” you ask him.

 

 “As little as I can,” he replies. “But there’s not much else to do in our sleepy little town, so sometimes I grace them with my presence.”

 

 “How do you find it?”

 

 “Stimulating. Invigorating. The centre of my world.” 

 

 He looks at you, waiting for you to respond. “You’re Phillips’ older brother, right? She’s in some of my classes. Cute, in an earnest sort of way.”

 

 You look at him, feeling odd to be discussing your sister in this way. *Especially as recently your sister has been you.* 

 

 “Now, if you don’t mind,” Logain says, gesturing away. “I have things to do.”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 “So,” you begin. “Why are you out of school?”

 

 Logain grins. “Our illustrious leader Mr. Stitch gave me permission to leave school early. Special privileges, like all the top performers. Cheerleaders, geeks, jocks. He seems to think it's a reward for keeping in line.” Logain snorts. “Letting us wander this dead town aimlessly. Such a generous guy.”

 

 You tilt your head a little. “And which group do you figure you fall into?”

 

 Logain’s grin widens. “Family connections,” he replies, voice laced with sarcasm. “My old man would rather I bunk off with his blessing than end up in detention.”
 
 <>

 ”Why are those kids giving you money?” you ask him quietly. “What are you up to, Logain?"

 Logain shrugs, cocky grin returning. “I don’t like to kiss and tell. But I do like to brag. So… yes.”

 

 You cross your arms. “And how exactly did you get one?”

 

 He pauses, briefly glancing to the door to McTafeys. “The old man knows people," he says with a smirk. "Has friends in the right places. You know. Connections. Family. Everything you’d expect from Charlton’s close knit elites.”

 

 He glances back at you, grin sharpening. “Not sure you’ve got that kind of clout in those crowds, squirt.”

 

 You bite back a retort. “So how would someone without ‘clout’ get one?”

 

 Logain chuckles again. “You want advice on how to break out of class? I’m sure I can think of better ways to run a scam. You scratch my back, I scratch yours.”

 

 You huff. “I don’t think I want you scratching my back, Logain.”

 

 He grins. “Your loss. I can be gentle when it suits.”

 

 When you don’t respond, he rolls his eyes. “Talk to Dennis. He’s odd, but plays his bad hand well. Enough to get Harrow on side. It’s definitely not his family that gets him out of lessons. You might be able to talk him ‘round. Just bat those pretty little eyes at him and I’m sure he’ll scramble to help you.”

 

 He stretches, as if signalling he’s done with this topic. “Anyway. That’s your best shot. Just don’t say I never gave you anything.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 You stare at Logain. He glares at you. "What?"

 

 You mentally stir the magic within your body and take a deep breath, threading the air in your lungs through the swirling energies.

 

 Logain's eyes cloud over as you breathe out, his wry smile returning as his blue eyes glimmer as he looks at you. You see the alarm within them for a moment before it fades away. The magic has taken hold.

 

 "Want something, cutie?" he murmurs, keeping his smile up at the side of his mouth. His eyes lock on to you, his attention consumed by your presence.

 
 Something is wrong with the code, as Logain has no magic.

 You take a deep breath, trying again. “So you're a talent scout?”

 You give him a smile, trying to warm him to you. "So you're looking for new talent?"

title: MartinDialogue
text:
Whether it’s due to Martin’s imposing physicality or his domineering personality, something inside you prevents you from standing up to him. You instead freeze, as the strong brute pulls you against his body.

 

 “Looks like you do,” Martin taunts. “What do you say, darl? My van is parked out on the street. Want to see what a real man looks like?”

 

 Images flash up in your mind. Martin’s van parked in a dark alley. The imposing drunk brute towering over you. The sort of things that you can only imagine he’s insinuating in his offer for fun.

 

 “Think you should leave the girl alone,” you hear a voice say from behind you. 

 

 A hand reaches in and twists Martin’s arm, instantly forcing him to let go of you. You look up to see Clive, holding Martin back with one arm.

 

 “What’s the matter, Burtle?” Martin spits at him. “Got a soft spot for her?”

 

 Clive stares back at Martin, not flinching. “Go. Sit.”

 

 "It's okay," you interject. "I don't mind."

 

 Noise in the bar has fallen away to silence. You take a step back, free from Martin's grasp, looking straight back at him. He grins.

 

 Out of the corner of your eye, you see Clive bristle. "Well don't treat ladies like that in here," he says after a moment. "Maybe try downstairs, Martin. Either way, take your business elsewhere. I think I speak for everyone when we say we don't want to see you back here for a while."

 

 After a tense moment, Martin snorts. “I’ll see you later,” he says to you, winking. He then walks out.

 

 The tense atmosphere diffused, you hear conversation start up again and soon the bar returns to normal. Clive stands by you, only turning his eyes to you once Martin has left.

 

 “You okay?” he asks you. 

 

 You nod. “Yes.”

 

 He studies you for a moment, before grimacing. “You do you, darlin'. But my advice - avoid that one. The drink doesn’t mix well with him.”

 

 Clive smiles with concern, then returns to his own seat, leaving you alone once more.

 
 Whether it’s due to Martin’s imposing physicality or his domineering personality, something inside you prevents you from standing up to him. You instead freeze, as the strong brute pulls you against his body.

 

 “Looks like you do,” Martin taunts. “What do you say, darl? My van is parked out on the street. Want to see what a real man looks like?”

 

 Images flash up in your mind. Martin’s van parked in a dark alley. The imposing drunk brute towering over you. The sort of things that you can only imagine he’s insinuating in his offer for fun.

 

 “That’s enough!” you hear Rhiannon shout from behind the bar, her playful demeanour evaporated and replaced with a serious and assertive tone far beyond her young age.

 

 “What’s the matter?” Martin asks her, mockingly, as his hand starts to grope at your waist. “She wants it.”

 

 “You want me to call my father?” Rhiannon replies. 

 

 "It's okay," you hear your meek voice saying. "I don't mind."

 

 Rhiannon stares at you, then raises an eyebrow. "Well, I mind it happening whilst I'm working. I think you should leave, Martin. You're barred."

 

 At that, Martin gives you a look. A menacing smile passes across his face. "Come see me later," he mutters to you. "Better be worth being barred."
 
 

 You watch him go as he walks out the door, before turning to look at Rhiannon from underneath your eyelashes. She smiles politely, but returns to work. Other patrons follow her lead and turn back to their conversations. Soon the bar returns to normal.

 

 Except, your eyes linger on the door. To where Martin left.

 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 

 
 You swallow hard, trying to summon the words to appease Martin’s lecherous comments. Your movements are hesitant, and your voice wavers as you attempt to give him what he wants, but it’s clear you’re out of your depth.

 

 Martin’s grin fades into a scowl, his thick fingers tightening briefly on your arm. "What’s this?" he growls, his voice heavy with disdain. "You think you’re cute, playing coy? Don’t waste my time, darl. If you’ve got nothing to offer, don’t bother trying."

 

 Before you can respond, Martin’s looming presence is interrupted by a calm but commanding voice from behind you. "Let her go, Martin."

 

 You glance back to see Clive, his expression steady but his eyes sharp. Martin’s grip loosens, and he sneers as he sizes up Clive. "Burtle," Martin spits, his tone dripping with mockery. "You always gotta stick your nose where it doesn’t belong?"

 

 Clive steps closer, his towering frame radiating quiet authority. "I said, let her go," he repeats, his voice leaving no room for argument.

 

 After a tense moment, Martin snorts, shoving you away as if you were nothing more than a minor inconvenience. "She’s not worth it anyway," he mutters, flashing you a nasty smile. "Next time, don’t waste my time."

 

 He storms back to his table, muttering under his breath. The tension in the room begins to dissipate, conversations resuming around you. Clive gives you a once-over, his tone softening as he asks, "You alright?"

 

 You nod, feeling a mix of shame and relief. "Thanks," you manage to say.

 

 Clive nods, his expression unreadable. "Be careful around him," he says quietly. "He doesn’t take kindly to games. If I were you, I'd get out of here before he has another."

 

 You glance over at Martin, then nod to Clive. "Sure."

 
 You try to appease Martin, but your shaky movements and hesitant voice betray your lack of confidence. Martin’s grin twists into an ugly sneer, his hand tightening on your waist as his patience wears thin.

 

 "Pathetic," he growls, his tone dripping with disgust. "What’s this supposed to be? You think batting your eyelashes is gonna work? If you’re not gonna play properly, don’t bother wasting my time."

 

 His grip becomes uncomfortably firm, but before you can respond, a sharp voice cuts through the tension. "That’s enough!" Rhiannon shouts from behind the bar, her playful tone gone, replaced by a commanding authority that silences the room.

 

 Martin turns his glare to her, his lip curling. "What’s the matter, little missy?" he taunts. "She’s the one asking for it. Can’t you see that?"

 

 Rhiannon doesn’t flinch, her hands gripping the edge of the bar. "You want me to call my father, Martin?" she says, her voice steady, with just enough edge to cut through the room.

 

 The name hangs in the air like a warning. Martin’s sneer falters as he glances between you and Rhiannon. After a tense moment, he lets go, shoving you aside. "Not worth it," he mutters, his tone filled with venom as he stalks back to his table.

 

 Rhiannon offers you a sympathetic look as the noise in the bar gradually returns to normal. "You okay?" she asks, her voice softer now.

 

 You nod, though your hands are still trembling. "Thank you," you say quietly.

 

 "Don’t thank me," she replies with a small smile. "Just steer clear of Martin. He’s not someone you want to mess with. If I were you, I'd leave before he drinks more."

 

 With that, she moves on to serve another customer, leaving you alone with the lingering unease of Martin’s glare burning into your back. You decide to take her advice. Time to leave.

 <>

 
 "Let me go!" you snap, your voice sharp and steady as you glare up at Martin. When he doesn’t release you, you shove against his chest, forcing him to stumble back slightly. The shock in his eyes lasts only a second before anger begins to flare.

 

 "Back off, Martin," you say, your tone firm and unwavering. "You don’t scare me, and you’re not going to touch me again. Got it?"

 

 For a moment, Martin just stares at you, his chest heaving as though trying to decide whether to lash out or back down. Then he smirks, though it’s more a grimace than a grin. "Oh, you’ve got a big mouth, don’t you?" he growls, taking a step toward you.

 

 "Careful, Martin," Clive’s calm voice cuts through the tension like a knife. Martin freezes, his head snapping toward the sound. Clive steps forward, his expression unshakably neutral, but his presence radiates authority.

 

 "What’s the matter, Burtle?" Martin sneers, his tone dripping with venom. "Always jumping to the rescue of little girls?"

 

 Clive doesn’t flinch, his eyes locked on Martin. "Go sit down," he says quietly, his voice carrying an unmistakable edge. "Now."

 

 "No," you hear yourself say, looking directly at the lecherous man. "Better still. Leave."

 

 The bar grows even more tense. You don't look away from Martin, but out of the corner of your eye see Clive give you an appreciative look.

 

 "You heard the lady," you hear him say. "Best leave. Don't come back for a while."

 

 Martin’s jaw tightens, and for a moment, you think he might push back. But then he snorts, nostrils flaring. "This isn’t over," he mutters, storming out the door.

 

 Clive turns to you, his expression softening slightly. "You alright?" he asks, his voice low.

 

 You nod, your pulse still racing. "Thanks," you say, your voice steadier than you expected.

 

 He nods in return, giving you a small smile. "You handled yourself well. Just keep your distance from him - he’s not worth your time."
 
 
 "Let me go!" you snap, shoving against Martin’s chest with a burst of force that catches him off guard. He stumbles slightly, his grin faltering as he straightens up, anger flashing across his face.

 Rhiannon doesn’t flinch, her hands firmly planted on the bar. "Why don’t you?" she retorts, her voice steady and unyielding. "Walk away, Martin. Unless you want me to call my father."

 

 Martin’s sneer falters, his anger simmering just beneath the surface as he glares at both of you. After a long pause, he snarls, "Not worth it," and stalks back towards his table.

 Martin glares over at her, breaking off from looking at you. A moment passes where you think he's going to leap over the bar. Instead, he turns and storms out.

 

 It takes a long time for people to resume their chatter. You look over to Rhiannon, watching her stern expression soften as she looks at you.

 

 "You okay?" she asks, her tone more gentle now.

 

 You nod, exhaling a shaky breath. "Yeah. Thanks."

 

 "Don’t thank me," she says, her lips quirking into a small smile. "You handled yourself. Just... steer clear of him, alright? He’s not someone to mess with."

 Ron’s frown deepens as he steps further into the shop. "Get to work, Martin," he says curtly, jerking his head toward the door. The bell rings again as he opens it for him.

 

 Martin hesitates, his glare flicking back to you one last time. "This isn’t over," he mutters, but the threat in his tone lacks its usual edge. He brushes past you, muttering curses under his breath, and steps out into the street.

 

 Ron sets the groceries on the counter, giving you a hard but not unsympathetic look. "Standing up to him, now?" he mutters gruffly. "You better fix yourself up and get back to work."

 

 You glance at the mirror behind the counter. Your blouse is rumpled, your face flushed, but your reflection shows more than just disarray. You see strength there - your own. As you smooth your clothes and steady your breath, a small, determined smile creeps onto your lips. Martin won’t try this again.

 

 You are confident that you can now exit Fresh Pot without arousing suspicion. Alternatively, you know Flo will be unconscious for a while. You could work a shift as her at the coffee shop.
 

 *If you really wanted to.*

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 <>

 "Take your hands off of me!" you shout as you thrust your elbow back into his stomach.

 

 Martin yelps and involuntarily eases his grip on your body. You seize the moment, pushing him back and ducking under his arms.

 

 "You'll pay for that, bitch," Martin says flatly, looking at you.

 

 Backed up against the benchtop opposite the counter, you stare up at him. You see the rage in his glare and the aggression in his snarl. He looks down on you, almost a foot taller than your current form.

 

 "Get out," you say to him, with strength in your voice in spite of your lip trembling.

 

 You watch as his eyes flick up and down your body. He doesn't move. A grin spreads across his face.

 

 Suddenly the bell rings out as the door opens and you spin around to see the sweaty owner, Ron Denver, entering with a grocery box under his arm. "Goddamn this weather..." he says before seeing the situation unfolding in his shop.

 

 "What are you doing behind the counter, Martin?" Ron asks him.

 

 "Just spending some quality time with the lady," Martin replies.

 

 Ron's eyes dart between you and Martin, narrowing. "You should get to work," he tells Martin. The bell rings again as he opens the door for him.

 

 After a long moment, Martin sighs and walks around the counter. He flashes you a grin as he moves by. "I'll see you later, babe," he says as he leaves.

 

 There is a long moment of silence as the door closes behind him. Ron looks at you, offering the closest to a sympathetic smile you've ever seen in Charlton.

 

 He puts the box down on the counter. "Here's the bread for the sandwiches. I've got to go to the town hall. Get to work."

 

 You nod silently, and Ron exits, leaving you alone in the shop.
 
 

 You are confident that you can now exit Fresh Pot without arousing suspicion. Alternatively, you know Flo will be unconscious for a while. You could work a shift as her at the coffee shop.

 

 *If you really wanted to.*

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 <>

 Your heart is pounding as you force yourself to step forward, every high-heeled stride a reminder of how exposed you feel.

 

 “C’mon Phillips, don’t be shy!” he shouts again, his tone growing more insistent. He's slowed down to a crawl, matching your pace even as you speed up as best you can in the heeled boots.

 

 You try not to meet his eye, instead looking forward. You feel the weight of every exposed inch of your legs and every unnatural sway in your movements. Over the clip-clopping of your heels is the sound of the purring engine from Martin's delivery van. Menacing. A threat.

 

 "Feeling shy, are ya'?" you hear his bellow. "Don't worry about that, darl'. Come see me one night at McTafeys. A few drinks will loosen you up."

 

 Again, you ignore his words. Finally, you hear the van's engine purr and Martin speeds up, leaving you alone walking the street once more.

 

 You continue walking along the street, feeling your body shaking from the unwanted attention. More aware of the dangers Charlton poses to women.

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>

 Your body jolts as your eyes finally meet his, and for a moment, the vulnerability surging through you transforms into raw defiance. Every high-heeled stride, though still making you feel exposed, now carries the weight of your refusal to be objectified. The familiar crunch of your boots on the pavement punctuates the tension as Martin’s crude voice slices through the night air once more.

 

 You force yourself to stop as your heart races. With a tremor of anger and resolve, you spin to face the van and shout back, “In your dreams! I’m not here for your lecherous games, Martin!”

 

 There’s a brief, charged silence before his coarse laughter slithers through the open window. “Oh, so you’ve got some bite now, huh?” he sneers, the challenge clear in his tone. The retort hangs heavy in the air as you stand there exposed, vulnerable. Yet unyielding.

 

 "Go find your entertainment at the bottom of a bottle," you spit. "I hear that men that drink like you do can't do much else."

 

 "You little..." Martin spits, but is interrupted by a driver coming up behind him, honking their horn. "I'll be seeing you, I'm sure," he mutters, eying you darkly. Then with a dramatic curse, he slams his foot on the accelerator and speeds off.

 

 You continue your walk. The echo of his mocking tone lingers, but with each determined step you take down the street, you feel a growing strength that pushes back against the intrusive threat.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Your heart stutters as Martin’s lecherous call slices through the air. For a breathless moment, the cool wind on your bare legs and the tight press of your high heels fade into the background as his voice - raw and provocative - fills your mind.

 

 A shiver of excitement runs through you, mingling with the awareness of your own vulnerability. Despite knowing full well that Martin’s words are nothing more than crude flirtation, a thrill pulses beneath your skin. “Maybe I will…” you murmur softly, your voice betraying a mix of nervous delight and forbidden daring. In that instant, the dangerous allure of being the center of his unwanted attention sends butterflies careening through you.

 

 “Good answer, darlin’!” Martin bellows back, his words dripping with a mix of mockery and promise. “You know, you should swing by McTafey’s later. Maybe let me show you just how big the back of this van really is.” His invitation is as brazen as it is unsettling, a crude dare that leaves your pulse racing even as you recoil internally at the implications.

 

 You force a breathy laugh, replying with a touch of coyness, “I’ve got somewhere to be, but maybe… we’ll run into each other later.” You find yourself giving him a smile as he chuckles.

 

 "Count on it," he says, before his van roars away, the sound of its engine fading, leaving you standing there, heart pounding and thoughts in tumult. The encounter - a mix of illicit thrill and a stark reminder of how exposed you are - continues to echo in your mind.

 

 Alone once more on the quiet street, you walk with a tentative mix of exhilaration and caution. That dangerous, alluring spark of flirtation with Martin’s crude advances still tingles on your skin, tempting you to stray further from what you know is right.

 

 It’s just harmless flirting, you tell yourself. You wouldn't really go see him later, would you?

 

 Would you?

 
 
 **Actions**

 You clear your throat. “Mary, have you met Annie?”

 

 Mary’s lips tighten into a thin smile. “I’ve seen her around. Quite a few outings with different young men, I hear.” She casts a disapproving glance past you, as if Annie might be lurking in the shadows. “Those skirts she wears… far shorter than I’d ever have dared at her age.”

 

 Her voice softens to a whisper. “I wouldn’t want Terrence bringing home someone like that. He needs someone who knows her way around a home. More of a homemaker, if you will.” She pauses, then adds with unintended sharpness, “It’s a shame you’re taken, Jennifer. Otherwise I’d have set him up in a heartbeat.”

 

 *A wave of queasiness washes over you as Mary’s well-meaning joke settles in your stomach.*

 You fold your arms, meeting Mary’s eyes. “Honestly, Mary, I’m not convinced this biology tutoring is doing Terrence much good.”

 

 Her brow lifts in surprise. “He’s improving,” she insists, voice firm. “He’s more confident each week.”

 

 You press on, voice steady. “Perhaps it’s the setting. I don’t think it’s conducive to education.”

 

 Mary gives you a strange look. “You think that… about the library? How can the library not be conducive to education?”

 

 You hold back a smile, if only to try and justify how strange your statement sounded. “Maybe it’s overwhelming Terrence,” you say. “All that knowledge. It could be intimidating.” An eyebrow is raised in your direction, as you feel yourself digging yourself into a hole. “Don’t worry about it. I’ll persevere.”

 

 The receptionist looks at you curiously. Mary might be giving you a strange look, but you got what you needed out of it.

 

 
 
 *Success! Jennifer seems to be tutoring Terrence for his biology classes on Sunday mornings in the library. You should go to the library at this time to find out what exactly she’s up to.*

 You shrug, unable to find the right words to explain your doubts. Mary’s confident nod tells you she’s closing the conversation. The location of the tutoring remains unspoken.

 Her practiced smile falters for a heartbeat, worry flickering behind her eyes before she masks it again. “He’s very focused on his studies,” she replies softly. “Honestly, I doubt he’s given dating much thought.”

 

 You press a finger to your lips, leaning in slightly. “Are you sure? A boy his age…”

 

 Mary exhales, gaze drifting toward the frosted door. When she meets your eyes again, her voice is gentler. “It’s been such a relief that he’s grown so fond of your company. I admit, I was worried for a time. About him. But seeing how he’s taking to you…” 

 

 She offers you a small, wistful smile. “So just indulging a little crush isn’t the worst thing, is it? He just needed the quiet space away from other people to come out of his shell. Looks like he’s a little shy with his feelings. Thankfully.”

“What are you looking at?” you ask her. 

 

 She smiles widely and her face lights up at the chance to talk about what’s on her mind. “Just a little window shopping! The Groomed Gal is now offering spa treatments. I can't believe we've got this in Charlton!” 

 

 She turns to the window and points to a handwritten poster taped to the window. “Look. Manicures. Pedicures. Facials. The full treatment!” Even without a make-over, Michelle is already glowing. “I wish I could afford it. Only yesterday I found a pimple underneath my nose. It almost ruined my morning.”

 

 “Looking to treat yourself?” you ask her, nodding to the advert.

 

 She winces. “Yeah. But it’s so expensive. I wish I could afford it. Rhiannon always likes a gossip. People tell hairdressers everything.” 

 

 You look back into the salon, with newfound interest. Michelle makes a point. You might learn a thing or two from spending some time at the salon.

 

 *Because that’s the only reason you’d want a spa treatment, isn’t it?*

 Olaf stares back at you, eyes narrowing. “What?” he grunts.

 

 Focusing your mental eye, you grimace as you feel there is not even an echo of magic upon him. You rack your brain to consider what you did wrong. It felt like you cast it correctly. The void in your inner magical reserves is testament to that. Whatever caused the spell not to take must be something to do with him.

 

 You give Olaf a polite smile, mentally making a note to check with someone on what could be stopping you casting magic on the janitor.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 
 You look back at Olaf, stirring the magic within your body. Taking a deep breath, you feel the energy curdle around the air in your lungs.

 

 Olaf stares back at you as you breathe out, his leering expression remaining. “What?” he grunts.

 

 Focusing your mental eye on him, you see the embers of magic within your breath lingering around his face, but as they touch his skin they flicker and dissipate into nothing. He remains untouched by your spell.

 

 Looking over him carefully, you rack your brain to consider what you did wrong. It felt like you cast it correctly. The magic in the air is testament to that. Whatever caused the spell not to take must be something to do with him.

 

 You give Olaf a polite smile, mentally making a note to check with someone on what could be stopping you casting magic on the janitor.
