title: PrichardDialogue
text:
You raise your hand before the lesson begins. Prichard hasn’t even opened her register yet, but her eyes snap to you like a hawk spotting movement.

 

 “Yes?” she says crisply, voice sharp. “Something to share before you begin?”

 

 You straighten slightly. “I’d like to be excused from the lesson.”

 

 Her expression doesn't shift. “Excused?” she repeats, as if testing the word on her tongue. “This is an important subject for ladies. The dangers of the world will prey on those ignorant to them. Do you consider that knowing this matter is optional to your safety?”

 

 You falter under her stare. There’s no warmth. Only the cold certainty of someone who’s never once allowed nonsense in her classroom.

 

 She continues, voice unchanging. “There is a syllabus, little Miss. There is structure. You will find that women who ignore both often end up lost. I presume you have a reason?”

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

 <>

 You reach into your satchel and draw out the hall pass. Prichard’s eyes flick to it, narrowing almost imperceptibly. “Well,” she says, her tone dry. “It seems someone believes you have more important business than learning how to survive the world’s dangers.”

 

 She studies you with the faintest curl of disapproval. “Are you quite certain this is the best use of your time, Miss Phillips? There is much to learn today. Things that might save your life one day.”

 

 You nod, though the certainty doesn’t quite reach your chest. A small part of you itches to stay and follow the rules. But you hold her gaze.

 

 Prichard inhales through her nose and gestures briskly toward the door. “Then go. And do try not to speak to strangers on the way. I’ll see you next lesson.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 

 You lean forward slightly in your chair. “Please, Miss Prichard,” you say quietly. “I think I may need to be excused. It’s… women’s matters.”

 

 Her eyes sharpen. “Speak up, girl.”

 

 You hesitate, then murmur again, even lower, “It’s… cramps. I didn’t want to be disruptive.”

 

 Prichard’s nose wrinkles faintly. “Really, Miss Phillips. There are certain topics a lady doesn’t voice aloud. Decorum is part of discipline.”

 

 You bow your head slightly, saying nothing. She exhales tightly. “Fine. If your body truly insists on misbehaving, I won’t have it interrupting my lesson.”

 

 She strides to her desk and retrieves a square of notepaper, scribbling a few words with a firm, stabbing motion of her pen. She tears the slip and walks it over to your desk with the precision of a drill sergeant.

 

 “This excuses you for today only,” she states. “Report to Nurse Rancy. She’s accustomed to handling girls with… weaker constitutions.”

 

 You nod, murmuring your thanks, but she’s already turned back to the blackboard. “And do try not to faint in the hallway,” she adds. “We’ve enough mess to clean up in here as it is.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You raise your hand quickly before the lesson begins. Prichard's eyes snap to you. “Yes, Miss Phillips?”

 

 You straighten slightly. “I’d like to be excused from the lesson.”

 

 Prichard's eyes narrow as they focus on you. "Is your constitution still proving challenging?"
 
 

 You shift, feeling the eyes of the class on you. "Just feeling unwell, miss."

 

 The teacher watches you, but snorts. "Nurse Rancy said you might need to be excused," she mutters. "Fine. Head straight there though, Miss Phillips."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: RancyDialogue
text:
Nurse Rancy folds her hands behind her back as you shift awkwardly on to the edge of the gurney. She studies you for a moment. “So,” she says calmly. “Why don’t you tell me what seems to be the matter?”

 

 You offer a vague shrug. “It’s probably nothing. Just, you know. Cramps. Or something like that.”

 

 “Mmm.” She doesn’t write anything down. Doesn’t even move.

 

 “I didn’t want to make a fuss,” you add quickly. “I just needed a moment to sit down somewhere. That’s all.”

 

 She tilts her head slightly. “So, no sharp pain? No nausea? No bleeding?”

 

 You blink. “No.”

 

 “Then you came here on your own?”

 

 “Well, no. I mean, sort of. I was let out of class, and then -”

 

 “And then you wandered the halls,” she cuts you off. “Rather than coming here. Until you were escorted by a hall monitor.”

 

 Her voice is calm. Measured. But behind her eyes is something harder.

 

 “Something must be wrong, Emily,” she says. “The body is smarter than the mind. We just have to listen to it. And right now, your body is saying something’s off. That means a physical inspection is required.”

 

 She gestures toward you with a subtle flick of her fingers. “All right, missy,” she says, her voice suddenly firmer, “Let’s get those clothes off so we can see what’s what.”

 
 Nurse Rancy closes her folder without looking up. “Back again,” she says, almost pleasantly. “Still something not quite right, is there?”

 

 You try to reply, but she raises a hand gently. “No need. I’ve seen enough to know when a girl’s body is out of step with her mind. And when she’s telling the truth.”

 

 She steps forward with that same crisp professionalism. “Another physical inspection is required.”

 

 She gestures calmly toward your clothes. “Spit spot. Get those clothes off so we can see what’s what.”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 You stiffen on the edge of the gurney. “I’d really rather not,” you say, trying to keep your voice even. “I don’t think that’s necessary.”

 

 Nurse Rancy tilts her head slightly, as if you’ve given the wrong answer on a test. “Not necessary,” she repeats. “I see.”

 

 She turns away for a moment, walks to her desk, and begins leafing through a folder with deliberate calm.

 

 “You know, Emily,” she says. “Refusal isn’t defiance. It’s a symptom. Of confusion. Discomfort with the body.”

 

 She turns a page. “These things don’t fix themselves. But they can be corrected. With the right support.”

 

 She looks up again, eyes steady. “If I report non-compliance, it won’t just stay in your file. There may need to be adjustments. Nutritional support. Reduced marks to redirect focus. You might find yourself placed on a different path. Something more suited to your needs.”

 

 Rancy smiles gently. “I’d rather avoid that, of course. I want to help you. And I believe that deep down, you want to be helped.”

 

 She steps closer. “You remember what I said, don’t you? The body is smarter than the mind. Yours is speaking. And I’m the one trained to listen.”

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 You keep your voice steady. “I said no.”

 

 Nurse Rancy doesn’t flinch. She simply exhales through her nose, almost sadly, and closes your file.

 

 “Then that’s the choice you’ve made,” she says. “Non-compliance noted.”

 

 She moves back to her desk and begins writing. “I’ll be docking your grades in physical education and self-discipline,” she says. “We’ll consider it part of a motivational correction.”

 

 You open your mouth to object again, but she’s already continuing.

 

 “I’ll also submit a dietary revision,” she adds without looking up. “There are compounds that can help students recalibrate their sense of... cooperation. I don’t personally think you need them, but clearly something’s misaligned.”

 

 She stands. “You’re dismissed. Come see me again though if you find yourself self-reflecting.”

 

 There’s no anger in her voice. No drama. You step into the hallway, feeling her eyes on your back the entire time.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 You pause, your protest caught halfway in your throat. Then you exhale and nod.

 

 Nurse Rancy’s expression doesn’t change, but there’s a quiet satisfaction in her voice. “I’m glad you’ve seen the light.”

 

 She gestures toward you again, briskly this time. “Now, missy. Let’s get those clothes off.”

 

 Her tone is all business and clinical. But her eyes never leave you.

 

 Actions

 <>

 
 
 
 Stripping out of your school uniform, you shiver as the cold air in the office brushes your skin. You disregard your socks, shoes, blouse and skirt, finally standing on the vinyl floor in nothing but your underwear.

 

 "All of your clothes, Emily," Rancy says as she looks as you. When she doesn't look away, you sigh and strip down to nothing.

 

 Rancy smiles sweetly. “Take a look in the mirror here,” she tells you.

 

 You do as she asks, and look into the mirror. Emily. You stare at your own reflection. Nothing about the scene is amiss. Your body has quantifiable imperfections - one breast has a slightly larger nipple, your nose has an odd little dip to it - that only magnify the reality of what you're experiencing. You can see the nurse behind you in the mirror's reflection. Behind you and above you. You feel tiny next to her, and being naked doesn't help.

 

 You look over your shoulder at her. “What is this about?” you ask.

 

 “Positive body reinforcement,” she says. “Or helping identify where our girls have body issue problems. I bet your women’s issues come from you feeling at odds with your body. Now, do you like what you see?”

 

 You look back at your reflection, staring at the reflection in the mirror.

 
 Once again, you step out of your uniform and approach the mirror. The air in the nurse’s office is cool, still. Rancy stands just behind you - always just behind - her reflection tall and impassive beside your own.

 

 “Take a good look,” she says quietly. “Your body is speaking. The question is whether you’ve learned to listen.”

 

 You meet your eyes in the mirror. Emily stares back.

 

 
 Your gaze drops to your chest. Your breasts are fuller than they were before. The slope more pronounced. When you shift your shoulders, you can see the weight of them respond. A faint flush creeps into your cheeks as you realise how unfamiliar they still feel.
 
 
 Your gaze settles on your chest. Still modest, still uneven. One breast sitting slightly lower, one nipple a touch wider. Nothing unnatural, but enough to remind you of your own scrutiny.
 
 
 

 Nurse Rancy doesn't comment. But she watches closely. Measuring your hesitation. Watching for discomfort, or pride.

 

 “This is the moment that matters,” she says softly. “Not what I see. Not what the boys see. What you see.”

 

 She lets the words linger, then leans slightly forward and lowers her voice. “Do you feel aligned? Or is there still a dissonance between who you are and what’s in the mirror?”

 

 She straightens. “Be honest. You owe yourself that much.”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 You nod slowly, eyes still on the mirror. “I’m… satisfied,” you say.

 

 Behind you, Nurse Rancy’s brow lifts, just slightly. “Satisfied,” she echoes, like testing a term she rarely hears.

 

 There’s a pause. Then a soft, measured exhale.

 

 “Well,” she says, voice clipped. “That tells me what I need to know. Clearly we’re not getting the right nutrients into you. I’ll be sure to inform Jackie to change your lunch options.”

 

 She crosses to her clipboard and begins writing. “Good meals support mental clarity. Hormonal balance. Self-awareness. When a girl insists she’s perfectly happy with her body, it’s often a sign something is being missed. A vitamin, a trace element, a core truth.”

 

 She glances up again. “It’s natural to have doubts, Emily. There’s always something girls wish they could change. You’ll see that, in time.”

 

 She clicks her pen closed. “Now,” she says, returning to her usual brisk tone. “Get on the scale, missy.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 

 You hesitate, your eyes still on your reflection. Then, softly, “I wish I were a little different.”

 

 
 Behind you, Nurse Rancy’s smile fades slightly, replaced with something quieter. More knowing. “Bigger?” 

 

 You look at the nurse in the mirror. You can only nod.

 

 “Oh, Emily,” she says softly. “I didn’t think you’d turn out to be one of those girls.”

 

 She steps closer, leaning in until her voice is almost a whisper in your ear. “I’ve done what I can for you. But girls like you... well, there are others in the world who can help. Or at least, beyond this town.”

 

 Her eyes flick to yours in the mirror. “You know what I mean. You’ve felt it. The places that exist just out of sight. Out of town. If you really want to become one of those girls, there are plenty of people who’ll help you take the next step.”

 

 The implication curls in your stomach. She isn’t offering you a choice. She’s telling you what you will do. What your body wants to do.

 

 And even as your mind reels, part of you finds the thought appealing. You want to seek them out. Whoever they are.

 

 *You want… more?*
 
 

 She steps back and taps the clipboard with a click of her pen. “Now,” she says crisply, “get on the scale, missy.”

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 
 Behind you, Nurse Rancy smiles. It’s warm. Pleased. Understanding. “I’m so glad you said that,” she murmurs. “It means we can begin.”

 

 Before you can respond, you feel a sudden sharpness at your upper arm. A brief sting. You blink and look down just as she pulls away a small syringe, already half-hidden in her pocket.

 

 “Shh,” she says, still smiling. “Nothing to worry about. Just something to help your body along. Take a look.”

 

 You glance back at the mirror. Your breasts look fuller. Plumper. You press your arms against your sides slightly. There’s a difference. Not huge but enough to notice.

 

 “You see?” Rancy says, almost maternally. “Your body just needed the right encouragement. You’ll welcome it soon enough.”

 

 You nod. Almost instinctively. Even though something about this - and her - still feels off, the change doesn’t unsettle you the way you thought it might.

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You step up onto the scale on your bare feet, the cold metal plate cool against your soles. Nurse Rancy makes a small adjustment to the counterweights, levelling your eyes with the beam.

 

 “Seven stone,” she notes aloud. “Just about. A little thing, aren’t you?”

 

 Her tone is light, but you hear the faint disapproval threaded behind it.

 

 Without asking, she swings up the height bar and adjusts it until it rests against the crown of your head. “Five foot four,” she announces. Then squints at the mark again. “And a quarter. Just.”

 

 She makes a small ‘hmm’ sound in the back of her throat and steps around you, tapping her pen against her clipboard. “Well,” she muses. “You’re not tall, thank goodness. Tall girls always think they have to lead.” Her smile is polite, even warm. “But still, I’d imagine you’d feel more secure if you were just a touch shorter. Boys like it when you fit beneath their arms. Makes them feel needed.”

 

 She looks up at you, her voice lowering. “Don’t you sometimes wish you were a little more petite? Just enough to feel safe. And looked after.”

 
 You step onto the scale again, the familiar chill of the metal plate pressing against your feet. Nurse Rancy doesn’t say a word. She just adjusts the counterweights, watching the beam settle into balance.

 

 “Still hovering around seven stone,” she murmurs, scribbling something on her clipboard. “At least you’re consistent.”

 

 She reaches for the height bar and brings it down carefully.

 

 
 “Five foot three,” she says crisply. “Perfect. I can’t tell you how pleased I am with your progress. Petite girls walk through the world differently. They learn to move with care. With deference.” She smiles, not unkindly. “It suits you.”

 
 “Still five four,” she says with a hint of disappointment. “You’ve got a long way to go if you want to feel truly delicate. But we’ll get there.”

 
 

 She folds her arms and looks you over. “You’d feel more protected if you were a touch smaller. Just imagine how much easier life might feel, when the world sees you as softer. Smaller.”

 

 She cocks her head slightly. “Wouldn’t you like that?”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 
 
 “I wish I was shorter,” you murmur.

 

 Nurse Rancy pauses. “Even shorter than you are now?” she asks, voice barely above a whisper. Her expression shifts into something more curious and more conspiratorial.

 

 You nod.

 

 She steps closer, her tone lowering further. “Do you see yourself as the smallest girl in the room, Emily?” Her eyes study you carefully. “Looking up at everyone. Letting them tower over you. Feeling their presence above you. And letting them guide you.”

 

 You swallow, but say nothing. Rancy doesn't need you to. She sees the answer on your face. Her voice softens, almost affectionate. “You're not just chasing height, are you? You want to feel meek. Submissive. Like the world was meant to keep you protected. Or pressed down.”

 

 She lets that sit between you for a moment, before leaning in just a touch more. “I can’t help with that. Not anymore. But there are clubs outside of town. Quiet places. Discreet. People there who understand what girls like you need. Who can help you become what you’re really trying to be. Physically. Mentally. And they'll indulge your needs.”

 

 Her smile is gentle, but her eyes are not. “You'll find them,” she murmurs. “If you really want to.”

 
 
 Then she steps back and clears her throat. “Now do me a favour and bend over, missy.”

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 
 You nod slowly. “I guess… I wish I was a little shorter.”

 

 Nurse Rancy’s expression doesn’t shift, but her hand is already moving towards the tray. She pulls out a slim syringe filled with a liquid. The amber glow of it pulses faintly, almost hypnotically.

 

 “This’ll help you on your journey,” she says, almost kindly. “You’d be amazed what an inch or two can do for a girl’s perspective.”

 

 Before you can reply, the needle pricks your thigh. It stings, but with a strange warmth that lingers. Magic. You can feel it.

 

 Your limbs feel looser. Your clothes subtly looser too. The room tilts ever so slightly, like it’s expanded around you. Like you’ve shrunk into it.

 

 You blink. Nothing feels wrong.

 

 “You’ll welcome it,” she says softly. “You’ll feel more manageable. And the world will seem just a bit more secure.”

 

 And oddly, you do. Even though something in the back of your mind tells you not to.

 

 Then, her voice sharpens again. “Now do me a favour and bend over, missy.”

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You hold her gaze, looking up at her. “I think I’m fine as I am.”

 

 Nurse Rancy’s smile tightens. She nods once, but it feels more like punctuation than agreement.

 

 “Mm. Of course. And sometimes it takes a little time before the body admits what the mind won’t say.”

 

 She turns to your file and begins writing. “I’ll adjust your lunch intake,” she says. “Not to change anything, mind you. Just to support clearer thinking. The right nutrients, properly administered, can do wonders for self-perception.”

 

 She closes the folder gently and turns back toward you. “Most girls come around. In time. Especially once they realise how much easier things become when they take up less space.”

 

 She steps aside, all professionalism again. “Now do me a favour and bend over, missy.”

 
 
 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 You bend over, grabbing your ankles as instructed. The vinyl beneath your feet squeaks faintly. Your legs tremble slightly as you spread them wider. Your breasts sway forward, drawing tight under gravity, and your cheeks flush from the blood rushing to your head.

 

 Behind you, you hear the snap of gloves. Then the cold press of metal against your inner thigh.

 

 Without warning, Nurse Rancy inserts the speculum in-between your legs. She inserts a gynecological clamp into your womb, then ratchets it open. It feels like a giant fist is inside your body.

 

 “You know,” she says casually, as though commenting on the weather. “This part isn’t strictly necessary.” She adjusts the clamp with clinical detachment. “I’ve already read your file. I know your hormone baselines.”

 

 Then her voice drops, lower, almost amused. “But this serves as a reminder that girls who lie to get out of classes might need to rely on other assets to get them through life.”

 

 A gloved hand presses against your lower back, holding you in place. She pauses. Then adds, almost cheerfully, “Besides. I enjoy this.”

 

 Her hand twists suddenly into your hair, pulling you upright. You gasp as she steers you toward the gurney.

 

 “You can get dressed now.”

 
 You bend over again, fingers brushing your ankles. The motion is familiar now. Mechanical. Your skin prickles in the sterile air, your bare back exposed under the office lights.

 

 Behind you, Nurse Rancy moves efficiently. The cold speculum is already poised. There’s no hesitation as she inserts it and begins to ratchet it open.

 

 The tension spreads through your body, just as it did before. Your womb feels full. Stretched. But this time, the feeling isn't shocking. Feeling this full sends shivers across your body. You feel your breath quicken.

 

 “Curious, isn’t it?" Rancy says from behind you. "I wonder what brought you back here. Are you really feeling unwell?” She leans closer, voice softer now. “Or did something inside you want this?”

 

 The metal clicks gently as she adjusts. You gasp as the clamp inside you opens further. “Perhaps it’s not me,” she muses. “Perhaps it’s the feeling. The exposure. The helplessness. You’re not the first girl to discover she needs this kind of attention.”

 

 You swallow, but say nothing.

 

 “I know a few men,” she continues, a whisper now. “Who would pay handsomely for someone like you. Needy. Compliant. Not quite aware of how far she's already gone.”

 

 Your thoughts swirl. You’re not that kind of girl. You didn’t come here for this. And yet part of you wonders. Wonders what it is she sees. Wonders if you’re starting to see it too.

 
Aren't you forgetting something? You aren't any kind of girl!

 

 Her voice threads between your thoughts. “There’s something inside you, Emily. Something small. Something that just wants to be told what to do.”

 

 She twists the speculum one final notch. Your breath catches. You can’t quite tell if it’s pain. Or pressure. Or something else.

 

 Then, abruptly, she pulls it free. “Up,” she says simply. And you stand.

 

 “You can get dressed now.”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 You reach for your uniform in silence. The air in the nurse’s office feels thicker now, like it’s pressing against your skin. You move slowly, limbs still buzzing from the cold examination table and everything that came with it.

 

 Your blouse catches awkwardly as you tug it over your head. You smooth it down with trembling fingers. Your skirt feels tighter than you remember. Or maybe you just feel more exposed.

 

 Across the room, Nurse Rancy is already back at her desk, scribbling something into your file with clean, deliberate strokes. She doesn’t look up.

 

 When you’re fully dressed, she finally stands and tears a slip from a notepad. “Fit for studies,” she says flatly, handing it over.

 

 Then, with the same calm finality, she gestures toward the full-length mirror near the cabinet.

 

 “Take a look,” she says. “Make sure everything’s in place.”

 

 You step forward slowly, glancing into the reflection. Yourself, in uniform. Just as you were when you entered. Or mostly. Your gaze catches on your silhouette. Lingers on your face. Something feels off. Or maybe it’s just your imagination.

 

 
 Nurse Rancy steps closer, her eyes meeting yours in the mirror. “This is you, isn’t it?”

 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 

 
 Nurse Rancy’s voice cuts in behind you. “Are you really happy with this?”
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 
 
 You look in the mirror and nod slowly. “Yes,” you say. “This is me.”

 

 Nurse Rancy’s expression doesn’t shift, but something in her posture relaxes. “Of course it is,” she murmurs. “That’s who you’ve always been. It just took your body a little time to catch up.”

 

 She steps closer, voice low and steady. “And this body. It suits you better. Doesn’t it?”

 

 You pause. Your mouth opens on its own. “Yes.”

 

 The word feels easy. Like it’s always been true.

 

 Rancy smiles. “Good girl.”

 

 
 She places the file back in her drawer. “I’m glad you’ve finally accepted who you are. A lying little thing like you, trying to skip class. Well, you’ll just have to rely on other charms.”

 

 Her eyes flick down your body with clinical appraisal. “And now,” she says. “You have them.”

 

 She folds her hands behind her back. “I don’t think I can do much more for you here. But if you ever feel like you need further support, there are places. People. Resources just outside Charlton who specialise in helping girls like you.”

 
Rancy picks up a pen and scribbles something down on a notepad. "I'll make a note to adjust your lunch intake, too. Girls with a positive body image of themselves don't need extra supplements and nutrients, after all."

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 She tilts her head. "Still, your chest could do with a little help," she says, tone almost playful. “You feel a little inadequate, don’t you?”

 

 Your heart stirs. “Maybe.”

 

 She nods. “That’s natural. You’ve already started your journey. And it’s perfectly normal to want more.”

 

 She taps your file lightly. “Come back again. I can help you feel complete.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 “You’re still so tall,” she says, her voice calm. “Don’t you think that clashes with your personality?”

 

 You feel the suggestion settle in. Unease prickles at your neck. “I… guess it might.”

 

 Rancy nods, warm and reassuring. “That’s okay. You’re still learning about yourself. And that’s a good thing.”

 

 She rests a hand on your shoulder. “Come back again, if you’d like. I can help you feel more proportionate.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 You shake your head. “No,” you say softly. “This… isn’t me.”

 

 For a moment, the room is still. Nurse Rancy’s lips press into a thin line. “I see,” she says at last, her voice even. “After all that effort. After all the support I’ve provided. And still denial.”

 

 She turns back to your file, flipping it open with clinical precision. “It’s always the same with girls like you. You want change. You seek help. But the moment progress is made... the moment your body begins to reflect who you are. You run from it.”

 

 She looks up again. “You need help, Emily. Real help. But until you’re willing to accept what you asked for, you’ll never be at peace.”

 

 She closes the file with a soft thud. “A small dietary adjustment should help clear your mind. Just enough conviction to get through the fog of your own resistance.”

 

 Rancy gives you a final, tight-lipped smile. “You may go. Come see me when you're serious about your health.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 You meet her eyes in the mirror. “Yes,” you say quietly. “I’m happy with what I see.”

 

 For a moment, Nurse Rancy doesn’t respond. Then she exhales. “There’s no shame in wanting to be the best version of yourself, Emily,” she says softly. “It’s not weakness. It’s clarity.”

 

 She steps back to her desk and makes a note in your file. “I’ll be adjusting your lunchtime intake,” she adds, her tone crisp again. “Something to help clear the fog. Once your mind is a little quieter, you might find it easier to hear what your body’s really trying to tell you. Maybe then you’ll find your way back here and we can begin helping you.”

 

 She hands you your slip again - now stamped with **Fit for studies** - and gives a final nod toward the door.

 

 “You’re dismissed.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 You stare at your reflection. The same reflection you’ve seen a hundred times. But today it feels different. Not better. Just off.

 

 You shake your head. “No,” you admit softly. “I don’t think I am.”

 

 Behind you, Nurse Rancy smiles with quiet satisfaction. “There’s no shame in that, Emily,” she says. “It’s perfectly healthy to want self-improvement. To acknowledge that how we feel on the inside doesn’t always match what we see in the mirror.”

 

 She closes your file with a gentle snap. “We’re out of time today,” she says, “but I want you to know that I’m here. When you’re ready to begin your treatment, all you have to do is ask.”

 

 She places the slip into your hand - **Fit for studies** - then gently guides you toward the door.

 

 “You’ve made progress,” she says warmly. “Just recognising the dissonance… that’s the first step.”

 

 Actions

 <>
