title: TerrenceDialogue
text:
At the mention of the word, Terrence's alert eyes bounce from side to side, looking up and down the street. “Nervous? No reason. Why?”

 

 “You seem a little on edge,” you try. “Is everything alright?”

 

 Terrence gives you a look, indecision clear in his expression. Just as he looks set to speak, a pigeon coos, making him jump.

 

 “It’s nothing,” he replies quickly. “I’m fine.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “I didn’t expect to see you in detention,” you tell him. “What happened?”

 

 He leans back with a confident grin, arms casually crossed. “I was just keeping things interesting,” he says, voice smooth. “Got caught writing Chantelle a note. Apparently Geography isn't the place to be writing to girls.”

 

 You frown. “I didn't know you liked Chantelle?”

 

 Terrence steps closer, gaze locked on you. “Why, are you jealous?" He chuckles, sensing your unease. "Just some harmless flirting. Geography’s a snooze anyway. Mountains and rivers aren't as interesting as girls. So detention's totally worth it if it means getting to talk to someone who actually keeps my attention.” His smile flickers with genuine interest. “Like you.”

 

 "And it was worth detention for that?" 

 

 He nods, smirking. “She made me spend an hour writing lines on the board. ‘Men's minds are for places and history. Women can afford to daydream.’ Over and over again.”

 

 As he says the words, he chuckles. "It's nonsense, but I can handle her. My grades are improving, anyway.”

 

 You smile, unsure you know the person in front of you.
 
 
 “I didn’t expect to see you in detention,” you tell him. “What happened?”

 

 “I misbehaved,” he tells you, his words straining through clenched teeth.

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “What did you do?” 

 

 “I…” Terrence begins, but seems to change his mind. “I shouldn’t discuss it.”

 

 “It’s alright,” you assure him. “I won’t tell.”

 

 He looks at you, then sighs with exhaustion. “It’s just that – it’s such nonsense. All I did was ask if the people in other countries were happy with being conquered. She threw her book at me. Literally.”

 

 You give him a look. “She gave you detention for asking that?” 

 

 He nods, growing angry with his words. “She made me spend an hour writing lines on the board. ‘Men don’t negotiate. They subjugate.’ Over and over again.”

 

 As he says the words, he gives you a look. You notice his eyes flick over your body. He takes a stifled breath. “I hate her,” he mutters. “It’s such bullshit.”

 

 Terrence seems to suddenly realise who he’s talking to and blushes. “Oh! I’m sorry! I didn’t mean to say that! That word!” 

 

 You smile, trying to assure him no offence was taken.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “I’ve been wondering,” you begin. “What are the boys’ versions of the single-sex classes like?”

 

 Terrence chuckles, leaning back on the pillar with casual ease. “Honestly? It’s all pep talks. ‘How to be a man’ this, ‘stand your ground’ that.” He glances at you, grin lighting his eyes. “Meanwhile, I’m stuck thinking about you and whatever the girls are up to in your classes.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow, letting his comment slide. “So you don’t buy into it?”

 

 He shakes his head, stepping closer. “Not at all. I’d trade every push-up for a real conversation. Especially if it’s with you.”
 
 
 “I’ve been wondering,” you begin. “What are the boys' versions of the single-sex classes like?”

 

 Terrence rolls his eyes, momentarily distracted from his nervous disposition of looking up and down the road. “It’s exactly what you’d expect. Macho posturing. Sexist stereotypes. How to be a man.”

 

 “You don’t agree with it?” you ask him.

 

 He snorts quietly. “That’s not how my world operates.” 

 

 “I’m curious to see it,” you reply.

 

 “You shouldn’t be,” he says, a touch of a warning in his voice. “I’m serious.”

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “Hey Terrence,” you say. “I was wondering if you could do me a favour.”

 

 He lifts his chin, confidence in his stance. “Anything for you. What’s up?”

 

 “I need to get into Geography class,” you explain. “Without Prichard.”

 

 He grins. “Distract her? The only time I’ve ever seen her leave someone unattended is when you distracted her when I had detention.”

 

 You let one of your eyebrows rise up. He catches sight of it, then shakes his head furiously. 

 

 “Just get her attention for a moment,” you say. “I’m sure something will come to mind. I’ll owe you one.”

 

 
 
 He tilts his head, eyes lighting up. “Speaking of owing. I heard you aced the Math test. Is that true?”

 

 “Pretty solid,” you admit with a small smile. “Why do you ask?”

 

 He steps closer, lowering his voice. “I could use a tutor. Mr. Rogers is merciless.”

 

 “You want me to help?” you ask.

 

 His grin turns earnest. “Yeah, meet me at your place after school? And I can handle Prichard.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 He shrugs, giving you a playful look. “Funny thing. I was wondering if you could do me a favour. Math’s kicking my butt.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “You need help?”

 

 “Big time,” he admits, running a hand through his hair. “Think you could tutor me at your place? In return, I’ll make Prichard look the other way.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 
 “Hey Terrence,” you say. “I was wondering if you could do me a favour.”

 

 His eyes focus sharply on you, before looking around the street. “What?” he stammers. 

 

 “I need to get into Geography class,” you tell him. “Without Prichard.”

 

 “That's impossible,” he replies. “The only time I’ve ever seen her leave someone unattended is when you distracted her when I had detention.”

 

 You let one of your eyebrows rise up. He catches sight of it, then shakes his head furiously. 

 

 “Just get her attention for a moment,” you say. “I’m sure something will come to mind. I’ll owe you one.”
 
 

 
 
 He looks at you for a moment, his eyes narrowing. After a long moment he begins to talk in a measured voice. “I guess you did help me. When I had my panic attack. And I need a bit of help on Maths anyway.”

 

 You give him a look. “What's maths got to do with it?”

 

 “I’m failing,” he says, with a hint of embarrassment. “Mr. Rogers is not nice. To me. I could do with help. A lot of it.”

 

 “You want me to tutor you?” you ask him.

 

 He nods eagerly. “Do that, and I’ll distract Prichard. When the time comes. I can’t fail Maths. I won’t.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 
 
 He looks at you for a moment, his eyes narrowing. After a long moment he begins to talk in a measured voice. “I heard you did well on your Maths test. Is that true?”

 

 You give him a look. “Pretty good,” you say casually. “Why?”

 

 “I’m failing,” he says, with a hint of embarrassment. “Mr. Rogers is not nice. To me. I could do with help. A lot of it.”

 

 “You want me to tutor you?” you ask him.

 

 He nods eagerly. “Do that, and I’ll distract Prichard. When the time comes. I can’t fail Maths. I won’t.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 He looks at you for a moment, but sighs sadly. “The only thing I need a favour for is getting through Maths,” he tells you. “I hear you did about as well on the last test as I did, though.”

 

 You grimace, recalling how the clock absorbed your attention in the first maths class you took as Emily. If only he knew what I did for a living…

 

 “I’m sorry,” he tells you quietly. “It’s too risky. I can’t afford to get into any more trouble.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 “Hey Terrence,” you say. “I was wondering if you could do me a favour.”

 

 He lifts his chin, confidence in his stance. “I'm not putting your camera where it doesn't belong, Dennis."

 

 You wince, trying not to think of what he meant by that. “I need to get into geography class,” you explain. “Without Prichard.”

 

 He grins. “Want to capture some shots of Geography? That's weird, Dennis. Even for you.”

 

 "Come on, Terrence," you try. "I just need to get into that room."
 
 

 He chuckles. "Sorry, mate. I'm not sticking my neck out. Even for you."

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “Hey Terrence,” you say. “I was wondering if you could do me a favour.”

 

 His eyes focus sharply on you, before looking around the street. “What?” he stammers. 

 

 “I need to get into geography class,” you tell him. “Without Prichard.”

 

 “That's impossible,” he replies. “The only time I’ve ever seen her leave someone unattended is when you distracted her when I had detention.”

 

 You let one of your eyebrows rise up. He catches sight of it, then shakes his head furiously. 

 

 “Just get her attention for a moment,” you say. “I’m sure something will come to mind. I’ll owe you one.”

 
 
 He looks at you for a moment, his eyes narrowing. After a long moment he begins to talk in a measured voice. “You're pretty good at maths, aren't you?”

 

 You shrug, trying to gauge the right response. “Yeah,” you say casually. “Why?”

 

 “I’m failing,” he says, with a hint of embarrassment. “Mr. Rogers is not nice. To me. I could do with help. A lot of it.”

 

 “You want me to tutor you?” you ask him.

 

 He nods eagerly. “I can come over to your place. Any evening. You can help, can't you?"

 

 You briefly consider risking it, but you're not sure how long Dennis will be asleep. Nor whether you can get away with going home as him. It seems risky. Too risky.

 

 "Sorry, Terrence," you say. "I can't at the moment."
 
 

 “I understand,” Terrence replies. “It’s a busy time, the end of the year. Lots of study. Everyone’s trying to graduate.”

 

 A car with a loud exhaust drives past and Terrence’s attention is taken away momentarily. When he returns to focus on you, he seems twitchy and nervous once more. “I need to go. My mum will be waiting for me. But the offer still stands. If you want my help, I can come over."

 

 You watch Terrence walk off quickly, almost tripping as he rushes to move away from the school.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 

 
 “Thank you!” Terrence says, stepping closer. As he reaches for your hand, his fingers brush yours in a deliberate, confident shake. His grip is warm and steady. “You have no idea how much this means,” he murmurs, gaze flickering to your lips before meeting your eyes again. “Phone me when you get home tonight. I’ll be there faster than you can say ‘Geography’.”

 

 He fishes a pen and notebook from his backpack, then scribbles his number with a quick, practiced flourish. Tearing off the page, he presses it into your palm, thumb lingering against your skin. “It’s a landline, so if someone picks up, just say you’re a friend from school.”

 

 You slip the paper into your satchel. 

 

 “Perfect,” he says, raking a hand through his hair and offering you a slow, easy grin. He gives a small nod, then turns on his heel, shoulders relaxed. “Talk soon?”

 
 “Thank you!” Terrence stammers, reaching for your hand and shaking it rapidly. “Thank you so much. Give me a call in the evening when you get home. I'll come right over." 

 

 “Oh!” he adds, reaching into his backpack and pulling out a pen and notebook from a compartment. He scribbles down his phone number and rips off a sheet to give to you. “Here’s my number. It’s a landline. If my mom answers, just pretend to be a salesman. Or woman.” He seems to consider this for a moment. “Actually. Just say you’re a girl. From school.”

 

 You nod, putting the paper in your satchel. 

 

 “Alright,” he says, running his hand through his hair. “I better get home. Prepare. Give me a call.”

 

 Terrence smiles politely, then strides off, his eyes tracking every sound and movement as he goes. 

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “Ah, playing hard to get, are we?” Terrence teases, feigning a dramatic sigh. “End-of-year crunch. Can’t blame you.” He takes a step closer, grin teasing. “But don’t think you’re rid of me. If you ever change your mind, you know where to find me. About tutoring. Or anything else."

 

 He winks, then turns on his heel and strides off with easy confidence, shoulders relaxed and eyes still on you as he goes.
 
 
 “I understand,” Terrence tells you. “It’s a busy time, the end of the year. Lots of study. Everyone’s trying to graduate.”

 

 A car with a loud exhaust drives past and Terrence’s attention is taken away momentarily. When he returns to focus on you, he seems twitchy and nervous once more. “I need to go. My mum will be waiting for me. But the offer still stands. If you want my help, come see me. I think Prichard’s keeping me back a lot for what I said.”

 

 You watch Terrence walk off quickly, almost tripping as he rushes to move away from the school.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You step toward Terrence, holding your test paper in one hand as you try to calm his obvious nerves. "Terrence, I know you’re struggling, but I really can help," you say, your voice steady. "I’ve got the grades to prove it."

 

 Terrence fidgets with the edge of his textbook, not quite meeting your eyes. "Y-you want to tutor me?" he stammers, his voice pitching slightly. "I mean, sure, I’m failing, but that doesn’t mean just anyone can help." He pulls at the collar of his shirt as though it’s suddenly too tight. "Didn’t you, uh... didn’t you fail that last test too?"

 

 You calmly pull out some of your most recent work, holding it out for him to see. His hands tremble slightly as he takes it, his eyes darting across the page. "Oh," he mutters, blinking rapidly. "Wow. That’s... that’s actually really good." He bites his lip, then quickly hands the paper back, like he’s worried someone might see it.

 

 "Okay, uh... yeah," he says, nodding a bit too quickly. "I guess you could... I mean, you seem like you know what you’re doing. I just - I need help, okay? But not in a way that makes it, you know, obvious. People might, uh... get the wrong idea."

 

 He glances over his shoulder nervously, his voice dropping to a whisper. "We can meet somewhere quiet, right? Maybe your home? After school. Just studying. I didn't mean... I mean. Not that." His words come in a rapid-fire burst, and he’s already packing up his books like he’s ready to flee. "Don’t tell anyone, okay? Just - just keep it between us."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 "Terrence, I’ve been going over my math notes," you say, pulling out a stack of papers. "I know I can help you. Look, I’ve even written out the solutions!"

 

 Terrence hesitates, his fingers twitching nervously at the edge of his desk. "Uh... okay," he says, his voice shaky. "Let me see, I guess?" He reaches out cautiously as if the papers might bite him.

 

 He stares at the top sheet, tilting his head slightly as his eyes dart over your handwriting. "Wait... is this a quadratic equation?" he asks, his brow furrowing. "Why is the answer a heart?"

 

 You glance down at the paper. "Oh, that’s not an apple. That’s an approximation symbol."

 

 Terrence looks up at you, his mouth slightly open, before shifting his gaze back to the page. He flips to another sheet, where an answer is circled three times and underlined with a question mark. "And, uh... what’s going on here? Did you... change your answer? Three times?"

 

 "That’s just me double-checking my work," you reply, trying to sound confident.

 

 "Uh-huh." Terrence nods, his lips twitching as he flips to the next page. "And this one?" He points to a graph where the axes are mislabeled. "Did you just... label time as ‘Taco Tuesday’? Why is ‘joy’ the other axis?"

 

 "Okay, that one was just a shorthand to help me visualize the problem," you mumble.

 

 Terrence exhales sharply, clutching the papers like they’re the punchline to a very strange joke. His shoulders start to shake as he lets out a nervous giggle, which quickly grows into a full-on laugh. "Wow," he gasps, wiping his eyes. "I mean, I’m failing math, but this... this is something else. You’re really sure you’re the one who’s going to help me?"

 

 You open your mouth to respond, but he’s already shaking his head, the laughter tapering off into nervous chuckles. "Thanks, but, uh... I think I’ll figure it out on my own. Or maybe get a tutor who knows why time isn’t a taco."

 

 He quickly gathers his books, muttering to himself as he hurries off. "Taco Tuesday," he repeats under his breath, still snickering. "Unreal."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 “Your mum sounded happy when I called,” you say.

 

 He offers you a confident smile, settling into his chair. “She’s not used to me chatting away with girls on the line. But talking to you? I wouldn’t trade it for anything.”

 

 "I'm here to tutor you, Terrence," you tell him. "This isn't a date.”

 

 Terrence’s confident smile wavers. “Right… sorry, Em. She's just not used to me getting calls from pretty girls.”

 

 You shift, gathering your notes. “Let’s stick to maths, okay?”

 
 “Your mother seemed surprised when I called,” you tell him casually. 

 

 “I don’t get many callers,” he replies. “Especially not from girls at school.”

 

 You give him a curious look. “Not popular with the girls?”

 

 “Oh no,” he says, smiling. “I have a lot of friends. Just -” He breaks off his sentence before he can complete it. “I don’t really date.”

 

 You eye Terrence for a moment, sensing his reluctance to embellish. You wonder if you should push further, or return to the safer topic of Maths.

 
 

 Actions

 <> 

 
 “You’re pretty smart, you know,” you tell him. “How come you are struggling at school?”

 

 He shrugs, leaning casually against the table. “Honestly? I stopped seeing the point. All these books and lessons… I’d rather be out having fun, chasing girls while we’re young.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “What about after school? Your future?”

 

 He waves a hand dismissively. “It’ll sort itself out. Life’s not one big exam.” He steps closer, grin teasing. “Don’t you think it would be nice to take a break from all these equations and have a little fun?”

 

 You mutter under your breath, “Sounds like you fit right in at Charlton.”

 

 Terrence laughs, eyes sparkling. “Funny. The same guys used to pick on me for not having a girlfriend. But ever since I stopped caring what they think… they’ve backed off.” He offers you a confident look. “Maybe I could take you out one evening. Away from textbooks?”

 

 You clear your throat. “Let’s stick to tutoring for now.”

 

 Terrence leans in, grin unwavering. “Sure, but I’ll definitely wear you down eventually.”
 
 
 “You’re pretty smart, you know,” you tell him. “How come you are struggling at school?”

 

 He glances up from his textbook, pen hovering as he breaks from work. “I don’t know. Maybe it’s the teachers. They don’t really like me.”

 

 “Like Mr. Rogers?” you ask him.

 

 He nods, rapidly. “Him. And the others. They make fun of me. Call me names. It’s called a pecking order.”

 

 You frown, feeling yourself lean in slightly. “What sort of names?”

 

 He eyes you carefully, tense and guarded. “They say…” he tries, breaking off. “They mock me. For not having a girlfriend.”

 

 An eyebrow rises above your right eye. “Not popular with the girls?”

 

 “Oh no,” he says, smiling. “I have a lot of friends. Just –” He breaks off his sentence before he can complete it. “I don’t really date.”

 

 You eye Terrence for a moment, sensing his reluctance to embellish. You wonder if you should push further, or return to the safer topic of maths.

 <>
 
 

 Actions

 <> 

 
 You decide to focus your attention on Terrence’s studies. He flips open another notebook and begins copying down equations in neat, mechanical strokes. But just enough to keep up appearances. His brow never furrows in real concentration. Instead, his gaze drifts up to meet yours whenever he thinks you’re not watching. 

 
 
 A sudden thought tugs at you. Terrence is more interested in you than studying.

 

 You shake off the distraction and guide him through the final problem. He scribbles the answer quickly, then closes the notebook with a soft snap. “Thanks, Emily,” he says quietly, voice low. “Everything’s simple now.”

 

 “So you’ll help distract Prichard if I end up in detention?” you ask.

 

 Terrence straightens, meets your eyes with a warm grin. “Absolutely. Whenever you need me.”
 
 

 He stacks his books neatly, tucks them under one arm with ease, and strides toward the door without a hint of hesitation. You open it for him; the cool night air tousles his hair. A pigeon’s soft coo draws a playful grin instead of a startled jump.

 

 “Goodnight, Emily,” he says, tipping his head and holding your gaze for a brief moment before turning to walk away with confident steps.

 
 You decide to focus your attention on Terrence’s studies. He is a fast learner and before you anticipated he’s completing exercises that an hour ago were beyond his comprehension.

 

 Finding a degree of pride in your efforts, you give him an encouraging smile. When he returns it, you only see gratitude behind the gesture.

 

 Something gnaws away and you have a small epiphany. In all of your experience since coming to Charlton, Terrence is the first man not looking at you with any degree of lust.

 Something gnaws away and you have a small epiphany. In all your recent experiences of being in a girl’s body, Terrence is the first man not looking at you with any degree of lust.

 

 You feel a little sting. A twinge of wounded pride inside your brain. You can think of a few reasons to counter the incoming thought that you can’t suppress. Why doesn’t he like me?

 

 Returning your focus to his studies, you wrap up the tutoring as he completes the final task. "Thanks, Emily," he says quietly. "It's simple. All simple now."

 

 “So you’ll help distract Prichard?” you ask him. “If I’m in detention?”

 

 “I don’t know why you’d want to do that,” he replies. “Believe me. I know. But yes. Okay. If you need me, I’ll be there.”

 

 Terrence packs up his books into a stack and awkwardly walks towards the front door, holding them in both hands. You open the door for him. His eyes become alert as soon as he sees night has set in. The sound of a pigeon cooing almost causes him to drop his pile of books to the floor.

 

 "Goodnight, Emily," he tells you, as he leaves. You watch him move down the street with as much speed as he can muster. 

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 “Would you like to date, though?” you press him. “Is there anyone at school you like?”

 

 Terrence’s confident smile flickers with mischief. “I do now,” he replies, leaning in close. His eyes drop to your lips before returning to your gaze. “Actually, I’ve been thinking about you.”

 

 Without warning, he leans in and presses his lips to yours. Sure, warm, and deliberate. For a heartbeat, you’re caught off guard by the boldness and the spark of his confidence.

 

 You pull back, heart racing. “Terrence, I… I don’t want that.”

 

 He straightens, grin unwavering. “That’s just a maybe later. I bet I’ll win you over for a date soon.”

 

 "I don't think so," you tell him.

 

 He chuckles. "We'll see."
 
 

 Terrence slides his chair back and scoops up his books. "Thanks, Em," he stammers. "It's been fun. I'll keep an eye out for you. If you’re ever in detention. Or elsewhere.”

 

 “Terrence…” you begin.

 

 But he's already heading toward the door. He pauses in the frame, hand on the knob. “Goodnight, Emily,” he calls softly, then strides off with relaxed confidence.

 

 You watch his silhouette fade down the hallway, still feeling the warmth of his touch on your lips.
 
 
 “Would you like to date, though?” you press him. “Is there anyone at school you like?"

 

 He takes a deep breath. His eyes roam around the room, as if looking for some way to escape. 

 

 “I don’t know,” he stammers. 

 

 You brace yourself to ask the question that bubbles up in your mind. “But you do like girls, right?” 

 

 He looks down at the table, not meeting your eye. He shrugs. “I don’t know.”

 

 A long moment of silence draws out between you two before he looks up again. You give him a sympathetic smile. “That’s okay,” you say quietly. “It’s okay not to know.”

 

 “That’s not what they say at school,” he replies, with a rush of words threatening to merge into one another. “Girls are made for boys. Boys should like girls. I must like girls.”

 

 You see the tears in his eyes. “You don’t have to,” you tell him. 

 

 He shakes his head. “I should. I do. Of course I do. Girls are made for boys. I should go.”

 

 Terrence slides his chair back and scoops up his books. "Thanks, Emily," he stammers. "You've been helpful. I'll keep an eye out for you. If you’re ever in detention.”

 

 “Terrence…” you begin.

 

 “Thank you. Again,” he says, rushing to the door. Awkwardly, he can’t open it with a stack of books in his arms and you have to pull it for him. Terrence nods in appreciation, then bounds out the door.

 

 You watch him go. He doesn’t look back. 

 <>
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 “I’ve noticed Britney, Stacey and Reagan hanging around you,” you say. “Everything okay?”

 

 Terrence hesitates. His eyes flick around like he’s checking for witnesses. Then he exhales, voice low.

 

 “They’ve... been kind,” he says. “Said they understand what I’m going through.”

 

 You tilt your head. “What exactly do they understand?”

 

 He fidgets, glancing down at his shoes. “The pressure. The teasing. They thought maybe they could help.”

 

 You frown. “The cheerleaders? Understanding bullying? Aren’t they usually the ones doing it?”

 

 “You don’t get it,” he snaps, louder than he means to. His voice drops again. “They’re listening to me! They know what it's like… to be different.”

 

 You wait. He looks like he wants to say more, but swallows it down.

 

 “I don’t think Chrissie and her friends have your best interests at heart,” you tell him flatly.

 

 “You sound like…” he begins, then trails off. “Look, it's fine, Emily. I can handle it.”

 

 Watching Terrence carefully, you nod. There's a degree of assertiveness bubbling underneath the surface of all that nervousness that you haven't seen before.

 
 “I’ve noticed Britney, Stacey and Reagan hanging around you,” you say. “Everything okay?”

 

 Terrence hesitates. His eyes flick around like he’s checking for witnesses. Then he exhales, voice low.

 

 “They’ve... been kind,” he says. “Said they understand what I’m going through.”

 

 You tilt your head. “What exactly do they understand?”

 

 He fidgets, glancing down at his shoes. “The pressure. The teasing. They thought maybe they could help.”

 

 You frown. “The cheerleaders? Understanding bullying? Aren’t they usually the ones doing it?”

 

 “Yes! But I mean, no!” he snaps, louder than he means to. His voice drops again. “They’re listening to me, Dennis! They actually know what it's like… to be different.”

 

 You wait. He looks like he wants to say more, but swallows it down.

 

 “I don’t think Chrissie and her friends have your best interests at heart,” you tell him flatly.

 

 “You sound like…” he begins, then trails off. “Look, it’s fine. I can handle it.”

 

 Watching Terrence carefully, you nod. There's a degree of assertiveness bubbling underneath the surface of all that nervousness that you haven't seen before.

 
 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 “Hey Terrence, do you know a woman called Jennifer Chambers?” you ask him.

 

 His eyes flicker, panic rising. He swallows hard. “No,” he says, voice barely above a whisper.

 

 You press on, gaze steady. “Are you sure?”

 

 He looks down at the floor, then back at you. “I’m sure.”

 

 You lift an eyebrow. “Then why would she have your landline?”

 

 His face goes pale. He stammers, unable to meet your eyes. “I… I don't know,” he mutters, stepping back. His eyes dart around and you sense he's not going to say anything more about whatever connects Jen with him.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 “Hey Terrence, do you know a woman called Jennifer Chambers?” you ask him.

 

 His eyes flicker, panic rising. He swallows hard. “No,” he says, voice barely above a whisper.

 

 You press on, gaze steady. “Are you sure?”

 

 He looks down at the floor, then back at you. “I’m sure.”

 

 You lift an eyebrow. “Then why would she have your landline?”

 

 His face goes pale. He stammers, unable to meet your eyes. “I… I don't know,” he mutters, stepping back. "How do you know that, Dennis?"

 

 For a moment his eyes start darting around, focusing on you. Even when you shrug, his narrowed eyes don't ever leave you. That is, until a pigeon cooing makes him jump.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 

 You glance up from the workbook between you, letting your voice stay casual. “So the cheerleaders. They’ve been paying you a lot of attention recently. Are they helping you too?”

 

 Terrence pauses, pencil mid-air. “They just… talk to me.”

 

 “About studying?”

 

 He gives a short laugh. “No. Not school stuff. Not really. More like... attitude. Standing up straighter. Smiling more.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. “So, motivational cheerleading.”

 

 He shrugs. “I guess.”

 

 You glance down at his notebook. You flick back a few pages, sensing his unease as you do so. His answers for biology stand out. Precise and succinct. Nothing like the confused guesswork you saw the week before.

 

 “You’re doing better. Especially in Biology.”

 

 That makes him stiffen. He reaches for his pencil again, head ducked.

 

 “I’ve just been… paying more attention.”

 

 “Christina and Britney helping you to study?”

 

 “No,” he says quickly. Too quickly.

 

 Your eyes flick to his bag. The flap’s half open, and you spot one exercise book he’s kept off the table. A worn biology book, stuffed with cuttings and sheets from note paper. 

 

 He sees your gaze, and with a quick movement, flips the flap over the bag. “Biology's not what I'm here for. It’s it’s all… starting to make sense now.”

 

 “Biology?” you ask.

 

 He shakes his head. “It doesn’t matter.”

 

 His hand rests on the flap of his bag now. Protective. You study him a moment longer. Whatever’s in that book, he doesn’t want you seeing it. You’re going to have to find another way to see it. Perhaps you can find a way to open his locker during the day, when he's occupied.

 

 Actions

 <> 

 
 “Do you know how I could get a hall pass?” you ask.

 

 He raises an eyebrow at you, clearly amused. “Skipping class? Emily, I thought you were a good girl.”

 

 You fold your arms. “I’m serious.”

 

 He chuckles. “Alright, alright.” He leans in a little, conspiratorial. “Stitch gives them out sometimes. But only to students who do well in lessons. Top of the class. Model behaviour. If you get special lessons from Stitch, you can get privileges.”

 

 You nod, already considering your grades, but then he adds with a grin, "Personally, I don’t think you need to worry about studying. There are more fun ways to spend your time.”

 

 He leans back, watching you with interest. “I could show you some of them, Em.”
 
 
 “Hey, Terrence,” you begin. “Do you know how someone could get a hall pass?”

 

 He blinks. “A… pass? I guess maybe from Mr. Stitch? He gives them out sometimes.”

 

 You frown. “Based on what?”

 

 Terrence adjusts his bag strap. “Grades, mostly. If you’re doing well. He notices that stuff. You’ve got to stand out, but he invites all his favourites for extra lessons. They all seem to avoid trouble if they’re seen out of classes.”

 

 You nod slowly. “Have you done those lessons?”

 

 He hesitates, then shakes his head quickly. “No. I wouldn’t. Even if my grades were high enough. I don’t want to stand out to Stitch.”

 

 He lowers his voice. “It’s better to just keep your head down, Em. Trust me.”

 

 Terrence glances back at the building, eyes scanning the windows. 

 
 

 Actions

 <>

title: TerryDialogue
text:
You take a steadying breath. "What did you need me for, sir?"

 

 His silver eyebrows lift as he smooths a hand over his unbuttoned jacket. He stands, slowly walking around the desk. Lingering dangerously close to you. “Jenna,” he whispers. “Your performance today is…integral. In fact, your future here may well depend on it.” 

 

 He leans closer, his eyes looking deeply into yours. You push back into the leather chair, trapped between its back and Terry, towering over you. “No need to be fearful,” he says, voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. “When we’re done. I’m about to make you a star.”

 

 With a flourish, he spins and whisks off a velvet cloth from a nearby easel… displaying a poster.

 

 [image: ./images/receipts_from_the_heart.png]
 
 
 
 A boyish grin spreads across Terry’s face. “If Selfridges can have a brand voice, why can’t we?” he enthuses. “And… why can’t it be a soprano?”

 

 You stare between Terry and the poster, your brain trying to register what you’re seeing. The stylized soprano clutching a perfume atomizer, the older gentleman gesturing behind her. Did Terry model these on Jennifer and him?

 

 Terry draws you from the image with his enthusiastic gestures, grinning with glee. “Think of it, Jenna! I’ve paid a fortune in focus groups and research. They all say the same things. Get better stock control. Sort out the tills. Mundane. Dull. Boring. I told them to go to hell.”

 

 You watch him pace the room. Almost performing a pitch. Grinning manically. “I’ve been in this business since my father set up this store,” he continues. “I can tell you what Evans' Department Store really needs isn’t better signage or modern payment systems, but…” he pauses briefly, stepping near you again. “… a retail opera experience.” 

 

 And ends his pitch with jazz hands. 

 

 You look up at him, your brain struggling to process what is occurring. You are thankful when there’s a knock at the door. Mary Handle peeks in. "Just leaving," she murmurs. “Do you need anything?”

 
 
 Terry waves her off with a laugh. “Nothing. I’m simply bringing Jenna up-to-speed.”

 

 She offers you a sympathetic smile. “Enjoy,” she says, and slips away.

 

 You glance at the wall clock, time already slipping by. Terry turns, dragging your chair around to face the open floor. “Now, on to business. We’ve cast the mannequin, Jenna. But no one will sing the Refund Aria. I was hoping…” He trails off, getting lost in his own thoughts.

 

 “Well,” he says, finding his thought process again. “First let me tell you about the heroic perfume spritz girl looking for love in all the wrong departments.” He grins, leaning closer to you again. “And I’ll tell you a trade secret,” he whispers. “She reminds me of you.”

 

 You glance at the clock again. If you’re not careful, you are going to see the evening slip away.

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [Citizen Charlton] <>

 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 [Citizen Charlton] <> - You feel you can't say you want to leave

 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 <>
 
 
 Something in you can't say no to him. You lean forward, eager to listen to his ideas. Already hanging on his words, ready to listen to Terry’s grand plan for the department store.

 

 He dives back into his pitch, rifling through a drawer piled high with lyric sheets. He reads aloud the set list. ‘Sale Ends Sunday (But Love Is Forever)’, ‘Floor Two Fantasia (Linens & Regret),’ ‘The Till Won’t Ring Without You…’

 

 Each title blooms into a fifteen minute monologue as Terry explains the thematic through-line of his retail opera. Those minutes stretch into hours. You watch as the office clock’s hands spin forward until the glow outside has faded to night.

 

 At last, Terry’s voice trails away. He gathers up his notes with a satisfied sigh. “Oh, look at the time!” he exclaims. “Creativity does sweep you away, doesn’t it? See you tomorrow, Jenna!”

 

 He bounds from the office, leaving you alone in the dim light. The evening wasted, but you can’t bring yourself to be upset. Terry needed you as a sounding board and naturally, you said yes.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You lean forward, voice soft and playful. “You know, Mr. Evans, I’m very intrigued by playing your leading lady. Are you going to be the star in the show? Or just direct me? From behind.”

 

 Terry looks startled. Taken aback. But you think you see his eyes wander over you, just for a moment, before looking curiously back at you. Then he bellows with laughter. “I always knew you had the makings of a great actress, Jenna! Such fire! Playfulness. Perfect… just perfect.”

 

 You offer a coy smile. “I do have an appointment to keep, though. Perhaps we can rehearse another time?”

 

 “Sure. Sure,” he says, nodding as he looks down at you. The grin is there, but it’s fused with something more now. Curiosity. “How about over dinner? To iron out the scene. Talk about your role.”

 

 You look up at him. Something inside twists. You’ve taken this too far, haven’t you? 

 

 You tilt your head. “Perhaps.”

 

 “Excellent,” he states, as he moves away from your chair. You get up, adjusting your skirt. “I’ll see you tomorrow, Jenna,” he says. 

 

 He watches you slip from the room, gaze lingering on your retreating figure. You step into the corridor, heart racing. Do you really want to set Jennifer up with Terry for dinner?

 

 *Or would you attend that too?*

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You lean forward, voice soft and playful. “You know, Mr. Evans, I’m very intrigued by playing your leading lady. Are you going to be the star in the show for me?”

 

 He looks back at you, frowning. The subtext missed. “I can’t star in the show and direct, Jenna,” he says, as if it’s the most obvious thing in the world. “I need to be driving everyone’s performance, making the show authentic. Honesty will be the key to this show’s success. I can’t get sucked into a role. If I did, who would ensure the escalator was hitting their marks?”

 

 You’re not sure how to answer that. Terry seizes the opportunity and dives back into his pitch, rifling through a drawer piled high with lyric sheets. You sigh as you realise you’ve missed your opportunity to leave.

 

 He reads aloud the set list. ‘Sale Ends Sunday (But Love Is Forever)’, ‘Floor Two Fantasia (Linens & Regret),’ ‘The Till Won’t Ring Without You…’

 

 Each title blooms into a fifteen minute monologue as Terry explains the thematic through-line of his retail opera. Those minutes stretch into hours. You watch as the office clock’s hands spin forward until the glow outside has faded to night.

 

 At last, Terry’s voice trails away. He gathers up his notes with a satisfied sigh. “Oh, look at the time!” he exclaims. “Creativity does sweep you away, doesn’t it? See you tomorrow, Jenna!”

 

 He bounds from the office, leaving you alone in the dim light. The evening wasted, you sigh.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You lift your chin. “Sir, I’m sorry, but I really must be going.”

 

 Terry’s shoulders slump in true disappointment. “Already?” he murmurs. 

 

 He opens his mouth to protest further, but you smile and add, “I’m sorry, sir. It’s important. You’re a good boss, Mr. Evans. You value a good work-life balance, don’t you?”

 

 His frown brightens into a grin. “Balance… yes, yes!” He drums his fingers on the desk, thinking. “The trials and tribulations of maintaining a work life balance. Her head is at home, but her heart is in the store.” He rushes around his desk and begins scribbling. “Dear Jenna, you are my muse!”

 

 You watch him for a moment, frenziedly writing down new lyrics, muttering to himself. “Another song,” he says without looking up, “about work–life harmony… and how we so often miss the mark.”

 

 Evans then glances at you, eyes gleaming. “I’ll see you tomorrow, Jenna. I need to get these lyrics down. But we can talk tomorrow about the ballad. And who will perform it.” He flashes you a knowing smile. “I think you’ll be happy,” he says.

 

 You nod, slip past the desk, and step into the corridor, leaving him lost in his scrawl. Thankful you’ve gained your evening back.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 
 You lift your chin. “Sir, I’m sorry, but I really must be going.”

 

 Terry’s shoulders slump in true disappointment. “Already?” he murmurs. 

 

 You go to protest further, but Terry cuts you off with a wave. “Just ten minutes, Jenna. That’s all I ask.”

 You nod. Quickly. Quietly.

 He disappears back into the office. The door swings shut behind him.

 You give a small, sympathetic smile. “Maybe they just need… some firm direction," you say. "Like you do with me.”
 

 That lands. Thompson sits back, looking at you. "I thought you wanted me to loosen your leash, Annie?"

 

 You gulp, seeing a slight smirk appear on the man's face. "I can take direction," you mumble.

 

 "Then prove it," he says slowly, before pushing a stack of notes forward towards you. “Let’s see if you can still follow instructions.”

 

 You hesitate, but your hands are already moving toward the keys. The moment your fingers brush them, you feel a faint pulse. Not from the machine, but from something deeper. Something in you shifts.

 

 The keys are warm. Eager. The magic crackles at your touch. You didn’t mean to smile, but somehow, you are.

 

 As the typewriter clacks, you feel yourself adjusting. Submitting. It’s easier than arguing. Easier than disappointing him again.

 

 You glance at Thompson. He’s watching you now, studying your response. You find yourself smiling politely. Almost meekly.

 

 For the next hour there's no mention of booking systems or bugs. Key after key, line after line, you type. Before you know it, the afternoon has slipped away.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 You let your lips part into a soft smile. Just enough to seem sincere. Just enough to be noticed.

 

 “Mr Thompson,” you say gently, voice lilting. “I’m sure it was just a small mix-up. I know can be a bit scatterbrained, but… they mean well.”

 

 Thompson grunts, flipping another page. “Means well? So do golden retrievers. Doesn’t mean I’d let one loose on my booking system.”

 

 You force yourself to giggle lightly and cross your legs, drawing his eyeline to your exposed thigh. "Golden retrievers have their place," you say. "They're loyal."

 

 "I didn't take you for a golden retriever girl," Thompson murmurs. "Thought you'd go for something more manly. Like a pitbull."

 

 His eyes wander your body, then up to you. A crooked smile forms, waiting.

 

 You tilt your head. “I like all sorts of dogs, sir.”

 

 He lets out a snort. "I know you do." He grins, now letting it turn lecherous. "Thing about dogs, Annie. Hard to train. Obedience is a rare quality these days. Once they stop obeying, you either retrain them, or you put them down.”

 

 He reaches forward slowly and slides the notes across to you.

 

 You gulp, looking between the papers, Thompson and the typewriter. “Of course, sir," you say sweetly. “I'm always happy to be helpful.”

 

 The moment your fingers touch the keys, you feel it. The warm tingle of magic as the machine hums beneath your hands. It wants you to type. To perform.

 

 And you do. Line by line, letter by letter. Even as your stomach knots.

 

 You feel Thompson’s eyes on you as you work. You feel your posture shift. Straighter. Neater. More... proper. Your smile stays fixed.

 

 For the next hour there's no mention of booking systems or bugs. Key after key, line after line, you type. Dropping into a gentle rhythm of the mind-numbing typing, as magic seeps into your fingertips.

 

 You are suddenly aware of Thompson behind you, reviewing your work. You glance to the clock and see the afternoon has slipped away.

 

 "Good girl," he says. And he pats your head gently.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 You try to smile, keeping your voice light. “Mr Thompson, I’m sure it was just a little mix-up. has a lot on their plate lately, and, well… maybe they just need a little more support.”

 

 Thompson doesn’t look up. “Support? Phillips has got two hands, like the rest of us."

 

 You laugh, but it's awkward and too high-pitched. “I just mean… I’m sure they didn’t mean any harm. You’re so good at keeping everything running smoothly. Maybe they just need someone like you to set them straight.”

 

 Thompson turns the page in his hand with slow, deliberate disdain. “Set them straight? Annie, if I wanted praise, I’d talk to my mirror.”

 

 You shift in the chair, heat creeping up your neck. “I just thought -”

 

 “That’s your first mistake,” he snaps. He finally looks up, irritation heavy in his gaze. “I don’t pay you to think. I need someone who can follow basic instructions. But, clearly, you're not yet prepared to accept this.”

 

 He pulls off the top paper and begins reading again. "Make yourself useful. Go get on with something. That's not in here."

 

 Your hands tremble as you stand up. Thompson doesn't look at you. As you leave, you glance down at the typewriter. The magic embers on each of the keys straining towards you.

 

 As your hand hits the door, you realise you’ve narrowly avoided something worse. But Thompson’s anger isn’t gone. It’s just waiting for you tomorrow.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <> 

 You straighten your back in the chair and meet Thompson’s gaze. Calm. Professional.

 

 “With respect, sir,” you say evenly, “ isn’t here to defend themself. I don’t think you’re being fair.”

 

 That gets his attention. Thompson lowers the paper slowly, one eyebrow raised.

 

 “You’ve seen the state of the systems,” you continue. “They’re out of date. Duct-taped together. We’re running a modern business on computers two decades old. Anyone’s going to slip up eventually.”

 

 He watches you, eyes narrowing almost to slits.

 

 “And it’s not like they're slacking,” you quickly add. “They answer the phones, take notes, respond to emails. It's a lot. Something was bound to slip.”

 

 Thompson drums his fingers on the desk, staring at you. You can sense the anger rising up. “So what, we just accept incompetence?”

 

 “No, sir. But you give more time. It's hard to find good help."

 

 A long pause. Then Thompson exhales sharply through his nose. “Alright, Annie. You want me to give them a break? Then it’s time you remembered your old duties."

 

 Fear bolts through you. Thompson reaches out... and pushes a stack of notes forward towards you. “Let’s see if you remember how to type.”

 

 You gulp, looking between the papers, Thompson and the typewriter. “Of course, sir," you say sweetly.

 

 The moment your fingers touch the keys, you feel it. The warm tingle of magic as the machine hums beneath your hands. It wants you to type. To perform. You pause for a heartbeat, but something in your spine straightens before you can resist.

 

 You begin to type. Line by line, letter by letter. Even as your stomach knots.

 

 You feel Thompson’s eyes on you as you work. You feel your posture shift. Straighter. Neater. More... proper. Your smile stays fixed.

 

 For the next hour there's no mention of booking systems or bugs. Key after key, line after line, you type. Dropping into a gentle rhythm of the mind-numbing typing, as magic seeps into your fingertips.

 

 You are suddenly aware of Thompson behind you, reviewing your work. You glance to the clock and see the afternoon has slipped away.

 

 "Glad to see things are going back to normal around here," he says. "You're dismissed."

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 You sit up straighter, choosing your words carefully. “Sir, with respect, has been juggling a lot lately. They're not trying to sabotage anything. Just overwhelmed.”

 

 Thompson’s eyes don’t move from the paper in front of him. “Overwhelmed?” he repeats, voice flat. “By what? Reading the morning paper whilst bunking off work?”

 

 You ignore the sting. “The reception software is outdated. The work’s doubled since I was on the front-end. It’s not fair to lay this all on one person.”

 

 He exhales loudly through his nose, flipping the page. “You know what’s not fair? Hudsons don’t have their boiler. I’ve got suppliers breathing down my neck, and I'm missing a receptionist who thinks being at reception is an optional extra.”

 

 You try again. “All I’m saying is maybe you speak to them before assuming the worst.”

 

 That finally gets his eyes on you. Cold. Sharp. “You think I don’t know how to manage my own damn staff?”

 

 “No, I -”

 

 He slams the stack of papers down on the desk with a thud. “Then don’t tell me how to do my job.”

 

 You swallow your words. Thompson pulls another envelope from the pile and waves a hand toward the door without looking at you.

 

 “Get out of my office, Annie. Before you say something that puts you on the list next.”

 

 Your throat tightens, but you nod. You stand and turn to leave, catching the typewriter in your periphery. The keys still glow faintly, hungry for fingers that never touched them.

 

 You may have avoided the spellwork, but next time won't be fun for you.

 

 If you actually come in as you, that is.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

 You open your mouth… then close it again. Thompson is already red in the face, his eyes scanning the report like it personally betrayed him. Anything you say now could land you in deeper trouble.

 

 So you just nod slightly and fold your hands in your lap.

 

 Thompson doesn’t even look at you. “Goddamn waste of salary,” he mutters, dragging a file across the desk. “Should’ve let Phillips go when I had the chance.”

 

 The typewriter beside you buzzes faintly, hungry for attention. You keep your eyes away from it.

 

 Finally, Thompson exhales and gestures toward the door without lifting his head. "I'm too busy with this mess to deal with your typing, Annie. You’re dismissed."

 

 You stand without a word, your shoes quiet on the carpet. As you open the door, you glance at the typewriter. The glow of the typewriter keys fades as you move away.

 

 You survived Thompson this time. But you wonder what waits for you next.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

Pull up your outfit and leave
Return to reception and finish for the day
Charm him into going easy on you

title: CurrentStateEnd
text:
Thank you for playing! This has been a big undertaking, expanding out the initial two-day jam into what I envisioned for The Secrets at Charlton School.

Charlton is, and will be for the foreseeable future, a passion project. When I can devote time to it, I will do. There are two more acts planned.

If you like what’s here, please let me know on tfgamessite. I also encourage bugs, typos and needed clarifications to be reported. As the game has blossomed / ballooned into its current form, QA will always be a struggle.

Once again, I hope you enjoyed your time in Charlton, and can't wait to share with you the secrets that are still to be revealed. In the interim, here's a sneak peek at the next act:

[image: ./images/act2_splashscreen.png]

**Links**

Secrets of Charlton School on itch.io

Charlton discord channel

TFGamessite Forum Thread

title: GameOverEvents
text:
**Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 
Your family home has an open-plan kitchen within the living room. A large table separates the kitchen space from the lounge area, which boasts a big sofa and a giant TV at the other end.

 

 
 You rush down the stairs to find Emily standing in the hallway, tears streaming down her face. She shakily holds out a letter to you - the Charlton Upper School crest clear and ominous at the top.

 

 "They've expelled me," she chokes out, her voice trembling with despair.

 

 
 Without hesitation, you step forward and wrap her gently in your arms. Emily collapses into your embrace, sobbing against your shoulder. Her voice cracks as she whispers desperately, "Is there anything we can do? Anything at all?"

 

 You gently stroke her hair, knowing how hard you've both tried. Your heart sinks; you remember Stitch’s warnings all too clearly.

 

 "We'll figure something out," you whisper reassuringly, even as dread settles into your bones.

 
 You reach out instinctively to comfort Emily, but she recoils sharply from your touch.

 

 "Don’t," she hisses bitterly, eyes narrowed with hurt and anger. "This is your fault! You didn't help! You didn't do anything!"

 

 "Emily, that's not true -" you begin, but she's already turning away.

 

 "Don't bother," she snaps. With tears still wet on her cheeks, she grabs her jacket and storms out the front door, slamming it hard enough to make the windows rattle.

 

 You're left standing alone in the hall, the weight of your failures pressing down on your shoulders.

 
 
 
 Groggily hearing downstairs, you hear the catchy, unapologetic refrain ringing clearly: "Can't tell me nothing, gonna live my own way..."

 

 You find Emily in the living room, energetically dancing, completely oblivious to the world around her as she belts out the lyrics, her voice ringing boldly through the house. She notices you entering, flashing a carefree grin and holding up a piece of paper.

 

 "It's finally happened!" she shouts gleefully over the pounding music. "Expelled! No more school, no more rules!"

 

 She tosses the letter onto the couch dismissively. "Good riddance. School was just holding me back anyway." Her eyes sparkle mischievously.

 

 
 "Maybe I'll see if Coach Beach wants me to clean up his apartment sometime. Who knows what might happen now he's not my teacher anymore?" She laughs, teasing and unashamed.

 "This gives me more time to get ready for my date with Jake tonight anyway. I think I'll wear something he'll really like."

 "More time for me to get ready for my date with Brendan tonight. Might as well spend effort looking cute, as school's not a worry anymore."

 
 

 She spins away from you, returning to her exuberant dancing, seemingly delighted by her newfound freedom.

 
 Descending the stairs, you find Emily dancing without restraint, her movements wild, defiant, completely indifferent to your arrival.

 

 She glances over her shoulder, holding up an official-looking letter with Charlton Upper School's crest. "Guess what? They finally kicked me out," she smirks, rolling her eyes dismissively. "Not like you'd care."

 

 She tosses the letter onto the couch carelessly. "Honestly, I'm relieved. School was pointless anyway."

 

 
 She gives a defiant grin. "Maybe now I'll go see if Coach Beach needs his apartment cleaned. I bet he'd appreciate my company -- especially now he's not my teacher."

 "At least this gives me more time to get ready for my date with Jake. Not that it's any of your business."

 "Means more time to get ready for Brendan tonight. At least he knows how to treat me well."

 
 

 Without waiting for your reply, she turns her back, cranking the music louder as she resumes dancing - purposefully ignoring your presence. You're left standing awkwardly, the painful gulf between you clearer than ever.

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 
 You are sitting in your living room at the kitchen table in the morning, idly flipping through the latest issue of the Charlton Gazette. The soft creak of footsteps on the stairs draws your attention, and you look up to see Emily slowly descending, dressed reluctantly in her Charlton Hotel uniform - the short, frilled French Maid costume that has become a symbol of her new life.

 

 The last two months have clearly worn on her. Emily's previous spark seems diminished, her eyes duller, demeanor subdued and apologetic. Charlton has left its mark. She's quieter, uncertain, resigned to a life she never envisioned for herself, and yet unwilling or unable to fight it anymore. Faced with her resignation, you found yourself avoiding the amulet. You barely remember when you last saw it. The investigation, with Emily's growing acceptance, seems so irrelevant now.

 

 You glance pointedly at her uniform. "Are you sure you should wear that outside?"

 

 Emily shrugs weakly, her voice small but resigned. "It'll be fine. Lennox already criticizes me constantly. One more thing won't matter. Besides, is picking me up."

 

 There's still a faint hint of rebellion in her voice, but it's buried beneath layers of resignation and defeat.

 

 You hesitate briefly, then carefully ask about .

 

 
 
 
 Emily hesitates, voice low and conflicted. "Coach Beach is... complicated. He’s protective. He's older, sure, but at least he cares. It's not like he has a wife or anything." She pauses awkwardly, avoiding your eyes. "He's introduced me to some of his friends. Or, at least, I've waitressed for them during football matches.

 

 She holds your stare for a moment, then looks down. "I wouldn't have chosen this," she mutters. "But it's something to hold onto."

 
 Emily sighs softly. "Jake wouldn't have been my first choice, but at least he's protective of me." She pauses, guilt flickering in her eyes. "I know you tried your best, but... I just wish things hadn't ended up this way."

 

 When you cautiously ask if Jake is officially her boyfriend now, she winces faintly. "He's still seeing Christina, technically. But beggars can't be choosers. Not in Charlton."
 
 
 "Brendan’s nice enough," she admits softly, her voice weary. "A bit of a meathead, but protective. He’s broken things off with Chantelle, at least, or so he says."

 

 Her gaze drifts, filled with quiet resignation. "He's even talking about working at Thompson's Repairs when he graduates, starting a family... It's all happening faster than I'd like, but maybe it's what Charlton expects."

 
 

 Emily manages a meek, almost apologetic smile as she heads out the door. You watch your sister go, guilt and regret weighing heavily on your shoulders. Your parents are furious about Emily dropping out, but even without their anger, you know your time in Charlton is done. You can't shake the sadness at what's become of Emily, and fear for what her future now holds.

 
 
 She crosses her arms, eyes challenging you. "Coach Beach will look after me - better than you did, anyway. I don't care what you think about his age."

 

 When you ask cautiously if something is happening between them, she replies curtly, "What do you care?"
 
 
 She looks away sharply, defensive. "Jake actually looks out for me. Better than you ever did, even if he is a bit rough sometimes."

 

 When you cautiously ask if he's her boyfriend now, she snaps defensively, "It's complicated - not that you'd care."
 
 
 Emily gives you a cool glance. "Brendan's more protective of me than you've ever been. He's even talked about settling down, you know."

 

 When you gently press further about their relationship, she turns defensive. "What's it to you? It's none of your business."

 
 

 Emily doesn't wait for your response, turning away sharply. She heads out the door without another glance in your direction, leaving a painful silence behind.

 

 You watch your sister leave, regret heavy in your chest. Your parents are enraged that Emily dropped out of school. Without their support, and now feeling disconnected from your own sister, you know your time in Charlton has come to a bitter end. Guilt gnaws at you as you wonder what her future holds - and if she'll ever forgive you.

 
 
 You are sitting at the kitchen table, idly flipping through the latest Charlton Gazette. Footsteps echo lightly down the staircase, and you glance up to see Emily enter, dressed confidently in the Charlton Hotel’s uniform - a short, revealing French Maid costume.

 

 Emily has embraced Charlton more than you ever imagined. Her demeanor has shifted drastically - flirty, carefree, and decidedly ditzy. Her previous interests have vanished, replaced entirely by fashion, makeup, and boys. Plenty of boys. Whenever she's not working, she's out on dates. You can't remember the last time you used the amulet. Or saw it, even. With her embracement of her new life, it almost seemed like a second betrayal trying to rectify the situation.

 

 You raise an eyebrow at her uniform. She giggles, spinning playfully. "What's wrong? Jealous?" she teases, flaunting her outfit. She shrugs breezily. "Anyway, is driving me today, so I'll be fine. Besides, Lennox loves me. I know exactly how to wrap him around my finger."

 

 She giggles suggestively, clearly implying how she secures special treatment from the hotel staff.

 

 Cautiously, you ask about .

 

 
 
 
 Emily grins boldly, clearly enjoying your surprise. "Coach Beach might be older, but he's not boring. He's even introduced me to some of his friends - I served beer for them during the football games. You should've seen their faces when I showed up in this uniform! It's not exactly how I thought things would go, but it's entertaining."

 
 Emily giggles brightly, eyes sparkling mischievously. "Jake? He's fun. It’s nice having a big strong footballer protecting me." When you ask if they're officially dating, she laughs lightly. "Christina can have his whining - I just want to have some fun. And trust me, he's plenty of fun."

 
 Emily smiles, amused but a touch overwhelmed. "Brendan's sweet, in a meathead kind of way. Protective, at least. He even broke things off with Chantelle - or so he says. He’s already talking about getting a job at Thompson’s Repairs and starting a family when he graduates. It's not exactly what I planned, but who am I to say no? It's kinda fun, for now."
 
 
 

 Emily gives you a coy smile as she steps out the door. You watch her leave, regret settling heavily in your chest. Your parents' anger over Emily dropping out of school has severed any remaining ties to Charlton. You can't help but wonder with sadness and guilt about Emily’s future, even as she seems perfectly content.

 
 
 Emily crosses her arms defiantly. "Coach Beach actually cares about me, more than you ever have. And before you say anything, I don't care about his age." When pressed for details, she snaps, "It's none of your business."

 
 Emily dismissively rolls her eyes. "Really? You suddenly care now? Jake's looking after me, better than you ever did - even if he’s a bit rough sometimes." When you hesitantly ask if they're officially dating, she deflects curtly. "It's complicated. Not that you'd care."
 
 
 She narrows her eyes, defensive. "Brendan's protecting me better than you managed. He's already talking about settling down, actually - which is a bit much, but at least he's serious." When you ask if he’s officially her boyfriend, she sharply retorts, "What's it to you, anyway?"

 
 

 Emily strides out without another glance your way. You watch her go, feeling the heavy weight of regret. Your parents are furious that Emily dropped out of school, and without their support - or Emily’s - you realize you have no choice but to leave the secrets of Charlton behind. The guilt remains with you, a constant reminder of your failures.

 
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home_Caravan.png]

 

 
 You sit at your kitchen table, pulling at your uniform. It's itchy and it stinks. Which, you reflect, is exactly what you'd expect from the uniform of a garbage collector.

 

 Unfortunately the smell has seeped into everything in your home. Although it doesn't take much to make the cramped caravan stink.

 

 You glance around the tiny living space. A scrunched-up sleeping bag rests at the end of the cushion you’ve been using as a makeshift sofa. There’s only one bedroom - you gave that to Emily. Not that she’s here much these days.

 

 You lean back, sighing. After the house was forfeited, your parents were clear: Emily still had to graduate. That part wasn’t up for debate. You didn’t have many options. You rented a caravan at Misty Falls Caravan Park and took whatever job you could get.

 

 But Charlton had already made up its mind about the Phillips family. Almost every door was slammed shut. It felt like revenge when the only job offered was cleaning up after the rest of town.

 
 You sit at your kitchen table, pulling at your uniform. Try as you might, the skirt won’t come down any further, riding up almost the whole of your thigh. The cropped blouse smells of beer and alcohol, and your feet ache from the high-heels you’re forced to wear. But what else would you expect from the Red Room bar? The dive bar where Charlton's underbelly go to drink, only tolerated because it’s out of town.

 

 Being outside Charlton seems to be the new reality for you, though. Case in point - where you live. A tiny cabin in the Misty Falls Caravan Park thirty minutes away from your old home.

 

 You look around the confined space, grimacing. A scrunched-up sleeping bag rests at the end of the cushion that passes for a sofa. The only bedroom went to Emily. Not that she’s here much these days.

 

 You lean back, exhausted. When the house was forfeited, your parents made one thing clear: Emily still had to graduate. That was non-negotiable. You didn’t have many options. You scraped together what little money you had and rented a caravan at Misty Falls.

 

 Most businesses in Charlton wouldn’t even look at you. The town had made its judgment on the Phillips family. Petty revenge, maybe, that the only work you could find was serving the town’s dregs in a bar that smells like regret.

 
 

 The door creaks wide, bringing you out of your reminiscing. And through the small opening, Emily walks in. The smell of cigarette smoke wisping in off her as she enters.

 

 It’s early - and definitely a school day - but that doesn’t seem to matter anymore. She’s dressed in ripped stockings and a skirt that barely covers her bum. Her makeup is heavy and smeared, her torn leather jacket slung over a stained crop top. You don’t want to know what the stains are.

 

 Just back from another night out. Another party. Another escape.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 Emily steps through the caravan door with a tired shuffle. "Hey," she says softly, eyes lowered. There’s no fight in her tone. Just exhaustion and something close to embarrassment. She lingers in the doorway, not quite meeting your gaze.

 

 "Are you going to school today?" you ask gently.

 

 She shrugs. "I dunno. Maybe."

 

 "Where were you last night?"

 

 She hesitates, eyes drifting downward. Beneath the bold makeup, she looks younger. Fragile.

 
 Emily sighs. "Coach Beach's house. He had some friends over to watch the football. They needed entertaining... he has a big living room too."

 "I hung out with Jake. We drove around. Parked up. A cramped car feels like home these days."

 "Brendan's parents are away. I stayed over. It was... comforting to sleep in a bed."

 
 

 "You need to concentrate on school," you say quietly.

 

 She nods, but her lip trembles. "Yeah. I know. It’s just... it all feels so pointless now."

 

 You try to say something reassuring, but the words won’t come. Instead, you offer a smile - a small, tired thing.

 

 "Have you spoken to Jennifer?" she asks.

 

 You shake your head. "I think that ship has sailed."

 You shake your head. "I’ve not had much time to keep up friendships."

 

 She nods slowly, then rubs her eyes. "I’m tired. I think I’m going to bed. I’ll try to go to school tomorrow.” It doesn’t sound like she means it.

 

 “Can you call them?” she asks. “Tell them I’m sick.”

 

 She doesn’t wait for a reply. She slips toward her room and gently pulls the thin, faux-wooden partition shut behind her. Leaving you alone with your thoughts.

 

 The foreclosure was enough to ruin Emily’s reputation at school. She didn’t drop out, but she might as well have. Dubbed the Caravan Queen, she became the focus of whispers, of judgment. People made assumptions. Assumptions that stuck.

 

 You tried to protect her. You tried to guide her. But between the long hours of your degrading job and the slow rot of Misty Falls, it wasn’t enough.

 
 
 Jennifer tried to help you pull through, but you grew distant. Eventually you just stopped returning her calls. Emily was your priority. She listened to you, respected you. But the influence of Charlton was just too much. In spite of your relationship, she changed.

 Some of your friends tried to help, but you grew distant. Eventually you just stopped returning calls to give more time to Emily. She listened to you, respected you. But the influence of Charlton was just too much. In spite of your relationship, she changed.
 
 

 You sigh, dragging your bag over your shoulder. Another day in Charlton. Another day playing the role the town carved out for you.

 

 As you reach for the door, you hear the faint sound of music coming from Emily’s room. Lexi Star’s latest ballad, soft and slow, slips through the thin walls like a lullaby.

 

 *“If I vanish, will they notice?

 

 If I scream, will they pretend?

 

 I used to dream of shining.

 
 
 Now I just want the hurt to end.”*

 
 Emily steps through the caravan door with a toss of her bag and a casual, "Hey." She doesn't stop to make eye contact, just heads straight for the back of the cabin. 

 

 "Are you going to school today?" you call after her.

 

 She doesn’t break stride. "What’s it to you?"

 

 "Where were you last night?"

 

 She stops and turns to you, glaring. She rolls her eyes.
 
 
 “Like you don’t know already,” she replies. “I was at Beach’s house. At least he has a normal bed.”

 “If you must know, I was with Jake. And trust me, you don’t want anymore details than that.”

 “Yes, I was at Brendan’s. And yes, I spent the night. And yes, his parents are away. Why would I stay here when he’s got an actual house still?”

 
 
 
 “Is that how you want to live your life?” you try. “Staying out all night with guys?”

 

 Emily scowls at you, enraged. “Give me a break. Just because Jennifer dumped you, doesn't mean that everyone else should live like an incel.”

 Emily snorts. “Leave it alone. Just because you act like a nun, doesn't mean that other people don't need attention.”

 

 You open your mouth to respond, but she storms off, yanking the thin, faux-wooden partition shut with a slam that reverberates through the entire caravan. You sit in the stillness, the air thick with tension and a hundred words left unsaid.

 

 The foreclosure was enough to destroy Emily’s reputation at school. She didn’t officially drop out, but she might as well have. Rumors circled like vultures, dubbing her the Caravan Queen. It didn’t take long before the insinuations started: names, labels, all the things people assumed about girls from a trailer park.

 

 You tried to hold her back. Tried to guide her. But between your exhausting job, the emotional weight of everything you’d lost, and the toxic influence of Misty Falls... it was hopeless.

 

 Jennifer tried to help you pull through, but you grew distant. Eventually you just stopped returning her calls. Emily was your priority. But too little, too late. The damage between you and her had already been done.

 Some of your friends tried to help, but you grew distant. Eventually you just stopped returning calls to give more time to Emily. But too little, too late. The damage between you and her had already been done.

 

 You sigh, standing up and grabbing your bag. Another day in Charlton. Another day living out the role the town has written for you.

 

 As you move toward the door, you hear the muffled thump of bass from Emily’s room. Lexi Star’s latest anthem blasts through her cheap stereo. Saccharine, biting, and painfully on brand.

 

 *“You call it falling, I call it flying.

 

 You say I’m lost, but I’m just not trying.

 

 Let the whispers talk, let the curtains twitch,

 

 I’d rather be a mess than someone’s fix...”*

 
 

 Actions

 <>

title: GameOver

Charlton is, and will be for the foreseeable future, a passion project. When I can devote time to it, I will do. There are two more Acts planned, plus a whole host of refinements for what's already here.

If you like what’s here, please let me know on tfgamessite. I also encourage bugs, typos and needed clarifications to be reported. As the game has blossomed / ballooned into its current form, QA will always be a struggle.

title: AnniesApartmentInvestigate
text:
You look around the apartment for signs of anything personal. Everything looks stylised and unique to Annie, from the 50s furnishings to the pastel coloured flowers. Nothing, however, seems treasured. 

Until your eyes fall on a photo frame on the shelves, tucked behind a plant. You move over to it, brushing aside the leaves to see more.

The photo is of two girls sitting outside on a beautiful cloudless day, smiling brightly at the camera. One of them you instantly recognise as Annie, although she looks a year or two younger. The other you’ve never seen before. Her dark hair contrasts with her pale skin, her eyes are dark to the point where you can barely separate her pupils from their iris. 

The two of them sit on a grass verge, legs sprawled across each other, their temples leaning against each other. Both look carefree. Happy. Innocent.
 

 “Friend of yours?” you ask Annie, as she continues to mix you both some drinks.

 

 She looks over at you and her eyes linger on the frame for a moment. Then she turns back to cutting up a lime for the gin. “Penny,” she says, her back turned to you. “We went to Charlton together. We were... friends.”

 

 “Just friends?” you ask.

 

 
 Annie stops cutting and turns to face you. Her smile gone, but not replaced with anger or pain. To the best of your reading, she just seems confused. You catch sight of her blushing slightly.

 

 She glances at the frame again, then back to you. “Girls are made for boys, .” she says without feeling.

 

 She looks at you with confused eyes, almost faltering. “Of course,” she says quietly. “That’s what they taught us at school.”

 

 Annie turns back to preparing your cocktails. You look back up at the photo. In spite of her reaction, you are sure that this is personal to her. It could probably power the amulet.
