 “I’m really busy today, but I’ll see you soon, okay? And tell your sister to come round - I'd love to catch-up!"
 
 “I’m really busy today, but I’ll see you soon, okay? And tell your brother I'm expecting him tonight."

 

 “Okay,” you mumble, not for the first time trying to make sense of the messy situation in your brain. You decide to leave Jennifer alone.

 “Hey Andrea,” Jennifer says as you approach. She looks you up and down, then leans in to whisper. "Are you sure you should be walking around dressed like that? Doesn't Sermon mandate you don't wear your uniform outside?"

 

 You feel a nervousness spreading inside your body at the words. "I'm just on a break."

 

 Jennifer raises an eyebrow. "If you say so."

 

 Her attention is drawn away by a customer coughing politely nearby. “Sorry ma’am. One second,” she tells them, before turning back to you.

 

 “I’m sorry. Busy day. But we should grab a coffee soon. And be careful walking around like that. You don't want Mr. Sermon to catch you."

 “Hey Flo,” Jennifer smiles as you approach. "Taking a break from work?"

 

 "Something like that," you reply.

 

 “You should take a look at the clothing racks,” Jennifer replies. “There’s some new stock that just arrived. That yellow dress on display would really work with your hair.”

 

 You smile politely and glance over at the display. The yellow dress is strappy and casual. You could imagine wearing it on a summer day, your red locks swaying in a gentle wind.

 

 Don't you mean, you could imagine Florence wearing it?

 

 A customer coughs politely nearby, bringing you back to reality. Jennifer turns to apologise. “Sorry ma’am. One second."

 

 “I’m sorry," she then says to you. "Busy day. But I'll come by Fresh Pot soon. We should catch-up."

 Jennifer eyes you cautiously as you approach. Only a twitch at the edge of her mouth hints of emotion. "Can I help you?"

 
 
 She stares back at you, meeting your eyes. For Jennifer, they look dead.

 

 When you don't reply, she lets out a little sigh. "Look Annie. If you need something, go ask at the counter. I'm sure Maisie is around. Or should be. She'll be only too happy to help."

 

 "Aren't you a shop assistant here too?" you say, with a tone that you weren't expecting.

 

 Jennifer's eyes narrow, locking on to you. Her lips tighten. Then sighs. "How can I help you?"

 

 There is no sign of the joy or excitement you've grown accustomed to. Nor the mischievous smile. She instead looks deflated.

 

 "It's okay," you whisper, then take a step back away from her. She watches you with confusion. You nod, then step back.

 Jennifer smiles professionally as you approach her. “Hello, welcome to Evans' Department Store. How can I help you?"

 

 You return the smile, but unsure of what to say you tell her that you’re just browsing. 

 

 She nods, retaining her professional expression. “If you need anything, don’t hesitate to ask.” 

 

 Jennifer returns to her work. You decide to leave her be for now.

Actions

<>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreChristinaDialogue0
text:
Christina glares at you as you approach. An eyebrow lifts, almost daring you to speak. In spite of the hostile invitation, you decide to leave her alone.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 Christina looks up as you approach. “Oh hey, Em. Doing a little shopping?”

 

 You nod. “Something like that.”

 

 The cheerleader rolls her eyes just a little, but pulls out a white leather miniskirt from the clothing rack. “What do you think?” she asks you. “Sophisticated or slutty? I can’t decide.”

 

 You shrug, unsure what Emily would say, or what the right answer is. Christina laughs at your reaction.

 

 “Really, Em. We need to work on your sense of style.” Christina eyes you, appraisingly. “How would you like to do some retail therapy? I’m sure Daddy wouldn’t mind if we picked out some things for you. So. My treat.”

 

 You look back at Christina. Do you want to spend your time with her?

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 Christina politely smiles as you approach. “Oh hi there,” she says, the sing-song tones in her voice just a little too forced.

 

 “Hey Christina,” you reply. “What are you doing?”

 

 “Browsing the new ranges,” she tells you. “My father might be the businessman of our house, but he has terrible taste. Mum picks out most of the stock.”

 

 She eyes you with her cold blue eyes, but turns her attention back to the clothing racks. “I’ll see you at school, then,” she adds, not looking back at you.

 

 Understanding an implied dismissal when you’ve received one, you say goodbye and step away, leaving her to shop.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 Christina looks up from the clothing racks as you approach. Her icy eyes look over you, a smile forming. “Jennifer,” she says. “Why aren’t you working? Or have you been slacking off again in the storeroom?”

 

 You glare back at her, trying to hold your head high. At this, she titters. “Oh, Jen. Let’s not pretend. It’s been years since you’ve frightened me. Don’t pretend that we don’t know who you are, now.”

 

 The resolve within your bones falters, as curiosity in her words takes the better of you. “And who’s that?”

 

 She offers you a polite smile, as false and fake as some of the brands in the department store. “A has-been,” she says, flatly. “Under all that bravado, you’re now just powerless and timid as the rest of them.”

 

 She gestures around to the other customers, unaware that they’ve just become Christina’s punctuation mark. “Run along, shop girl,” she adds. “Go serve.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 Christina glances up from the clothing racks as you approach. Her icy eyes look over you and a curious smile playing across her lips. “Hello Annie,” she says. “Looking for another dress? I believe there’s some more revealing outfits back in the discount section.”

 

 You look back at Christina, considering your response carefully. “I’m just browsing,” you tell her, unable to think of exactly what Annie would reply with.

 

 “I’m not surprised,” Christina says. “I would imagine that you don’t get paid well at a repair shop.” Her eyes glance up and down your body. “Although I’m sure Mr. Thompson is generous with his gifts. Shame he has a particular taste in clothes.”

 

 A flush of anger spreads across your frame. Her patronising smile infuriates you. For a brief moment, you’d like nothing more than to wipe it off her face.

 

 **Actions**
 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 <>

 Christina looks up from the clothing racks as you approach. Her icy eyes look over you, casting judgement. Disinterested, she returns her gaze to the clothes.

 

 When you linger, she speaks quietly without looking at you. “I don’t work here. Find one of the staff if you need something.”

 

 Giving you no more attention, you step away and leave Christina to her browsing.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Christina furrows her eyebrows as she sees you approach. “Yes?” she asks.

 

 She barely gives you a moment to respond before sighing. “I am so not interested, if you’re going to try and hit on me.” 

 

 Suddenly feeling embarrassed, you begin to shake your head vigorously. Before you can reply Christina has stepped up towards you, close enough that her perfume overpowers your nostrils. 

 

 “Did you realise that my father owns this store?" she whispers. “And that I’m only eighteen?”

 

 A menacing smile creeps up her face. “Now. Get out of here, you little pervert. Don’t come back.”

 

 Without a second glance she turns and returns back to browsing the clothing racks, leaving you standing there dumbfounded.

 

 Not wanting to press the issue, you decide to leave the store.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreChangingRoom
text:
Christina motions toward the row of curtained-off changing cubicles, standing just outside with her arms crossed. “Go on, Em,” she instructs, tilting her head toward the nearest one.

 

 You hesitate for only a moment before stepping inside, pulling the curtain closed behind you. A breath of relief escapes as you realize Christina isn’t following. Even as Emily, the thought of undressing in front of her - especially here, in public - would be too much.

 

 Still, the reprieve is short-lived. The curtain rustles, and a sliver of Christina’s face appears at the side, peeking in. “Strip to your underwear,” she orders casually, as if it’s the most natural request in the world.

 

 You blink, caught off guard. “What?”

 

 Christina sighs, rolling her eyes. “Em, I have to see what we’re working with. Clothes should complement your natural shape. Now hurry up.”

 

 There’s no real room to argue. Exhaling slowly, you begin undressing, sliding out of your clothes until you’re left in just your underwear. The room suddenly feels cooler against your skin.

 

 When you mutter, “Done,” Christina doesn’t wait. With a swift motion, she pulls back the curtain, exposing you completely to her scrutinizing gaze. Her eyes flick up and down, appraising, as if she’s evaluating a dress on display. You shift uncomfortably under the intensity of it.

 

 “Like I thought,” she says at last, arms still folded. “You have some natural assets we can work with.”

 

 Before you can even process that, the door to the changing area opens.

 

 Jennifer steps in, holding a neat stack of clothes, and immediately freezes. Her eyes widen at the sight of you in just your underwear. “Oh,” she stammers, quickly averting her gaze. “Sorry. I didn’t mean to --”

 

 Christina dismisses her embarrassment with a wave. “Oh, don’t be such a prude, Jennifer. Just do your job and make sure no one else comes in here while we work. Understand?”

 

 Jennifer looks up at her, grimacing as she bites her tongue. But nods.

 

 “I mean it.” Christina’s voice lowers, deliberate. “It would be a shame if I had to let daddy know I had a less than pleasant experience with the help. Especially after she was recommending his customers such... plain clothes.”

 

 Jennifer stiffens, as you look at the clothes Jennifer brought. Simple skirts, a cardigan, a plain white blouse. Nothing particularly bold. Exactly what Emily would usually wear.

 

 The disapproval from Christina is palpable. “Jennifer. Better choices. Find something that Emily could wear at home without hiding in shame. Now.”

 

 Jennifer doesn’t say anything this time. With a curt nod, she turns and disappears into the store again, off to find something more fitting for Christina’s standards. As soon as she’s gone, Christina turns back to you, expression calculating.

 

 “Here’s the real test, Em,” she says, gesturing to the discarded clothes. “This isn’t just about trying things on. It’s about asserting your standing.”

 

 She leans against the cubicle’s frame, arms crossed. “When that assistant brings back her selections, you’re going to judge them. Tell me what you really think of them. Don’t be shy. You need to prove you have an eye for style. That you can tell good taste from mediocrity.”

 
 
 Her lips curl into a smirk. “If you can’t, well… at least I’ll know how much work we still have to do on you.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 The curtain sways slightly as Jennifer steps back into the changing area, a new stack of clothes in her arms. She sets them down carefully on the nearby bench, keeping her expression neutral. Forcing it to be neutral, like she’s bracing for something.

 

 Christina barely acknowledges her presence, already flipping through the selections. Her fingers trail over a soft beige sweater, a pair of pastel shorts, and a breezy floral dress.

 

 She exhales sharply. Disappointed.

 

 “Well, at least this is an improvement,” she muses, lifting a simple white sundress by its hanger. “But honestly? This entire selection looks like it was pulled from the end-of-the-line section."

 

 Jennifer says nothing, standing stiffly near the entrance. She meets your eyes. You can only look away.

 

 Christina tilts her head, then turns to you, curiosity gleaming in her blue eyes.

 

 “What do you think, Em?” she asks smoothly, stepping aside so you can look over the options yourself. “Has Jennifer done a good job?”

 

 You look over the selection. All you know is how you expect Christina to react. Any support for Jen will be seen as bad, any mockery good. Can you really do that to Jen, though?

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 Jennifer soon steps back into the changing area, her posture still rigid as she carefully lays out a new selection of clothes. This time, she doesn’t even glance at you. Whatever frustration she’s feeling, she keeps it tightly bottled.

 

 Christina hums in approval as she lifts up a pale pink dress, twirling it slightly by the hanger. A full skirt with layers of soft petticoats, cinched at the waist with a delicate white belt. Short puffed sleeves, lace trim, and tiny pearl buttons running down the front give it a dainty, doll-like charm. The rest of the selection follows the same style. Girlish. Pristine. Perfectly suited for the Kaplars’ country club.

 

 Christina’s grin sharpens as she inspects the pieces.

 

 “This is more like it,” she muses, brushing a hand over the starched fabric of the blouse. “Something fitting for a Charlton girl.”

 

 Then her gaze flicks to you. “Well, Em? What do you think? Did Jennifer finally get it right? Do you want to try it on?”

 

 You hesitate. Everything about these outfits is deliberate. The soft, pastel colors. The cinched waist. The subtle yet undeniable femininity woven into each thread. It’s the ideal of a young Charlton woman.

 

 And yet, you can’t imagine yourself wearing any of it. Jennifer, standing by the door, finally risks a glance at you. Her expression is carefully neutral, but her fingers tighten slightly against her forearm.

 

 Christina, meanwhile, is waiting.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 The click of Jennifer’s heels echoes through the changing area as she re-enters, carrying an armful of daring, body-hugging outfits. She says nothing this time, simply setting the clothes down with a measured, professional air, as if forcing herself to act like this is just another task.

 

 Christina barely acknowledges her, already plucking a dress from the pile. It’s a slim, black number, with a plunging neckline, hugging every curve with precision. The other options follow a similar theme. Low-cut blouses, skirts that barely graze mid-thigh, tight-fitting sweaters that leave little to the imagination.

 

 The second you take in the selection, something clicks in your mind. If you saw a girl wearing these on a date… 

 

 Your thoughts drift before you can stop them. A mental image flashes. You at a dimly lit movie theater, sitting beside a girl dressed like this, her perfume lingering in the air, her fingers brushing against yours in the shared popcorn bucket.

 

 You swallow, blinking. Except… The image shifts. Suddenly, it’s not just the girl beside you. It’s you.

 

 You are the one in the outfit. You are the one being admired. The soft glow of the theater lights catches the curve of your legs, the shimmer of lipstick on your lips. You’re laughing, leaning just slightly into the broad shoulder of the boy next to you. A football player. Tall. Confident. Chiseled. Strong. You can almost hear his voice in your ear, feel the weight of his hand resting on your thigh. A sudden rush of something coils deep in your stomach. Excitement, maybe, or confusion.

 

 Christina, oblivious to your sudden spiral, clicks her tongue. “Well, Jennifer,” she says, drawing out the name, her smile sharp as ever. “This is certainly… bold.”

 

 Jennifer doesn’t react, though you swear you see the way her fingers twitch at her sides.

 

 Christina turns to you, lifting a silky, wine-red dress with thin straps and a dangerously short hem. “What do you think, Em?” she muses, voice carefully leading. “Think you could pull this off?”

 

 Her expression is unreadable, but the slight raise of her brow says everything. She's waiting to see if you'll go along with Jennifer, or deliver a deathblow.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 

 You change back into your normal clothes, the fabric feeling strangely neutral after the extravagant outfits you’ve seen. Taking a final glance at yourself in the mirror, you exhale and step out of the cubicle, joining Christina in the changing room lobby.

 

 She’s already waiting, casually inspecting her nails, as if the entire experience had been more of a test than a shopping trip.

 

 
 Christina’s smile is slow, deliberate as she looks you over. There’s something different in her gaze now. Approval.

 

 “Well, well,” she muses, clearly pleased. “I think you’re starting to understand how things work around here.”

 

 She steps closer, lowering her voice slightly.

 

 “There’s a pecking order at Charlton,” she continues smoothly. “Cheerleaders and jocks at the top. Nerds and outcasts at the bottom. I want to see you at the top of the food chain. And you? You’re learning exactly where you belong.”

 <>
 

 She pauses, then smirks, tilting her head. “You handled Jennifer beautifully. That girl needed reminding of her place.”

 

 Christina doesn’t wait for a response, instead linking arms with you effortlessly, guiding you out of the changing area and back into the store.

 

 As you walk past the counters, you feel the weight of Jennifer’s glare. It’s not subtle. Her fingers are tight around a neatly folded sweater, her eyes following your every step as you and Christina stride toward the exit.

 

 Your stomach tightens. But you don’t look back.

 

 At the door, Christina slows, turning toward you. “I mean it, Emily,” she purrs, eyes gleaming with mischief. “Prove you belong on the squad. When you have, come see me at practice.”

 

 With that, she steps through the glass doors and disappears onto Orchid Road, leaving you standing just inside the store.

 

 You don't dare look behind you. You know that in doing so, you'd have to meet Jennifer's eyes.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Christina studies you for a moment, then lets out a soft hum of consideration.

 

 “You’ve got a way to go,” she finally says, not unkindly, but there’s still an edge of expectation in her voice.

 

 “There’s a pecking order at Charlton,” she continues, as if reminding you. “Cheerleaders and jocks at the top. Nerds and outcasts at the bottom. I want to see you at the top of the food chain. And I can help you get there.”

 <>
 

 She flashes you a knowing smile, almost conspiratorial. “Stick with me, Em. You’ll learn.”

 

 With that, she guides you out of the changing area and back through the store. Jennifer is still at her post, carefully folding clothes. This time, she’s watching. Not glaring. Not angry. Just… confused. Like she’s trying to figure out what she just witnessed.

 

 You don’t meet her eyes, but you can feel her stare following you as you and Christina head for the exit.

 

 At the door, Christina pauses, turning toward you. “I mean it, Emily,” she purrs, voice still sickly sweet. “Prove you belong on the squad. When you have, come see me at practice.”

 

 With that, she steps outside, leaving you standing at the threshold. Wondering if you should turn back to speak to Jennifer.

 

 But you can't even begin to formulate what to say.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreJenniferWork
text:
**Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 Your heart thrums with a dull mix of dread and resignation as you push open the “Staff Only” door, stepping into the dimly lit back halls of Evans’. You walk quickly and quietly, certain that somebody is going to call you out for entering a private area, not open to the public.

 

 With some trepidation you move through the endless corridors. You pass a cleaner, polishing the floor. A lone electrician, fiddling with a fuse box. Two other sales assistants that you don’t recognise. 

 

 No one treats you as though you shouldn’t be there. Nobody stops you. Nobody questions you. Instead, they barely acknowledge you.

 

 In the cramped staff room, the bulletin board groans under the weight of today’s roster. Names scrawled in bright marker mock you:
 
 

 “Stock control - Jenna! The early zest gets the dress!” 
 

 A sigh escapes you. In the grand scheme of retail, inventory is the dullest rung on the ladder.

 

 You punch the time clock and steel yourself for a morning of dusty boxes and misplaced price tags. Does Jennifer really do this every day?
 
 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 You push open the Staff Only door and walk the back corridors of the department store, this time without the anxiety of being an imposter. In some ways the reality is worse. Despite working in the same store, people go out of their way to avoid acknowledging you.

 

 Entering the staff room, you check the schedule. Once again, you’ve been assigned to the stock room in the morning. You take a breath, then turn on your heels and walk out.

 
 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

 
 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 You enter the staff room again. It’s lunchtime, but the room is empty. The kettle is cold. You’d bet if you checked the fridge, there wouldn't be any food in there. As far as you can tell, no one eats at Evans' department store.

 

 You check the board and see the same bright scrawl against lunchtime:

 

 “Perfume counter: Jenna / Maisie. Two noses are better than one!” 
 

 Your stomach grumbles, but you walk out the door.

 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 You briskly enter the staff room, glancing at the schedule. Again, Jenna and Maisie, assigned to the perfume counter at lunchtime. Nothing ever seems to change around here.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 You crack open the staff room door, the fluorescent buzz and stale coffee scent washing over you. At the battered corkboard the afternoon roster is pinned in bright marker:
 
 

 “Sales counter: Jenna. Dress them to impress them!” 
 

 Taking a deep breath, you open the door to the staff room and once more walk to the shop floor.

 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 You slip into the staff room again and glance at the schedule: Still assigned to the sales desk. You let out a quiet sigh and step back out.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 **Evans' Department Store - Staff Room**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Staff_Room.png]

 

 
 
 You slip into the deserted staff room, legs aching from hours spent balancing perfect poise, enthusiastic smiles and cheerful demeanor. Your mind hums with the echo of compliments you never meant.

 

 With a soft sigh, you pull on your coat and push open the door. Another shift over. Another day of being the reflection of everyone else’s desires. You wonder how Jennifer copes with this without losing herself. And how many shifts you can do without it happening to you.

 

 Then you remember what Jennifer asked of you. *Pick something nice to wear. For in there,* You gulp. You know exactly what she means.

 

 You’re not seriously considering this, are you?

 

 You stop before exiting, debating what you’re going to do.

 

 **Actions**

 Almost like a worm burrowing up inside you, an unsettling idea forms in your mind. Maybe she wanted to... experiment?

 

 You’re not seriously considering this, are you?

title: EvansDepartmentStoreJenniferWorkResponses
text:
“You see,” he begins, and you instantly know there’s a wave of bullshit coming your way. “The loading bay has been blocked by someone’s new car. These rich folk, think they own this town, don’t they? I can’t get my van in there.” He looks down at your body once again. “It’s too tight to fit in.”

 

 You fold your arms. “Then park on the double yellows and deliver,” you fire back.

 

 Martin’s lips twitch into a grin. He steps forward and you find yourself backing up, brushing against the unopened crate next to the door. “And risk a fine?” he says. “Fifty quid for a few boxes of ladies’ underwear? Not worth it.” His voice dips low, rough as gravel. “Council don’t care if I’m late, but they love writing tickets.”

 

 You let out a huff. “That’s not my problem. You’re paid to deliver.”

 

 He straightens, expression twisting into something almost like pity. “Funny,” he says, voice thick with mock regret, “I heard about you.” He leans in, boots scraping the concrete as he shifts his weight. “Big fall from grace, isn’t it?”

 

 His hand drifts to the crate behind you, pressing just enough to pin you there. “Makes me wonder,” he murmurs, eyes dark. “How far you’ll go to stay on top… even just in this shop?”

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [The Appeaser] <>

 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 [The Appeaser] <> - You can't seem to stand up for yourself

 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 You can’t help it. Before you even think, the words spill out of your mouth. “Alright, Martin. What is it you want?”

 

 His grin turns predatory. “Something I’ve been hoping for all morning. Just a kiss.” 

 

 He looks at you. You feel like you don’t have a choice. Not with him. You can only nod.

 

 Before you can react, he sweeps you up on the crate. Your skirt rides up as he settles you down, his eyes now on the same level as yours. He pushes forward, parting your legs, skirt now up around your waist.

 

 He leans in close, voice low. “Just a little one. I’m sure you’ll enjoy it.”

 

 His lips crash against yours - stubbly and rough - with the acrid tang of cigarette smoke and last night’s whiskey. You don’t pull away. Instead, you close your eyes, letting him guide the kiss. His tongue teases past your lips, and a hand slides under your blouse at the small of your back, the other curling around your exposed thigh.

 

 There is a tingle in your body. The taste of Martin is abhorrent. Logically, you are repulsed by him. But after spending hours doing mindless work, something flutters inside of you. You recognise it as an emotion. At least you're feeling something.

 

 Despite everything telling you that this is wrong, you find yourself responding. Longing for a feeling that isn't brain-numbing. The smell of alcohol and cigarettes more valuable to you than any control you have.

 

 After what feels like a heartbeat stretched into an eternity, he steps back. You catch your breath as he straightens, dust motes drifting through the fluorescent glare. His dark eyes flick over you appreciatively.

 

 “Expected nothing less from Charlton’s top student,” he murmurs, voice thick with mock admiration. "Read about you in some articles in the Charlton Gazette. You were going to be something. Now, look at you.”

 

 He reaches for the door, pauses, and looks back. “But now school’s over. You're just like me. I suppose this will be the highlight of your day.”

 

 With a final crooked smile, he slips out, the door thudding shut behind him. You hear the van’s engine roar to life, then the shuffle of boxes being unloaded.

 

 You press your hand to your racing heart and adjust your clothing, then shift off the crate. Something inside you stopped you from doing anything he wanted. But the troubling thought on your mind is the sensation - the actual feeling - you experienced was as rare in this work as the disgust you feel from appeasing him.

 

 Not for the first time, you wonder how Jennifer manages to get through an entire day.

 <>
 
 
 **Actions**
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 Take a break - *You feel compelled to work throughout today as Jennifer told you to*

 He leans in close, voice low. “Just a little one. I’m sure you’ll enjoy it.”

 

 His lips crash against yours - stubbly and rough - with the acrid tang of cigarette smoke and last night’s whiskey. You try to block out the sensation. His tongue teases past your lips, and a hand slides under your blouse at the small of your back, the other curling around your exposed thigh.

 

 You grow still, focusing all your efforts on not throwing up. The taste of Martin is abhorrent. There is nothing in the world you’d want to do less.

 

 After what feels like a heartbeat stretched into an eternity, he steps back. You look away as he straightens, dust motes drifting through the fluorescent glare. His dark eyes flick over you with disappointment.

 

 “Not feeling it today?” he murmurs, almost annoyed. “Don’t worry, you’ll learn your place soon enough. From where I’m standing, it looks like you’re not so different to me.”

 

 He steps back, loosening his grip. His gaze lingers as he sneers, “Yup. Here you are. A sales assistant hiding in the stockroom with the delivery man. Remember that. When you finally accept where you are, I’ll be waiting.”

 

 He pivots and strides out, leaving the door swinging and your pulse pounding in the sudden silence.

 You approach the perfume counter. A glass-topped display cabinet gleams under soft lighting, lined with frosted crystal bottles and gilt-trimmed atomizers. The air is thick with floral powder, citrus zest, and something with a sickly sweet undertone that lingers longer than expected.

 

 Behind the counter, a poised assistant in a peach blouse and pencil skirt offers quiet suggestions with a practiced smile. Maisie Peterson.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Maisie is already behind the counter. She smiles politely at you as you approach. “Am I late again?” you ask, rushing around the counter.

 

 
 
 She smiles, as if sharing a secret. “It’s fine. I just got in myself. It feels wrong to be cooped up in here at the weekends. I wanted to spend longer at the country club.”

 

 "You wouldn't believe what Hazel Evans was saying to that lifeguard, Ethan," Maisie whispers. "He's young enough to be her son. She thinks she can get away with it, being married to a town statesman."

 
 She smiles, as if sharing a secret. “It’s fine. I just got in myself. The school receptionist wouldn’t believe that Stitch had signed my pass. As if I’d bother to forge it to come here.”

 

 Her smile creeps up on the left hand side of her face, as she lowers her voice. “Making other people miserable is probably the only joy she gets in life. It’s not as if she’ll marry well, stuck in that school.”

 
 

 You smile politely, thoughts briefly considering that Jennifer has to listen to this everyday. This idle bitching and gossiping being the only thing to break up the mundane job of working in a quiet store. 

 

 Maisie suddenly stops her chatter mid-sentence. Eyes widening. You know what’s coming. “Darling!”

 

 You turn to see Aunt Joan approaching the perfume counter, heels clacking. At seeing Maisie, she pauses. Eyes narrowed.

 

 “My dear, what on earth is that?” she snaps, jerking a finger at Maisie’s uniform blouse. “That silk looks like your mother draped a napkin over you. And that skirt’s hemline like it’s been dragged along by a cart.”

 **Evans' Department Store - Sales Desk**

 [image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Sales_Desk.png]

 
A hexagonal sales counter topped with clunky cash registers and gaudy pin-up posters, ringed by blank-faced mannequins and endless rails of drab dresses.

 

 
 
 You step behind the counter and feel instantly on display. The glare of fluorescent lights seem to be directed at the counter, whilst the shape of the counter gives people a view of you almost from every angle. Like the counter is a podium and the customers are your audience.

 

 Forcing a smile, you step up to the till. They are archaic, but you see the basics are the same as a string of part-time jobs you did at uni. But customer questions are a different matter. After a few honest truths to some unhappy customers, you force a bright smile and a cheerful tone in your voice. The reactions are instant and pleasant.

 

 The monotony of it dulls your mind. You find yourself dropping into a rhythm. The ancient tills clatter at your fingertips like props. The drawers ding like an ending to a song. As you serve, you complement your smiles and cheery tone with graceful movements. Every movement is choreographed: a hand on your hip here, a tilt of the head there, each flourish theatrical. This is a stage that you find yourself performing a role on.

 

 Your words are similarly refined as you go. Women lean in, nodding at your praise of their choices; men hover at the edge of the desk, smirking when you catch their eye. There is no honesty needed here. You realise quickly that you are a bright, cheerful carnival mirror, designed to reflect the best versions of your customers.
 
 
 
And all the while, at the back of your mind you distantly remember that you need to get away from the desk and sneak upstairs to see Mary. Your eyes periodically flick up to a clock and you grimace as time ticks by. But the drum and monotony of the tasks of a sales girl keep stacking up, and you struggle to break the brain-numbing performance that you all-too easily slip into.

 

 The act becomes so overbearing that it takes you a number of attempts to recognise your own name. “Jennifer!”

 

 Except that’s not your name, is it?

 

 Before you can give it much thought, your heart sinks when you see the source of the voice. Grinning back at you from over the counter is Christina.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You take up position behind one of the counters, it all feeling familiar to you now. You bustle around the counter with a bounce and enthusiasm, keep your voice a pitch higher than normal, and above all, smile. It still feels like a stage, but you’re growing used to being both the centre of attention and an empty vessel, letting your mind slip away as you parrot back compliments and smile at leering men.
 
 
 
 
Still, all the while, looking for a moment to get upstairs to see Mary. But the queues seem to appear just as you think you have caught a break.

 
 

 Just like clockwork though, as you say goodbye to the last customer currently at the desk, Christina appears from behind a clothing rack. “Oh hello, Jennifer! Can you possibly do me an awful favour? I need to find a new outfit that won’t look unseemly at Daddy’s croquet afternoon.”

 
 
You glance up at the clock. If you’re going to catch Mary before she leaves for the day, you’re going to have to get rid of Christina. Fast.

 <>
 
 
 
 

 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 You straighten your shoulders and meet Christina’s cool gaze. “I’m sorry, but I’m swamped today. I can’t help you.”

 

 Her lips curl into an elegant, poisonous smile. “You hardly look busy,” she purrs. “Perhaps I will tell father you’ve been slacking off when I walked in.”

 

 Something in you welters. Christina, watching you carefully, seems to spot the doubt on your face. “I’m not scared of you, Jen. I haven’t been scared of you for quite some time. You might still fool some people with the bravado, but all I see is a meek little shop girl. Maybe the self-confident high achiever back at school was the mask, after all.”

 

 You gulp. Finding yourself lost for words.

 

 “Now. About that help. And to be clear, you’re the help, here.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 <>
 

 You glance at the till, piled high with receipts and customer requests. “Sorry, Christina, I’m swamped,” you say, voice curt. “I’ve got sales to ring up, restocks to sort, and display checks to finish.”

 

 She arches an elegant brow. “Hardly looks like you’re busy,” she retorts, stepping close enough so you can smell her perfume. “You wouldn’t be trying to slack off, would you, Jen?”

 

 You let a cold edge slip in. “You can tell me about being busy when you work a day in her life.”

 

 She reacts with a thin smile. “Be careful now, Jennifer,” she says quietly. “You wouldn’t want me telling daddy how rude the service was today, would you?”

 

 A flicker of anger warms your cheeks, but you bite back another retort. The threat in her tone reminds you where you stand.

 

 “Fine,” she says when you don’t respond. “Remember your place, Jen. You're not top-dog anymore. Not for quite some time."

 

 She turns on her heels and glides away. You watch her go. The sensations of standing up against Christina course through your body, like something awoken. Bringing you out of the glaze that seems to have overtaken you since working the counter. 

 

 But there’s a mixture of something else there too. Your cheeks redden as you repeat her final words in your head. Along with the defiance, there’s shame in there too.

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 
 
 Sneak up to the office - *You feel compelled to work throughout today as Jennifer told you to*

 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 

 You sigh, steeling yourself, and follow Christina back to the ladies’ fashion rails.

 

 She plucks a fuchsia sheath from the rack and holds it against you. “This is far too loud,” she snaps, tossing it back. “Honestly, Jennifer. Did they teach you nothing about balance at Charlton?”

 

 You slide out a muted silver wrap instead. “This drapes nicely -”

 

 She rolls her eyes. “Silver? At a theatre production? I’ll look like a walking mirror.”

 

 An hour crawls by in the same rhythm. You produce dress after dress and she dismisses each one. Her voice drips with thinly veiled threats, constantly mentioning her father and his impending disappointment at your work ethic with every hanger you hand her.

 

 You feel the afternoon bleed away under her scorn. Each criticism weighs heavier than the last: the fabric is too stiff, the cut too conservative, your own taste too provincial. If this is what Jennifer must endure in retail, you wonder why she hasn’t walked out of Charlton and never looked back.

 

 At last, Christina abandons the exercise. “None of this is right,” she declares. “Perhaps I’ll simply borrow from a friend. One who knows style.” She brushes past you, expression cool.

 

 You straighten, quietly relieved that the ordeal is over. As she disappears down the aisle, you murmur under your breath, “Well done, Jen. Always good to indulge your betters.”

 

 Afternoon wasted, you stand in the centre of the store alone. Wondering if Christina ever had any intention of buying something this afternoon.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreReception
text:
**Evans' Department Store**

[image: ./images/Evans_Department_Store_Reception.png]

A wood-paneled reception dominated by a lone desk, an old rotary telephone, and a frosted door with Terry Evans' name stenciled into it. The muted decor radiates sterile authority and quiet isolation.

 You slip away from the sales floor, heart thudding, and quickly ascend the narrow staircase to the upper level. The air grows still and hushed. Gone are the bright rails and glass displays, replaced by warm wood paneling, muted green accents, and quiet overhead lights that lend the reception a calm, somber precision.

 

 A lone wooden desk stands beneath a wall clock, an old rotary phone perched at its corner; framed abstract prints hang on the walls, their muted tones echoing the soft carpet underfoot.

 

 Behind the desk sits Mary Handle. A woman in her forties with motherly poise. Her blouse is crisply ironed, her hair pulled into a tidy chignon, and though laugh lines crease the corners of her eyes, she wears them like a badge of experience. When she looks up, her gaze is both welcoming and perceptive, as if she’s seen every kind of face pass through these doors.

 

 She looks up from the shift roster, offering you a warm, practised smile. “Jennifer,” she says, voice soft and steady. “Everything all right? Need to see Mr. Evans? He’s always happy to make time for his girls.” 

 

 You step forward, your heart ticking like the clock on the wall. You know Mary is Terrence’s mother and that the note you found at Jennifer’s apartment had her phone number on. You need to find out what it means, and you bet that Mary can help you make sense of it.
 
 
 Mary continues to patiently wait for you to talk. A soft creak from inside Terry’s office makes her jump. The pulse in your throat quickens.
 
 
 Mary waits for you to speak. Through the frosted door you hear heavy footsteps, followed by a growl of curses and muttered profanity that rattles the wood. Mary’s polite smile falters for the briefest moment. Her eyes dart toward the door, then back to you, calm and composed despite the storm thriving just out of sight.
 

 The door slams open with a crack that rattles the reception desk glass. Terry Evans fills the frame, his silver hair mussed, blue eyes locking on to you. “Jenna!”

 

 Mary returns quickly to looking at the schedule in front of her, leaving you alone. Terry smiles thinly as he looks at you. “I thought I heard you,” he says in a low voice. “Come on in.”

 

 You look back to Mary, then to the corridor. Neither feels like an option. Terry gestures with his thumb for you to join him.
 
 

Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 <>

 
 <>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreSleepwear
text:
Almost like a dream, you wander through the empty store, finding yourself quickly standing in the sleepwear section. Your mind races. Too often you've seen things in this section where your mind has jumped to what Jennifer would like wearing it. Now, the thought process is the same. But in the image, you’re Jennifer. And Jennifer is you.

 

 Do you want to appear sexy for your man? the snide voice that lives in your head snaps at you. Imagining what he’ll say when he sees you.

 

 You bite your lip. Your eye wanders to a rack of silk nightwear. You’ve seen Jen in a similar one before, but these seem like a different design. The hemline short, the top more open. Backless, tied together by lace trim.

 

 Something in you stirs. A picture of what it would be like to wear it. You can’t escape it. Looking at it is turning you on.

 

 You pick up a couple, and mull over what colour to buy.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 
 You pick out the pink colour. A small giggle escapes as you run it through the till, feeling the silk material in your fingers. You picture yourself in it. Standing in Jennifer’s bedroom. Looking cute. Girly. Feminine.

 

 And shut down the memory as the thought of who is watching as you model it.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 You pick out the red colour. A sultry laugh escapes as you run it through the till, feeling the silk material in your fingers. You picture yourself in it. Standing in Jennifer’s bedroom. Looking alluring. Sexy. Hot.

 

 And shut down the memory as the thought of who is watching as you model it.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

 
 You pick out the black colour. A wicked cackle escapes as you run it through the till, feeling the silk material in your fingers. You picture yourself in it. Standing in Jennifer’s bedroom. Looking assertive. Confident. Dominant.

 

 And shut down the memory as the thought of who is watching as you model it.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

title: EvansDepartmentStoreShopWorkout
text:
The male selection is sparse but straightforward. One rack of folded shorts and T-shirts in muted greys and dark blues. No labels boast of trend or appeal. Every one lists out the benefits to exercise. Moisture-wicking, stretch-fit, durable.

 

 You find a pair of shorts in your size, along with a workout shirt. The fabric is light but tough, designed to move with you and soak up sweat without complaint. There’s nothing flashy about any of it. No mesh panels, no logos, no tailoring to accentuate anything.

 

 It’s not meant to show you off. It’s meant to let you workout. As you check the fit, you feel readiness. These clothes are for testing yourself. Pushing yourself. Winning.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You look around Evans’ Department Store for any sign of workout clothes. After some searching, you notice a sign pointing to “Activewear.”

 

 The first thing you notice is how small everything is. Cropped tops, high-cut leggings, sheer mesh panels. The whole collection seems less designed for exercise and more for visibility. You scan the tags. Nothing here promises support or durability. But they all will bring attention.
 
 
You aren’t sure how you feel about wearing anything here, especially as Emily. Even if you only wear it whilst working out, people will still see. The thought of what you will look like as they watch unnerves you.

 

 After flicking through racks, you realise there are realistically only three options available to you. On-brand for Evans, the options are distinguished by colour - Red, Black and Pink - but more than the colours, the trims and design on each couldn’t be more different.

 

 The red set is made of material that is slick, tight, and unmistakably meant to be looked at. The top has a deep scoop neck, and the leggings cut high across the hips. Wearing this would make your body impossible to ignore. When you fold it over your arm, you can’t help but think about being seen in it. And why it feels exciting to imagine it.

 

 In contrast, the black set is made of matte stretch fabric with glossy straps that criss-cross the back like a harness. There are clasps you can’t imagine being useful for anything athletic. The top even includes a black collar to hold it in-place. You wonder why workout gear would be designed to restrict movement and impede airflow, but it's designed that way. Almost intentional. Not for comfort of the wearer, but the control and restriction of them.

 

 Finally, the pink set is soft and frilly, with ruffled hems and a cute little bow at the waistband. The top has capped sleeves and a sweetheart neckline. It’s absurd. Infantilising. You can’t imagine anyone taking you seriously whilst wearing it. But as you picture yourself in it, a giggle stifles out from between your lips.

 

 You regard all three options, trying to see if there is any sense of magic about them. You can’t detect anything, but the urge remains - whichever you choose, you can't help but feel it will reflect a part of you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 <>
 
 Running your hand over the red outfit again, you feel the smooth stretch of the fabric between your fingers. It’s bold. Showy. There’s no pretending this is about fitness. This is about form and how to accentuate the curve of your hips and the cut of your neckline. 

 

 You picture yourself stretching in it. Bending. Squatting. Stretching. Breathing heavy. You imagine how eyes will follow your curves and lines. And not just anyone’s eyes. Men's.

 

 You pause, caught off guard by the warmth in your chest. You weren’t thinking of smiling, but there it is on your face. 

 

 You fold the outfit carefully and hold it close, already lost in a dream of how you'll look in your future workouts.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You pick up the black outfit again, tracing the lines of the glossy straps and the neat black collar. It’s snug. Intentionally so. You can feel, just from holding it, the way it will wrap around your body. How it’ll press against your skin. How it’ll cling to your throat.

 

 It’s not made for comfort. That much is clear. It’s made to hold you in place. To keep you still. Presentable.

 

 You think about how you’ll look in it. What people will think of you as you struggle to breath and move in the straps. For some reason, that doesn’t feel frightening. Paradoxically, it’s empowering.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You hold the pink outfit up to the light. The frills bob slightly, and the little bow at the waist bounces as you shift it in your hands. It’s ridiculous.

 

 But as the thought crosses your mind, a tiny laugh slips out. You try to stifle it, but fail. The neckline is sweet. The sleeves are puffed. You imagine yourself bouncing into class in it, all smiles and energy. No one would expect anything of you. They would assume you’re a girly girl with little going on in your pink-tarnished brain.

 

 For a second, that sounds nice. You smile at that thought. The only thought you currently have.

 

 Maybe thinking’s overrated.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: FreshPotFlorenceDialogue0
text:
“Oh hi Annie! How’s it going?” Florence smiles broadly as you approach the counter.

 

 You chatter and gossip with Florence for a few minutes, but she tells you nothing of note. Eventually, you tell her you have to leave. She gives you a pleasant smile and tells you to come see her soon for a catch-up.

 
 “Hey Andrea,” Florence greets you as you approach. “How are you? How’s work?” There is a genuine hint of concern in Florence’s voice, as she looks at you with a serious expression.

 
 “Hey Jen, what brings you here?” Florence says warmly. 

 

 You chat with Florence for a while. She asks you a number of questions about the latest ranges that are coming to Evans’ Department Store. You definitely don’t have much in the way of details, so you make a sharp exit when the conversation draws to a close.
 
 
 “Oh hi Emily!” Florence greets you as you approach the counter. “What brings you do Fresh Pot? Got a date?”

 

 With nothing specific to ask Florence as Emily, you make small talk for a few minutes, then politely say goodbye.

 
 
 "Oh, hello ", Florence deadpans. "How can I help you today?"

 

 The sarcasm hangs on every one of her words.

 
 “Morning !” Florence says warmly as you step up to the counter. “Your usual?”

 

 
 You nod. She picks down her paperback book, spine turned downward, and starts preparing your coffee.

 You nod. She stops wiping down the counter and starts preparing your coffee.

 
 

 Florence waits patiently for you to ask her a question.

title: FreshPotDateDennis
text:
You walk over to Dennis, hearing your heels clicking on the ceramic as you approach. He glances up and double-takes, his mouth agape as he looks you up and down. You can’t help but smile at his reaction.

 

 “My gosh, Emily,” he says. “You look…”

 

 He trails off. You realise he’s not going to complete the sentence. “Thank you,” you say to him. 

 

 You sit down in the booth opposite him. You can’t help but let out a giggle as he continues to stare at you. You sense some butterflies in your stomach in reaction to Dennis’ clear desire for you. Why do I feel flattered that a boy is lusting after me?

 
 You walk towards Dennis, smiling as he notices you. His eyebrows rise a little and you see a big grin spreading across his face as he looks you up and down.

 

 “You look nice,” he stammers out. “Thanks for coming, Em. I wasn’t sure if you would show up!”

 

 You slide into the booth on the opposite side to him. His eyes glance over your body before he realises what he is doing and looks back up at you. “Sorry.”

 

 “That’s alright,” you say quietly, unsure how to feel that a boy is checking you out. Especially as you did go to a bit of effort. 

 
 Dennis notices you as you approach. He gives you a look, then smiles politely. He is wearing a neatly pressed shirt and some awkward looking formal trousers. You can tell he’s disappointed at your lack of effort.

 

 “Hi Em. It’s nice to see you,” he mumbles.

 
 Dennis almost doesn’t notice you as you approach. When he sees you, he looks at what you are wearing and how little effort you’ve put into preparing. He himself is wearing a freshly pressed shirt and some formal trousers that look brand new. Disappointed, he looks down at the table.

 

 “Hi Em,” he mutters, not meeting your eye.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Flo comes over and the two of you order some drinks and food. Dennis tries to make small talk, but it quickly peters out. He looks flustered and nervous. You consider asking him some questions, but you feel just as awkward as he does. For very different reasons.

 

 You look back at the shy teenager, fiddling with his glasses. You want to make sure he is satisfied that you are taking this seriously, otherwise you doubt whether he’ll give you the key.

 

 You really wowed him with your clothes, hair and make-up, so it shouldn’t be too hard to keep him on side and get that key from him.

 He seemed pretty happy that you made an effort. With a small amount of effort, you should be able to win him over and get the key.
 
 You didn’t put in much of an effort preparing for the date, so you’ve got a bit of work to make him believe you are taking this seriously. Otherwise, you wonder if he’ll give you the key.
 
 You made no effort at all for this date, so you realise you are going to have to go all out to get him back on-side and make sure he’s happy enough to give you that key.

 
 

 “So Em,” Dennis blurts out. “What is something you could tell me about yourself that would surprise me?”

 

 You look back at him, raising an eyebrow. That sounded suspiciously like a question from an online dating guide. He waits for your response. You know you need to make sure he has a good time, but how much do you need to do to get that key?

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 
 “I have a soft spot for nerdy guys,” you say, offering him a coy smile. 

 

 “What?” he stammers. “But why?”

 

 “I don’t know,” you shrug. “Intelligence just turns me on.”

 

 “Like, scientists and stuff?” Dennis asks, fascinated by your answer.

 

 “Not just that,” you tell him. “Just people who know things. They can teach me about things. Like you.”

 

 Dennis grins. His cheeks blush, but he maintains your eyeline. A rare interaction from him.

 
 “My best friend when I was young was Miranda Hilly,” you tell him.

 

 His eyes widen. “The movie actress?” 

 

 You nod, recalling your sister’s childhood best friend. “She went to my primary school. We used to do everything together, until she started going to auditions. Then one day, she got an agent and the rest is history.”

 

 “Do you still keep in contact with her?” Dennis asks excitedly. 

 

 You shake your head. “We haven’t spoken in a long time,” you say sadly. You mean it, too. She may bury it, but you know Emily gets upset whenever Miranda is on TV.

 

 “That’s insane!” Dennis blurts out, enthused. “We should try to go see her on a movie set!”

 

 You smile politely. “Yeah, maybe we could try,” you say, but offer nothing more.

 
 “I used to have a tank full of fish back home,” you say, recalling the aquarium that Emily had in her room back in the city.

 

 “Do you like fish?” Dennis asks. 

 

 You shrug. “Not particularly.”

 

 Dennis opens his mouth like he’s going to say something, but nothing comes out. He just stares at you.

 
 

 The moment is interrupted by Flo, who sets down your order. You both thank her and start eating. Dennis asks you about your food and whether you like it, but struggles to keep the conversation going.

 

 “So, what’s the most spontaneous thing you’ve done?” Dennis asks you in a tone that tries all too hard to sound casual, and fails miserably.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 
 You think carefully about how Emily would answer the question, trying not to break character and ruin his expectations of you.

 

 “Well, I went to a comic convention dressed as one of the characters from Sailor Moon,” you tell him, remembering one event that your sister did attend.

 

 His eyes light up. “Which one?”

 

 “Tsukino,” you reply, thankful you spent a summer when you were fifteen indulging an anime binge. 

 

 He smiles, mouth open a little. “Do you have pictures?”

 

 You giggle. “Maybe I’ll send you a few. If you’re nice.” 

 

 Dennis is beaming. “I’d love to see that.”

 

 You say nothing more, but smile back at him. *Are you enjoying turning him on?*

 
 You consider one of the things that you know Emily did when she was younger that will pique his interest. “On the last day of school last year, we all jumped on a train and went to see if we could spy on the filming of the new Ultra Girl movie.”

 

 “What?” he stammers, shocked.

 

 You recall how Emily told you and your parents when you found out. “We learned that they were filming it in a forest just outside the city, so we got tickets to the nearest station and then hiked to try and find the location."

 

 “What happened?”

 

 You laugh, remembering the end of the tale. “Security guards caught us before we even got close. I ran away and ended up twisting my ankle. My parents weren’t happy when I was dropped off at home by one of the Production Assistants. But they gave me some signed autographs anyway.”

 

 Dennis smiles, clearly happy that you and him have some shared interests. Maybe Emily and him would make a good couple, you think. Although, it is me currently acting as Emily…

 

 You find yourself lost in worrying thoughts and the conversation peters out. 

 
 “I don’t know,” you shrug. “I guess moving here was pretty spontaneous.”

 

 “Why did you move here?” Dennis asks.

 

 “My parents,” you reply, without feeling. “They wanted to get away from the city. I didn’t have much of a choice.” 

 

 You find yourself drifting into your own thoughts, realising that for once, your thoughts are definitely your own and not a mixture of your perception of someone else. 

 

 Coming back to reality, you look up at Dennis. “Not really that spontaneous, was it?”

 

 He smiles politely, but without comment.

 
 

 You both turn your attention back to your meals, finishing eating. Breaking the silence, you ask Dennis about his parents and where he lives. He talks without much enthusiasm about how his parents met at the Town Hall, where his dad works as an accountant and his mother a clerk, until she quit when Dennis was born. He doesn’t give you a hook to ask follow-up questions and once again the two of you fall into silence.

 

 Dennis takes the opportunity to try another conversation starter straight from a how-to guide. “So, how would you describe yourself in 5 words?“

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 
 “I have a better idea,” you say, coyly. “Why don’t you describe me?”

 

 Dennis’ eyes widen. “I don’t know…” he stammers. 

 

 “Oh come on,” you tell him. “Just one word then. How would you describe me?”

 

 Dennis looks at you, his lip quivering. “Pretty,” he says, immediately looking down at the table.

 

 “You think I’m cute?” you ask him, playfully. 

 

 He nods, barely glancing up at you. “Yes.”

 

 Instinctively you lean forward, lowering your voice to a conspiratorial tone. “Well, I happen to think you’re cute too.”

 

 You watch his eyes flick up to you, even looking down. He is blushing profusely, but a grin spreads across his face. “You’re hot,” he whispers.

 

 “Dennis!” you whisper. “You’ll make me blush.”

 

 His smile widens. You notice his eyes flick over your body with a flicker of desire.
 
 
 “I don’t know,” you say, smiling. “Happy, carefree, hopefully fun to be around. That’s only three though.”

 

 “I think you’re fun,” Dennis says. You watch his cheeks redden. “I like hanging out with you. You don’t make fun of me. Or the things I like. Like movies and comic books and stuff.”

 

 You smile. “I like hanging out with you too, Dennis.”

 

 “Besides,” you add, thinking honestly about Emily’s own hobbies. “I happen to like those things too.”

 

 You watch a smile creep up on his face. This time, he dares look directly at you.
 
 
 You think about how you would describe your sister. “Bookish, studious, caring, honest, shy.”

 

 Dennis grimaces, unsure what to do. “So you like school?” he asks. 

 

 “I used to,” you say. “Not so much at Charlton.” 

 

 “I don’t like it, either,” he says. “I can’t wait to leave.”

 

 “One more year to go,” you add. 

 

 Dennis smiles sympathetically. You feel a shared sense of camaraderie over your feelings about school, but there’s nothing romantic or sensual about the bond. Dennis looks away, surveying the coffee shop, and you can see the desperation and disappointment in his face about how the conversation is going.

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 
 
 
 
 The two of you are interrupted by Florence, who puts down a platter with the bill on. Without hesitating, Dennis takes out his wallet and puts some cash down, leaving Florence a decent tip.

 

 The two of you stand, Dennis putting on his coat, you taking your purse, and you both walk towards the coffee shop door. Continuing his chivalrous behaviour, Dennis opens the door for you. 

 

 You take a step into the street, feeling the cold temperature of the night hit you. Dennis walks out behind you, and you stand looking at each other, a nervous tension in the air.

 

 “Thank you for the dinner,” you say to Dennis. “I had a nice time.”

 

 
 “So did I!” he says. You watch him smile, his eyes slyly wandering over you. “Would you like to do this again? Another date, I mean?”

 

 “Maybe,” you tell him, smiling. You can’t help but notice how the nervous boy has warmed to you, exuding a quiet confidence with your encouragement over the evening.

 

 “How about a movie night?” he says. “You could pick out a film from the AV library and we could watch it at my house.”
 
 

 
 
 “I’m sure there would be something in there that would take my fancy,” you reply, hoping to steer the conversation back to the key. *That’s why you came on this date. Isn’t it?*

 

 He takes the hint and reaches into his coat, taking out a small brass key. “Oh yes.” Taking a step towards you, he offers it to you. “Here you go.”

 

 Dennis stands close to you, his hand out offering you the key. You look down on it and note the Charlton crest etched on it. Gently, you take it from him.
 
 
 
 

 "And the pass?" you ask, reminding him.

 

 Dennis nods eagerly and smiles nervously. “I'll also speak to Harrow. I'm sure I can convince him to get you a pass.”

 

 You offer him a smile, feeling a pain at embarrassment about how transactional this date feels. “Thank you,” you murmur.
 
 
 
 “I’m sure there would be something in there that would take my fancy,” you reply, hoping to steer the conversation back to the pass. *That’s why you came on this date. Isn’t it?*

 

 He takes the hint and smiles nervously. “I'll also speak to Harrow. I'm sure I can convince him to get you a pass.”

 

 You offer him a smile, feeling a pain at embarrassment about how transactional this date feels. "Thank you."
 
 
 

 “I really had a great time tonight,” he says quietly. And without warning, he leans in to kiss you. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 “I had a nice time too!” he replies, glancing up at you. “Would you… like to do this again sometime?”

 

 You smile at his nervous attempts to ask you on another date. “Maybe,” you reply.

 

 “We could watch a movie together?” he says, taking your words with encouragement. “Maybe over at my house?” 

 

 “Let’s see,” you tell him, not wanting to commit Emily to something that she may not want to do. Or you, if you were to take Emily’s place again. “Maybe I could pick a movie and see if there’s something I’d like?”

 

 
 
 Dennis nods eagerly and, remembering your deal, reaches into his coat and takes out a small brass key. “You can look through the cupboard, if you like. Pick anything you like. I’d love to watch something with you.”

 

 He hands you the key. You note the crest of Charlton etched into it. “I’ll see what I can find,” you murmur.
 
 

 “Anything!” Dennis continues. “Anything you like!”

 

 
 
 "And the pass?" you ask, reminding him.

 

 Dennis nods eagerly and smiles nervously. “I'll also speak to Harrow. I'm sure I can convince him to get you a pass.”

 

 You offer him a smile, feeling a pain at embarrassment about how transactional this date feels. “Thank you," you murmur.
 
 

 
 You put the key into your purse and give Dennis a smile. “Well. It’s getting late. I better get home.”

 
 Dennis nods eagerly and smiles nervously. “I'll also speak to Harrow. I'm sure I can convince him to get you a pass.”

 

 You offer him a smile, feeling a pain at embarrassment about how transactional this date feels. “Thank you. And I’ll see what I can find,” you murmur.
 
 

 “Anything!” Dennis continues. “Anything you like!”

 

 You give Dennis a smile. “Well. It’s getting late. I better get home.”

 
 

 He nods, but doesn’t move. As if he’s waiting for something. *A kiss, maybe?*

 

 “Goodnight Dennis,” you tell him, gently. 

 

 His mouth flinches, but he nods again. “Goodnight, Emily. I’ll see you soon?” 

 

 You titter. “We’ll see.” 

 

 It’s enough to bring a beaming grin to his face. As he walks off, you notice a spring in his step. You watch him go, leaving you alone with only the sounds of pigeons in the trees to keep you company.

 “Did you?” Dennis snaps back, a little frustration in his voice. “Or did you just want a hall pass?” 

 
 

 He looks up at you and you can see he’s shaking a little. “You didn’t really want to go on a date with me, did you?”

 

 “Dennis…” you begin. But you trail off, unsure what to say.

 

 “If you didn’t want to be here, you could have just said,” he continues. He sighs and lets out a bit of his frustration. You can tell he’s hurt by your lack of effort. “I thought, maybe, there was a chance you liked me.”

 

 He looks at the floor, not meeting your eye line. Consoling a boy who likes you but you have no interest in is not something you’ve had much experience dealing with.

 

 “I’ve got to go,” he says, finally. “Goodnight Emily.”

 

 
 
 “What about the key?” you blurt out.

 
 “What about the pass?” you blurt out.

 
 

 He looks up at you. “I’ve changed my mind.”

 

 
 
 You watch Dennis turn on his heels and walk off, leaving you alone on the quiet street outside Fresh Pot, accompanied only by the sounds of pigeons cooing in the night. It looks like you’ll have to find some other way of getting into the AV room.

 You feel his lips meet yours. Awkward, nervous, but present. A boy’s lips against your own. And you let yourself respond.

 

 Thoughts flash through your mind. *You already have what you wanted. You don’t need to do this. So why are you responding?*

 

 But you find yourself pressing your lips against his, letting your mouth lock with his. You feel a surge of butterflies in your stomach as you kiss him back. You actually want this, don’t you?

 

 You feel his hand on the back of your neck, pulling you in for an embrace as you continue to lock lips. He is tender, clumsy even, but being pulled up against him feeling your bodies touch as your mouths meet sends shocks across your frame.

 

 After some moments, he pulls back and looks at you, his eyes close to yours. You feel his arms awkwardly around your waist, holding you close to him.

 

 “We should do this again,” he says, with a quiet confidence you have rarely seen from him before.

 

 You hear yourself giggle. “I’d like that.”

 

 He smiles and plants another kiss on your lips before letting you go. “I’ll see you at school,” he says. Uncharacteristically for Dennis, it’s not a question.

 

 He grins again and waves, as he walks off, a definite spring in his step. You feel yourself smiling as you watch him go. *What was that?* 

 

 He rounds a corner into another street and leaves you alone on the pavement. You notice Flo looking out from behind the blinds of Fresh Pot. She gives you a conspiratorial smile.

 

 
 
 Only then do you remember the key in your hand. You put it away and come back to your senses, trying in vain not to let your thoughts on what just happened. A kiss. With a boy.

 
 Only then do you come back to your senses, trying in vain not to let your thoughts on what just happened. A kiss. With a boy.

 
 
 You feel his lips on yours, awkward and nervous. Instinctively you pull away, taking a step back.

 

 “I’m sorry,” Dennis stammers, looking to the floor. “I shouldn’t have done that.”

 

 You stare back at the boy in front of you, shaking with embarrassment. He looks wounded. Hurt. Scared stiff, unable to move, but as if he wants to be anywhere but here.

 

 “I should go,” he mutters. “Goodnight.”

 

 He spins around and strides off, almost jogging to get away. You watch him go. Not once does he look back.

 

 
 
 You feel the cold brass key in your hand and quickly put it away. At least you got the key. You just wonder how Dennis will react to you going forward now.

 
 You consider if Dennis will keep his word to speak to Harrow. And wonder how Dennis will react to you going forward now.

title: FreshPotTransformFlo
text:
You feel the amulet tingle underneath your clothes and let your hand move to touch Flo’s paperback. *Here we go*, you think.

 

 Flo frowns at you as you stare at her. You look her up and down, taking in her flame-red hair, her ruby red lipstick and her plucked eyebrows. You form a picture of her in your mind, dressed in her waitress uniform, her warm smile beaming. 

 

 “You okay, ?” you hear her say. 

 

 “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 The amulet burns against your chest and you feel the sensation of magical energy leaping across your body. You scream as you feel the waves rippling out from the amulet. Your scalp feels like it’s on fire and your body starts to crunch as changes sweep across it.

 

 
 Now familiar sensations register inside your brain. Your chest changes. Arms morph. Bones inside your body crunching. Your womb burns as it shifts and changes.
 
 
 Now familiar sensations register inside your brain. Chest expanding. Arms shrinking. Bones inside your body crunching. Penis burning as it shrivels back inside your body.
 
 
 

 And with a final shriek, the pain subsides. You look up, seeing Florence staring back at you in abject horror. A strand of flame-red hair falls across your eye. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You prepare for the change, but something feels off. The amulet's energy seems drained. 

 

 You curse inwardly, realising the amulet needs more time to re-charge.

 

 **Actions**

title: FreshPotTransformFlo2
text:
“Fall asleep,” you say quickly, “and let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 Florence stares at you for just a second, then drops behind the counter. You round the counter and see her passed out on the floor. Once you are satisfied she’s taken no injuries from her sudden fall, you look up in the mirrored glass behind the counter to see your reflection.

 

 The perfectly made-up face of Florence looks back at you. Her bushy flame-red hair. Her luscious red lips. Her finely plucked eyebrows.

 

 You become aware of the waitress uniform you are wearing. The hem of her skirt brushing against the bottom of your bum. Her blue blouse tight, hugging your curves. Breasts held firmly in place by a bra. The squeeze of her feet in the glossy red heels.

 

 You smile to yourself, feeling giddy. Your brain seems foggy and for a moment you completely forget why you are holding a paperback book. You feel your *intelligence* has been impacted by your most recent change.

 

 You take a moment more to acknowledge your new form before turning your attention to the pressing matter of the unconscious Florence at your feet.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 You grab Florence with both your arms and drag her through the kitchen to the back room. The lack of strength in your new form is noticeable, whilst her heels are higher than you're used to. A few times you are perilously close to losing your balance. You shudder to think what would happen if you fell and were knocked out.

 
 You grab Florence with both your arms and drag her through the kitchen to the back room. The lack of strength in your new form is noticeable, as is moving backwards in high heels. A few times you are perilously close to losing your balance. You shudder to think what would happen if you fell and were knocked out.

 
 

 The back room is little bigger than a closet, barely able to contain the small desk covered in paperwork. With little choice, you prop Florence up in the desk chair, trying to make her as comfortable in her deep sleep as you can.

 

 In her slumber she looks peaceful and innocent. Angelic, even. Her skirt rides up a little as you position her, exposing the top of her bare thigh. Far from aroused, it just calls attention to the fact that it’s the same outfit you currently wear. 

 

 
 
 From outside the room the bell rings out, taking you away from your thoughts. Someone has entered the coffee shop.

 

 **Actions**

title: StaceyBritneyFreshPot
text:
You quietly slide into the booth behind Stacey and Britney in an attempt to listen to their conversation, but as soon as you sit down they fall silent and shoot you a look. It appears that if you want to listen into their conversation, you’ll need to be less conspicuous.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Britney and Stacey see you approach. Stacey is cautious, but Britney smiles. She welcomes you to sit down with them.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 Stacey and Britney sit tucked into their usual corner booth, half-finished frappes sweating on the table. You move past them slowly, clearing cups, cloth in hand. They don’t notice. Or don’t care.

 

 “I swear he’s doing it on purpose,” Stacey mutters, arms folded tight. “He’s shutting down again.”

 

 Britney sighs, resting her chin on her palm. “He was doing so well. Then bam! Walls up. He’s not even looking at me anymore. And don’t say it’s nerves. I couldn't have been more flirty.”

 

 "How's that different to usual?” Stacey quips. Britney scowls at her.

 

 “Whatever," she replies. "Chrissie’s not happy. That's what matters. She said that if I couldn't bring a boy around, what value did I have?"

 

 Stacey grimaces. "It's got something to do with that book. I know it."

 

 "That biology one?" Britney bites her lip. "You think he’s choosing diagrams over me?"

 

 "No doofus," Stacey snaps. "I’ve seen him reading it during lunch. It's full of notes. He's been different since he's been reading it."

 
 
 Britney sighs. “So why don't we pick his locker? He doesn't take it everywhere.”

 

 "You know how to pick a locker?" Stacey says, raising her eyebrows.

 

 "People do it on TV all the time!" Britney bites back.

 

 "Well, if you manage to learn how to use a hairpin to pick a lock, let me know," Stacey says, rolling her eyes.

 

 "We could... ask that janitor for a key?" Britney offers.

 

 Stacey gives her a dark look. "I am not going back to that basement. Not after last time.”

 

 Britney exhales, frustrated. “We’ve got to get it. Whatever’s in that book, it's changing him. And not in the way Chrissie wants.”

 

 They lapse into silence, and you slip away with the tray.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 Stacey and Britney pay no attention to you as you move around them, collecting used coffee cups and wiping down tables. They continue their conversation and you listen in as they whisper.

 

 “It’s just so unfair,” Britney laments, her button nose flaring. “Christina should quit being so picky and just get someone to replace Tandi.”

 

 Stacey rolls her eyes. “Someone has to do it. Chrissie will kill us if Jackie starts making lunch that hasn’t been cursed. Or worse. You don’t want to end up like Tandi, do you?”

 

 Britney twizzles a strand of her curly blonde hair, looking to see she has split ends. “It’s just… every morning! I have to get up at, like, eight o’clock to make it in time.”

 

 “Quit whining!” Stacey barks back. “Do you know how hard it was to get the key to the kitchen? Do you want to know what the janitor made me do for it in that basement of his?”

 

 Britney frowns and baulks her head. She motions a blowjob with hand. 

 

 “Jesus, Brit!” Stacey snaps. “I meant… posing for photos.”

 

 “Oh!” Britney replies. “Olaf’s such a perv.”

 <>
 <>
 
 
 
 
 Stacey looks around the cafe once more, then reaches into her bag. Reaches down further. Further still. Finally scrambling around in her handbag.

 

 "It's gone!" she whispers to Britney, eyes wide.

 

 "What do you mean, it's gone?" Britney asks, her own eyes widening.

 

 Stacey visibly gulps. The two cheerleaders stare at each other, for once, in silence.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 Stacey looks around the cafe once more, then reaches into her bag and slides a key across the table to Britney. “It’s your turn,” she tells her. “Make sure it gets done.”

 

 
 
 You glance at the key. You can’t be sure, but you would bet money that it opens the cafeteria kitchen at school.
 
 

 You look around. Apart from Stacey and Britney, the cafe is now empty. If you wanted to steal it, you could use your magic without suspicion.

 

 **Actions**
