title: FreshPotFloWork
text:
The morning shift at Fresh Pot is quiet. The windows are still misted from the early air, and the soft rattle of the espresso machine hums beneath the low murmur of conversation. You glance around the café and sigh, stepping into Florence’s routine. Wiping down surfaces. Replacing bakery stock. Folding napkins just so. You try to mimic the easy efficiency you've seen from her on your rare visits.

 

 Then the door creaks open… and Andrea walks in. You almost don’t recognise her at first.

 

 Gone is the lacy French Maid uniform that Charlton Hotel insists on. Instead, she’s wearing a simple cardigan and jeans. Her hair tied back loosely. It's the first time you’ve seen her dressed out of costume. For a moment, that feels more disorienting than the uniform ever did.

 

 She gives you a glance - soft, tired - and heads straight for one of the booths near the back.

 

 You wipe your hands, glance toward the empty counter, and cross the floor. “Hey,” you say gently. “You alright?”

 

 Andrea shrugs. She tries to play it off with a small exhale through her nose, but the slump in her shoulders tells you everything. “Didn’t sleep,” she mutters. “Lennox kept me late. Had me redoing the same load of linen three times. Then he asked if I’d ‘ironed the bows’ on my apron before I left.”

 

 You raise an eyebrow. She gives a hollow smirk. “I didn’t know I was supposed to. Guess I’ll add that to the list.”

 

 You sit across from her as she stares at the table. “And Sermon... he’s been watching me more. Following me with his eyes.”

 

 There’s a pause. She doesn’t look up. “He used to do the same with Amber. Before she quit. And we all know where she ended up.”

 

 Your stomach twists. You’re not sure who Amber is, or where she ended up. But you bet it isn’t good.

 

 The bell over the door rings again. Customers. The line at the counter is starting to build. You know you won’t earn tips unless you’re behind it, smiling sweetly and handing over cappuccinos with perfect froth. But Andrea looks like she’s barely holding herself together.

 
 The morning rush hasn’t started yet. You’ve just finished stacking croissants in the display case when the door creaks open and Andrea walks in. Like clockwork. She makes her way to the booth by the window, shoulders hunched.

 
 
 “Morning, Flo,” she says, flatly, as you approach. Her voice is tired.

 

 You slide into the seat across from her. “Rough night?”

 

 Andrea scoffs softly. “Define rough.”

 

 Another customer enters. The kettle behind the counter whistles.

 

 Andrea glances out the window like she’s somewhere else. But she came here again. To talk. To sit. To feel safe. Even if only for a few minutes.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 
 Lunchtime at Fresh Pot isn’t quiet. It’s controlled chaos, and that control is fraying by the second. Office workers pile in with tired eyes and clipped voices. Retail girls gossip at the counter while tradesmen bark orders across the queue. You wipe a streak of syrup from your arm and try to remember how many sugars that last order had.

 

 Whilst serving, you move around the counter to waitress at the tables. One patron subtly tries to get your attention with a hand raised casually at you.

 
 
 Notebook open. Pen positioned neatly by the side. You recognise him from his profile picture in the local paper immediately. Owen Oakwood. Reporter for the Charlton Gazette.

 
 
 You approach cautiously, order pad in hand. “Afternoon,” you say.

 

 He looks up, eyes cutting through the lenses of his black rimmed glasses. A smile blooms, false and pristine. “Well now,” he says, voice syrup-smooth. “If it isn’t Fresh Pot’s very own example of feminine fortitude.”

 

 You blink. “Excuse me?”

 

 He gestures vaguely at you, pen still in hand. “Hardworking. Presentable. Composed. A model for the younger generation of Charlton.”

 

 He doesn’t wait for a reply. “I’ll take a grilled chicken panini. And a black coffee, naturally. None of that almond milk nonsense. Can’t imagine who introduced that sort of thing around here.”

 

 You smile politely, without comment. “One second,” you tell him.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 Lunchtime is a busy period for Fresh Pot. Office and retail workers from the Charlton flood in on their lunch breaks, frantic to eat something before returning to work. Meanwhile, tradesmen pull up and dash in to grab something between jobs.

 

 Owen Oakwood is already at his booth as the rush comes in. Notebook out. Coffee half-sipped. He’s been writing, waiting, watching. When you approach with his usual order, he doesn’t even look up. “Florence,” he says casually. “Still working hard, I see. Still resisting the inevitable, I assume? How’s that reading come along?”

 

 You smile thinly. “Okay. When the job gives me quiet time.”

 

 He looks up now, glasses flashing. “Ah, priorities. This town runs on young women like you. Pleasant. Pretty. Perfect.” His fingers tap the rim of his coffee cup. “We all have a place. And yours should be in a home, don’t you agree?”

 
 
 You say nothing. Your jaw is tight. But you see the notes he’s left on the table. Just within reach. Of you. And him.

 

 Behind you, you hear another giggle. You look back briefly to Stacey and Britney. They whisper conspiratorially between themselves. 
 
 

 **Actions**

 
 
 [Old Fashioned Values] <>

 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 <>
 
 <>
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 The lunch rush has faded into silence, and with it, most of your energy. You move slowly behind the counter, wiping down trays and resetting sugar bowls. Your feet are aching from the heels. At this point, you’d give anything for a moment off them, but Ron keeps drifting in and out of the back room like a spectre. Watching. Checking.

 

 Just as you think you might get a breather, the bell above the door rings. Two women step in, framed by light from the street. Pristine. Perfect. Powerful in that quiet Charlton way. Hazel Evans and Jeanette Thompson. You recognise them both instantly.

 

 Hazel is Christina’s mother, poised and polished in a pale blouse and gold bracelets. Jeanette is the wife of Mr. Thompson, sharp-eyed and immaculately coiffed, her pearls resting neatly at the hollow of her throat.

 

 Shopping bags dangle from their wrists. The smell of department store perfume follows them like a mist. “Honestly,” Hazel is saying, “I’ve told Terry again and again. The girls want refined silhouettes. Dresses with structure. Not all this… form fitting nonsense.”

 

 Jeanette gives a disapproving sniff. “Logain took a girl out last week. Britney Hudson. She turned up in a skirt that was practically a belt.”

 

 “Ah, Britney,” Hazel drawls. “She’s lucky she comes from money. If she didn’t, well… let’s just say I’d be surprised if she ended up anywhere respectable.”

 

 They both laugh softly, conspiratorially, like they’re sharing a joke only they understand.

 

 You approach the counter as they reach it, and Hazel leans in with a flawless smile.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 The afternoons at Fresh Pot always follow the same rhythm. Silence. Cleaning. Ron’s occasional peeking. And then the door opens. Hazel Evans and Jeanette Thompson.

 

 Shopping bags. Tennis skirts. Voices already halfway through a conversation.

 
 
 “...and I told Terry, if we can’t trust the girls in fitting rooms not to stretch the fabric, we need to stop stocking elastane.”

 

 You nod at them politely as they approach the counter. “Two almond croissants,” Hazel says, like it’s already been rehearsed.

 

 “Light roast coffee,” Jeanette adds.

 

 They pay with a twenty. Again. And before you’ve even finished counting out the change, Hazel is peering into your palm with narrowed eyes. “Oh dear, I think we’ve had this little mistake before.”

 

 “Ron never has these problems,” Jeanette murmurs.

 

 Hazel smiles sweetly. “Now, Flo. Two big coins. One small one. Let’s not make it harder than it needs to be.”

 
 
 **Actions**

 
 
 
 
 [Ditzy] <> - Try as you might, you just can't seem to think straight

 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [Citizen Charlton] <> - You can't muster up the courage to challenge them

 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 
 [Citizen Charlton] Argue with them - For some reason you can't bring yourself to argue with them

 
 <>
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 The evening shift at Fresh Pot has a different rhythm. Slower, quieter. The lunch crowd’s long gone, replaced by couples on casual dates, lonely souls with lattes, and a few regulars decompressing after work. You find yourself weaving between tables, tray in hand, smile at the ready.

 

 You catch a few sideways glances from other girls. Not glares exactly, but close. Their dates, meanwhile, seem a little too eager to thank you for their orders. You’re starting to see a pattern.

 
 
 Then you spot them near the back window: Brendan, a quarterback from school, slouched in his seat with the permanent smirk of someone who thinks charm is a personality trait. And Chantelle, Charlton Academy’s queen of eye-rolls and perpetual exasperation.

 

 You approach to take their order, and Brendan immediately lights up. Too bright, too quick. “Evening,” he says, voice dripping with the kind of flirtation you’ve seen used on a dozen other girls. “Didn’t think Fresh Pot came with such… refined service.”

 

 You smile tightly. Chantelle groans audibly.

 

 They place their order. Mocha for her, flat white for him. And you walk off.

 

 From behind the counter, you can still hear them. Chantelle’s voice, low and annoyed: “You’ve been staring at her this whole time. Just like with Emily Phillips.”

 

 Brendan laughs it off. “You know I’m just being nice. Come on. It’s harmless.”

 

 But his eyes flick back to you. More than once. When Chantelle heads to the bathroom, you bring over the bill. Brendan is all smiles again. “You know,” he says, leaning just a bit too far over the table, “if the coffee came with a smile like yours every time, I’d be here every night.”

 

 He stares back at you, his grin a dare.

 
 The dinner crowd at Fresh Pot always has a few familiar faces. And a few too many familiar flirty glances.

 

 You catch sight of Brendan and Chantelle again, tucked into their usual booth. She’s got her arms crossed. He’s got that grin. You don’t need to hear the conversation to guess how it’s going. But you do anyway.

 

 “You were looking at her again,” Chantelle snaps, cutting into her salad. “Like with Emily.”

 
 
 Brendan shrugs. “What? I was just being friendly.”

 

 You bring over their drinks, and Brendan gives you a smile that says he hasn’t learned a thing. When Chantelle excuses herself, you return with the bill. Brendan’s eyes follow you as you approach.

 

 “You know,” he says again, “if they ever need someone to taste test your lattes, I volunteer. Or if you’re off shift, maybe we compare notes.”

 

 Same smile. Same tone. Same expectation.

 
 

 **Actions**

 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 [Boy Crazy] Be professional - You find yourself drawn to his attention

 
 <>
 
 
 <>
 
 
 As the day draws to a close, you usher the final customers out the door at closing time. You make some assumptions on how to close up, mopping down the floor and wiping down the booths. 

 

 Then finally, you go into the back room and check on Flo. She still sleeps soundly in the chair. Happy that she'll wake up soon, you lock up and leave the shop for the night.

title: FreshPotWorkResponses
text:
You glance back at the growing line of customers… then sit.

 

 Andrea doesn’t speak right away. She just lets out a breath and leans her head in her hand, fingers rubbing at her temple. “I know I need the job,” she murmurs eventually. “It’s not that I’m… ungrateful. It’s just…”

 
 
 She trails off, staring at the tabletop like it might have the answers.

 

 “I keep thinking about us. Back at school. You remember? Always thinking things would work out. The teachers were full-on. Sure. But I thought that was the worst of it. Turns out the real world’s just… slower to understand. But meaner. More humiliating. Is this really all there was waiting for us on the other side?”

 

 Your eyes flick towards the counter. The queue is creeping towards the door. A number of impatient customers give you dirty looks. But you turn back to the young woman opposite you. She exhales again, steadier now.

 

 “Sorry. Didn’t mean to dump all that on you. I just needed to sit for a second.”

 

 Before you can respond, a voice snaps from the counter. “What do you have to do to get a coffee around here?”

 

 Andrea rises, gathering her bag. “I should go. Thanks for listening, Flo.”

 

 She slips out the door. Shoulders still heavy, but maybe a little less.

 

 You turn, apologising with a smile as you move around the counter to serve the irritated customers. They barely acknowledge your efforts and tips are not forthcoming. But you feel that, at least, you’ve made Andrea’s day a little better.

 
 You sit beside her, trying to ignore the queue forming. She tells you a little more about her evening. About Lennox. And Pierre. On the surface, she is doing what you’d expect from a maid. Cleaning. Washing. Helping out in the kitchen. But the tone from the rest of the staff. You can’t imagine it is easy at all.

 

 A number of hisses and tuts come from the side, as customers increasingly look at you expecting services. Andrea smiles sweetly, but doesn’t talk much more. When she gets up, she thanks you, as always. And leaves.

 

 Then it’s back to the counter. Cold stares. No tips. But… Andrea seemed steadier.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 
 
 You glance at the growing line. “Shall we talk later?” you say gently. “The morning rush is starting. This is important, and I don’t want to brush you off, but…”

 

 Andrea nods quickly, waving it off. “No. No, I get it. You’ve got customers.”

 

 She stands, adjusting her coat. “Besides… Lennox is probably already thinking up some new fresh hell to torture me with.”

 

 She tries to smile. It doesn’t stick.

 

 You watch her slip out the door. Then turn to the counter. Smiling. Laughing. Taking orders. Letting your voice bubble into sweetness. The tips are good. Especially from the older men. But your thoughts wander. Andrea just wanted someone to talk to. And you couldn’t give her that.

 
 Andrea gives you a hopeful look. You smile, but shake your head toward the counter.

 

 She nods, doesn’t argue. “Another time?”

 

 “Another time,” you say, trying to enforce a sincerity that you know you can’t guarantee. Would Flo really brush off her friend like this?

 

 But before you can act on any second thought, she’s gone.

 

 You turn back to the line, putting on your best fake smile. The men grin at you and the women are polite with their appreciation. The coins clink generously into the tip jar and before you know it, the morning rush is gone.

 

 But Andrea’s presence still lingers.

 
 

 **Actions**

 You nod and move quickly to the kitchen, returning moments later with his order.

 

 He sets his pen down again, steeples his fingers, and watches you like you’ve taken a seat in an interview chair. “Florence, isn’t it?”

 

 You hesitate. “Sure.”

 

 “I must say,” he begins, “I admire a young woman with a sense of duty. That apron suits you. Just the right amount of… modesty.”

 

 A youthful giggle interrupts your attention. You look back over to the back of the shop, where Britney and Stacey are laughing over pastries and gossiping.

 

 “All energy and rebellion,” he muses. “But even they will grow to know how girls should act publicly in time. Charlton has a way of instilling proper behaviour.”

 

 

 He sips his coffee. “Tell me, how’s the reading coming along? I’ve heard whispers you’ve been brushing up on your literacy.”

 

 You nod faintly.

 

 He smiles. “But surely you’ve realised by now, some things are simply beyond a woman’s grasp. Too much thinking, and suddenly the cake doesn’t rise. The laundry goes cold.”

 

 You can’t help it. Your eyes narrow. He sees.

 

 “Oh, don’t be cross. You’re quite good at this, you know,” he says, gesturing with a hand to the coffee shop. All the right instincts. You’ll make some lucky man a perfect little homemaker one day.”

 

 He tilts his head. “Don’t you agree? A woman’s place… is naturally in the home.”

 

 You want to say something. To wipe the smile off his face. But the tip he’s already placed on the table is folded, thick, and generous.

 

 Behind you, you hear another giggle. You look back briefly to Stacey and Britney. They whisper conspiratorially between themselves.

 Owen beams, as if he’s just confirmed something he’s always known. “There it is,” he says, voice warm with approval. “Knew you had your head on straight. You’re a beacon, Florence. A real light for the young women in Charlton to follow.”

 

 He reaches into his coat and pulls out a few extra folded notes sliding them onto the table with a practiced elegance. “Put that towards a pretty dress,” he says. “Time to start thinking about bagging yourself a man. Clock’s ticking, after all.”

 You don’t quite remember deciding to say it. But you did.

 For a moment, he seems to lose his place entirely. His eyes flicking up to yours, then quickly down to the notes in front of him, then back up again. A cough. A polite clearing of the throat.

 

 “Well, now," he says, adjusting his glasses unnecessarily. “That’s quite the… charming notion.”

 

 You watch his fingers tap the edge of the table, then reach into the inside pocket of his jacket. He produces another folded note - generous in size - and slides it toward you.

 

 “For your trouble,” he says. “Maybe towards a perfume. Perhaps something floral. Light. The kind of scent that lingers, ever so gracefully.”

 

 His words are still wrapped in practiced polish, but his ears are definitely pink. “Charlton needs more girls like you, Florence. Steady. Well-mannered. Delightful.”

 

 You smile. And leave him to his blushing.

 His smile is tight, but there’s a faint twitch at the corner of his mouth that suggests he’s more affected than he lets on.

 Jeanette nods. “Ron always gives us a little discount. And this isn’t even the correct amount from a twenty.”

 

 They lean over the counter together, inspecting the coins like you’re handing them puzzle pieces. Hazel counts deliberately, speaking slowly. “Two of the big coins, Flo. And one of the small ones. Surely that isn’t too tricky.”

 

 You freeze. You’re sure you counted it right.

 You glance down at the coins in your hand, your eyes narrowing as you mentally retrace the bill, the prices, and what you handed over. It all adds up. You know it does.

 

 “I’m sorry,” you say gently. “But I think the total was £12.60, and I gave you £7.40 in change from the twenty. That’s two pound coins, a fifty, a twenty, and a ten.”

 

 You pause. “That’s correct, isn’t it?”

 

 Hazel tilts her head, examining the coins again. Jeanette frowns. There’s a silence that stretches a little too long. Then Hazel gives a small, polite smile - tight at the edges. “Ah. So it is. My mistake.”

 They don’t apologise. But when you return to clear the table later, you find a folded five tucked discreetly beneath a napkin.

 Jeanette picks up a twenty-pence piece like it’s been fished out of a drain. “This one’s barely got the Queen left on it. Are you sure this is still legal tender, love?”

 

 You try to protest, but the math is slipping through your fingers like steam. You know you were right when you counted. But now all the coins feel suspicious. Are the fifties even bigger than the pounds? Why are the twos so sneaky?

 

 “I just thought --”

 

 “Well that’s the problem, isn’t it?” Hazel says, placing the coins back on the saucer with theatrical delicacy. “You thought.”

 

 They take their coffees with a huff of polite disappointment. You watch them go, sure of one thing: you were definitely right. You just couldn’t prove it under pressure. Or coin scrutiny.

 

 **Actions**

 You clear your throat and try to keep your voice measured. “I understand Ron may have offered a discount before,” you say carefully, “but there’s no formal policy for that. And the change I gave is correct, based on the current prices.”

 

 Hazel narrows her eyes slightly. Jeanette blinks like you’ve just told her she was banned from the country club. There’s a long pause. Then Hazel exhales. “Well. If that’s how things are now.”

 

 They take their drinks without further complaint. Hazel even drops a coin into the tip jar.

 

 You smile politely, heart pounding just a little. You held your ground. And survived.

 

 **Actions**

 You try to match their tone, firm but not rude. “I’m not sure what arrangement you had with Ron,” you begin, “but Fresh Pot doesn’t actually offer a discount policy --”

 

 Hazel’s face pinches. “Excuse me?”

 

 Jeanette sets her croissant down like it’s poisoned. “Ron always gives us a little something. It’s good manners. Maybe you could learn a bit of that, dear.”

 

 You try again. “I’m just saying --”

 

 “Oh no, no need to say anything,” Hazel cuts in sweetly. “Maybe we’ll just have a chat with Ron about his waitress’s attitude. Customer service matters, especially when you’re wearing the apron of Fresh Pot.”

 
 
 Jeanette gives you a tight, insincere smile as they stand. You watch them go, resisting the urge to bite your tongue clean through. No tip. Just a promise of an uncomfortable conversation later.

 

 **Actions**

 You try to stay polite. Really, you do. But something about the way Hazel says “big coins” like you’ve never seen money before just… snaps something.

 

 “I gave you the correct change,” you say flatly. “There is no discount. And honestly, maybe if you spent less time critiquing women under thirty and more time checking receipts --”

 

 Hazel gasps. Jeanette’s eyebrows shoot up like she’s just witnessed a public scandal.

 

 “Well!” Hazel huffs, collecting her purse like it personally offended her. “I see Ron’s lowered the hiring standards. I’ll be sure to mention that next time we’re at the country club.”

 

 Jeanette mutters something about “young people these days” as they storm out, heels clacking dramatically.

 

 No tip.

 

 Just two perfectly powdered storms in teacups, vanishing out the door.

 You pause… then quietly take the coins back and count out the “correct” change as Hazel described. Two big coins. One little one.

 

 She smiles, triumphant. Jeanette gives you a warm pat on the hand like you've just solved your first jigsaw puzzle. “See? That wasn’t so hard,” Hazel says sweetly. “Always good to trust those who know better.”

 

 They take their croissants and saunter off to the booth by the window, dropping a tip in the jar as they go. You force a smile. But even after they’re seated, the words echo in your skull.

 

 Two of the big coins. One of the small ones.

 

 You stare at the till. You were sure that was the right change before. Weren’t you?

 You let a smile tug at your lips, just enough. He’s grinning like a kid who thinks he’s smooth, and, well, he is kinda cute, in that try-hard, Charlton-boy way.

 

 You lean in slightly, setting the bill down with a flutter of your lashes. “Careful,” you say lightly, “keep talking like that and I might think you actually like the company more than the coffee.”

 

 Brendan blinks, caught off guard for just a second. Then he laughs, a little too loud, and his chest puffs up like he’s just won a prize.

 

 “Oh, I definitely know what I like,” he says. “And I tip what I like, too.”

 

 He slips a folded note onto the tray. More than generous.

 

 You walk away with a polite smile and his eyes trailing after you. From the corner of your vision, you see Chantelle returning from the bathroom. She’s not smiling.

 You try. Really, you do.

 

 You soften your voice, tilt your head, and reach for something flirtatious. But what comes out is more awkward than alluring.

 

 “I mean… maybe someone like you could, uh, give me… pointers? About good company. Or something.”

 

 Brendan grins. “That so?” he says, amused. “Well, hey, points for effort. You’re cute when you try.”

 

 He still drops a bill onto the tray. Less than he would’ve, but not nothing.

 

 You catch a glimpse of yourself in the coffee machine’s reflection as you head back to the counter.

 

 Not your finest moment. But at least your tip jar’s a little fuller.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You approach the situation with practiced calm, placing the bill between the salt and pepper shakers without so much as a glance.

 

 Brendan leans back in his seat slightly, clearly waiting for a look, a smile, something.

 

 You offer none.

 

 “Aw, come on,” he mutters, grin slipping. “Not even a thank you?”

 

 You smile politely. “Enjoy the rest of your evening.”

 

 Then you turn and walk away.

 

 When you circle back to clear the table later, the bill is gone. So is the tip.

 

 Figures.

 

 Still, you feel better for not playing along. That kind of attention? It’s not worth chasing.

 

 Even if your purse feels a little lighter for it.

 You approach with the bill and don’t say a word at first. Just let your body do the talking.

 Brendan exhales through his nose, like he’s trying to stay cool. “Y’know,” he says, “they don’t serve this kind of charm at the school cafeteria.”

 

 You don’t answer. Just tilt your head, give him the ghost of a wink, and straighten back up. He reaches for his wallet and slips a note under the bill. More than you’d expected. Not as much as he might have, but enough to feel like a win.

 

 Just as you’re turning away, Chantelle returns. She sits, notices your position, then glances at Brendan. Still watching you with a grin.

 

 “Oh,” she says, tone flat, scowling at you. “So it’s that the kind of service you offer here now, huh?”

 

 You don’t answer. You just walk back to the counter. But the comment stays with you. He’s a senior. You’ve seen him at school. This isn’t playful back-and-forth. This wasn’t clever wordplay. This was your body, leaning into something you’re not sure you meant to offer.

 

 *And it was just for tips… right?*

title: FreshPotWorkEvents
text:
With a cursory glance around the cafe, you sigh and get to work. You spend your time preparing take-away food and wiping down counters, trying to mimic some of the things you’ve seen Flo do when you’ve swung by for coffee.

 

 
 Walking around the cafe, you adjust to working in such high heels. On more than one occasion you almost slip, but thankfully there’s always a table or countertop for you to grasp on to. It never ceases to make customers chuckle when you stumble. 

 
 Walking around the cafe, you slowly adjust to working in heels. On more than one occasion you almost slip, but thankfully there’s always a table or countertop for you to grasp on to. It never ceases to make customers chuckle when you stumble. 

 
 

 In fact, there’s a lot that you do that make customers react. Without exception everyone treats you as an old friend. You find yourself returning their smiles and laughing at their jokes. Especially when you receive tips for your efforts.

 

 It does not go unnoticed how men and women treat you differently. Women are polite and chatty, but the men in their different ways are flirtatious and voyeuristic. You feel their eyes on your legs as you saunter around the coffee shop. You see them staring at your breasts as you lean over to serve them. 

 

 One particularly flirty customer is Dan, from Thompson’s Repairs. You inwardly sigh when you see him walk in. He smiles like a tiger when he sees you and doesn’t take his eyes off you as you prepare a coffee for him.

 

 “Damn fine cup of coffee” he says as you bring a coffee to his booth. As he reaches into his wallet to pay, you catch him looking you up and down. “Although with legs like those, I’d drink anything you served me.”

 

 You notice he is taking his time rifling through notes, counting out how much he’s going to pay you.

title: Gym
text:
**Casey's Gym**

[image: ./images/Gym.png]

Basic by any standards, Casey’s Gym is no more than a room covered in soft mats and littered with exercise gear. A full length mirror runs down one side of the room and a ballet barre runs down the entire length.

Gordon, one of the local labourers, sits at one of the weight lifting machines. His tight biceps flex as he pulls the plates high into the air, and then slowly lowers them down with control and confidence.

 
 
Casey stands in the centre of the gym, kicking gym mats together in a square. His hands are encased in blue boxing gloves, yet somehow a lit roll-up dangles on his bottom lip.

 
Casey stands behind the till, leafing through a boxing magazine. A lit roll-up hangs on his lips, which he occasionally takes a drag on.

Mrs. DeBussy stands beside the full-length mirror, clipboard clasped firmly to her chest. She wears a collared polo shirt tucked into thick black leggings, ballet slippers barely visible beneath the hem.

Jake, the school quarterback, is at the back of the gym, running through some dumbbell exercises. Jake seems to strain at the weight he's chosen, regularly just letting go of the dumbbell once he's lifted it, letting it crash to the floor.

 
 
*You watch Jake for a moment. If you really wanted to know what went on in those boys’ classes, Jake could be an option. If you could get your hands on something of his, something personal. Something to power the amulet. Getting him somewhere private wouldn't be a challenge.*

 

**Actions**

title: GymJakeDialogue0
text:
The jock’s eyes flick from the window to you, roaming your body. And yet he remains silent.

 

 “Hey Jake,” you say.

 

 “What do you want?” he spits. “Or did you decide you want to see what a real man looks like?”

 

 He stares back at you, almost daring you to say something. When you don’t reply, his eyes drift to over your shoulder. You glance back, noticing two girls watching from outside, whispering and giggling as they subtly eye Jake.

 
 
 
 The jock raises his eyebrow as you approach, his eyes flicking across your body.

 

 “Hey Jake,” you greet him.

 

 “Hey yourself, nerd,” he says, a wry smile resting on his face. His eyes drift over your shoulder for a moment, and when you glance behind you notice two girls watching from outside, whispering and giggling as they watch the jock.

 

 But when you turn back, Jake’s eyes are firmly settled on you.
 
 
 
 Jake's eyes drift up and down as you step near him. He gives you a smile that you assume he thinks is seductive. It comes across as predatory and lecherous.

 

 “Hey there,” he says to you. “Haven’t seen you around for a while.”

 

 You study him carefully, not sure of the relationship you currently have with him. “I’ve been busy,” you tell him. 

 

 He smiles, his eyes again lingering over your body. “What can I do for you, sweetheart?”

 

 Before you can reply, you hear muted girlish laughter from behind you. Turning, you see two girls watching through the window, whispering as they try to pretend they aren’t watching Jake.

 

 But when you turn back to him, you can’t help but notice his attention rests firmly with you.

 
 Jake looks at you with derision as you approach. “Yeah?” he snaps. “What are you looking at?”

 

 You are about to reply when you hear muted giggles from behind you. Turning, you note there are two girls looking into the gym from outside, whispering and eying both you and Jake with interest. 

 

 By the look of his lingering grin and drifting eyes, Jake has noticed too.

 

 Jake waits for you to speak, smirking as he looks at you. Behind, you hear the titters of the girls looking in from the street.
 
 Jake barely pays you attention, his face rising into a grin as his eyes look over your shoulder out to the girls on the pavement, who you know are watching him.
 

 
 
*As Jake looks back at you, something stands out. His low-neck workout shirt exposes the bottom of his neck, around which his dog tags are notably absent. *

title: GymDeBussyDialogue
text:
As you approach, DeBussy looks up, her face lighting with a beaming smile. “Oh! Emily. What a delight. I didn’t expect to see you here on a weekend. But then, you are one of my more proactive girls.”

 

 Her eyes drop momentarily to her clipboard before returning to yours. “Here to take part in my ballet instruction, are you?” she asks, voice syrupy. “A sharpened mind requires a graceful body, after all. And discipline is discipline, no matter the subject.”

 

 Her smile lingers, polite and practiced. “I’d be very pleased to include you. Provided, of course, you’re willing to take it seriously.”

 
 As you approach, DeBussy looks up. A polite smile forms. “Hello dear. I didn’t expect to see you, today. What brings you here?”

 

 She straightens a little, folding her arms over the clipboard. Her ballet slippers peek out beneath her leggings, though she makes no effort to draw attention to them. “Are you here to partake in my ballet lessons?” she asks when you don’t respond. “Typically I don’t encourage my students to partake. Weekends are for reflection. Quiet study. Perhaps even a little revision.”

 

 Her eyes meet yours, as if burrowing into your brain to work out your thoughts. “For you though,” she says after some time. “I will make an exception.” A thin smile forms on her lips, but she stands waiting for your answer. 

 
 
 DeBussy looks up as you approach, a smile appearing that can’t quite mask her confusion. “Good afternoon,” she murmurs. “You’re Emily’s , aren't you? What brings you here?”

 
 
 You pause before replying, a cold shiver spreading up your spine. “Yes. I’m Emily’s .”

 

 
 At this, DeBussy breaks into a smile. “Oh! She’s a bright girl! I shouldn’t say this, but between us two, she’s one of my favourites. So diligent. Observant. A sharp eye for detail. She’ll go far, with the right tutoring.”

 A nod comes from the teacher, her smile wavering slightly. “She seems like a pleasant girl. Could do with a little focus, but I can see a certain potential. There are good jobs for young ladies in Charlton if they practice their typing.”

 

 “Thank you,” you say. “I’m sure she values your teaching.”

 

 DeBussy breaks out into a smile. “Oh, that’s lovely of you to say. But if you’ll forgive me, I must return to my class. A young lady’s education doesn’t end at the school gates, thank heavens. Or was there something I can assist you with?”

 
 As you approach, DeBussy looks up. A polite smile quickly forms on her lips. “Hello dear,” she says in a crisp tone. “What a pleasant surprise. I haven’t seen you in the longest of times.”

 

 You eye DeBussy cautiously. She wears a set of ballet shoes underneath some thick black leggings that are functional but not revealing. Her collared polo shirt gives an air of superiority that only just seems appropriate in Casey’s Gym.

 

 “Are you here to partake in my ballet lessons?” she asks you. “My dedication to your moral and physical education doesn’t simply expire after graduation, you know.”

 

 You eye DeBussy cautiously. She wears a set of ballet shoes underneath some thick black leggings that are functional but not revealing. Her collared polo shirt gives an air of superiority that only just seems appropriate in Casey’s Gym. 

 

 A thin smile forms on her lips, but she stands waiting for your answer. 

 
 
 DeBussy holds the clipboard to her chest, meeting your eyes through her glasses as she waits for you to speak.

 On the next rep, you tilt your pelvis, flattening your lower back into the bench. The strain shifts, making the pull cleaner. It also means less curve, less spectacle and more stability.

 

 Jake’s eyes narrow in the mirror. “That's not what I said.” His voice tries for neutral, but there’s a sharpened edge beneath it.

 

 You don’t look at him. “Proper engagement’s about control, not arching your spine like a bow. Unless you want me to throw it out before the set’s done?”

 

 For a moment he doesn’t answer. His reflection hovers close, watching, judging. Then he exhales through his nose. “Fine. Whatever.”

 

 He takes a step back, suddenly disinterested as his smugness falters.

 

 Reps flow smoother now. You focus on the rhythm, the weight working your shoulders and chest without forcing yourself into a posture designed for someone else’s entertainment. In the mirror, you see the girls have gone quiet. Now watching you with interest.

 

 By the tenth rep your arms burn, but it’s clean. Solid. Yours.

 

 Jake crosses his arms, leaning back against the mirror with a curl in his lip. “Guess that works too,” he mutters, reluctant.

 

 You sit up slowly, catching your breath. For once, you’ve beaten him without brute force. Just by being sharper.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 Jake continues with his instructions. “Arms out. Wider. Back arched,” he says, tone steady, rehearsed. “That’s the form.”

 

 You are sure this isn't the best way to do this. In fact, you know Jake's not trying to help you. He’s focused watching the show. But you can't work out how to do this any better without emphasising your body.

 

 “That’s not how you do it,” he says sharply. “Arch. Back high. You’ll never get full extension otherwise.”

 

 You hesitate. “Feels more stable this way.”

 

 His smirk deepens. “Stable isn’t strong. Proper form means arch. Big chest. Wide spread. You want results? Do it my way.”

 

 Finally, you let out a breath and ease back into the curve he wants. Back arched, chest raised, exactly the pose he’d engineered from the start. “That’s it,” he murmurs, satisfied. His hand brushes your side, pressing you deeper into the posture. The cables tremble as you pull, your chest rising each time, your reflection performing exactly as he intended.

 

 In the mirror you see the girls outside nudge each other, smirks playing at their lips. One tilts her head with a knowing grin. They can see what this looks like, and so can you.

 

 Jake steps back only once the set is complete. He nods, smug and certain. “Better. But not good enough. Think you'll have to put in some more practice if you want to meet what I'm after.”

 

 You sit up slowly, a frown tugging at your lips. You did finish, but Jake's not admitting the victory. This display was all for nothing.

 

 Did you expect for him to play fair?

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You steady your breathing, cables taut in your hands. You already know you’re not going to finish this set. Not with Jake standing so close, his shorts brushing your hairline, his smirk heavy in the mirror. But there’s another way to get through this. An easier way.

 

 Is that how you’re justifying it?

 

 Keeping your eyes locked on his, you arch your neck just enough for your nose to brush against the fabric of his shorts. The sweat-darkened cotton carries his scent. Sharp and musky. It should be repulsive, but instead there’s a pull, an animal part of you responding to it.

 

 You glance up at him, seeing Jake’s eyes widen. But he doesn’t move back. If anything, it seems to root himself in place. You have to crane higher, lips grazing the fabric now. The outline beneath is unmistakable. The heat rising from him, the stiffness against your mouth, makes your pulse kick.

 

 Your arms sag, the cables hanging limp at your sides. You’re no longer even pretending to row. Through his legs, you see the world upside down. A humiliating picture of a girl on back, legs astride a bench, face pressed against Jake’s crotch. And through the window, the girls are watching. Wide-eyed, half-laughing, half-whispering, drinking in the display.

 

 Jake tilts his head, voice low and smug. “Maybe we should take this somewhere else.” He makes no move to end the moment himself, but he doesn’t need to. The cables swing idly from your hands, the exercise already long forgotten.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 Your voice cuts the air. “Those twenties look thicker than mine. You hiding something, Jake?”

 

 Outside the window, the girls outside lean in to look at his weights. Jake freezes and for a moment, his grin falters. Then he forces a laugh. “Huh. Must’ve been a mistake.”

 

 “Sure,” you reply. “I’ll just match, then. Fair's fair.”

 

 You glance over to the window, seeing the girls murmuring. They’re watching you now.

 

 You slide into position and take the bar. The weight feels good. Your muscles flex as you push the first rep skyward. Breathe in, brace, press. The burn is there, but it’s steady and manageable.

 

 Beside you, Jake grunts. Rep after rep, you keep pace. You quickly match his score, then push ahead. By the time you rack the bar with a final slam, you've left his effort in the dust.

 

 Outside, the girls exchange looks, then grin at you.

 

 Jake’s jaw works. “Whatever,” he mutters, too low for swagger. The bravado’s fraying.

 

 The pride hits like a rush of blood, hotter than the strain in your chest. You didn’t just out-lift him. You owned him.

 

 How does it feel? You didn’t just beat him. You made him kneel.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You grip the bar, palms slick, shoulders tight. The stack feels heavy even before you press, but Jake’s smug grin keeps you rooted.

 

 The first rep grinds upward, slow and rough. Your clench your teeth. Out of the corner of your eye you catch the girls watching intently.

 

 Heat floods your chest. You drive the bar up again. One rep. Then another. The rhythm starts to build, though every movement sends fire up your arms. Jake watches. You see his smug grin fade.

 

 “You’re fading, old man,” he says, but there's nervousness in his voice.

 

 You block it out, focus on the bar and the next rep. Your lungs burn, your shoulders scream, but you won’t quit. You force the steel upward, lockout rattling as the plates clang against each other.

 

 The final stretch is nothing but pain. Your vision blurs, sweat dripping hot into your eyes, but you bite down and push. The bar crawls upward, inch by inch, until you slam it back onto the rack with a roar. Your chest heaves, muscles trembling on the edge of collapse.

 

 Through the glass, the girls shift. They trade quick grins, impressed. The sight makes your pulse hammer harder than the weights ever could.

 

 Jake notices, too. His jaw tightens. “Alright. You got one. That was an easy weight, though.” The bravado is there, but thinner, his voice edged with frustration.

 

 You can’t help but let a grin spread across your face, even as your arms shake with exhaustion.

 

 Yes. This is what it means to be stronger. Pain is nothing when you can put someone beneath you.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 You grip the bar hard, teeth clenched, every nerve screaming that you’re not about to fold here. The first reps come heavy but steady. Shoulders straining, chest tight. You force each push with a grunt, bar trembling over you.

 

 By the tenth, your breaths come ragged. Each press shakes, your wrists scream in pain, elbows wobble under the weight. Out of the corner of your eye, you see the girls smirking through the window. They've written you off already.

 

 You press again. Halfway up, the bar quivers. Your chest burns, your arms dead. Jake's laugh echoes as he watches you.

 

 “Come on, old man,” he calls loud enough for the girls to hear. “Thought you had grit. Looks like you’re just made to spot me.”

 

 You dig in, straining, face hot. The bar stalls mid-air. No matter how you push, it won’t move. With a clatter, it drops back to the rack. You sag into the bench, chest heaving. Done.

 

 “Better luck next time,” Jake says, wiping his forehead with deliberate ease. The smugness drips from every word. "Although maybe the ballet class is more your thing."

 

 You can’t meet his eyes. Your gaze stays on the ceiling, hot with frustration.

 

 Pathetic. Maybe he's right. Maybe ballet is more suited to you.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 The weights groan as you both press. First few reps are clean and steady. Jake watches you with mild interest, but keeps looking back to window where the girls cluster.

 

 “Christina ever spot you?” you jab, keeping your voice casual. “Heard she’s stronger than you.”

 

 Jake snorts. “Just stick to your own set, old man.”

 

 You grit your teeth, raising the bar again, then let your voice rise, loud enough for the girls against the glass. “Funny, though. Don’t see your dad in here much.” You pause just long enough to draw it out. “Guess he saves the proud-dad act for Steve, huh?”

 

 Jake's attention is suddenly upon you. "What did you say?"

 

 You feel the grin crawl onto your face. Pressing through another rep, you twist the knife. “Must sting. Everyone says you’ve got your dad's temper, but none of his strength.”

 

 Jake is right above you now, looking down with fury. You briefly consider stopping, but there's something about this that brings you satisfaction. “Bet the old man wishes Steve was still in Charlton. At least then he’d have a son worth watching.”

 

 The sound Jake makes is halfway between a growl and a gasp. He lashes out to push the bar down. It lands on your chest, knocking the air out of you. "You take that back!" he snaps, pushing the bar down against your body.

 

 Casey’s voice snaps across the room. “Get that bar off him!" Out of the corner of your eye, you see him limping over.

 

 Jake glares down at you for a moment longer, then releases his grip. You immediately push the bar back up and lock it in place, gasping for air.

 

 "You alright, son?" Casey asks you, as you sit up. You nod to him, silently, looking over to Jake who stands off to the side.

 

 "I'd say he wins this one by default," Casey tells Jake. The quarterback turns to look between the two of you, his cheeks red with fury. “Whatever,” he spits.

 

 See? Find the crack. Push. Watch him break. That’s how you win.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 You step back from the final set, breath still heavy, sweat slick against your skin. Jake eyes you, his grin sharp. Through the window you see the girls are still there, smirks pressed to the pane, waiting to see who came out on top.

 

 
 For the first time Jake’s grin falters. He rolls his neck, scowling faintly as the girls’ eyes slide from him to you. Their expressions aren’t subtle. A new appraisal, one that used to be his alone.

 

 “Alright,” he mutters. “You did okay. For a girl.” He tries for a shrug, but it doesn’t hide the edge in his voice.

 

 You press him, steady. “And the bet?”

 

 His jaw tightens. For a heartbeat he looks like he might wriggle out of it. But when he glances back to the window, you see acceptance set in. “Fine. A bet’s a bet.” He jerks his thumb toward the locker room. “C’mon. Let’s settle it.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Jake looks at you with barely concealed lust. “Not sure you won,” he says, voice low. “But I think you deserve a reward, anyway.” His eyes narrow, grin returning.

 

 The way he says it is pitched just loud enough for the girls outside to catch, drawing a ripple of knowing smiles. He tips his chin toward the locker room. “Want to go somewhere private?”

 

 Through the window you see the girls watching carefully, smirking.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <> 
 
 Jake’s grin only widens, all cocky bravado. Through the window the girls’ attention swings back to him like it never left. He tosses a towel across his shoulder, flexing as though he’s already forgotten you.

 

 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “That's what you get for sitting behind a reception desk all day. All talk and no action.”

 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “A girl who couldn't hack it as a cheerleader can't handle a gym set.”
 
 
 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “You can dress up like a slut, but you don't have the moves to back it up, nerd.”
 
 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “You're more of a passive nerd than an active girl, aren't you?"

 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “Rather be playing with activewear barbie than do it yourself, hey nerd?"

 
 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “You might look like you've got the goods, but you can't back it up.”
 
 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “Don't think a gym's for you. Maybe you'd feel more at home in a dungeon."

 “Like I thought,” he crows, pitching his voice so the girls can hear. “Might want to try the ballet class, sweetheart. More suited to your tastes."

 
 
 
 The girls giggle behind the glass, smirks aimed your way before returning to their favourite spectacle - Jake. He soaks in their laughter and looks like it’s fuel.

 
 
 Actions

 <> 
 
 
 You step back from the final set, breath still heavy, sweat slick down your arms. Jake eyes you from across the room, a towel slung over one shoulder. His chest still rises steady, but there’s no mistaking the tension in the way he looks at you.
 

 
 His scowl says it all. He's not happy. Not with you, not with the way the girls on the other side of the window are watching you now instead of him. Their whispers aren’t subtle, one even hides a grin behind her palm.

 

 Jake spits to the side, jaw tight. “Wasn’t even fresh today. Football practice took it out of me last night. Be a different story if I wasn't training for a game.”

 

 You towel the sweat from your hands and step closer, voice cutting through. “That’s not how this works. We had a deal. You lost.”

 

 For a moment he doesn’t answer, the towel bunched in his fist, the muscle in his jaw twitching. Then he snorts, turning toward the locker room. “Whatever. Let’s get it over with.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Jake grins wide, planting his hands on his hips, chest still flushed from the effort. “Just as I thought. Knew you couldn’t keep up.”

 

 He doesn’t even lower his voice. “Come back when you’re ready to compete. Until then, stick to the light weights. Leave the real work to men who can handle it.”

 

 The girls outside giggle at the jab. One mimes flexing a bicep and nods toward Jake, the other shakes her head with a laugh at you.

 

 Jake wipes his palms on the towel and returns to posing in front of the mirror, pretending to go back into another set while the girls’ eyes stay fixed on him.

 
 
 Actions
 <> 
 
 
 
 You shake your head, firm enough to leave no doubt. Whatever Jake’s suggesting, you don’t want it like that.

 

 For a second his grin falters. Then the mask slips neatly back into place. He shrugs, all loose shoulders and feigned indifference. “Suit yourself,” he says, tone light. As if it doesn’t matter.

 

 He slings a towel across his shoulder, turns his back on you and raises an arm to flex. The motion’s casual, but angled perfectly toward the glass. The girls respond immediately, laughter bubbling as they lean forward, eyes sliding over his muscles. They’re already nodding, approving, as if he’s moved on from you without a second thought.

 

 The sting lands sharper for that. You made the call, but somehow it feels like you’re the one being refused.

 

 See how easily he twists it? That's how a real man gets his way. Indifference.
 
 
 Actions

 <>

choices.label: Hold your legs open and show off
Drop a dumbbell on his foot
Grind back against him to distract him
Taunt him loudly to distract him
Nuzzle your nose against Jake’s groin to distract him
Go to locker room with Jake to get your reward
Go to locker room with Jake to get your 'reward'
Go to locker room with Jake to get your reward

title: GymBoxingClass
text:
**Casey's Gym**

 [image: ./images/Gym.png]

 

 You walk back into the gym. Casey’s finished adjusting the mats and is bouncing lightly on the balls of his feet, rolling his shoulders, shifting his weight, almost dancing. It’s a little uneven, his limp catching now and then, but he moves like someone who remembers at least how it used to feel.

 

 At the sight of you, he stops. “Alright,” he says, taking one last drag from the cigarette. Then, without ceremony, he stubs it out directly on the skirting board. “You ready?”

 

 Before you can answer, he tosses a pair of gloves your way. You fumble slightly catching them, but more from the unexpected speed than the weight. Casey chuckles, but in doing so stumbles a little over his bad leg. He grunts, recovers, and says nothing.

 

 You pull on the gloves slowly, tightening each strap. As you do, your eyes flick toward the window. The boys are still there. Their breath fogs faint patches in the glass. One of them points at Casey and says something you can’t hear, but it makes the others snicker. 

 

 Casey doesn’t look, but his shoulders square just slightly as if he’s trying not to hear what he’s already heard. He steps onto the mat and gestures for you to join him. “Hands up,” he says simply. “Keep your guard tight. Stay light on your feet.”

 

 He adjusts his stance, loose and low, one glove tapping lightly at his chin.

 

 “If you’re ready, we’ll begin.”

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You step onto the mat, gloves raised. Casey starts circling you, light on his feet despite his leg. His eyes flick across your stance, watching every shift in your balance. Then, without warning, he throws a couple of slow, easy punches toward your gloves.

 

 They land with a soft thud. The technique is still sharp, but there’s no weight behind them. Not anymore.

 

 “Turn that lead foot in,” he mutters. “You’re open on the left. Chin down. Guard tight.”

 

 You adjust, and he nods. He keeps circling, throwing a few more lazy jabs. You sense he’s not trying to hit, but testing your footing. Each time, he calls something out. “Don’t step back. Pivot. Jab now. Again.”

 

 Nodding, you follow his rhythm. One-two. Then another jab. Your fist connects with his glove. Then his shoulder. Then, surprisingly, his chest.

 

 You weren’t trying to land a clean shot, but it hits harder than expected. Casey stumbles a half-step back, readjusting his stance with a grunt.

 

 Glancing towards the window, you see the boys are still there watching with glee. One of them mimics your punch and the others burst into laughter. Looking back, you see Casey’s eyes on them before catching sight of yours.

 

 He nods again, more slowly this time. “Not bad,” he mutters, rebalancing himself on his bad leg. “But you’ll need more than that to beat me.”

 

 The words are said to be challenging, but his stance says otherwise. You’re sure it wouldn’t take much at all to put him down.

 

 The gym door creaks open behind you. Glancing back, you see the boys now standing in the doorway, grinning wide. One of them steps forward. “Don’t be a sissy!” he shouts. “Finish him off!”

 

 They laugh again, and suddenly the room feels smaller. Heavier. You glance back at Casey. His hands are up. Barely. His face is blank. Waiting.

 

 Go on, show those boys what sort of man you are.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 
 You adjust your footing. Casey’s still moving, but slower now. You begin to press forward with purpose. Every time he shifts to favour his bad leg, you shift with him. Cut off his angle. Force the weight onto it.

 

 He throws another jab, but you don’t back off this time. You dip inside and deliver a clean shot to his jaw. Casey staggers. The boys snigger again.

 

 Casey grins, trying to play it off. “Careful now,” he mutters. “This is meant to be your lesson.”

 

 But you don’t answer. You glance at the doorway. They're not laughing at you anymore. They're watching with sharp eyes. Devilish smiles spurring you to continue. You look back at Casey. Something tightens in your chest. You want them to see. Be impressed by you.

 

 That’s it. Show him who’s the man here.

 

 You swing again. This time, Casey nearly folds. He catches himself on one knee, breath caught in his throat. You quickly follow-up, not waiting for him to recover. Your fist lands square against his temple. And Casey crumples.

 

 He hits the mat, hard. His gloves fall to the side and his arm lifts slightly, signalling to yield.

 

 You take deep breaths, as if inhaling the testosterone in the air. A satisfied grin spreads across your face, as you tower over the old man. Laughter erupts from the doorway. “Oof, he's done!” you hear one say. “Thought you said he was a boxer?” “Bet a girl could’ve done better!”

 

 Casey growls and throws his glove in their direction. “Scram!” he shouts, voice cracked. “Get outta here before I knock your blocks off!”

 

 The boys back off, still laughing, but they leave. The gym door swings shut behind them. Casey stays on the mat for a moment longer. Then, slowly, he stands. “You’ve got good instincts,” he says, brushing himself off. “Well done.”

 

 But his voice doesn’t match his words. He avoids your eye, instead glancing toward the window. There’s a tight, embarrassed silence hanging between you.

 

 You stand tall. Your body is thrumming with energy. Testosterone buzzes in your chest. You showed them. Showed him. This is what kind of man you are now. Charlton saw it.

 

 Even if Casey just took yet another beating, mentally and physically.

 

 Actions

 <>
 
 You could win this. You know it. He’s off-balance. Slower. And you’ve already landed the cleaner shots. A few more and he’d be on the mat. But you glance at the window. At the boys. At their wide grins and waiting sneers. You don’t want to put him through that.

 

 Taking a breath, you start to pull back. Let your guard dip just slightly. Miss the timing on a jab. You create space where none needs to be. Quickly, Casey steps into it. He lands a clean one to your ribs. Then another to your arm. The third hits harder. You grunt.

 

 Casey chuckles, breath catching a little. “Looks like you’ve still got a few things to learn,” he mutters, wiping sweat from his brow.

 

 You glance back to the window. The boys have gone quiet. Watching more closely now. A smirk flickers across one of their faces as Casey lands another punch. 

 

 *Are you really going to let yourself be shown up in front of them by a has-been?*

 

 Casey’s next punch answers that question. It lands square across your jaw. Your hearing reduces to a low buzzing, as if underwater. You stagger, hands rising too slow.

 

 Another jab. Then a hook. Casey’s on you now, the confidence returning to his movements, even if the speed never does. He’s working the angles, shifting his weight, in spite of his limp showing every time.

 

 One more punch lands and your knees give way. The mat hits you hard.

 

 From somewhere behind the ringing in your ears, the laughter starts. “Couldn’t even beat the old man!” “What a sissy!”

 

 You lie there for a moment. Not from pain, but from the shame. To his credit, Casey rounds on them. “Scram, the lot of ya!” he shouts, voice raw. “This ain’t your lesson!”

 

 The boys retreat, laughing all the way, but they leave. The gym door swings shut. You feel a glove nudge your shoulder. Casey offers a hand. “Don’t worry about them,” he says, pulling you up. “You did alright. Tried your best. Some men… just ain’t built for fighting.”

 

 He pats your back, but it’s awkward. He’s panting hard now, leg shaking slightly under the effort. With a smile, he limps toward the counter and lights another cigarette. You glance toward the window again. The boys are still out there. Gesturing. Laughing.

 

 Is this what Charlton expects of you? To prove yourself by knocking down an old man?

 

 And if so, you wonder - are you really cut out to be a man in this town?

 

 Actions

 <>

choices.label: Get changed and leave the gym
Get changed and leave the gym

title: GymBalletClass
text:
**Casey's Gym**

 [image: ./images/Gym.png]

 

 You step back into the gym and immediately recognise a few familiar faces gathered near the mirrored wall.
 
 
Florence leans against the barre, her flame red hair pulled into a high ponytail. One foot rests along the barre as she stretches, her gaze sharp.
 
 
 
Annie sits on a bench, tying her ballet slippers with a practiced rhythm. She flicks her blonde hair back through a headband, suddenly glaring when she catches the sight of you.

 
Annie sits on a bench, tying her ballet slippers with a practiced rhythm. She flicks her blonde hair back through a headband without looking up.

 
 
 

 Britney and Stacey stand side by side in front of the mirror. Britney tugs at her leotard with a grimace. “I look frumpy,” she complains, pouting.

 

 You hesitate for a moment as their eyes shift toward you. Then DeBussy steps briskly into your path, clipboard tucked under one arm.

 

 “Ah, . Just in time!” she beams. “Ladies, please line up against the mirror and we’ll begin.”

 

 You take your place among them, the mirror stretching out in front of you. Somewhere in the background, Casey lingers behind the gym counter, disinterested, barely glancing your way. But through the wide gym windows, you see the real audience. A cluster of teenage boys gathered outside, grinning, pointing and waiting.

 

 “Eyes sharp, ladies,” DeBussy calls, smiling as she walks the line. “Now. Let’s get started, shall we?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You stand in line with the other girls, your reflection stretching beside theirs in the mirror. DeBussy walks the row slowly, clipboard tucked beneath one arm, a long wooden baton now in her hand.

 

 “Ladies,” she begins, voice crisp. “Ballet is discipline. Ballet is posture. Ballet is presence.” She taps the end of the baton lightly against the floor. “When done properly, you needn’t say a word. You command a room by the way you hold your body.”

 

 She turns toward a small sound system set up by the mirror and taps a button. Classical piano begins to play. Then she turns back to you all. “First position. Let’s begin.”

 

 You fumble to copy the pose that the rest of the girls drop into naturally. Heels together, toes out, back straight. The slippers on your feet slip too easily on the polished gym floor.

 

 “Good,” DeBussy says, ignoring your slip. “Now relevé.”

 

 You rise. Not gracefully, but more than Stacey who staggers into Britney. “Hey! Watch it, Bambi!”

 

 “You’re taking up too much space,” Stacey snaps back.

 

 From across the room, DeBussy’s voice cuts cleanly. “Miss Kaplar, Miss Hudson. Less commentary. More commitment.”

 

 Both girls straighten, synchronised and sulking. Stacey glares at Britney in the mirror. Britney sticks out her tongue as a reply. 
 
 
A few spots down the mirror, Annie moves with surprising ease. Her arms raise and lower with elegance, back arched, chin high. She glances over her shoulder towards the window, flashing a smile at the boys watching.

 
Florence, by contrast, is absorbed in the steps. Her eyes never lift from her feet, and she barely reacts to the mirror at all. But there’s a faint, peaceful smile on her lips. “Very good, Miss Drew,” DeBussy comments as she passes.
 
 

 DeBussy claps once. “Demi plié,” she says. “And stretch. Reach down, ladies. Forward from the hips.”

 

 You follow the motion awkwardly, fingers extending toward the floor. The stretch tightens across your calves. Your back arches. Your bum lifts. And as you dip low, you catch sight through your own legs of the boys gathered at the window.

 

 They’re still there. Still watching. Grinning now. You feel your cheeks flush, suddenly aware of every inch of yourself. Of what you must look like and what they must be seeing.

 

 DeBussy glides past behind you, gently adjusting your arm. “This is how you hold attention,” she says softly. “With elegance. With awareness. With pride.”

 

 You try to hold the pose. Your muscles strain. The slippers slip again. Your balance wobbles. But DeBussy’s baton taps once against your bum. “Again,” she calls. Then her voice lowers to a whisper. “And remember. Assert yourself. You deserve to be looked at.”

 

 You take another breath and prepare to bend again, but your eyes catch those of one of the boys looking in through the window. He grins, directly at you. Almost daring you to resume posing. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 You take another breath and bend again, but this time, you choose how. As your fingers reach toward the floor, you fold slowly from the hips, pushing your weight back through your heels. Your rear lifts as you rise onto your toes, arching deeper into the stretch. Then you dare a glance to the window.

 

 The boys are staring. Not at your face, but eyes firmly on your bum held high into the air. Then their glance drifts to your face. Instinctively, you flash them a grin.

 

 Some part of you wishes to fight the urge, but as you rise up there’s a flutter inside your body that is difficult to ignore. You maintain eye contact with the boys through the window, noting their looks follow your every gesture and flourish. Rightly or wrongly, you are in control.

 

 DeBussy’s voice comes from next to you, whispering. “Very good. Perfect form.”

 

 You look to her, noting her warmth as she taps the barre with her baton. “Now, leg up. Let’s see a good extension through the hips. Toes pointed. Groin forward.”

 

 You obey, lifting your leg in a slow arc until your ankle rests on the barre. The stretch runs like a line of tension down your inner thigh. Your arms float outward, one hand lightly gripping the rail. The leotard pulls at the seam between your legs, tugging taut across your groin. You glance up as you lean over, meeting the boys' gaze. Their eyes don’t drift now. Instead they stay exactly where the stretch reveals the most. Your crotch.

 

 “Capture their glances,” DeBussy murmurs next to you. “Hold their attention.”

 

 Your breath catches. The boys don’t look away. A surge spreads through your body. You feel powerful.

 

 *Is this what you think of power now? To hold stares of boys with your body?*

 

 DeBussy turns back to the class, nodding in approval. “Final position, please. Arms back. Chest high. Show pride in your poise.”

 

 You lower your leg and reposition, stepping back from the barre. Your feet draw together, heels touching. Slowly, you reach behind your back, arms stretched wide as if embracing the room. Your shoulders roll, and your chest pushes forward. Your eyes flick to the window. The boys are captivated by your chest. Grins gone. Now staring.

 

 You smile as you hold their attention. What must they be thinking, you wonder. What they would say if you could speak to them. Maybe they’ll hang back after the lesson. Chat to you outside. What would they ask of you?

 

 *It sounds like you want them to.*

 

 You continue to hold the pose and their gaze, feeling in control. Beneath the sensation, however, is something more. A titter of endorphins. At being admired. And watched. 

 

 Actions

 <>

 You glare back at the boy outside. You’re not here to put on a show. Not for DeBussy. Not for a gym class. And certainly not for the boys outside.

 

 The classical music continues its steady rhythm. Around you, the girls move in time, limbs stretching in elegant arcs. But your body stays still. 

 

 “Demi plié,” DeBussy says from behind, her tone as sweet as ever. “And stretch. Let your presence speak through your posture.”

 

 You lower into the position just enough to count. Your knees bend, but you minimise the effort. You don’t rise onto your toes. No lift in your arms. You keep your movements tight, efficient, stripped of flourish. You glance out the window, noting the smiles on the boys' faces now wiped.

 

 “Leg up,” DeBussy adds, tapping the barre. “Extension through the hips. A dancer commands the gaze.”

 

 “Posture is power,” DeBussy says, near your ear. “Don’t lose their gaze. Be in control.”

 

 But you don’t. You raise your leg just enough to rest your ankle on the bar, keeping your torso upright. Your back stays stiff. You lean forward only slightly, stretching your hamstring. Chin down, fingers barely touching your leg. In the mirror, you see the boys begin to shift. Their attention pulls away to the other girls who are playing more of a part.

 

 DeBussy doesn’t comment, but now walks past you without comment. “Good extension, Miss Hudson. And nice turnout, Miss Kaplar.” Nothing for you. Not even a glance.

 

 You draw out of the pose. Your breath is steady, but your heart beats fast in the unspoken confrontation. If this is what Charlton calls power, then maybe power isn’t what you want.

 

 Actions

 <>

 The music fades, and DeBussy claps twice. “Very good, ladies. That will do for today.”

 

 Around you, everyone seems to exhale at once. Faces are flushed. Breathing shallow. Tights and leotards cling with effort.

 

 
 DeBussy meets your eyes immediately. “Excellent work today,” she says, stepping toward you. She tilts her head faintly toward the window. “They certainly noticed.” The boys are still there, grinning, one of them catching your eye and mouthing the words call me with a wink.

 

 “You’re learning,” DeBussy adds. “To control a room, you must know its secrets. And people carry their secrets on their eyes. Especially boys. Let them believe you’re showing them everything. And you’ll see what they’re really thinking.”

 

 Florence smiles as she leans against the barre, taking deep breaths. She doesn’t speak, but her quiet nod tells you she noticed, and maybe understood more than she’s letting on.

 
 
 Annie stares at you, slick with sweat. “Showing off, Jen?” she mutters. “Or just living your cheerleading glory days?”

 
 Annie bounces over, slick with sweat but smiling. “You were amazing,” she says. “Did you see their faces? They were watching you over me. That never happens.” She nudges you with a grin. “You turned a few heads.”

 
 
 Britney and Stacey look your way, but say nothing. You catch the end of a hushed exchange. "I could've done that," Britney huffs.

 

 “Sure, once you lay off those ice cream shakes at Fresh Pot,” Stacey mutters back. Britney pouts, but turns to the mirror and tugs at the waistline of her leotard.

 

 You glance to the window one more time. The boys are still watching. You feel their eyes on your skin. Your chest rises with a breath you didn’t mean to hold. It feels nice. To be seen like this. To have earned that attention. Or maybe claimed it.

 

 DeBussy’s baton taps the floor. “Next weekend, same time,” she calls. “Do keep practicing. We are not finished.”

 
 DeBussy doesn’t approach you. Her praise is already elsewhere. “Lovely elevation, Miss Hudson,” she says, moving toward Britney and Stacey. “And you, Miss Kaplar. Well, I’m not sure you need to learn anything.” Stacey smirks. Britney sulks. “I was elegant,” she mutters, tugging at her tights.

 

 “Not with that bounce,” Stacey mutters. “Or your lunch orders.”
 
 

 Florence wipes her brow with the sleeve of her arm. “It’s harder than it looks,” she says softly. “But I guess it comes easier if you go all in.”

 
 
 Annie catches your eye from across the gym, grinning with satisfaction. Her attention then returns back to the window, offering her audience a coy smile. 

 
 Annie catches your eye from across the gym, smiling politely. But her attention quickly drifts back to the window, where the boys linger. Her expression shifts to a coy smile. She knows they’re still watching her.

 
 
 DeBussy’s baton taps the floor. “Next weekend, same time,” she says. “Do keep practicing. We are not finished.”

 
 

 
 You watch as the others turn to leave for the locker room. You glance around the gym, trying to make sense of it. The promise of assertion... through exhibitionism? You question whether DeBussy will see you back here next weekend. Is this really for you?

 
 
 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You watch as the others turn to leave for the locker room. You glance around the gym, trying to make sense of it. The promise of assertion... through exhibitionism? You question whether DeBussy will see you back here next weekend. And then it dawns on you that in spite of how you feel about it, you've just taken ballet class. As a girl. And you're not sure why you're even considering coming back.

title: GymLockerRoomChanging
text:
Changing quickly, each layer brings a strange blend of embarrassment and curiosity. The top rides high, the shorts lower still. When you glance in the mirror, what stares back is unmistakably Annie. Flushed cheeks, long legs, bare midriff, the soft contour of a chest framed for visibility.

 

 You should feel exposed. But somehow, you don’t. Instead, you smile in the mirror. There’s a strange thrill that catches in your chest. You’re not sure if this is how Annie feels when she walks into a room. But in her skin and in her clothes, it’s hard not to feel like you’re meant to be looked at.

 

 *Or like some part of you wants to be?*

 

 You breathe in. Gordon will be waiting. Watching. Compared to other men in Charlton, he seemed disinterested in obviously looking at you. But this is Charlton. You’ve learned the hard way that things are never as easy as they seem.

 

 Or do you wish he was more interested in you?

 

 You step toward the exit.

 
 You need to do this, you think, and begin changing your clothes. Putting them on isn’t tricky. You pull the bra over your head and over your breasts. The leggings are surprisingly stretchy and comfortable to wear. You pull and tug them up, ensuring they are free of wrinkles. 

 

 A full-length mirror hangs nearby on the wall. You look at yourself in it, turning to face away and looking at yourself over your shoulder.

 

 The activewear might be comfy to wear, but it looks tight and restrictive, riding up between your buttocks and clinging to your body like paint. The face of Jennifer smiles back at you in the mirror, looking cheeky. You remember that Jennifer looks like this for all her sessions with Gordon. You’re not sure how that makes you feel.

 
 You need to do this, you think, and begin changing your clothes. Each piece fits too snugly. Whether it clings, clasps, or rides high, the end result is the same. When you look in the mirror, there’s no mistaking what you look like.

 

 You might look like Emily, but it’s an Emily ready to be watched. And in front of Gordon.

 

 Gordon has never expressed any ill will or malice towards Emily. But this is Charlton. You’ve learned the hard way that things are never as easy as they seem.

 

 Or do you wish he was more interested in you?

 

 You step toward the exit.

 
 You need to do this, you think, and begin changing your clothes. Each piece fits too snugly. Whether it clings, clasps, or rides high, the end result is the same. When you look in the mirror, there’s no mistaking what you look like.

 

 An image comes into your mind. The picture of you, working out, as guys watch and gawp at your bum and your exposed midriff.

 

 Now that could become a reality. With Gordon as the observer. He’s never expressed any ill will or malice towards you. But this is Charlton. You’ve learned the hard way that things are never as easy as they seem.

title: HotelKitchenMaid
text:
You peel away your clothes with mechanical movements, folding them neatly onto the bench beside the locker. For a moment, you hesitate, just looking at the uniform laid out before you. It’s absurd. Sexy. Impractical. 

 

 You slide into the dress.

 

 It hugs close where it shouldn’t. The fabric is light, clinging to your form with an unsettling accuracy, and the lace feels more decorative than functional. You tug at the hem, but it barely grazes mid-thigh.

 

 The stockings whisper as you pull them up your legs. The heels are a battle of their own. Unsteady, sculpted things that force your hips into a sway you didn’t ask for.

 

 By the time you leave the locker room, the echo of your footsteps down the hallway seems… louder. More noticed. Staff glance as you pass. Guests turn. A man gives a second glance, smiling to himself. You feel exposed. Like decoration.

 

 You reach the kitchen doors and push through.

 
 You slip out of your clothes with practiced ease, folding them with care. The uniform waits for you like a second skin. You no longer hesitate.

 

 The dress slides on smoothly now, its cut familiar, its cling expected. It cinches at the waist and lifts in all the right places. You adjust the hem, but not to tug it lower. Just to smooth it flat.

 

 Stockings stretch up your thighs with a whisper, and the once challenging heels now feel natural. Even flattering. You move differently in them. You know it.

 

 You step out into the hallway. You’re not sure if you’ve stopped noticing the stares… or if you’ve just started accepting them.
 
 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 You don’t even think about it. The second your hands are in the water, something just… clicks. A rhythm. A pull. You scrub the dishes with careful attention, polishing each plate until it gleams. Cutlery gets stacked in perfect alignment. Pans lose their grease like a challenge you’re eager to meet.

 

 You’re not doing this because you want to. Not exactly. You’re doing it because it feels right.

 

 Natural.

 

 The scent of lemon soap, the clink of clean plates. There’s comfort in it. Focus. Order. You lose track of time, only surfacing when you realise you’re halfway through the stack without noticing the minutes pass.

 

 Pierre circles you a few times, arms folded. He watches without comment. Until finally, he grunts. “Hmph. Surprised,” he mutters. “Didn’t think lazy English girls knew how to work.”

 

 You don’t say anything. But part of you is… pleased. Not at him. At the result. At the shine.

 

 By the end of your shift, your arms ache and the front of your uniform is damp with soapy water. But the sinks are empty, and everything is exactly where it should be. Pierre even reaches into the tip jar near the door and stuffs a wad of notes in your hands.

 

 You exhale. Satisfied.

 

 Even if you know you shouldn’t be.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You roll up your sleeves and try to focus. The water is hot. The pile of dishes, endless. You do your best to scrub with purpose, but the pressure of doing it right weighs heavy.

 

 And Pierre wastes no time making it worse.

 

 “Non, non, non!” he snaps, swooping in like a hawk. “You clean like a girl who has never worked a day in her life. Look! Look at this pan! What is this? English laziness? Oui?”

 

 You grit your teeth.

 

 He steps in behind you, muttering in French. His hands reach around, grabbing yours, forcing them into the soapy water.

 

 “This is how you scrub. With force. With purpose. Not like some dainty little mouse too afraid to chip her precious nails.”

 

 He presses in closer, his body heavy and invasive. His breath hot and sour near your ear. “You girls are always the same. No discipline. No pride.”

 

 Your stomach tightens. The closeness. The stink of cigarette smoke and sweat. The roughness of his grip. And his crotch, pushing against you, undeniably there, pressing into the back of your uniform.

 

 You try to keep breathing steady. Try to stay focused on the task. He says he’s teaching.

 

 But it feels like something else.
