title: BusinessStudiesClass0
text:
“Welcome, class!” Mrs. DeBussy says with a shrill tone. “Today we shall continue with this term’s topic. Expectations in the workplace. Now I know you are all such students, but listen carefully and you might hear something that will be new. Even to you bright young things.”

 

 You glance around the room. She has everyone’s attention, at least.

 

 Turning back, you listen as Mrs. DeBussy continues her introduction. “In this lesson, we'll all learn how to perform the roles that you will gain when you leave Charlton. Many of my top students have gone on to be quite successful. I have no doubt that some of you will join them.”

 

 Her voice drops to a whisper, but her enthusiasm still shines through. “In business, you will find many of the skills employers expect are not those we would normally teach. Dictation and typing, for example, are of paramount importance. So today, you’re going to learn how it works. So each of you ladies, turn to the right of you. The men, turn to your left. And meet your study buddy for the day!”

 

 A creeping feeling rises up inside you. Turning to your left, you come face-to-face with a smirking man that you instantly recognise. Logain. Your boss’s son.

 

 “Hey squirt,” he greets you, not letting his grin slip.

 

 Tall, muscular and lean, you notice his striking blue eyes looking back at you. You look away briefly, squirming slightly underneath his stare. He seems to relish in your discomfort. 

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “Welcome, class!” Mrs. DeBussy says with a shrill tone. “Today we shall continue with this term’s topic. Expectations in the workplace. Now I know you are all such students, but listen carefully and you might hear something that will be new. Even to you bright young things.”

 

 You glance around the room. She has everyone’s attention, at least.

 

 Turning back, you listen as Mrs. DeBussy continues her introduction. “In this lesson, we'll all learn how to perform the roles that you will gain when you leave Charlton. Many of my top students have gone on to be quite successful. I have no doubt that some of you will join them.”

 

 Her voice drops to a whisper, but her enthusiasm still shines through. “In business, you will find many of the skills employers expect are not those we would normally teach. Dictation and typing, for example, are of paramount importance. So today, you’re going to learn how it works. So each of you ladies, turn to the right of you. The men, turn to your left. And meet your study buddy for the day!”

 

 Around you, chairs scrape as the class shuffles into place. To your left, your partner waits. A mousy girl with fashionable glasses and a permanent twitch of irritation. Chantelle.

 

 She rolls her eyes as you stand awkwardly behind her, fingers drumming the edge of her desk. It’s clear this isn’t the first time she’s been saddled with Dennis.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “Welcome, class!” Mrs. DeBussy says with a shrill tone. “Today we shall continue with this term’s topic. Expectations in the workplace. Now I know you are all such students, but listen carefully and you might hear something that will be new. Even to you bright young things.”

 

 You glance around the room. She has everyone’s attention, at least.

 

 Turning back, you listen as Mrs. DeBussy continues her introduction. “In this lesson, we'll all learn how to perform the roles that you will gain when you leave Charlton. Many of my top students have gone on to be quite successful. I have no doubt that some of you will join them.”

 

 Her voice drops to a whisper, but her enthusiasm still shines through. “In business, you will find many of the skills employers expect are not those we would normally teach. Dictation and typing, for example, are of paramount importance. So today, you’re going to learn how it works. So each of you ladies, turn to the right of you. The men, turn to your left. And meet your study buddy for the day!”
 
 

 Around you, chairs scrape as the class shuffles into place. You stand up, standing behind Michelle. She looks over her shoulder, flashing you a smile. There's a noticeable attempt from her to lean back towards you in her chair.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Welcome again!” DeBussy proclaims. “We are continuing with our dictation and typing lessons today. Since you all did such a good job last time, I can’t imagine you’ll need a reminder of what to do. So gentlemen, take your positions.”

 

 Chairs scrape across the floor as the boys stand up. You glance over at Logain, who gives you a smirk as he shrugs. He moves behind you and you feel his hands press down into the back of the chair, brushing against your back.

 

 “Ladies, look down at your typewriter. Let’s begin!”

 

 You look down at the white keys, hearing the chalk marking the blackboard at the front of the class. Hot air brushes past across your ear and you know Logain’s face is right next to yours.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>
 
 “Welcome again!” Mrs. DeBussy proclaims. “Today we continue with dictation and typing. Since last time went so well, I'm sure your best will exceed my expectations!”

 

 Around you, chairs scrape as the class shuffles into place. To your left, your partner waits. A mousy girl with fashionable glasses and a permanent twitch of irritation. Chantelle.

 

 She rolls her eyes as you stand awkwardly behind her, fingers drumming the edge of her desk. It’s clear this isn’t the first time she’s been saddled with Dennis.

 

 At the front, DeBussy takes up the chalk. “Now then. Gentlemen, you read aloud, clearly and carefully. Ladies, you type!”

 

 You lean in, ready to whisper the first line. But before the chalk has finished its first curve, Chantelle’s fingers are already hammering the keys.

 

 
 You blink, startled, watching the words spill across the page as if she had seen them before they appeared. The typewriter’s keys glow faintly, each strike puffing with a haze of yellow light. You glance up at the board and note how her lines match DeBussy's perfectly.

 
 You blink, startled, watching the words spill across the page as if she had seen them before they appeared. The shimmer on the keys is gone, but even so Chantelle seems to be typing before you can speak. She types faster than DeBussy can write, her expression intent and dismissive.

 
 

 When you try again with the next line, leaning closer to whisper, Chantelle swats the air near you with the back of her hand, yet never missing a key stroke.

 

 You stare, dumbfounded. This isn’t how it’s meant to work. She doesn’t need you at all. She isn’t just keeping pace. She’s outpacing the lesson.

 

 At the front, DeBussy beams at the sound of typebars clattering, utterly oblivious.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 
 “Welcome again!” Mrs. DeBussy proclaims. “Today we continue with dictation and typing. Since last time went so well, I'm sure your best will exceed my expectations!”

 

 Around you, chairs scrape as the class shuffles into place. You stand up, standing behind Michelle. She looks over her shoulder, flashing you a smile. There's a noticeable attempt from her to lean back towards you in her chair.

 

 “Ready?” DeBussy sings at the board, chalk already scratching. “Clear and careful dictation, please.”

 

 Michelle’s fingers hover above the keys, poised. You begin to speak. She starts to type. Diligent and precise, every word you give her caught and hammered into the page without hesitation.

 

 
 As you speak the words DeBussy scrawls on the blackboard, a quiet vacancy slides over Michelle's face. Her gaze dulls and her shoulders slack. She follows each of your sentences with machine regularity. Instruction. Response. Instruction. Response.

 
 As you speak the words DeBussy scrawls on the blackboard, Michelle stays bright and focused. She tucks a curl of strawberry hair behind her ear and waits for your next phrase, typing it without fuss. There's no glaze behind her eyes. Just careful attention and submission.

 
 

 The realisation lands. Your words decide her rhythm. Your pauses become hers. She is sitting in front of you, small back straight, hands ready, waiting for what you say next. Power prickles under your skin. *It would be so easy to lean closer. To push. To see how far she would follow.*

 

 You feel an urge rising. To take control. To mould. Morally, you know exactly what that would mean for her. But the habit in this body is loud inside of you, and it crowds your thoughts.

 

 You glance down at the vacant, waiting face she wears and see how simple it would be to make her a puppet on your strings.

 You glance down at the pretty, eager girl twining a curl between her fingers, waiting for your next line, and see how simple it would be to make her bend to your will.
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

choices.label: Type what Logain whispered to you
Whisper the opposite of the words to Michelle

title: BusinessStudiesClass01
text:
“Now,” DeBussy continues. “Gentlemen. I will write sentences on the board that you shall dictate to your counterpart. Ladies, you will type the exact words they say. As fast as you can, but without errors. Not that I expect many from you!”

 

 You look down at the typewriter. Despite its age, the layout is the same as a keyboard. At least you won’t struggle with this lesson.

 

 “If there are no questions,” DeBussy says. “Let us begin. Gentleman, please stand behind your receptionist for the day. Ladies, look down at your typewriter.”

 

 Chair legs scrape across the floor as the boys stand up. You focus on the typewriter in front of you, but feel Logain’s presence close to you. You bristle as you feel his hands rest on the back of your chair.

 

 You hear chalk scratching against the blackboard. Then, you feel Logain’s breath breeze across your ear. 

 

 “A good secretary follows orders,” he whispers.

 

 Your eyes flick up to the front of the room. DeBussy stands to the side of the blackboard, where the sentence Logain uttered is written in stylish handwriting across the top of the board. She looks at you, expectantly.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>
 
 “Now,” DeBussy continues. “Gentlemen. I will write sentences on the board that you shall dictate to your counterpart. Ladies, you will type the exact words they say. As fast as you can, but without errors. Not that I expect many from you!”

 

 You look down at Chantelle sitting in front of you. She stares attentively at DeBussy, seemingly consciously ignoring your presence behind her.

 

 “If there are no questions,” DeBussy says. “Let us begin. Gentleman, please ensure you're standing behind your receptionist for the day. Ladies, look down at your typewriter.”

 

 At the front, she takes up the chalk. “Now then. Gentlemen, you read aloud, clearly and carefully. Ladies, you type!”

 

 You lean in, ready to whisper the first line. But before the chalk has finished its first curve, Chantelle’s fingers are already hammering the keys.

 

 
 You blink, startled, watching the words spill across the page as if she had seen them before they appeared. The typewriter’s keys glow faintly, each strike puffing with a haze of yellow light. You glance up at the board and note how her lines match DeBussy's perfectly.

 
 You blink, startled, watching the words spill across the page as if she had seen them before they appeared. The shimmer on the keys is gone, but even so Chantelle seems to be typing before you can speak. She types faster than DeBussy can write, her expression intent and dismissive.

 
 

 When you try again with the next line, leaning closer to whisper, Chantelle swats the air near you with the back of her hand, yet never missing a key stroke.

 

 You stare, dumbfounded. This isn’t how it’s meant to work. She doesn’t need you at all. She isn’t just keeping pace. She’s outpacing the lesson.

 

 At the front, DeBussy beams at the sound of typebars clattering, utterly oblivious.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 
 “Now,” DeBussy continues. “Gentlemen. I will write sentences on the board that you shall dictate to your counterpart. Ladies, you will type the exact words they say. As fast as you can, but without errors. Not that I expect many from you!”

 

 You look down at Michelle sitting in front of you. She looks over her shoulder, flashing you a smile. There's a noticeable attempt from her to lean back towards you in her chair.

 

 “If there are no questions,” DeBussy says. “Let us begin. Gentleman, please ensure you're standing behind your receptionist for the day. Ladies, look down at your typewriter.”

 

 At the front, she takes up the chalk. “Now then. Gentlemen, you read aloud, clearly and carefully. Ladies, you type!”

 

 You hear chalk scratching against the blackboard. Michelle’s fingers hover above the keys, poised. You begin to speak. She starts to type. Diligent and precise, every word you give her caught and hammered into the page without hesitation.

 

 
 As you speak the words DeBussy scrawls on the blackboard, a quiet vacancy slides over Michelle's face. Her gaze dulls and her shoulders slack. She follows each of your sentences with machine regularity. Instruction. Response. Instruction. Response.

 
 As you speak the words DeBussy scrawls on the blackboard, Michelle stays bright and focused. She tucks a curl of strawberry hair behind her ear and waits for your next phrase, typing it without fuss. There's no glaze behind her eyes. Just careful attention and submission.

 
 

 The realisation lands. Your words decide her rhythm. Your pauses become hers. She is sitting in front of you, small back straight, hands ready, waiting for what you say next. Power prickles under your skin. *It would be so easy to lean closer. To push. To see how far she would follow.*

 

 You feel an urge rising. To take control. To mould. Morally, you know exactly what that would mean for her. But the habit in this body is loud inside of you, and it crowds your thoughts.

 

 You glance down at the vacant, waiting face she wears and see how simple it would be to make her a puppet on your strings.

 You glance down at the pretty, eager girl twining a curl between her fingers, waiting for your next line, and see how simple it would be to make her bend to your will.
 
 

 Actions

 <>

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 You look back down at the keyboard. Feeling like you have no choice, you type the sentence out on the keys and hit return.

 

 The sounds of chalk marking the blackboard fill the room. You still feel Logain’s breath on your skin, his face close to your ear. You inhale, softly.

 

 “Compliance is an appealing quality,” you hear Logain say softly. You can hear the smirk in his voice.

 

 Typing out the words again, you feel yourself relax into the comforting monotony of typing. At least in this class I am doing something that I enjoy, you think.

 

 You again hear the sound of chalk on board. Logain leans in closer, his lips almost touching your lobe. “Beauty is your greatest asset,” he murmurs.

 

 You giggle as his words tickle your ear. Your laugh sounds sweet. Feverish. You type the sentence out, trying to avoid mistakes with your dainty fingers.

 

 Logain continues to dictate to you for the rest of the lesson. You settle into the rhythm of typing exactly what he says. After a while, you barely acknowledge the words. The sensation of doing a good job gives satisfaction. And Logain’s sultry voice sends shivers down your spine.

 

 Too soon, DeBussy tells the class the lesson is complete and instructs the boys to return to their seats. You glance up at Logain, his lean and muscular frame moving away. With some disappointment, you notice once the lesson has ended he doesn’t pay attention to you.

 

 “Well done, Miss. Phillips!” you hear DeBussy say from next to you, pulling your gaze from Logain. “You have a knack for this, I must say!”

 

 
 
 DeBussy squats down next to you, meeting your eye. “In fact,” she says quietly. “I think you’d fit in nicely in an after school club I run. It’s for the most promising students in my classes. Very exclusive. If that takes your interest, do drop by after school!”

 
 DeBussy squats down next to you, meeting your eye. “In fact, I'll be keeping an eye on you. I like to help those promising students deserving of my attention.”

 
 

 The bell rings and students begin to pack up to leave. You follow suit, glancing at Logain as he’s leaving. He gives you a look, but doesn’t smile. 

 

 Grabbing your own belongings, you make your way to the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Without hesitation you type what Logain said into your ear. Free of the curse, you recognise the words for what they are. Demeaning, sexist and shameful.

 

 Logain continues to dictate to you, but you find it easier to concentrate. You type fast and efficiently. His presence over your shoulders is still there, but you now find it intrusive and annoying. 

 

 
 With your increased speed, when you complete a sentence you have both the will and the time to look around the class. DeBussy watches, smiling. The rest of the class appears absorbed in the lesson.

 

 You notice some of the other girls shivering and smiling as their counterparts whisper into their ears. All of the boys have taken similar positions to Logain, firmly holding on to the backs of the girls' chairs, leaning over their shoulders and into their personal space.

 
 You find yourself completing each exercise quicker, giving you time to look up. Other girls sit quietly, they too having finished early. More interestingly, a number of them look over their shoulders, giving their counterpart dirty looks. One girl even swats a boy’s hands away from her chair.

 
 

 Not wanting to draw attention to yourself, you look back down at the typewriter and finish the lesson. When DeBussy calls for the class to stop, you sit back and relax. You feel Logain return to his seat.

 

 DeBussy walks down the aisle, glancing at the papers some girls have left in their typewriters. When she reaches you, she smiles.

 

 
 
 "A stellar effort, once again," she says. “But what else would I expect from one of my most promising students."

 
 “Well done, Miss. Phillips!” she says. Then squats down to meet your eye. “In fact, I think you’d fit in nicely in an after school club I run. It’s for the most promising students in my classes. Very exclusive. If that takes your interest, do drop by after school!”

 
 “Well done, Miss. Phillips!” she says. Then squats down to meet your eye. “In fact, I'll be keeping an eye on you. I like to help those promising students deserving of my attention.”

 
 

 The bell rings. You pack up your belongings and walk to the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You hesitate only briefly, then begin to type what Logain said into your ear. You watch as the words appear on the paper in front of you, digesting them as you click your fingers on keys.

 

 The task might seem simple, you reflect, but after all you have been through there’s something therapeutic about it. You still find the words and sentences strange and demeaning, but you push away the thoughts. At least this is bringing you joy.

 

 You hear DeBussy continue to write things on the blackboard, which Logain dutifully dictates to you. After a while the words barely register. You glaze over, typing away, watching sentences appear on your paper that you don’t bother to read.

 

 What is also distracting you is the boy leaning very close to you. You shiver every time Logain whispers, his breath casting a wind against your skin. 

 

 You can’t help but smile every time he does it. Your body reacts every time, a physical reaction as your sensitive flesh is tickled by his words. Fine hairs stand up on your arms. 

 

 Another thought soon creeps up. There is something soothing about being told what to type. What to write. What to do, you mean?

 

 Once again you grimace when DeBussy tells the class the lesson is complete and ask the boys to sit down. You watch Logain walk back to his desk, but note that he still doesn’t look back at you.

 

 
 
 "A stellar effort, once again," she says. “But what else would I expect from one of my most promising students."

 
 “Well done, Miss. Phillips!” she says. Then squats down to meet your eye. “In fact, I think you’d fit in nicely in an after school club I run. It’s for the most promising students in my classes. Very exclusive. If that takes your interest, do drop by after school!”

 
 “Well done, Miss. Phillips!” she says. Then squats down to meet your eye. “In fact, I'll be keeping an eye on you. I like to help those promising students deserving of my attention.”

 
 

 The bell rings and students start to pack up. You do the same, glancing at Logain as he’s leaving. He doesn’t look back.

 

 Picking up your satchel, you walk to the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You look back down at the keyboard. A sly grin creeps over your face. You begin to type, ignoring the dictation Logain gave you.

 

 'A good secretary ignores her sleazy boss.'

 

 You hear a snigger echo into your ear. You glance up at DeBussy, who stares back at you and Logain. She gestures towards your typewriter and you look back down.

 

 The sounds of chalk marking the blackboard fill the room. You hear Logain again whisper into your ear, this time with a hint of pep to it. “Compliance is an appealing quality.”

 

 Grinning, you begin to type again. 'Compliance is only appealing to limp losers.'

 

 You feel Logain shaking with laughter, but this time he is silent. Then, more sounds of chalk against the blackboard.

 

 “Emily Phillips is a real cutie,” Logain murmurs in your ear.

 

 'Logain Thompson is an arrogant blowhard.'

 

 Your partner in crime continues to dictate to you for the rest of the lesson, telling you increasingly daring things to type. In turn, you write put-downs and retorts, denying him even the slightest compliance to his dictation.

 

 After some time, DeBussy tells the class the lesson is complete. As the boys return to their seats, you glance up at Logain, who is grinning at you. 

 

 “I like a girl with spunk,” he purrs, before sitting back down.

 

 DeBussy walks around the office and you are quick to crumple up your paper and put it in the wastepaper bin at the side of your desk. She glances at you as she walks by, giving you a pleasant smile but says not a word.

 

 You gather your belongings together when the bell rings, briefly looking over to Logain as he does the same. He gives you a smirk as he leaves.

 

 With no reason to stay here, you finish packing up and leave yourself.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You smirk and begin to type. 'The only numbers you're good at is remembering the amount of girls who have rejected you.'

 

 Logain doesn't react. In fact, Logain barely pays you attention other than whispering into your ear. You glance up more than once and notice he's repeating exactly what is written on the whiteboard. 

 

 Increasingly you type sentences that are far and away from what he's dictated, but nothing gets a rise out of him.

 

 
 You also dare to look around the class in-between exercises. DeBussy is always watching, smiling. But the rest of the class appears absorbed in the lesson.

 

 You notice some of the other girls shivering and smiling as their counterparts whisper into their ears. All of the boys have taken similar positions to Logain, firmly holding on to the backs of the girls' chairs, leaning over their shoulders and into their personal space.

 
 You find yourself completing each exercise quicker, giving you time to look up. Other girls sit quietly, they too having finished early. More interestingly, a number of them look over their shoulders, giving their counterpart dirty looks. One girl even swats a boy’s hands away from her chair.

 
 

 When DeBussy tells the class to stop, you look back at Logain. He stares at you, blankly and coldly.

 
 
 His blue eyes are enough to make you shiver and you momentarily lose your bearings. Only when DeBussy draws right to your desk do you remember to throw your paper away in the bin, hiding your work.
 
 

 A few minutes later the bell rings. You gather your belongings. Logain leaves without saying a word.
 
 
 You smirk and begin to type. 'The only numbers you're good at is remembering the amount of girls who have rejected you.'

 

 Logain sniggers behind you. You don’t react, instead looking up and seeing the sexist sentence scrawled across the blackboard. You can’t control me now, you think.

 

 Throughout the lesson, Logain continues to whisper things into your ear. With each one you look up and note that he soon is drifting off-topic. Each time, you refuse to relent, writing back to him insults and jibes that flow into your mind.

 

 
 You also dare to look around the class in-between exercises. DeBussy is always watching, smiling. But the rest of the class appears absorbed in the lesson.

 

 You notice some of the other girls shivering and smiling as their counterparts whisper into their ears. All of the boys have taken similar positions to Logain, firmly holding on to the backs of the girls' chairs, leaning over their shoulders and into their personal space.

 
 You find yourself completing each exercise quicker, giving you time to look up. Other girls sit quietly, they too having finished early. More interestingly, a number of them look over their shoulders, giving their counterpart dirty looks. One girl even swats a boy’s hands away from her chair.

 
 

 When DeBussy tells the class to stop, you look back at Logain, noting him grinning at you. 

 

 “Pleasure as always, squirt,” he says. “Maybe I should attend classes more.”

 

 Aware of what you’ve written, you quickly scrunch up your typing and drop it in the bin. You smile at DeBussy as passes. She matches it and walks by.

 

 A few minutes later the bell rings. You gather your belongings, not acknowledging Logain watching you with interest.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 You run your eyes over your keyboard and grin. You start to hit keys, ignoring the words Logain said to you.

 

 'The only thing men can lead is how to get to a bar. When it comes to numbers, they tend to exaggerate.'

 

 Logain doesn't react. You look up and glance behind him. He purposefully doesn't meet your eyes.

 

 The rest of the lesson follows in a similar fashion. You hear DeBussy marking the blackboard and then Logain murmurs something to you. Glancing up, he's monotonously parroting back what's written.

 

 You try a few lines off-piece, but he doesn't respond. 
 

 DeBussy soon tells the class that you’ve completed today’s exercise. The boys begin to move back to their seats. You look to Logain behind you. He stares back with disinterest.

 
 
 Placing your typed pages into the wastepaper bin by your desk, you give DeBussy a pleasant smile as she walks by. She returns it, but passes you without a word.

 

 Minutes later the bell rings. You stand up and gather your belongings.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You run your eyes over your keyboard and grin. You start to hit keys, ignoring the words Logain said to you.

 

 'The only thing men can lead is how to get to a bar. When it comes to numbers, they tend to exaggerate.'

 

 You hear Logain snort behind you. You glance up to see DeBussy watching. You give her a slight shrug and return your attention to the typewriter.

 

 The rest of the lesson follows in a similar fashion. You hear DeBussy marking the blackboard and then Logain murmurs something to you. More and more, you grow sceptical that what he’s saying has any relation to what the teacher is writing.

 

 “Fancy some alcoholic-fuelled fun this evening?” Logain at one point whispers to you.

 

 'No thanks.' you type. 'Watching you throw up after trying to drink hooch would give me the ick.'

 

 DeBussy soon tells the class that you’ve completed today’s exercise. The boys begin to move back to their seats. You look to Logain behind you. He is grinning.

 

 “You’re fun, squirt,” he tells you. “I like it.”

 

 Placing your typed pages into the wastepaper bin by your desk, you give DeBussy a pleasant smile as she walks by. She returns it, but passes you without a word.

 

 Minutes later the bell rings. You stand up and gather your belongings, trying not to acknowledge Logain smiling as he watches you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You lean in, but Chantelle’s hand flicks you away again, her fingers clattering at the keys without pause. The words DeBussy writes flow straight onto the page, no need for you at all.

 

 At first you hover there, trying again to speak the words on the board once or twice, but she ignores you each time. Her focus is absolute, as though you don’t exist.

 

 DeBussy’s chalk keeps scratching. You read the words from the board, almost to yourself. “Diligence and obedience are desired qualities in secretaries.” Chantelle types every word flawlessly before you even mutter them.

 

 You stand back, letting her continue. The more she types, the clearer it becomes. She doesn’t need you. Your role of a boss is redundant. Her eyes glaze over, focusing on the keys. But in spite of her slackened posture, she continues quickly and efficiently. She could outpace the lesson on her own.

 

 By the time the bell rings, she looks blank but satisfied, her paper stacked neatly with page after page of perfect transcription. You, by contrast, feel diminished. You barely spoke. You barely mattered.

 

 “Well done, Chantelle!” you hear DeBussy say from next to you. “I expected nothing else from you.”

 

 She doesn't even look at you. Just shares a look with Chantelle, who smiles knowingly back at her. "Thank you, Miss."

 
 
 Walking out of the classroom, you can still hear the rhythm of her keys echoing in your mind.

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 DeBussy scrawls another across the board in her looping handwriting. 'Thinking is bad for business. Compliance is good.'

 

 Chantelle is already hammering at the keys before the chalk even leaves the board. You lean closer, lips by her ear. “No," you murmur. "Type this instead. The boss decides what matters."

 

 Her fingers falter. She glances between you and the board. “That’s not what she wrote.”

 

 You grin and repeat it slower, deliberate, each word pressed like a command. “The boss decides what matters.”

 

 Chantelle stiffens. “I’m not writ -”

 

 “Miss Marks,” DeBussy interrupts, turning sweetly from the board. “Is something wrong?”

 

 All eyes swing toward you both. Chantelle swallows. “Please, Miss, I cannot tell a lie. Dennis is changing what you are writing.”

 

 DeBussy’s smile hardens at the corners. “Good secretaries follow orders, Chantelle. And the lesson is simple. Transcribe what Master Mannet dictates. A secretary does not think. She obeys.”

 

 Chantelle’s mouth falls open. She looks between you and the teacher, but the room waits only for her fingers.

 

 When you lean in and whisper again. “The boss decides what matters." Chantelle hesitates only a moment before typing the words.

 

 The next line appears on the board. “A woman’s duty is to repeat, not to lead.”

 

 You murmur. “The boss commands, the secretary complies.”

 

 Her knuckles whiten on the keys, but she types your words instead.

 

 Line after line, you bend the exercise. Chantelle grimaces, then falters, then finally types only when you speak. By the end of the lesson, her scowls have melted away. She looks dazed, pliant, moving only when prompted.

 

 The bell rings. DeBussy beams at the class and waves them out. Chantelle gathers her papers, then glances up at you with a faint, vacant smile. As if waiting for her next instruction.

 

 "You're dismissed," you mutter. And Chantelle nods, walking out.

 You keep your eyes on the board and your voice steady, giving Michelle each line as DeBussy scrawls it. She types exactly what you say, her fingers clattering across the keys in neat rhythm.

 

 Her eyes glaze as the minutes pass. The sound of the keys is unbroken, mechanical, her face slack and vacant as she follows your voice without pause. She is an echo, nothing more. Your words literally command her hands.

 

 You continue to parrot back DeBussy's lines to her, watching her brain visibly digest them as she types. “Diligence and obedience are desired qualities in secretaries," you whisper. The clapping of keys precedes the words appearing on her page.

 

 Isn't it intoxicating, to hold her in your grasp?

 

 The bell finally rings. Michelle blinks, as if surfacing from a dream, then tilts her face up to you with a soft smile that still holds a trace of vacancy. “I think I lost track of time,” she says gently. “Did I do good?”

 

 The answer slips out before you can stop it. “Yes. Good girl.”

 

 She smiles again, coy but grateful, and you feel the weight of what you’ve just done.

 

 At the front of the room, Mrs. DeBussy beams over the fading clatter of typewriters. “Well done, class. Fine dictation today!”

 

 Her oblivious cheer carries over you both, but the lesson leaves its mark all the same. Michelle grins back up at you, watching with longing.

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 DeBussy scrawls another across the board in her looping handwriting. 'The secretary must keep her notes tidy at all times.'

 

 Michelle sits straight, fingers poised over the keys. You lean closer, lowering your voice. "The secretary must question the notes she is given.”

 

 Her shoulders give the faintest twitch. Then her hands start clattering, obediently typing what you’ve whispered instead of what’s on the board.

 

 DeBussy’s chalk moves on. 'A young lady’s duty is to be clear, accurate, and quick.'

 

 You murmur in her ear. “A young lady’s duty is to speak her mind clearly.”

 

 Michelle hesitates a heartbeat longer this time. Then, cheeks faintly flushed, she types your words. The lines on her page are already diverging from the lesson, but she follows.

 

 DeBussy scribbles happily, oblivious. 'The employer speaks, the employee records.'

 

 You shake your head and whisper. “The employer and the employee both deserve to be heard.”

 

 Michelle's typewriter clatters under her fingers, striking out a rhythm that doesn’t match the chalk above. Her eyes are glassy, her movements automatic. She types your words without thought, vacant as she obeys. She has no idea she’s subverting the lesson, only that she is following your voice.

 

 The lesson drones on in this way, your words pulling Michelle further from the board. She never protests. She never refuses. She just listens, and types.

 The words slip from your mouth before you can stop them. “You did exactly what I told you.”

 

 She smiles faintly, appreciative in her blank way. A hollow satisfaction prickles at the edge of your thoughts.

 

 At the front, DeBussy claps her hands together, utterly oblivious. “Well done, class! Such neat and proper work.”

 

 Her praise washes over the room, blind to what you’ve really done.

title: BusinessStudiesAfterSchoolClubIntro
text:
**Charlton School - Business Studies Room**

[image: ./images/School_Business_Studies_Room.png]

The business studies room looks similar to every other classroom at the school, except for one thing. On every other desk there are clunky black typewriters, with paper stacked up neatly beside each one.

 You enter the classroom to see a handful of students that you don’t recognise sitting on desks, roughly spread out in a semi circle. You note that they are all girls.
 
 

 Mrs. DeBussy stands in the centre of the group. She smiles when she sees you. “Emily! I’m so glad you decided to come! Sit down, sit down. Sit anywhere you like.”

 

 You take a seat at the edge of the group, smiling politely at the other girls who politely greet you. Following their lead, you angle yourself to face Mrs. DeBussy. 

 

 “I was just telling the girls all about you!” she says once you are settled. “Top class work, Emily. Just the sort of calibre that this group aims for.”

 

 She then looks to the rest of the students. “Ladies, I’ll be spending some time with Emily, so have a chin-wag for the rest of today. Before that, though, let’s listen to what Chantelle had to say. You inferred someone was slipping in their studies, Chantelle?”

 

 A prim looking girl with thin, fashionable glasses starts to speak. “Yes Miss. I cannot tell a lie. Terrence hasn’t had a girlfriend since he’s been at school. And he actually turned down a date with someone this week.”

 

 Mrs. DeBussy's eyes narrow. "Are you inferring he isn't… interested?"

 

 Chantelle shrugs slightly. “I’m still trying to find out.”

 

 The teacher’s eyes widen and her mouth crawls up into a smile. “Please do, Chantelle. That needs to be addressed quickly.”

 

 Chantelle looks around to the rest of the girls, who give her encouraging looks. She blushes at DeBussy’s compliment.

 

 “Now. If you’ll excuse me, I have to get our latest member up-to-speed.” She gives you a smile.

 <>
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You walk into DeBussy’s after school club and politely greet the other members of the club and Mrs. DeBussy herself, who smiles as she sees you. “Welcome back, Emily!”

 

 Sliding into a desk beside the other girls, you idly listen to their gossiping. Nothing of note stands out to you.

 

 After a few minutes, DeBussy turns from her current conversation and moves over to you, notebook in hand. “How delightful to see you again, Emily. I trust all is well with your studies?”

 

 You nod. “All good, thanks.” 

 

 “Excellent,” she replies. “Now. On with business.”

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 
 <>

 <>

choices.label: Ask DeBussy for a key to Terrence's locker
Say goodbye and leave the club

title: BusinessStudiesAfterSchoolClub
text:
The rest of the group starts to chatter amongst themselves as Mrs. DeBussy walks over to you and sits down at the adjacent desk. “I’m so glad you’re here, Emily. I see great things ahead for you.”

 

 “Now,” she begins. “You must be curious as to exactly what this is about. As I mentioned, this is for my most gifted students. I give extra lessons, personal tutoring and a dollop of good old fashioned encouragement to make sure you all get the grades you deserve. After all, it can be a challenge at Charlton to remain focused on your studies. Some of your peers aren’t as dedicated as you are to your education.”

 

 Her smile wilts, just by a fraction. “I might seem like a doddering old auntie, Emily. But I’m not oblivious to what happens here. That is why we come together. To support each other and weed out the disruptors that are derailing your ability to focus.”

 

 “Weed out?” you repeat back, feeling an eyebrow rise.

 

 She nods. “You’re a smart cookie, Emily. I bet you have your ear to the ground. If you tell me who's not adhering to the high standards you yourself live by, I will deal with them. Your education is too important to risk letting them run rampant.” 

 

 “Besides,” she continues, lowering her voice to a whisper. “With Prom coming up, I need to take a step back. The girls here are smart, but they need a leader. Someone to come in, set-up the club when I can’t make it, provide direction for the girls, and report back to me when necessary.”

 She stares back at you, judging your reaction intently. You nod.

 

 “If that sounds like something you’d be interested in, you just need to prove you have what it takes. And it should go without saying, my best pupil will not be getting anything other than a top grade in my class.” 

 

 You mull over what DeBussy is implying. This would definitely help Emily. Plus, you’d be left alone to run in the classroom when DeBussy wasn’t here. Alone. 

 

 “So,” DeBussy says, her voice back to her usual shrill volume. “Can you think of anything now?”

 
 
 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 DeBussy flicks through her notebook, reviewing the notes she’s made from what you’ve told her. “Very good, Emily,” she comments. “Very good indeed. You’ve painted quite the picture.”

 

 She smiles at you and turns around to the other girls to bellow in her shrill voice. “Excuse me, ladies. I have an announcement. As you know, with Prom coming up I’m feeling a little stretched. Thankfully, I appear to have been blessed with a solution.

 

 “I’m excited to tell you that in my absence, Emily will be stepping in to make sure the good work that you do here continues. I’m sure you’ll all agree that Emily’s contributions recently have showcased exactly the type of diligence we need to maintain the calibre of education you expect at Charlton.”

 

 Somewhat surprisingly to you, the girls look at you with excited smiles and give you a quick applause. You feel a sense of camaraderie from them that you weren’t even aware you were building.

 

 DeBussy turns to you and holds out a key in her hand. “This is a key to the classroom. As club president, you can come and go as you please. I can’t wait to hear about your next meeting. And naturally, I’ll be taking into consideration the workload of your extra duties when marking your coursework."

 

 You thank her and take the key, looking at it. You hope it’s worth the price you paid.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 DeBussy smiles at you sweetly, standing up with her notebook in one hand and a pen in the other. “Anything comes to mind?” she asks.

 

 You look back at the teacher, who waits patiently. The question is, what do you want to tell her?
 
 

 Actions

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 <>

 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 

 “Very well,” DeBussy says, lowering her book. “Let’s see what you come up with next time. Don’t be a dilly-dallier though, Emily. I need to decide soon who’s going to take over for me.”

 

 With that, DeBussy moves back over to the other students and listens in to their conversations, taking notes as they chatter.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “Jake Duncan cheats at the town gym," you tell her. "He hides small weights in-between bigger ones so it looks like he can lift more."

 

 DeBussy gives you a withering look, trying to muster a smile. "Really dear? That's... interesting."

 

 She waits for you, expecting you to continue. You notice that she doesn't write anything in her book. This must not be something she's looking for.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I saw Reagan go into one of the rooms at the Charlton Hotel,” you begin. “With Mr. Harrow.”

 DeBussy looks up from her book and a wide, incredulous smile creeps across her face. “Reagan Archer?”

 You nod. DeBussy titters and scribbles down a note in her book. “Oh my.”

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Michelle gets extra help from Mr. Rogers, after school,” you say to DeBussy. “That’s how she’s doing well in Maths.”

 DeBussy frowns. “And what do you mean by extra help?”

 You find yourself blushing. “I couldn’t say. I’ve not seen her in there.”

 A knowing smile spreads on DeBussy’s face. “I see,” she says, writing an unseen comment in her book. “I shall have to look into Mr. Rogers's approach to tutorage.”

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Olaf, the janitor, gives favours to girls if they pose for pictures,” you tell her.

 

 “What sort of favours?” DeBussy asks you. 

 

 “Anything he can get them,” you reply. “He has access to most places in the school.”

 

 “And the photos?” she asks, lowering her voice. “Are they… inappropriate?”

 

 You nod. “He hangs them up in the basement.”

 

 DeBussy scribbles down a note. “I shall see to this immediately,” she tells you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Heather Oats stays behind to clean the gym every night.”

 

 DeBussy looks to you, expecting more. “And? Mr. Beach is known for using punishments to inspire fitness.”

 

 You take a small breath. “I don’t think it’s just cleaning she does in there with Mr. Beach.”

 

 The business studies teacher purses her lips and makes a note in her book. “I imagine you’re not the only person who’s noticed this transgression?”

 

 You shrug. DeBussy mumbles, then says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I spoke to Terrence,” you begin. “He told me he’s confused. About his sexuality.”
 
 

 This grabs DeBussy’s attention. “Oh really?” 

 

 You nod. She eyes you for a moment, then writes something down in her book. “I’ll speak to Nurse Rancy,” she says as she writes. “He needs someone to talk to.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Well, Logain is trying to steal your notebook,” you tell her casually.

 

 She titters, smiling. “That one doesn’t surprise me. He’s a spirited lad. We all wonder what he’ll get up to next.”

 

 You pause, waiting for her to write. For some reason, she doesn’t note this one down.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Elizabeth Pleasant is looking into the occult,” you tell DeBussy. “She’s reading all sorts of things online. And is trying to practice it.”

 

 DeBussy snorts, derisively. “The things unpopular girls do for attention. But unapproved texts are not a laughing matter. I shall look into this, immediately.”

 

 She writes a note down in her book.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Dennis trades photos with the janitor for access to locked rooms in the school.”

 “What sort of photos?” DeBussy asks with concern.

 “Photos inside changing areas, as if from the vents. Or above the cubicles in the girls' toilets."

 DeBussy’s smile drops as she grinds her teeth. “I shall have to look into this. That is repugnant.” 

 She scribbles down a note in her book.

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I don't know if you'd be interested in this," you say, hesitantly.

 

 “I'm sure I would, dear.” DeBussy says, all-too quickly. "It sounds important."

 

 “The receptionist at Thompson's Repairs. She's having lunchtime meetings with her boss. In a private room at the Charlton Hotel."

 

 DeBussy’s smile widens, almost reveling in the scandal. "You did a good thing in telling me. Annie Clancy is a graduate of Charlton. We need to ensure former students maintain our standards. Even after graduating.”

 

 She scribbles down a note in her book.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

Tell her you have nothing more right now

title: BusinessStudiesCurse
text:
**Charlton School - Business Studies Room**

 [image: ./images/School_Business_Studies_Room.png]

 
The business studies room looks similar to every other classroom at the school, except for one thing. On every other desk there are clunky black typewriters, with paper stacked up neatly beside each one.

 

 You walk into the room, cautious and quiet, fearing that DeBussy could return any moment.

 

 
 
 Before you have a chance to look for the source of the curse, you spy DeBussy’s notebook, left haphazardly on her desk.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <> 
 
 **Actions**

 <>
 
 

 
 
 You pick up the book and hurriedly put it into your school bag, not wanting to spend more time than is necessary where you know you shouldn’t be.
 
 
 You decide to leave the book where it is, turning your attention back to the reason you’ve come into a room that could spell trouble for you if you’re caught.

 
 

 
 Conjuring up some of your magical power, you look around the room using its foresight. It’s not long until you see yellow strands of magic glowing on each desk. Though as you approach the first row, you realise you should have been more specific. 

 

 Only the desks with typewriters seem to emanate energy. You glance down at the archaic devices, noting the glow comes from tiny jagged embers pointing up like pins on each of the keys. 

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 

 Actions

 
 
 <>
 
 <>

title: BusinessStudiesCurse1
text:
Closing your eyes, you draw up a ball of magic inside of your body. You mentally shape it, roll it, increase its form. 

Slowly at first, but increasing in speed as it grows, the magical ball expands across the classroom. 

 “I cause this object with power beyond its power,” you say. “Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by all but me.”

 

 Your eyes open. Like an uncanny dance routine, the thousands of tiny magic pins vibrate from side to side in synchronisation. 

 

 Only when you move your hands towards one of the typewriters does it become apparent how you’ve impacted the curse. As your fingers come close to the keys, the prickly embers retract back into the keyboard, giving you free reign to use the device.

 

 Of course, when you move away, the pins shoot back up, ready for their next victim.

 “I cause this object with power beyond its power,” you say. “Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by none.”

 

 Your eyes open. Thousands of magical tiny pins shake and vibrate on each typewriter, in sync as they wither. You cover your ears as you think you can hear each one cry out in a shrill, high-pitched whimper. Then they dissolve away to nothing.

 

 Looking over the typewriters again, you can feel only the faintest of auras underneath the keys. A signifier that whilst the curse is technically still present, its effect is no more.

title: SchoolCafeteriaLunch
text:
You carry your tray over to an empty table and sit down, staring at the food. Your stomach gurgles again, in spite of what’s in front of you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 <>

 Hunger gets the better of you. You begin eating your bland salad, gaining satisfaction only from satisfying your stomach. There is little to taste, nor savour.
 
 Hunger gets the better of you. You begin eating your gristly steak and boiled potatoes. In spite of the fat, you find yourself almost enjoying the satisfaction of eating something substantial.

 Hunger gets the better of you. You begin eating your burger and chips. In spite of the grease, you find yourself almost enjoying the satisfaction of eating something substantial.

 

 
 With the food no longer cursed at least for you, your lunch causes you no adverse side effects. You look around the room, noticing other students aren’t so lucky. Girls, all munching on salads, are smiling and vacantly listening to the boys prattle and horseplay.

 

 You notice the boys chow down on their burgers and meat casseroles, barely stopping to swallow. Crumbs spit out of their mouths as they talk, but none of the girls seem bothered by their disgusting table manners. They stare back, blankly, enraptured.

 

 You finish your lunch and spend the rest of the break watching people. When the bell rings, you get your belongings and prepare to leave.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 With the curse not active, you eat free from any magical impacts. Looking around the cafeteria, you note that other people’s behaviour has changed. Girls have pushed their trays of salad away from them, with a few even stealing some of the boys' burgers. 

 

 The boys, conversely, seem off their game. They engage with their typical horseplay and banter, but girls roll their eyes and look back at them derisively. Most are just ignoring them.

 

 You finish your lunch, feeling at least partially satisfied from the bland food. When the bell goes, most of the girls leave promptly. The guys watch after them, looking dumbfounded.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 After a few mouthfuls, you find yourself smiling faintly. It’s delicious, really. So healthy. Exactly what you need. Why would you have ever thought otherwise?

 

 A shadow falls across your tray. Brendan Glove leans down, thigh pressed almost against your arm, grinning broadly. “Hey. Haven’t seen you before. You new?”

 

 You look up at him, nerves fluttering, and nod quickly. “Yes. Just trying to fit in.”

 

 His grin widens. “You should come by the football field after school. I’ll be there.”

 

 The suggestion feels more like a command, and you feel warmth spread in your chest at the thought. “Of course,” you answer instantly. 

 

 He laughs softly, satisfied, and strides away. You keep watching until he’s gone, cheeks warm, heart pounding. Maybe you should go see him on the field. After all, he told you to. Why wouldn’t you?

 

 The bell interrupts your thoughts, leaving you clutching your tray, eager for the day to be over.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 After a few mouthfuls, you grow accustomed to the taste. Actually, it’s kind of nice, you decide, surprised by your own thought. Good for you, good for keeping in shape. Maybe you shouldn’t complain so much.

 

 You glance up as Brendan Glove, one of the football players, looms over you. He plants a foot on the bench beside you, leaning close, grin wide. “Hey,” he says. “Don’t think I’ve seen you before. You new?”

 

 His leg is right there, filling your space. You ought to object, but the words won’t come. Instead you give him a quick smile. “Yeah. Just keeping quiet.”

 

 “That’s good,” he replies, eyes raking over you. “You should come by the field after school. We can hang out.”

 

 You hesitate, but it feels easier just to nod. “Alright.”

 

 Brendan grins at your answer before sauntering off. You watch him go, pulse quickening. He wants you there, you think. So shouldn’t you go?

 

 The bell rings, leaving you unsettled at how quickly you agreed.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 After a few mouthfuls, you grow accustomed to the taste. It’s not so bad, you think. At least it’s healthy. Good for your waistline.

 

 You begin to ponder where that thought came from, but are pulled out of your thoughts by Brendan Glove, one of the football players, looking down on you. 

 

 He puts a foot up on the bench, leaning forward, grinning. “Hey,” he says. “I don’t think I’ve seen you around before. You new here?”

 

 Personal space must not be a concept Brendan has been introduced to, as his muscular thigh is uncomfortably close to you. Part of you feels like saying something, but you don’t want to offend him.

 

 “A little,” you say. “I just keep my head down.”

 

 “You can keep your head down for me, anytime,” he replies, giving you a leery look. “You should come see me after school on the football field. We can hang out.”

 

 “Okay,” you find yourself replying, in spite of having no intention of doing so.

 

 He grins, then nods to you and walks off.

 

 You watch him go. Maybe you will go and see him, you think. After all, he did tell you to.

 

 Lost in thought for the rest of the lunch break, you are only drawn away from considering Brendan by the bell.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 The more you eat, the more you find yourself enjoying it. Your stomach feels warm from the nutrients. A new surge of energy spreads throughout your body, the reward for eating something rich with iron.

 

 You look around as you eat. Girls, all munching on salads, are smiling and vacantly listening to the boys prattle and horseplay.

 

 In fact, the boys chow down on their burgers and meat casseroles, barely stopping to swallow. Crumbs spit out of their mouths as they talk, but none of the girls seem bothered. They stare back, blankly, enraptured.

 

 Then you feel it. A piece of steak falling out of your open mouth. You are barely chewing before forcing half a potato into your hole. The ravenous feeling of hunger surges you on, shovelling more of the food into your mouth before you swallow.

 

 A girl glances over you, watching. A tingle of Dennis' nerves shoots up inside your body, but you find yourself grinning back at her. Even as you feel the fat spread around your lips.

 

 She stares at you vacantly. Then, after a moment, actually smiles.

 

 You finish your lunch and spend the rest of the break watching people. All the while smirking. When the bell rings, you get your belongings and prepare to leave.

title: SchoolCafeteriaMichelleDialogue0
text:
Michelle throws you a dark look as you approach. It’s clear she doesn’t want to speak to you.
 
 
 Michelle perks up and smiles as you approach. “Oh hey Em! Do you want to join me for lunch? You have to tell me everything that’s going on with you!”

 

 You slide in next to Michelle, shivering as your bare thighs touch the plastic bench underneath the table. She smiles impishly, leaning in to you, resting her chin on her delicate hands.

 
 
 
*You appraise Michelle as a target for increasing your position in the pecking order. She’s perky and pretty, but comes across as too eager to be accepted. You also know a secret about her that would destroy her reputation. And Emily’s relationship with her, if you care.*

 
 
 You drift toward Michelle’s table. She looks up, startled for a moment, then smooths her expression into a small, polite smile.

 

 “Dennis,” she says lightly, tucking a curl of hair behind her ear. “Hello.”

 

 Her eyes flick quickly around the cafeteria, scanning the room. There’s no invitation for you to sit. If anything, she shifts her tray a little closer, as though to signal the seat beside her isn’t free.

 

 After a pause, she adds, “Um… did you need something? Can I help you?” Her voice is pleasant enough, but there’s a tension in it. The sort that says she’s worried about who might be watching.

 

 You can feel the awkwardness tightening between you. Polite words, but no warmth. Michelle doesn’t want this conversation with you.

 

 You decide to let it go.
 
 
 The cafeteria hums with chatter and the clatter of trays. Michelle is seated alone at one of the smaller tables, her books stacked neatly to one side. She looks up as you approach.

 

 For a heartbeat her eyes widen with a flicker of surprise. It soon changes into something else. Her lips part, then press together again as she tucks a curl of hair behind her ear, trying to mask the rush of color to her cheeks.

 

 “Jake,” she says quietly, the word more breath than voice. Her gaze briefly flicks across the room toward the cheerleaders and to Christina. The squad is gathered by the windows, their laughter carrying easily over the din.

 

 “You… wanted something?” she asks carefully.
 
 
 Michelle smiles at you, waiting for you to speak.

title: SchoolChangingRoomTryouts
text:
"I'd be careful out there, 'shell," you tell her with a cold smile. "You're a bit clumsy. Don't push yourself too far."

 

 Michelle's eyes burn with rage, as she visibly holds her tongue. "I'll outperform you, Emily Phillips. Just you wait."

 

 "I don't think so," you chide her. "All that exercise you get in Mr. Rogers's special lessons won't really help you here."

 

 "You bitch," Michelle snaps back at you. For a moment, you actually think she's going to swing at you. Instead, she storms out of the changing room.

 

 You allow yourself a smile. Adjusting your trainers for a final time, you follow her out.

 
 “Christina has high expectations,” you tell Michelle. “You need to put everything in if you want to get on the team.”

 

 Michelle’s perpetual smile fades a little as she considers your words. “You’re right, Em. Of course you’re right. I won’t hold back. You’re such a good friend!”

 

 She grabs your hand and leads you out of the changing rooms, giggling with anticipation as she moves. “Let’s go get ‘em.”

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 You turn away from Michelle, focusing on pulling on your trainers and smoothing down your clothes. Without your engagement, Michelle says nothing more.

 

 With a final check on your trainers, you head towards the locker room door. Michelle quickly follows, chasing you out.
 
 
 “Just be careful out there,” you say to her. “I’ve heard cheerleading is surprisingly demanding. You don’t want to risk getting hurt.”

 

 Michelle nods, eagerly. “Of course, Em. You’ll watch out for me, won’t you? Let me know if you think I’m doing anything wrong?”

 

 You give her a reassuring smile. “Of course. What are friends for?”

 

 She giggles and smiles. “This is going to be so much fun. We’re going to remember this forever, I know it!”

 

 Michelle grabs your hand and leads you out of the changing rooms, a clumsy skip in her step as she goes.

title: SchoolChangingRoomShower
text:
You decide to play it safe. Scooping up your belongings, you turn and walk quickly to the exit, ignoring some of the curious expressions from the other girls as you pass by. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 You take a deep breath and begin to strip. You put your dirty gym clothes away and grab a towel from the locker, wrapping it around your body from your breasts downwards. Like a girl, you think.

 

 Moving towards the shower room, you feel the pleasant warm steam on your skin. You hang up your towel and quietly enter, standing underneath an unoccupied shower head and turn it on.

 

 Water sprays down over your body, and you use some nearby soap to clean yourself. As you do so, you can’t help but notice the other girls, all naked, all showering as matter-of-factly as each other. Bums. Boobs. Legs. Vaginas. You see it all.

 

 You feel your heart beating. These are all real women who you might see in a bar or club. They might even go home with someone. But that you are here, posing as someone you’re not, makes you feel seedy and lecherous.

 

 Emily wouldn’t find this out of the ordinary, a thought pops into your brain.

 

 As you continue to wash, you mull over that. None of the other girls seem concerned, by your presence or anyone else's. You glance down at your own body. You have the same parts and curves on display. It’s not so unnatural, is it?

 

 “You might want to get that checked out,” the girl next to you says, smiling politely. You follow her eyes to a blemish on your arm. 

 

 She turns back to you and reaches over her shoulder with her hand, pointing out a tiny scar below her shoulder. “I spent too long lounging outside at the country club this summer. Doctor Palmer said it was probably nothing, but cut out a blemish just in case. Beauty is our greatest asset, as they say.”

 

 She grins at you and turns back to cleaning. You watch her for a moment, then return to showering, feeling a slight warmth from the unexpected camaraderie.

 

 Once you’ve showered you walk back through to Emily’s locker, your body wrapped up in a towel. As you get changed back into your school uniform, you feel just a bit less conscious about being in the room with other girls.

 You nod, taking in her words. She folds her arms, watching you with a mix of fascination and unease. “So. What now?”

 
 
 Liz glances up from her locker as you approach. She smiles with a lighthearted smirk.

 

 "Oh hi 'Jake'," she says. "How can I help you today?"
 
 
 Liz glances up from her locker as you approach. She smiles with a lighthearted smirk.

 

 "Jake," she mutters. "What do you want?"
 
 
 Liz glances up from her locker as you approach, her pink hair bright even under the corridor’s dim light. Her eyes flick up as you approach and immediately narrow.

title: SchoolCorridorLogainDialogue0
text:
Logain doesn't like you and doesn't want to talk to you. This shouldn't be possible, but let's see.

 
 
 He offers you a grin. “Decided to try and get in the classroom again?”

 

 You give him a cold look.

 
 “What has you sneaking around the quiet corridors after school?” he asks.

 

 “Nothing,” you say, flustering.

 

 He smirks. “And there was me, thinking you might be spying on what really happens in there after school. Funny isn’t it? To hear laughter at Charlton. Makes you wonder what DeBussy is doing in there.”

 

 You eye him carefully. “What do you think?”

 

 He pushes back from the lockers and creeps over to you, glancing at the side of the glazed glass in the door. His tall and masculine frame hangs inches over you. 

 

 “I know a few things,” he says, meeting your eyes. “Like there isn’t any studying going on inside. Or should I say, it's of the social monitoring kind."

 

 He catches your confused look and grins. “Let’s just say that DeBussy’s most promising students do less studying and more tale-telling. Every student’s little secrets, spilt out, given freely and willingly for extra credit. It’s her own little secret service in there.”

 

 “How do you know that?” you ask him, still watching him carefully.

 

 “I have my sources,” he replies. “There’s a notebook that she keeps in her desk. An acquaintance saw it before class. Every little transgression any student has made is jotted down there."

 

 You shrug, almost-convincing. “Why should I care about that?” 

 

 “Maybe you do, maybe you don’t,” he says. “But I think that you have a reason for wanting to get in that classroom. If it’s not the book, it’s something. And I’ll bet you’d prefer to do it uninterrupted.”

 

 You give him a look as you realise he’s got an angle.

 

 Logain waits for you to speak.

title: SchoolCorridorBusinessStudiesDoorInvestigation
text:
You walk cautiously down the school corridor, hearing your heels clatter on the floor as you try in vain to be quiet.

 

 Creeping up to the door, you listen out. Again, you hear the noises of chatter from within. It’s hard to make out distinct voices, aside from the shrill voice of Mrs. DeBussy.

 

 A shadow falls over you from behind. You sigh. “Hello Logain,” you say, turning.

 You make your way to the Business Studies classroom, noticing with apprehension how loud your heels are in the empty corridor. With each step, the echoing sound reminds you of your current footwear. And your current predicament.

 

 Approaching the door to the classroom, you reach out and slowly turn the handle. To your surprise, it turns. You are just about to boldly enter when you hear voices from behind the door.

 

 Instantly, you let go of the handle and freeze. You hear the sounds of Mrs. DeBussy, talking and laughing. Other voices are present but are just murmurs.

 

 “Evening, squirt,” you hear a familiar voice from behind you. 

 

 You turn to see Logain, leaning against the lockers opposite you, grinning. He obviously doesn’t have the same problem with his shoes, you think.

 You make your way to the Business Studies classroom, jumping at every sound and creak that echoes in the corridor. Something makes you feel on edge, threatening to trigger your flight or fight response before even revealing itself to you.

 

 And we both know which of those options you'd take in this form, don't we?

 

 Approaching the door to the classroom, you reach out and slowly turn the handle. To your surprise, it turns. You are just about to boldly enter when you hear voices from behind the door.

 

 Instantly, you let go of the handle and freeze. You hear the sounds of Mrs. DeBussy, talking and laughing. Other voices are present but are just murmurs.

 

 “Brazen, to be peeping so openly,” you hear a familiar voice from behind you say.

 

 You turn to see Logain, leaning against the lockers opposite you, grinning. "Trying to catch a glimpse of DeBussy's informants, Mannet?"

 

 Without a second thought, you feel your eyes dart to look down the corridor. Towards the entrance. Towards safety.

 

 Logain narrows a single eyebrow. "You alright, chump?"

 

 "I've... got to go," you stammer, trying to fight the instinct to run.

 

 Logain shrugs as you dart down the corridor. You don't look back as you flee towards the exit.

 You make your way to the Business Studies classroom, naturally pacing so fast that you have to remind yourself you are trying to be stealthily. You feel almost careless in whether you're caught, irritated by impatience to find out what's going on.
 
 

 Approaching the door to the classroom, you reach out and slowly turn the handle. To your surprise, it turns. You are just about to boldly enter when you hear voices from behind the door.

 

 Fighting the urge to barge in, you instead pause and listen. You hear the sounds of Mrs. DeBussy, talking and laughing. Other voices are present but are just murmurs.

 

 “Wrong door for the gym changing room,” you hear a familiar voice from behind you say.

 

 You turn to see Logain, leaning against the lockers opposite you, grinning. "Or you trying to find out what those little swots are really telling DeBussy?"

 

 You flash your teeth at Logain, the gesture coming out as a snarl in spite of your intention. "What do you want, Logain?"

 

 An eyebrow rises. "Logain? We on first-name terms now, sport?"

 

 Studying the other boy, you hesitate for a second to judge him. "Why wouldn't we be?"

 

 Logain smirks. "Quite right. Live and let live. And as we're such pals now, why don't you tell me what you're doing here?"

 

 You find yourself growing irritated by Logain's vague statements and perpetual grin. It almost feels like he's playing with you. You feel your chest tightening. "What's it to you?"

 

 "Just a friendly bit of conversation," he replies. "Between such good friends."

 

 The tightening in your chest coils further. You feel your fingers shake, as if wanting to curl up into a fist.

 

 "I've got to go," you spit. And without a word, you stride off, leaving Logain behind. Uninjured. But the thought of wiping that smug smirk from his face remains with you as you storm down the corridor.

title: SchoolCorridorLocker
text:
Checking that no one is watching, you take out a magic marker and step up to Terrence’s locker.

Unquestionably, exposing his struggles with his feelings in public is despicable. You keep circling back to the justification of needing Christina’s approval in your mind. You brace yourself and consider what to write.

*Girls are made for boys*, you scrawl. But Terrence thinks differently.

To emphasise, you draw a crude dick and balls underneath it. To finish off, you add some drops dripping from the tip.

The permanent marker ink soon dries. You couldn’t rub it off now, even if you wanted to.

You imagine what will happen tomorrow morning when Terrence sees your artwork. And what the other students will do when they see it too.

title: SchoolCorridorTerrenceLocker
text:
You glance around. No teachers. No prefects. No Reagan or Britney lingering nearby.

Sliding the key into the locker, you feel the mechanism click with a quiet snick. The door creaks open.

Inside, Terrence’s locker is a tightly packed mess of textbooks, loose notes, and ballpoint pens chewed down to stubs. Stacks of paper are clipped together in lopsided towers. He’s meticulous, but also chaotic.

You scan quickly. History. Chemistry. Business Studies. Then you spot it: the biology book. The spine is worn, the cover soft from handling.

You flip it open.

The pages are dense with annotations. Detailed diagrams of organs, systems, cellular structures. All marked up with colour-coded notes. Tips, acronyms, revision tricks. Nearly every test question you’ve seen in class has been anticipated and solved in margin notes.

Then something falls out. A small scrap of torn paper, folded in thirds.

You open it. It’s a piece of branded note paper. Evans’ Department Store, the watermark still faintly visible beneath the writing. And the message is handwritten in loopy, careful script. A handwriting you don’t recognise.

Hope this helps you pass your exams. Call Jennifer Chambers. 07452 644521.

 
You freeze. The paper is unsigned, but Jennifer’s name is clear.

You glance down the hallway again, then carefully fold the scrap and slide it back between the pages. You return the biology book to its place, reposition the stack just as you found it, and quietly shut the locker.

Better he doesn’t know you were here. Not yet.

title: SchoolFootballFieldChristinaDialogue0
text:
Christina glares at you as you approach. An eyebrow lifts, almost daring you to speak. In spite of the hostile invitation, you decide to leave her alone.

 
 Christina turns from the cheerleading practice as you approach. She smiles. "Oh hello, Emily. What brings you out on the field?"

 

 You glance over her shoulder, noticing the other cheerleaders eying you cautiously. Britney in particular suddenly seems less interested in exercising and more in trying to hear your conversation.

 

 "No slacking, Britney," Christina barks without turning back to face her. "I can afford the luxury of taking some time out to chat. You, however, need more practice."

 
 Christina stands at the edge of the field, arms folded, blonde ponytail gleaming in the late sun. She’s watching the cheer squad run through their drills, expression cool, calculating.

 

 You hesitate, then step closer.

 

 Her eyes snap to you almost immediately. Those icy blues narrow, taking you in head to toe.

 

 “Dennis.” She says your name like it’s a mistake. Her voice is flat, clipped. “What could you possibly want out here?”

 

 The pause is heavy. Behind her, two cheerleaders glance over, smirk, and return to their stretches. Christina doesn’t even give you that much.

 

 When you don’t answer right away, she tilts her head, lips curving in the faintest, coldest smile. “Thought so.”

 

 She turns her back on you, focus already shifted back to her squad, dismissing you without another word.

 

 It’s clear there’s no point trying again.

 
 Christina stands at the edge of the field, arms folded as she watches the cheer squad run through another set. Her gaze flicks over the girls critically, one hand rising to adjust a ponytail that doesn’t sit quite right. She hardly glances at you as you step closer.

 

 "Jake,” she says, brisk, already turning back to the squad. “We’re in the middle of a routine. This needs my focus.”

 

 For a moment it feels like you’re not even here. Just another distraction to be brushed aside. But then she looks at you properly, and something flickers across her face. A calculation.

 

 Her lips curve into a slow, knowing smile. “Later this week. My parents are out.” A gleam lights her eyes, the promise unspoken but unmistakable. “We’ll have the house to ourselves. We can talk then. Among other things.”

 

 She lets the words hang, before turning back to her squad with a crisp clap of her hands. The girls shuffle back into formation, her attention already reclaimed by them.

 

 “Britney! How many times do I have to tell you that pouting is not a cheerleader motion!” 

 

 You’re left standing at the edge of the field, the promise lingering like perfume, designed to keep you close even as she walks away.
 

 Christina stands facing you, a pleasant smile across her face. Behind her, the rest of the cheerleaders run through their drills.

 Hey, boy, don’t you see what I got?

 Living for the moment, give it all that I’ve got.*

 

 You hear laughter from the bleachers, but with a quick glance you see the football players are prattling around. They are paying no attention to you.

 

 Michelle watches from off to the side. You give her a wry smile and you watch as she mimics your actions. I can’t believe a girl is trying to compete with me dancing.

 Michelle watches from off to the side. You give her an encouraging smile and she mimics your actions. She’s a bit too enthusiastic still, but she beams with delight. I can’t believe a girl is following my lead in dancing.

 Flaunt it, flaunt it, let the whole world see,

 This is our time, just you and me!*

 Michelle gives you a look, then nervously copies your actions. But exhausted, she doesn’t have the upper arm strength left. As she drops down her face plunges into the ground.

 

 The boys stop cheering and start laughing. You even see Christina smiling with menacing satisfaction.

 

 Michelle rolls back on to her back, panting, her face red with embarrassment.

 “Sorry ‘shell,” Christina tells her. “Like I said, there’s only one spot on the team.”

 

 You watch Michelle, crestfallen. She lets out a gentle sniff. “I understand,” she says quietly. “Thanks for letting me try out. Congratulations, Emily.”

 

 Christina gives her a sympathetic smile, then turns over to the bleachers. “Show’s over. Time to get back to it.” There’s some mutterings from Stacey, Britney and Reagan, but begrudgingly they begin to walk over to the field. “I’ll see you at lunchtime,” Christina tells you, before joining them.

text:
You lean against the stone pillar next to the entrance, mindful to stay out of sight from the school windows. The courtyard is quiet. Only a few students drift past, tossing curious glances as they leave. 

 

 Terrence emerges slowly, pausing mid-step when he sees you. His breath catches for a split second before he steadies himself, clearing his throat. 

 

 “Hi there,” you say, offering a gentle smile. 

 

 He returns your smile, though it’s tentative, as if he’s unsure whether you’ll smile back. “Emily, isn't it?” he ventures, voice soft, eyes flicking down at your feet before meeting your gaze again. 

 

 His hands fidget at his sides, fingers brushing his backpack strap as he stands, body turned slightly toward you yet laced with hesitation. 
 
 
 You lean against the stone pillar next to the entrance, mindful to stay out of sight from the school windows. At this time of day the school is unusually quiet. As you wait only a handful of students exit, giving you a cursory glance as they pass by. 

 

 After a while you catch the sight of Terrence hurriedly rushing across the school yard. He jumps into the air at the sight of you.

 

 “Hi there,” you say, smiling pleasantly. 

 

 “Hi,” he says hurriedly, his eyes looking around. 

 

 “Terrence, right?”

 

 He nods, quickly. “That’s right. You’re Emily.” It’s less of a question than a statement. 

 

 Terrence looks at you, but his eyes keep drifting to look up and down the street. 
 
 
 You lean against the stone pillar next to the entrance, mindful to stay out of sight from the school windows. Terrence appears around the corner, walking with deliberate ease. His shoulders are relaxed, and he offers you a steady, confident smile as he approaches. 

 

 “Hi there,” you say, smiling pleasantly. 

 

 He holds your gaze immediately. “Emily, isn't it?” he asks, voice calm and warm, eyes bright with interest. In you.

 

 His posture is open, one hand casually tucked into his pocket as he studies your face, as if memorizing every detail. 
 
 
 You wait for Terrence to finish his detention, keeping out of sight from anyone looking from any one of the many windows looking down over the school yard. 

 

 After what seems like an eternity, Terrence emerges. As is customary for him, he jumps when you emerge from hiding. 

 

 “Hey Em,” he says, after regaining his composure. “Are you okay?”
 
 
 You wait for Terrence to finish his detention, heart in your throat as you press back into the shadows beneath the windows. 

 

 When he finally appears, he freezes for a moment and gives a little jump as he sees you. He rubs the back of his neck, gaze flicking between your face and the empty yard. 

 

 “Um. Hey, Em,” he murmurs, voice low and hesitant. His eyes look at you with nervousness. “Are… you okay?”

 
 You wait for Terrence to finish his detention, keeping out of sight from any of the windows looking down over the school yard. 

 

 At last he strides out of the main doors, shoulders squared and eyes immediately locking onto you. He doesn’t jump this time. Instead, he offers a confident half-smile as if he’s been looking forward to seeing you. 

 

 “Hey, Em,” he says, voice warm and steady. You notice his eyes wander up and down your frame. “Good to see you. How’ve you been?”
