 A crack of a hardback book brings you out of your daydream. You look up to see Mr. Rogers towering over you. 

 

 "Pay attention, Miss. Phillips," he barks at you. "Or have you already accepted you'll be spending your adult life writhing around a pole?"

 

 There are a few muted gasps from the other students. Rogers eyes you darkly. You meet his eyeline, unflinching.

 

 The moment passes and Mr. Rogers walks away, leaving you to do the lesson. You sit there, feeling the eyes of the other students watching you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You stare at the pictures in your book, but your mind begins to drift. You wonder what sort of school uses baking and flower decorating to teach maths. Then a voice whispers inside your brain what you already know. This sort of school.

 

 A crack of a hardback book brings you out of your daydream. You look up to see Mr. Rogers towering over you.

 

 “It seems someone didn’t learn their lesson in detention,” he says, loud enough for the class to hear. “Or perhaps you think the rules don’t apply to you, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 You look back at him, saying nothing.

 

 “This behaviour will not be permitted to continue. See me after class.”

 

 He turns on his heels and strides back away. You hear some murmurings from other students, but you avoid their gaze.

 

 The lesson continues uninterupted and soon the bell rings. Other students gather their belongings, but you remain seated. Within a minute, only you and Mr. Rogers stay.

 

 He walks over to the door and closes it, then walks over. You remain sitting at your desk as the teacher puts his hands on each side of it and looks down at you.

 

 “It seems my last intervention has not borne fruit,” he tells you with barely concealed frustration in his voice. “Now. You have a choice. You can either submit to my after school tutorage. Or.” He pauses, considering his words. “Let’s just say you don’t want to choose the other option.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 You stare at the pictures in your book, focusing on the panicked faces of the housewives. They seem to be looking at you, begging for help in solving their kitchen-specific fractions and percentages.

 

 Actually, they seem to be talking to you. Pleading for you to tell them how to use the right amount of ingredients for their recipes. Squeaking, shrill voices, full of nervousness and worry. The clocks in their kitchens are ticking down to when their husbands will get home from work. Tick. Tick. Tick –

 

 Something slams down on your desk and you jolt up, suddenly realising that you had drifted off. Mr. Rogers hand claps on to a thick exercise book, which he clearly struck your desk with.

 

 “I see my lessons continue to tire you, Miss. Phillips. Or perhaps you just find these exercises challenging to the point of exhaustion.”

 

 You go to speak, but he holds out his hand. “Save your excuses, young lady. We shall discuss them in detention this evening.”

 

 Rogers gives you a final look, then walks off. Soon, the bell rings for the end of the lesson. You realise that you must have slept through the majority of his class.

 

 You gather up your things and join the rest of the students leaving the classroom. Mr. Rogers watches you as you go.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 You can’t help yourself. With the need to focus on something other than the book, you glance up.

 

 Immediately, the clock is in your eyeline. As you hear your neck crack, your eyes lock on to it. You watch as the second hand moves around the face, hearing the faint tick, tick, tick as time slips by.

 

 A finger taps against your desk. You look up to see Rogers looking down at you, an eyebrow raised. “Pay attention, Miss. Phillips. Second question in your book. What percentage of the roses and lilies would you need an even number of flowers in the vase?”

 

 You glance back at your book. Once again, in spite of the subject matter, the question is rooted in maths. This time, even though your haziness had evaporated, the answer perplexes you.

 

 You struggle for the remainder of the lesson, trying to answer basic maths questions that seem so simple at first-glance. True, they are all about flower arranging and cake making, but the core to each is percentiles and fractions that should come second nature to you.

 

 When the bell rings finally, you are relieved to be leaving the maths class behind you. You gather up your belongings and join the rest of the students exiting the door. You catch sight of Mr. Rogers watching you leave, a thin smile painted across his lips.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 You lean back in your chair, looking at Rogers. He stops as he reaches your desk and meets your eyes. His eyes briefly flick to your unanswered exercise book, then back you.

 

 
 "Pay attention, Miss. Phillips," he barks at you. "Or do you want to find yourself back in detention this evening?"

 

 His cold smile may appear normal to the other students, but to you there's something more shared between you.

 

 The moment passes and Mr. Rogers walks away, leaving you to do the lesson. He says nothing more about joining him after school. As if he's content to leave you to decide for yourself.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 "Pay attention, Miss. Phillips," he barks at you. "Or do you want to find yourself back in detention this evening?"

 

 His cold smile may appear normal to the other students, but to you there's something more shared between you.

 

 The moment passes and Mr. Rogers walks away, leaving you to do the lesson. He says nothing more about joining him after school. As if he's content to leave you to decide for yourself.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 "Pay attention, Miss. Phillips," he barks at you. "Or have you already accepted you'll be spending your adult life writhing around a pole?"

 

 There are a few muted gasps from the other students. Rogers eyes you darkly. You meet his eyeline, unflinching.

 

 The moment passes and Mr. Rogers walks away, leaving you to do the lesson. You sit there, feeling the eyes of the other students watching you.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “It seems someone didn’t learn their lesson in detention,” he says, loud enough for the class to hear. “Or perhaps you think the rules don’t apply to you, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 You look back at him, saying nothing.

 

 “This behaviour will not be permitted to continue. See me after class.”

 

 He turns on his heels and strides back away. You hear some murmurings from other students, but you avoid their gaze.

 

 The lesson continues uninterupted and soon the bell rings. Other students gather their belongings, but you remain seated. Within a minute, only you and Mr. Rogers remain.

 

 He walks over to the door and closes it, then walks over. You remain sitting at your desk as the teacher puts his hands on each side of it and looks down at you.

 

 “It seems my last intervention has not borne fruit,” he tells you with barely concealed frustration in his voice. “Now. You have a choice. You can either submit to my after school tutorage. Or.” He pauses, considering his words. “Let’s just say you don’t want to choose the other option.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 “Taking a break, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 Full of confidence, you can’t help but smile innocently back at him. He glances down at your exercise book and rolls his lips when he sees your empty answer box.

 

 “So. You enjoy wasting my time, do you?” he says, annoyance creeping into his words. “Very well, Miss. Phillips. Two can play at that game. I too enjoy wasting people’s time. Specifically, yours. I’ll see you for detention this evening.”

 

 He gives you a hard stare, then walks past. You look around to see some of your classmates eying you, an equal mix of fear and admiration.

 

 You spend the rest of the class doodling in the answer boxes. You pack up your things when the bell rings and leave the room with everyone else, giving Rogers a pleasant smile as you walk by his desk.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You scrunch your notes into a tight wad and flick it back across the room. Jake catches it square in the chest. He looks up quickly and meets your eyes, a hint of surprise that quickly evaporates into dark glee.

 

 Another ball comes your way. No doubt this one is soaked with saliva. You duck and roll another from your workbook, gobbing into the sheet. Soon it’s back and forth. Spit-soaked missiles arcing behind Rogers’ back. Each hit spurs the next. The sniggers of the class turn sharper, egging you both on.

 

 Jake hurls one that smacks your cheek, wet enough to sting. You grit your teeth, twist the top from your pen, and jam the nib into a fresh ball. Ink seeps through the paper, dark and heavy.

 

 You stare down at the paper, now dripping with ink. Something surges up inside you. It could be endorphins. Testosterone. Or at Charlton, maybe even some kind of magic. But the outcome is the same. You want to see this ink-soaked paper hit Jake right in the face.

 

 Do it.

 

 You pull your hand back behind your head and launch the projectile across the classroom. It flicks overhead of desks, drops of ink spraying out over other boys, before landing right on top of a shocked Jake Duncan.

 

 The aim isn't perfect, but you watch as your near-miss is even better. Ink spatters across Jake’s white shirt, spreading in a blot. Jake looks down at it in disbelief. Cheers erupt from the classroom.

 

 “Enough!” Rogers’ voice cracks across the room. He wheels around and instantly there is silence. Over the spectacles his eyes scan each and every student. You shudder when he meets yours and inwardly sigh when he moves on. 
 

 Then his eyes lock on Jake, the ink still spreading. “Bathroom. Now," he barks. "Scrub that off before you ruin the uniform entirely.”

 

 Jake starts to protest, but Rogers cuts him off. "Enough, Master Duncan! I don't care who your father is. I won't have tomfoolery in my classroom!"

 

 The silence grows icy. With his jaw tight, Jake slams his book shut and storms out.

 

 A few boys smirk. One even mutters approval. You feel it wash over you. A spark of respect and the warm rush of having won. For a moment, you can almost see Jake hunched at the sink, cursing as he scrubs at the ink.

 

 
 You are taken out of your daydream by one of the girls staring at you with disdain. At meeting her eyes, she looks away and shakes her head. Her derision takes a little of the wind out of your sails, but the next backslap from one of the boys makes up for it. For the moment, you feel you fit in.

 
 You are taken out of your daydream by the sight of one of the girls, staring blankly ahead. Your smile falters as you look around the room. The boys might be quietly joking and grinning at you with respect, but the girls either just sit there unblinking, or asleep on their desks. It's almost as if they haven't even registered what happened in the classroom. Or Roger's bellow bringing them back from sleep.

 
 
 
 When the bell rings for the end of the lesson, you still manage to smile to yourself as you gather your things. You’ll need to steer clear of Jake later. But right now? Right now, you’ve beaten him.

 

 *Feels good, doesn’t it?*
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You bend low over your exercise book, pen scratching down numbers. The noise from the other students fades. Only Rogers’ questions land in your ears. You aren't passing up this opportunity. For once, you can actually think.

 

 Another wet wad thuds against your shoulder. Then another. This time against the back of your head. You ignore it, keeping your eyes on the page.

 

 More follows. Spit-damp, flicked with practiced aim. One bounces off your hand, smearing the ink across your answer. Another smacks your cheek and clings there for a second before sliding down. The boys laugh, high and mean.

 

 Then something harder skims across your arm. You wince, looking down at the sudden pain. A shard of broken plastic protractor scrapes across your skin, leaving a thin red line that stings. But you grit your teeth and keep writing.

 

 Rogers drones on, oblivious. The lesson grinds forward, problem after problem, and you work each one through, steady and stubborn. Bits more of the protractor are launched at you, now evidently shared by the football players. A spread of rough plastic shards hits the back of your neck from all angles. You look back and scowl, but this only encourages them further.

 

 
 Hoping for aid, you look around the room for anyone paying attention. A few of the other boys are keeping their heads down, not making eye contact. As for the girls, they sometimes look up from their books at your yelps. But for the most part, they offer disinterested looks, almost irritated by the disruption.

 
 Hoping for aid, you look around the room for anyone paying attention. A few of the other boys are keeping their heads down, not making eye contact. As for the girls, they are either staring blankly ahead, waving pens around on their books idly drawing circles, or in a few cases are sound asleep. It's almost as if they haven't even registered what is happening in the classroom. Those sitting behind you look through you, not meeting your eye.

 
 
 
 The shame bites and you feel heat in your ears. But you keep your eyes fixed on the desk while laughter rattles around you. In spite of the bullying, for the first time in this lesson you can actually solve these math problems.

 

 The bell finally cuts the air. Chairs scrape back. As you gather your belongings, another crumpled missile skids across the desk. You side-step a footballer’s leg stretching out to trip you, slipping past without breaking stride.

 

 Your arm stings. Your shirt is blotched with spit. But your book holds neat rows of answers, and that feels like victory. Just about.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You take the ink cartridge from your desk. It is small and heavy, the pierced hole dark where the key went through. For a second you feel the classroom close around you. The scrape of pens. The steady tick above the board. Dennis’s bent shoulders.

 

 Without another thought, you flick your wrist.

 

 The ink smacks into the middle of Dennis' back with a wet thud. It bursts. Black blooms across his shirt and spatters his open workbook. His pencil jerks, scoring a crooked streak down the page. He goes rigid, as if bracing for a blow that has already landed.

 

 Manny barks a laugh that draws attention. A couple of boys join in, whistles and short jeers. Chairs creak as they shift to see. Dennis tries to look at the blot on his back, fingers trembling around his own pen. His awkwardness more awkward by his lack of agility.

 

 At the edges of the room, a few girls glance up, voices low and fast. They glance between you and Dennis. Some roll their eyes.

 Most of the girls do not stir. Their pens drag. Eyes half-lidded, faces slack in the clock’s slow pull, they keep working through half-finished questions as if nothing has happened.

 

 “Master Mannet.” Rogers’ voice cuts across the air as he strides between desks. He does not look at you, nor Manny. He stops at Dennis’s table and stares at the mess. “Enough fooling about. Focus.”

 

 Dennis looks as though he's about to object, but only for a moment. Instead, he nods without lifting his head. He hunches over his exercise book and returns to answering questions, as ink spreads over the back of his white shirt. Warmth runs through you and a grin forms. You watch Dennis’s shoulders hitch, the stain soaking into the cotton.

 

 *That will show him. Remind him at least it's not easy street around here just because he's a boy.*

 

 Manny sniggers next to you. "Nerd looks like an ink blot."

 
 
 You glance back at him, a sinking feeling in your stomach forming. He grins back with a sneer, satisfied in your efforts. You glance up at the clock. Whatever you just did, you don't think it was the school's impact on you.

 

 This is not you. The thought arrives sudden and sharp. It was wrong.

 

 *But it felt good, didn’t it?*

 

 You briefly hear the bell ring, summoning you back to reality. As you pack up, in spite of your best efforts some part of you has to agree with that.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You look at the ink cartridge Manny has set on your desk. The black surface is dull, the pierced hole dark where the key went through. It sits there heavy with suggestion.

 

 Your hand twitches. The urge is there, hot and immediate. You want to hurl it into Dennis’s back. To smear the pages he’s scratching through, to show him his efforts are pointless.

 

 But instead, you grip the book a little tighter, keeping your hand away.

 

 Manny watches. The grin fades into a thin sneer. “What, too good for it?” he mutters under his breath.

 

 "Got to get this work done," you mutter back. Manny shoots you a confused stare.

 

 You feel the testosterone surging through your body, as you now try to avoid both looking up at the clock and the ink cartridge on Manny's desk. Not to mention, Dennis, who you're eyes are drawn back to. He sits there, oblivious. Still writing, pencil scratching lines through equations. 
 

 Looking around, you see the girls answering their questions on baking and washing. In spite of the content, they are trying to make do with what they are given. Even if the math in the questions is clearly aimed at a comprehension level way below their age. But with Dennis, he gets the opportunity. Whilst they are set up for failure. It infuriates you.

 Looking around, you see the girls sink further as the clock ticks slowly. They are suffering, barely awake. Some staring vacantly to an unseen horizon, not even present. And Dennis gets to write with immunity, whilst they are set up for failure. It infuriates you.

 
 

 You force your eyes back to the numbers. Fractions blur, but you scrawl them anyway, pushing the irritation down with every mark of the pen. Manny shakes his head, still smirking. The moment passes. Rogers drones on.

 

 The urge to punish Dennis fades. And with it, you feel shame begin to burn. Was that really you? That desire to put him in his place. Or was that some part of this school that you haven't uncovered yet.

 

 *Come on! You wanted to. Don’t pretend you didn’t.*

 

 For the rest of the lesson, you try to bury yourself in work, ignoring the glances you see Manny giving you from the corner of your eye. When the bell rings, he leaves without saying a word.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You quietly sigh. “Fine. I’ll do it.”

 

 “Do what?” he asks you, coldly.

 

 “Submit,” you reply.

 

 He raises an eyebrow, mockingly. “I’m not sure I understand.”

 

 You grit your teeth. “I’ll submit to you. Sir.”

 

 He gives you a smile of victory. “There. Wasn’t so hard now, was it?” 

 

 He reaches into his pocket and takes out a key, placing it on your desk. “Here. You can come and go freely. If I feel you are slipping behind in my class, I will tell you to come by.”

 

 Not taking your eyes off him, you take the key and pocket it.

 

 “Now. You may leave.” He gestures to the door.

 

 Only pausing for the briefest moment, you gather up your belongings and rush towards the door. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I won’t,” you spit out. “Not in a million years.”

 

 Rogers looks down at you, his smile morphing into a sneer. “Fine. I hope you are fulfilled by the kind of the jobs a woman can find without a school diploma. How does stripping sound as career? I hear they’re hiring at Dicks.”

 

 He spins around and strides over to his desk, pulling out paperwork and scrawling furiously. “Get out,” he says without looking up. “And don’t bother with detention.”

 

 After only the slightest hesitation, you scramble up and grab your belongings. Not looking for a second at Mr. Rogers, you bolt out the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: MathsDetention0
text:
After a long few minutes, the silence is broken as the door to the classroom swings open. Mr. Rogers strides in, glancing at you as he enters.

 

 “Ah, Miss. Phillips,” he says coldly. “So glad you could join me.”

 

 Rogers eyes you for a moment longer, then takes out a key and locks the door behind him. You watch as he walks over to his desk, standing behind it. His eyes momentarily roam over your body, lingering on your legs underneath the desk.

 

 “I’ll speak plainly, Miss. Phillips,” he tells you, returning to look at your face. “Your behaviour in class is unacceptable and your marks are well below a passing grade. Fortunately for you, my tutorage after school has proven effective.”

 

 He reaches underneath his desk and you hear a click. When his hands return you see an object resting on his palms. A bamboo school cane, complete with a curved handle.

 

 “It’s quite simple, Miss. Phillips. If you want me to forgive your exploits, and if you wish to pass this class, you will come over here, willingly and without question. And,” he pauses, with a relish for the drama. “Assume the position.”

 

 He taps the cane on the edge of his desk. You feel your heart sink as the situation crystallises for you. Your eyes linger on the cane, and the cold smile of your Maths tutor, as he stares back at you.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>
 
 You stare at him, feeling the conflict pumping through your body. Emily has to graduate, you think.

 

 *Is this the price you're willing to pay for it?*

 

 With a deep sigh, you push back your desk and stand on your heels. Your eyes from the cane in his hand to his icy smile. You know exactly what is in-store for you.

 

 Wordlessly, you move up to the desk. Rogers watches you from the other side, as you put your palms face down and lean over, feeling your skirt rise up your legs as you do so.

 

 Mr. Rogers watches you for a moment as you look up at him. Then he slowly walks around the desk. You begin to watch him move, but he shakes his head.

 

 “Face forward,” he says from behind you.

 

 You stare at the classroom wall behind the desk, but feel his eyes on your body. Conscious of how your skirt hem is tickling your buttocks, aware that your underwear must be at least partially exposed.

 

 “Move your legs wider,” he says. You feel his shoe prod at your Mary Jane heels. You do so, feeling your skirt rising even more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You shake your head. “No. There’s no way I’m doing that.”

 

 Rogers stares back at you, his cold smile not leaving his face. “Are you quite certain, Miss. Phillips?” he asks you. “The world can be an unforgiving place to women who fail to graduate from school.”

 

 You stare back at him, feeling the rage boil inside you. Emily must graduate, you think,

 

 *But is this the price you want to pay for it?*

 

 Pushing your chair back, you stand on your heels. “Unlock the door.”

 

 His smile slowly fades. “Very well,” he mutters. With a swift motion, he returns the cane to where he pulled it out. You hear a click as he fastens it underneath his desk.

 

 Not taking his eyes off you, he walks slowly over to the door. Purposefully he takes the key from his suit pocket, and turns it around in the lock, pulling the door open.

 

 “Good luck, Miss. Phillips,” he says as you walk to the door. “You may find that in future, your grades aren’t as high as you might expect.”

 

 You brush past him as you move past, shuddering as you do so. Your thoughts drift to Emily and how this will affect her, but you are glad to have escaped Rogers grasp. For now.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 WHACK!
 
 

 You feel a surge of pain pulsate out from your bare thigh, between where your socks end and where your underwear covers your bottom. You bite into your bottom lip, trying not to cry out.

 

 WHACK!

 

 Another strike from the cane lands on your skin, this time higher. You feel tears forming. You bite down harder on your lip.

 

 WHACK!

 

 The blow is higher still, falling across the fabric of your underwear. It’s not enough to take the sting out of the strike. You feel your buttocks radiate with heat. 

 

 You tense up, waiting for another sting. But one doesn’t come. Silence hangs in the air.

 

 “Now Miss. Phillips,” you hear Rogers say from behind you. “Tell me. Will you continue to be a bad girl?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 
 
 <>

 
 <> 
 
 
 
 You hold back your words for the longest moment, as thoughts bubble up in your mind. Whether it’s for ulterior motives or not, the pain ebbing from your thighs has touched you deep inside. “Spank me harder,” you whisper to him.

 

 “Spank you harder, what?” you hear Rogers ask, a cold tone to his voice.

 

 “Spank me harder, please,” you say, this time a little louder.

 

 “Please, what?”

 

 You gulp, as you strain to remain standing in this position. “Spank me harder please, sir.”

 

 A crack of the cane strikes against your bottom through your underwear, and this time Rogers is not holding back. You almost slip in your heels, feeling your palms growing sweaty and your balance perilous as you lean forward.

 

 Another blow. Then another. Each time the sudden rush of pain surges through your body. But with it comes a yearning for the next strike. A desire for more. A need to feel helpless and dominated by this man who has authority over you.

 

 You're getting off on it, aren't you?

 

 It’s a question no more when the final strike lands and you hear yourself moan with arousal.

 

 “You may stand up now, Miss. Phillips,” you hear Rogers tell you.

 

 And just like that, it’s all over.

 

 And with some disappointment, I bet

 

 You push yourself back away from the desk, brushing your thighs with your fingers. You wince. The bruising is forming and it’s not small.

 

 The sound of metal scraping across the desk takes your attention and you look up to see Rogers pushing a key towards you. He smiles, a degree of satisfaction on his face. “Take this. My door will be open to you. Anytime you feel you need extra lessons.”

 

 You cautiously pick up the key and put it away. Rogers watches you, then sits down at his desk and takes out some paperwork.

 

 “You may go,” he tells you. “I’ll be seeing you, Miss. Phillips. I look forward to it.”

 

 Without saying anything, you walk to the door and unlock it. Your thighs and bum throb as you walk. What you try to push out of your mind is the other sensations in that region, which are contributing more to your struggles to walk than the pain.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You try to consider what you think Rogers wants to hear. Thoughts rise up inside your mind, each one making you wince and grimace as you consider speaking them out loud. “Spank me harder,” you mutter.

 

 “Spank you harder, what?” you hear Rogers ask, a cold tone to his voice.

 

 “Just... spank me harder,” you try, uncertainty in your voice.

 

 “Ask nicely," you hear Rogers say. "And remember who you are referring to.”

 

 You grit your teeth, straining as you try to remain standing in this position. “Just do it harder,” you whine.

 

 A crack of the cane strikes against your bottom through your underwear. This time, you notice the force is tempered. You barely have to push against the desk to remain upright.

 

 Another blow. Then another. But with each one, there's less effort and passion behind the strokes.

 

 Then, just like that, it's over. “You may stand up now, Miss. Phillips,” you hear Rogers tell you.

 

 You push yourself back away from the desk, brushing your thighs with your fingers. The bruising is swelling, but the pain is minor.

 

 “For a moment, I thought you were finally applying some degree of enthusiasm to something", you hear Rogers say as he walks around the desk and stares back at you. "A pity. But no matter."
 

 "That is the punishment for failing my class,” Rogers says to you. “I will overlook this transgression once. But don’t test my patience again.”

 

 Rogers walks over to the classroom door and unlocks it, opening it wide. “You may go.”

 

 You walk slowly over to the door, your legs shaking with both nerves and the pain. He smiles thinly at you as you pass him, but says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I’ll be good,” you say, holding back tears.

 

 “You’ll be good, what?” you hear him ask.

 

 “I’ll be good, sir,” you tell him.

 

 “Very well,” you hear Rogers say. He walks around the desk, meeting your eyes as you look up, still bent over.

 

 “You may stand,” he tells you, returning his cane underneath his desk.

 

 You push yourself back and stand up, cautiously running your fingers over the bruising that is forming. You yelp when they touch the inflamed areas.

 

 “That is the punishment for failing my class,” Rogers says to you. “I will overlook this transgression once. But don’t test my patience again.”

 

 Rogers walks over to the classroom door and unlocks it, opening it wide. “You may go.”

 

 You walk slowly over to the door, your legs shaking with both nerves and the pain. He smiles thinly at you as you pass him, but says nothing more.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “I won’t,” you manage to yelp back at him through gritted teeth.

 

 WHACK!

 

 The strike lands directly across your buttocks with a ferocity Rogers hadn’t displayed before. You squeal as the pain sears up. You hold back the tears, barely.

 

 Then, silence. A moment passes. Then another. You hear the sound of Rogers shoes walking around the table, and you let out a sigh.

 

 He puts the cane back underneath the desk and meets your eyes. A cold satisfied smile rests on his face.

 

 “You’ll grow used to it,” he says to you. “Enjoy it, even. Because I’m sure I’ll be seeing you a lot in detention.”

 

 You shake your head, your trembling legs almost giving way as you still hunch over your teacher’s desk.

 

 “Pity,” Rogers tells you. “But I am a man of my word. Stand-up.”

 

 You push yourself back from the desk. Your fingers brush against the backs of your thighs. The pain is almost unbearable, but you refuse to show it to Rogers.

 

 “You may leave,” he tells you, walking over to the door and unlocking it. Walking is painful, but you try not to show it. 

 

 “Let’s not have a repeat in my lessons, Miss. Phillips,” he says to you as you walk out the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: SchoolMathsInvestigation
text:
**Charlton School - Maths Room**

 [image: ./images/School_Maths_Room.png]

 
Walls are covered with formula and maths equations. Single wooden desks are spaced out evenly, each weathered but free of graffiti. A sturdy desk rests in front of a sturdy blackboard, with faded chalk maths questions etched into it.

 

 You enter the maths room, quietly and quickly. You check to make sure it’s empty. When satisfied, you close the door behind you and look around.

 

 The eerie silence keeps you alert. The only sound comes from the clock above the blackboard, its ominous ticking marking each second you spend in danger.

 

 **Actions**

 
 <>

 <>

 
 You stare up at the clock, letting the magical energies inside you bubble up and spread across your body.

 

 With the time to focus, immediately the curse becomes clear. Yellow tentacles made of the arcane arts writhe out of the clock, each swaying around the room as if trying to find a target.

 

 You keep from their reach, backing up against the wall of the classroom.

 

 **Actions**

 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 You stare up at the clock, trying to summon the magical energies inside you. But try as you might, nothing comes.

 

 The quiet ticking of the clock continues to fill the room. You see nothing more.

 

 The realisation comes quickly. In order to use magic, you need to be a girl.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 Closing your eyes, you reach out to the clock with your mind. The tentacles appear to sense you, suddenly diverting their attention from the room and towards you as your mind moves towards the clock.

 

 As your mind edges towards it, one skims past you. You feel a twinge of vacancy in your brain. Your concentration threatens to slip.

 

 Regathering your focus, you push forward, slipping your projection around the tentacle's frenzied movements. Then you reach your goal. Bright and warm, the magic from the curse crackles around the clock. 

 

 
 “I cause this object with power beyond its power,” you whisper. “Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by all but me.”

 

 The embers of magic crack and crystallise, then fuse together at the heart of the clock in a new shape. The frenzy of tentacles then subsides. One brushes past you. It does nothing.

 
 “I cause this object with power beyond its power,” you whisper. “Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by none.”

 

 The energies within the clock seem to crackle. The tentacles thrash out, then begin to fade. Within moments, there is nothing but a kernel of inert magic at the centre of the timepiece.

 
 
 <>
 
 

 Actions

 <>

title: ThompsonsBossOfficeSearch
text:
You move around the desk and begin rifling through the drawers. Fortunately, they aren’t locked. Thompson must be content with just keeping his office door secure. 

In the middle drawer you find what you are looking for. A ring of keys sits on top of some cardboard folders, labelled with locations and addresses. You quickly flick through the keyring, noting that Thompson seems to have access to a wide variety of shops and homes across Charlton.

About halfway around the ring, you see a key labelled ‘Charlton Hotel - Basement’. Hands shaking from nerves, you pull the key off the ring and put it on the office keychain you took from Annie.

 As you do so, you notice the next key on the ring is marked up as ‘Charlton School - Business Studies Room’. As you already have a key for this room, you leave it be. You briefly search for other keys for Charlton School, but strangely you can’t find another one.

 As you do so, you notice the next key on the ring is marked up as ‘Charlton School - Business Studies Room’. You smile at your luck and take it off the ring too. Strangely enough, there aren’t any other keys labelled for Charlton.

As you go to put the keyring back, something in the desk drawer catches your eye. The label on the top folder in the drawer. "Charlton School - Candidates Assessment." 

You glance up at the door back into the office, well aware of what would happen if you were caught. But the folder calls to you.

**Actions**

<>

title: ThompsonsInvestigation
text:
Your curiosity gets the better of you. You pick up the folder and open it, flicking through the memos and paperwork filed inside it.

 

 A memo instantly catches your eye:

 

 **Subject:** Secretary candidates

 **From:** Peter Stitch

 **To:** Tucker Thompson

 

 As per your correspondence regarding Annie Clancy, it is with sincere regret that I note you are having difficulties. I assure you our assessment during her tenure at Charlton found that her skills evident in her business studies exams made her a good match for your needs. Her reluctance to engage with the ‘softer skills’ of the role (i.e. your use of the word ‘frigid’) is a surprise to all the staff that taught her.

 

 Attached is a number of candidates from our current senior year. If any of these candidates prove interesting, we would be more than happy to set up an interview in advance of The Prom as a replacement for the role ready for when they graduate.
 
 

 Regards,

 

 Peter Stitch,

 Headmaster, Charlton Upper School

 

 As you finish reading the memo, a sound from outside the office makes you jump. You look up, frozen in place, feeling your blood pumping through your body. But you hear nothing more.

 

 Actions

 <>

 <>

 Not wanting to spend any more time than necessary in this room, you decide to leave the folder as it is. You put the keyring back in the drawer and close it shut.

 

 Actions

 <>

 Thumbing your way through the attachments, you see a number of one-page files on students - all women - that you recognise as seniors at Charlton School. Each with a photo, description of their academic achievements, and somewhat disturbingly, a physical description too.

 

 Your heart leaps when you see on a file a picture of your sister, Emily.

 

 
 
 **Candidate summary:** Miss Phillips has demonstrated enthusiasm for Business Studies classes, taking direction from her male students admirably. In her short time at Charlton, she has already been invited to Mrs. DeBussy’s after school club. She seems willing to do what is necessary to achieve results. It is our assessment that with a strong hand to guide her, she would be a compliant employee that would suit your needs.

 
 **Candidate summary:** Miss Phillips has shown resilience to direction in Mrs. DeBussy’s class. Further education would be necessary should she be a desired candidate for the role. Nevertheless, it is our assessment that with the right guidance, her rebellious attitude could be amended to be spirited and an enthusiastic employee. Should you wish to spend time course correcting, we estimate she would fall in line.

 
 

 The words make you shudder. The thought of Emily doing the job that Annie does makes your skin crawl.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 Unnerved by the sound, you put the folder back in the drawer and close it shut.

 

 Actions

 <>

 
 You put the attachments back in the folder and place it in the drawer, closing it shut.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: WorkGeneric
text:
Free of distractions from anyone else in the office, you boot up the antique machine and get on with some work. The backlog of bugs seems only to be increasing, so you pick the top of the priority list. You begin to analyse what could be going wrong.

 

 
 [Ditzy] *The silence of the office helps, but not much. Your mind keeps slipping away - thinking about what was muttered on the breakfast show you recently watched. What should be obvious now just feels frustratingly out of reach.*

 
 
 You sit down in front of the ancient machine that Thompson has assigned you to undertake your work. The cheap fan in the desktop case sputters when you switch it on. The CRT monitor takes ages to heat up.

 

 Finally, once the old system boots up, you start by looking through the list of bugs and analysing the top issue, mulling over what the cause could be.

 

 
 [Ditzy] *You rub your temples. Concentration feels like wading through treacle. The error messages blur into each other, and for some reason you keep thinking about your hair. You know this stuff - or at least, you used to. So why is it so hard to focus now?*

 
 

 Your fingers move fast, intuition guiding each keystroke. One bug collapses, then another, then a third. Everything lines up like you planned it. For once, the system seems to respond to your work. You lean back, the rare feeling of victory settling over you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 It takes effort, but your concentration holds. One fix, then another. You're in the zone - methodical, focused, capable. By the time you glance at the clock, you've dealt with two significant problems. Thompson might even be pleased.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You manage to get to the bottom of one of the persistent issues. It isn't pretty, but it works. That's all that matters right now. One bug down. Too many left to go.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You make a little progress - some logs understood, a stack trace followed - but the solution's just out of reach. You've started the work, but it's going to take another round to get through it properly.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You think you're making progress, but it's slow. Really slow. You've covered the basics, maybe laid some groundwork, but the solution still looks miles away. You're starting to lose confidence.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You try. You really do. But it's no good. You can't think straight. The logs make no sense. The screen seems to mock you. You eventually stop typing altogether and just… sit. Completely lost.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: WorkResearch
text:
You decide to put work aside for the moment and see if you can find something to help you understand what’s going on.

 

 Your first attempts display pages of results about what you knew about magic before that amulet came into your life. Wikipedia pages on its place in fiction, new age movements selling crystals, pseudoscience articles on affirmations and social media content from bored teenagers.

 

 Trying to narrow your results, you decide to focus your search around Charlton and related topics.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <>

 Unsurprisingly, Charlton has little presence online. Search results mention some of the local businesses and brief summaries of the history of the town that are little more than Wikipedia stubs. The town has existed in one form or another for hundreds of years, serving as a small farming community before the industrial revolution caused it to shrink to little more than a hamlet. 

 

 One thing that does draw your attention is the town being referenced in a history of rural counterculture movements of the 1960s. The surrounding fields and valleys were a hot spot for impromptu gatherings of pagans, hippies and flower children. Free love festivals used the town as a base, filling the sleepy town with Volkswagen vans and the shops and hotel with children of the revolution. 

 

 Then, just as the ‘60s ended, results fall off. The only references to Charlton between then and now are the businesses, the school, the shops. The picture of a sleepy town, untouched by modernity.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 The results from combining Charlton and magic brings up a number of pages detailing the town’s history with counterculture movements and pagan festivals in the ‘60s. Whilst noteworthy, nothing strikes you as being relevant, or indeed real. Even when you take into consideration that ‘real’ to you means something very different than before.

 

 That is until a result stands out. You click on a result page buried in the articles about the town’s history titled, “Gladys’ Shop of Curiosities.” You are taken through to a black page, full of words and graphics that look like a website designed in the 1990s.

 

 Designed for the curious mind, Gladys’ offers services and advice to make your heart’s desire come to life.

 

 The page is littered with badly taken photographs of trinkets and jewellery with vague descriptions of what they are. You notice that a few of them are very similar to the amulet that your sister gave you. 

 

 You also see an address at the bottom of the page. The shop apparently is on Avian Lane, wedged between McTafey’s bar and a block of apartments. Strangely enough, it’s almost opposite where Jennifer lives. You are certain that you’ve never seen it before.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: ThompsonsOfficeAnnieWork
text:
You step around Annie's new desk, taking in the clutter and chaotic mess that is Annie's filing system. Folders are sprawled out over the desk. Brightly coloured post-it notes line the edges of the monitor. A dull mouse is livened up by the glittery pink mouse mat it rests on.

 

 Booting up her computer, you check her inbox. Half a dozen emails came in requesting meetings with Thompson overnight. You check his calendar only to find large blocks are blocked out. The subject blocked from view.

 

 Before you can schedule the first meeting, the phone interrupts you. "Good morning, Thompson's Repairs," you say, echoing the words you've heard from Annie. "Mr. Thompson's office. How might I help you?"

 

 Over the next thirty minutes, you try to answer emails in-between the constant calls. Every time you answer one email, two more arrive. Most of them are minor. Mundane.

 

 “Hey darling, can I get a phone call in with Tucker this afternoon? Need to have a chat about the bill that hit my doormat today.”
“Your boss free for golf Friday?”
“Can you ask the owner if he's interested in changing his stationary order?”
 

 Even the phone calls feel off. It's mostly Thompson's friends and business acquaintances looking for him, but at the sound of your voice they begin to chat. It almost goes without saying that it's exclusively men.

 

 You’re halfway through scheduling a lunch meeting when you hear boots on the carpet.

 

 Gordon appears in the doorway. "Annie," he says, not waiting for a reply. "Where's Phillips?"

 

 "I'm not sure," you feign, trying to think of an excuse.

 

 Gordon grunts. "Need someone to do my receipts. No one's on reception."

 

 You try not to grimace. "Can I help?"

 

 He shakes his head. "Not your job, anymore. Phillips is slacking. Need to have a word with Thompson. He free?"

 

 You eye him with concern. If you don't act now, you'll risk Thompson's wrath. Not to mention his anger at you not showing up to work.

 

 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>

 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 <>
 
 
 
 The office is quieter now. The phone stopped ringing five minutes ago, and you’ve just started sorting through calendar when the door from reception swings open.

 

 Dan barrels in, phone in one hand, sunglasses in the other. It doesn't matter that it's permanently overcast in Charlton. “Annie,” he announces. “Is there a reason I just spent thirty minutes driving to a meeting only to discover that my phone thinks our client lives in a parking lot?”

 
 
 You blink, caught off guard. “I haven’t touched it,” you say.

 

 He stops, dramatically sighs, and slides his sunglasses up onto his head. Despite the dim lighting.

 

 "Of course you didn't," he replies. "You don't need to worry your pretty little head with anything other than Thompson's diary. What I need is for Phillips to explain what the hell they think they're doing. Where are they?"

 

 "I'm not sure," you reply, trying to assess the situation.

 

 “Well," he says, dramatically pulling his glasses down to look over the rim. "If you see them, tell them I’m grabbing lunch with Thompson. Got some thoughts to share."

 

 He starts toward the corridor, still muttering to himself.

 

 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>

 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 <>

 <>
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 You are working away at the front desk when you hear the bell chime out in reception. You leap up and rush through the door to see Emily standing in the entrance, looking back at you.

 

 
 
 
 Emily eyes you sheepishly. "Hey," she says quietly. "Annie, right? I'm Emily. I'm supposed to start an internship today."

 

 The internship...

 

 Emotions flutter inside you. Shame. Embarrassment. An odd sensation where your mind is trying to make sense of what feels like a dream. But you push it all down. "Sure," you reply. "Take a seat."

 

 You gesture to the visitors chair. Emily puts her bag neatly underneath the reception desk and sits down, waiting expectedly.

 
 Emily grins, strolling around the counter with confidence and purpose. She tosses her bag behind the counter and leans casually against the computer. "Hey! Annie, right? I love your dress. Where did you get it?"

 

 "Emily..." you begin, but realisation hits you. The internship...

 

 You take a gulp. "Evans," you mutter.

 

 "I didn't know that sold skirts that short," Emily whispers to you, grinning. "But if you've got it, you might as well flaunt it."

 

 "You're here for the internship?" you ask her, playing for time.

 

 She shrugs. "I mean, I'd much rather get your advice on how to find bargains at Evans. But sure. Where do we begin?"

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Emily smiles meekly at you, still feeling uncomfortable being here. She walks around the desk and pops her school bag down, then hangs awkwardly off to the side.

 

 "So. What are we doing today?" she asks.

 
 Emily grins at the sight of you, but strolls in with confidence and purpose. She tosses her bag behind the counter and leans casually against the computer. "Hey Annie! Another day of manning phones and talking to beefy tradesmen. That reminds me, I don't suppose Dan is around, is he?"

 

 Her eyes wander. You move the mouse, bringing the monitor back to life, trying to make a point. "Oh," she exclaims. "Right. Work."

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You are working the Thompson's inbox, responding to his friends flirtatious emails, when Thompson's door creaks open. You glance up and see his face in the shadows, looking at you.

 

 "Need you in my office. Now."

 

 You stop what you're doing and stand up, knowing full well not to risk Thompson’s wrath. You step up to the door and open it.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 The day draws to a close.

 

 You shut down the computer, logging out of systems and wiping down the dusty monitor. You glance over to Thompson's office and see light seeping out from underneath the door. He's still working.

 

 Which is just as well, as Annie didn't give you her set of keys.
 
 

 Flicking off the desk lamp, you gather your belongings and exit, grateful for the end of the working day.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: ThompsonsReceptionIntern
text:
Annie wastes no time. She begins walking you through the basics - how to answer the phones, greet customers, schedule appointments for Clive and Gordon, and manage Mr. Thompson’s calendar. None of it is particularly hard. It’s repetitive. Monotonous. But there’s something quietly satisfying about it.

 

 Then the bell above the front door rings.

 

 Dan strolls in, loud as ever. You can smell the alcohol on his breath from across the desk. "Afternoon," he says, grinning.

 

 Annie doesn’t miss a beat. "Been busy at lunchtime, Dan?"

 

 He lets out a chuckle, leaning against the counter. "Liquid lunch with John Kaplar. Talking renovations for the country club. Although he mostly wanted to ask how I avoid slicing the ball on the tennis court."

 

 Annie raises an eyebrow, barely concealing her amusement. "Isn’t that a golf term?"

 

 Dan stiffens. "No, no, definitely tennis. Girls wouldn’t understand. Bit advanced, that one."

 

 She offers him a saccharine smile. "Of course."

 

 Then Dan’s eyes land on you. His grin widens. "Well, well. Look who it is. The elusive Miss Phillips. I was starting to think your kept you locked up somewhere."

 

 You shift uncomfortably in your seat.

 

 He leans in slightly. "Didn’t expect to see you behind the desk. Coffee girl now, huh? I like it. Adds a little charm to the place."

 

 Annie gently steps in front of the desk, blocking Dan from you. "Emily’s still being assessed. She doesn’t have time to chat.”

 

 Dan waves a dismissive hand. "Come on, just being friendly. In fact,” he says, stepping around her and leaning over the desk, his face coming close to yours. “She and I should have a little chat. I can tell her about how things really work around here. And Friday afternoons are so dull.”

 

 Annie looks back at you, then to Dan. Her smile fades. “If Mr. Thompson sees her slacking off, it’ll go straight back to the school."

 

 
 “Don’t worry about Thompson,” he replies. Then his voice drops, just a little. "Otherwise, I might find myself in his office. Talking about my unfavourable first impressions. Be a shame to spill the beans."

 “Don’t worry about Thompson,” he replies. Then his voice drops, just a little. "Otherwise, I might find myself in his office. Talking about how her ’s been doing such a bad job lately. Shame, really."

 

 He grins at you, lingering a second too long, the breath of alcohol invading your face. “What do you say, Phillips? Fancy keeping me occupied?"
 
 
 Another Friday afternoon. Another slow, humming stretch behind the reception desk.

 

 You're halfway through updating the calendar when the bell above the door jingles. Dan strolls in, his cologne strong enough to mask the stench of alcohol on his breath. He shoots you a grin that you’ve come to recognise all too well. "Afternoon, Phillips," he says, swaggering toward the counter. "Fancy keeping me company today?"

 

 He leans on the desk, watching you with a gleam in his eye, waiting.

 

 Annie glances over from the filing cabinet but says nothing. You’re not sure if she’s giving you space - or leaving you to fend for yourself.

 

 The office seems to quieten. The ball’s in your court.

 
 

 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>

 <>

 [Saucy Secretary] Decline Dan's offer - *Something compels you to positively respond to him*

 
 
 
 [Dutiful Doer] <>

 <>

 [Dutiful Doer] Decline Dan's offer - *It makes you feel queasy even thinking about defying him*

 
 <>

 <>

 
 

 
 
 You lean back in your chair ever so slightly, lips parting into a smile. You can’t help it - not anymore. Your instinct is to smile sweetly, rely on your charm, your curves, your ability to make men feel like they’re winning.

 

 "I really should concentrate on my internship," you say with a gentle, playful lilt. "But… if there’s something I can help with… anything at all. Just let me know. I’m here to help."

 

 Dan’s eyes light up instantly. "Oh, I can think of a few things," he says with a grin, eyes slowly trailing down your body. His gaze lingers, and without thinking, you arch your back just a little. Just enough.

 

 "Tell you what," he says, snapping his fingers. "Daddy needs a coffee. That liquid lunch turned into a solid deal. Gotta close it out if I want that commission. And you know I need that bump - got some lucky ladies to wine and dine."

 

 The words escape your lips before you even realise you’re saying them. "Lucky girls."

 

 Dan laughs. "Bring it when you can, sweetheart."

 

 He walks off, smug and satisfied.

 

 Annie gives a low whistle. "Well. You sure know how to wrap them around your finger. That’s the key to success around here."

 

 Then, quieter, more solemn: "Just... know where your line is, okay? It’s hard to walk back once you’ve crossed over it."

 

 You nod, unsure whether she’s warning you, or herself. Getting back to your tasks, you lose yourself in calendar entries and extension numbers until you remember Dan’s coffee order. You make a quick run to Fresh Pot, then bring it to the office.

 

 Dan’s eyes are on your legs the entire time.

 

 "Thanks, sweetheart," he says, smirking.

 

 "Anytime," you say, flashing a small smile as you turn and walk away, fully aware of his eyes following your every step.

 
 You flash Dan a sweet smile as he leans in with that familiar grin.

 

 "I’ve still got work to do for my internship," you say lightly. "But I’ll pop by later. I want to hear all about that big commission you’re getting."

 

 Dan grins. "Oh, I’ll be happy to show you how big it is." He winks, then walks off into the office.

 

 Later, you swing by his desk with a coffee in hand. He launches straight into a boastful rundown of the deal he landed, his voice loud and animated. He’s riding high, talking about connections, commissions, and Charlton’s high society.

 

 "You should come by the country club sometime," he says. "I’ve spent a chunk of that bonus on some... premium equipment. You’ve got to see how I use it."

 

 You cringe inwardly, but the compulsion tugs at your instincts. “I’d love to see you in action,” you reply, giving him a smile. 

 

 He laughs, clearly pleased. “Look forward to it.”

 

 You leave the office with his eyes still following you.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 You nod automatically. You don’t think. You just... do what you’re told. That’s what’s expected of you here. He asked. You accepted. Simple.

 

 Annie raises an eyebrow but doesn’t say anything.

 

 You follow Dan through the door to the office, walking behind him as he sits down at his desk. He gestures next to him and you lean against it, noting your stocking-clad legs are uncomfortably close to him, your short skirt riding up just enough to make you hyperaware of yourself. Vulnerable. Exposed.

 

 "Let me tell you how things really work around here," Dan begins, stretching back in his chair. "You want to get ahead in business? It’s not about performance. It’s about relationships."

 

 He gestures vaguely as he talks, his eyes occasionally flicking to your legs.

 

 "People aren’t complicated. They’ve got needs. Once you figure out how to meet them, you’ve got them in the palm of your hand. And the ones to pay most attention to? The basic needs."

 

 His gaze lowers again, across your legs. Lingering. His tongue runs across his lips.

 

 "It’s important to know your place though," he adds, looking back at your face. "I’m an alpha. Top of the food chain. And a receptionist? She’s there to help me do my job. Support. Obey. You understand that, right?"

 

 You nod, finding yourself taking in his words. Not because you want to. Because you have to. Your instincts push you to remember every word he says.

 

 "You’ll fit in nicely," Dan says, satisfied.

 

 The conversation is interrupted by the sound of a door slamming open, the frame bouncing off the wall as it hits it. Almost immediately, Mr. Thompson strides out. His eyes land on the two of you immediately.

 

 Dan straightens up, slamming his hands onto his keyboard, pretending to work. But you don’t have time - or learning reflexes - to react. As Thompson's eyes fall on you, his scowl deepens. 

 

 "What do you think you’re doing, young lady?” he asks, but doesn’t wait for a reply. “Just because I’m not paying you doesn’t mean you can treat this as an afternoon off. This is your chance to prove you can hold down a job. Not to bag a husband."

 

 His glare could cut glass. "Mr. Stitch will be hearing about this."

 

 He strides across the office and out into reception. “Annie!” you hear him bark. “Draw up a memo to Charlton School!” 

 

 Dan mutters something under his breath and starts typing furiously, his bravado evaporated. "We’ll chat later," he says, not looking up.

 

 You slink away, cheeks burning, returning to the reception. Annie glances your way as you walk in. She gives you a small, sympathetic smile, but says nothing.

 

 You sit back down and answer the next call, the dial tone almost drowning out the shame burning beneath your skin.
 
 
 You find yourself beside Dan’s desk again, exactly where he likes you - leaning in, listening. He doesn’t have to ask anymore. You’ve learned to come when expected.

 

 Dan continues his usual spiel, half lecture, half self-congratulation. He tells you how the business runs on people like him. How success is about knowing who to please. How a good receptionist doesn’t question. Just listens, supports. Obeys.

 

 "This place would fall apart without me," he mutters as he scrolls through his emails. "Everyone else? Replaceable. Except the ones who know how to play the game."

 

 You nod along. It’s not enthusiasm. It’s instinct now. He talks. You listen.

 

 Then the door slams open. "Slacking off again, Phillips?" Thompson’s voice booms across the office.

 

 You jolt upright, but it’s too late.

 

 "This isn’t a dating service," he barks. "Leave your flirting to your own time and get back to work, before I phone the school and take back this opportunity I’m giving you."

 

 You retreat quickly, cheeks burning, back to your desk. You weren’t flirting. You were just following instructions. Just doing what you were told.

 

 But that doesn’t seem to matter.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 You give a small nod. “Sure, that would be nice.”

 

 Dan walks toward the office. He doesn’t wait for you - he assumes you’ll be behind him. You follow, walking over to his desk as he sits down and gestures to the spot next to him. You lean against it, legs crossed, skirt riding up slightly as you settle in. His grin widens.

 

 "Let me tell you how things really work around here," Dan begins, stretching back like a man completely at ease. "Success isn’t about spreadsheets. It’s about people. It’s about knowing what someone wants. And making sure they get it."

 

 He talks as if he’s giving you a masterclass. “The secret”, he says, “is knowing how to listen. How to follow orders. How to support those of us who make things happen. You can do that, can’t you, sweetheart?”

 

 You offer him a polite smile, holding back your thoughts on his patronising tone.

 

 "People have needs," he adds, his eyes drifting over your legs before settling on your face. "You meet those needs, and you get ahead. Annie’s been pretty good at keeping up with that, but there’s still some room for improvement. There’s room for you to take her spot, if you know how to play the game, love.”

 

 “Just remember your place. You’d be surprised how many people fall over when they get too cocky. I’m an alpha. Top of the food chain. And you? You help me do my job. That’s what receptionists are for."

 

 Once again, you nod. Sensing the break in the conversation, you seize the opportunity to try and gain at least some value from him. “Say Dan, I was wondering if you could tell me about -”

 

 The moment is shattered when Thompson’s office door swings open with a crash. He strides into the room, eyes immediately locking onto you both.

 

 Dan jolts upright, pretending to be buried in work. But you’re caught. His eyes flick to you, solely. He flares his nostrils.

 

 "What do you think you’re doing, young lady?" Thompson snaps. "Just because I’m not paying you doesn’t mean you can treat this like an afternoon off. This is your chance to prove you can hold down a job. Not to bag a husband."

 

 “I wasn’t…” you begin, but his glare is enough to stop you in your tracks.

 

 “Save it,” he says. His glare is scalding. "Mr. Stitch will be hearing about this."

 

 Without waiting for a reply, he storms out toward reception. "Annie! Draw up a memo to Charlton School!"

 

 Dan avoids your gaze, suddenly far more interested in his keyboard. "We’ll chat later," he mutters.

 

 You return to reception. Annie gives you a small, understanding smile, but nothing more. You silently sit down at the reception desk and take the next call, feeling your cheeks burning red.
 
 
 Once again, you find yourself accepting his offer and fall in beside Dan’s desk in the office. You take your usual spot, leaning against the side of his desk while he talks.

 

 Without small talk, Dan continues to tell you about how to succeed in the corporate world. You smile at the right moments, nod when he looks for a reply. But continually trying to find someway to interject and get something of value from him. And all the while your eyes flick back to the door to Thompson’s office, listening for any signs of activity.

 

 Dan is mid-rant about his latest deal, but you gently interrupt. "Hey Dan, could you tell me a bit about how Charlton puts forward interns here?"

 

 Dan glances around, then leans in slightly. "There’s a selection process," he says, quieter than usual. "Usually it’s the ones doing well in Business Studies. Thompson’s very particular on - "

 

 The door to Thompson’s office slams open. You flinch.

 

 Thompson strides out, his eyes landing on you immediately. "Slacking off again, Phillips? This isn’t a dating service. Leave your flirting to your own time and get back to work before I phone the school and take back this opportunity I’m giving you."

 

 Dan snaps to attention, hammering nonsense into his keyboard like a guilty schoolboy.

 

 You retreat back to reception, face burning. Annie catches your eye briefly, but doesn’t say a word. You slide into your chair and answer the next call, the weight of Thompson’s words still pressing on your shoulders.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 You offer Dan a polite but firm smile. “Thanks, but I should really concentrate on my internship.”

 

 He raises an eyebrow, clearly not expecting resistance. “Come on, don’t be like that. It’s just a chat. Bit of friendly advice.”

 

 You shake your head. “I’m here to work. That’s what I need to focus on.”

 

 Dan sighs dramatically, pulling back from the counter. “You’re not going to get far thinking like that. Receptionists are ten a penny. Anyone can answer a phone. The real trick is personal relationships. That’s what matters.”

 

 
 
 "Something your doesn’t understand either.” Dan gives you a thin smile. “Which reminds me, I found another bug in the system this morning. Stopping me closing out my latest sale. Now that I don’t have anything to keep me occupied this afternoon, I might pop into Thompson’s office. See if he's free for a little chat… about your .”

 

 He walks out of the reception, the door closing behind him. You feel the tension settle over you like a fog.

 

 Annie steps over quietly, smiling warmly. “You did good,” she says. “The men around here… they’re used to getting their way. But sometimes it’s good for them not to.”

 

 She pauses, eyes distant for a beat. “I wish I had been more like you when I started.”

 

 Then her smile returns. “Come on. Let me show you how the job booking system works.”

 

 You return to your desk, the moment behind you. Although the unease lingers. Annie walks you through how to schedule jobs for Gordon and Clive. A little later, the office door slams open and Thompson strides out. He looks at you, then to Annie. “She settling in?”

 

 Annie nods. “She’s learning fast.”

 

 “Good,” Thompson replies. “Glad to see someone in your family has a work ethic. Speaking of - Annie, send me the leads report from yesterday. Dan says the system’s still not giving him what he needs.”
 

 He returns to looking at you, his narrowed eyes locking on to yours. “Your is on thin ice, young lady. Take my advice - don’t be like them.”

 

 He strides out. Annie meets your gaze, but says nothing. After a moment, she returns to showing you the booking system. Time slips away and before you know it, the afternoon has passed by.

 
 Dan stands up. “You remind me of your ,” he says flatly. “Same stubborn attitude.”

 

 He smirks. “Maybe I’ll go check if Thompson’s free. Wouldn’t hurt to bring up a few things. You know, professional concerns about our latest intern.”

 

 Before you can speak, Annie steps in. “If you do that,” she says calmly, “I’ll let Thompson know how many clients really attend those long lunches at the Charlton Hotel.”

 
 
 Dan freezes, eyes narrowing. Annie leans in towards him, her voice dropping to a whisper. “You might know how to talk to him, but who do you think he really listens to?”

 

 Anger quickly rises up on his face. For a moment, you fear what he’s going to do. But he releases it with a scoff. “Fine,” he says through clenched teeth. “I’ve got deals to close out anyway. Real work.”

 

 He stalks off back into the office. The door closing quietly behind him.

 

 Annie turns back to you with a smile. “You did good,” she says. “The men around here… they’re used to getting their way. But sometimes it’s good for them not to.”

 

 She pauses, eyes distant for a beat. “I wish I had been more like you when I started.”

 

 Then, snapping back to cheerful: “Come on. Let me show you how the job booking system works.”

 

 You return to your seat and try to settle back into the rhythm of the work. Annie walks you through how to schedule jobs for Gordon and Clive. A little later, the office door slams open and Thompson strides out. He looks at you, then to Annie. “She settling in?”

 

 Annie nods. “She’s learning fast.”

 

 “Good,” Thompson replies. “Glad to see someone in your family has a work ethic."

 

 He exits without another word. Annie meets your eyes again, but says nothing. After a moment, she returns to showing you the booking system. Time slips away and before you know it, the afternoon has passed by.

 
 
 You straighten your back and offer a polite but firm response. “Thanks, but I still want to focus on my internship.”

 

 He exhales sharply, trying not to let the irritation show. “Receptionists are ten a penny, you know. You’d get further if you thought about long-term relationships, not how to answer calls.”

 

 
 
 He crosses his arms. “Still, there’s some lingering bugs in the system that I need to flag. Stuff that’s stopping me closing deals.”

 

 He eyes you as he steps away. “Might have a little word with Thompson this afternoon. Just to make sure he’s aware of the ongoing issues.”

 

 The door to the office shuts behind him. You let out a small breath you didn’t realise you were holding. Annie gives you a small nod. “Good choice,” she says. “Keep him at arms length. It’s healthy. For him and you. Alright. Let’s make sure Clive doesn’t get double-booked again.”

 

 You slide into the afternoon’s tasks, grateful for the structure. 

 

 Later, the office door swings open. Thompson strides out, eyes scanning the reception. “Still working out?” he asks Annie.

 

 “Better than I did,” Annie replies.

 

 Thompson nods curtly. “Dan says the system’s throwing out bad data again. Pull out the latest reports.” He looks at you. “Your doesn’t deserve the money I pay them.”

 

 He leaves without another word. Annie smiles politely at you, then returns to walking you through your work.

 
 Dan smirks. “Same attitude as your sibling. Thought they could get by on their own too.”

 

 “She’s doing a good job,” Annie says to him, a hint of a warning in her tone. “Don’t you think, Daniel?”

 

 He grits his teeth, then wordlessly walks through the office door.

 

 Annie turns back to you, smiling. “Good call,” she says quietly. “Men like him don’t like being told no. But that doesn’t mean they shouldn’t hear it.”

 

 She trails off, thoughtful, then smiles. “Come on. Calendar work is backing up.”

 

 You slide into the afternoon’s tasks, grateful for the structure. Later, the office door swings open. Thompson strides out, eyes scanning the reception. “Still working out?” he asks Annie.

 

 “She’s learning fast,” Annie replies.

 

 Thompson nods once. “Let’s hope it sticks. I’ve had enough of that family coasting.”

 

 He moves on without another word. Annie returns to her task like nothing happened.

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 

 
 
 The day draws to a close.

 

 Annie walks you through how to shut down the systems - logging out of the appointments software, powering down the dusty monitor, unplugging the temperamental printer. You follow her lead carefully, mirroring each step.

 

 She hands you the key to the front door, watching with a smile as you turn the lock.

 

 You glance over. "How did I do?"

 
 The day draws to a close.

 

 You move through the routine with practiced ease - shutting down the appointments software, powering off the monitor, locking the front door with a quick twist of the key.

 

 You turn to Annie. "How did I do today?"

 
 

 
 
 "You did good," Annie says. "Picked up the basics quickly. It’s admin work, sure. But it’s important to get right. And you’re picking it up well. I’ll be sure to sing your praises when I write my report for the school."

 

 She leans slightly against the desk. "And the way you handled Dan? Impressive. Men like that are one of the biggest challenges in an office. Give them too little, they make your life miserable. Give them too much and..."

 

 She trails off, the smile fading. For a moment she looks far away. "Well. Let’s just say they start expecting things."

 

 You smile politely, nodding, but the thoughts twist inside. You didn’t handle Dan. Not really. You were compelled to flirt, to lean in, to charm him. Worse still, it felt good. Powerful. Until you realised what that power might cost you. 

 

 You shudder at the thought of what Dan might expect next time... and whether you could even say no.

 

 Annie waves her hand in front of your face, bringing you out of your thoughts. “Time to go, daydreamer. Have a good night. See you next week!”

 
 "You did good," Annie says. “Getting the hang of it. I’ll make sure the school knows how well you’re doing.”

 

 "And Dan? You’re handling him well. Keep walking that line, but don’t go too far. That kind of man always wants more."

 

 You nod, offering a practiced smile. But inside, you wish it was a choice. The flirting, the posture, the tone. It came too naturally. You don’t even think about doing it. You just do.

 

 And worst of all? You’re not sure you’d stop if Dan ever decided he wanted more.

 

 Annie interrupts your thoughts. “That’s a wrap. Have a good night. See you next week!”

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 She hands you the key to the front door, watching with a smile as you turn the lock.

 

 You glance over. "How did I do?"

 
 The day draws to a close.

 

 You move through the routine with practiced ease - shutting down the appointments software, powering off the monitor, locking the front door with a quick twist of the key.

 

 You turn to Annie. "How did I do today?"

 
 

 
 
 Annie hesitates for just a moment before replying. "You seemed to pick up the basics well. Good instincts."

 

 You grimace, sensing the "but" coming before she even says it.

 

 "But Thompson wasn’t happy," she admits. "He saw you hanging around with Dan. Sent a note to the school. Said you were slacking off. Spending your time with the men in the office, not working."

 

 You feel heat rise in your cheeks. "Not all men. Just Dan. And I was responding to his request."

 

 "I know," Annie replies, soft but firm. "But Thompson didn’t see it that way. And his opinion is the one that counts. You need to be careful of the choices you make around here."

 

 You nod, but thoughts float up in your mind. You want to say it wasn’t your choice. Dan had asked, and you just followed. You try to picture yourself saying no to him. Or to Gordon. Or Clive. And can’t. But how could Annie understand that?

 

 She shrugs, brushing it off gently. "Just something to think about. See you next week."

 
 "Thompson saw you chatting with Dan again. He sent another note. This time to the headmaster."

 

 You feel your stomach twist.

 

 "I know Dan has a certain appeal," Annie says gently, "but remember, you’re being graded on this. I don’t want to see you suffer because some guy in the office wants to spend his Friday afternoons flirting with a young girl."

 

 You nod. Annie’s right. You know she is. But you can’t figure out how to stop. Being near Dan, responding to him - it just happens. Like there’s no option to say no.

 

 "Try to remember why you’re here," Annie says. She grabs her bag, then offers a small wave. "See you next week."

 "But Thompson wasn’t happy," she admits. "He saw you hanging around with Dan. Sent a note to the school. Said you were slacking off. Spending your time with the men in the office, not working."

 

 You feel heat rise in your cheeks. "Not all men. Just Dan. And I was responding to his request."

 

 "I know," Annie replies, soft but firm. "But Thompson didn’t see it that way. And his opinion is the one that counts. You need to be careful of the choices you make around here."

 

 You nod, lips pressed into a line. But deep down, you wonder why you agreed in the first place. It wasn’t a command. Dan had asked. And you had gone. Maybe you were curious. Maybe it felt safer to say yes. Maybe... you just didn’t want to say no.

 

 She shrugs, brushing it off gently. "Just something to think about. See you next week."

 
 A little grimace spreads across Annie's face. "Thompson saw you chatting with Dan again. He sent another note. This time to the headmaster."

 

 You feel your stomach twist.

 

 "I know Dan has a certain appeal," Annie says gently. "But remember, you’re being graded on this. I don’t want to see you suffer because some guy in the office wants to spend his Friday afternoons flirting with a young girl."

 

 You nod slowly. You know she’s right. But you still find yourself walking toward Dan every week. Maybe it’s easier. Maybe it feels expected. Maybe it’s just a habit now. You’re not even sure anymore.

 

 "Try to remember why you’re here," Annie says. She grabs her bag, then offers a small wave. "See you next week."

 <>

 She hands you the key to the front door, watching with a smile as you turn the lock.

 

 You glance over. "How did I do?"

 
 The day draws to a close.

 You turn to Annie. "How did I do today?"

 
 

 
 
 "You did good," Annie says with a warm nod. "Kept your head down. Worked hard. That’s the right instinct."

 

 She hesitates, just a moment.

 

 
 "Dan’s spiteful though. After you turned him down, he had a little word with Thompson about your . Said something about their performance. Thompson didn’t look too happy."

 "Dan’s spiteful though. He didn’t say anything about you to Thompson, but I wouldn’t put it past him. Even after I ‘persuaded’ him not to.”

 

 Annie sighs. "I’m not saying you were wrong to focus on your work. You weren’t. But maybe there’s a way to brush him off without giving him an excuse to lash out. Something to think about."

 

 You nod, grateful for the honesty. Annie smiles gently. "Try to remember why you’re here," she says. "See you next week."

 
 She smiles, then lowers her voice slightly. 
 
 "You did good. Thompson hasn't said anything new about your work... but Dan’s still nursing that ego. He made another offhand comment about your to Thompson earlier today."

 "You did good. Thompson hasn't said anything new about your work... but Dan’s still nursing that ego. He hasn’t said anything to Thompson about you. But I wouldn’t put it past him."
 
 

 She shrugs. "Just... keep it in mind. I know you’re doing the right thing. Be careful he doesn’t find new ways to punish you for it."

 

 Annie sighs. "You’re not wrong to shut him down. Just... be smart about how you do it. Men like Dan don’t always play fair."

 

 She gathers her bag and slings it over her shoulder. "Stay sharp. See you next week."

 
 

 Actions
