title: ThompsonsReceptionLunchtimeCover
text:
As you approach, Annie spots you and practically leaps up from her chair.

 

 "Oh, thank god," she grins. "I’ve been dying to swing by Evans’ - they’ve got this clearance sale on coats, and I swear I saw one with fur trim."

 

 She grabs her long coat from the stand, swishing it around her like a movie star. Even on the soft carpet, her heels click with purpose.

 

 "Maybe I’ll grab a coffee, have a natter with Flo. I’ll be back in an hour… or so." She winks. "Shouldn’t be too hard. Just some emails to write back to."

 

 Without waiting for a reply, she breezes out the door, leaving the faintest trace of expensive perfume in her wake.

 
 You glance over to the reception desk. Annie’s already gone. A large pastel post-it note is stuck to the monitor, the handwriting unmistakably hers - loopy, elegant, and overly familiar:

 

 *“Thanks ! See if you can make a dent in my inbox. See you soon x”
*
 

 The screen is awake, the mail client open and buzzing with unread messages. You sigh and pull out the chair.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 
 
 You sit down at Annie’s desk and immediately understand why she was so happy to hand it off.

 

 Her computer hums like an old fridge, the monitor slightly discolored in one corner. The plastic is yellowed with age. And the logo? *“Curstons.”*

 
 
 You frown. You’ve never heard of it. Wait, weren’t they a typewriter manufacturer? That would explain a lot. The keyboard clacks like it’s trying to bite your fingers.

 

 Your own work computer is bad, sure. This one feels like a relic. You half-expect it to ask for a floppy disk. When you tap the mouse, the screen flickers and then loads Annie’s email inbox.

 

 It’s... overflowing.

 

 Dozens of messages sit flagged, unopened, or half-replied to. Most are from customers: people chasing invoices, asking about timelines, confused about missed appointments. You start to read through a few threads.

 

 **From:** Ron Denver
Chasing that water heater install again 😅 any updates, sweetheart?
 

 Annie's reply: *"You know I love making you sweat, Ron 😉 I'll chase it up today. Promise x"*

 

 **From:** Ian Palmer
Still waiting for my receipt. Any chance of seeing that before next week?
 

 Annie's reply: *"Only if you promise to give me more than five minutes for my next check-up, handsome. 😘"*

 

 **From:** Marc Hudson
Boiler's still knocking in the barn. Can someone look at it before it explodes?
 
 
 Annie's reply: *"Sounds like it’s begging for attention, just like me. I’ll get someone on it x"*

 

 You stare at the screen, deep in Annie’s inbox now. These customers are clearly expecting her. That tone. That playful, charming, slightly-too-familiar energy.

 

 If you start replying... do you try to match that? Or do you stick to your own style?

 
 You slide into Annie’s chair, already bracing yourself.

 

 The inbox is as messy as ever. Unread emails stacked like a game of digital Jenga. You’re starting to recognize names now. And patterns.

 

 Same customers. Same cheeky tone. Same disorganized chaos.

 

 One screen flicker from the ancient “Curstons” machine reminds you just how far back this desk is stuck in time.

 

 You crack your knuckles and get to work. The only question is how you're going to reply.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 
 You stare at the blinking cursor, Annie’s half-finished draft open like a dare. The words in your head feel stiff, clunky. Not a single wink emoji that you can summon.

 

 First, you try typing something casual. Then delete it. Try again, softer. A little teasing. Still off. Eventually, you piece together a reply. Something about how you’re 'chasing the boys in the back room' and 'wouldn’t want to leave a handsome guy waiting too long.' You wince as you hit send.

 

 But a minute later - ding.

 

 The same customer replies. Quickly. His message is even flirty.

 

 Knew I could count on you, gorgeous 😉 I’ll put in a good word with your boss. Maybe he’ll give you that raise you deserve 😘
 

 You should probably get back to the earlier emails. But instead, you open his again. Reread it. Then reply. *"Appreciate the good word, just don’t tell them how easy I am. To bribe." 😘*

 

 You hit send, sure he’ll be happy. And you’ve updated the schedule. It’s all sorted. The customer feels heard. Flattered.

 

 You lean back in the chair.

 

 It’s fine, right? You’re getting the job done. They’re happy. There’s no harm in what you’re doing...

 

 *Right?*

 
 It’s becoming second nature now.

 

 You slip into the seat, fingers already tapping before the screen finishes loading. Your inbox lights up with familiar names - customers who almost seem disappointed when someone else replies.

 

 You match Annie’s tone without thinking. A little teasing, a lot of charm. You even recognize the emojis they prefer.

 

 Messages pour back in. Grinning emojis, appreciative words, playful winks.

 

 Tell your boss he’s lucky to have such a charming secretary.
 

 If you ever want a drink, name the time 😉
 

 You hesitate... somehow, you can’t just say no.

 

 *"Maybe. I’ll let you know."*

 

 You feel a faint pang. Like maybe you’re stepping into territory that isn’t quite yours. Annie’s inbox. Annie’s tone.

 

 But the customers are happy. And you’re good at this. You try not to dwell on how natural it feels now.

 

 It’s just part of your job.

 

 But this isn’t the job you really want to be doing. Is it?

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 
 You stare at Annie’s half-finished reply, the blinking cursor waiting for something light, playful… teasing.

 

 You delete it.

 

 Your fingers hover for a moment before typing something clearer. Straighter. More you.

 

 "Apologies for the delay. I’ve followed up with our scheduling team, and your appointment has been re-confirmed for Thursday at 3pm. Let me know if you need to reschedule."

 

 You press send, then move on to the next one.

 

 *"A copy of your invoice has been attached to this message. Please let us know if you require anything further."*

 

 *"We’ve escalated the boiler issue and will aim to have a technician out by tomorrow morning. Thank you for your patience."*

 

 No emojis. No flirtation. Just... efficient.

 

 But the responses that come back?

 

 "Wow. That’s the tone you’re using with a paying customer?”
 

 “This is the third time I’ve emailed. If you can’t be bothered to help, I’ll take it up with your boss.”
 

 “I’ve had it. Your customer service is abysmal.”
 

 Your stomach tightens.

 

 You know exactly where these complaints are going to land. And who Thompson will blame. But still. You can’t bring yourself to reply like Annie. You shouldn’t have to.

 

 You keep typing. Professional. Cold, maybe. But honest.

 

 *You need to hold onto something of yourself.*

 

 Even if it’s costing you.

 
 You slip into the chair, open the inbox, and brace yourself. The messages waiting for replies are already testy. Some downright furious. You keep your tone measured. Professional.

 

 *"We’ve passed your request on to dispatch. Please allow 24 hours for a response."*

 

 *"Our apologies for the confusion. I’ve forwarded your message to the correct department."*

 

 And then the replies hit:

 

 “Don’t give me copy-paste nonsense.”

 “I’ve already been waiting a week. This isn’t good enough.”

 “Tell your manager I’ll be leaving a review. And calling.”
 

 You sit back in the chair, jaw clenched. You could soften it. Just a little. Make it go down easier.

 

 But that’s not you. You didn’t sign up to charm your way out of other people’s mistakes. You’re trying to fix things. You’re being clear. You’re being right.

 

 But it’s not enough.

 

 And you know the blame won’t land where it belongs.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: ThompsonsReceptionSecretaryJob
text:
You’re juggling the phones, trying to triage a packed inbox that just won’t stop growing. Every time you answer one email, two more arrive. Most of them are minor. Mundane.

 

 “Can I push my appointment by fifteen minutes?”
“Where do I park?”
“Can you pop a reminder in my calendar?”
 

 You were once a programmer. Now you’re being asked to babysit inboxes and book diary slots like someone’s flustered personal assistant.

 

 Even the phone calls feel off. Customers want to chat. "How's your day going?" they ask, like you're just another sunny voice on the other end. They don’t care about the work. They just want the performance.

 

 You’re halfway through flagging a broken link in the supplier portal when you hear boots on the carpet.

 

 Gordon appears in the doorway. "Phillips," he says, not waiting for a reply. He’s already striding toward you, a creased folder tucked under his arm.

 

 He stops in front of the desk and sets it down without ceremony.

 

 "Expenses," he says. "Thompson says they won’t go through unless they’re done today."

 

 He taps the folder once, then looks at you.

 

 "I don’t do forms. Computers either. This stuff," he adds, gesturing at the monitor and keyboard. "Not for me." He shrugs. "Women’s work, really. But you can do it, yeah?"

 

 There’s no edge in his tone. No apology, either. Just a task. Like handing you a wrench. You're here. You’ve got fingers. And he’s got receipts.

 
 You’ve barely sat down before the inbox pings. Three new queries. All trivial. Someone wants to push an appointment back by ten minutes. Another can’t find your street on Maps. Someone else wants to know if you can send a technician who’s "good with cats."

 

 Then come the boots. The door to the office opens. Gordon. Again.

 

 He steps into view with that same folder tucked under one arm. All creased, bulging, edges frayed. The same as last time. Maybe literally the same.

 

 "Phillips," he says, flat. Nods at the desk. "Expenses. Thompson says they need doing today."

 

 He sets the folder down. Same gesture. Same tone. "Pink job. You’ve got this. Right."

 

 It’s not a question. Not even a request. Just an assumption. This is what you do now.

 

 Another chore. Another tab open. Another piece of someone else’s job sliding across your desk.

 
 

 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [Dutiful Doer] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You’re behind the desk at lunch. The phones are quiet for now and the inbox is only mildly overflowing.

 

 You’re just starting to catch your breath when you hear the office door creak open.

 

 Dan steps in.

 
 
 
 
 He doesn’t say anything. But the look he gives you? Like he owns you. Like something’s been settled. Won. His smirk is subtle now. Confident. Lazy. Like a man who doesn’t need to boast anymore.

 

 He doesn’t linger. Just throws a glance your way as he heads toward the door again. "If anyone calls," he says, casual, "tell them I’m in my personal office."

 

 You don’t need to ask. He means the pub. Then he’s gone.

 

 You return to focusing on your computer, stomach tight. You thought the tension might ease. It hasn’t. It's now just shifted.

 
 Dan walks in and stops just long enough to look at you. It’s not a leer. Not a smirk. Just something darker. Heavy. Calculating.

 

 He doesn’t speak. Not directly. Just grabs his jacket from the hook and mutters as he passes. "If anyone calls, tell them I’m in my personal office."

 

 You know what that means. Everyone does. The pub.

 

 He walks out, the door swinging shut behind him with a little too much force. You stare at the screen for a second before turning back to work. It’s quiet now. But it doesn’t feel peaceful. It feels like the silence before something else.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You’re deep into emails, finally making a dent in the inbox backlog, when you hear a loud male laughter echoing across the reception area.

 

 Dan.

 

 He strolls toward the desk like he owns the place, grinning and mid-conversation with himself. "And so I told him, ‘You want the job done right, you come to Dan.’ And guess what? He did."

 

 He leans against the counter, arms crossed, his eyes finally resting on you. "See, this is why people trust me. You’ve got to be bold. Make noise. Put yourself out there."

 

 He’s not talking to you. He’s performing. Still, you nod politely, glancing back to your screen.

 

 "Anyway," Dan continues, waving a hand like he’s wrapping up a TED Talk. "Thinking of getting something from Fresh Pot. Bacon roll, maybe a wrap. You mind grabbing it for me?" He flashes a smile. “Wouldn’t want to step away while I’ve got deals on the go, you know?”

 
 It’s become part of the routine now - emails, phones, blinking lights - and Dan, swaggering over at lunch just as things start to calm down.

 

 He leans on the desk, already mid-boast. "So this guy, right, complete amateur, tries to undercut me on a supply quote. I tell him, ‘You’re not just buying parts. You’re buying Dan.’”

 

 He chuckles at his own genius, then grins at you like you're lucky to be in his presence.

 

 "Thinking about lunch. Fresh Pot’s calling me. Bacon roll, bit of sauce, maybe crisps. You mind grabbing it?"

 

 He gives you a wink. “Be a sweetheart. I’m right in the middle of something big.”

 
 

 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [Dutiful Doer] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You are working away at the reception desk when you hear the bell chime above the door as someone enters. You paint your customer service smile on your face before looking up to see Emily standing in the entrance, looking back at you.

 

 
 
 
 
 
 Emily's shock drains quickly, but not fully. She steps into reception, eying you sheepishly. "Hey," she says quietly.

 

 The internship...

 

 Emotions flutter inside you. Shame. Embarrassment. An odd sensation where your mind is trying to make sense of what feels like a dream. But you push it all down. "Hey," you reply.

 

 "I guess you'll be the one showing me the ropes?" Emily asks. "My , teaching me how to be a secretary."

 

 "Don't make this weird," you say quietly. Your voice trembling. She smiles with sadness, but nods. "Okay. Where do we start?"

 
 Emily's eyes widen and a strange smile creeps up on her face. You can see she's holding back her laughter. Your cheeks begin to burn. "Don't," you warn her. But it just encourages her smile to grow.

 

 "I didn't say anything," she mock protests. "I must say, knowing it is one thing. Seeing the great programmer behind a reception desk, that's another."

 

 "That's mean," you tell her quietly.

 

 "Oh relax," your sister replies. "This could be fun. Just so long as you don't cramp my style. I don't need my daggy getting in the way of showing how well I can charm and banter."

 

 She walks assuredly around the counter and leans up against the desk, giving you a smirk. “So boss. Where do you want me?”

 
 
 
 Emily's mouth drops open. She stares at you, disbelief on her face. "? What are you doing there?

 

 You try to make sense of your sister standing in front of you. Then realisation hits. The internship...

 

 Emotions flutter inside you. Shame. Embarrassment. An odd sensation where your mind is trying to make sense of what feels like a dream. But you push it all down. "Hey," you reply. "I'm on reception now."

 

 Her eyes narrow. "What, are you covering for Annie whilst she's popped out?" When you don't reply, her eyes only grow narrower. "This isn't your job. Is it?"

 

 You sigh. "I got... demoted. I was going to tell you. I just didn't have time"

 

 "Demoted?" she repeats back. "But why, ? What's going on?"

 

 The switchboard phone rings, making you jump. You glance over at it, then to Emily. "Let's talk about this at home. For now though, I'll be the one showing you the ropes this afternoon. Just... let's try to get through this, okay?"

 

 She smiles with sadness, but nods. "Okay. Where do we start?"

 
 Emily's mouth drops open. She stares at you for a long moment, before a strange smile creeps up on her face. You can see she's holding back her laughter. Your cheeks begin to burn.

 

 You try to make sense of your sister standing in front of you. Then realisation hits. The internship...

 

 Emotions flutter inside you. Shame. Embarrassment. An odd sensation where your mind is trying to make sense of what feels like a dream. But you push it all down. "Hey," you reply.

 

 "Is this what you really do at work?" she asks. "I didn't know programmers manned phones?"

 

 "I've been reassigned," you reply. "Temporarily. I hope."

 

 "You hope?" she snarks, her grin growing wider. "Are you trying to tell me that the great maths whiz is now working as a secretary?" She can't help but let out a giggle. "I can see why you didn't tell me."

 

 "That's mean," you tell her quietly. "We can talk at home about it."

 

 "Sure," your sister replies, grinning. "Can't wait to hear all the details." Sudden realisation crosses her face. "So you're going to teach me how to be a receptionist?"

 

 "I guess," you say, without conviction.

 

 At this, she laughs. "Well, today just got real interesting. But maybe this could be fun. Just don't cramp my style. I don't need my daggy getting in the way of showing how well I can charm and banter."

 

 She walks assuredly around the counter and leans up against the desk, giving you a smirk. “So boss. Where do you want me?”

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Emily smiles meekly at you, still not used to seeing you behind the counter. She walks around the desk and pops her school bag down, then hangs awkwardly off to the side.

 

 "So. What are we doing today?" she asks.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 Emily grins at the sight of you, but strolls in with confidence and purpose. She tosses her bag behind the counter and leans casually against the computer. "Hey . Another day of manning phones and talking to beefy tradesmen. That reminds me, I don't suppose Dan is around, is he?"

 

 Her eyes wander. You move the mouse, bringing the monitor back to life, trying to make a point. "Oh," she exclaims. "Right. Work."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You are working the reception inbox, responding to customer’s queries, when a message pops up on your screen.

 

 Need you in my office. Now.
 

 You stop what you're doing and stand up, knowing full well not to risk Thompson’s wrath. You walk through into the office - where you used to work - and notice Annie sitting at a new desk, pushed up against Thompson’s door. 

 

 “You should go in,” she says, her trademark enthusiasm absent. 

 

 Taking a step up, you knock on the door. In an instant you hear Thompson’s voice bellow. “Enter!”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 The afternoon passes easily, as you answer phones and check calendars for availability. The familiar ping draws your attention to the bulky monitor.

 

 Need you in my office. Again.
 

 With only a slight hesitation, you stand and walk through the office, passing by Annie as you knock. “Come,” you hear Thompson yell.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 

 The day draws to a close.

 

 You shut down the computer, logging out of systems and wiping down the dusty monitor. You glance over to the office and see light seeping out from underneath the door. Someone is still working.

 

 Which is just as well, as Thompson hasn't given you a key to lock up. In spite of taking over Annie's position, he hasn't afforded you the one perk of her job - complete access to the office with your own set of keys.

 

 Flicking off the desk lamp, you gather your belongings and exit, grateful for the end of another working day.

 

 Actions

 <>

choices.label: Tell him you’ll have a word with Mr. Thompson
Flirt your way out of his request
Teach Emily how to be a receptionist
Teach Emily how to be a receptionist

title: ThompsonsReceptionSecretaryResponses
text:
You give Gordon a small, playful smile. "Maybe I’ll have a word with Mr. Thompson," you say, voice light. "Tell him you’re flat out and could use a hand."

 

 Gordon doesn’t blink. Doesn’t smile. "Just get it done," he mutters, already turning back toward the shop floor.

 

 So much for charm.

 

 You glance down at the paper stack of receipts he’s left you. Then at the mounting wave of emails flooding the inbox. You need to act fast. Opening a new message, you start typing.

 

 Hi Mr. Thompson. Gordon’s totally snowed under today. He asked me to help with his expenses, and of course I didn’t want to let the company down 😉 Just wondering if I could take a little time to get them sorted properly. Promise I’ll be very grateful… x
 

 You hover for a moment. Then hit send. The reply comes back faster than expected.

 

 End of the week’s fine. If you need to stay late to catch up… I’ll be working late too. We can keep each other company.
 

 You stare at the screen. The reply. Something in your stomach turns, but you push it down.

 

 The receipts will get done. The emails will get answered. You got through a tricky situation without letting anything fall apart. Even if you had to pander to the boss.

 

 You try not to think about it too much.

 
 You already know Gordon won’t react to flirting. So you switch it up. "Alright," you say, keeping your tone breezy. "I’ll have a word with Thompson. Buy you a bit of time."

 

 Gordon just grunts. Not impressed. But not arguing either. “Thanks,” he mutters, walking off.

 

 You take the folder and settle back at the desk, already typing up a message.

 

 Hi Mr. Thompson. Just letting you know Gordon’s still up to his neck today. He’s asked me to handle his expenses, but I didn’t want to slow anything down. If we could have a bit of leeway to get them in, I’d really appreciate it 💋
 

 Thompson’s reply lands a minute later.

 

 That’s fine. Maybe you should come into my office later. We can discuss how to make things easier for Gordon. Just the two of us.
 

 You wince. It’s a win, technically. The work’s bought some time. The inbox hasn’t exploded. But Thompson’s “encouragement” feels like it comes at a price.

 

 And you’re not sure how many more wins like this you can stomach.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You barely hesitate. It just comes out: "Yeah, of course."

 

 Gordon gives a short nod. "Thanks." He’s already walking back toward the shop floor.

 

 You’re left with the folder… and a growing weight in your chest. The rest of the morning is spent inputting receipts into the clunky spreadsheet.

 

 A bacon sandwich and tea from Fresh Pot - overtime breakfast.

 

 Three separate parking stubs from outside the Town Hall.

 

 A hand-written receipt from Pete’s pharmacy for "stationery and bits."

 

 You remember - not long ago - you were writing code to help automate the field schedules. You were literally solving how Gordon could avoid needing overtime. Now you’re logging his tea breaks into a finance form.

 

 When you finally close the spreadsheet, the red light on the phones is blinking. At least five missed calls. You flick to the inbox. Twelve new emails. All angry at the lack of a response. You know Thompson’s going to be furious.

 

 But Gordon asked. And you said yes. Before you even thought about it.

 

 *Why would you?*

 
 "Yeah," you say. "I’ve got it." You’re already pulling up the spreadsheet. Already moving aside the call log. Already shifting tabs.

 

 As you begin to process the receipts, you reflect back on what you do - or did - for a living. It feels like another life. One where you were coding backend schedules and catching bugs Gordon didn’t understand. 

 

 *And now?*

 

 Now you log his receipts. Cross-check parking times. Input the mileage for a run to a supplier. Attach a photo of a breakfast wrap from Fresh Pot. Yet it just seems normal.

 

 You barely notice how long it takes. But when you look back at the monitor, the phones are flashing again. The inbox is worse. 

 

 You sigh, rub your temple, and keep working. Thompson won’t be happy, but Gordon asked. And this is what you do now.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You pause for just a second. Then say, "Sure. I’ll do it."

 

 Gordon nods and moves off without a second glance. You’re left holding the folder. It's not heavy, but it feels... beneath you.

 

 You settle into your seat, open the spreadsheet, and start sorting through the receipts. Fuel. Lunch. A bacon sandwich and tea from Fresh Pot. A handwritten slip from Pete’s for "stationery."

 

 You glance over at the inbox. It’s piling up again. Phones are blinking too. You should be dealing with them. Instead, you’re inputting Gordon’s overtime snacks. You sigh. You’re not even sure why you said yes. He didn’t push. You weren’t compelled. You just… did.

 

 And as you keep typing, you find yourself picturing Gordon hunched over this spreadsheet. Carefully logging the correct VAT code. Matching the mileage. You can’t even imagine it.

 

 Something about you doing it feels... right. Expected. Gordon’s words echo faintly in your mind. "Women’s work."

 

 You scoff to yourself. That’s Charlton talking. That bias. Maybe you’re thinking that way because of the town. Maybe because the amulet. Maybe both.

 

 But you still don’t stop. You process every last receipt. And try to ignore the blinking red lights on the phone.

 
 You take the folder automatically. "Yeah, I’ll get to it."

 

 There’s no real thought behind the response anymore. No guilt, either. As Gordon walks off, you open the spreadsheet. Start sorting. Fuel. Snacks. Another scribbled receipt from Pete’s pharmacy. It doesn’t feel like a favour now. Not even a disruption. It’s just... routine.

 

 You glance at the inbox. Eighteen new emails. The red light on the phone is blinking again. It pulses like a heartbeat. You ignore it and look back to Gordon’s receipts. You’re getting used to this. 

 

 You shouldn’t be. You remember a time - back in the city - when that phrase Gordon used would’ve made you snap. "Pink jobs for the girls. Blue jobs for the men."

 

 It pops into your head now like something natural. Like breathing. You try to push it down. Remind yourself that Charlton is weird. That this isn’t who you are.

 

 But still... as your fingers fly across the keys, the repetition becomes soothing. The inbox, the blinking lights. They feel... loud. Like dealing with that would be too much for you.

 

 But this? Gordon’s admin? This you can handle.

 

 And for a moment, you feel almost... grateful.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You glance at the growing inbox. The flashing phones. Then you look up at Gordon. "Sorry. But I’ve got scheduling to get on with. You wouldn’t want to turn up at the wrong address, would you?"

 

 Gordon exhales through his nose. Frustrated, but not unreasonable. "Guess I’ll have to find time myself then."

 

 He picks up the folder and walks off, muttering something under his breath that you don’t catch. You turn back to your screen and get to work. Calls. Confirmations. Re-bookings. More emails than you can count, and all of them petty.

 

 It’s trivial work. But there’s a lot of it.

 

 Your thoughts flick back to what Gordon said earlier. “Women’s work.” You scoff. The idea’s ancient. Archaic. Stupid. But as you flick between call logs and shared calendars, fingers flying over keys, you feel it. That little itch.

 

 This isn’t what you were built for. That’s right. This isn’t you. Is it?

 

 You sigh. You’re just not sure anymore.

 
 "I can’t, Gordon," you say, without looking up. "Sorry! I’ve got ten jobs to confirm and a call waiting already."

 

 He huffs. Shifts the folder under his arm. "Alright," he mutters. "Can’t blame a guy for trying."

 

 He turns and walks off, and you spin back to the blinking red lights, the inbox, the post-its. You keep typing. Keep answering. Keep smiling. It’s just work. It’s all work.

 

 But your thoughts drift. To how the guys treat you now. Like you’re support staff. Backup. An extra pair of hands. Charlton treats its receptionists like second-tier employees.

 

 And the worst part?

 

 As you answer the next call with a bright, cheerful voice... you wonder how long it’ll be until you’re okay with that.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You don’t even think before the words leave your mouth. "Yeah. I’ll get it."

 

 Dan grins. “Knew I could count on you, darl. Bacon roll. Bit of sauce. And get yourself something sweet while you’re at it. My treat.”

 

 You ignore the comment and step out of the reception area. By the time you get to Fresh Pot, it’s packed. The lunch rush in full swing. Flo is darting behind the counter, trying to smile, take orders, and not lose her mind. You stand in the queue, and for a few minutes just wait.

 

 Thoughts turn to Dan. About the fact he could’ve gone himself. You know he’s not busy. He’s either heading down to the pub or on the phone at his desk, talking to his country club friends on speaker about his latest romantic "conquest." He could’ve got his own lunch. But he asked and you said yes. Not because you wanted to.

 

 Because you needed to.

 

 *That’s what good employees do.*

 

 It takes fifteen minutes to get served. You return to the office with the warm paper bag in hand. Dan is at his desk, feet up, phone wedged under his chin. “That power shot really aced him,” you hear him mutter. “You should have seen his wife giving the eye.”

 

 As he sees you, he winks. “Oh, brilliant. Knew you were the reliable type.”

 

 He doesn’t stop his conversation. Just waves vaguely in your direction and keeps talking. You walk back to reception in silence. Feeling underappreciated. Invisible. But deep down, you know you couldn’t have said no.

 

 Sitting back at your desk, it’s not half an hour until a message comes through from Mr. Thompson.

 

 
 Just spoke to Dan. Mentioned you got him lunch so he could close out a deal. Good work. Helping the men do the actual work is a great way for women to support. Maybe this is the role you were born for, Phillips!
 
 Just spoke to Dan. Mentioned you got him lunch so he could close out a deal. Good work. Usually say that helping the men do the actual work was a woman’s job, but you’re doing it nicely. Maybe you should have been born a girl, Phillips!
 
 

 For some reason, you can’t help but dwell on it for the rest of lunch.

 
 "Sure," you say, already reaching for your coat. Dan barely reacts. “Nice one,” he says, already half-turned back toward his desk. “You’re a star.”

 

 Fresh Pot is busy. Again. It always is. Flo catches your eye and gives you a quick, tired smile before turning back to the till. You join the queue. Wait. Think. Tell yourself you’ll push back next time. That Dan can fetch his own bacon roll and crisps like every other adult.

 

 But when the moment comes - when he grins and asks - you know you’ll just say yes. Every time.

 

 When you return, Dan’s got his feet up again. Phone in one hand, already mid-call. “Ah, the hero returns,” he says, barely looking at you. “Cheers, sweetheart.”

 

 He doesn’t even take the bag from your hand. Just gestures to the desk, still talking. You walk back to reception and sit down. The phones are blinking again. The inbox is filling. This is just your life now. To do what’s asked of you.

 

 Your computer chimes and you see another message from Thompson.

 

 
 Getting the men what they need. Keep it up. Might bag yourself a husband with an attitude like that, Phillips!
 
 Getting the men what they need. Keep it up. Might want to pick out a girl’s name soon, Phillips!
 
 
 

 You sigh, trying to ignore the comment for the rest of lunch.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You pause. You could say no. But instead, you nod. "Sure. I’ll get it."

 

 Dan grins. “Knew you’d come through. Bacon roll, bit of sauce. And maybe something sweet. You pick.”

 

 You slip on your coat and head out. When you get to Fresh Pot, it’s packed with the lunch rush. Flo’s barely keeping up, her hair swinging as she rushes between counters.

 

 You wait in line. Quiet. Still. There’s a strange comfort in it. You think about what just happened. About how you didn’t have to do this. But you did. Not because you were told. Because… it felt expected. Dan’s not busy. You know that. He’ll be on the phone, bragging about the country club or chatting up whoever’s at the Charlton Hotel in the restaurant. But he asked. And in Charlton, when a man like him asks, it’s easier to say yes.

 

 When you return, Dan is exactly where you pictured him. Feet up, phone at his ear. “Cheers,” he says, glancing at the bag. “You’re a star.”

 

 He doesn’t break conversation. Doesn’t say thank you.

 

 You return to your desk and sit down. Phones blinking. Inbox refilling. Another task waiting. You don’t feel angry. Just… smaller.

 

 It’s not half an hour until a message comes through from Mr. Thompson.

 

 
 Just spoke to Dan. Mentioned you got him lunch so he could close out a deal. Good work. Helping the men do the actual work is a great way for women to support. Maybe this is the role you were born for, Phillips!
 
 Just spoke to Dan. Mentioned you got him lunch so he could close out a deal. Good work. Usually say that helping the men do the actual work was a woman’s job, but you’re doing it nicely. Maybe you should have been born a girl, Phillips!
 
 

 For some reason, you can’t help but dwell on it.

 
 Dan doesn’t need to ask twice anymore. You grab your coat. Nod. “I’ll go.”

 

 He smiles like it’s only natural. “Get something sweet, yeah? I trust your taste.”

 

 You step into the high street, shoulders hunched. The queue at Fresh Pot almost out the door, and you already know how this will go. Wait. Deliver. Return. Smile. Dan never says thank you. He just takes what you bring and throws a grin your way like a tip.

 
 
 And the worst part? It doesn’t bother you like it used to.

 

 You walk back into the office, coat damp, fingers tight around the paper bag. He waves you toward his desk, already talking on the phone. You drop it off and return to yours. Another hour, another dozen emails. Then a message from Thompson:

 

 
 Getting the men what they need. Keep it up. Might bag yourself a husband with an attitude like that, Phillips!
 
 Getting the men what they need. Keep it up. Might want to pick out a girl’s name soon, Phillips!
 
 

 You sigh and return to your work.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You glance at the inbox. The phones. You’re actually getting ahead for once. So you shake your head. "Sorry, Dan. I’ve got a lot to get through."

 

 Dan doesn’t frown. Doesn’t yell. He just smiles. Slowly. "See, Phillips," he says, leaning on the desk like he’s your guidance counsellor, "that’s not how things work in Charlton. This place isn’t about ticking boxes or playing Tetris with meetings. It’s about who you know. Who you help. Who you're friends with." He leans in slightly. "And you and me? You’re going about the wrong way of becoming my friend."

 

 He taps the counter once, gives you a little wink, and strolls off.

 

 You watch him go. When he doesn’t return, you assume he’s gone to the pub instead. You keep working. You’re ahead on call logs. The inbox is under control. Appointments confirmed, meetings managed. Still, half an hour later, a message from Thompson drops into your inbox.

 

 Heard you’ve been behind on calendar bookings. Not good enough. Be a team player, Phillips. You don’t want to make enemies here.
 
 
 You stare at the screen. Everything’s on schedule. But you already know: Dan had a word.

 
 You turn him down again. Polite. Calm. "I’ve got work to finish."

 

 Dan exhales like you’ve disappointed him. "You’re still not getting it," he says. "Charlton’s not like where you came from." He adjusts his cufflinks. "Survival here? It’s not about getting the job done. It’s about having people who speak up for you."

 

 Then his voice drops just a little. "And if I’m not one of them - well, people misunderstand things. They hear something wrong. They start to talk. Coffee runs and office smiles won’t fix that."

 

 He walks out, same as always. You slump in your chair. Dan continues to be Dan. And almost expecting it, half an hour later a message from Thompson appears.

 

 Just had feedback about your tone on the phone. Curt. Unhelpful. You’re the face of this company, Phillips. Start acting like it. Think about how you're reflecting us when you talk to people.
 

 You clench your jaw. You know it’s Dan. And you wonder, how many more of these quiet words of his can you take?

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You give him a teasing smile. "I’d love to, really, but I’ve just done my hair… and you’ve seen the drizzle out there. You wouldn’t want me coming back looking like a drowned rat, would you?"

 

 Dan raises an eyebrow, then grins slowly. "Depends on the blouse," he says. "Bet there’s a few contests you’d win if it got see-through."

 

 You should be disgusted. But something in it flickers deep inside you. Not outrage. Something closer to… amusement. You lean on the desk, offering a coy smile. "Know anywhere that runs contests like that?"

 

 Dan chuckles. "There’s a bar out of town. They do event nights. I could take you. You’d clean up."

 

 "That would be nice," you reply, voice soft.

 

 He straightens, adjusting his jacket. "I’ll leave you to it then. Can’t have Flo missing out on my lunchtime charm. But you just say the night, sweetheart - I’ll show you a very good time."

 

 He walks off, smug. You turn back to your screen. You may have pushed him off today, but now you’re wondering how far you could push him. 

 

 And disturbingly… you smile.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You rest your chin on your hand and give him an apologetic look. "Can’t today. I’ve got meetings lined up... unless you want me to cancel everything just for you."

 

 Dan smirks. "I’d be fine with that if I get you to myself instead."

 

 You laugh, flirtatious. "Tempting. But not today. Maybe after work. And I charge overtime."

 

 That lands. Too well. "Don’t worry," Dan says. "I’ve got the hotel on speed dial. Quiet little corner room. Has its… advantages. Especially if the night goes where I think it might."

 

 You deflect again. “I might have a scheduling conflict this evening. You know how bad this booking system is.”

 

 He narrows his eyes, mock-offended. But there’s steel behind the smile. "Keep teasing, sweetheart. I’ll expect some personal attention soon."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 You try to play coy again. "Not today. Too much to do. But I could make you some toast later on. I bet I can butter you up, nicely."

 

 Dan lets a dark grin spread across his face. He steps in closer. Drops his voice. "Maybe we skip lunch. I’ve got something I need to show you."

 

 You blink. "What, now?"

 

 He leans in, voice low and insistent. "Bathroom. It’s quiet at lunchtimes. We won’t be interrupted. Five minutes. I’ll keep it quick. You’ll enjoy it. See how you do at spreading."

 

 You try to laugh it off, make another joke. But he cuts you off.

 

 "You. Me. Bathroom. Now."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 
 Your pulse is still pounding when you nod. You don’t know why you do it. You’re not scared. Not exactly. Not even convinced it’ll help. But you do it anyway. 

 

 Dan’s grin says everything. “Attagirl,” he mutters, already stepping towards the exit. “Come on.”

 

 He doesn’t wait for a response. Just heads down the corridor, casual as anything. You follow. You don’t stop to think. Don’t ask yourself where this leads. You already know. 

 

 Dan opens the bathroom door, gestures you in.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You try to laugh it off, even as your pulse starts to quicken. "Not today," you say, voice soft, coaxing. "Some other time, maybe. I’ve got a full plate… and I wouldn’t want to leave all the boys waiting, would I?"

 

 You even smile. Just enough to soften it. But it doesn’t land. Dan’s grin doesn’t shift. Doesn’t falter. It drops. What’s left behind isn’t amused. Or flattered. It’s something mean. Dangerous.

 

 He steps in, too close. His voice lowers, but the words are sharp, now cutting. "You think this is a game?"

 

 You open your mouth to speak. Say something, anything. But he keeps going. "I’ve been patient with you. Polite. Fun. But now? Now I see what you are.”

 

 He leans in, his breath hot and sour. "Don’t worry, sweetheart. I’ll have a word with Thompson. About his new secretary. I’ll tell him how she strings along the guys who work hard. Makes promises. Flirts. Smiles. Leads ‘em on. But never follows through."

 

 He straightens, eyes scanning your face. "See how long you last."

 

 He walks off, slow and deliberate. You stay frozen at the desk. Cold all over. You don’t have to wait long for his revenge. Thirty minutes later, your computer chimes. A message from Thompson.

 

 Dan’s just been in touch. Says he’s seen you slipping out during work hours. That you were spotted in the Salon. Not acceptable. Buck your ideas up. Or I’ll find someone who will.
 

 You stare at the screen, heart in your throat. You said no. Politely. Firmly. And this is what it gets you. In Charlton, you realise, you push the wrong person too far, and they push back harder. They expect certain things. And not following through has consequences.

 

 On you.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 
 **Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Thompson's Office**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Office_Thompson.png]

 

 
 
 You enter the office, the dark oak wood lit by office lamps and the blinds pulled down. Thompson sits behind his desk, flicking through papers. “Phillips,” he says. “Take a seat.”

 

 You step forward towards his desk and spot an object in front of the seat immediately. Sitting on the desk beside a pile of thick envelopes is a black, boxy typewriter - matte casing, faint gold engraving curling around the edges, and yellowed keys. Keys that fizzle with magic. 

 

 Thompson doesn’t notice your hesitation. He’s already halfway through explaining what he needs. “Correspondence for the McTafey account. I’ll dictate, you type. You can manage that, can’t you?”

 

 You step forward slowly. The keys glint with yellow energy. Almost waiting for your touch.

 
 You enter, seeing the same typewriter sitting exactly where it did last time - solid, humming faintly, slightly too warm to the touch. Magic emanating from its keys.

 

 Thompson gestures to the typewriter. “Same deal. Listen and type.”

 

 You stare at the machine. Its blank paper already loaded. The aura’s still there.

 
 
 
 Actions

 
 
 [Saucy Secretary] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [Dutiful Doer] <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You offer him a playful smile, voice honeyed. “Might break a nail, typing boss. And I know how much you care about my needs.”

 

 Thompson’s grin spreads, wide and leering. “Glad to see you understand how I look out for my people,” he says. “But I really need these letters typed up.”

 

 Flirting your eyelashes, you mock pout. “Oh, come on. There must be something you’d rather do with me this afternoon?”

 

 The old man sighs, his eyes flicking across your body. “I can think of a few things,” he mutters. “But not in the office. Thin walls.”

 

 He leans back in his chair, looking you up and down. “But I’ve got a good relationship with the manager at the Charlton Hotel. Business lunch, say, next week? Private room. Solid brickwork.”

 

 You hear yourself giggle, a small one, like a young girl in love for the first time. “Sounds like we won’t be disturbed.”

 

 “I mean, no one can hear the screams from outside,” he adds, with a chuckle. “That is, if you haven’t already got something in your mouth.”

 

 You freeze, his grotesque stares appraising you like a plaything for his entertainment. 

 

 Thompson then leans forward, gesture crisp toward the typewriter. “But work first. Can you type? Or not?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You try again. Light smile. Flirty tone. Soft voice. “Bit worried about my nails, still…”

 

 But Thompson cuts you off sharply. “Drop the act.” He doesn’t shout. But his voice is all blade. “You wanted things to be professional, didn’t you? To not be - what was your word - inappropriate? Fine. So don’t think you can flirt your way out of what I pay you to do. How’s that for appropriateness?”

 

 He leans back in his seat, adjusting the cuffs on his shirt. “And if you try that again, I’ve got the school on speed dial. Always a few girls who didn’t finish sixth form. Ones who’d do anything --” His eyes glint. “-- and I mean anything – for a respectable job.”

 

 He points at the typewriter. Cold. Final. “Now. Type. And no excuses.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 

 
 
 You lean on the edge of his desk, eyes soft, voice sweet. “I would, but… I wouldn’t want to break a nail. You wouldn’t want me to ruin my best assets, would you? After all, beauty is my greatest asset.”

 

 Thompson raises an eyebrow, unimpressed. But he doesn’t shut you down immediately. “Plenty of secretaries manage to type just fine. Even with their little pedicures.”

 

 You shrug, smile still in place. “I’m still learning,” you say, playing with the edge of your sleeve. “I’d just prefer to… practice a little first. Get more confident. Before I risk looking anything less than perfect.”

 

 You let the final words hang in the air. Seeing skepticism on his face, you realise you need to go one step further. Softer, you add: “Perfect for you.”

 

 Thompson gives a short laugh through his nose. “Fine. Today’s a pass. But typing’s not optional, sweetheart. You want to keep this job, you make sure you’re better prepared next time.”

 

 You nod, almost relieved. But some part of you… enjoyed that. Too much.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You flash a smile. “Still worried about my nails. It’s silly, but I’d hate to chip one.”

 

 Thompson rolls his eyes. “You’ve had enough time. If you can’t do the basics, you’re no use to me.”

 

 You lean in a little closer. “I am useful,” you murmur. “Just not always in the ways people expect. I’m more of a… morale booster. Don’t you think?”

 

 The words come out of your mouth without forming in your brain. Part of you feels aghast at what you said. What you implied. But you instantly feel the rush of endorphins within your body. It feels good.

 

 His expression shifts. Not quite approval, but curiosity. Appraisal. “I’m giving you one last pass,” he says. “You’ve got one more chance to learn. After that, there’ll be consequences.”

 

 You lower your lashes, savouring the sensation of your body responding. “Oh, I’ll look into it.” Then, lightly: “We wouldn’t want to have to punish me, would we?”

 

 Thompson grins. But doesn’t answer.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You try again. Smile bright. Voice light. Another flirty deflection on your lips. “I just don’t think I’m up for this, today. Isn’t there something else I can be doing for you?”

 

 He stands from behind his desk as he looks at you. Appraising you. His frustration from your ongoing resistance in conflict with his curiosity.

 

 “You’re right. If you won’t type, I’ll have to find another use for you in the afternoons.” He gestures toward the desk. “Bend over.”

 

 Your breath catches. “Excuse me?”

 

 He steps around the desk. “You heard me. Over the desk. Now.”

 

 You feel the weight of the magic inside you, the compulsion pressing faintly at the edge of your thoughts. But this time, it’s not the effects of magic that makes you hesitate.

 

 It’s simple fear.

 

 Thompson’s voice drops, low and commanding. “A good secretary follows orders.”

 

 **Actions**

 
 Accept his demand - *If you know one thing about Thompson, you know that he won't respond kindly to your micro-penis. You don't want to take the chance.*

 
 <>
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 You take a seat and place your fingers on the typewriter. The keys are warm, almost pulsing. And as Thompson starts speaking, your hands begin moving before your mind fully catches up.

 

 “McTafey,” Thompson begins, “Thank you for your ongoing commitment. In regards to your challenges with regulations for your sun room, I suggest we convene at the Mayor’s office to discuss a way forward. Red tape shouldn’t stop any of us making the most of our hard earned savings to improve our homes.”

 

 “Feel free to call and arrange a time that’s suitable for you. My new secretary can work out the details with Town Hall. I trust you’ll find them up to standard. Be specific with your requests, though - details confuse them sometimes, but they are trying their best.”

 

 You flinch. The phrasing lands wrong. But your fingers don’t stop. As you type, you hear the words echo in your mind. Details confuse them sometimes, but they are trying their best. Arranging an appointment doesn’t seem beyond you. But something seems suddenly complex about the task. But you’ll at least try to do it, despite the difficulty.

 

 Some part of you knows it’s the magic. The embers of magic leap up from the keys, sparking against your fingertips. But even as you try to pause or question, your fingers don’t respond. The words appear on the paper anyway. Smooth. Compliant. Mechanical.

 

 Another line comes: “I’ve instructed them to take notes, though I doubt they’ll grasp the full picture.”

 

 Your cheeks flush. Not just embarrassment. Confusion. Because it doesn’t feel false. For a moment, you really don’t know if you understand it all. Maybe you're missing something. Maybe there’s more to booking appointments than you thought. You try to shake it. But the typewriter hums beneath your skin.

 

 Time passes and Thompson continues to dictate. Letters for McTafeys, for the most part responses to problems they are having with their extension. But you wince whenever Thompson injects a phrase that references you. Demeaning. Condescending. Belittling your abilities. When it’s done, he dismisses you. You stand and exit the office, aware of the impact of the typewriters magic, even as you find the idea of arranging appointments with the town hall overwhelming.

 
 You sit. Keys ready. Fingers waiting. Thompson begins to speak. “Client requires discretion. Have them call my secretary directly. They get lost in the details, but enthusiastic. After all, a good secretary follows orders.”

 

 You wince. But you don’t stop typing. Each word slides through your fingers, and the magic tingles deeper now, settling in like an old perfume. It clouds your thoughts, just a little. Makes you question yourself. There’s a line: “With encouragement, even the simplest secretary can become adequate.”

 

 And you believe it. Maybe that’s what you are. Simple. In need of guidance.

 

 You know this is magic. You know it’s the machine. Still, you want Thompson to think you’re doing well. You want him to praise you. You want to be good at this, even if part of you knows it’s a spell whispering that need.

 

 When he finally finishes, you blink down at the finished letter. Typed perfectly.

 

 But your thoughts feel fuzzier than when you started.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You pause for a second too long. You could say no. Could tell Thompson you’re not comfortable using that thing. But instead, you nod. “Alright. I’ll do it.”

 

 You sit. Place your hands on the keys. They’re warm. Buzzing faintly. Like they’ve been waiting for you. Thompson begins. “McTafey’s sunroom issue. Let’s start there.”

 

 His voice is calm. Businesslike. But it’s the phrasing that catches you. “Feel free to call and book an appointment. My secretary’s still getting the hang of things, but they are eager to help. Just be clear. Complicated details tend to go over their head.”

 

 You don’t flinch. Not visibly. But you feel it. The magic buzzes stronger with every word you transcribe. You know it’s happening. You can feel it softening your focus, dulling your thoughts at the edges. The phrases nestle into your mind - *complicated details tend to go over their head* - and part of you starts to believe it.

 

 The worst part? You’re letting it happen.

 

 There’s no invisible hand on yours. You just… don’t want to say no to Thompson. You don’t want to see how he’d react if you did. You’re choosing this. That’s what scares you. And as Thompson continues, dictating lines that belittle your intellect, wrap it in faux-praise and backhanded encouragement, you feel something sinking inside you.

 

 You’ll be fine, you tell yourself. You’re still you.

 

 *How long can you keep saying that?*
 
 
 You take the seat as Thompson begins speaking. The keys thrum beneath your fingers. Familiar. So familiar.

 

 “Tell them my secretary will call to confirm,” he dictates. “They are diligent, but gets tangled up in long words sometimes.”

 

 You nod as you type. No heat in your face. No reflexive frown. These words feel… normal now. Not kind. But expected. It’s only after the letter’s done that you pause. Blink. And realise what just happened. You didn’t wince. You didn’t question it.

 

 He called you muddled. Slow. And you accepted it like it was a fair observation. The thought sends a chill through you. You’re not under a spell to force you to do this. Not exactly. But Charlton doesn’t just rely on incantations. Just repetition. Expectations. And words.

 

 Trouble is, you’re starting to believe them.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You hesitate. Just for a second, trying to think of an excuse. “I, uh… I don’t actually know how to type.”

 

 Thompson stops mid-shuffle of his paperwork. Stares. “What do you mean you don’t know how to type?” His tone is flat. Disbelieving. “That’s all you used to do. As a programmer.”

 

 You scramble. “It’s different. I mean, keyboards and typewriters. They’re not the same.”

 

 He snorts. “It’s exactly the same thing.”

 

 There’s a long silence. You know it’s not a good excuse. You’re not even sure why you said it. Maybe panic. Maybe instinct. Maybe that hum under the keys scared you more than you thought. Thompson eyes you like you’re wasting his time.

 

 “There’s differences,” you repeat. “Have you tried yourself?” 

 

 “Of course not,” he says immediately, with a scoff. “That’s women’s work.”

 

 The words linger in the air. They land like a verdict. You realise how Thompson sees this role. How he sees you. Suited. Apt. Like it was always meant to be yours.

 The words linger in the air. Heavy. Ugly. Thompson looks back at you, as he himself realises what he’s said. He doesn’t even look at you like a man anymore. For once, you can see a truth behind his eyes.

 

 Thompson shakes his head. “If you can’t type, you can’t even perform the basics of the job. Maybe I should send you back to school. Get you sat in Business Studies with the girls.”

 

 He grabs a folder from the desk, then just as quickly tosses it aside. “In the meantime, go to the library. I’m sure they’ve got a book. Learn it. For next time.”

 

 He waves you out like you’re a waste of his breath. You leave, stomach twisting. You might’ve avoided the typewriter this time. But you know he’s going to keep asking.
 
 
 You see the typewriter. Already humming. Waiting. But you keep your distance. “I haven’t had a chance to get to the library yet,” you say quickly.

 

 Thompson glares at you. “Stop dithering. Either you want to this job or you don’t.”

 

 He doesn’t shout. Doesn’t bark. Just lets the disappointment drip from every word. “You’ve been here long enough now. You can’t make excuses forever.”

 

 He gestures to the door. “Go learn how to type, Phillips. Or I’ll find someone who already can.”

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Beginning with the basics, you teach Emily how to answer the phones, greet customers, schedule appointments for Clive and Gordon, and manage Thompson’s calendar. You stumble a lot - it’s all new to you – but you get through the basics. None of it is particularly hard. It’s repetitive. Monotonous. Emily picks it up without a challenge.

 

 Then the bell above the front door rings.

 

 Dan strolls in, loud as ever. You can smell the alcohol on his breath from across the desk. "Afternoon," he says, grinning.

 

 Then Dan’s eyes land on Emily. His grin widens. "Well, well. Look who it is. The elusive Miss Phillips. I was starting to think your kept you locked up somewhere."

 

 You shift uncomfortably. “Emily’s here to do an internship,” you tell him. “I’m just showing her what she needs to do.”

 

 “Hope you’re better at teaching than you were at keeping Thompson on side,” Dan snarks, a cruel smile forming. “Takes a real alpha to know how to work the old man. It’s all about people skills. Gotta’ have some charm. Looks like your sister got all those genes to herself, though.”

 

 
 You glance over to your sister, watching Emily squirm back into her seat. She tries to avoid his looks, but he moves to hang over the counter and look directly down at her. "Come on, just being friendly. In fact,” he says, his face coming closer to Emily’s. “She and I should have a little chat. I can tell her about how things really work around here. And Friday afternoons are so dull.”

 

 “She’s here to work, Dan,” you tell him flatly. “If Mr. Thompson sees her slacking off, it’ll go straight back to the school."

 

 “Don’t worry about Thompson,” he replies. Then his voice drops, just a little. "Unless I’m not occupied this afternoon. Then I might find myself in his office. Talking about how her ’s not even managing reception. Shame, really."

 

 He grins at Emily, lingering a second too long, the breath of alcohol invading her face. “What do you say, Miss Phillips? Fancy keeping me occupied?"

 

 Emily looks up at him, then to you. Waiting for guidance.

 
 You glance over to your sister, but you’re surprised to see her coyly looking up at Dan. A girlish giggle escapes her mouth. Dan hears it and grins. 

 

 “See, she’s okay with a little banter,” he tells you, his predatory eyes not moving from Emily. "What do you say, Miss. Phillips. Fancy a little chat in the back of the office? I’ll let you know how things really work around here.”

 

 Before Emily can reply, you interject. “She’s here to work, Dan. If Mr. Thompson sees her slacking off, it’ll go straight back to the school."

 

 “Don’t need to worry about Thompson with me around,” he says, but now his words firmly targeted at Emily. “You’re not as big of a stick in the mud as your , are you? Want to see how the closers celebrate their big deals?”

 

 Looking over to Emily, you notice her relaxed posture and small grin. She runs a fingernail across her lips before she sees you watching. She quickly drops her hand back to her side, trying to regain some composure.

 

 “Come on, big . Let her out to play. You wouldn’t leave me alone on a Friday afternoon, would you? I might grow bored and have a chat with Thompson about how well you’re doing on reception. Or how badly you are, to rephrase.”

 

 Emily looks back at you, waiting for your direction. Her creeping smile at the edge of her mouth tells you what she wants to do, but you are sure nothing good can come of it.

 
 
 You spend the afternoon walking Emily through more reception tasks. Calendar reminders, rescheduling calls, chasing up Gordon’s notes. She's still attentive, but less tentative now. Either she’s getting the hang of it… or getting too comfortable.

 

 The bell chimes. Dan again.

 

 “Look who’s back,” he grins, slouching against the counter, eyes already drifting to Emily. “Was hoping I’d run into you again, Miss Phillips.”

 

 
 Emily stiffens. Her fingers hesitate over the keyboard as Dan leans in. “Thought maybe we’d pick up our little chat,” he says, voice low. “You seemed real keen.”

 

 You cut in quickly. “Emily’s still here to work, Dan.”

 

 Dan’s smile fades slightly. “She’s allowed a break, isn’t she?” Then, quieter: “Be a shame if I had to fill Thompson in on how the front desk’s been run lately.”

 

 Emily looks to you. Nervous, expectant. Waiting for your lead.

 
 Emily barely looks up from the desk, but there’s a flicker of amusement in her eyes. She toys with her necklace as Dan leans closer.

 

 “Good to see you’re still around,” he says. “You learn that trick with your necklace from Annie, or are you born this way?”

 

 She giggles softly.

 

 “Reckon she’s earned a coffee, don’t you?” Dan asks, not even looking at you now. “Or we could step into the back and talk about her future here.”

 

 You step in, your tone sharp. “She’s working.”

 

 Dan shrugs, unbothered. “Your call. But maybe Thompson needs a reminder of how things used to run smoother.”

 

 Emily gives you a sly look, waiting for permission.

 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 <>
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 You’ve been waiting too long.

 

 Whatever Dan wanted to “chat” about, it’s taking more than a few minutes. The front desk feels quieter without Emily nearby, but it’s not in a peaceful way. It’s the kind that tightens your chest. You keep glancing toward the door, hoping to hear footsteps. Nothing.

 

 Then, at last, the door opens.

 

 
 Emily steps out, head lowered, cheeks pale. She doesn't speak. You hear Dan's voice bellow out as she walks through the door. "See you again soon, sweetheart."

 

 Her eyes flick to you, but only briefly. Instead she sits down in silence. A long moment passes, but you hear her sigh. "Alright. What's next?"

 

 You open your mouth. “Emily…”

 

 She cuts you off with a look. "Don't. He's just a creep. Enough said. You were showing me the filing on the server."

 

 You monotonously walk through the details of how to file documents across the network, but your voice is flat and emotionless. Emily keeps her comments to a minimum, focusing on the work at hand.

 

 The last hour of the day drips away. Soon, it is time for Emily to leave.

 

 "I'll see you at home," you say. "I've got to finish up."

 

 She nods. Then silently picks up her bag and walks out the door without a word.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 The door swings open mid-laugh. Dan’s voice is louder than it needs to be: “Maybe next time, you can show me how you do it.”

 

 Emily stands in the doorway, looking back over her shoulder into the office. Her voice, lowered and sultry, sings with amusement. “Maybe I will.”

 

 She saunters back to the desk, cheeks flushed, tucking a strand of hair behind her ear. There’s a new bounce in her step, something performative in the way she smooths her skirt and pretends not to notice your stare.

 

 You lower your voice. “You should be careful with him. He’s not --”

 

 “He’s not that bad,” she interrupts gently, almost dreamily. “Actually kind of charming, once you get past the bluster.”

 

 You stare. She flashes you a grin. “I put in a good word for you, by the way. Dan said he might talk to Thompson about giving you a break. Now, where were we.”

 

 For the next hour you walk her through how to file documents across the network, but her attention is elsewhere. She keeps staring back over to the office door.

 

 The day soon gets away from you and before you know it, Emily's afternoon has passed.

 

 "Thanks for today," she says as she picks up her bag. "And thanks for not being, well, overbearing." She grins. "It's nice to have... some fun."

 

 You watch her go without comment. She bounces over to the door with her grin not leaving her face.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After some time, you hear the office door creak open. Emily steps out, her face carefully blank. She doesn’t look at you, doesn’t say a word. She walks straight to the desk, drops into the seat, and picks up where she left off like nothing happened.

 

 For a moment, you just watch her. Eventually, you ask, “Everything okay?”

 

 She doesn’t look up. “Fine.”

 

 Taking her at her word, you start to show her some complexity in the calendar scheduling system. She follows along, clicking when told, nodding when expected. There’s no conversation. No connection. Just silence filled with keystrokes.

 

 As the hour ends, Emily gathers her things.

 

 “I’ll see you at home,” she says, still not meeting your gaze.

 

 And she leaves. You glance over to the door, wondering what Dan said to her this time. And how long you'll get the silent treatment from her.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 The door opens with a laugh. Dan’s, loud and satisfied.

 

 Emily appears a second later, grinning as she steps out. Her cheeks are flushed again. You catch the soft sway of her hips as she walks back to the desk, seemingly unaware of how it looks.

 

 She slides into her seat, humming something under her breath.

 

 You keep your voice low. “Be careful with him.”

 

 Emily just shrugs. “He’s funny. Besides, he said Thompson might be lightening up on you. I told him you’ve been carrying the place.”

 

 You blink, unsure what to say.

 

 But she’s already leaning back in her chair, half-listening as you try to walk her through filing protocols. She keeps glancing toward the door, as if half-expecting Dan to call her back in.

 

 Eventually, after another hour passes, she stands and grabs her bag.

 

 “Catch you later,” she says breezily, already moving for the door. “Same time next week?”

 

 The door clicks shut behind her.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
 Dan finally gets the hint, wordlessly leaving and the door swings shut behind him with a smug little click. Silence fills the front office again. Not peace, but pressure.

 

 You and Emily don’t speak at first.

 

 Eventually, you clear your throat and gesture to the screen. “We should get back to the scheduling interface. You were asking about recurring appointments?”

 

 She nods, wordlessly. You ease back into the teaching.

 

 
 Emily follows along, if a little slowly. Her focus isn’t quite there, and you can see her glancing now and then at the door Dan walked through. More out of dread than distraction.

 

 You guide her through the double-booking system and how Clive prefers phone confirmation on anything marked 'tentative.' She listens. She's trying. She doesn't say much, but when she does, her voice is steady.

 

 By the end of the hour, she’s moving with more confidence again. As she gathers her things, she pauses beside you.

 

 “Thanks,” she says. “For stepping in. I didn’t… I didn’t want to be alone with him.”

 

 A beat passes. “I mean, not just because of him. But… I’m glad you had my back.”

 

 Then, softly, “I’ll see you at home.”

 

 She smiles and opens the door, stepping out into Charlton.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 

 
 Emily takes her seat, but her posture is closed. You resume your explanation, but she’s barely engaging. Her replies are clipped. Her fingers tap impatiently at the edge of the desk when you pause.

 

 You walk her through the internal memo process, but she doesn’t seem to be listening. When you ask her to repeat something back, she sighs and leans back. “I’m not an idiot. I know how to send a stupid email.”

 

 You give her a look. “I’m just trying to help you learn.”

 

 “I am learning. But I don’t need you hovering every second like I’m some clueless little kid.”

 

 After an hour passes, you have not gotten much further. Emily seems reluctant to learn, almost purposefully derailing your teaching.

 

 "Everything okay?" you try, as the day draws to a close.

 

 She sighs. “You wouldn't understand," she mutters. "I just want to have some fun. Not sitting behind a desk. Following the rules.”

 

 Her expression softens, only slightly. “I’m not you.”
 

 She grabs her bag and stands, moving towards the door. “I’ll see you at home.”

 

 The door closes gently. But firmly.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 Dan’s exit is a little less dramatic this time, but no less unwanted. The door shuts. Silence returns.

 

 You look over to Emily. “Calendar system?” She gives the faintest nod.

 

 
 She listens quietly as you walk her through the process again. She asks fewer questions this time. Not out of boredom. Just restraint.

 

 There’s a heaviness to her silence, but not bitterness. Just tiredness. She finishes the tasks without fuss.

 

 When the hour ends, she picks up her bag.

 

 “Thanks, ,” she says simply. “For again keeping him out of my face.”

 

 And she leaves.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 Emily slouches back in her chair as you begin, not bothering to pretend she’s interested. Her eyes glaze over halfway through the example booking flow.

 

 After trying for some time, you stop explaining. "Do we have a problem?"

 

 She lets out a quiet snort. “No, no problem. Not at all. Just once again, I’m not allowed to have any fun.”

 

 No eye contact. No thank-you. Just that.

 

 She stands, pulls her bag over her shoulder, and walks out without another word.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: ThompsonsReceptionAnnieWork
text:
**Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 
 
 You step around the front desk, taking in the clutter and chaotic mess that is Annie's filing system. Folders are sprawled out over the desk. Brightly coloured post-it notes line the edges of the monitor. A dull mouse is livened up by the glittery pink mouse it rests on.

 

 The phone begins to ring. You sit down and answer it. "Good morning," you say, echoing the words you've heard from Annie. "Thompson's Repairs."

 

 Over the next thirty minutes, you try to answer emails in-between the constant calls. Every time you answer one email, two more arrive. Most of them are minor. Mundane.

 

 “Can I push my appointment by fifteen minutes?”
“Where do I park?”
“Can you pop a reminder in my calendar?”
 

 Even the phone calls feel off. Customers want to chat. "How's your day going?" they ask, like you're just another sunny voice on the other end. They don’t care about the work. They just want the performance.

 

 You’re halfway through flagging a broken link in the supplier portal when you hear boots on the carpet.

 

 Gordon appears in the doorway. "Annie," he says, not waiting for a reply. "Booking system's broken again."

 

 You frown at him, curious. "What's wrong with it?"

 

 "Doesn't say where to go," he replies flatly. "No address attached. Theodore's making it worse."

 

 You eye him with interest. This could be a chance to win over support in getting Thompson to rehire you. You just need to think of a way to do it that will convince Gordon without raising suspicions.

 You step around the front desk, taking in the clutter and chaotic mess that is Annie's filing system. Folders are sprawled out over the desk. Brightly coloured post-it notes line the edges of the monitor. A dull mouse is livened up by the glittery pink mouse it rests on.

 

 The phone begins to ring. You sit down and answer it. "Good morning," you say, echoing the words you've heard from Annie. "Thompson's Repairs."

 

 Over the next thirty minutes, you try to answer emails in-between the constant calls. Every time you answer one email, two more arrive. Most of them are minor. Mundane.

 

 “Can I push my appointment by fifteen minutes?”
“Where do I park?”
“Can you pop a reminder in my calendar?”
 

 Even the phone calls feel off. Customers want to chat. "How's your day going?" they ask, like you're just another sunny voice on the other end. They don’t care about the work. They just want the performance.

 

 You’re halfway through flagging a broken link in the supplier portal when you hear boots on the carpet.

 

 Gordon appears in the doorway. "Annie," he says, not waiting for a reply. "Where's Phillips?"

 

 "I'm not sure," you feign, trying to think of an excuse.

 

 Gordon grunts. "Booking system's broken again."

 

 You frown at him, curious. "What's wrong with it?"

 

 "Doesn't say where to go," he replies flatly. "No address attached. Phillips is slacking. Need to have a word with Thompson. He free?"

 

 You eye him with concern. If you don't act now, you'll risk Thompson's wrath. Not to mention his anger at you not showing up to work.

 **Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 
 
 The reception is quieter now. The phone stopped ringing five minutes ago, and you’ve just started sorting through emails when the door swings open behind you.

 

 Dan strides in, loosening his tie like he’s just stormed out of a courtroom drama.

 

 “Annie,” he says, exasperated. “Is there any reason I just walked out of a meeting without the damn contract notes?”

 

 You blink. “I haven’t touched the system,” you say, careful to keep your tone light.

 

 He barks a laugh. “Course you haven’t. Would’ve noticed - there weren't emojis in my meeting invite.”

 

 You say nothing. He’s already pacing. “Theodore’s mangled the code again. No tags, no trail, no quote. I’ve got a client waiting to sign and nothing to show but my charming personality. Which normally gets the job done. Today though, I needed the paperwork.”

 

 He points vaguely at nothing. “I told Thompson this would happen. You can’t fire the one bloke holding the place together and expect it not to fall over. Phillips knew how to keep a pipeline clean. Mostly.”

 

 That last bit hangs in the air. That was most definitely something he didn't say.

 

 He flops into the visitor chair, leering at your legs as he does so. “Honestly, if someone in this place had half a brain, I’d propose. But until then, I guess I’m stuck doing everything myself.”

 

 This is it. Your moment. You could push now and plant the idea of Dan having a word with Thompson about getting you rehired.

 The front desk is quiet when Dan barrels in, phone in one hand, sunglasses in the other. It doesn't matter that it's permanently overcast in Charlton.

 

 “Annie,” he announces, like he's walking into a courtroom. “Is there a reason I just spent ten minutes trying to schedule a meeting only to discover that the calendar app thinks our client lives in a parking lot?”

 
 
 You blink, caught off guard. “I haven’t touched the system,” you offer.

 

 He stops, dramatically sighs, and slides his sunglasses up onto his head. Despite the dim lighting.

 

 "Of course you didn't," he replies. "You don't need to worry your pretty little head with business. What I need is for Phillips to explain what the hell they think they're doing. Where are they?"

 

 "I'm not sure," you reply, trying to assess the situation.

 

 “Well," he says, dramatically pulling his glasses down to look over the rim. "If you see them, tell them I’m grabbing lunch with Thompson. Got some thoughts to share."

 

 He starts toward the corridor, still muttering to himself.

 **Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 
 
 You are working away at the reception desk when you hear the bell chime above the door as someone enters. You paint your customer service smile on your face before looking up to see Emily standing in the entrance, looking back at you.

 

 
 
 
 Emily eyes you sheepishly. "Hey," she says quietly. "Annie, right? I'm Emily. I'm supposed to start an internship today."

 

 The internship...

 

 Emotions flutter inside you. Shame. Embarrassment. An odd sensation where your mind is trying to make sense of what feels like a dream. But you push it all down. "Sure," you reply. "Take a seat."

 

 You gesture to the visitors chair. Emily puts her bag neatly underneath the reception desk and sits down, waiting expectedly.

 
 Emily grins, strolling around the counter with confidence and purpose. She tosses her bag behind the counter and leans casually against the computer. "Hey! Annie, right? I love your dress. Where did you get it?"

 

 "Emily..." you begin, but realisation hits you. The internship...

 

 You take a gulp. "Evans," you mutter.

 

 "I didn't know that sold skirts that short," Emily whispers to you, grinning. "But if you've got it, you might as well flaunt it."

 

 "You're here for the internship?" you ask her, playing for time.

 

 She shrugs. "I mean, I'd much rather get your advice on how to find bargains at Evans. But sure. Where do we begin?"

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Emily smiles meekly at you, still feeling uncomfortable being here. She walks around the desk and pops her school bag down, then hangs awkwardly off to the side.

 

 "So. What are we doing today?" she asks.

 
 Emily grins at the sight of you, but strolls in with confidence and purpose. She tosses her bag behind the counter and leans casually against the computer. "Hey Annie! Another day of manning phones and talking to beefy tradesmen. That reminds me, I don't suppose Dan is around, is he?"

 

 Her eyes wander. You move the mouse, bringing the monitor back to life, trying to make a point. "Oh," she exclaims. "Right. Work."

 
 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 You are working the reception inbox, responding to customer’s queries, when a message pops up on your screen.

 

 Need you in my office. Now.
 

 You stop what you're doing and stand up, knowing full well not to risk Thompson’s wrath. You walk through into the office - where you used to work - and step up to the door. In an instant you hear Thompson’s voice bellow. “Enter!”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 
 **Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 The day draws to a close.

 

 You shut down the computer, logging out of systems and wiping down the dusty monitor. You glance over to the office and see light seeping out from underneath the door. Someone is still working.

 

 Which is just as well, as Annie didn't give you her set of keys.
 
 

 Flicking off the desk lamp, you gather your belongings and exit, grateful for the end of the working day.

 Emily looks up as you approach, idly playing with her nails. She doesn’t seem as tense anymore. In fact, she doesn’t seem emotionally engaged at all.

 Emily lounges back, her eyes drifting over towards a nearby copy of A New Woman magazine. She hums a soft tune to herself, her movements light and unbothered.

 Emily crosses her legs elegantly as she glances up at you, a smile playing on her lips. She’s adjusting a bracelet on her wrist, her movements slow and deliberate. 

 
 

 As you approach, she looks disinterested, almost as if pretending not to notice you. When she finally does, her gaze is distant, disinterested. "Did you need something?" Her tone is clipped, her patience thin.

 As you approach, there’s a flicker of hesitation before she speaks. "Oh. Hey." She smiles, but it doesn’t quite reach her eyes. There’s something careful about the way she watches you, like she’s trying to gauge your intentions before deciding how to respond.

 As you approach, her expression is unreadable. "Hey." She gives you a polite smile, but you can see in her expression that her mind is on other things that you can’t draw her away from.

 As you approach, she perks up slightly, shifting in her seat to face you properly. "Hey ! Got a minute?" There’s an easy familiarity in the way she greets you, as if she’s relieved to have you around.

 As you approach she beams, setting aside whatever she was doing without hesitation. "! How are you?" Her voice is warm, her expression open. There’s no guard, no hesitation. Just a sense of comfort in having you near.

 

 Emily stares back at you, waiting for you to speak.
