title: YourHomeTerrenceDialogue0
text:
A few minutes pass before the doorbell rings. You usher your sister away and open the door to find Terrence standing there with a stack of textbooks in one hand and a pen tucked behind his ear. He offers you an easy grin. “Hey,” he says as he steps inside, eyes lingering on you.

 

 You lead him to the kitchen table. He sets the books down but keeps his gaze on you, flipping open his notebook with deliberate slowness. “So,” you prompt, “which problems are giving you trouble?”

 

 He leans forward, the book angled so he can sneak peeks at your face between the equations. “This one,” he says, tapping the page. But then his finger trails off as he catches your eye, smiling. “But honestly, I’m more interested in the teacher than the question.”

 

 You ignore his words and show him the steps through the problems. He nods, but he also reaches out, brushing the back of his hand against yours when he turns the page. “Wow, that actually makes sense,” he murmurs, voice low. “I could listen to you explain math all evening.”

 

 He closes the notebook with a soft thud and meets your gaze directly. “Mind if I take a short break? Maybe… chat a bit?”

 
 A little time passes before the doorbell rings. You usher your sister up to her room to avoid any complications and answer the door. Terrence stands awkwardly outside, a number of books stacked up in his hands. “Hey,” he nervously says to you.

 

 You invite him in and the two of you sit down at the kitchen table. He looks around, surveying the living space cautiously. “Nice house,” he comments after some time, as he finally relaxes.

 

 “So,” you begin. “What areas of maths are you struggling with?”

 

 Terrence opens an exercise book and talks you through some of the maths exercises that are proving challenging for him. You are happy that it not only seems simple to you, but that you can see where he’s tripping up.

 

 Time passes as Terrence diligently follows your tutorage. With a little encouragement, he soon improves. For the first time since talking with him, he seems calm.

 

 
 Terrence perches on the edge of the kitchen chair, book open but eyes lifting from the equations to meet yours with a warm, teasing smile.

 
 Terrence fidgets on the kitchen table chair, trying to focus on his book.

title: YourHomeEmilyFirstDay
text:
"Hi ," Emily says hesitantly. "How did you sleep?"

 

 You look down at your younger sister and find yourself reminded of how small and vulnerable you felt yesterday. No longer is Emily just another person. Something has permanently changed in your mind. Even if it's just a memory, you feel in some way that you are looking at a reflection of you.

 

 "Good thanks," you reply, pushing the uncanny feeling aside in your mind. "Or as well as can be expected."

 

 She nods, silent. Then looks down at the table, not meeting your eyes. "So. What do you want to do today?"

 

 You mull over your response. "I'm not even sure I know where to begin, Em," you begin. "This time yesterday I thought we lived in a world where magic was something in fantasy books and kids' tales. And now this." You take out the amulet from your pocket, showing Emily its shining brilliance.

 

 She looks between the amulet and you. "You could try finding out more about that amulet. Where Liz got it from and how it works."

 

 You look at Emily, quizzically. "Do you have her number?"

 

 Emily shakes her head. "But she'll be at school today. Plus, we need to understand what's happening at school."

 

 "You want me to transform again and go back again today, don't you?" you ask her.
 
 

 She bites her lip, saying nothing.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 You sigh and start to talk. "This isn't an easy decision, but I think it's best if I go to work. We need to keep up appearances. I can investigate the town to see if I can find anything about magic, the amulet or the school whilst you go there today.

 

 Emily's eyes glisten, but she holds back tears. She nods. "I understand," she murmurs.

 

 "Just keep your wits about you and try to avoid anything that feels odd," you say, trying to provide comfort. "Until we know more about what is going on, we have to assume that anything you do or say at school could have an effect on you."

 

 "I'll try," she says, standing up. She picks up her school satchel from the kitchen table and puts it on.

 
 
 “Have a good day at school,” you say as she moves to the door. “I’ll see you after work.”

 

 She nods, and walks out the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “Let’s get this over with,” you tell Emily. “Give me your lipgloss.” 

 

 Emily’s eyes widen and she smiles gratefully. She hurriedly rifles through her school satchel and hands over the lipgloss - a now treasured possession for her. You are sure the school’s effects had something to do with this. You hope it doesn’t have the same impact on you.

 

 “Just remember,” Emily says. “Liz gave me that amulet. Try and find her. From the sounds of what she said to you, she knows more than she’s told either of us.”

 

 You nod and take the lipgloss from her. 

 

 **Actions**

title: YourHomeTransformEmily

You put the necklace around your neck and clutch Emily's lipgloss, bracing yourself. The amulet tingles, almost as if the trinket is anticipating the change to come.

 

 
 Holding on to the lipgloss, you visualise Emily in your mind. You think of what she looks like now.

 Holding on to the lipgloss, you visualise Emily in your mind. You think of what she looks like now. Still dressed in her school uniform.

 
 

 Remembering the note, you speak the words out loud. “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 The emerald warms your chest against your shirt as you picture her. You take a breath and not a moment later you feel warm energy pulsate out from the emerald and spread across your body.

 

 Your hair stands up on edge as the pain cascades across your skin. You hold on to the mental picture of Emily. Her slender figure. Fair complexion. Her large expressive brown eyes. Her hair, straight and long.

 
 
You picture Emily's increased chest size and decreased height, remembering the changes Nurse Rancy made. You visualise how her uniform fits differently now. Tighter across the bust, looser at the hem. How she seems to take up less space, but draw more attention. A compact, exaggerated version of herself.

 
 
You picture Emily's increased chest size, remembering the changes Nurse Rancy made. You visualise how her shirt now clings more tightly to her bust, the weight altering her posture just slightly.

 
 
You picture Emily’s decreased height, remembering the changes Nurse Rancy made. You visualise how she now stands just that bit smaller. Unmistakably petite. You recall the way her feet barely touched the floor when she sat, or how she looked up at taller boys with a softened gaze.

 
 

 You squeal as you feel your bones crunching and your skin changing again, but you push against the pain. You hear yourself shriek in agony in a pitch that belongs to Emily's voice. Then the pain suddenly vanishes, leaving only your heavy breathing as your chest rises and lowers underneath your new clothes.

 

 You glance over at the mirror and see a perfect copy of Emily, staring back at you. You feel smaller, more fragile. A little less *assertive*. And you notice that your *intelligence* seems sluggish. Thoughts that came quickly now seem to take a tiny bit longer.

 

 
 You lean over and pick up her backpack that she carries around at the weekends. You're ready for the day ahead.

 You visualise Emily in your mind and speak the words from the note. The emerald warms slightly, but its energy crackles only momentarily before sputtering out. 

 

 You remember Liz’s words about the amulet needing time to recharge. As certain as you can be about anything right now, you’d bet that you need to wait a little more time before it can be used again.

Every attempt you make to engage her ends in frustration - she ignores your explanations, fiddles with her phone that barely works, and openly yawns in your face. In fact, the only time that she looks happy at all is when you can't explain one of the answers. To your discomfort, that seems to happen more regularly than you would like.

 

 "Can I go now?" she eventually asks, standing up without waiting for an answer. "I've got better things to do."

 

 You watch her leave, a sinking feeling in your stomach. Charlton's influence on her seems stronger every day, and it's becoming clear that academics no longer matter to her at all. That she took glee in your inability to explain anything only makes you think you've only emboldened her outlook on school work.

 

 **Actions**

 For the rest of the evening you sit beside Emily, but barely say a word to her. Instead, you run the questions through on your own. Trying to spark thoughts and solutions that you would have previously thought would come naturally.

 

 "Is this a lesson me, or yourself?" Emily finally says, after trying to pull one of the books from you.

 

 "I need to understand this to help you, Em," you tell her.

 

 She throws you a dark look. "It doesn't seem like you're that interested in helping me," she bites back with more than a little venom.

 

 She pushes back her chair and stands. "I'm going to bed." Her eyes narrow as she regards you with malice. "Enjoy brushing on up school work."

 

 You watch her go as she stands and walks quickly up the stairs to her room. A bedroom door shuts firmly.

 

 You glance back to the book in front of you. This is helping Emily, isn't it? You need to be sharp to help her.

 

 Or are you more concerned with how the town is affecting you now?

title: YourHomeResistanceRingResolution
text:
Remembering the ring that Jennifer gave to you, you take it out from your pocket and look at it closely.

 

 Physically it looks like an unmarked, unfancy gold ring. Smooth and clear of etchings or symbols. But focusing your mind on it, you recognise the tingling properties of magic infused within its elements.

 

 You ponder what Jen said. If Emily wore it to school, you are sure it would in some part help her resist the curses at school. But your thoughts also consider how you could use it to resist the same effects. Certainly it would help diminish the impact of the school on you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 “Hey Em,” you say to your sister. “I’ve got something for you.”

 

 You hold out your hand, revealing the ring in your palm. She looks at it curiously. 

 

 “Is it… magic?” she asks you.

 

 You nod. “A gift. It should help you study at school. Allow you to concentrate.”

 

 She eyes it for a moment, unsure. “Are there any side effects?”

 

 “Not that I know of,” you say, shaking your head. “Just protection. Against the effects of the school.”

 

 “Where did you get it?” she asks you.

 

 “A friend,” you reply, avoiding revealing too much about what you discussed with Jennifer. “Don’t worry. I trust them.”

 

 She nods and takes the ring from your palm, sliding it on. When she’s assured that nothing unexpected has occurred, she smiles politely at you. “Thank you.” 

 

 “No problem,” you say. She begins fiddling with the ring. You decide to let her be.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You slip the ring on to your own finger. Through means of magic or pure coincidence, it perfectly fits you.

 

 The magic emanates from the ring out across your body, warming your skin. The sensation subsides quickly, leaving only a lingering shiver as the ring seems to pulsate energy out of its metal.

 

 You feel a slight surge of confidence rush through you. As if there's something protecting you. It takes a few moments to become accustomed to it, before it fades into the background of your body’s regular functions and feelings.

 

 Emily continues with what she was doing beforehand, oblivious. And still protected from the curses at Charlton school.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: YourHomePENote
text:
Seeing you settle down to do something, Emily shrugs and stands. "I guess I'm going to school today."

 

 Without another word, she walks out the door.

 

 Remembering what you witnessed in PE, you sit down at the kitchen table and draft a note that you hope will exclude Emily from gym lessons.

 

 To whom it may concern,

 

 Unfortunately my sister, Emily, has been diagnosed with severe cramps. Our Doctor has advised her to avoid any physical activity for the foreseeable future. This includes gym exercises and any strenuous workouts. As her legal guardian in absence of our parents, I’d like to request that Emily sit out any activities within her PE lessons.

 

 Kind regards.

 

 

 

 You sign the note and review it. It’s not foolproof, but you are confident that the school and Coach Beach won’t have the time or inclination to question it. This is Charlton, though. Who knows if patient-doctor confidentiality is even considered here.

 

 You push the thought from your mind. At least this gives you the option to try, if you really want to skip PE lessons.

 

 Want Emily to skip PE lessons, don’t you mean? 

 

 You gulp and bury the ramifications of your mental slip deep down in your mind.

 “You wouldn’t have to,” you reply. “I’m going to.”

title: YourHomeTerrenceTutor
text:
You dial the number Terrence gave you. After a couple of rings, a warm female voice answers. 

 

 “Hi,” you say. “Is Terrence there?”

 

 There is a slight pause in the reply. “Uh, yes. Can I ask who’s calling?”

 

 “Emily,” you reply. “From school.”

 

 “Oh, Emily!” she exclaims, tone proud. “Terrence has been talking about you nonstop. I can't wait to have you round for dinner. One second.”

 

 After a moment, Terrence’s voice slides onto the line. “Emily, hey! Thanks for calling. I’ve been looking forward to this.”

 

 You give him your address, and he chuckles low. “Got it. I’ll be there in ten,” he says, voice warm. “See you soon.”

 You call the number that Terrence gave you. After a number of rings, a female voice answers.

 

 “Hi,” you say. “Is Terrence there?”

 

 There is a slight pause in the reply. “Uh, yes. Can I ask who’s calling?”

 

 “Emily,” you reply. “From school.”

 

 Another pause. “Oh. One second.”

 

 Terrence’s voice quickly comes on the line. “Oh. Hello,” he says, his usual nervousness creeping in.

 

 You tell him to come over and give him your address. He says he’ll be right over.

title: YourHomeElizabethMagic0
text:
“I spoke to Liz,” you tell Emily.

She looks up from the TV, her attention squarely on you. “What did she say?”

“Lots of things. She told me about where to find the junk shop she got the amulet from, and that she’s done a lot of research in the town library. Have you been there?” Emily shakes her head. 

“She also said that she could teach me some magic,” you continue. “She wants to come over to do it here.”

Emily gives you a look. 

“What?” you ask. 

She sighs and shrugs. “Just listen to us. My friend is going to come over and teach my magic. Where have we moved to?”

You can’t help but smile. “I know. This might help us, though. I think we should give it a try.”

She nods. You walk over to the phone mounted next to the kitchen cabinets, only realising that the excuse your phone company gave about Charlton having mobile coverage feels too much of a coincidence, given everything else happening in the town. 

You dial Liz’s phone number and are momentarily confused when a man answers. “Can I speak to Liz?” you ask. 

After a few moments, Liz’s familiar enthusiastic voice comes down the phone line. “I was wondering if you wanted to come over,” you tell her.

“Of course!” she beams. “I’ll be right there!”

You give her the address and wait for her to arrive, sitting with Emily and paying only a little attention to the TV as your mind wanders.

 You both look at Emily, still sitting on the sofa. Her expression is unreadable, but you can hear a slight tremor in a voice. “Why did you do this to her?” she clarifies.

 

 Liz moves over to the sofa and sits down with Emily. “Listen Em, I had no idea. I was just trying to find something to help you. I didn’t even think it would work.”

 

 “But why her?” Emily says with tears in her eyes. “Why put her through this? Why not try it on me.”

 

 On this point, Liz looks over at you. “Because she can use it. And you can’t.”

 

 “I don’t know all of how this works,” Liz continues, turning back to Emily. “Or even a lot of it, for that matter. But one thing I read, and I now think it’s true, is that only certain people have magical affinity. I can sense it. You don’t, hun. I’m sorry.”

 

 Emily looks from her to you, then back again. “But she does?”

 
 
 Liz nods and glances at you once more. “I think magic is linked to souls. Like your sisters."
 
 

 You give her a look and again she shifts uneasily, returning back to focus on Emily. “I promise I’ll help her,” she says. “That’s why I’m here, after all.” 

 

 Liz looks back at you. “So, Em, do you still want to learn some magic?"

title: YourHomeElizabethWard
text:
About half-an-hour goes by before the doorbell rings. You let Liz in, who bounces in with enthusiasm. “Hey Em! Where’s your twin sister?”

 

 “She’s up in her room,” you reply, before realising that you’ve grown to accept Liz’s jibes. Do I really think of Emily as my twin now?

 

 “Probably for the best,” Liz says. “After all, we wouldn’t want a civilian getting hit by stray magic. Especially something as powerful as a curse.”

 

 The seriousness of what you’re practising is either lost on Liz or she is too blinded by enthusiasm to worry. Not for the first time, you question whether teaching her how to play with curses is really a good idea.

 

 “Alright. Let’s get comfortable,” you say, pulling back the coffee room table to give you room to meditate. 

 

 “It looks like you’re making space for a slumber party,” Liz remarks. “Just us girls though, right?”

 

 “Are you going to take this seriously?” you snap. 

 

 Liz forcefully wipes the smile from her face. Nods. You take a seat on the floor and she joins you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “We’ll start by breathing in and out,” you tell Liz. “Close your eyes, and focus on your breathing.”

 

 She looks like she’s about to make a comment, but thinks twice about it and instead follows your instructions. Minutes pass as you watch her drop into a meditative state. You begin to sense the innate magical powers building within her body.

 

 “Try to reach out,” you tell her. “That feeling inside you. Try to find it elsewhere.”

 

 Elizabeth nods, her typical crooked grin minimal. You can feel her mind’s eye turning out from her body, gazing across the room. With a tingle, it rests on you.

 

 “Found you,” she murmurs, smiling.

 

 You pause, thinking of the next step, realising you’ve forgotten the vital ingredient. Nothing in your living room is cursed. 

 

 As you consider what to do, the tingling sensation of Liz’s focus roves across your body. You suddenly shudder, as a jolt hits your chest. The amulet.

 

 “It’s so pretty,” Liz says. You gasp, feeling her affinity probing the object that hangs around your neck.

 

 “Don’t,” you tell her. But you already can feel her mind gently nudging the energies flowing within the amulet. 

 

 “Have you got a better option?” she asks, her crooked smile rising. “You did promise.”

 

 You sigh. “Just be careful, okay.”

 

 “Hey!” she retorts. “It’s me.”

 

 Liz’s mental probing continues to prod at the amulet. You look down to see the yellow embers of magic bubbling inside of its gem.

 

 “Okay,” you say, relenting. “Repeat after me. I cause this object with power beyond its power. Unseen and unheard, its effects will be felt by…” you consider the best phrasing. “All who wear it.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 

 Liz repeats the words you told her. It’s a trickle at first, but soon you can feel the energies of the amulet break apart, sizzling like meat grilling on the stove.

 

 “I think that’s enough,” you say. But Liz doesn’t respond.

 

 You look down, seeing the yellow strands of magic circling around the gem in the amulet. A few stray beads drift off into the air, disappearing from your enhanced sight. 

 

 “Liz!” you say, loudly. 

 

 “Don’t distract me,” she snaps back at you.

 

 Thankfully, although slowly, the embers begin to reform into a shape, enclosed inside the gem. You feel the chaos of the raw magic fade, contained once more.

 

 Liz opens her eyes, blinking as she adjusts back to reality. “That was epic,” she murmurs.

 

 You look down at the amulet hanging around your chest and pull it out for closer inspection. Nothing seems different. Yet. You can sense a subtle shift in its power. More potent. Has Liz messing around with it made it stronger?

 

 “That was reckless,” you spit, turning your attention back to Liz. “What would I have done if you broke it?”

 

 Liz shrugs her shoulders. “Well I guess all those jokes about you being Emily’s twin sister wouldn’t be very funny anymore,” she tries.

 

 You throw her a look. “I think you should leave,” you tell her.

 

 “Come on, !” she says, making a point of using your name. “No harm, no foul. And I’ll make sure I put on a show for Prichard when you need me.”

 

 “You better,” you tell her darkly.

 

 “I will,” she says, grinning. “Now, I’ve got some experimenting to do. See ya’ at school!”

 

 Liz leaps to her feet. Within a moment, she’s out the door. 

 

 You turn your attention briefly to the amulet again. It definitely feels more powerful.

 

 **Actions**

text:
Deciding it’s time to decide what to do about Christina’s final test, you give Liz a call. The phone is promptly picked up and you hear Liz’s voice. “Hello?”
 

 
 
 
 “Hey Liz” you say. “It’s .”

 

 “Oh. Hey ,” she replies, surprised. “What’s up?”

 
 ”Hey Liz,” you say. “It’s .”

 

 “Don’t you mean Emily?” she replies, a hint of playfulness in her tone. “Is getting really hard to tell you two apart these days. You’re not making fun of me, are you Em?”

 

 You feel yourself clench your teeth. From through the phone, Liz laughs. “What’s up?”

 
 “Hey Liz,” you say. “It’s .”

 

 There is a marked pause before Liz replies. “You don’t sound like .”

 

 “I’m trying a new look,” you tell her.

 

 “Oh. Experimenting some more, are we ?” A small playful laugh comes down the line. “Colour me intrigued. What’s up?”

 
 

 “I was wondering if you’d like to come over?” you tell her. “I’ve been doing some investigating. I think I’ve found something that we should talk about.”

 

 “Oh really!” you hear Liz say. “Sounds delicious. I’m just having dinner with my parents, but I’ll be right over after that. Okay?”

 

 “Sure. I’ll see you soon.”

 

 You say goodbye and hang up. From the sofa, your sister shoots you a look. “What’s that about?” she asks.

 

 Looking over at your sister, you ponder how much to tell her. In spite of Emily's recent changes, you are confident she wouldn’t approve at all of messing with Liz’s memories. Not to mention, you’d have to confess some of the things you’ve been doing as Emily.

 
 
 

 “Hey Liz” you say. “It’s .”

 “Sure. I’ll see you soon.”

 

 You say goodbye and hang up. From the sofa, your sister shoots you a look. “What’s that about?” she asks.

title: YourHomeElizabethCheerleaders
text:
“I’ve got some things to discuss with Liz,” you say. “Some personal things.”

 

 Emily looks at you, darkly. "This is magical stuff again, isn't it?”

 

 You nod. Emily grinds her teeth. "I hate all this stuff," she mutters. "It's so unfair."

 

 “If it makes you feel any better, I wish I'd never heard of any of it," you try.

 

 Emily glares at you, in spite of herself. "It doesn't. It just makes me wish I could use it instead of you."

 

 Tension hangs in the air. She stands up from the sofa and walks up the stairs. “Enjoy,” she says sarcastically.

 

 You hear Emily’s door shut, harder than usual.
 
 
 “I’ve got some things to discuss with Liz,” you say. “Some personal things.”

 

 Emily frowns, looking confused. Then the smallest hint of a smile appears on her face. “You want me to leave you two alone?”

 

 “It’s nothing like that,” you correct her. But she gives you a sceptical look.

 

 “I’m sure your girlfriend would see it exactly like that,” Emily replies. “Don’t do anything stupid. I really like Jennifer.”

 

 “It’s not like that, Em,” you try. “I just have some things to talk through with her.”

 

 Emily raises an eyebrow, but relents. She stands up from the sofa and walks up the stairs. “Whatever you say. Have a good night.”

 

 You hear Emily’s door shut, harder than usual.

 
 

 Actions

 <>

 "I need to talk to her," you begin. “About the cheerleaders.”

 

 Emily looks at you, curious. “What about them?”

 

 You brace yourself. “They’re behind the curses at the school. Christina tried to recruit me – well, you – into their coven.”

 

 Your sister stares back at you, visibly trying to come to terms with what you’re saying. “What have you been doing at school when you pretend to be me, ?”

 

 “I’m close, Em,” you deflect, not wanting to get into everything you’ve done at Charlton School as her. “Real close. If I can get in with them, I can figure out what they are doing. I can stop them.”

 

 Emily mulls this over for a few moments. “And what’s Liz got to do with this?” 

 

 “As a final test, Christina asked me to wipe Liz’s knowledge of magic.”

 

 This grabs Emily’s attention. “You’re not going to do that, are you?”

 

 “Of course not,” you tell her. “But we need to think of a plan so Christina believes I’ve done it.”

 

 Emily considers this, gazing off to the side as she becomes lost in thought. Finally, she stands. “I don’t like this, . I don’t like it one bit. I need some time to think.”

 

 She walks towards the stairs, heading to her room. Halfway up, she turns back to you. “Try to remember that when you’re at school, you’re me. Whatever you’re doing, you're playing with my life. My reputation.”

 

 A moment later, you hear Emily slam her door.

 

 Actions

 <>

 
 
 Not long after, the doorbell rings. You open the front door to see Liz standing on the porch, a crooked smile on her face as she sees you.

 

 
 ”Oh hey ,” she says. “I didn’t recognise you for a second. Done something with your hair?”

 
 ”Hey ‘Em’. Don’t you look nice today. Like a whole new you.”

 
 “Hello,” Liz says, looking you up and down. “You’re really pushing the boundaries, aren’t you ? This is… amazing.”

 
 

 You gesture Liz inside. She bounds in, her ankle boots clicking on the floor. 

 

 Throwing herself down onto the sofa, she looks back at you. “So. What’s new?”

 

 Standing nearby, you look at Liz. There’s no audience here. No one to see what you’re doing. It’s now time to decide what to do.

 
 Not long after, the doorbell rings. You open the front door to see Liz standing on the porch, glaring at you.

 

 
 ”,” she says, curtly. 

 
 “, I presume?” Liz says, looking you up and down.

 
 

 You gesture Liz inside. She cautiously walks in, her ankle boots clicking on the floor. 

 

 You close the door and turn back to the living room. Liz walks over to the sofa and sits down, looking at you with burning hostility. 

 

 “So,” she says. “Talk.”

 

 You look at Liz. There’s no audience here. No one to see what you’re doing. It’s now time to decide what to do.

 
 

 **Actions**

 
 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 <>
 
 
 
 

 You reach deep down inside you for your reserves of magical energy. “Fall asleep,” you say, “and let your memories drift as you slumber.”

 

 “No!” Liz mutters as you utter the words. It’s too late. You watch as she slumps over on the sofa, out cold.

 

 Silence fills the air. You move over quietly to the sofa, checking her pulse. As expected, she is just in a deep-sleep.

 

 Confidence you got the spell right, you shake her to bring her around. Her eyes flicker after some gentle nudges. 

 

 
 ”Emily?” Liz sleepily says. You smile reassuringly and nod. She looks around. “Where am I?”

 

 “You’re at my house,” you tell her. “You came over to study, but it looks like you overdid it. I just came back from the toilet to find you passed out.”

 

 You help Liz to sit upright, as her eyes scan the living room. “I don’t remember,” she mutters. “What were we studying?”

 

 “Maths,” you tell her. “I thought I could help, as you keep zoning out in maths. You don’t know why that is, do you?”

 

 Liz looks at you, still half-dazed. She shakes her head. 

 

 You smile. “I think you should go home,” you say. “Might want to call it tonight.”

 

 She nods, getting to her feet. “Yeah. That sounds good,” she mutters. “Goodnight Em.”

 

 You watch as Liz walks over and leaves through the front door. Mission complete.

 
 ”?” Liz sleepily says. You smile reassuringly and nod. She looks around. “Where am I?”

 

 “You’re at my house,” you tell her. “You came over to study with Emily, but it looks like you overdid it. She said you were studying and you just passed out.”

 

 You help Liz to sit upright, as her eyes scan the living room. “I don’t remember,” she mutters. “Where is she?”

 

 "She even rushed out," you tell her. "To see if any of our neighbours have smelling salts. Doesn't look like we need them after all, thankfully."

 

 Liz looks at you, still half-dazed. She shakes her head. 

 

 You smile. “I think you should go home,” you say. “Might want to call it tonight.”

 

 She nods, getting to her feet. “Yeah. That sounds good,” she mutters. “Goodnight .”

 

 You watch as Liz walks over and leaves through the front door. Mission complete.

 
 She eyes you carefully as she comes back around, a look of utter confusion spread across her face.

 

 “It’s alright,” you tell her. “You’re safe. You’re at the Phillips’ house. Emily phoned me in a panic. She said you were studying and you just passed out.”

 

 Liz gives you a baffled look, then scans the living room. “The Phillips’ house?” she repeats, her words sounding like she’s still in a dream.

 

 You nod. “Emily was in a real state. She even rushed out to see if any of her neighbours had smelling salts. Doesn’t look like we need them after all, thankfully.”

 

 You help Liz to sit upright. “I don’t remember,” she mutters. “I don’t remember anything.”

 

 “Emily mentioned you’ve been zoning out in Maths too. You don’t know why that is, do you?”

 

 Liz looks at you, still half-dazed. She shakes her head. 

 

 You smile. “I think you should go home,” you say. “Might want to call it tonight.”

 

 She nods, getting to her feet. “Yeah. That sounds good,” she mutters. “You’ll tell Emily I’m okay?”

 

 You nod. Liz walks over and leaves through the front door. Mission complete.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 
 “I’ve found out some things,” you begin. “It’s the cheerleaders, Liz. They are the ones causing the trouble at Charlton school.”

 

 Liz shoots you a sceptical look. “You’re telling me the likes of Britney Hudson are capable of casting magic? Come on.”

 

 “There’s a coven,” you explain. “Britney, Stacey, Reagan, Christina. And, if we can keep up the charade, now Emily.”

 

 “You’ve joined their coven?” Liz asks, bristling.

 

 You shake your head. “No. But I am pretending to. I’m close, Liz. Close to finding out exactly what they are doing. I think I can stop them.”

 

 “Do you even know what a coven is?” Liz asks, with a twinge of venom. “You come together. As one. If you don’t join in, it’s obvious.”

 

 “I can handle it,” you tell her. “But I’m going to need your help.”

 

 Liz looks at you, eyes burrowed. “How?”

 

 “Christina set me one final test. She wanted me to cast a spell on you to make you forget everything you knew about magic. Even that it existed.”

 

 The words make Liz flinch in her seat. “She knows?”

 

 You nod. “I’m not going to do it, obviously. But she has to think that I’ve done it. So I can get closer to them.”

 

 Liz looks to the floor, thinking. After a moment, she looks up at you, all traces of her usual enthusiasm gone. “So you’re asking me to stop looking into magic?”

 

 Smiling sadly, you nod. “For the time being. At least until we stop them.”

 

 Liz scuffs one of her boots with the other, mulling over your request. “Okay,” she mutters. “I’ll pretend I’ve forgotten. Everything.”

 

 After a moment of silence, Liz stands to her feet. Wordlessly, she walks towards the front door. 

 

 She looks back at you as she opens it, thinking. “One thing. Did you ever consider, even for a moment, actually making me forget?”

 

 You shake your head. She nods, smiling appreciatively back at you. “Thank you.”

 

 With that, Liz walks out and shuts the door. Mission accomplished. Of sorts.

 
 “First of all, I wanted to apologise,” you tell Liz. “I didn’t want to upset you. I just had to.”

 

 Liz snarls her nose up, clenching her jaw. “You had to?” 

 

 “I’ve found out some things,” you say. “I had to get close to the cheerleaders, Liz. It’s them. They’re the ones behind all of it.”

 

 Liz shoots you a sceptical look. “You’re telling me the likes of Britney Hudson are capable of casting magic? Come on.”

 

 “There’s a coven,” you explain. “Britney, Stacey, Reagan, Christina. And, if we can keep up the charade, now Emily.”

 

 “You’ve joined their coven?” Liz asks, bristling.

 

 You shake your head. “No. But I am pretending to. I’m close, Liz. Close to finding out exactly what they are doing. I think I can stop them.”

 

 “Do you even know what a coven is?” Liz asks, with a twinge of venom. “You come together. As one. If you don’t join in, it’s obvious.”

 

 “I can handle it,” you tell her. “But I’m going to need your help.”

 

 Liz can’t help but laugh. “You want my help? This… you’re a real piece of work.”

 

 “I understand how you must feel,” you say, pleadingly. “But Christina set me one final test. She wants me to cast a spell to make you forget everything you knew about magic.”

 

 The words cause Liz’s eyes to glance at the door. She shifts in her seat, like she’s readying for a confrontation. 

 

 “I’m not going to do it, obviously,” you blurt out. “But she has to think that I’ve done it.”

 

 Liz looks at you, her eyes burning with anger. “Are you seriously going to ask me to pretend I don’t know magic?”

 

 “Come on, Liz,” you beg. “Just stop practising for a while. Until I can stop Christina.”

 

 Liz rolls her nose, burying her top teeth down into her bottom lip. Her pale face is red with anger. 

 

 “Fuck,” she barks. “This is bullshit.”

 

 After a moment of silence, you break the tension. “So you’ll do it?”

 

 Liz stares back at you, but nods. You take a sigh of relief.

 

 She stands to her feet and walks towards the door. She looks back at you for a moment as she holds the handle. “Why didn’t you just cast the spell on me?”

 

 “I didn’t want to,” you reply. 

 

 She gives you a look, then nods. Her anger dissipates just a little. “Thank you.”

 

 With that, Liz walks out and shuts the door. Mission accomplished. Of sorts.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: YourHomeMakeup
text:
You approach Emily, not sure exactly how to begin.

 

 "Hey, Em, can I ask a favor?"

 

 She barely glances up from her phone, flicking her nails against the screen. "Sure. What’s up?"

 

 "I was wondering… you seem to get a better reaction when you’re wearing makeup. Have you found that?"

 

 She lets out a dry laugh, finally looking at you. "You do live here, right? Of course I get a better reaction. This is Charlton."

 

 "Right. Makes sense." You hesitate for a second, then go for it. "So, uh… do you think I could use your vanity table? Just for touch-ups, I mean. And only when I'm you."

 

 That gets her attention. Her gaze sharpens, her phone lowering slightly. "You need my makeup?"

 

 You nod.

 

 She exhales, shaking her head. "I know you own your own makeup. You’re telling me that’s not good enough now?"

 

 "That’s not what I -"

 

 She clicks her tongue, already sighing. "No, whatever, it’s fine. Just don’t make a habit of it. And don’t you dare ruin my brushes."

 

 You smile politely and turn away from your sister. At least you have permission to use her stuff when you're in your form. Her words about you having your own make-up dwell within your mind. She's not wrong. But...

 

 Since when did you start owning any make-up?

 

 You approach Emily, not sure exactly how to begin.

 

 "Hey, Em, can I ask a favor?"

 

 She looks up, brows raising slightly. "Sure. What’s up?"

 

 You shift your weight, suddenly aware of how awkward this is going to sound. "I was wondering... you seem to get a better reaction when you’re wearing makeup. Have you found that?"

 

 Emily snorts, rolling her eyes. "Well, obviously. This is Charlton."

 

 You nod, half-expecting that response. "Right. That’s what I figured." You hesitate, then push forward. "So, uh… do you think I could use your vanity table? For when I’m you, I mean."

 

 Her eyes look back at yours for a moment as if she’s waiting for the punchline.

 

 When you don't deliver it, her faces melts. "Oh my god." She slaps a hand over her face, groaning. "Why do you keep making this worse?"

 

 "It’s not -"

 

 "It is!" she cuts in, waving a hand in your general direction. "First, you take my body, now you want to mess with my face? Do you even know what you’re doing? Makeup isn’t just stuff you slap on! It’s curated! It’s precision! There’s an art to it!"

 

 You open your mouth, but she’s already on a roll.

 

 "Do you even know what foundation shade I use? What brushes go with what? What brands are safe? No, you don’t! And I refuse to let you walk out of this house looking like some tragic, over-contoured clown just because you..."

 

 She stops mid-rant, exhaling sharply. She takes in your expression. Realises this isn't something you're comfortable with too.

 

 Then, after a moment, she shakes her head. "You know what? Fine. Fine. Just - don’t break anything, don’t touch my best stuff unless it’s a literal emergency, and if you use up my mascara, I will end you."

 

 You smile politely and turn away from your sister, feeling the unease about using her makeup only increasing now it's only a step from reality.

**Actions**

<>

title: YourHomeDateOutcome
text:
You shrug. “It was… fine. Well. Not really.”

 

 Emily frowns, setting her book aside. “Not really?”

 

 You exhale, rubbing the back of your neck. “Let’s just say Dennis figured out pretty fast that I wasn’t actually into it. It got awkward. And then worse.”

 

 Emily winces. “Oof. Poor guy.”

 

 You nod. “Yeah, it wasn’t great. He shut down completely, and when we left, he basically bolted. No key.”

 

 Emily sighs, rubbing her temples. “So much for that plan.” She looks at you carefully, her lips pressing together in thought.

 

 “Well,” she says after a beat, “at least you tried. And at least you didn’t lead him on.”

 

 She shifts slightly, her eyes flicking toward you, hesitant. “Did… you feel weird about any of it?”

 

 You pause, considering. “Not in the way you’re thinking.”

 

 Emily doesn’t push further, but her expression stays conflicted. She looks like she's deciding whether to say something.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You exhale, dropping onto the couch across from Emily. “It actually wasn’t terrible.”

 

 Emily raises an eyebrow. “Really?”

 

 You nod. “I mean, yeah, it was weird at first. He was nervous. I was nervous. But once we started talking, it… I don’t know. It felt normal.”

 

 Emily leans forward slightly, eyes narrowing in curiosity. “Normal?”

 

 You hesitate, then shrug. “He was just… nice. He talked about stuff he liked. I talked about stuff I liked. I think he was happy.”

 

 Emily watches you, her gaze searching, like she’s waiting for you to add something.

 

 “And?” she prompts.

 

 “And that’s it,” you say, voice firm. “I made him feel like it was real enough that he gave me the key. That’s what we needed, right?”

 

 Emily nods slowly, but there’s a thoughtful look in her eyes, one she doesn’t fully voice. She looks like she's deciding whether to say something.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You hesitate, suddenly feeling aware of every small detail - the way your lips still tingle, the way Dennis’ eyes lingered on you, the way you didn’t pull away.

 

 Emily notices immediately. She narrows her eyes. “Okay, now I need details.”

 

 You sit down carefully, choosing your words. “It went… really well.”

 

 Emily’s frown deepens. “You mean, like… normal well? Or Charlton well?”

 

 You rub your temples. “We talked, we ate, he gave me the key.”

 

 Emily tilts her head. “And?”

 

 
 
 You clear your throat. “And… he might have kissed me.”

 

 Silence.

 

 Absolute silence.

 

 Emily stares at you, her face frozen, mouth slightly open, like she can’t process what she just heard. “Wait.” She holds up a hand, eyes wide with horror. “He kissed you?” She physically recoils, shaking her head like she’s trying to erase the thought from existence.

 

 “You mean - he kissed *me*. But it was you...” She makes a strangled noise. “Oh my God.”

 

 You hold up your hands. “It wasn’t. Look, I just, he leaned in, and I -”

 

 “Did you kiss him back?!” she practically shrieks.

 

 You look away.

 

 Emily groans loudly, throwing herself backward onto the couch. “This is the worst thing that’s ever happened to me.”

 

 You roll your eyes, but your stomach twists at the memory. “Emily, it got us the key.”

 

 She groans louder, covering her face. “Yeah, but at what cost?!”

 

 She shakes her head, clearly distressed, then peeks at you through her fingers.

 

 “Did you like it?” she asks, like she can’t believe she’s even saying the words.

 

 You open your mouth. Close it. You say nothing.

 

 Emily lets out a soft gasp. “You did.”

 

 “I -”

 

 “You liked it.”

 

 “Emily, can we focus?”

 

 Emily groans again, sitting up and rubbing her temples. “No. We are never speaking of this again.”

 

 You are happy with that, at least. But Emily stares back at you. As if she wants to say something more.

 
 You clear your throat. “And… he tried to kiss me.”

 

 Silence.

 

 Absolute silence.

 

 Emily stares at you, her face frozen, mouth slightly open. “He tried to kiss you?” She shakes her head like she’s trying to erase the thought from existence.

 

 “You mean - he tried to kiss *me*. But it was you...” She makes a strangled noise. “Oh my God.”

 

 You hold up your hands. “It wasn’t. Look, I just, he leaned in, and I -”

 

 “Did you kiss him back?!” she practically shrieks.

 

 "No!" you exclaim.
 

 Emily grimaces, letting out a loud exhale. "Still."

 

 You roll your eyes, but your stomach twists at the memory. “Emily, it got us the key.”

 

 She groans louder, covering her face. “Yeah, but at what cost?!”

 

 She shakes her head, clearly distressed, then peeks at you through her fingers.

 

 "Even to end up with him thinking he should kiss you," she continues. "He must have thought. Well, you wanted him do."

 

 You open your mouth. Close it. Then mutter. “Emily, can we focus?”

 

 Emily groans again, sitting up and rubbing her temples. “We are never speaking of this again.”

 

 You are happy with that, at least. But Emily stares back at you. As if she wants to say something more.
 
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 Emily exhales sharply, shaking her head. “This is too much,” she mutters. “I can’t stop picturing it.”

 

 “I didn’t say it would easy,” you reply. “There are things I’m going to have to do that seem abnormal. Because this whole thing is abnormal, Emily.”

 

 She looks at you, considering her response. “You mean… you might have to do that again?”

 

 You shrug. “If it helps.”

 

 “I don’t want to know,” she says, shaking her head. "If you're going to keep on doing this, just keep me out of it. There’s a dozen things already that I wish I didn’t have memories of. Just… help yourself”

 

 You frown. “What are you saying?”

 

 Emily rolls her eyes, gesturing vaguely toward her room.

 

 “I’m saying, if you ever need clothes. You can use my wardrobe.”

 

 You stare at her. "Why would I want to do that?"

 

 She raises an eyebrow. "Why would you want to go on a date with a boy? You're doing a lot I didn't expect from you. It's just going to be easier for me if I don't know."

 

 She sighs, looking away like she’s already regretting it. “Everything will fit you, anyway.”

 

 You pause, absorbing her words. You don’t want to do this again. Do you?

 

 Emily sighs, returning to her book. Leaving you to digest her offer.

 

 Actions

 <>

title: YourHomeEmilyOnDate
text:
You sigh. "Do you need a hand?"

 

 Emily looks darkly at you, but nods. "Sure."

 
 You sigh softly, meeting Emily’s wary eyes. "I know he's a creep, Em. But it's just coffee or something quick. I promise, you won't be there long."

 

 Emily stares at you incredulously, eyes blazing. "Just coffee? Just a quick date? Do you even hear yourself? You're asking me to spend time alone with Dennis so you can get a key."

 
 
 You try to soften your tone, knowing how delicate this conversation is. "Look, I hate it as much as you do. But we need that key. It's the only way we'll stop what's happening."

 

 Emily crosses her arms tightly, shaking her head. "I can't believe you're seriously asking me to do this. After everything we've talked about, you're still willing to throw me at the wolves?"

 

 "I'm sorry," you say quietly, genuinely remorseful. "I wouldn’t ask if there was another way."

 

 Emily takes a deep, shuddering breath, eyes cold with disappointment. "Fine," she mutters. "I'll do your stupid date. But don't pretend you're doing this for me anymore. You’re using me."

 

 She walks past you without another word, leaving the tension thick in the air behind her. Minutes later, she returns. A fresh set of plain clothes on her. She looks ready to leave.

 
 You approach cautiously, giving Emily a reassuring look. "I know Dennis isn't great, but just think of it like playing a part. One quick date and we're closer to getting the answers we need."

 

 Emily scoffs openly, rolling her eyes. "Oh, wonderful. So now I'm supposed to play nice with Dennis just because you need information? This isn't exactly my idea of an ideal date."

 

 "It won't take long," you promise carefully. "And then you'll never have to deal with him again."

 

 Emily eyes you carefully, arms folded, voice dripping with irritation. "This is so beneath me, . Seriously. Dennis is repulsive."

 

 She sighs dramatically, shaking her head in frustration. "Fine, if it gets you your precious information, I'll do it. But if anyone from school sees us, you’re going to hear about it."

 

 You nod, acknowledging her irritation. "Thank you, Em. Really."

 

 She waves you off dismissively, her expression sour. "He better pay for me." 

 

 She walks past you without another word. Minutes later, she returns. A fresh set of plain clothes on her. She looks ready to leave.

 

 Emily looks at you, her patience visibly thin. "Anything else?"

title: YourRoomSleep
text:
As you decide to sleep, your mind keeps reminding you that you haven't heard the door open yet. You wonder what Emily must be doing to keep her working so late at the hotel. Burying thoughts before you spiral, you nevertheless feel a cold shiver spread across your skin.

 

 Feeling exhausted, you put the amulet down on your bedside table and take off your clothes. You pull back the covers and slip in. The bed is as comfortable and familiar as the body you are in. *Your body.* After all that’s happened, the comforting pull of sleep relaxes you. Soon you find yourself drifting to sleep.

 
 Tiredness threatens to overcome you. You put the amulet down on your bedside table and strip down. You feel especially awkward stripping down to boxers in this body, as if you are invading someone's privacy by the very act.

 

 Pulling back the covers, you lie down in your bed. This body feels foreign. Its proportions and parts are unfamiliar. You feel the appendage between your legs, alien and discomforting.

 

 Sleep doesn’t come quickly, and when it does, it’s broken, as you try in vain to adjust to relaxing in such a different state. It takes you hours to finally fall unconscious, as your active mind finally succumbs to the physical pressure of needing to rest.

title: YourRoomTransformBack
text:
You put on the amulet, feeling its warmth against your breasts. You pick up the photo and think about yourself in your mind. You concentrate and recite the words that by now you know off by heart.

 

 “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 The energy jolts out of the emerald and with it comes the painful sensation of magical crackling across your body. You focus inward, thinking about who you are. How you look. What you will become.

 

 You shriek as your body crunches and changes. You mentally grasp to retain consciousness. Then, with a howl that comes out of your mouth, the sensation passes.

 

 Taking a deep breath, you glance at yourself in the mirror. That looks like you. *Doesn’t it?*

 You put the necklace back on and pick up the photo of you and Jennifer. You feel the energy from the amulet, but it feels weak. 

 

 You visualise yourself in your mind and speak the words from the note. The emerald warms at the utterance of the words, but its magic fades quickly. 

 

 You sigh. It seems the amulet needs more time to recharge before it can be used again.

title: YourRoomReadingDeBussy
text:
You take out DeBussy’s notebook and stare at the frayed blank cover. Charlton is full of secrets and you know that this book contains a great many of them. Yet the thought of riffling through the private lives of Charlton students is questionable.
 
 

 And whilst you’re certain that hiding it in your room will keep it away from prying eyes, recent events have caused you to doubt how certain you are of anything, anymore.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 
 
 
 

 <>
 
 Taking out a set of matches from one of your drawers, you open up a window to let in a breeze flow into your room. Once a corner of the book begins to burn, you hold it out of your window as long as you can bear the heat, then shake it vigorously to put it out.

 

 Crumples of paper and ash float into the air. Large sections of the book fold and wilt from the flames. Soon enough, there is nothing but dark smoke plumes left of DeBussy’s handiwork.

 

 You shut your window once the burning smell has dissipated and smile, content that you may have just saved a student a day of embarrassment. Or worse. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You open the book and flick through the pages, scanning the neat hand-written notes penned on each page. 

 

 
 
 With increasing disappointment you turn each page to find nothing but idle gossip. A number of references to the school basement and Olaf are peppered throughout, which appear to have consumed DeBussy’s thoughts in the most recent entries. Unfortunately, there isn’t much that isn’t known to you.

 

 Until, that is, you get near the front of the book. The pages here are faded and worn. DeBussy must have had this book for years. Her writing style shows evolution, with her overt references to people replaced with more cautious initials. It’s enough to make it challenging to understand who these rumours pertain to. But one stands out.

 

 From JC - AC and PS have been seen in each other’s company. Possibly more than friends. Next step - alert headmaster.

 

 Two initials are familiar to you - Jennifer Chambers and Annie Clancy. The other, you can take a good guess at.

 

 Closing the book, you toss it aside. If there are more secrets to be found at Charlton, you’ll need to investigate elsewhere.

title: YourRoomReading
text:
You sit down on your bed and take out the book, reading its title once more. *Translations of the Sevrene Shards.* It looks old, but not ancient. The pages are printed cleanly, with sporadic illustrations in black ink. 

 

 The introduction gives context to the title. It’s a translation of the text from shards of tablets found in the moors near the village of Sevrene. They were uncovered by a bomb defusal team after the Second World War. Whilst academic scholars dismissed the scratches as random and decorative, the author of this book seems convinced they are the language of an unknown sect.

 

 Until recently, you would have scoffed at pseudoscience and fringe history. But given what you’ve gone through, you approach the book with an open mind.

 

 You spend some time reading through the various translations. It’s not an easy read. The prose is overly descriptive and poetic, with vague allegories hinting of mysticism and the occult. 

 

 Then, just as you are about to put it down for now, a paragraph leaps out at you as familiar. The prose hasn’t changed, but given your recent experience you understand the subtext. You are reading the instructions for casting a spell. 

 

 Scanning your eyes across them, you think it alludes to the manipulation of people’s perceptions of you. A charm spell, you think. The instructions are all there, but based on your experience with magic so far, you are sure it will take some time to master it.

 You sit down on your bed and again take out *The Translations of the Sevrene Shards.* After briefly looking through the chapters, your attention returns to the section that you know contains the instructions to a new spell.

The instructions are laid out for you, but you know it will take some time to master it.

title: YourRoomReading2
text:
You read the words over and over, hearing your internal monologue whispering them in your mind. Your body reacts. You feel the stirrings of magic inside your chest, tense and aching to relax.

 

 You begin to breathe deeply, focusing on the feeling inside your torso. Under your rib cage. Inside your lungs. You feel a yearning to breathe. Inhale. Exhale. Inhale again.

 

 And, with a sudden contraction of your abdomen, you breathe out, watching yellow energy seep out of your mouth.

 

 It hangs in the air like vapour, then slowly disperses. As you are practising alone it’s impossible to know for certain what effect that would have on anyone around you, but you feel the same rush of endorphins that occurs after a successful spell. 

 

 You find yourself grinning. You can sense the magic in your lungs. Waiting. Anticipating. You have not just learned a new spell. You have grown stronger.

 

 As you watch the vapor dissipate, you consider briefly how the spell works. Even when used with the best intentions, you're effectively messing with people's memories and emotions. If the situation was reversed and the spell was cast on you, how would you feel?

 

 A thought bubbles up in your mind. Do you really care about other people, though? You're looking at the long-term, after all?
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You read over the words again and again, even reading them out loud. Yet they have no effect on you. They seem hollow and empty, with no hint of power or meaning beyond cryptic inference.

 

 But you are certain these are instructions to cast a spell. It seems that what you’ve learned about magic is true. Only women can channel it. You sigh, accepting that in your current form learning a new spell will be impossible.

 

 **Actions**

title: YourRoomPotion
text:
You sit on the edge of your bed, the vial in your hand, the red liquid swirling as you roll it between your fingers. Gladys’ words echo in your head. Stacking magic upon magic can lead to unexpected effects.

But you have to know.

With a slow breath, you tip the vial back, the liquid cool and smooth as it slides down your throat.

The effect is immediate.

The room blurs, the edges of your vision softening, your limbs suddenly heavy.

You barely have time to set the vial on your nightstand before your head hits the pillow. And then...

You’re falling.

**Actions**

title: YourRoomLeaf
text:
Faced with no other choice, you take off your clothes, hang up the amulet on your bedside table and slip under the covers. The naked form of this body feels alien to you, pressing against your worn sheets.

 

 You slip the glowing leaf beneath your pillow, its faint warmth pressing against your temple. You settle your head onto the soft fabric, the hush of your room folding around you as your eyelids grow heavy. A gentle pull at the edges of consciousness drags you under, and sleep takes hold.

 Typically you wouldn’t risk transforming into someone else without using a forget spell. It would be too risky if they happened to walk into the same place as you. Looking around your room, though, you think you can risk it. Taking out Annie’s photo, you feel the amulet tingling.

 

 “From this item, I see you in your time of need,” you say. “Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 Energy blows out away from your body. You focus on the mental image of Annie. You feel your skin stretch and distort, your clothes pull tighter. Blonde locks fall across your eyes as you strain to keep your brain locked on the image of the receptionist who’s greeted you every day for months.

 

 And then, the pain of the transformation stops. You are Annie.

 

 Looking briefly at your reflection in your mirror, you step towards your bed and you take off your clothes. The cold sends shivers across this body. You hang up the amulet on your bedside table and slip under the covers. The naked form of this body feels alien to you, pressing against your worn sheets.

 

 You slip the glowing leaf beneath your pillow, its faint warmth pressing against your temple. You settle your head onto the soft fabric, the hush of your room folding around you as your eyelids grow heavy. A gentle pull at the edges of consciousness drags you under, and sleep takes hold.

 And... nothing. You grimace. You might have Annie's photo, but the amulet feels cold and heavy around your neck. As if it's not charged. You haven't given it enough time to re-charge.

title: YourRoomPostLeafAnnie
text:
**Your room**

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_7.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_6.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_5.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_4.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_3.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_2.png]

 
 [image: ./images/Your_Room_1.png]

 
 
<>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You bolt upright to a noise. A sharp, crashing thump. Your eyes snap open. Your throat is parched. Your heart is pounding. You feel displaced. And your eyes flick around the room to see what disturbed you.

 

 Across the room, frozen in the doorway, stands Emily. Hand still on the door knob, eyes wide, lips parted as if in mid-sentence. Then, at the foot of your bed, you notice a figure looming.

 

 The dazzling blue eyes of Annie Clancy look down at you, her mouth wide open.

 

 She stares down at you, speechless. Not at you. At themselves. Their own face beneath the sheet. Your face.

 

 You remember, too late, the rule. To walk another’s dream, you must become them. Now they stand before themselves in your bed. Your mind can’t comprehend what’s going through their mind.

 

 The silence stretches unbearably. Emily remains statue-still. Annie goes to take a step forward --

 

 You feel the heat rise in your chest. Your fingers twitch. You know one spell that might help.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Amber light flares in your palms, shimmering with power, and you fling it toward Annie. It strikes her chest…

 

 And fizzles.

 

 The magic crawls down their body like it’s been rerouted. Draining harmlessly into the floor. Protected. By instinct. Or enchantment. Or something older.

 

 Annie staggers back, eyes wide in alarm, hand clutching at her chest. “What… what was that?” she gasps.

 

 Her breathing quickens. “Magic?” she whispers, disbelief lacing her voice. “You did magic?”

 

 Another step back, panic blazing in her eyes as they flick to Emily, still frozen in the doorway. Then back to you. Tears glisten at the corners of her eyes. “What’s happening?”

 

 Actions

 <>

 You shoot up in bed, instinctively pulling the sheets up with you over your breasts. Annie’s breasts. Her breasts.

 

 She’s still staring at you, wide-eyed and trembling. Staring at your face. Her face. Her doppelganger. Almost a scene from a nightmare. She stumbles back, breath catching in her throat. “Who… who are you?”

 

 Your mouth opens, sound lodged somewhere behind your teeth. Finally you manage, in a voice that is unmistakably hers. “Annie, it’s me.”

 

 Annie’s brow furrows in confusion, voice shaking. “Me? What do you mean, me?”

 

 “It’s me,” you repeat. “.”

 

 “No,” she replies. “You’re not… you’re not…” 

 

 But she struggles to finish her sentence. As much as this is cracking her sanity, you can see in her eyes she doesn’t know what to say.

 

 “I’m ”, you repeat. “Only I look like you. Like you said. It’s magic.”

 

 Her eyes go wide, suspicion and dread rippling across her features. She looks down at her chest, then to the floor, seeing the residual embers of your spell flickering on the carpet. When she looks up, there’s something resembling Annie looking back at you. “Prove it.”

 

 You reach back into your memories of you and Annie. Right back to something no one else would know. “Remember when I first started at the repair shop,” you begin. “My first day. When I first walked in, with a coffee from Fresh Pot. I went to shake your hand, stumbled, and spilt coffee all over your white blouse.”

 

 You watch as her eyes widen. A memory that she still has bubbling up. “You could see that I wasn’t wearing a bra underneath,” she says quietly.

 

 “Did you ever tell anyone about that?” you ask. “And didn’t I promise you I would do the same.”

 

 Annie’s eyes drift to the floor, lost deep in thought. From the door, a quiet cough breaks the silence. You look up to see Emily standing there, awkwardly. 

 

 “It’s okay,” you tell her. “Can you give us a minute?” 

 

 She looks back to Annie, then to you. Nods. She slips away wordlessly, the door clicking shut behind her.

 

 Annie drops down with a gentle thud on the end of your bed, staring off without focus. Finally, she looks back at you. “? But how?”

 

 You offer her a sympathetic smile. “This is going to sound wild, Annie. But I’ve got some things to share with you. About magic.”

 

 She looks at you, her skepticism replaced with bafflement. Amongst the fear. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You take a deep breath, recalling how not-so-long-ago this was explained to you in a way that didn’t seem crazy. “So there’s a power. Hidden usually. It’s deeply entwined with all things. And certain people have some sort of affinity for using it.”

 

 “Like Harry Potter?” Annie asks.

 

 You give her a grin. “Not quite. But kind of. They can cast spells. Create charms. Change things using their powers. Honestly, I’m new to this. It’s usually reserved for women, but…” You reach over and pick up the amulet from your bedside table. “This is something I can use. To change. Pretend to be someone else.”

 

 Annie looks at the amulet in your hand for a moment, then her eyes flick back to you. “You’ve been pretending to be me?”

 

 You catch your breath as you're reminded once more of your current form. Of Annie. And now she’s staring right back at you.

 

 “I had a good reason,” you say flatly, Annie’s usual chirpy inflection missing from the voice that emerges from your mouth. “Something’s wrong at the school. Among other things, I think something bad is going to happen to one of the students.” You take a deep breath. “Something that I think happened to you.”

 

 She looks at you, her eyes appraising your face and the outline of the body underneath the covers. “You’ve been pretending to be me,” she states again. “Why?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Something happened to you at school,” you begin. “Something between you and the cheerleaders. Something to do with Penny. And Jennifer. I used a spell to find out what that was.”

 

 She stares back, an incredulous look on her face. She’s lost for words.

 

 You press on. “You reclaimed some memory this morning. What did you see?”

 

 
 Annie’s stomach clenches; she presses a trembling hand to her temple. “I… flashes,” she murmurs. “A dream that felt more real than life. Almost memories from another person.” She glances up at you. “But also. They were real. It all happened.”

 

 She shakes her head, as if trying to understand. Her green eyes fill with fear. “Why would you do this?”

 

 You reach for her hand. “There’s something planned for a boy at school. Terrence. I had to see what they intended for him, to stop it. I think it’s what happened to you.”

 

 Annie’s breath hitches. “No,” she whispers. She pauses, looking away. “I…” 

 

 After a long pause she turns back to face you, face almost calm. “Ask me what you need to know.”

 
 Annie shakes her head. “Nothing. Nothing worth talking about. I don’t want to reopen old wounds. Please. Can’t we just leave it be?” 

 

 “It’s important, Annie,” you reply. “Trust me, I wouldn’t have done this if it wasn’t.”

 

 She once again looks you up and down. Again shaking her head. “This feels like a dream.”

 

 “I know it’s a lot,” you say. “But you might know something that could help someone. Isn’t that enough?”

 

 Her shoulders slump. “Ask me what you need to know,” she murmurs.

 
 

 Actions

 <>
 
 Annie sits at the end of your bed, looking to you almost vacant. Her legs are curled around on the edge of the bed, facing away from you.

 

 **Actions**

<>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You bolt upright to a noise. A sharp, crashing thump. Your eyes snap open. Your throat is parched. Your heart is pounding. You feel displaced. And your eyes flick around the room to see what disturbed you.

 

 Across the room, frozen in the doorway, stands Emily. Hand still on the door knob, eyes wide, lips parted as if in mid-sentence. Then, at the foot of your bed, you notice a figure looming.

 

 The shimmering green eyes of Jennifer Chambers look down at you, her mouth dropped.

 

 She stares down at you, speechless. Not at you. At themselves. Their own face beneath the sheet. Your face.

 

 You remember, too late, the rule. To walk another’s dream, you must become them. Now they stand before themselves in your bed. Your mind can’t comprehend what’s going through their mind.

 

 The silence stretches unbearably. Emily remains statue-still. Jennifer goes to take a step forward --

 

 You feel the heat rise in your chest. Your fingers twitch. You know one spell that might help.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Amber light flares in your palms, shimmering with power, and you fling it toward Jennifer. It strikes her chest...

 

 And fizzles.

 

 The energy rolls off her like rain on glass. She doesn’t flinch. She doesn’t step back. Instead, looks at you with burning anger. You think you can sense power flickering around her fingers before it subsides.

 

 “Emily,” she says quietly. “Could you leave us alone for a moment?” Then looking directly back at you. “I think we better talk.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 When Emily’s eyes drift towards you for direction, Jennifer’s voice snaps. “Out,” she barks, her voice carrying the weight of steel.

 

 Without a sound, Emily backs out. The door clicks shut behind her. Silence spreads through the room like it was a living thing.

 

 Jennifer exhales, the sound sharp and controlled. She turns away, then pivots, letting her eyes roam over you as if cataloguing every detail of your appearance. How you lie, where your breath catches, how your fingers grip the sheet. She raises a single brow. “How long has this been going on?”

 

 You hope to heaven that the ground swallows you up. The question hangs in the air like a challenge.

 

 “What have you been doing as me?”

 

 She begins to pace, her footsteps soft on your bedroom floor. “Did you go to work as me? Walk the streets where I live? Speak to people I know?” She stops and looks at you, her green eyes hardened. “Did you… like it?”
 
 
 
You hold the sheets up, paralysed with the fear of Jennifer asking you to stand. You are conscious that beneath the sheets, you are naked. But she continues to pace, only occasionally throwing glances at you.

 

 "It makes so much sense now," she continues. Gordon saying I was flirting with him? Being drunk in McTafeys? Helping Maisie’s Aunt. My mysterious facial treatment. Christina’s tale to her dad. Terry Evans dinner invite. Kissing Martin! Even that stuff about Martin and his van! She looks back at you, realisation spread visibly across her face. "That was you."
 
 
 

 You look up from over the covers of your bed, feeling the naked skin of your body touching the fabric. Struggling yourself to comprehend the stark reality of looking up at your , but just seeing a reflection of you.

 

 “Jennifer, I --” you begin, but stop as soon as you hear yourself. She freezes, eyes widening at the sound of your voice. Her voice, don’t you mean?

 

 Silence festers, as Jen stares down at the bed, her face looking like it’s about to crack.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Silence hangs in the air. Jennifer remains fixated on you. Her shimmering green eyes meeting your own perfectly identical pair.

 

 <= 4>>
 
 Eventually her look drifts from you, wandering down towards the floor without focus. You see her mouth flinch, her eyes flicker. Her brain is racing. Like wave upon wave of realisation is striking her each second.

 

 “You liked it… didn’t you?” she whispers, finally returning to lock looks with you. “You like being me.”

 

 “Jennifer,” you say quietly, still conscious of the sounds of your words. “Please.”

 

 But she’s not listening. She slowly walks towards the mirror hanging on the wall. Stares at her own reflection. Then her eyes flicker to you in the mirror. Herself. Lying in your bed.

 

 “Maybe you should just be me,” she whispers, still looking at you through the reflection. “Go to the Department Store everyday. Smile politely. Keep your head down. Cook when you get home.”
 
 
 “I can’t believe you would do this,” she whispers slowly. “After everything. I’d never thought I’d feel so lost again. Especially not because of you.”

 

 “Jennifer,” you say quietly, still conscious of the sounds of your words. “Please.”

 

 But she’s not listening. She slowly walks towards the mirror hanging on the wall. Stares at her own reflection. Then her eyes flicker to you in the mirror. Herself. Lying in your bed.

 
 

 Finally, Jennifer turns. Relative to the situation, she manages to resemble being composed. 

 

 “The obvious question is why, of course,” she says flatly. “What possible reason you had for doing something…” her eyes flicker up and down your form underneath the sheets. “Like this.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 “I needed to know what happened,” you say, still wincing at the sound of Jennifer's voice coming from you. “Between you and Annie. Back at school. Neither of you would speak about it!”

 

 
 Realisation again flashes across Jennifer’s face. “This morning,” she murmurs. “When I woke up. My mind was full of memories.” She looks back at you, her expression hardening. “Things I fought so hard to bury. They all came bubbling up. You did that, didn’t you?”
 
 
 “And did you find what you were looking for?” she asks.

 

 “Some of it,” you say with a little hesitancy. “But not everything.”

 

 At that, Jennifer actually sighs. She closes her eyes for a moment, taking a deep breath. When they open she seems calmer. At least a little.

 

 “It was a painful time for me, ,” she tells you. “Why won’t you just leave it alone? Is it really worth going through this?”

 

 Again, her eyes seem to gesture to your body. You flinch, feeling even more self-conscious.
 
 

 “I had to,” you say, feeling frustration in your own voice. “You know something’s happening to Terrence. That it’s just like what happened before.”

 

 Your volume raises as it becomes harder. “I tried, Jen! Really I did. But you wouldn't say! So I used magic to try and get to the truth myself! Christ, do you hear how insane this all sounds. How crazy it is!”

 

 Silence returns. But for once, Jennifer’s rage appears to fizzle. Her eyes still rest darkly on you, but there’s a measured sense of control behind them now.

 

 “Ask your questions, then” she tells you. “And then we’ll figure out what to do.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You shift in the bed. She still stands, slightly awkwardly in the centre of your room. Staring right back at you. Waiting.

title: YourStreetSiobhanDialogue0
text:
You step closer as the girl’s silhouette resolves in the shallow glow of the streetlamp. Her voice drifts like velvet. “Siobhan,” she murmurs. Her eyes stare back at you. Too bright and too clear, as if they see straight through you. “You’re lookin’ for summat. Strugglin’ to get the truth out of them, are ya? You’d pay a good amount of coin for the truth, I bet.”

 

 You clear your throat. “Excuse me?”

 

 She tilts her head, letting the silence stretch thin. Finally, she answers. “Those girls at school. They got up to summat, didn't they? And that poor boy Terrence… he’s got something comin’ to him if nobody finds out what went down back then.”

 

 Your pulse hammers. “How do you know about Terrence?”

 

 She brushes a stray lock of hair aside. “Names matter less than what they hide.” Her gaze flicks away for a heartbeat, then back. "Old sins circle back, you’ll see."

 

 The girl looks back at you, eyes sparkling. "Too cryptic for you? Or do you like your riddles served blunt?”

 
 You step forward as Siobhan’s coy smile fades into that familiar, knowing expression.

 

 
 “Talked to both of ’em, have ya? Neither gave you what you came for. Ye want to know what happened? Understand Jennifer? Or help Annie remember? Annie can’t recall, and Jennifer won’t confess. But ye needn’t beg ’em. Ye can see it yerself… and set their memories free. Choose: the careful one or the broken one.”

 

 With a graceful flick, she produces a small tin from her clothes and snaps it open. Inside, two delicate leaf cuttings pulse with a faint, otherworldly light. One is brittle and splintered, its edges jagged as though fractured; the other a perfect maple leaf, its veins glowing like living runes.

 

 “Only one,” she whispers, voice soft as moth wings. “Ye have to decide.”

 
 “Talked to the blonde one, have ya? Ye want to know what happened? Help Annie remember? Ye needn’t beg her. Ye can see it yerself… and set her memories free.”

 

 She flicks her wrist, and the tin appears in her palm. With a careful snap, it opens to reveal a single leaf cutting, its brittle, jagged form pulsing with faint, otherworldly light.

 

 “Or,” she adds, voice soft but insistent, “you can try talking to the brunette - Jennifer. See if she’ll shed any light herself. And if she won’t… I can help you there too. But you’ll have to choose: the broken one or the careful one. Only one. Ye have to decide.”

 
 “Talked to the brunette, have ya? Ye want to know what happened? Help Jennifer confess? Ye needn’t beg her. Ye can see it yerself… and set her memories free.”

 

 With a practiced gesture, she reveals the tin and snaps it open. Inside lies a single, perfect maple leaf cutting, its veins glowing like living runes against the night.

 

 “Or,” she murmurs, “you can seek out the blonde - Annie. See if her memories might surface. And if she stays silent… I can help you there too. But you’ll have to choose: the careful one or the broken one. And only one. Ye have to decide.”
 
 
 

 You meet her gaze, heart still thudding, as Siobhan inclines her head and stays silent. Her bright eyes gleam in the streetlamp’s glow, patient and expectant, waiting for your next question.

title: YourStreetSiobhanBell
text:
Burying the sense of embarrassment, you take out the miniature bell and ring it once, as per Siobhan's instructions. The high-pitched sound bounces off the suburban houses, ringing out in the quiet night.

Nothing. Only the sounds of pigeons cooing and the background breeze fills the air.

You look around for signs of life, but you see nothing. Suburbia remains as it was. Peaceful, static, still.

You jump as you hear a giggle behind you. Spinning around, Siobhan stands again in the shallow glow of a streetlamp. She smiles coyly. "Sorry. Couldn't resist making ye wait."
