 <> 

 “Like I said, I think it just needs some time to recharge. When the emerald is glowing again, just picture the ideal version of yourself. You should become you again.”

 

 “What about the times of trouble stuff?” you ask. “And that line on the note about only helping those who need aid. How does that work?”

 

 “It looks like you definitely need aid, so I think we’re fine on that.” Liz quips. “Plus, and this is the real interesting part, I think you could help to bend that clause just a bit, if you take the long view.”

 

 
 
 “You looked at the clock in that test, didn’t you?” she whispers. “I saw you. Time just disappeared, didn’t it? And those questions felt harder every time you did, even for a maths brain like you. That wasn’t you being sluggish. There’s something going on at this school.”

 
 “I saw you glance at the clock, right?” she whispers. “Good job you didn’t look again, because it does some funky stuff. Time disappears, and you find yourself, well, your brain seems slower. That’s not a reflection on the people here. They are doing something to manipulate us.”

 
 
 
 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 "What's wrong with this school?" you ask, narrowing your eyes.

 

 “Look around,” Liz says, glancing around the emptying corridor. “This place is out of the last century. They have blackboards. Old desks. And don’t get me started on the mandated uniform. This is like some sick version of an old man’s fantasy of a boarding school.”

 

 “I don’t think this is natural,” she continues. “That clock is just one of the weird things going on here. So - and this is where you can come in - I think you can help get to the bottom of what’s happening. Definitely fulfils the times of trouble and those who need aid, don’t you think?”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You look around and grimace. "Yeah," you admit. "But what can I do about it?"

 

 “Use your brain,” Liz chides. “You’re an adult. We're at school. You can do some investigating in the daytime. See what else is happening in Charlton. I’m sure you can get far, especially now with that amulet. It's like you sort of have some kind of superpowers.” She smiles, in spite of herself, and takes her glasses off to wipe the lenses.

 

 “One thing though. Be careful how you use it. Just as we’re bending the rules of it only working for those in need, that line about shaping the person within worries me. This place does things to your mind. Slide too far and you –”

 

 “Why are you hanging about in the corridor?” you hear a voice bark from back at the entrance to the classroom. 

 

 You turn to see Mr. Rogers standing in the doorway, looking at you both with a scowl.

 

 “Just changing our lockers, sir,” Liz replies, before leaning into you. “I’ll speak to you later.” She slinks off, and seeing the look from Mr. Rogers still watching you, you glance at your schedule. Lunchtime.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Tell her it's not too bad
Threaten her and demand to know how she did this
Ask her how to reverse it
Ask her how to reverse it
Ask her how to reverse it
Ask what's wrong with the school

title: PrologueSchoolGates
text:
**Charlton School - Gates**

 [image: ./images/School_Gates.png]

 

 Charlton Upper School looks like it was built in Victorian Times and hasn’t been updated since. The imposing brick school rests back from the road and is surrounded by iron rails. Inside, students stand talking in groups of girls and boys.

 

 You approach from the opposite side of the street, take a deep breath and cross the road to stand out the front of the school.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You stand by the entrance, conscious of your new form. Thankfully no one pays that much attention, aside from the occasional grin from some boys. You avoid their eyes as they walk past, knowing what goes through the minds of teenage guys all too well.

 

 “Hey nerd!” you hear a voice say. 

 

 Instinctively you look up and see a muscular teenager in a quarterback jacket approaching you. 

 

 You begin to clam up, but the jock walks straight past you and gets right up in the face of a small boy with glasses nearby. You can’t be certain, but you have the feeling that he was standing there staring at you.

 

 “Hey nerd, I’m talking to you,” the jock says, shoving the other boy against the railings.

 

 “It’s Dennis,” the boy mutters. “My name’s Dennis.”

 

 “No, it’s not,” the jock says. “It’s nerd. N-E-R-D. Nerd. And nerds shouldn’t be eying up girls outside school.”

 

 Dennis glances over at you then turns back to the jock. "I wasn't looking at her, I swear!"

 

 Jake grabs Dennis' by the ear and twists it. He cries out in pain. "Yes you were, nerd. Yes you were. You perving on her, like you always do."

 

 He looks over to you, still clutching Dennis' ear. "What do you say? Do you want to hear an apology from him?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “Leave him alone,” you say, hearing the timidness in your voice.

 

 Jake raises and eyebrow and releases Dennis, who drops clutching his ear. “Oh,” he says as he walks over to you. “I didn’t realise you were so in love.”

 

 He steps closer, absolutely standing in your own personal space. He grins at you. “I’ve seen you around, but we’ve never met before. I’m Jake. How about I show you what a real man looks like?”

 

 “He’s a real man,” you mutter, aware of how tall and overbearing Jake is compared to your new body.

 

 “Is that right?” I didn’t know girls went for guys with small dicks. Unless you’re the domineering type.” He glances you up and down again. "Somehow I don’t think that’s you.”

 

 He leans in and you can smell his cheap deodorant and the musk of his jacket. You stand still, looking up at him as defiantly as you can. 

 

 “Yeah, I bet you’re the other type,” he murmurs. “You might be all for feminism and books and nerds, but deep down I bet you just want a man to tell you what to do.”

 

 Before you can reply, you hear an authoritarian voice from behind you. “That’s enough, Duncan!”

 

 You glance over Jake’s shoulder and see a stocky middle-aged man in short shorts and a tracksuit jacket looking over at you both. “You can flirt on your own time. Inside.”

 

 “Sorry Coach,” Jake says as he withdraws. He flashes you a smile and then walks through the school gates. The man in shorts looks at you for a moment, then follows him inside.

 

 Feeling your pulse slow, you look around to see all the other students staring at you. You meet Dennis’ eyes for a moment, before he looks away and hurries inside too.

 

 The first bell hasn't even rung and you're either being hit on or intimidated by every boy you see.

 

 “Oh my god, Emily!” A voice brings you out of your thoughts and to look around to see a young woman approaching. You recognise her from a few nights she’s come over for dinner. This is Emily’s friend, Michelle.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Terrified, you don’t say a word. The jock takes this as a sign to continue and turns back to Dennis, shoving him hard against the rails, still holding on to one ear.

 

 “Please Jake, don’t hurt me!” Dennis cries, on the verge of tears.

 

 “It’s not nice to leer at girls,” Jake snarls. “Especially those that are way out of your league. I bet you were going to follow her to the stairwell, weren't you? Take some upskirt photos of her as she went up the stairs, like you did to my girlfriend.”

 

 “I wasn't!” Dennis cries, visibly shaking. You notice there’s a group of pupils now stood around, watching the situation unfold.

 

 “Don't lie! It's what you do to all the new girls!” Jake says. “She's been here for months, I'm surprised you haven't started selling some pervy pictures of her already."

 

 Dennis is crying now, as Jake continues to twist his ear. “Please! Let me go!”

 

 “Oh I'll let you go. But first, a warning to stop your little upskirt perving, and a little payback for doing it to Chrissie!"

 

 You watch as Jake pulls back his fist. Dennis quivers, accepting his fate.

 

 "That’s enough, Duncan.” you hear an authoritarian voice bark. 

 

 You glance over and see a stocky middle-aged man in short shorts and a tracksuit jacket looking over at Jake and Dennis. “You can fight on your own time. Inside.”

 

 “Sorry, Coach,” Jake says as he withdraws. He flashes a menacing smile at Dennis and then walks through the school gates. The man in shorts looks at Dennis with derision for a moment, then follows after Jake. 

 

 You look around, watching the other students disperse. You meet Dennis’ eyes for a moment, before he looks away and hurries into the school too.

 

 You are soon left alone with your thoughts. Day one and some guy is already trying to take creepy photos of me, you think despairingly. And Jake was going to beat him up for it too.

 

 Day one?

 

 “Oh my god, Emily!” you hear, bringing you out of your thoughts. You spin to see a young woman approaching. You recognise her from a few nights she’s come over for dinner. This is Emily’s friend, Michelle.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You smile as Michelle approaches. Her strawberry blonde hair flows around her face in curls. She’s slightly shorter than you, but she's definitely grown in other areas. You feel your cheeks redden as you realise you’ve been checking her out.

 

 “What drama for before school!” she says, slyly. “I must admit, I wouldn’t have minded seeing Jake pummel Dennis, even though he is a brute. Dennis is such a sleaze.”

 

 You nod, trying to stay as noncommittal to any conversation as you can. Thankfully, Michelle likes to talk.

 

 “So, did you do last minute cramming for the Maths test today? Hopefully your brother gave you some last minute pointers. I bet he's nice, like that. But don’t fret, it’s an easy one, okay?”

 

 You nod. Somehow, passing a Maths test this morning is the least of your problems.

 

 The bell rings and Michelle grabs your hand. “Come on! Let’s get to class.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: PrologueSchoolGym
text:
**Charlton School - Gymnasium**

 [image: ./images/School_Gym.png]

 

 
 Walking slowly, you enter the gym and notice the girls are sitting on one side of the gym, and the boys on the other.

 

 Mr. Beach looks at you appraisingly as you walk in. He's not the only one. Everyone is staring at you.

 

 “Nice of you to join us, Phillips,” he says. “I’m sure the boys appreciate it."

 

 There’s a few wolf whistles and cheers as you sit down with the girls, who mostly roll their eyes and whisper. You clamp your legs tight together, aware the boys are looking over and trying to see up skirts.

 
 You enter the gym with the other girls to see the boys entering too, sitting on the opposite side. You walk with the other girls and sit opposite, careful to keep your legs together to prevent the boys from looking up your skirt.

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Alright kids,” he begins. “Wet weather activities. Today you’ll be doing obstacle challenges. Five minutes on each one, split into groups of five. Girls stay with girls, boys stay with boys. Try to complete each one. Those who don’t will be cleaning up the gym after the lesson.”

 

 There’s a murmuring as the students begin to break into groups. Thankfully Emily is not a social pariah, so a group of girls welcome you into their group.

 

 You look around the gym at the obstacles. Ropes, a climbing wall and some yoga balls. You let out a small sigh of relief. It’s been a while, you think, but these seem achievable to you. 

 

 "Come on kiddies," you hear Beach bellow. "Get on with it!"

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You look around the gym at the activities. Other students are racing to claim what they deem the best activities to begin with.

 

 “Where should we start?” one of the girls in your group asks you.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <> 
 
 Taking a deep breath, you look around at the gym to the activities you've still got to attempt.

 

 You notice that your group is looking to you now for direction. "What next?" one of the girls asks.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 <> 

 With all three challenges attempted, you regain control of your breath and sit down with the rest of the girls, waiting for everyone to finish.

 

 Once everyone is seated, Mr. Beach looks at his noteboard. “Alright kids, the results are in. As always, some good successes, some not so good attempts. Whilst there are many winners today, there can only be one loser. And today, that is…”

 

 < 1>>
 “Heather Oats!”

 

 You look over, following the other girls stares. A waifish girl gasps. Mr. Beach smiles at her. 

 

 “That’s right, Oats, you’re on cleaning duty. The rest of you, head to the locker rooms.”

 

 You join the other girls, leaving Heather sitting on the bench on her own.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Emily Phillips!”

 

 The other girls turn to look at you, all smiling darkly. Mr. Beach steps up and offers a similar smile. 

 

 “That’s right, Phillips. You’re on cleaning duty. The rest of you, head to the locker rooms.”

 

 You watch as the other students walk out, soon leaving you alone in the gym. After a couple of minutes, Mr. Beach returns with a bucket of warm water and a towel. He tosses it down in front of you.

 

 “Alright Phillips, as forfeit your going to clean the gym for thirty minutes. You can clean what you like, but one thing I do want to see is this floor spick and span. So get to it.”

 

 He sets his stopwatch and waits for you to start cleaning.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 Feeling ashamed, you get down on your hands and knees to begin cleaning. The smell of stale sweat is everywhere. You can almost taste it. The warm water Mr. Beach has given you does nothing to hide it too. Soon you feel as though you're bathing in it.

 

 Instead of being repulsed by it, though, in time you find yourself adjusting to it. As you clean the gym floorboards, you begin to think about the people who must have used this gym over the years. The dozens, if not hundreds, of boys who sweated over these floors.

 

 And the smell might be the sweat of boys barely used to using deodorant, but you begin to think about those boys and their physical education. Their muscular bodies playing basketball. Sweat dripping down their toned abs. A lot of testosterone is baked into these boards.

 

 You idly look up from the floor, seeing Mr. Beach watching you perched on a vaulting box. You look up at him as you clean on all fours. 

 

 You notice that in spite of his age, he too has kept up his physique. He is toned, fit and has a pair of manly thighs on display below his short shorts.

 

 “Keep it up, Phillips,” he says to you. “We might have found something you’re good at.”

 

 Absent-mindedly you feel yourself moving to clean right in front of the box he perches on. Leaning over to get your elbow working on a particularly grimy sweat stain, you feel your polo shirt hanging down, giving him a good look down your top at your breasts.

 

 “Like this sir?” you find yourself purring.

 

 He smirks. “Oh yes, Phillips. Careful though, we wouldn’t want you to rub your shirt on the floor. It would get all dirty, and then what would we do?”

 

 “I don’t know sir,” you say, wringing out the towel when his watch goes off and savouring in the smell of the dirty water. You stare back up at him. “Will that be all, sir?”

 

 He grins. “Yes Phillips. For now. Go along to the changing rooms. I’ll see you again, I’m sure.”

 

 You smile coyly at him and then walk out of the gym. Something didn't feel right about that entire experience, but for the life of you, you can't put your finger on it.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Go back into the changing room
Go back into the changing room

title: PrologueSchoolGymEntrance
text:
**Charlton School - Gym Entrance**

 [image: ./images/School_Gym_Entrance.png]

 

 You walk through the Charlton corridors, following the signs that point to the gymnasium and to your final lesson of the day. Hopefully, with any luck, the final lesson you'll ever have to face as a girl.

 

 Eventually, you spot a group of students lining up outside the changing rooms. One line for boys and one for girls. Reluctantly, you join the girls.

 

 At the front of each line stands Mr. Beach, the stocky man who broke up Jake and Dennis when you first arrived this morning. Still wearing short shorts and a tracksuit jacket, he now carries a clipboard and in one hand and a stopwatch in the other.

 

 "Alright!", he bellows, silencing the corridor. 

 

 "Alas, rain has stopped play outside today, so this afternoon we'll be staying inside. So change into your gym clothes and I expect to see you all in there within minutes!"

 

 The line surges forward as people rush into the changing rooms.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: PrologueSchoolMathsRoom
text:
**Charlton School - Maths Room**

 [image: ./images/School_Maths_Room.png]

 

 Michelle leads you into a classroom a minute before the lesson starts. She takes a seat at one of the desks near the front and you sit down at the one next to her. She leans over and looks at you.

 

 “Did you go without make-up today, Em?” she asks you conspiratorially. “You look like you’ve been up all night. What will the boys say?” She winks at you. 

 

 The conversation is interrupted by the entrance of an aging man dressed in a suit and tie. As soon as he steps in the idle chatter from the other students simmers down. 

 

 “Alright, alright, close those mouths,” he says, shutting the door behind him and drawing all conversations to silence.

 

 You look up at him, very aware that your desk at the front of the classroom does nothing to hide your legs. You push them together, trying to retain some level of modesty. You think how Emily would be mortified if you flashed her teacher whilst pretending to be her.

 

 “Good morning class,” the man says, almost in a singsong.

 

 “Good morning Mr. Rogers,” the class parrots back.

 

 “Today is the day you’ve all been waiting for,” Mr. Rogers says, as he takes a seat behind his wooden desk. “This term’s Maths exam. I hope you’ve been studying.”

 

 The door that Mr. Rogers closed suddenly bursts open and a girl almost falls in through the entrance. She's dressed generally like another student, but her uniform is pushing the boundaries of what is acceptable and her make-up is definitely on the darker side of what's permitted.

 

 “Take a seat, Miss Pleasant,” Mr. Rogers says. “I’m sure you are as excited to take this test as I am to mark it."

 

 You watch the girl walk through the classroom. She smiles as she takes a seat a row back from you. This has to be Elizabeth.

 

 “Now,” Mr. Rogers continues. “If there are no further interruptions, we may begin. You will find your exam in your desk drawer. You have fifty minutes. No calculators. No phones. And above all, no talking. Your time starts now.”

 

 There is a mad rush as each student takes out their exam papers from their drawer and begins scribbling down their names at the top.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You open the desk drawer and take out the maths exam. You glance over the questions and your heart skips. Despite everything that has happened today, at least this is what you expected.

 

 You glance up at the ticking clock above the blackboard. You won’t need fifty minutes. You can do this in fifteen. Although weirdly enough, you seem to have daydreamed for five already. The clock now shows there is only forty five minutes until the end of the lesson.

 

 Shrugging, you take out your pencil and are set to answer the first question when a crumpled roll of paper lands on your desk. 

 

 You glance back in the direction of where it came and see Elizabeth looking at you. She looks over the rim of her dainty glasses, puts a finger to her lips, motioning for you to be silent, and then puts her head down to work.

 

 Your eyes drift to the ball of paper now resting on your desk.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 You glance up at Mr. Rogers, who seems absorbed in a book. Cautiously, you reach over and open it up to reveal some scribbly writing in black pen.

 

 Did it work? Are you really ? Let’s meet after class. And whatever you do, don’t look at the clock above the blackboard.

 

 You look back at Liz, but she’s now concentrating on the exam. You crumple the paper back up, put it in your bag, and return to the test.

 

 Heeding the words on the note, you set down to business, but not once do you look up at the clock. 

 

 The questions would be challenging for the average eighteen year old, but as you thought they would be, they are easy. Not wanting to draw attention to yourself, you try to take your time answering them, but you can’t help but finish quickly.

 

 You look up after completing the last question and see that Mr. Rogers is staring at you over the rim of his glasses with interest. “Something wrong, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 You shake your head. He holds his stare for a moment longer, then returns to his book.

 

 Soon the bell rings and Mr. Rogers barks for everyone to put their pens down. “That bell is a signal for me, not you. Now leave the exam on your desk and you may go to your next lesson.”

 

 Students begin filtering out of the room. As you're packing up your things, Michelle leans over to whisper to you. 

 

 “How did you find it? I think I got at least ten right, but they were really hard. Hopefully Mr. Rogers goes easy on me. See you in the cafeteria in a bit!”

 

 Michelle bounds out the door. You begin to follow, but hear Mr. Rogers voice again. 

 

 “Finished so quickly, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 You glance back at him, still sitting behind his desk. “I hope for your sake that you studied hard. I will find your exam paper most intriguing.”

 

 Without saying a word, you walk out. As you notice the time, you briefly wonder about your job. Your real job. You're certain that your boss will have noticed your absence. He'll take note when you're away from the office. You might have aced Emily's exam, but you don't look forward to having to make it up to Thompson tomorrow.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You ignore the note and get to work on the exam questions, trying to keep your mind free from distractions. You answer the first questions with ease, glancing up to see how quickly you are breezing through the exam.

 

 Discouragingly, you see that another five minutes has passed without you realising. You wince, not understanding where time has gone. 

 

 You turn over the next question and read it a few times. It’s a simple algebra question, but it takes a bit for your brain to get to the answer. It has been a while since you’ve done theory. Still, you find the next question a little odd to understand too.

 

 You look back up the clock and feel your mouth dropping open. You are only a third of the way through the exam, but over half the lesson has gone. 

 

 The exam isn’t getting easier, either. You spend a long time just reading the next five questions, eventually comprehending what they are asking for. You also make a few basic mistakes that would cause so many bugs if you let them slip through in your day job.

 

 Come on , you think. Focus. You only have…

 

 And you glance up at the clock to see you only have five minutes left. 

 

 You begin to hurry, trying to get through as many questions as you can. Rushing leads to a number of mistakes and there’s even a few questions that you just can’t get your head around.

 

 The bell goes just as you move on to the final question, which you scrawl a guess at. “Pens down!” Mr. Rogers orders. He steps up next to your desk and slaps a ruler against your desk. “That includes you, Miss. Phillips. I will be penalising you for not listening to the bell.”

 

 Mr. Rogers turns to the whole class. “Alright, now leave the exam on your desk and you may go to your next lesson. You are all dismissed.”

 

 Students begin filtering out of the room. As you pack up your things, Michelle leans over to whisper to you. 

 

 “How did you find it? I think I got at least ten right, but they were really hard. Hopefully Mr. Rogers goes easy on me. See you in the cafeteria in a bit!”

 

 Michelle bounds out the door. You begin to follow, but hear Mr. Rogers voice again. 

 

 “Struggled a little there, Miss. Phillips?”

 

 You glance back at him, still sitting behind his desk. You feel his eyes drifting over your body. “I will find your exam paper most intriguing. I suspect in the future I’ll find you back in my class after school.”

 

 Without saying a word, you walk out. As you notice the time, you briefly wonder about your job. Your real job. You're certain that your boss will have noticed your absence. He'll take note when you're away from the office. And you didn't even manage to ace Emily's exam. You don't look forward to having to make it up to Thompson tomorrow.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: PrologueThompsonsOffice
text:
**Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Office**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Office.png]

 

 You walk into the small room full of desks and ancient computers that you somehow have to make do as a contemporary office.

 

 Sitting down at your desk, you check emails before looking at the bug that forced you to give up your Sunday. Apparently there was a glitch on Friday evening and Gordon was booked for two jobs at once.

 

 You grimace, bracing for another lecture from the owner, Mr. Thompson.

 

 “Hey Phillips,” you hear a voice say from behind you.

 

 You turn and see your co-worker Dan entering, dressed in a cheap suit and smelling like old cologne. He looks back through the door as it closes, waving out to Annie in reception. “I’ll see you later, Annie!”

 

 He chuckles, taking a seat at the desk opposite and opening a rolodex, as he eyes you with a smirk. "Didn't expect to see you pulling overtime. Me? I'm already hitting targets. Don't need to work weekends. But I heard Annie was working and thought I could keep her company. Man, that's a piece of arse if ever I saw one,” he says. “Get a few drinks in that one and I bet she’ll be up for it, am I right?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “She’s got a lovely figure,” you reply, trying to match his lecherous tone. He takes that as encouragement and grins.

 

 “I bet she wouldn’t be picky, too,” he continues. “I reckon you are in with a shot there, mate. Maybe I could take her out for drinks, have some fun in the bathroom, and then I’ll text you to let you know she’s ready for you to pick up sloppy seconds."

 

 His laughter is interrupted by his ringing phone. “Good morning," he says as he picks it up. "Thompson Handyman Repairs. Daniel Mendel speaking. How can I help you?”

 

 You look back to your screen as Dan takes his call, his loud voice echoing throughout the room.
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I don’t think you should be talking like that at work,” you tell him.

 

 He frowns at you and waves his hand dismissively as he snorts. “It’s just banter, mate. No need to get your panties in a twist.”
 
 

 But thankfully a moment later his phone rings. He picks up the receiver, adopting a smooth salesman tone. “Good morning, Thompson Handyman repairs. Daniel Mendel speaking. How can I help you?”

 

 You look back at your screen, listening to Dan’s grating voice as he chats to a customer.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 You open up the development window on your computer and try to find the bug that caused Gordon to be double-booked. Whoever worked here before you was an amateur. It’s held together by logic that you quickly see will break as people use it.

 

 After about an hour of searching in vain, you brace yourself as a door slams open nearby. “Phillips!” you hear someone bark. You look up to see your boss, Mr. Thompson, striding over to you.

 

 “I’ve just had Sean McTafey on the phone!” he shouts. “He needed Gordon to get over there on Friday to fix a leak in the basement. But thanks to you, Gordon was working over at Harold Sermon’s hotel on a routine check!”

 

 You look up at your boss and gauge how to respond. An overweight man by any definition, his white shirt is stained from years of profuse sweat. His face is puffy and red, his breathing rapid just from walking out of his office.

 

 "It was the old code -," you begin.

 

 “I don’t care why it happened,” he cuts you off. “If that keg cellar isn’t dry by this afternoon, a lot of thirsty people are going to be without a drink after a day out at the Country Club. Get it sorted.”

 

 Mr. Thompson storms back into his office and slams the door.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 Feeling blood rush to your face, you try to avoid Dan's stare and get your head down into the code. But you find it hard to focus as adrenaline from being shouted at rushes around your body.

 

 About an hour into the investigation, Annie walks into the office and makes a beeline for you, smiling sympathetically. 

 

 “Hey , just wondering if you wanted to get some lunch. Maybe some time away will help?”

 

 You gather from her expression that she’s well aware of the problem and Mr. Thompson’s outburst.

 

 “Not today, Annie”, you tell her. “I’ve got to get this done before the issue happens again.” 

 

 You don’t have to look around to sense Dan leaping on this opportunity. “I’m free for lunch,” he says to Annie. “Maybe we can grab a drink too. Make it an extended working lunch. I’ve just made a decent sale, Mr. Thompson will be more than happy if I treat his lovely secretary.”

 

 She looks between you two, then shrugs. “Sure”, she says. “I’ll get my coat.”

 

 She walks out and you see Dan watching as she leaves, grinning. He smiles at you and follows her, not once letting his cheesy grin fall from his face.

 

 After he leaves, you turn your attention back to the computer and focus on the problem. At least now Dan's piercing voice won't interrupt your concentration. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Two hours of hard work later and you find the bug, unsurprisingly from legacy code before you started working here.

 

 Some time later, Dan returns, smelling of alcohol. He falls into his chair and shoots you a look. “What a lunch,” he exclaims. “Annie sure is a hungry girl.”

 

 You don’t respond to him and continue to finish out your work day in silence.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 Sighing, you stand up and take a deep breath. You catch Dan looking up at you with a quizzical look. “Taking a break?” he asks with smugness in his voice.

 

 “I think I need it,” you reply, and walk out to the reception area to get some air.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 Unlike your job back in the city, you are least thankful that you now get to go home at 5:30pm on the dot. Even on a Sunday. You watch the clock tick over and say your goodbyes, leaving just as the sun is setting.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 

 **Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Office**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Office.png]

 

 You and Annie walk back to work, trying not to announce your late lunch. Dan raises an eyebrow as you sit down, but says nothing.

 

 With a fresh mind, you quickly find the bug that caused the issue. Unsurprisingly it's from legacy code written before you started working here. You send an email to Mr. Thompson explaining the issue and how you resolved it and receive a quick ‘Thanks’ as a reply.

 

 For the rest of the day, you clean up some of the code and try to ensure that nothing can go wrong overnight with the rest of the incoming bookings.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

choices.label: Get back to work until you’ve fixed the issue

title: PrologueThompsonsReception
text:
**Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 You walk into the reception of Thompson’s Handyman Repairs. It’s no more than a room with a cheap desk and a couple of doors either side. One to the warehouse, where electricians and plumbers store supplies and their vehicles. The other to the office where you spend your days working to bring order to a software system built decades ago.

 

 “Morning ,” the receptionist says as you enter. Annie is in her early twenties, blonde and pretty. She's always dressed for a much more professional company than the one you work for.

 

 She is sitting behind the desk, staring up at you with a flirtatious smile that you have come to learn is just her natural demeanour. “How are you today?”

 

 “Good thanks Annie,” you reply. “Spending Sunday living the dream.” She grimaces at the mention of the day, but tries to smile politely.

 

 Just then, you feel your phone vibrate in your pocket. Reception is so terrible around Charlton that since moving here you’ve quickly gotten out of the habit of idly scrolling every second you have a spare moment.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You take out your phone and see you have a message from your girlfriend, Jennifer. It’s a picture of her dressed in a short skirt and crop top in front of a changing room mirror. You read the caption.

 

 **Jennifer:** Put these aside before my shift. Think I might wear it tonight. My place for dinner? Xxx
 

 You smile to yourself. There are certainly things you don’t like about Charlton, but Jennifer is not one of them.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 
 
 **Thompson Handyman Repairs - Reception**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Reception.png]

 

 Annie looks up at you as you enter the reception, smiling sympathetically. You deduce she heard Mr. Thompson’s tirade.

 

 “Hey , just wondering if you wanted to get some lunch,” she asks. “Maybe some time away will help?”

 

 You look at her, sitting behind her desk. She smiles warmly, waiting for your response.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <> 

 “A break would be good,” you say. Annie smiles and stands, revealing her long legs as she puts on her coat.

 

 “Do you want to go to the hotel restaurant?” she asks. “It’s got a lunchtime special today. Come on, my treat.”

 

 You open the door for Annie and she walks outside. Following her, you take note of the sun warming your body. It makes you feel better instantly. 

 

 Annie leads you across the road to the Charlton Hotel and you try to ignore Gordon’s van in the car park as she leads you inside.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You shake your head. “Not today, Annie”, you tell her. “I’ve got to get this done before the issue happens again.” 

 

 She nods and offers you a smile. “I’m sure you’ll fix it, . Mr. Thompson can just get in a mood sometimes.”

 

 She stands and puts on her coat. “We’ll do lunch another time,” she adds. “Good luck.”

 

 You watch her leave, noting her long legs previously hidden by the desk. She looks back and smiles at you, before leaving. You sigh.

 

 Returning to your desk, you sit down and get back to the task at hand. You try to ignore Dan looking up.

 

 “Did Annie just leave for lunch?” he asks. You don’t reply, but he stands up anyway. “I think I’m going to catch-up with her and see if she wants to join me. A nice long-lunch, if you get my drift.” He grins and dashes out the door.

 

 **Actions**
 
 <>

title: PrologueThompsonsShopFloor
text:
**Thompson's Handyman Repairs - Shop Floor**

 [image: ./images/Thompsons_Shop_Floor.png]

 

 If you were to believe the labourers and electricians, the shop floor is where the actual work for the company takes place. Which they remind you of every opportunity.

 

 This morning there’s a couple of branded vans parked near the shutters in different states of loading. The rest of the space is covered in plumbing parts and electrical wiring that Thompson’s Handyman Repairs use to charge large sums of money to Charlton residents with no other alternative.

 

 You notice two employees, Gordon and Clive, loading up their vans, ready for a day’s work.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You know Gordon and Clive primarily through work. Clive is a tall and lean man with an easy going nature that doesn’t fit the stereotype of an electrician. You remember him mentioning that he played touch rugby over the summer with your brother Brock, before he went to University. Lean and nimble, you reckon he'd be a great winger.

 

 Gordon, on the other hand, could be a bodybuilder. He barely says a word, except when talking about how much he’s benching or how unfit people are at the gym. His attitude makes you feel that people would not want to workout when he’s there, which unfortunately seems to be all the time.

 

 “What’s happening, Phillips?” Clive says as he sees you. “The boss pulled you in today, too? Mighty nice of you to come in and try to fix the reason we're working overtime.” The words sting a bit, even though his tone is playful and far from mean.

 

 "I don't know what's happening," you tell Clive. "It was working fine on Friday."

 

 Clive gives you a grin. "Always works until it doesn't. So you taking a break from working hard sitting down, or come to see how real men make their living?"

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “You wouldn’t have a living if I didn’t sort out the piece of junk that is your booking system,” you reply.

 

 Clive chuckles. “Pen and paper would suit me fine,” he says. “That’s how I learned at school. Sometimes the old ways are the best. Think that we're in today proves that right.”

 

 Gordon looks up from his packing, his face the picture of disinterest. He shakes his head as he sees you and returns to his work.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “I don’t think I’m built for doing manual labour,” you respond, playing to his bias. 

 

 He laughs as he looks you up and down. “Don’t worry about it, champ. Some men aren’t just built to do it,” he replies.

 

 Gordon looks up at you over a stack of boxes he’s carrying. “You should come by the gym," he says. “There’s plenty of people in worse shape than you. I’m sure that girl of yours would appreciate you adding some muscle to that body.”

 

 There’s no hint of joke from Gordon’s face. He returns to packing his van.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: PrologueTownCentre
text:
**Charlton Town Centre**

[image: ./images/Town_Centre.png]

The centre of Charlton is nothing more than a road of shops and offices, barely built up beyond second storeys. There are no skyscrapers, no bustling malls, no signs of the noise and bustle you used to call home in the city.

Damn, I could do with a coffee, you think.
 

**Actions**

 <>

 Enter the Fresh Pot Cafe - *You've already been here today.*

<>

title: PrologueYourHome
text:
**Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 Emily sits at the kitchen table, surrounded by school books and notepads. Eighteen and usually perky and positive, she is dressed casually in a T-shirt and jeans.

 

 “Morning ,” she says as you enter. “How did you sleep?”

 

 You mutter a neutral reply. You don't ask her the same question, as it's obvious she’s been up all night studying. You can tell the move has been hard for many reasons, but it most prominently shows in her studies. Back in the city she was a top-of-the-class student. Since the move though, she’s been struggling with maintaining an average grade.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You sit down with her and look at the textbook open on the kitchen table. Algebra. Even when you were at school, Maths came naturally for you. Now it feels like child's play.
 
 

 Emily smiles meekly as you help her. You spend thirty minutes walking her through how the Maths questions can be solved, but she grows more frustrated with each mistake she makes.

 

 “I don’t know what’s wrong with me,” she exclaims after missing a step you just talked through. “Even Michelle is doing okay with her grades. I'm way smarter than her!"

 

 You remember that despite struggling with school, Emily has at least met someone she can call a friend. "Maybe this particular type of Maths just suits her?" you offer, trying to be helpful.

 

 “It’s like I just can’t keep all of this in my head," Emily continues, ignoring your question. "Everything seems so hard and complicated right now. This all was so simple back… home.”

 

 The word hangs in the air between you. You look at each other and remember, not for the first time this week, that the move has been tough on the both of you.

 

 “You’ll get the hang of it,” you say reassuringly. “The test is tomorrow, right? Still another night of studying to get in before then.” 

 

 That causes her to smile at least. Just a little, but you’ll take the win. 

 

 “I’m going to see Jennifer this evening,” you add. “But we can get up early tomorrow and do some last minute cramming.” 

 

 She nods. You can tell she’s still despondent, but she is trying to cling on to the positivity that used to define her.

 

 “Have a good day,” you say as you get up. “I’ll see you after work.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 
 
 You enter your parents house to the familiar sight of Emily hunched over the kitchen table, surrounded by homework. She smiles politely as you walk in, but quickly puts her head back in a book.

 

 “How’s it going?" you ask.

 

 She looks up, tears in her eyes. “, I think I'm going to fail!" Then the tears begin to stream.

 

 You put your arm around her and hug her gently. “Look, you’ve still got another night,” you console her. “And plus, I’ll help you cram in the morning. I promise.”

 

 “I don’t think that’s going to help!” she stammers. “I just can’t get my head around this. I feel so stupid! This is so unlike me! Plus, Mr. Rogers said that if I failed this class, he’d have to keep me back for detention to make up for it!"

 

 "I'm not sure you can get detention for failing an exam," you reply.

 

 "You can! He apparently did the same to Michelle last term and she had to stay behind after school to do extra work!”

 

 You look down at your sister. You’ve never seen her like this. Not just her struggling with grades, but her being this emotional. You smile, unsure of what to say to her like this.

 

 “You can only try your best, Em,” you tell her. “There’s not much else you can ever do.”

 

 Emily looks up at you, her teary eyes causing her make-up to run a little. You are taken aback momentarily, not noticing before that she had started to wear such heavy make-up. But you don't have a chance to mention it before something else takes your attention. Emily reaches underneath her maths book and pushes something to the centre of the table. “Maybe there is,” she says.

 

 You look down at the object. It’s an amulet, old and faded, with a green emerald gem embedded in it.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You look down at the amulet. It’s made from a metal you can’t determine, but looks faded and worn. The green emerald, however, sparkles with none of its sheen lost. More noticeably, you feel a sense of warmth irradiating from it.

 

 “What is this?” you ask her, not taking your eyes off it.

 

 “A girl at school gave it to me,” Emily says. “When I told her that you were tutoring me, she said that if you would help me this could be the answer to my problems.” She takes out a faded piece of paper and hands it to you. “She also gave me this.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You look at the note. Like the amulet it’s old and faded. You notice some hand writing on one side that reads:

 

 **For times of trouble, use me well. Take a treasured possession from those who need aide, and see them for who they are in your world. Then say these words. ‘From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.’**

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Em, what do you think this is?” you say, trying not to laugh. “It sounds like a magic spell.”

 

 Emily looks up at you, pleadingly. “Maybe it is. Or maybe it’s just some positive affirmations stuff. Either way, it can’t hurt, right? I need all the help I can get.”

 

 You smile politely at your sister. “I think what would help would be more studying.” 

 

 You see her crestfallen face react to your dismissal and can’t help but want to appease her. You sigh. “If you think it would help," you say, "let’s talk about it tomorrow morning. For now continue studying.”

 

 Her eyes light up at your gesture. “Thanks ! You're the best!” She turns back to her books and you remember that even though she’s eighteen, she can be so naive sometimes.

 

 Just then, the landline rings. Even after a couple of months of having almost no phone reception, reverting to a landline seems like you’ve stepped back to another time.

 

 You pick up the receiver from the wall and answer. The warm voice of your girlfriend greets your ear. “Are you coming over?”

 

 “I’d love to, Jen,” you say. “I’ll be right over.”

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 You bid Jennifer farewell and go home, thinking about the day you’ve had.

 

 All the lights are off when you get in, but notice Emily has fallen asleep at the kitchen table in front of her books. Illuminating the room in a green light is the amulet, lying off to the side of the table where you left it. You don't understand how it does that.

 

 You wake up Emily and tell her to go to bed. Groggy and half-asleep, she nods. 

 

 You help her up the stairs, then go to your room and collapse in your bed for a restful night.

 

 Actions

 <> 
 
 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 Emily still sits at the kitchen table, now fidgeting in the stuffy uniform that you know she hates. Charlton Upper School mandates it though, as if you were living in the last century. You can’t tell if she's just come down or she snuck back down to study. Her eyes look more tired than you’ve seen before,

 

 “Morning,” she says sleepily. “How did you sleep?”

 

 "Okay," you reply. "Let's see how you are doing."

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You sit down again and look at the textbook in front of her. You begin to talk about the first question, but she quickly starts to cry. 

 

 “I can’t do this !” she cries, as you hug her gently. “It’s just all too hard!”

 

 “Look,” you say reassuringly. “It’s not so bad. Just another hour of studying and I’m sure you’ll be fine.”

 

 Her hand darts across the table and she pushes the amulet towards you. “It won’t be! Not without this! Please help me, ! Please can we try it! I can’t fail this test!”

 

 You look at the amulet. “Em,” you begin. “I don’t think this is the answer…”

 

 “Please !” she cuts you off. “I know it’s stupid. But I can’t fail. If I fail, then who knows if I’ll be able to graduate. I… we,” she emphasises, “need to do anything to get me to pass.”

 

 You picks up the amulet. Even now, there’s something odd about it that unsettles you. But seeing Emily like this is a hundred times worse.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “Alright, if you think this will help,” you say, putting it around your neck. You feel a bit stupid wearing the ancient trinket, but if you can convince Emily you are putting your heart into it she might get some confidence for her exam.

 

 You pick up the note and read the instructions out loud. “Alright, For times of trouble, use me well. Take a treasured possession from those who need aid, and see them for who they are in your world.”

 

 You look to Emily. “I need something from you to hold."

 

 She nods and reaches into her purse, pulling out some lipgloss. You raise an eyebrow. “It calms me down,” she says, but you don’t push her new interest in cosmetics any further.

 

 Holding on to the lipgloss, you visualise Emily in your mind. You think of a mental picture from happier times, before you moved here. A memory surfaces in your brain. Back at the beginning of summer, not four months ago, when your parents took you all to the beach. Emily, wearing a sundress, carefree, confident and happy. 

 

 You feel the emerald warming your chest against your shirt as you picture the image. The warmth makes you feel something else. Carefree. Confident. Happy. You almost feel them as things you're experiencing right now for yourself. 

 

 “Okay, here goes,” you tell Emily. “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 “Look, I’m going to prove you don’t need this,” you say, putting it around your neck. You feel a bit stupid wearing the ancient trinket, but you need Emily to realise that she’s the only one who can help herself today.

 

 You pick up the note and read the instructions out loud. “Alright, For times of trouble, use me well. Take a treasured possession from those who need aid, and see them for who they are in your world.”

 

 You look to Emily. “I need something from you to hold."

 

 She nods and reaches into her purse, pulling out some lipgloss. You raise an eyebrow. “It calms me down,” she says, but you don’t push her new interest in cosmetics any further.

 

 Holding on to the lipgloss, you visualise Emily in your mind. You think of a mental picture from happier times, before you moved here. A memory surfaces in your brain. Back at the beginning of summer, not four months ago, when your parents took you all to the beach. Emily, wearing a sundress, carefree, confident and happy. 

 

 You feel the emerald warming your chest against your shirt as you picture the image. The warmth makes you feel something else. Carefree. Confident. Happy. You almost feel them as things you're experiencing right now for yourself. 

 

 “Okay, here goes,” you tell Emily. “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 A moment passes, then another.

 

 You find yourself sitting at the kitchen table, staring back at your sister, expectation evident in her eyes.

 

 “I’m sorry Em,” you begin. “It’s just a hokey old -”

 

 A wave of warm energy rushes across your skin, making your hairs stand up on end. You cry out, feeling as though a burning wave of flames is passing over you. Your have the sensation inside of your organs exploding and contracting and exploding all over again. If your throat wasn't constricting you'd try to throw up your lungs.

 

 You are barely aware of your surroundings, but feel the hard ceramic floor hit your body as you collapse to the floor. You lie on the cold tiles, but your skin is tingling and your clothes feel like they are burning away.

 

 And then, bones breaking inside. You cry out again in pain. There's a surging around your chest. Your hips somehow are crushing against each other. Your penis - your wonderful penis - is inflamed with pain.

 

 A strand of hair passes in front of your blurring vision. Giving into the agony, you pass out.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “? ! Oh my god !”

 

 You hear a voice, distant and murky, as if you are hearing it from underwater. You feel yourself blinking and see a light blur. Slowly, shapes begin to form and you see you are still lying on the floor.

 

 You feel something shaking your body. “? ? Oh my god , wake up! Please be alright.”

 

 You look up in the direction of the voice. You make out your sister, Emily, coming into focus. She stands above you, looking down in horror. 

 

 “Em?” you mutter. Then stop. Something about that wasn’t right.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You look around and immediately see something that definitely isn’t right. You can feel you are lying on the floor of your kitchen, but where your body should be is one of a young girl.

 

 As you stare down at the body, your brain struggles with incomprehension. You tense your toes to check. You can feel your legs and stomach, but where you feel you can only see toned legs wrapped in a sundress.

 

 “!”

 

 You look up at Emily. She is still standing over you. Her mouth is wide open and her eyes full of panic. “Are you… are you… oh my god.”

 

 “What happened?” you hear your sister say. Then it dawns on you. You said that. 

 

 “Oh my god,” you blurt out. There’s no mistaking it. You are talking, but you sound like a girl. Like your sister.

 

 “I think you better stand up,” Emily says. “Look in there.” She gestures to the mirror.

 

 **Actions**

 <> 
 
 Feeling like you are in a dream, you pull yourself up by grabbing on to the table. Even this feels wrong. Your arms look smaller and dainty. Hairless. Feminine.

 

 You glance over to the mirror, confirming what you already knew. Staring back at you, mouth open, looking struck with terror, is the embodiment of the picture you had in your mind. Your sister, eighteen years old, wearing a sundress.

 

 You tell your leg to move a little. The girl in the mirror matches your movement. The girl in the mirror.

 

 You.

 

 “What?” you exclaim, again hearing your sister's voice. Your movements match the ones in the reflection. There’s a mistake here. You are looking at yourself, and yourself is a duplicate of your sister.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 “Oh my god! What have you done?” you exclaim!

 

 “Easy ” you hear Emily say. “Breathe. Just breathe” 

 

 You reach out to one of the kitchen chairs and fall down into it, feeling the wood touching your new hairless legs. The amulet bounces on your chest - your breasts - and angrily you rip it off and toss it on to the kitchen table. 

 

 “What the hell, Emily!” you say. “What have you done?”

 

 “Easy ”, she says, trying to remain calm. “Just breathe. We’ll figure this out together. Just breathe.”

 

 “I am breathing Emily, I’m just breathing in your body!” you snap. You hear the voice again, a familiar one, but that you struggle to comprehend as your own. You feel a surge of tears coming. “This isn’t happening," you stammer. "This can’t be happening.”

 

 “Look, it must have been the amulet!” Emily replies, gesturing to the jewellery on the kitchen table. “It must be magic!” 

 

 “There’s no such thing as magic, Em!” You intended to sound venomous, but you catch yourself sounding more meek with the higher voice.

 

 “Well, I beg to differ,” she says flatly. She signals to your body. “The proof is there, ."

 

 You look again at the amulet. Then to the note nearby. You just can't believe that this is real.

 

 “How did you do it?” you hear Emily asking.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 You pick up the amulet, looking at the infernal trinket. It looks the same, but where there was once a warmth radiating from the emerald, now there is just only a hint of an ember. It almost feels cold to the touch.

 

 “Maybe it needs time to recharge?” Emily offers, unconvincingly.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 
 You look over the note once more.
 
 

 **For times of trouble, use me well. Take a treasured possession from those who need aid, and see them for who they are in your world. Then say these words. ‘From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.’**

 

 “I thought of you,” you mutter. Emily frowns as you show her the note. “I thought of you, when I said the words.”

 

 She looks at it, then looks up with some understanding. “You became how you saw me. In your head.”

 

 “I thought it would just effect you!” you say. “Not like this, of course, but if there was any mumbo jumbo I thought it would give you positive energy. Or something.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>

 After looking over the amulet and the note, your brain calms down just by a fraction, but enough to try and process the situation. You pictured Emily in a sundress. You are now Emily in a sundress. What if you pictured yourself again?

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You grab the amulet and concentrate as hard as you can on a mental picture of yourself. You remember what you looked like on that beach. You spent the day in T-shirts and swimming trunks. You smiled the whole day.

 

 Ready to say the words on the note, you remember you need an item. “Grab me that photo on the side! Of me and Jen!”, you shout at Emily. “Quickly!”

 

 She rushes over to the photo on the side and hands it to you. The first the two of you took together. You snatch it up and focusing hard on the mental picture, start speaking.

 

 "From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within."

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 Nothing. You say the words again. Still nothing. The warmth from the amulet is just not there. You think you sense the faintest of a warmth against your breasts, but nothing like when you changed.

 

 “It’s not working,” you finally admit. “Whatever did this,” you say, avoiding the word magic. “It’s not there. Just a flicker.”

 

 “Maybe we need to wait a while,” Emily says, trying to be helpful. “It might need time to -”

 

 “Recharge,” you cut her off. “I know. But I have to go to work. And you have to go school.”

 

 Something clicks in your head. “Who was the girl at school who gave this to you?” you ask.

 

 “Elizabeth,” Emily replies. “She’s a bit of an outsider. I haven’t spoken to her that much. She’s in my Maths class.”

 

 “You need to call her!” you blurt out. “Now!”

 

 “I don’t have her number,” Emily replies. “But she will be at school.”

 

 “Then you need to go to school and get her to come here!” you say. 

 

 You notice something in Emily’s eyes. A pleading look. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 "What?" you ask.

 

 “Well, I was just thinking,” Emily begins. “Liz said the amulet was for someone to help me in my time of need. She gave it to me after I said you were a whizz at Maths and were tutoring me for my exam. And now you look like me.”

 

 “You’re not serious?” you say, realising her line of thinking.

 

 “Please !” Emily cries, standing close and looking at you with needy eyes. “You need to talk to Liz, she’s at school, and you could just do my exam whilst you’re there so we don’t have to worry about me failing. I would be able to pass and you could go away with Jennifer!”

 

 Jennifer. You think about her for a moment. What would she think about all of this.

 

 *Now you are a girl.*

 

 “Just think, you could pass my exam for me,” Emily continues. “You can also talk to Liz, and we could everything back to normal by the end of the day.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 “Absolutely not," you say. "I’m not leaving the house like this. Let alone going to school as you and pretending to be my sister.”

 

 “If I go to school, I’m going to be there for the day,” Emily tells you. “I’m going to have to take that test. And I’ll fail. Then who knows what will happen. To the both of us.”

 

 You look at your sister, then glance at your reflection in the mirror. You are a spitting image of her. No one would know.

 

 “It wouldn’t be so hard,” Emily says. “I’ll phone your work and tell them you’re sick. I’ll stay home for the day, and we can reverse this tonight.”

 

 “You don’t know if it can be reversed,” you reply flatly.

 

 “We can only try.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 "This is crazy," you say, as much to convince yourself. "It better work."

 
 
 “Oh it will!” Emily exclaims. “Look, it should be easy. I’ll phone your work and tell them you’re sick. Then I’ll stay home for the day, and you can take my place at school. Then we’ll get Liz and try to reverse this all tonight.”
 
 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 “Alright!” Emily says, and you note there’s a sense of optimism that you haven’t seen in your sister in ages. “I’ll phone your work. Whilst I do that, you can go up to my room and change.”

 

 “Change?” you say, barely believing what’s about to come.

 

 “Yes silly!” Emily laughs. “You can’t go to school in a sundress. You need to wear my uniform. I think we’re about the same size!”

 

 You give her a look and she stops with her playfulness. "Sorry," she says.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 You stand up, adjusting to your new body. As , you were just short of six foot tall. In comparison, Emily, whilst not petite, is at least six inches shorter than you once were. 

 

 As you stand you feel sundress hug your curves and the hem brush against your upper thigh. You have never felt more vulnerable and exposed.

 

 “Let me know if you have any challenges with anything,” she says, whilst dialling a number on the phone. “Bras take a bit of getting used to.”

 

 You walk up the stairs, feeling your body swaying as you walk with more pronounced hips. You feel your breasts rising and falling as you breathe. You continually brush back your brunette hair out of your vision.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 You walk down the stairs cautiously, hearing the clip-clop of your heels on the wooden steps. Emily looks over at you from the kitchen and smiles.

 

 “You look great, ,” she says. “I never really appreciated how pretty I look.”

 

 “Can you not, please,” you reply.

 

 Emily apologises and thrusts you her school bag. “Now you’ve got a schedule in there. Just follow that. And meet Michelle at the school gates. Just stay quiet and say you’re tired, then she’ll be able to help.”

 

 “Did you phone work?” you ask, still getting used to your voice.

 

 “Yes”, Emily replies. “Someone called Annie answered. She said that your boss won't be happy, but she sends her best wishes.”

 

 You sigh. To keep your boss happy, you imagine that you'll have to make up the work you're missing today.

 

 “Alright, here we go,” you say to Emily, stepping towards the front door.

 

 “Have a good day at school,” she says, parroting the very thing you tell her every morning.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 **Your home**

 [image: ./images/Your_Home.png]

 

 It takes you twenty minutes to get home, but the walk is uneventful. More relieved than you can remember ever feeling, you open the front door to see Emily sitting in the sofa watching TV.

 

 “You’re back!” she says, excitedly. “How did it go? I must admit - it's weird seeing you like this. Until now I was half-convinced it was a dream.”

 

 You spend the next five minutes recounting the day. Everything you went through, how the test went, and more importantly, everything that Elizabeth told you about the amulet and the school.

 

 Emily listens intensely, but when you recount Liz’s warning about Charlton, she leans in and hangs on every word. 

 

 “I knew it,” she mutters after you finally finish. “All this time, I’ve felt funny when I was there. Now I know why.” She seems to enter a daze, as if remembering something. But a moment later she shakes her head and stares back at you. 

 

 You realise that in your concern to find a way to get through the day, you have completely forgotten about Emily. Forced to deal with that strange school, its demeaning lessons and sexist teachers, for the entire time you've moved here. You notice her eyes glisten with tears, even as she tries to smile reassuringly. 

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 <>
 
 "I'm so sorry, Em", you say.

 

 Before you can speak another word, she rushes forward and throws her arms around you. You hear her sniffling as she lets her tears run. Not for the first time today, you become acutely aware of your diminished height, as she tries to bury her head in your shoulder. 

 

 "I thought I was going mad", she stammers. "All this time, thinking I wasn't who I thought I was. I felt so alone and afraid."

 

 "I thought you were just struggling with the move," you reply. "But we'll figure this out. I'll find a way for us to get through this."

 

 "I don't want to go back there", you hear her spit out. 

 

 You pull back so you can look at her. Looking into your own current reflection. As tender as you want to be, it feels eerie and uncanny. Her eyes flick across you and you guess she feels the same.

 

 "Neither do I," you reply to her. 

 

 Your eyes lock on each other's and you stare back in silence. The reality sets in. Like it or not, for at least the time being one of you is going to have to go back there tomorrow.

 

 “First things first,” she says, wiping the tears from her eyes. “Let’s reverse this amulet.” She hands you the amulet and the photo of you and Jen. Much to your delight, the emerald is glowing green and is warm to the touch.

 <>
 
 "I don't want to go back there," you say. 

 

 A rush of tears suddenly streams from your eyes, and you find yourself sobbing. You feel Emily draw her arms around you into a comforting embrace. You bury your head in her shoulder. Not for the first time today, you become acutely aware of your diminished height. 

 

 "I feel like I'm going mad," you stammer. "This can't be happening to me."

 

 "It's okay," you hear Emily say, stroking your long hair. "We'll get through this together."

 

 "I don't want to go back there," you spit out. 

 

 You feel her pull your head back and you stare into her eyes. A reflection of you. A reminder of what you've become and what you've been through today. It feels eerie and uncanny. Her eyes flick across you and you guess she feels the same.

 

 "Neither do I," she replies.

 

 Your eyes lock on each other's and you stare back in silence. The reality sets in. Like it or not, for at least the time being one of you is going to have to go back there tomorrow.

 

 “First things first,” Emily says, wiping the tears from your eyes. “Let’s reverse this amulet.” She hands you the amulet and the photo of you and Jen. Much to your delight, the emerald is glowing green and is warm to the touch.

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You put on the amulet, feeling its warmth already against your breasts. You remember the image of yourself on the beach. A happy go-lucky twenty-something in swimming trunks and a T-shirt, with a skinny body and short hair. In a nutshell, you think of you. 

 

 “Here we go again,” you say to Emily. You concentrate, and recite the words.

 

 “From this item, I see you in your time of need. Now form shape to the person I see within.”

 

 The energy fuses out of the emerald, but this time you are ready for it. The pain is still unbearable, but you focus on the picture in your mind. Your face. Your skinny body. Your hairy legs. Your penis.

 

 You squeal as you feel your body crunching and changing again, but you fight to remain conscious. Suddenly, it’s over. 

 

 There is silence in the room. You take a deep breath and look down to see your flat chest and loose swimming trunks. You can’t help but cry out in joy.

 

 “Oh my god - , it worked!” Emily cries, and runs over to hug you. You hug her back, remembering that you’re taller than her and you can wrap her up in a big hug to celebrate.

 

 "I've never been so happy with my body!" you tell her, recognising your own voice again coming out of your body.

 

 “Thank god!” Emily says. “I don’t think I could have explained to mum and dad how I now had a twin sister! This calls for celebration - I’ll order some pizza!”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 You sit around with Emily, waiting for the pizza delivery to arrive. Thanks to staff shortages, it’s late, but you don’t mind. Nothing can faze you tonight.

 

 Whilst waiting, you reply to some phone messages that have gotten through the bad reception. A few people from work checking in on you, your boss checking if you’ll be at work tomorrow. 

 

 Most importantly are the text messages from Jennifer. You give her a call and talk to her, placating any fears she might have had in you not responding to her for a whole day.

 

 “I’m feeling much better now,” you tell her. “Just one of those twenty-four hour things.”

 

 “Do you want to come over?” she offers. “I can be a good nurse for you.”

 

 You chuckle. “Tempting, but I should get some sleep.”

 

 “Will you come over tomorrow, then?” she asks. “I can cook us dinner, if you want?”

 

 You tell her that would be nice and you will come round after work.

 

 “Love you,” she says. 

 

 You hear Emily shouting up to your room that the pizza has arrived. “Love you too,” you tell Jennifer. “I’ll see you tomorrow.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 You go downstairs and see Emily has already spread the pizza across the now clear kitchen table. “No more study books?” you ask Emily.

 

 “Not for a while, at least,” she replies, happy.

 

 She grabs a slice and you do the same. You savour the sensation of eating in your own body. Everything feels so perfect.

 

 “, what are you going to do now?” Emily asks.

 

 “What do you mean?” you say in-between eating pizza. 

 

 Emily looks at you hesitantly. “You might have helped me today, but if Liz is right there’s a whole school that needs help too. I was just wondering what you were going to do. Now that we know."

 

 “The smart thing to do would be to leave,” you reply flatly.

 

 “You know I can’t do that,” Emily says. “What would we tell our parents? What would they do if I dropped out of school? What would they ask you to do if I had to resit my entire year elsewhere?”

 

 You finish off another slice of pizza, trying to find a way out of this conversation by not speaking.

 

 “There’s a lot of people here. That could use someone helping them.” Emily looks to you. “Including me. Who knows what that school will do to me if it’s not stopped?”

 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 "What do you expect me to do?" you ask Emily, with a slight tone of exasperation.

 

 “I don't expect you to do anything,” Emily says. “You've already gone through the weirdest day of your life, . No one could expect you to do anything like that again. It's just that... you don't need magic to do some snooping around."

 

 "You want me to figure out what's going on?" you ask her flatly.

 

 She nods. "Use that amulet or not. But help the people here and get to the bottom of what’s going on. And stop it. After all, you can go back to work tomorrow. I have to go back to that school."

 

 You pick up the amulet that still rests around your neck and finger it gingerly, mulling it over. “I need to think about this,” you say. 

 

 “Sure, take your time,” Emily replies. “But just remember what happened to you today. I have to go through that everyday."

 

 You smile sadly, thinking it through. “Too much has happened today, Em. I need to rest on it.” You stand. “I’m going to bed.” 

 

 She nods. “Alright. Sleep tight.”

 

 “You too.”

 

 **Actions**

 <>

title: PrologueYourRoom
text:
**Your room**

 [image: ./images/Your_Room_1.png]

 

 You wake up and momentarily feel sluggish and unsure of your surroundings. Then it dawns on you. The room, though still foreign, is at least full of your clothes and belongings. It’s your new’ish bedroom, in this new’ish house, in this new’ish town called Charlton that you moved to just two months ago.

 

 You debated for a week whether you’d move with your parents when they announced they were moving to a quiet town away from the city. All your friends were there and you had a job as a software developer that paid at least a little. But your parents made the argument that your sister, Emily, still had a year to go in school. Someone needed to look after her. 

 

 What you didn’t realise was that not three weeks after moving, your mother and father would pack up and go to Italy for an extended vacation. A business trip, they said. Business so vital that they would leave you in a new town to look after your sister, but not enough to stop your younger brother from going to University as planned. 

 

 Still, it hasn’t been all bad. As an educated man of twenty-five, you quickly found a new job developing a booking system for one of the local businesses. Even better, you found that the slim pickings of new men on dating apps meant you landed a wonderful girlfriend, Jennifer. She's about the best thing that has ever happened to you.

 

 Now all you have to do is get your sister through her final year at school and make sure she gets the grades she needs to go to University. Then you’ll be free to finally move out of your parents' house and see the world like you planned. With the added bonus of having Jennifer along for the ride.

 

 Speaking of, you remember you agreed to help Emily study for her big Maths exam tomorrow. In spite of being a Sunday, you've been called into work today, but an hour tutoring might make the difference between her passing or failing. You put on some clothes and get ready for the day ahead.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 Your dreams are muddled and fragmented. You see Emily's face wincing, her eyes full of tears. A maths textbook flutters in the wind, equations falling out and taken away by the breeze.

 

 And everything is tinted by a yellow-amber hue, emanating from a green gem that grows larger by the minute. A coy smile presses through its edges, the lips unmistakably those from a woman.
 
 

 
 

 **Actions**

 <>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 /* Clear deltas */
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 **Your room**

 [image: ./images/Your_Room_1.png]

 

 You wake up and have the same sense of strangeness for a brief moment. Your room. Your new room. Your new life.

 

 Then you remember. Today is Emily’s test. You said you’d help her in the kitchen do some last minute cramming for her exam.

 

 **Actions**

 <>

 
 **Your room**

 [image: ./images/Your_Room_1.png]

 

 You go upstairs to your room and shut the door. You put the amulet down on your bedside cabinet and take off your clothes. Firstly, your T-shirt and then your swimming shorts. You look at yourself in the mirror.

 

 
 You see your reflection as you. A skinny man of twenty-five, with a penis and short hair. You think about your girlfriend, Jennifer, and you feel a familiar stirring in your loins. Everything seems to be working perfectly.

 

 Hidden beneath your T-shirt though and away from the prying eyes of Emily is cause for concern. Where you previously had a flat chest, you now have two small mounds on your chest. Your nipples are bigger and you notice they harden when you think about Jennifer. You wouldn’t exactly call them breasts, but they definitely weren’t there before.

 

 You reach up and give one of your nipples a brush with your finger. You gasp. The sensitivity is alien to you. It’s also alarming. And you hate to admit it, but it’s not unpleasant. You caress your nipples a little more and hear yourself moan in arousal.

 

 Your eyes drift down to your penis. You notice it immediately. It’s smaller. A lot smaller. Even stirring from the thought of Jennifer, you can tell it’s no longer the size it once was. Even more troubling, it reacts and stiffens when you play with your nipples.

 

 You gulp. You look over at the amulet and think about all the things that happened today, remembering Liz’s attempt to warn you about the spell shaping the person you see within. 

 

 Climbing into bed, you push the thought from your mind. Tomorrow is a new day. But how can you just return back to normal when you now know of the danger that Jennifer, and especially Emily, faces. Shouldn’t you look to help them if you can?

 

 Slowly, you drift off to sleep. Beside you, the cold amulet starts to recharge once more.

 **Actions**

 **Your street**

 [image: ./images/YourStreet.png]

 
 
 You step outside and feel a wave of nausea wash over you. The wind blows against your legs, and whilst the socks keep you mostly warm, you feel it continually brushing against the tiny bit of exposed skin.

 

 You walk slowly, getting used to the feeling of wearing heels. The sound is alien to you. You still can’t believe that this is your body and you are dressed like this.

 

 A van drives by and you jump as the driver beeps his horn. You look up and see Martin the delivery driver grinning at you lecherously as he passes.

 

 Wanting to avoid any other attention, you keep your head down and walk towards the school entrance.
